CHAPTER 10. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10.01. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters shall constitute and be designated as "The Revised Code of General Ordinances of the City of Dayton, Ohio," and may be so cited. The Code may also be cited as the Revised Code, abbreviated "R.C.G.O." or, in the provisions which follow, as "this Code." 
Sec. 10.02. - Authority of Code. 
    This Code is a recodification of the general ordinances of the City of Dayton, Ohio, which have been enacted and published in accordance with the authority granted by Ordinance 12355, passed under the provisions of R.C. § 731.23. 
Sec. 10.03. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of the provisions of this Code and all ordinances, the following rules of construction and definitions shall be observed unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the City Commission or unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
(A)  Definitions. 
    Administrative regulations. Written orders which are issued by the Mayor or chief administrative officer of the city. 
    And, or, and may be read "or" and "or" may be read "and" if the sense requires it. 
    Bond. An obligation in writing, binding the signatory to pay a sum certain upon the happening or failure of an event. 
    Building. Any structure intended to have walls and a roof. 
    Business. Any profession, trade, occupation and any other commercial enterprise conducted for monetary reward. 
    Charter. The Charter of the City of Dayton. 
    City. The City of Dayton, in the County of Montgomery and State of Ohio. 
    Commission or City Commission. The governing body of the city. 
    City limits or corporate limits. Within the city and including not only the corporate limits of the city, but also any property which the city owns or which is under its jurisdiction. 
    City Manager. The chief administrative officer of the city, appointed by the commissioners of the city as provided for in the Charter. 
    Clerk or City Clerk. The Clerk of the City Commission. 
    County. Montgomery County, Ohio. 
    Health officer. The head of the division of housing and health of the department of human resources or any person designated by the city commission to perform the city health functions and duties. 
    Joint authority. That authority given to several persons or officers. Such authority vests in a majority of such persons or officers. 
    May. The word "may" is permissive and discretionary. 
    Mayor. The Mayor of the city. 
    Month. A calendar month. 
    Oath. Any form of attestation by which a person signifies that he is bound in conscience to perform an act or to speak faithfully and truthfully, and includes an affirmation or declaration in cases where by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Owner. One who has complete dominion over a particular property and who is the one in whom legal or equitable title rests. When applied to a building or land, "owner" means any part owner, joint owner, owner of a community or partnership interest, life tenant, tenant in common, or joint tenant, of the whole or part of such building or land. 
    Person. Any individual, natural person, joint stock company, partnership, voluntary association, society, club, firm, company, corporation, business trust, organization, or any other group acting as a unit, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, partner, member, director, officer, or employee of any of them including an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver, or other representative appointed according to law. 
    Personal property. Any money, goods, movable chattels, things in action, evidence of debt, all objects and rights which are capable of ownership, and every other species of property except real property. 
    Preceding and following. Next before and next after, respectively. 
    Public place. Includes any public street, road, or highway, alley, lane, sidewalk, crosswalk, or other public way, or any public resort, place of amusement, stadium, athletic field, park, playground, public building, or grounds appurtenant thereto, school building or school grounds, public parking lot or any vacant lot, the elevator, lobby, halls, corridors, and areas open to the public of any store, office, or apartment building or any other place commonly open to the public. 
    Real property. Land, together with all things attached to the land so as to become a part thereof. 
    Revised Code or R.C. The Ohio Revised Code. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. That portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property along the margin of a street or other highway, designed, constructed, and intended for the use of pedestrians to the exclusion of vehicles. 
    Signature and subscription. The name of a person, mark, or symbol appended by him to a writing with intent to authenticate the instrument as one made or put into effect by him. 
    State. The State of Ohio. 
    Street. All streets, highways, avenues, boulevards, parkways, roads, lanes, viaducts, bridges, and the approaches thereto, docks built on public streets, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs, sidewalks, recreation and park lands used for vehicular traffic, or other public ways or thoroughfares in this city, over which it has jurisdiction, which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated by any law of this state. 
    Tenant, occupant. Applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Time. An hour of the day according to the official time of the city. 
    Time of performance. The time within which an act is to be done as provided in any section or any order issued pursuant to any section, when expressed in days, and is computed by excluding the first and including the last day. If the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall not be counted in the computation. When the time is expressed in hours, the whole of Sunday or a legal holiday from midnight to midnight is excluded. 
    Treasurer. The City Treasurer. 
    Watercourse. Any drain, ditch, and stream, flowing in a definite direction or course in a bed with banks. 
    Week. Seven days. However, publication in a newspaper or other required paper of any notice or other matter indicated to be for a stated number of weeks shall be construed to mean one insertion in each week, unless specifically stated to be for each day of the week or for more than one day in each week. 
    Writing and written. Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by printing or otherwise, capable of comprehension by ordinary visual means. 
    Year. A calendar year. 
(B)  Rules of construction. 
(1)  Definitions given within a chapter apply only to words or phrases used in the chapter unless otherwise provided. 
(2)  Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and others that have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
(3)  Words in any section importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter as well as the masculine. 
(4)  Words used in the singular include the plural and the plural includes the singular. 
(5)  Words used in the past or present tense include the future, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
Sec. 10.04. - Territorial applicability. 
    This Code shall refer only to the commission or omission of acts within the territorial limits of the city and to that territory outside this city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or Charter provisions, or any law. 
Sec. 10.05. - Enactment of ordinance. 
    No ordinance or amendment or repeal of any section here shall be operative, in full force and effect, unless it has been adopted in the manner prescribed by law. 
Sec. 10.06. - Code provisions as continuance of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, insofar as they relate to the same subject matter and are substantially the same as those ordinance provisions previously adopted by the city and existing at the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as restatements and continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 10.07. - Effect of repeal of ordinances; revival. 
(A)  Neither the adoption of this Code nor the repeal hereby of any ordinance of this city shall in any manner affect the prosecution for violation of ordinances, which violations were committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of any license or penalty at the effective date due and unpaid under such ordinance, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such ordinance relating to the collection of any license or penalty or the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof, required to be posted, filed, or deposited pursuant to any ordinance, and all rights and obligations thereof appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. 
(B)  Whenever any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision is repealed, the repeal shall not be construed as reviving the former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless expressly provided. 
Sec. 10.08. - References include amendments; construction. 
(A)  Any reference in this Code to an ordinance or provision of this Code shall mean such ordinance or provision as may now exist or is hereafter amended. 
(B)  Any references in this Code to titles, chapters, sections, or divisions shall be to the titles, chapters, sections, and divisions of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 10.09. - Catchlines and headings; construction. 
    All designations and headings of titles, chapters, sections, and divisions are intended only for convenience in arrangement and as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the titles, chapters, sections, or divisions. They shall not be deemed or taken to be any part of such titles, chapters, sections, or divisions; nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed upon amendment or reenactment; nor shall they be construed to govern, limit, modify, alter, or in any other manner affect the scope, meaning, or intent of any of the provisions of this Code. 
Sec. 10.10. - Continuing offenses. 
    Each day any violation of this Code occurs or continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
Sec. 10.11. - Prohibited acts include causing, permitting, concealing. 
    Whenever in this Code any act or omission is made unlawful, it shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering, or concealing the fact of such act or omission. 
Sec. 10.12. - Notices to be written and in English language. 
    All notices, reports, statements, applications, or records required or authorized by this Code shall be made in writing in the English language unless specifically provided otherwise. 
Sec. 10.13. - Notices; service and proof. 
(A)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, whenever a notice is required to be given pursuant to any section of this Code the notice shall be given either by personal delivery to the person to be notified or by deposit in the United States mail in a sealed envelope, postage prepaid, addressed to the person to be notified at his last known business or residence address as the same appears in the public records or other records pertaining to the matter for which the notice is served or by any other method of delivery approved by law. Service by mail shall be deemed to have been completed at the time of deposit in the post office or any United States mailbox. 
(B)  Proof of giving any notice may be made by the certificate of any officer or employee of this city or by affidavit of any person 18 years of age or over who actually accomplished personal service in conformity with this Code or other provisions of law applicable to the subject matter concerned, or by a return receipt signed by the recipient notified by United States mail. 
Sec. 10.14. - Acts by deputy or designee. 
    Whenever a power is granted to or a duty is imposed upon public officer or employee, the power may be performed by and authorized deputy or designee or by any person authorized pursuant to law or ordinances, unless this Code expressly provides otherwise. 
Sec. 10.15. - Certified copy of Code admissible into evidence. 
    Any printed copy of this Code or any printed supplement thereto published and certified according to law, shall be received into evidence in any court for the purpose of providing any Charter of ordinance provision therein contained with like effect and for the same purpose as the original ordinances, minutes or journals would be received. 
Sec. 10.16. - Same offense punishable by different sections of the Code; city attorney's option. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different sections of this Code, the City Attorney may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. 
Sec. 10.17. - Conflicting provisions. 
(A)  If the provisions of different titles, chapters, sections or divisions of this Code conflict with or contravene each other the provisions of each title, chapter, section, or division shall prevail as to all matters and questions growing out of the subject matter of that title, chapter, section, or division. 
(B)  If clearly conflicting provisions are found in different sections of the same chapter, the provisions of the section last enacted shall prevail unless the construction is inconsistent with the meaning of that chapter. 
(Am. Ord. 26353, passed 10-14-81) 
Sec. 10.18. - Code severability. 
    It is declared to be the intention of the City Commission that the sections, divisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and words of this Code are severable. If any section, division, paragraph, sentence, clause, or word is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, its unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the validity of any of the remaining sections, divisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and words of this Code, since the sections or parts of sections would have been enacted by the City Commission without and irrespective of any unconstitutional or otherwise invalid section, division, paragraph, sentence, clause, or word being incorporated into this Code. 
Secs. 10.19-10.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10.99. - General penalty. 
    Whenever, in this Code or in any other ordinance of the city, or rule, regulation or order promulgated by any law officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him, or it, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provisions of this Code or of any other ordinance of the city or any rule, regulations or order as aforesaid shall constitute a minor misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
CHAPTER 11. - INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM, AND RECALL 

Sec. 11.01. - Proposed ordinance; filing. 
    Whoever seeks to propose an ordinance, resolution, or an amendment to the Charter by initiative petition, or to file a referendum petition against any ordinance, resolution, or part thereof, shall file a duly verified copy of the proposed ordinance, or resolution, or amendment to the Charter, together with a synopsis of the same, with the Clerk of the City Commission before circulating the petition. If this copy is not so filed with the Clerk of the City Commission, the committee directing the circulation of the initiative or referendum petition shall within ten days after commencing the circulation of the same file with the Clerk a written notice setting forth the day when the circulation was commenced and embodying the title and text of the ordinance, Charter amendment, or any section or item thereof to be referred. This notice shall be signed by the committee promoting the circulation of the petition. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.02. - Sufficiency of petition. 
    When a petition for initiative, referendum, or recall is filed with the Clerk of the City Commission, or when a petition for an amendment to the Charter is filed with the election authorities under the provisions of the Charter, the Clerk shall proceed forthwith to ascertain its sufficiency and validity. Within 15 days thereafter, the Clerk shall report to the City Commission his findings thereon, in writing, which findings and report, as approved or amended by the City Commission, shall be spread upon the minutes of the City Commission as its official finding. A finding so made by the Commission and spread upon the minutes shall be deemed a final and conclusive determination of the validity and sufficiency of any such petition, unless at the public hearings before the City Commission provided for by Charter, § 23, it is otherwise proved. However, nothing herein shall be deemed by abrogation or denial of any right or rights by virtue of any legal proceedings, at law or in equity, to prevent the holding of an election upon a petition which is invalid because of failure to comply with the requirements of the Charter pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.03. - Correctness of petition presumed. 
    After an election has been held upon the petition, the petition and the signatures thereon shall be presumed to be in all respects sufficient. No ordinance or other measure submitted to the electors pursuant to a referendum petition or pursuant to an initiative petition, receiving an affirmative majority of the votes cast thereon, shall be held unconstitutional or void on account of the insufficiency of the petition, or proceeding had thereon; nor shall the rejection of any law submitted by initiative and referendum petitions, or proceedings had thereon, be held invalid because of such insufficiency. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.04. - Fraudulent signing. 
    At the top of each of the initiative, referendum, or recall petition or petitions for an election for the amendment of the Charter, the following words shall be printed in red, in the English language: 
Notice - Whoever knowingly signs this petition more than once, signs any name or address other than his own, makes any alteration of name, signature, or address or other material part of the petition, or signs when not a registered voter within the corporate limits of the City of Dayton, Ohio, is liable to prosecution. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.05. - Committee of petitioners designated. 
    The proponents of a petition for initiative, referendum, recall, or of an amendment of the Charter, shall designate a committee of five of their number who shall be regarded as the official representatives of the petitioners for all purposes connected with the proceedings and the election. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.06. - Statement of receipts and disbursements. 
    At the time when an initiative, referendum, or recall petition is filed with the Clerk of the Commission, or when a petition to amend the Charter is filed with the election authorities, the same committee of the petitioners shall file with the Clerk of the Commission a sworn, itemized statement of all moneys received for use in and concerning the preparation and circulation of any such petition and the securing of signatures thereto, and of all sums used for any of these purposes, which statement shall set forth the names of all persons, or organizations, from whom any such sums have been received and of all persons or parties to whom any of such money has been disbursed, with amounts received from and disbursed to each party, the purpose of the disbursement, and what service, if any, has been rendered in consideration of the disbursement. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.07. - Affidavit of circulator of petition. 
    At the time of filing the petition, each of the circulators thereof shall file with the Clerk of the Commission a sworn statement containing the following information: 
(A)  At whose request he circulated the petition; 
(B)  An itemized account of the moneys or other things of value received or promised for circulating the petition, or a statement, if such is the case, that no money or other thing of value has been either received or promised, directly or indirectly, positively or by inference; 
(C)  Full names and addresses of all persons from whom such payments or promises were received; 
(D)  If the circulator is an employee of another person by whom he was requested or permitted to solicit signatures for or circulate the petition as a part of his regular duties, the affidavit shall so state, and shall also state the time spent and salary earned while circulating the petition and any other consideration or promise made directly or indirectly, positively, or by inference for such service. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 11.99(A) 
Sec. 11.08. - Petition without affidavits ineffective. 
    The City Commission shall not consider any petition that may be filed for initiative, referendum, or recall election, nor shall any petition for amendment of the Charter be considered until the affidavits provided for in §§ 11.06 and 11.07 have been filed. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Sec. 11.09. - Prohibitions. 
    No person shall: 
(A)  Willfully misrepresent the contents of any initiative, referendum, or recall petition or petition for election for amendment of the Charter; 
(B)  Pay or offer to pay or promise to pay directly or indirectly, positively or by inference, any money or other things of value or to give any preference in advancement to office or to give any other consideration for signing any initiative, referendum, or recall petition or petition for amendment of the Charter; 
(C)  Promise to assist another in any manner or form to obtain appointment to any office provided for by the constitution or the laws of Ohio, or by the Charter or any ordinance of the city, or to any position or employment in the service of the state or any political subdivision thereof as consideration for signing or procuring signatures to an initiative, referendum, or recall petition, or a petition for amendment of the Charter; 
(D)  Make any alteration either by adding to or erasing any signature or address or other material part of the petition, or by tracing any signature or address with pen or indelible pencil, if the same was originally written in lead pencil or otherwise; 
(E)  Fail to file any of the sworn itemized statements required herein to be filed or willfully swear falsely to any such statement; 
(F)  Knowingly sign any initiative, referendum, or recall petition, or petition for amendment to the Charter more than once, or sign any other name than his own, or give a false address or sign same when not a legal voter in the city; 
(G)  Solicit or accept anything of value or any promise of support to any office or position or employment for signing an initiative, referendum, or recall petition, or petition for amendment of the Charter; 
(H)  Sell, purchase, steal, or attempt to steal, or willfully destroy or mutilate any initiative, referendum, or recall petition, or petition for amendment of the Charter; 
(I)  Directly or indirectly, either positively or by inference, intimidate any person either to sign or abstain from signing, or to solicit or abstain from soliciting signatures to any initiative, referendum, or recall petition, or petition for amendment of the Charter. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 11.99(B). 
Secs. 11.10-11.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 11.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Whoever shall willfully make a false affidavit of any matter required by any section of this chapter to be stated under oath, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(B)  Whoever, directly or indirectly, in person or through an agent, shall do any of the acts prohibited in § 11.09, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 12886, passed 6-23-26) 
CHAPTER 12. - THE CITY FLAG; THE CITY COAT OF ARMS 

Sec. 12.01. - Design of city flag; size. 
    The following design is hereby adopted as the official flag of the city: 
(A)  Material. It shall be made of bunting or silk. 
(B)  Dimensions. The standard size shall be three feet in width and five feet in length. 
(C)  Hanging. The flag shall be hung with the width fastened to the staff. 
(D)  Design and color. The entire field shall be of royal blue color. At a distance of six inches from the staff the word "Dayton" shall be superimposed in white on the field in a vertical position. The word shall consist of block serif letters three and one-half inches high and seven inches wide. Centered on the field 38-1/2 inches from the staff shall be a white gear. This gear shall consist of 32 beveled teeth. The gear shall have an outside diameter of 29-1/2 inches, with teeth cut to a depth of two inches. Centered within the gear shall be a gray globe. The globe shall have nine each of latitude and longitude marks outlined in white across its face. The globe shall have an outside diameter of 19-1/2 inches. Superimposed upon the gear in royal blue shall be a representation of the original Wright Brothers' aeroplane, "The Kitty Hawk" in flight. This plane shall have a wing-span of 18-1/2 inches. The plane shall be flying away from the staff. The width of the tape or binding at the staff shall not be counted in any dimensions. Flags manufactured in other sizes shall be in the same proportions as outlined above. 
(Ord. 10570, passed 8-15-17; amend. Ord. 19061, passed 6-11-58) 
Sec. 12.02. - Authority to display flag. 
    Authority to display flags or other decorations on, in, or about the city hall or other public buildings is hereby vested in the City Manager unless otherwise ordered by vote of the City Commission. 
(Ord. 10570, passed 8-15-17) 
Sec. 12.03. - Design of the city coat of arms. 
    The following design is adopted as the official coat of arms of the city: 
(A)  Enclosed in a golden circular band, a shield with crested top of gold leaves and rosettes. 
(B)  The shield divided. Blazoned on a field of red, five stars of gold, representing the five City Commissioners; the center star larger, honoring the Mayor. 
(C)  The dexter honor. Blazoned on a field of black, a gear in gold, representing the manufacturing industry. 
(D)  Sinister honor. Blazoned on a field of blue, a pair of wings in gold, representing aviation. 
(E)  Dexter base. Blazoned on a field of purple, a lighted lamp in gold, representing the cultural activities. 
(F)  Sinister base. Blazoned on a field of green, a replica of the Newcom Tavern in gold, representing the pioneer settlement of Dayton. 
(G)  At the fesse point, a gold circle embossed with a gold star, honoring the City Manager. 
(H)  The top of the crest, and the base point extend over the golden circular band and are embossed upon its surface. 
(I)  Also embossed upon the surface of the golden circular band: 
(1)  In the upper half the inscription "The City of Dayton, Ohio." 
(2)  In the lower half the inscription "Incorporated A.D. 1805." 
(J)  Also blazoned below the Newcom Tavern, on the sinister base the inscription "1796." 
(K)  All stars shall be five pointed stars. 
(Ord. 23140, passed 10-9-68) 
CHAPTER 14. - INVESTIGATIONS 

Sec. 14.01. - Powers of investigation. 
    The Commission, any committee thereof duly authorized, the City Manager, or any person appointed by the City Manager for the purpose of making any investigation authorized by the Charter, shall be vested with the following rights, powers, and prerogatives: 
(A)  Officer appointed to serve subpoenas. To appoint any police officer or other person to serve subpoenas for witnesses. 
(B)  Bailiffs appointed. To appoint any police officer or other person to maintain order and decorum at the sessions held by the Commission, committee, City Manager, or person appointed by the City Manager as aforesaid, and to carry out the orders thereof, and perform such other and further duties as are performed by the bailiff in a court of law. 
(C)  Employment of clerical and expert assistants. To appoint such clerks, stenographers, and other help and assistants, including legal counsel and expert assistance, as may be necessary in order to carry on the investigations at hand. 
(D)  Production of evidence. To compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers, and other evidence, and may issue subpoenas or attachments for them signed by the presiding officer of the Commission, chairman of the committee, City Manager, or person appointed by the City Manager as aforesaid, and no officer or employee of the city shall by virtue of such office or employment be exempt from being called as a witness. 
(E)  Power to adopt rules and regulations. To adopt such rules and regulations as the Commission, committee, City Manager, or person appointed by the City Manager as aforesaid, may deem proper and expedient for the purpose of conducting the investigation, and to do, in a lawful manner, all things which may be found necessary to successfully carry on the investigation. 
(Ord. 11167, passed 6-30-20; amend. Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 14.99. 
Sec. 14.02. - Witness fees. 
    Each witness not an officer or employee of the city subpoenaed hereunder shall be entitled to receive a fee of $12.00 for each day in attendance or $6.00 for each half day in attendance. 
(Ord. 11167, passed 6-30-20; amend. Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
Sec. 14.03. - Compensation of agents of investigating unit. 
    The compensation to be paid for the service of subpoenas or the performance of any other acts or duties authorized or specified by this chapter shall be fixed by the committee, City Manager, or person appointed by the City Manager as aforesaid, on the approval of the City Commission, except that no compensation in addition to his regular compensation shall be so allowed to any duly elected or appointed officer or to any employee in the classified or unclassified service of the city. 
(Ord. 11167, passed 6-30-20; amend. Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
Sec. 14.04. - Witness shall testify. 
    No witness shall fail or refuse to testify on any matter under investigation of which he has knowledge, but such testimony shall not be used against him in any criminal prosecution except for perjury. 
(Ord. 11167, passed 6-30-20; amend. Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 14.99. 
Sec. 14.05. - Expense of investigation. 
    All expenses of any investigation, including fees, compensation for services rendered, and all other expenses necessary and incidental thereto shall be vouchered in the usual manner then in use in the city and shall be paid by the city, on approval by the City Commission, out of funds appropriated for that purpose by the Commission. 
(Ord. 11167, passed 6-30-20; amend. Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
Sec. 14.06. - Report of investigation. 
    The Commission or any committee thereof duly authorized, sitting as a committee for the purpose of making any investigation shall make a full and complete report of its proceedings, together with its recommendations to the City Commission, and the City Manager or any person appointed by the City Manager to make any such investigation shall make a like report, together with recommendations to the City Manager, who in turn, shall transmit these reports together with a report of any action he may have taken pursuant thereto or any recommendations which he may make to the City Commission. All such reports, on being received by the Commission, shall be filed and kept as a permanent record in the office of the Clerk of the Commission. 
(Ord. 11167, passed 6-30-20; amend. Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
Secs. 14.07-14.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14.99. - Penalty. 
    Any person who fails to comply with a subpoena issued pursuant to the provisions of § 14.01(D) after having been personally served therewith or who violates the provisions of § 14.04 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 25548, passed 6-7-78) 
CHAPTER 15. - ELECTIONS 

Sec. 15.01. - Wards established. 
    The city is subdivided into 23 wards, which are created and established and their boundaries are fixed as set forth in §§ 15.02 through 15.24. The boundaries are fixed so that each ward is composed of adjacent and compact territory, and is substantially equal in population. 
(Ord. 31091-11, passed 8-24-11) 
Sec. 15.02. - First Ward. 
Beginning at the point where the Salem Ave. Bridge crosses over the Great Miami River; Thence following the Great Miami River and Mad River east to the Monument Ave. Bridge, crossing West Riverview Ave. northerly to the centerline of Grafton Ave.; Thence northerly along the centerline of Grafton Ave. to north property line of City Lot #83580, easterly along the north property line of City Lot #83580 to the centerline of Belmont Park North; Thence northerly along the centerline of Belmont Park North to the north property line of City Lot #14869; Thence easterly along the north property line of City Lot #14869 to the centerline of Stoddard Ave.; Thence south along the centerline of Stoddard Ave. to Forest Ave.; Thence south along the centerline of Forest Ave. to West Riverview Ave.; Thence east on West Riverview Ave. to U.S. Interstate 75; Thence south along U.S. Interstate 75 to the Great Miami River; Thence east following the Great Miami River and Mad River east to Keowee St.; Thence along the centerline of Keowee St. south to East Fifth St.; Thence west along the centerline of East Fifth St. to Bainbridge St.; Thence south and west along the centerline of Bainbridge St. to Wayne Ave.; Thence south along the centerline of Wayne Ave. to Jones St.; Thence west along the centerline of Jones St. to Abram Ave.; Thence north along the centerline of Abram Ave. to Cass St.; Thence west along the centerline of Cass St. approximately 126.71 feet to a line parallel to Clay St. said line being the east property line of the west one half of City Lot #1472 to a point in the centerline of the alley south of Van Buren St.; Thence west along the centerline of the alley south of Van Buren St. approximately 24 feet to a point; Thence north along the east property line of City Lot #1460 to Van Buren St.; Thence east 8.5 feet along the centerline of Van Buren St. to a point; Thence north along a line 8.5 feet east of the west lot line of City Lot #1452 to the alley south of East Fifth St.; Thence west along the centerline of the alley south of East Fifth St. to Jackson St.; Thence north along the centerline of Jackson St. to the alley south of East Fifth St.; Thence west along the centerline of the alley south of East Fifth St. to Brown St.; Thence north along the centerline of Brown St. to the alley south of East Fifth St.; Thence west approximately 138.75 feet along the centerline of the alley south of East Fifth St. to a point; Thence south along the east property line of City Lot #1981 to East Sixth St.; Thence west along the centerline of East Sixth St. to the first alley east of South Patterson Boulevard; Thence southwestwardly along the centerline of the first alley east of South Patterson Boulevard to Green St.; Thence west along the centerline of Green St. to South Jefferson St.; Thence south along the centerline of South Jefferson St. to the north right of way line of U.S. Route 35; Thence eastwardly along the north right of way line of U.S. Route 35 following the curve to Keowee St.; Thence south along the centerline of Keowee St. to Wayne Ave.; Thence south along the centerline of Wayne Ave. to Wyoming St.; Thence west along the centerline of Wyoming St. to the north property line of Woodland Cemetery; Thence following the Woodland Cemetery north property line south to the Dayton Corporation Line; Thence following Dayton Corporation Line and its meandering westwardly to the Great Miami River; Thence following the Great Miami River northwardly to the Salem Ave. Bridge and the point of beginning. 
(Am. Ord. 24166, passed 12-15-71; Am. Ord. 30067-02, passed 2-27-02; Am. Ord. 8547, passed 3-13-11; Am. Ord. 31091-11, passed 8-24-11; Am. Ord. 31360-14, passed 12-23-14) 
Sec. 15.03. - Second Ward. 
Beginning at the point the Keowee St. bridge crosses over the Mad River; Thence following the Mad River to the Dayton Corporation Line; Thence following the Dayton Corporation Line and its meandering to Fourth St.; Thence center line of Fourth St. west to Smithville Rd.; Thence center line of Smithville Rd. south to Fifth St.; Thence center line of Fifth St. west to Keowee St.; Thence center line of Keowee St. north to the Mad River and the point of beginning. 
(Ord. 17684, passed 12-30-53; Am. Ord. 24166, passed 12-15-71; Am. Ord. 30067-02, passed 2-27-02) 
Sec. 15.04. - Third Ward. 
Beginning at the confluence of the Great Miami River and the Stillwater River; Thence following the Stillwater River north to the Dayton Corporation Line; Thence following the Dayton Corporation Line and its meandering northeastwardly to the Mad River; Thence southwestwardly following the Mad River to the Stillwater River and the point of beginning. This Ward shall also include the James M. Cox Dayton International Airport. 
(Ord. 17684, passed 12-30-53; Am. Ord. 24166, passed 12-15-71; Am. Ord. 30067-02, passed 2-27-02) 
Sec. 15.05. - Fourth Ward. 
Beginning at the intersection of Salem Ave. and Emerson Ave.; Thence center line of Emerson Ave. east to Hudson Ave.; Thence center line of Hudson Ave. northeastwardly to Brookside Dr.; Thence center line of Brookside Dr. east to Wabash Ave.; Thence center line of Wabash Ave. south to Niagara Ave.; Thence center line of Niagara Ave. east to Linda Vista Ave.; Thence center line of Linda Vista Ave. south to south property line of Victor Ave.; Thence south property line of Victor Ave. east to Main St.; Thence center line of Main St. south to Ridge Ave.; Thence center line of Ridge Ave. east to the Stillwater River; Thence following the Stillwater River south to the Great Miami River; Thence following the Great Miami River to Interstate 75; Thence Interstate 75 north to Grand Ave.; Thence center line of Grand Ave. west to Forest Ave.; Thence center line of Forest Ave. north to Neal Ave.; Thence center line of Neal Ave. west to Richmond Ave.; Thence center line of Richmond Ave. north to Harvard Blvd.; Thence center line of Harvard Blvd. west to Salem Ave.; Thence center line of Salem Ave. north to Emerson Ave. and the point of beginning.

CHAPTER 30. - CITY COMMISSION 
DIVISION 1. - COMMISSION MEETINGS 

Sec. 30.01. - Time of Commission meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the City Commission shall be held on Wednesday of each week, as announced by the Clerk of Commission. When a Commission meeting would fall on any of the following days: New Year's Day, Washington's Birthday, Independence Day, Christmas Eve Day or Christmas Day, then and in that event the regular meeting of the Commission for the week shall be held on another day of that week, as announced by the Clerk of Commission. 
(Ord. 18107, passed 11-24-54; Am. Ord. 19560, passed 3-9-60; Am. Ord. 26535, passed 5-26-82; Am. Ord. 26568, passed 7-28-82; Am. Ord. 26843, passed 7-20-83; Am. Ord. 30262-03, passed 6-25-03) 
Sec. 30.02. - Place of Commission meetings. 
    All meetings of the Commission shall be held at the rooms which are provided, set apart, and designated from time to time as the City Commission rooms. 
(Ord. 9561, passed 1-5-14; Am. Ord. 14798, passed 5-29-34) 
Sec. 30.03. - Special Commission meetings. 
    Special meetings of the Commission may be held at such time as shall be fixed by the person or persons calling the meetings, which shall be noted in the notice thereof. 
(Ord. 9561, passed 1-5-14) 
Sec. 30.04. - Meetings shall be public. 
    All meetings of the Commission shall be public. 
(Ord. 9561, passed 1-5-14) 
Sec. 30.05. - Reading of legislative measures. 
    The reading of all ordinances, resolutions, or other legislative measures passed or adopted by the City Commission may be by title only. 
(Ord. 18749, passed 5-15-57) 
Sec. 30.06. - Conduct of persons at Commission meetings. 
(A)  No person in attendance at a Commission meeting shall do the following: 
(1)  Address the Commission without first being recognized by, and granted permission so to do, by the presiding officer, or by a majority of the Commission; 
(2)  Continue to address the Commission after being ruled out of order by the presiding officer, unless permission to continue is granted by a majority of the Commission; or 
(3)  Become boisterous or perform any act, either individually or in concert with another person or persons, which interferes with the good order and decorum of the Commission. 
(B)  Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of subsection (A) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(Ord. 23408, passed 6-25-69) 
Sec. 30.07. - Acting Mayor authorized. 
    The Mayor is authorized from time to time to designate other members of the Commission as Acting Mayor for limited or all purposes. Should the Mayor be absent and unable to designate an Acting Mayor, the Commission member with the greatest continuous seniority shall serve as Acting Mayor. 
(Ord. 18928, passed 1-15-58; Am. Ord. 30828-09, passed 2-18-09) 
Secs. 30.08, 30.09. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLERK OF COMMISSION 

Sec. 30.10. - Appointment and removal of the Executive Assistant and Clerk of Commission. 
    The positions of Executive Assistant to the Commission and Clerk of Commission shall be appointed and may be removed by motion approved by a majority vote of the Commission, which vote shall be recorded upon the minutes of the Commission. 
(Ord. 10986, passed 10-8-19; Am. Ord. 30826-09, passed 2-4-09) 
Sec. 30.11. - Clerk of Commission to serve as Executive Assistant. 
    The Clerk of the City Commission shall be additionally designated as its Executive Assistant, and shall perform such other and further duties as are customarily performed by such office. 
(Ord. 18929, passed 1-15-58) 
Sec. 30.12. - Clerk's bond. 
    The Clerk of the Commission shall give a bond in the sum set by the Commission conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. 
(Ord. 10986, passed 10-8-19) 
Sec. 30.13. - Authority of Assistant Clerk to act in Clerk's absence. 
    In the absence of the Clerk, the person holding the position of Administrative Assistant and Assistant Clerk, or such other person as may be designated by the Clerk, shall be fully authorized to perform any act or exercise any power which the Clerk may perform or exercise. 
(Ord. 26576, passed 8-11-82) 
Secs. 30.14-30.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MUNICIPAL JOURNAL 

Sec. 30.20. - Dayton Municipal Journal authorized. 
    The publication of a municipal journal to be known as Dayton Municipal Journal is authorized. 
(Ord. 11533, passed 2-15-22; Am. Ord. 18738, passed 5-15-57) 
Sec. 30.21. - Purpose of Dayton Municipal Journal. 
    The Dayton Municipal Journal shall carry copies of all ordinances, resolutions and other legal notices and advertisements required to be published by the city during a period or periods when a daily newspaper of general circulation is not being published or distributed within the city. 
(Ord. 11533, passed 2-15-22; Am. Ord. 18738, passed 5-15-57) 
Sec. 30.22. - Publication of journal. 
    The journal, as herein provided for, shall be published in the Daily Court Reporter or any other similar publication published in the city and having a general circulation therein, on occasions and during periods of time when a daily newspaper of general circulation therein is for any reason not being published and being distributed within the city. The portion of the Daily Court Reporter or other similar publication in which this journal is published shall be devoted exclusively to the matter to be carried by the journal. It shall be a solid block of space, set off by conspicuous lines or by a border, so as to call the attention of the reader to the fact that reading matter contained within the confines of such lines or border is that of the municipal journal and the name of such journal shall be employed in large type and in a conspicuous manner at the top of such space. Under the name of the journal shall be printed in similar style the words "Published by the City of Dayton". The matter published in the journal shall be in six-point type, with heads to articles set in larger type at the discretion of the Clerk of the Commission. 
(Ord. 11533, passed 2-15-22; Am. Ord. 18738, passed 5-15-57) 
Sec. 30.23. - Contract for publication of journal. 
    A contract for the publication of the journal shall be entered into by the purchasing agent on behalf of the city using such methods by competitive bidding or otherwise to secure the best price obtainable as in each case to him may seem best. Before this contract is entered into, a report shall be made to the Commission and the Commission may give its approval by motion adopted in the usual manner and entered upon its records. 
(Ord. 11533, passed 2-15-22; Am. Ord. 18738, passed 5-15-57) 
Secs. 30.24-30.29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIP REGISTRY 

Sec. 30.30. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Domestic partnership refers to the non-marital committed relationship of two adults of the same or different sex, who share a common residence and affirm that they share responsibility for each other's common welfare, and have signed and filed a declaration of domestic partnership with the city. 
    Share a common residence means that both domestic partners share the same residence. It is not necessary that both domestic partners have title to the property where they reside or the legal right to possess the common residence. Two people may share a common residence even if one or both have additional residences. Domestic partners do not cease to share a common residence if one leaves the common residence but intends to return. Shared common residence does not have the same meaning as bona fide residence. 
    Domestic partners will be deemed to have a "committed" relationship and to "share responsibility for one another's common welfare" if they execute a declaration of domestic partnership affirming that such facts are true. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
Sec. 30.31. - Domestic partnership criteria. 
    To establish a domestic partnership, both individuals must file a declaration of domestic partnership with the city affirming that they meet all of the following qualifications: 
(A)  Both individuals share a common residence; 
(B)  Both individuals affirm that they have a committed relationship and share responsibility for each other's common welfare; 
(C)  Neither individual is married to any other individual; 
(D)  Neither individual is part of an existing domestic partnership with any third party; 
(E)  Each individual is 18 years of age or older; and 
(F)  The individuals are not related to one another by blood in a way that would prevent them from being married to one another in this state. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
Sec. 30.32. - Filing. 
(A)  Filing location. Two individuals seeking to become domestic partners must complete and file a declaration of domestic partnership with the City Commission. 
(B)  Filing prohibition. No individual who has previously filed a declaration of domestic partnership in this city may file a new declaration of domestic partnership until a notice of termination of domestic partnership has been filed with the City Commission. However, this prohibition shall not apply if the previous domestic partnership ended because one of the domestic partners is deceased. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
Sec. 30.33. - Registration. 
(A)  Registration forms. The Executive Assistant to the City Commission shall develop "declaration of domestic partnership" and "notice of termination of domestic partnership" forms, and shall not add to or alter the requirements listed in § 30.31 of this division. 
(B)  Registration requirements. The "declaration of domestic partnership" form shall require each registrant to: 
(1)  Affirm that he or she meets the requirements of § 30.31 of this division; 
(2)  Provide a mailing address; 
(3)  Sign the form under penalty of perjury; and 
(4)  Have a notary public acknowledge his or her signature. 
(C)  Availability of forms. The city shall have declaration and termination forms available at the offices of the City Commission. 
(D)  Administrative fee. The city shall charge an administrative fee of $50.00 to persons filing a declaration of domestic partnership. No fee shall be charged for the filing of a notice of termination of domestic partnership. 
(E)  Partnership registration. The city shall register the declaration of domestic partnership in a registry and return a copy of the declaration form to the domestic partners at the address provided as their common residence. 
(F)  Termination registration. The city shall register the notice of termination of domestic partnership pursuant to the requirements set forth in § 30.34 of this division. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
Sec. 30.34. - Termination. 
(A)  Termination. A domestic partnership ends when: 
(1)  One of the domestic partners dies; or 
(2)  A notice of termination of domestic partnership has been filed by one or both domestic partners with the city. 
(B)  Notice of termination. If the facts affirmed in the declaration of domestic partnership cease to be true, one or both parties to a domestic partnership shall file a notice of termination of domestic partnership with the City Commission. Upon receipt, the city shall return a copy of the notice marked "filed" to each of the partners, if jointly filed; or two copies to the filing partner. Unless the partners jointly file the notice, the partner filing the notice shall, within five days, send a copy of the filed notice to the other partner's last known address. However, this requirement shall not apply if the termination is due to the death of one of the domestic partners. 
(C)  Effective termination date. Termination of a domestic partnership shall be effective upon filing of the notice of termination of domestic partnership with the city by one or both partners, or on the date of the death of one of the domestic partners. 
(D)  Notice to third parties. Following the termination of a domestic partnership the burden of notification rests with, each former domestic partner who has received or qualified for any benefit or right based upon the existence of a domestic partnership and whose receipt of that benefit or enjoyment of that right has not otherwise terminated, to give prompt notification to any third party who provides such benefit or right that the domestic partnership has terminated. The city shall not be liable for any injury to any third-party by virtue of lack of notice of termination to the domestic partnership, including any third-party which has provided any benefits regarding the domestic partnership. 
(E)  Failure to give notice. Failure to provide notice to third parties as prescribed in this section shall not delay or prevent the termination of the domestic partnership. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
Sec. 30.35. - Legal effect. 
(A)  Registering as domestic partners by two individuals who are also married to one other, in this or in another state, shall under no circumstances, be considered as evidence, knowledge, awareness, or an admission that the partners are not lawfully married and it shall not be given any other legal effect, in this or any other state, with regard to whether the persons are lawfully married. 
(B)  Nothing in this division shall be interpreted to alter or contravene county, state or federal law. 
(C)  Nothing in this division shall be construed as recognizing or treating a declaration of domestic partnership as a marriage or a legal status that intends to approximate the design, qualities, significance or effect of marriage. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
Sec. 30.36. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, clause or provision of this division is held invalid, the remainder shall not be affected by such invalidity. 
(Ord. 31167-12, § 1, passed 5-2-12) 
CHAPTER 31. - MUNICIPAL COURT 

Sec. 31.01. - Clinical psychologists for municipal court. 
    The presiding judge and other judges of the municipal court may, at their discretion, employ, when necessary for the purposes of their courts, clinical psychologists at a rate of compensation to be determined by the presiding judge. However, the aggregate of such special service compensation in any one year shall not exceed the total sum appropriated by ordinance of the City Commission for such purposes. 
(Ord. 21038, passed 1-8-64; Am. Ord. 21962, passed 3-2-66; Am. Ord. 26384, passed 11-25-81) 
Sec. 31.02. - Court stenographers. 
    The presiding judge and other judges of the municipal court may, at their discretion employ, when necessary for the purpose of their courts, special court stenographers at a rate of compensation to be determined by the presiding judge. However, the aggregate of such special service compensation in any one year shall not exceed the total sum appropriated by ordinance of the City Commission for such purpose. 
(Ord. 16211, passed 5-21-47; Am. Ord. 19918, passed 3-29-61; Am. Ord. 26384, passed 11-25-81) 
CHAPTER 32. - DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32.01. - Applicability of the chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to discriminatory practices including, but not limited to, discrimination in employment, public accommodations, and housing which occur within the territorial limits of the city, and to employment, contracted for, performed, or to be performed within these limits, and discrimination at places of public accommodation, resort, recreation, and amusement located within the territorial limits of the city. 
(Ord. 20343, passed 5-9-62; Am. Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69) 
Sec. 32.02. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them respectively, regardless of whether or not the words and phrases are capitalized: 
    Affirmative action. Includes, but is not limited to: hiring, reinstatement, or upgrading of employees with, or without, back pay; admission or restoration to union membership or training programs with utilization of objective criteria for admission; sale or lease of housing accommodation and lending of money upon equal terms and conditions; cancellation, rescission or revocation of a contract, deed, lease or other instrument transferring any housing accommodation which is the subject of a charge of unlawful discrimination to a person who had knowledge or record notice, prior to the transfer or the execution of the agreement to make the transfer, that a charge under § 32.20 was filed; payment to an injured person of profits obtained by respondent through a violation of § 32.05(I), payment for any injury caused by the practice; awarding of costs; and a requirement for reports of the manner of compliance. If the Council directs payment of back pay, it shall make allowance for interim earnings. 
    Aggrieved person. Includes any person who: 
(1)  Claims to have been injured by a discriminatory practice; or 
(2)  Believes that such a person will be injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur. 
    Because of sex or on the basis of sex. Include, but are not limited to, because of or on the basis of pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions; and women affected by pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions shall be treated the same for all employment related purposes, including receipt of benefits under fringe benefit programs, as other persons not so affected but similar in their ability or inability to work, and nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to permit otherwise. This shall also include denying or limiting housing accommodations, services, or facilities in connection with the sale, lease, or rental of housing accommodations or dwellings because a person failed or refused to provide sexual favors. 
    Burial lot. Any lot for the burial of deceased persons within any public burial ground or cemetery, including but not limited to, cemeteries owned and operated by municipal corporations, townships, or companies or associations incorporated for cemetery purposes. 
    Complainant. The person (including the Council) who files a complaint under this chapter. 
    Conciliation. The attempted resolution of issues raised by a complaint, or by the investigation of such complaint, through informal negotiations involving the aggrieved person, the respondent, and the Council. 
    Conciliation agreement. A written agreement setting forth the resolution of the issues in conciliation. The protections afforded against discrimination on the basis of familial status shall apply to any person who is pregnant or is in the process of securing legal custody of any individual who has not attained the age of 18 years. 
    Council. The Human Relations Council as established by § 32.10. 
    Discriminate and discrimination. Include any difference in treatment based on race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, familial status, or disability. 
    Employee. Does not include any individual employed in the domestic service of any person. 
    Employer. Any person who employs four or more persons, including the city, its departments, boards, commissions, and authorities, and any person acting in the interest of an employer, directly or indirectly. 
    Employment. Does not include the employment of individuals in domestic service. 
    Employment agency. Any person regularly undertaking, with or without compensation, to procure opportunities for employment or to procure, recruit, or place employees. 
    Familial status. Includes one or more individuals (who have not obtained the age of 18 years) being domiciled with: 
(1)  A parent or another person having legal custody of such individual or individuals; or 
(2)  The designee of such parent or other person having such custody with the written permission of such parent or other person. "Familial status" shall apply to any person who is pregnant or is in the process of securing legal custody of any individual who has not attained the age of 18 years. 
(3)  Family includes a single individual. 
    Gender identity. The gender-related identity, appearance, or mannerisms or other gender-related characteristics of an individual, regardless of the individual's designated sex at birth. 
    Handicap, handicapped, disabled, or disability means, with respect to a person: 
(1)  A physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or more of such person's major life activities; 
(2)  A record of having such impairment; or 
(3)  Being regarded as having such an impairment, but such term does not include current, illegal use of or addiction to a controlled substance (as defined in Section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 802)). Nothing in this division requires the inclusion of an individual whose inclusion would constitute a direct threat to the health or safety of other individuals or would result in substantial physical damage to the property of others. 
    Housing accommodations. Includes any building or structure or portion thereof which is used or occupied or is intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied as the home residence or sleeping place of one or more individuals, groups, or families whether or not living independently of each other, and any vacant land offered for sale or lease, including land offered for use as a trailer park and sites offered for mobile homes. It also includes any housing accommodations held or offered for sale or rent by a real estate broker, salesman, or agent, or by any other person pursuant to authorization of the owner, by the owner himself, or his legal representative. 
    Labor organization. Any organization which exists in whole or in part for the purpose of collective bargaining or of dealing with employers concerning grievances, terms, or conditions of employment, or of other mutual aid or protection in relation to employment. 
    Neighborhood. Any area or community within the city which has been recognized as such through custom and usage and which may be delineated by recognized boundaries, such as major highways, railroads, or rivers and other natural barriers. 
    Person. Any individual, partnership, corporation, labor organization, or other organization or association, including those acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity, whether appointed by a court or otherwise. The term "person," as applied to partnerships or other organizations or associations, includes their members, and as applied to corporations includes their officers. It also includes, but is not limited to, any owner, lessor, assignor, builder, manager, broker, salesman, agent, employee, and lending institution, and the heads of all departments, boards, commissions, authorities, and other administrative divisions of the city. 
    Place of public accommodation. Any inn, restaurant, eating house, barbershop, public conveyance by air, land, or water, theater, store, or other place for the sale of merchandise, or any other place of public accommodation or amusement where the accommodations, credit, advantages, facilities, or privileges thereof are available to the public. 
    Prevailing party. Has the same meaning as such term has in Section 722 of the Revised Statutes of the United States (42 U.S.C. 1988). 
    Redlining. The practice of financial institutions denying loans, mortgages, or home improvement loans and/or the practice of insurance companies or agencies in denying insurance to homebuyers and/or homeowners in a neighborhood which the lender and/or insurance company, as the case may be, has classified as being on the decline or dilapidated. 
    Residential real estate-related transactions. Any of the following: the making or purchasing of loans or providing other financial assistance, for purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing, or maintaining a dwelling; or secured by residential real estate. The selling, brokering, or appraising of residential real property. The purchasing and otherwise obtaining of insurance of other incidental transactions necessary to purchase and maintain a dwelling. 
    Respondent. 
(1)  The person or other entity accused in a complaint of an unfair housing practice; and 
(2)  Any other person or entity identified in the course of investigation and notified as required with respect to respondents so identified under. 
    Restrictive covenant. Any specification limiting the transfer, rental, lease, or other use of any housing because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, or ancestry, or any limitation based upon affiliation with or approval by any person, directly or indirectly, employing race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, or handicap, as a condition of affiliation or approval. 
    Sexual orientation. Homosexuality, heterosexuality, or bisexuality. 
    Steering. Any real estate marketing, financing, or advertising practice which limits the choice of a prospective user of housing accommodations due to the race. 
    Unlawful discriminatory practice. Any act prohibited by §§ 32.03, 32.04, 32.05, and 32.07. 
(1)  Credit. The right granted by a creditor to a person to defer payment of a debt, or to incur debt and defer its payment, or purchase property or services and defer payment therefor. 
(2)  Creditor. Any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit, any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit, or any assignee of any original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit, whether or not any interest or finance charge is required. 
(3)  Credit reporting agency. Any person who, for monetary fees, dues, or on a cooperative nonprofit basis, regularly assembles or evaluates credit information for the purpose of furnishing credit reports to creditors. 
(Ord. 20343, passed 5-9-62; Am. Ord. 24742, passed 6-5-74; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 28550, passed 5-27-92; Am. Ord. 28586, passed 9-9-92; Am. Ord. 28969-94, passed 12-28-94; Am. Ord. 30698-07, passed 11-21-07) 
Sec. 32.03. - Unlawful discriminatory practices-Employment. 
    It shall be an unlawful discriminatory practice: 
(A)  For any employer to: 
(1)  Refuse to hire or discharge any person or otherwise to discriminate against any person with respect to hire, compensation, tenure, terms, conditions, or privileges of employment, or any matter directly or indirectly related to employment because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(2)  Limit, segregate, or classify employees or applicants for employment in any way which would deprive any person of employment opportunities or otherwise adversely affect any person's status as an employee, because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(3)  Substantially confine or limit recruitment or hiring of employees, with intent to circumvent the spirit and purpose of this chapter, to any employment agency, employment service, labor organization, training school, training center, or any other employee-referring source which serves persons who are predominantly of the same race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(4)  It shall not be unlawful for any employer to take any action otherwise prohibited under subsections (1), (2), or (3) of this section where age, sex, or handicap is a bona fide occupational qualification reasonably necessary to the normal operation of the particular business, or where the differentiation is based on reasonable factors other than age, sex, or handicap. 
(B)  For any employment agency to: 
(1)  Fail or refuse to accept, register, classify properly, or refer for employment, or otherwise to discriminate against any person because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(2)  Comply with a request from an employer for referral of applicants for employment if the request indicates directly or indirectly that the employer fails to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(3)  It shall not be unlawful for any employment agency to take any action otherwise prohibited under subsections (1) or (2) of this section where age, sex, or handicap is a bona fide occupational qualification reasonably necessary to the normal operation of the particular business, or where the differentiation is based on reasonable factors other than age, sex, or handicap. 
(C)  For any labor organization to: 
(1)  Limit or classify its membership on the basis of, exclude or expel from its membership, or otherwise discriminate against any person because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(2)  Limit, segregate, or classify its membership or to classify or refuse to refer for employment any person, in any way which would deprive or tend to deprive any person of employment opportunities or would limit such employment opportunities, or otherwise adversely affect the status, wages, hours, or employment conditions of any employee, or applicant for employment because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(3)  It shall not be unlawful for any labor organization to take any action otherwise prohibited under subsections (1) or (2) of this section where age, sex, or handicap is a bona fide occupational qualification reasonable necessary to the normal operation of the particular business, or where the differentiation is based on reasonable factors other than age, sex, or handicap. 
(D)  Or any employer, labor organization, or joint labor-management committee controlling apprenticeship or other training programs, to discriminate in on-the-job training programs, to discriminate against any person because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap in admission to, or employment in any programs established to provide apprenticeship or other training or retraining. 
(E)  Except where based on a bona fide occupational qualification reasonably necessary to the normal operation of that particular business or enterprise, for the employer, employment agency, or labor organization, joint labor-management committee controlling apprenticeship or other training or retraining programs, or other persons engaged in advertising or publicizing training or employment opportunities to: 
(1)  Elicit or attempt to elicit any information concerning race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, handicap, or place of birth of an applicant for employment or membership except where required or permitted by the Human Relations Council, or by the government of the United States, or any department or agency thereof, or by the state or any department thereof, or by any court of competent jurisdiction; or 
(2)  Make or keep a record of the race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap of any applicant for employment or membership except where required or permitted by the Human Relations Council, or by the government of the United States or any department or agency thereof, or by the state or any department or agency thereof, or by any court of competent jurisdiction; or 
(3)  Use any form of application for employment, personnel or membership blank seeking to elicit information regarding race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap except where required or permitted by the Human Relations Council or by the government of the United States or any department or agency thereof, or by the state or any department or agency thereof, or by any court of competent jurisdiction. However, an employer holding a contract containing a nondiscrimination clause with the government of the United States or any department or agency thereof, may require an employee or applicant for employment to furnish documentary proof of United States citizenship and may retain such proof in his personnel records and may, after an employee is hired require photographic or fingerprint identification for security purposes; or 
(4)  Print, publicize, circulate, advertise, or cause to be printed, or published, circulated, advertised or publicized, any statement, notice, or advertisement relating to employment or membership indicating directly or indirectly any preference, limitation, specification, classification or discrimination, based on race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap; or 
(5)  Utilize in the recruitment or hiring of persons any employment agency, placement service, training school or center, labor organization, joint labor-management committee controlling apprenticeship or other training or retraining, or any other employee-referring source which discriminates against persons because of their race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(F)  For any person seeking employment to publish or cause to be published any advertisement which specifies or in any manner indicates his race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth or expresses a limitation or preference as to the race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap of any prospective employer. 
(Ord. 20343, passed 5-9-62; Am. Ord. 24742, passed 6-5-74; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 30698-07, passed 11-21-07) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 32.99. 
Sec. 32.04. - Same-Public accommodations. 
    It shall be unlawful discriminatory practice: 
(A)  For the owner, lessee, proprietor, manager, Superintendent, agent, or employee of any business or place of public accommodation, resort, recreation, or amusement to: 
(1)  Refuse, withhold from, or deny to any person because of his race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, marital status, handicap, age, national origin, or place of birth, either directly or indirectly, any of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, services, or privileges, products, or goods of such place of public accommodation, resort, or amusement; or 
(2)  Publish, circulate, issue, display, post, or mail, either directly or indirectly, any written or printed communication, notice, or advertisement to the effect that any of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, goods, products, services, and privileges of any such place shall be refused, withheld or denied to any person on account of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, age, martial status, handicap, or place of birth, or that the patronage of any person of any particular race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap is unwelcome, objectionable, or not acceptable, desired, or solicited. 
(B)  For any person, whether or not included in subsection (A), to aid, incite, compel, coerce, or participate in the doing of any act declared to be an unlawful discriminatory practice under this section. 
(Ord. 20343, passed 5-9-62; Am. Ord. 24742, passed 6-5-74; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 30698-07, passed 11-21-07) 
Sec. 32.05. - Same-Housing. 
I. PROHIBITED ACTS 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Fail or refuse to sell, negotiate, transfer, assign, rent, lease, sublease, finance, or otherwise deny or withhold housing accommodation from any person because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status or disability of any prospective owner, occupant, or use of such housing, or of any visitor, family member or associate of the prospective owner, occupant or user. 
(2)  Represent to any person, because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status or disability of any prospective owner, occupant, or user of such housing, or of any visitor, family member or associate of the prospective owner, occupant or user that housing is not available for inspection, sale, transfer, assignment, rental, lease or sublease, when in fact it is so available. 
(3)  Discriminate against any person in making available any residential real estate related transaction, or in the terms or conditions of such a transaction, because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, age, ancestry, marital status, familial status, or national origin. Nothing in this section prohibits a person engaged in the business of furnishing appraisals of real property to take into consideration factors other than race, color, religion, sex, disability, marital status, familial status, or national origin. 
(4)  Refuse to lend money, whether or not secured by mortgage or otherwise, for the acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair, or maintenance of housing to any person because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, age, ancestry, marital status, familial status or national origin of any present or prospective owner, occupant, or user of such housing or of any associates or neighbors of such person. This division shall apply only to persons who lend money as one of the principal aspects of the business or incidental to that business and not only as a part of the purchase price of an owner occupied residence which is offered for sale nor merely casually or occasionally to a relative or friend. 
(5)  Discriminate against any person in the terms or conditions of selling, transferring, assigning, renting, leasing, or subleasing any housing or in furnishing facilities, services, or privileges in connection with the ownership, occupancy, or use of any housing because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, or disability of any present or prospective owner, occupant, or user of such housing, or of any visitor, family member, or associate of the prospective owner, occupant or user of such housing. 
(6)  Discriminate against any person in the terms or conditions of any loan of money, whether or not secured by mortgage or otherwise, for the acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair, or maintenance of housing because of race, age, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, familial status, or disability of the prospective owner, occupant or user of such housing or of any visitor, family member, or associate of the prospective owner, occupant or user of such housing. 
(7)  Print, publish, or circulate, advertise, or publicize any statement, notice, or advertisement relating to the sale, transfer, assignment, rental, lease, sublease, or acquisition of any housing or the loan of money, whether or not secured by mortgage or otherwise, for the acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair, or maintenance of housing which indicates any preference, limitations, specification, or discrimination based upon race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, or disability.
