(B)  Discrimination includes a refusal to permit, at the expense of persons with disabilities, reasonable modifications of existing premises occupied or to be occupied by such person if such modifications may be necessary to afford such person full enjoyment of the premises; except that, in the case of rental, the landlord may where it is reasonable to do so, condition permission for a modification on the renter agreeing to restore the interior of the premises to the condition that existed before the modification, reasonable wear and tear excepted. 
(C)  Discrimination includes a refusal to make reasonable accommodations in rules, policies, practices, or services, when such accommodations may be necessary to afford such person equal opportunity to use and enjoy a dwelling. 
(D)  Buildings which consist of four or more dwellings and/or have one or more elevators that are scheduled for first occupancy on or after March 13, 1990, shall be designed and constructed to provide at least one building entrance on an accessible route unless it is impractical to do so because of the terrain or unusual characteristics of the site. The public and common areas must be readily accessible and usable by disabled persons, and all doors designed to allow passage into and within all premises must be sufficiently wide enough to allow access by disabled persons who are confined to wheelchairs; furthermore, all dwelling units within the building must provide an accessible route into and through the unit, light switches, electrical outlets, thermostats, and other environmental controls must be in accessible locations. Reinforcements must be in bathroom walls to allow later installation of grab bars around the toilet, tub, shower stall and shower seat, where such facilities are provided, and usable kitchens and bathrooms must be designed and constructed in a manner which allows an individual in a wheelchair to maneuver about in those areas. 
(1)  All new construction of multi-family dwellings which consist of four or more dwellings must conform to this division and the accessibility guidelines established by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) for buildings and facilities providing accessibility and usability standards for physically disabled persons. 
(2)  Section 32.05(D) shall apply to all buildings which have four or more dwelling units where there are elevators, or the ground floor of buildings which have four or more units and do not have elevators. 
(E)  Except where required or permitted by the Human Relations Council, or by the government of the United States or any department or agency thereof, or by the State of Ohio, or by any court of competent jurisdiction no person or entity shall make any inquiry, elicit any information, make or keep any record, or use any form of application containing questions or entries concerning race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, or disability in connection with the sale or lease of any housing or the loan of any money, whether or not secured by mortgage or otherwise, for the acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of housing. 
(F)  No person or entity shall include, honor, or exercise in any negotiation, sale, transfer, rental, or lease of housing, any restrictive covenant which is in conflict with any provision of Chapter 32 or other applicable federal, state, or local law. 
(G)  No person or entity shall induce or solicit, or attempt to induce or solicit, a housing listing, sale, or transaction by representing directly or indirectly, that a change has occurred or may occur with respect to racial, religious, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age, marital status, familial status, handicapped status, ancestral status or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood, or area in which the property is located, or induce or solicit, or attempt to induce, or solicit such sale or listing by representing, directly or indirectly, that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of any race, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age, marital status, familial status, handicapped, or ancestry in the area will or may have results such as the following: 
(1)  The lowering of property value. 
(2)  A change in racial, religious, or ethnic composition or influx of handicapped persons in the block, neighborhood, school district, or area in or near which the property is located. 
(3)  An increase in criminal or antisocial behavior. 
(H)  No person or entity shall deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers organization, or facility relating to the business of selling or renting housing accommodations, or to discriminate against him or her the terms or conditions of such access, membership, or participation, on account of such person's race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, marital status, age, or disability. 
(I)  No person or entity shall coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of or on account of his having exercised or enjoyed, or on account of his having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of any right granted or protected by this section. 
(J)  No person or entity shall, whether or not acting under color of law, by force or threat of force willfully injure, intimidate, or interfere with: 
(1)  Any person because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, familial status, marital status, age, or handicap, and because such person is or has been selling, purchasing, renting, financing, occupying, or contracting, or negotiating for the sale, purchase, rental, financing, or occupation of any dwelling, or applying for or participating in any service, organization, or facility relating to the business of selling or renting housing accommodations. 
(2)  Any person because such person is or has been, or in order to intimidate such person or any other person or any class of persons from: 
(a)  Participating, without discrimination on account of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, age, or handicap in any of the activities, services, organizations or facilities described in subsection (J)(1); and 
(b)  Affording with another person or class of persons opportunity or protection so to participate. 
(3)  Any person because such person is or has been, or in order to discourage such person or any other person from lawfully aiding or encouraging other persons to participate without discrimination on account of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, age or handicap, in any of the activities, services, organizations, or facilities described in subsection (J)(1) of this section, or participating lawfully in speech or peaceful assembly opposing any denial of the opportunity to so participate. 
(K)  No person or entity shall discourage or attempt to discourage the purchase by a prospective purchaser of housing by representing directly or indirectly that any block, neighborhood, school district, or area in or near which the property is located has or might undergo an influx of handicapped persons or a change with respect to the racial, religious or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood, school district, or area. 
(L)  No person or entity shall refuse to sell, transfer, assign, rent, lease, sublease, finance or otherwise deny or withhold a burial lot from any person because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, age, or disability of any prospective owner or user of such lot. 
(M)  No person or entity shall engage in any act of redlining as defined in § 32.02(Z). 
(N)  No person or entity shall engage in any act of steering, as defined in § 32.02(U). 
II. EXEMPTIONS 
(O)  The acts prohibited by this section shall not apply: 
(1)  To the rental of a housing accommodation in any building which contains housing accommodations for not more than four families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of the housing accommodations as his or her residence. 
(a)  This shall apply to rooming houses or apartments. 
(b)  Section 32.05(A)(7) shall remain applicable to the above-mentioned housing accommodations. 
(2)  To any religious or denominational institution or organization, or any charitable or educational organization by or in connection with a fraternal organization, so as to prohibit such organization from giving preference to persons of the same religion or denomination, or to members of such private or fraternal organization, or from making such selection as is calculated by such organization to promote the religious principles or the aims, purposes, or fraternal principles for which it is established or maintained. 
(P)  No provision in this section limits the applicability of any reasonable local, state, or federal restrictions regarding the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling. 
(Q)  No provision in this section regarding familial status shall apply with respect to housing for older persons. As used in this section, "housing for older persons" means housing: (1) Provided by any state, federal, or local program specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons (as defined in a state, federal, or local program); (2) Intended for, housing solely operated by, persons 62 years of age or older; (3) Intended and operated for occupancy by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit. In determining whether housing qualifies as housing for older persons under this division, the Human Relations Council shall develop regulations which require at least the following factors: 
(1)  The existence of significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the physical or social needs of older persons, or if the provision of such facilities and services is not practicable, that such housing necessary to provide important housing opportunities for older persons; and 
(2)  That at least 80 percent of the units are occupied by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit; and 
(3)  The publication of, and adherence to policies and procedures that demonstrate an intent by the owner or manager to provide housing for persons 55 years of age or older per unit. 
(R)  The authority to make the determination in subsection (Q) above, that the housing is specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons, the determination of whether housing qualifies as housing for older persons, and the development of regulations for such determination, shall be exercised by the Human Relations Council. Any such determination shall be consistent with a determination already made by the Secretary of HUD that a particular program is designed and operated to assist elderly persons. 
(Ord. 20343, passed 5-9-62; Am. Ord. 24860, passed 1-8-75; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 28550, passed 9-9-92; Am. Ord. 28586, passed 9-9-92; Am. Ord. 28969-94, passed 12-28-94; Am. Ord. 30698-07, passed 11-21-07) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 32.99. 
Sec. 32.06. - Same-Credit transactions. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful discriminatory practice: 
(1)  For any creditor to: 
(a)  Discriminate against any applicant for credit in the granting, withholding, extending, or renewing of credit, or in the fixing of the rates, terms, or conditions of any form of credit, on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, national origin, handicap, or ancestry, except that this division shall not apply with respect to age in any real estate transaction between a financial institution, a dealer in intangibles, or an insurance company, as these terms are defined in R.C. § 5725.01, and its customers; 
(b)  Use or make any inquiry as to the race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, national origin, handicap, or ancestry for the purpose of limiting or specifying those persons to whom credit will be granted, except that an inquiry of marital status does not constitute discrimination for the purposes of this section if the inquiry is made for the purpose of ascertaining the creditor's rights and remedies applicable to the particular extension of credit and except that creditors are excepted from this division with respect to any inquiry, elicitation of information, record, or form of application required of such creditor by an instrumentality or agency of the United States, or required of such creditor by an agency or instrumentality to enforce the "Civil Rights Act of 1968", 82 STAT 34, 42 U.S.C.A. § 36.08 (c); 
(c)  Refuse to consider the sources of income of an applicant for credit, or disregard or ignore the income of an applicant, in whole or in part, on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, handicap, national origin, or ancestry; 
(d)  Refuse to grant credit to an individual in any name that individual customarily uses, if it has been determined in the normal course of business, that the creditor will grant credit to the individual; 
(e)  Impose any special requirements or conditions including, but not limited to, a requirement for co-obligors or reapplication, on any applicant or class of applicants on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, national origin, handicap, or ancestry in circumstances where similar requirements or conditions are not imposed on other applicants similarly situated, unless the special requirements or conditions imposed with respect to age are the result of a real estate transaction exempted under subsection (B)(1)(a) of this section or are the result of programs that grant preferences to certain age groups administered by instrumentalities or agencies of the United States, a state, or a political subdivision of a state; 
(f)  Fail or refuse to provide an applicant for credit a written statement of the specific reasons for rejection of the application if requested in writing by the applicant within 60 days of the rejection. The creditor shall provide the written statement of the specific reason for rejection within 30 days after receipt of such request. For purposes of this section, a statement that the applicant was rejected solely on the basis of information received from a credit reporting agency or because the applicant failed to meet the standards required by the creditor's credit scoring system, uniformly applied, shall constitute a specific reason for rejection; 
(g)  Fail or refuse to print on or firmly attach to each application for credit in a type size no smaller than that used throughout most of the application form, the following notice: "The Ohio laws against discrimination require that all creditors make credit equally available to all creditworthy customers, and that credit reporting agencies maintain separate credit histories on each individual on request. The Ohio Civil Rights Commission administers compliance with this law." This notice is not required to be included in applications that have a multi-state distribution if the notice is mailed to the applicant with the notice of acceptance or rejection of the application; 
(h)  Fail or refuse on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, national origin, handicap, or ancestry to maintain on the request of the individual, a separate account for each individual to whom credit is extended; 
(i)  Fail or refuse on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, national origin, handicap, or ancestry to maintain records on any account established after November 1, 1976, and to furnish information on the accounts to credit reporting agencies in a manner that clearly designates the contractual liability for repayment as indicated on the application for the account, and if more than one individual is contractually liable for repayment to maintain records and furnish information in the name of each individual. This section does not apply to individuals who are contractually liable only if the primary party defaults on the account. 
(2)  For any credit reporting agency to: 
(a)  Fail or refuse on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, national origin, handicap, or ancestry to maintain, on the request of the individual, a separate file on each individual about whom information is assembled or evaluated; 
(b)  Fail or refuse on the basis of race, color, national origin, ancestry, religion, age, sex, marital status, handicap, sexual orientation, or gender identity to clearly note, maintain, and report any information furnished it under subsection (A)(1)(i) of this section. 
(B)  This section does not prohibit a creditor from requesting the signature of both spouses to create a valid lien, pass clear title, or waive inchoate rights to property. 
(C)  Nothing contained in this section shall bar a creditor from reviewing an application for credit on the basis of established criteria used in the normal course of business for the determination of the credit worthiness of the individual applicant for credit, including the credit history of the applicant. 
(Ord. 25133, passed 7-21-76; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 30698-07, 11-21-07) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 32.99. 
Sec. 32.07. - Obstruction of fair practices. 
(A)  No person shall: Discriminate in any manner against any other person because the person has opposed any unlawful practice defined in § 32.02 or because the person has made a charge, testified, assisted, or participated in any manner in any investigation, proceeding, or hearing under the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  Aid, abet, incite, compel, participate in, or coerce the doing of any act declared by this section to be an unlawful discriminatory practice, or obstruct or prevent any person from complying with this chapter or any order issued thereunder, or attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this section to be an unlawful discriminatory practice. 
(Ord. 20343, passed 5-9-62; Am. Ord. 24742, passed, 6-5-74) 
Secs. 32.08, 32.09. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HUMAN RELATIONS COUNCIL 

Sec. 32.10. - Human Relations Council established. 
    There is established in the Office of the Commission a Council known as the Human Relations Council. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24916, passed 5-28-75) 
Sec. 32.11. - Purpose of Human Relations Council. 
    It is found that prejudice and discrimination against any individual or group because of race, color, creed, national origin, familial status, ancestry, sex or place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap is inimical to our American tradition of equality of opportunity for all, and menaces peace and public welfare; that to eliminate such prejudice and discrimination an instrumentality of government should be established through which the citizens of the city may be kept informed of denials within the city of such equality of opportunity and may seek enforcement of the rights secured by §§ 32.01 and 32.07 and of developments which promote such equality. From this instrumentality, the elected and appointed officials and the departments of this city may obtain expert advice and assistance in adopting those measures to keep peace and good order and harmony among the citizens of the city, to bring about and maintain harmony, to avoid inter-group tensions, to promote tolerance and goodwill, and to insure equality of treatment and of opportunity to all regardless of race, color, sex, ancestry, national origin, familial status, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24742, passed 6-5-74; Am. Ord. 25862; passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 28586, passed 9-9-92) 
Sec. 32.12. - Members to serve without compensation. 
    Members of the Human Relations Council shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69) 
Sec. 32.13. - Membership; appointment; term. 
    The Commission shall appoint ten persons, all of whom shall be residents of the city, to serve as members of the Human Relations Council. Persons appointed to the Human Relations Council shall serve as members for a term of 36 months or until a successor is appointed, with three members appointed on September 1 of one year, four members appointed on September 1 of the succeeding year, and three members appointed on September 1 of the next succeeding year. No person shall serve as a member of the Human Relations Council for more than two consecutive 36-month terms without an absence of at least a 12-consecutive month period from membership on the Human Relations Council. The Commission shall appoint members who, as far as practical, represent in substantially equal proportions all areas of the city. 
    The Commission shall designate two members to serve as chairman and vice-chairman of the Human Relations Council. The chairman and vice-chairman shall serve for a term of 24 months or until a successor is appointed. The Commission may designate the same member to serve as the chairman or vice-chairman of the Human Relations Council for a second term of 24 months or until a successor is appointed. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24916, passed 5-28-75; Am. Ord. 26727, passed 3-2-83; Am. Ord. 30386-04, passed 9-8-04) 
Sec. 32.14. - Meetings of Council; quorum. 
    The Human Relations Council shall meet quarterly and at such other times as the chairman directs. No member shall be required to attend more than 12 meetings per year, including the quarterly Council meetings and meetings of various committees. A majority of the members of the Council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24916, passed 5-28-75) 
Sec. 32.15. - Vacancy; removal. 
(A)  Absence from three consecutive meetings or from six meetings during any calendar year shall operate to vacate the seat of a member. 
(B)  In the event of a death, resignation, or removal of any person either as member, chairman, or vice-chairman, the successor shall be appointed by the Commission to serve the unexpired term for which such person had been so appointed. A person appointed to an unexpired term pursuant to this section may, in addition, serve two consecutive terms pursuant to § 32.13. 
(C)  A member of the Council may be removed for cause by the City Commission, but only after opportunity has been afforded for a public hearing before the Commission at least ten days after written charges have been given the member by the Mayor and a copy filed with the clerk of the City Commission. The member shall be heard in person or by counsel and action of the Commission thereon shall be final. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24916, passed 5-28-75; Am. Ord. 30386-04, passed 9-8-04) 
Sec. 32.16. - Powers and duties of Council. 
    The Council shall have the power and it shall be its duty: 
(A)  To process any complaint, whether initiated by the Human Relations Council or by the filing of a complaint with it, of discrimination against any person because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, and disability in violation of any ordinance of the city or any laws of the state or of the United States, in accordance with the provisions of such ordinance or law. 
(B)  To make such investigations and to hold such hearings as may be provided for by the ordinance or law under which the complaint provided for in subsection (A) above is made. 
(1)  In conducting any investigation or holding any hearing, the Human Relations Council, acting through its Chairman, Executive Director, or hearing examiner may compel the attendance of any person believed to have knowledge of the facts relevant to such investigation or hearing to appear before the person or persons conducting such investigation or such hearing, and may compel the production of books, papers, records, or other evidence relevant to such investigation or hearing by the issuance of a subpoena upon the request of the Executive Director of the Human Relations Council or any member thereof, or upon the request of any respondent in such an investigation or hearing, either personally or through his attorney, and upon showing that there is probable cause to the person having such knowledge or having custody or control of such books, papers, records, or other evidence before the person or persons conducting the investigation or hearing. 
(2)  The person or persons making such investigation or holding such hearings may administer oaths, take the testimony of any person under oath, make findings of fact and orders, and do all other things necessary or incidental of the carrying out of the intent and purpose of the ordinance or law under which the investigation is being conducted or the hearing held. 
(C)  Require or permit any person to keep any records which the Council deems necessary to accomplish the purposes of this chapter. 
(D)  Investigate and study housing patterns and group relationships within the city and the extent of discrimination and segregation in employment, apprenticeship programs, on-the-job training programs, housing and related fields such as real estate, mortgage lending, and insurance, and the effect of such discrimination in the areas mentioned above. The Human Relations Council from time to time, makes recommendations to the Mayor and City Commission for the betterment of housing patterns and inter-group relations with the city. 
(E)  Formulate and carry out a comprehensive educational program designed to prevent and eliminate discrimination in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(F)  Discover all practices and policies written, calculated to create conflicts and tensions and recommend ways and means for their elimination. 
(G)  Report and recommend means of eliminating an unfair or unjust discrimination against any person or group, including persons of Spanish ancestry, and others which would be deemed detrimental to the best interest of the community. 
(H)  Initiate and conduct voluntary surveys, assemble pertinent data, conduct public hearings and expedite the work of the Council by making investigations and surveys. 
(I)  Advise the Executive Director and the professional staff, assisting such staff in planning, designing, and implementing the programs to carry out the policies established by the Commission. 
(J)  Recommend to the Commission legislation to promote and insure equal rights and opportunities for all persons regardless of their race, color, religion, sex, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, marital status, age, or handicap. 
(K)  Adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry out the purpose and intent of this chapter. 
(L)  Appoint qualified persons to act as hearing examiners to conduct public hearings held upon complaints filed with the Council or initiated by the Council, at such fees and upon such other terms and conditions as shall be agreed upon by the hearing examiner and the Council. The hearing examiner shall be an attorney at law admitted to practice in the state. The hearing examiner shall conduct the hearing and rule upon all questions of law and facts and admissibility of evidence and exhibits. At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing examiner shall submit a report to the Council, which report shall contain findings of fact, conclusions of law, and recommendations. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24916, passed 5-28-75; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79; Am. Ord. 28586, passed 9-9-92; Am. Ord. 28771-93, passed 12-22-93) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 32.99. 
Sec. 32.17. - Report of Council. 
    The Human Relations Council shall have power to publish and distribute, at public expense, such factual material as it shall deem necessary or desirable to the performance of its duties, but subject to the limitation or to the amount to be expended each year by the appropriation set up in the annual appropriation ordinance of the city for such purpose. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69) 
Sec. 32.18. - Executive Director of Council; duties. 
    The authority and responsibility for execution of the policies of the Human Relations Council is hereby conferred upon an Executive Director, who shall be appointed by the Commission and shall serve at its pleasure. The Executive Director shall be responsible, subject to § 32.19, for the recruitment, selection, training, and supervision of the professional and clerical staff and shall be in charge of the administration and operation of the Human Relations Council. 
(Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24916, passed 5-28-75) 
Sec. 32.19. - Professional and Clerical Staffs of Council. 
(A)  The Human Relations Council may create such professional, clerical, and other positions as may be necessary in order to properly carry on its duties. However, any position so created, before being filled, shall be approved by the City Commission by a vote spread upon its minutes. Except for the appointment of an Executive Director, all positions so created shall be filled by a person whose name is taken from an appropriate civil service list prepared under the civil service sections of the Charter. 
(B)  No commitments for employees or services shall ever exceed the appropriations made by the City Commission for such purposes. 
(Ord. 22664, passed 9-20-67; Am. Ord. 23466, passed 8-20-69) 
Sec. 32.20. - Complaint procedure. 
(A)  Whenever it is charged in writing and under oath, by a person, referred to as the "complainant", that any person, referred to as the "respondent", has engaged or is engaging in any unlawful discriminatory practices as defined in §§ 32.01 through 32.07, or upon its own initiative, in matters relating to such discriminatory practices, the Human Relations Council or a committee thereof designated pursuant to § 32.16, may initiate a preliminary investigation. The charge shall be filed with the Human Relations Council within six months after the alleged unlawful discriminatory practices are committed. If it determines after such investigation, that it is not probable that unlawful discriminatory practices have been or are being engaged in, the Human Relations Council or its committee shall notify the complainant that it has so determined, and that it will not issue a complaint in the matter. 
(B)  If the Human Relations Council or its committee determines, after such investigation, that it is probable that unlawful discriminatory practices have been or are being engaged in, it shall endeavor to eliminate such practices by informal methods of conference, conciliation, and persuasion. Nothing said or done during such endeavors shall be disclosed by any member of the Human Relations Council, or its staff, or be used as evidence in any subsequent proceeding. If after such investigation and conference, the Human Relations Council or its committee is satisfied that any unlawful discriminatory practice of the respondent will be eliminated, it may treat the complaint as conciliated. An entry of such disposition shall be made on the records of the Human Relations Council. 
(C)  If the Human Relations Council or its committee fails to effect the elimination of such unlawful discriminatory practices and to obtain voluntary compliance, or, if the circumstances warrant, in advance of any such preliminary investigation or endeavors, and if the Human Relations Council or its committee finds that the complainant acted with intention of fulfilling any contracts or agreements he was seeking, the Human Relations Council shall issue and cause to be served upon any person or respondent a complaint stating the charges in that respect and containing a notice of hearing before a hearing examiner appointed by the Human Relations Council, pursuant to § 32.16, at a place therein fixed to be held not less than ten days after the service of such complaint. The place of hearing shall be in the municipal building, or at such other place located within the city may be designated by the Human Relations Council. The City Attorney shall represent the Human Relations Council at such hearing, and if the complainant is not represented by counsel, shall present the evidence in support of the complaint. Any complaint issued pursuant to the provisions of this section must be so issued within one year after the charge of unlawful discriminatory practices is filed pursuant to § 32.20(A). 
(D)  Any such complaint may be amended by the Human Relations Council or its hearing examiner conducting the hearing, at any time prior to or during the hearing based thereon. The respondent shall have the right to file an answer or to amend an answer to the original or amended complaint, and to appear at such hearing in person, or by attorney, or otherwise to examine and cross-examine witnesses. 
(E)  The complainant shall be a party to the proceeding, and any person who is an indispensable party to a complete determination or settlement of the question involved in a proceeding shall be joined. Any person who has or claims an interest in the subject of the hearing and in obtaining or presenting relief against the acts or practices complained of, may be, in the discretion of the hearing examiner, permitted to appear for the presentation of oral or written arguments. 
(F)  In any proceeding, the Human Relations Council or its hearing examiner shall not be bound by the rules of evidence prevailing in the courts of law or equity, but shall, in ascertaining the practices followed by the respondent, take into account all reliable, probative, and substantial evidence, statistical, or otherwise, produced at the hearing, which may tend to prove the existence of a predetermined pattern of discriminatory practice; provided, that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to authorize or require any person to observe the proportion which persons of any race, color, religion, national origin, sex, ancestry, or place of birth bear to the total population or in accordance with any criterion other than the individual qualifications of the applicant. 
(G)  The testimony taken at the hearing shall be under oath and shall be reduced to writing, and filed with the Human Relations Council. Thereafter, in its discretion, the Human Relations Council, upon notice to the complainant and to the respondent with an opportunity to be present, may take further testimony or hear argument. 
(H)  No person shall be compelled to be a witness against himself in any hearing before the Human Relations Council or the hearing examiner. 
(I)  If upon all the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence the Human Relations Council determines that the respondent has engaged in, or is engaging in, any unlawful discriminatory practice, whether against the complainant or others, the Human Relations Council shall state its finding of fact and conclusions of law, and shall issue and cause to be served on such respondent an order requiring him to cease and desist from such unlawful discriminatory practice and to take such further affirmative or other action as will effectuate the purposes of this chapter including but not limited to hiring, reinstatement, or upgrading of employees with, or without back pay, admission or restoration to union membership, including a requirement for reports of the manner of compliance. If the Human Relations Council directs payment of back pay, it shall make allowance for interim earnings. Upon the submission of such reports of compliance, the Human Relations Council may issue a declaratory order stating that the respondent has ceased to engage in unlawful discriminatory practices. 
(J)  If the Human Relations Council finds that no probable cause exists for crediting the charges, or, if upon all the evidence, the Human Relations Council finds that a respondent has not engaged in any unlawful discriminatory practice against the complainant or others, it shall state its findings of fact, and shall issue and cause to be served on the complainant an order dismissing said complaint as to such respondent. 
(K)  Any party to the proceeding, claiming to be aggrieved by final order of the Human Relations Council, including a determination by it that a prima facie case was not established by the complainant, may obtain judicial review thereof by a resort to any court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the provisions of R.C. Chapter 2506. 
(Ord. 22664, passed 9-20-67; Am. Ord. 23735, passed 6-30-70; Am. Ord. 30945-09, passed 12-16-09) 
Sec. 32.21. - Housing complaint procedures. 
(A)  An aggrieved person may file a written complaint with the Human Relations Council alleging a discriminatory housing practice in violation of this chapter. The written complaint with the Human Relations Council must be filed not later than one year after the alleged discriminatory practice has occurred or terminated. The Human Relations Council, on its own initiative, may also file such a complaint. The Human Relations Council, or a committee thereof designated pursuant to § 32.16, may investigate any housing practice to determine whether a complaint should be brought under this section. 
(B)  Upon the filing of such a complaint: 
(1)  The Human Relations Council shall serve notice upon the complainant within ten days after the filing of the complaint; acknowledging the filing and advising the complainant of the time limits and choice of forums provided under this section; and 
(2)  The Human Relations Council shall promptly serve notice upon the respondent or person charged with the commission of a discriminatory housing practice advising of his or her procedural rights and obligations under this section, together with a copy of the complaint. Each respondent may file an answer to such complaint no later than ten days after receipt of notice from the Human Relations Council. 
(C)  After the filing of such a complaint: 
(1)  The Human Relations Council shall commence proceedings with respect to the complaint before the end of the 30th day after the receipt of the complaint. 
(2)  The Human Relations Council shall investigate the allegations of the complaint and complete the investigation in no more than 100 days after receipt of the complaint, unless it is impracticable. If the Human Relations Council is unable to complete the investigation within 100 days after receipt of the complaint, it shall notify the complainant and respondent in writing of the reasons for not doing so. 
(a)  The Human Relations Council shall, within such 100-day period, determine based on the facts whether reasonable cause exists to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred, or is about to occur, unless it is impracticable to do so, or unless the Human Relations Council has approved a conciliation agreement with respect to the complainant. 
(3)  The Human Relations Council shall make final administrative disposition of a complaint within one year of the date of receipt of the complaint, unless it is impracticable to do so. If the Human Relations Council is unable to make final administrative disposition of a complaint within one year of the date of receipt of the complaint, it shall notify the complainant and respondent in writing of the reasons for not doing so. If, after investigation, the Human Relations Council determines that no unlawful discriminatory practice has been or is being or is about to be engaged in by respondent, the Human Relations Council or its staff shall notify the complainant and respondent that it has so determined, and that it will not pursue the complaint further, and shall make public disclosure of each such dismissal. 
(D)  Investigation and conciliation. During the period beginning with the filing of such a complaint and ending with the filing of a charge or a dismissal by the Human Relations Council, Human Relations Council shall, to the extent feasible, engage in conciliation with respect to such complaint. 
(1)  Any conciliation agreement arising out of such conciliation shall be an agreement between the respondent and the complainant, and shall be subject to the approval of the Human Relations Council. 
(2)  A conciliation agreement may provide for binding arbitration of the dispute arising from the complaint. Such arbitration may award appropriate relief, including monetary relief. 
(3)  Each conciliation agreement shall be made public unless the complainant and the respondent otherwise agree and the Human Relations Council determines that disclosure is not required to further the purposes of this chapter. 
(4)  Whenever the Human Relations Council has reasonable cause to believe that a respondent has breached a conciliation agreement, the Human Relations Council shall refer the matter to the City Attorney for further action under an administrative hearing process or in a judicial proceeding, as provided in this chapter. 
(5)  At the conclusion of its investigation, the Human Relations Council or its staff shall prepare a final investigative report, to be kept on the records of the Human Relations Council and to be made available upon request to the complainant and respondent, which shall contain: 
1.  The names and dates of contacts with witnesses; 
2.  A summary and the dates of correspondence and other contacts with the aggrieved person and the respondent; 
3.  A summary description of other pertinent records; 
4.  A summary of witness statements; and 
5.  Answers to interrogatories. 
(E)  The Human Relations Council shall have comprehensive authority, including the power to: 
(1)  Issue subpoenas; 
(2)  Investigate the allegations of complaints; 
(3)  Conciliate complaint matters; 
(4)  Seek prompt judicial action, as provided in this chapter and under applicable state and federal law, for appropriate temporary or preliminary relief pending final disposition of a complaint if the Human Relations Council concludes that such action is necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter; 
(5)  Grant actual damages, or arrange to have adjudicated in court at the expense of the Human Relations Council the award of actual damages to an aggrieved person, as provided in this chapter and under applicable state and federal law; 
(6)  Grant injunctive or other equitable relief, or arrange to seek such relief in court, as provided in this chapter and under applicable state and federal law; 
(7)  Assess a civil penalty against a respondent, or arrange to have adjudicated in court at the expense of the Human Relations Council the award of punitive damages against a respondent, as provided in this chapter and under applicable state and federal law. 
(F)  Administrative enforcement. If the Human Relations Council determines that reasonable cause exists to believe that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, or that immediate administrative proceedings or adjudication are warranted by the circumstances, the Human Relations Council shall issue and cause to be served upon any person or respondent a complaint stating the charges in that respect and containing a notice of hearing before a hearing examiner appointed by the Human Relations Council pursuant to § 32.16 at a place therein fixed to be held not less than ten days after the service of such notice. The place of hearing shall be in the municipal building, or any other place located within the city may be designated by the Human Relations Council. 
(1)  Any such complaint may be amended by the Human Relations Council or its hearing examiner conducting the hearing, at any time prior to or during the hearing based thereon. The respondent shall have the right to file an answer or to amend an answer to the original or amended complaint, and to appear at such hearing in person, or by attorney, or otherwise to cross-examine witnesses. 
(2)  The complainant shall be a party to the proceeding, and any person who is an indispensable party to a complete determination or settlement of the question involved in a proceeding shall be joined. 
(3)  Any person who has or claims an interest in the subject of the hearing and in obtaining or presenting relief against the acts or practices complained of, may be, in the discretion of the hearing examiner, permitted to appear for the presentation of oral or written arguments. 
(4)  In any administrative hearing, the Human Relations Council or its hearing examiner shall ascertain the practices followed by the respondent, take into account all reliable, probative, and substantial evidence, statistical, or otherwise, produced at the hearing, which may tend to provide the existence of a predetermined pattern of discriminatory practice. The testimony taken at the hearing shall be under oath and shall be reduced to writing, and filed with the Human Relations Council. 
(5)  Thereafter, in its discretion, the Human Relations Council, upon notice to the complainant and to the respondent with an opportunity to be present, may take further testimony or hear argument. No person shall be compelled to be a witness against himself in any hearing before the Human Relations Council or the hearing examiner. If upon all the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence the Human Relations Council determines that the respondent has engaged in, or is engaging in, any unlawful discriminatory practice, whether against the complainant or others, the Human Relations Council shall state its findings of fact and conclusions of law, and shall issue a cease and desist order from such unlawful discriminatory practice, and to take such further action as will effectuate the purposes of this chapter. 
(6)  At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, should the Human Relations Council find that no probable cause exists for crediting the charges, or, if upon all the evidence, the Human Relations Council finds that a respondent has not engaged in any unlawful discriminatory practice against the complainant or others, it shall state its finding of fact, and shall issue and cause to be served on the complainant an order dismissing said complainant as to such respondent. 
(G)  Judicial review of the Human Relations Council. Any party to the proceeding, claiming to be aggrieved by a final order of the Human Relations Council including a determination by it that a prima facie case was not established by the complainant, may obtain a de novo review of the Council's findings by a resort to a court which is authorized to award the type of relief provided in this division. 
(H)  Civil enforcement. Any aggrieved person may commence a civil action in the Common Pleas Court, under this chapter or applicable state or federal law, whether or not an administrative complaint has been filed, and without regard to the status of any such complaint. However, if the Human Relations Council or a federal or state agency has obtained a conciliation agreement with the consent of that aggrieved person with respect to the alleged discriminatory housing practice which forms the basis for such complaint, that aggrieved person may not commence a civil action under this division with respect to any alleged discriminatory housing practice which forms the basis of a charge issued by the Human Relations Council if a hearing examiner has commenced a hearing on the record under this chapter with respect to such charge. 
(1)  Upon application by a person alleging a discriminatory housing practice or a person against whom such a practice is alleged, the court in which the action has been commenced may at its discretion: 
(a)  Appoint an attorney for such person; or 
(b)  Authorize the commencement or continuation of a civil action under this chapter, or applicable state or federal law at the trial judge's discretion, without the payment of fees, costs, or security, if in the opinion of the court such person is financially unable to bear the costs of such action. 
(2)  In a civil action under this section, if the court finds that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, the court may award to the plaintiff such actual, compensatory, and/or punitive damages, that may include emotional distress and such relief as the court deems appropriate, any permanent or temporary injunction, temporary restraining order, or other order (including an order enjoining the defendant from engaging in such practice or ordering such action as may be appropriate). 
(3)  Such order may vindicate the public interest, by assessing a civil penalty against the respondent: 
(a)  In an amount not exceeding $10,000.00 if the respondent has not been adjudged to have committed any discriminatory housing practice; 
(b)  In an amount not exceeding $25,000.00 if the respondent has been adjudged to have committed one other discriminatory housing practice during the five-year period ending on the date of the filing of this charge; and 
(c)  In an amount not exceeding $50,000.00 if the respondent has been adjudged to have committed two or more discriminatory practices during the seven-year period ending of the date of filing of this charge; except that if the acts constituting the discriminatory housing practice that are the object of the charge are committed by the same natural person who has been previously adjudged to have committed acts constituting a discriminatory housing practice then the civil penalties set forth in subsections (H)(2) and (3) may be imposed without regard to the period of time within which any subsequent discriminatory housing practice has occurred. 
(4)  In a civil action under this section, the court, at its discretion, may allow the prevailing party, other than the United States, a reasonable attorney fee and costs. Relief granted under this section shall not affect any contract, sale, encumbrance, or lease consummated before the granting of such relief and involving a bona fide purchaser, encumbrancer, or tenant, without actual notice of the filing of a complaint with the Human Relations Council or civil action under this title. 
(5)  (a)  An aggrieved person may commence a civil action, in a court authorized to award compensatory and punitive damages as well as attorney's fees, not later than two years after the occurrence or the termination of an alleged discriminatory housing practice, or the breach of a conciliation agreement entered into under this title, whichever occurs last, to obtain appropriate relief with respect to such discriminatory housing practice or breach. 
(b)  The computation of such a two-year period shall not include any time during which an administrative proceeding under this title was pending with respect to a complaint or charge. Should the court find that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, the court may award to the complainant or plaintiff, actual or punitive damages and any permanent or temporary injunctive relief or other order as the court deems appropriate. This division does not apply to actions arising from a breach of a conciliation agreement. 
(6)  Upon timely application, the City Attorney may intervene in any civil action in which housing discrimination under this chapter may be at issue, and the Human Relations Council certifies that the case is of general public importance. Upon such intervention the City Attorney may obtain such relief as would be available in a civil action. 
(I)  Enforcement by Human Relations Council. 
(1)  Election of judicial determination. When a charge is filed under this chapter, a complainant, a respondent, or an aggrieved person on whose behalf the complaint was filed, may elect to have the claims asserted in that charge decided in a civil action under subsection (I)(1)(a). The election must be made not later than 20 days after the receipt by the electing person of service, or, in the case of the Human Relations Council, not later than 20 days after such service. The person making such election shall give notice of doing so to the Human Relations Council and to all other complainants and respondents to whom the charge relates. 
(a)  If an election is made under this section, the Human Relations Council shall authorize, and not later than 30 days after the election is made, the City Attorney or special counsel retained by the Human Relations Council shall commence and maintain a civil action on behalf of the aggrieved person in a court authorized to award compensatory and punitive damages as well as injunctive relief under this division. The Human Relations Council shall be responsible for all complainant's expenses that are incurred as a result of this election. Any aggrieved person with respect to the issues to be determined in a civil action under this division may intervene as of right in that civil action. In a civil action under this division, if the court finds that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, the court may grant as relief any relief which a court could grant with respect to such discriminatory housing practice in a civil action. Any relief so granted that would accrue to an aggrieved person in a civil action commenced by that aggrieved shall also accrue to that aggrieved person in a civil action under this division. 
(2)  In any administrative proceeding brought under this section, or any court proceeding arising therefrom, or any civil action under this chapter, the administrative law judge or the court, as the case may be, at its discretion, may allow the prevailing party or agency, a reasonable attorney's fee and costs; provided, however, that a prevailing respondent may be awarded costs and reasonable attorney's fees only upon showing that the case is frivolous, unreasonable, or without foundation. 
(J)  Any party aggrieved by a civil action under this chapter granting or denying in whole or in part the relief sought may obtain a review of such order by the appropriate appellate tribunal. 
(Ord. 28550, passed 5-27-92; Am. Ord. 28586, passed 9-9-92) 
Secs. 32.22-32.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 32.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any person who fails to comply with a subpoena issued by the Human Relations Council as provided in § 32.16 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  Any person who fails to comply with an order to cease and desist or to undertake affirmative action ordered by the Human Relations Council after a public hearing or agreed to by such person pursuant to conciliation, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(C)  Any person who violates § 32.05 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(Ord. 22664, passed 9-20-67; Am. Ord. 24742, passed 6-5-74; Am. Ord. 25862, passed 10-17-79) 
CHAPTER 33. - PERSONNEL POLICIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Civil service, Charter §§ 93 through 107. 

DIVISION 1. - DEPARTMENT OF CENTRAL SERVICES 

Sec. 33.01. - Department of Central Services. 
(A)  A Department of Central Services is established. The Department of Central Services consists of a Director, Deputy Director and such other officers and employees as appointed by the City Manager. The Director shall manage and assign the work of the Department of Central Services, subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager. 
(B)  The Department of Central Services is divided into the following divisions: 
(1)  Central Services Director; 
(2)  Information Technology. 
(C)  The Department of Central Services and its divisions shall provide, maintain, and manage an integrated municipal information system and computer services for the city; and perform such other duties as required by the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(D)  Where necessary for the efficient operation of the office, the Director may substitute, reassign, modify or expand the functions of the Department of Central Services, with the advice and consent of the City Manager. 
(E)  The Director shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 31135-11, passed 12-21-11; Am. Ord. 31621-18, passed 2-7-18) 
Secs. 33.02-33.09. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BONDS OF CITY EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 33.10. - Bonds of unclassified employees. 
    The City Commission determines that the following officers and employees in the unclassified service shall be required to give bond in the following amounts: 
(A)  Commissioner as Sinking Fund Trustee ..... $5,000.00 
(B)  City Manager as Sinking Fund Trustee ..... 5,000.00 
(C)  Director of Finance as Sinking Fund Trustee ..... 5,000.00 
(D)  Clerk of the Commission ..... 1,000.00 
(E)  City Manager ..... 5,000.00 
(F)  Secretary to City Manager ..... 1,000.00 
(G)  Director of Law ..... 5,000.00 
(H)  Director of Public Works ..... 5,000.00 
(I)  Secretary to Director of Public Works ..... 1,000.00 
(J)  City Engineer ..... 2,000.00 
(K)  Director of the Department of Water ..... 3,000.00 
(L)  Superintendent of Property Management ..... 1,000.00 
(M)  Superintendent of Street Maintenance ..... 2,000.00 
(N)  Director of Human Resources ..... 5,000.00 
(O)  Superintendent of Human Rehabilitation Center ..... 2,000.00 
(P)  Superintendent of Park Maintenance ..... 1,000.00 
(Q)  Chief of Police ..... 1,000.00 
(R)  Chief of the Department of Fire ..... 1,000.00

(Ord. 12692, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 13098, passed 1-5-27) 
Sec. 33.11. - Bonds of classified employees. 
    The City Manager shall in his discretion determine what city officers and employees in the classified service shall be required to give bond and the amount of bond in each case. He shall make an order containing such information. This order shall be issued to the Director of Finance and it shall be the duty of the Director of Finance forthwith to procure bonds for all such officers and employees. 
(Ord. 12692, passed 12-30-25) 
Sec. 33.12. - Contracts for surety bonds; procedure. 
    Contracts for furnishing surety bonds to the city, bonding the officers and employees thereof required to be under bond shall be let in the following manner: 
(A)  The City Purchasing Agent shall advertise and solicit proposals to furnish such surety bonds by placing a legal notice to that effect in the newspaper with which the city then has a contract for legal advertising, or in a journal published by the city, which notice shall be published once in such newspaper or journal published by the city, not less than one week prior to the opening of such proposals, and, in addition, he may solicit proposals by correspondence or such other means or methods as may be deemed proper and expedient by the City Purchasing Agent. 
(B)  The legal notice to be published pursuant to subsection (A) shall give the place where and the time when bids will be received, and when and where opened, directions as to when and from whom detailed information may be received as to the specifications and conditions, pursuant to which such bids will be received and award made, and for what bond or bonds, the means of determining the amount of the certified check which must accompany each bid, and such other information and instructions as the City Purchasing Agent may determine in order to facilitate and encourage the submission of proposals. 
(C)  Prior to advertising and soliciting proposals, the Director of Finance shall prepare specifications which shall set forth in detail the positions to be bonded; the amount of bond required for each; that proposals will be received for furnishing bonds for such of these positions separately or in groups, or otherwise as may be determined by the Director of Finance; that the bond or bonds shall be in force for a period of three years, beginning on the following December 1; that award will not be made to any company which has not been conducting a general surety bond business continuously during the previous five years, nor to a company not authorized to do business in Ohio, nor to a company not acceptable to and permitted by the United States government to write surety bonds wherein the United States government is the beneficiary; that each company submitting a proposal shall accompany same with a sworn financial statement showing the true financial condition of the company at the close of its previous fiscal year, or any later regular financial statement duly sworn to; that each company (or its agents or agency) specify in detail its facilities for and the kind of service it is in position to render and will render for the benefit and convenience of the city and the Director of Finance and other officers and employees charged with administrative or executive duties incident to such bond or bonds; that each bid must be accompanied by a certified check equivalent to ten percent of the total annual premium upon the bond or bonds bid upon, conditioned to the effect that if awarded any or all of the bonds bid upon, proper bond or bonds, approved by the City Attorney as to form, will be executed and delivered to the Director of Finance ten days prior to the date when the bond becomes effective; that the right to reject any and all bids is reserved; that proposals not submitted upon forms furnished by the purchasing agent may be declared irregular and be rejected; that the City Commission shall have the right to waive any defects or irregularities in proposals if found not prejudicial to the interest of the city; that the award, if made, will be made to the lowest and best bidder, as determined by the City Commission; and that the Director of Finance is authorized to add such further requirements to the specifications as in his judgment may supplement the foregoing or will facilitate the receipt of proposals of a character to give the city the best possible type of protection under the bonds required, or to improve the service rendered in maintaining such bonds in force and effect during the life thereof. The Director of Finance may specify that the several positions to be bonded shall be bonded separately, or in groups, or partly by separate positions, and the remainder in one or more groups, or in such other manner as in his judgment may be preferable or advantageous to the general public interest and welfare. 
(D)  Proposals shall be received to be opened at 12:00 noon, on a convenient date, to be determined by the Director of Finance. 
(E)  Upon opening such proposals, the purchasing agent shall make tabulation and report same, together with all data in his possession, promptly to the Director of Finance, who shall transmit same with recommendations to the City Manager, who shall make report and recommendations to the City Commission, which shall determine whether or not an award shall be made, and to whom, that is, the Commission shall determine the lowest and best bidder or bidders in the event it determines that an award is to be made. 
(Ord. 11839, passed 5-31-23; Am. Ord. 20112, passed 11-1-61) 
Sec. 33.13. - Bond replacement. 
    In the event it becomes necessary to receive proposals for new or additional bonds or for a bond to take the place of a bond then in effect, or which is about to be or has been cancelled, or otherwise rendered ineffective, the provisions of § 33.12 shall apply in all respects, except that the Director of Finance in designating the date for the opening of proposals shall select a date which will allow not less than one week for advertising. 
(Ord. 11839, passed 5-31-23) 
Sec. 33.14. - Custodians of bonds. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the Director of Finance shall be custodian of the official bonds given by all officers and employees of the city. The Clerk of the Commission shall be the custodian of the official bonds given by the Director of Finance, the City Accountant, the City Treasurer, the Director of Finance as a member and Secretary of the Board of Sinking Fund Trustees, the Director of Finance as a member and Secretary of the Treasury Investment Board, the City Treasurer as custodian of the securities belonging to the Treasury Investment Board, and the City Treasurer as custodian of the police and firemen's pension funds. 
(Ord. 14147, passed 1-8-30; Am. Ord. 17436, passed 6-11-52) 
Secs. 33.15-33.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EMPLOYEE ORGANIZATIONS 

Sec. 33.20. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of §§ 33.20 through 33.26 the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively. 
    Confidential employees. Employees, who in the usual course of their duties, have access to confidential information concerning administrative, financial, personnel, or legal matters of the city subject to use by the city in collective bargaining. 
    Director. The Director of Personnel of the city and his senior assistants. 
    Employee. Any person employed by the city, except: 
(1)  The Mayor and members of the Commission; 
(2)  Employees within their probationary period; 
(3)  Part time, other than regular part time, casual, and seasonal employees; 
(4)  Confidential employees, management employees, professional employees and supervisory employees. 
    Employee organization. Any organization in which employees participate and which exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, of dealing with the city in matters concerning wages, hours, fringe benefits, and working conditions and which has registered with the city in accordance with the provisions of § 33.21, or is recognized as an employee organization under the provisions of § 33.22(A). 
    Impasse. The failure of the parties to an existing agreement to achieve agreement 30 days prior to the expiration date thereof, or the failure of the city and an employee organization to reach agreement on an initial agreement within 90 days after negotiations have commenced. 
    Management employee. A department Director, his chief assistant, and other positions as designated from time to time by the City Manager after consultation in good faith with employee representatives. 
    Negotiate. The mutual obligation of the city and the duly authorized representative to negotiate in good faith in order to freely exchange information, opinions, and proposals, and to endeavor to reach agreement on matters within the scope of representation. 
    Professional employee. Any employee engaged in work which is predominantly intellectual, involving the consistent exercise of discretion and judgment in its performance and requiring knowledge of an advance type in a field of science or learning customarily acquired by a prolonged course in an institution of higher learning or a hospital, as distinguished from a general academic education or from an apprenticeship; or an employee who has completed the courses of such specialized intellectual instruction and is performing related work under supervision of a professional person to qualify himself to become a professional employee. 
    Recognized employee organization. An employee organization which has been certified pursuant to the provisions of § 33.21, as representing the employees in a particular representation unit, or is recognized as such under the provisions of § 33.22(A). 
    Representation unit. A unit of city employees established pursuant to the provisions of § 33.22. 
    Supervisory employee. An individual: 
(1)  Whose primary duty consists of the management of the city or of a customarily recognized department or subdivision thereof, and includes the customary and regular direction of the work of two or more other employees therein; or 
(2)  Who does not devote more than 20 percent of his hours of work to activities which are not directly and closely related to the performance of work described in subsection (J)(3), provided, that the requirements of this division shall not apply in the case of an employee who is in sole charge of an independent activity or a physically separated establishment; and 
(3)  Who has some or all of the following responsibilities in the interest of the city: to hire, transfer, suspend, layoff, recall, promote, discharge, assign, reward, or discipline employees, or responsibility to direct them, or to adjust their grievances, or effectively to recommend such action, if in connection with the foregoing the exercise of such authority is not of a merely routine or clerical nature, but requires the use of independent judgment. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.21. - Registration procedure prior to recognition. 
(A)  Employee organizations shall register, in the manner hereinafter set forth, with the Director prior to representing their membership in their employee relations with the city. 
(B)  No employee organization shall exercise any rights under the provisions of §§ 33.20 through 33.26 unless and until it has been registered with the Director. This section shall not apply with respect to a representation unit existing and recognized at the time of passage of §§ 33.20 through 33.26, or to an employee organization recognized as the representative of such unit at the time of passage of these sections. 
(C)  The registration shall consist of: 
(1)  The name and address of the employee organization; 
(2)  A list of the officers and principal representatives of the employee organization with a statement of their authority to bind the employee organization in contractual matters; 
(3)  A statement that the employee organization has, as one of its primary purposes, the function of representing employees in their employee relations with the city; 
(4)  The designation of two or more persons and their addresses to whom notice to the employee organization for any purpose may be given; and 
(5)  A statement that the employee organization has no restriction on membership based on race, color, creed, national origin, sex, or citizenship. 
(D)  Any change in the registration shall be reported in writing to the Director within 30 days of the occurrence of the change. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.22. - Procedures for establishing representation units. 
(A)  The city shall continue to recognize employee organizations which presently represent representation units to the extent that such recognition is not inconsistent with §§ 33.20 through 33.26. 
(B)  Any employee organization desiring to represent employees in a representation unit, or anyone seeking to decertify an employee organization, shall first submit to the Director a petition in such form as the Director may prescribe together with evidence that at least 30 percent of the total number of employees in the proposed representation unit are interested in such representation or decertification. 
(C)  The Director shall recommend the appropriate representation unit or units sought; thereafter, the City Manager shall establish the representation unit or units, subject only to review as set forth in subsection (E). 
(D)  The city shall not include in any representation unit any employee who is excluded from the definition of employee. The City Manager shall initially designate the representation unit which in his opinion will be appropriate for collective bargaining. 
(E)  The final action of the City Manager in determining the appropriate representation unit, or in certifying the results of an election under § 33.23, shall be subject to appeal to an independent arbitrator by any petitioner or intervener in such a proceeding. The appeal must be in writing and must be filed with the City Manager in the form prescribed by him within ten calendar days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays or holidays, of the action appealed from. The independent arbitrator shall be appointed by the American Arbitration Association under its applicable rules. The fees and expenses of the independent arbitrator and of the American Arbitration Association shall be shared equally by the parties involved. The ruling of the independent arbitrator shall not add to, subtract from, or amend any rules or regulations validly adopted pursuant to the provisions of § 33.24. The ruling of the independent arbitrator shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.23. - Certification as a recognized employee organization. 
(A)  If, after reviewing the petition, it appears that a question concerning representation exists, the City Manager shall direct that a secret ballot election be held to ascertain whether a majority of the employees in the appropriate representation unit desire representation. The City Manager shall certify the results of any such valid election. 
(B)  No employee organization will hereafter be recognized for purposes of collective bargaining which has not been certified as the representative of a majority of the employees voting in an appropriate representation unit, except existing recognized employee organizations with respect to representation units described in § 33.22(A). Any employee organization so certified shall be awarded the exclusive right to represent the representation unit for a reasonable period of time (in no case less than two years). No further election shall be held for the duration of any collective bargaining agreement, nor for the first 24 months after certification as a recognized employee organization. 
(C)  If two or more employee organizations seek to represent the same or similar representation units, the City Manager shall direct that a secret ballot election be held in which the competing employee organizations may participate and in which employees in the representation unit shall have the opportunity to vote for any such employee organization, or for no employee organization. If no choice on the ballot has an actual majority, a runoff election between the two highest choices will be conducted. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.24. - Rules and regulations promulgated by City Manager. 
    The City Manager, with the approval of the Commission, shall promulgate appropriate rules and regulations to implement the provisions of §§ 33.20 through 33.26. Such rules and regulations shall be administrative and shall not change, add to, or subtract from the substance of these sections. They shall include appropriate proceedings for certification petitions and decertification petitions by employees, and the conduct of secret ballot elections. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.25. - Impasse resolution; mediation; fact finding Board; arbitration. 
(A)  In the event of an impasse and on the request of the city or an employee organization, the parties shall request the services of a mediator from the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to assist the parties in resolving the dispute. 
(B)  If the mediator certifies to the Commission that the city and the employee organization are unable to reach agreement, the city and the employee organization shall each appoint a member to a fact finding Board. The two members so appointed shall mutually agree upon the third member, who shall be disinterested in the dispute and representative of the public. If for any reason the public member is not appointed promptly, such member shall be appointed through the procedures established by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. 
(C)  The fact-finding Board shall investigate and determine the facts surrounding the dispute, and, within 30 days after appointment, report its findings of fact and recommendations to the Commission, the City Manager, and to the employee organization. This Board may submit majority and dissenting findings and recommendations, if appropriate. During the Board's appointment and work, the city and the employee organization in the dispute shall be under an obligation to cooperate with the Board and continue to negotiate for the purposes of resolving the dispute. 
(D)  If this dispute remains unresolved for 45 days following the submission of the Board's findings and recommendations, the findings and recommendations shall be considered by the Commission, and, upon a majority vote, the Commission will render a decision in the dispute at a regular meeting. The Clerk of the Commission shall notify the employee organization of the decision in writing. 
(E)  The decision of the Commission shall be final unless within ten days following receipt of such notice by the employee organization either the City Manager or the employee organization files a written protest with the Clerk of the Commission. The matter shall thereupon be resolved by advisory arbitration as set forth in subsection (F). However, upon the agreement of the employee organization and the vote of a majority of the Commission, all or any part of such arbitration may be authorized as final and binding on the parties. 
(F)  The city and the employee organization may mutually agree upon an arbitrator, or a joint letter requesting the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to submit the names of five arbitrators will be signed and mailed by the city and the employee organization. Upon receipt of such names, the city and the employee organization shall alternately cross off one name until one name remains, that person being selected as the arbitrator. A date for arbitration shall be set as soon as possible in accordance with the wishes of the city and the employee organization and the availability of the arbitrator. Both the city and the employee organization shall share equally the expenses and fees of the arbitrator and other expenses incident to the arbitration hearing. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.26. - Construction of sections 33.20 through 33.25. 
(A)  Nothing in §§ 33.20 through 33.25, shall be construed to deny any person, organization, employee or employer any rights granted by federal or state law, or local ordinance or the Charter. 
(B)  Subject to the limitations pertaining to employees and representation units contained in §§ 33.20 through 33.26, nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit two or more employee organizations from acting jointly, as a single organization, to register, to petition for a representation unit, or to petition for certification as a recognized employee organization, and if certified, to represent the employees within the representation unit. 
(Ord. 24262, passed 4-12-72) 
Secs. 33.27-33.29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STRIKES AGAINST CITY 

Sec. 33.30. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of §§ 33.30 through 33.36 the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively. 
    Employee. Any person holding a position by appointment or employment in the government of the city. 
    Employee organization. Any organization in which employees participate and which exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, of dealing with the city in matters concerning wages, hours, fringe benefits or working conditions. 
    Strike.
