The failure to report for duty, the willful absence from one's position, the stoppage of work, or the abstinence in whole or in part from the full, faithful, and proper performance of the duties of employment, for the purpose of inducing, influencing, or coercing a change in the conditions, compensation, rights, privileges, or obligations of employment, or of intimidating, coercing, or unlawfully influencing others from remaining in or from assuming such public employment. Such actions do not limit, impair, or affect the right of any employee to the expression or communication of a view, grievance, complaint, or opinion on any matter related to the conditions or compensation of public employment or their betterment, so long as such expression or communication is not designed to and does not interfere with the full, faithful, and proper performance of the duties of employment. 
(Ord. 24223, passed 2-16-72; Am. Ord. 24260, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.31. - Strike by employees against city prohibited. 
(A)  No employee shall engage in a strike against the city. 
(B)  No person exercising any authority, supervision, or direction over any employee shall have the power to authorize, approve, or consent to a strike by one or more employees, and such person shall not authorize, approve or consent to such strike. 
(Ord. 24223, passed 2-16-72) 
State Law reference- Strikes by public employees, R.C. Chapter 4107. 
Sec. 33.32. - Suspension of striking employee; notice; hearing. 
    Any employee who, without the approval of his superior, unlawfully fails to report for duty, absents himself from his position, or abstains in whole or in part from full, faithful, and proper performance of his duties for the purpose of inducing, influencing, or coercing a change in the conditions, compensation, rights, privileges, or obligations of employment or of intimidating, coercing, or unlawfully influencing others from remaining in or from assuming such employment shall be considered on strike. The employee shall be sent a notice by his Director, or the City Manager, addressed to his residence as set forth in his employment record, that he is on strike and is suspended without pay. The employee may request and subsequently be entitled to establish that he did not violate § 33.31. 
    This request must be filed in writing, with his Director, or the City Manager, within ten calendar days after regular compensation of such employee has ceased. In the event of such request, the employee's Director shall, within ten calendar days of receipt of such request, commence a proceeding for the determination of whether these sections have been violated by such employee. Such proceeding shall be undertaken without unnecessary delay. The employee shall have the right to appeal the decision of the Director or the City Manager to the Civil Service Board in accordance with that Board's rules and regulations. 
(Ord. 24223, passed 2-16-72; Am. Ord. 24260, passed 4-12-72) 
Sec. 33.33. - Failure to request hearing. 
    If the employee does not timely file the request as provided for in § 33.32, or, if after having filed said request, fails to establish that he did not violate § 33.31, he shall thereby be considered to have abandoned and terminated his appointment or employment and shall no longer hold such position, or be entitled to any of the rights or emoluments thereof. 
(Ord. 24223, passed 2-16-72) 
Sec. 33.34. - Reinstatement. 
    A person who has violated § 33.31, and has been thereby terminated from his employment with the city may, subject to the civil service rules and regulations, be appointed, or reappointed, employed, or re-employed, as an employee but only upon the following conditions: 
(A)  His compensation shall in no event exceed that received by him immediately prior to the time of such violation; 
(B)  His compensation shall not be increased until after the expiration of one year from such appointment or reappointment, employment or re-employment; 
(C)  The person shall be on probation for a period of two years following such appointment or reappointment, employment, or re-employment, during which period he shall serve without tenure and at the pleasure of the appointing or employing officer or body. 
(Ord. 24223, passed 2-16-72) 
Sec. 33.35. - Strike by employee organizations against city prohibited. 
(A)  No employee organization shall engage in, cause, instigate, encourage, or condone a strike against the city. 
(B)  In determining whether an employee organization has engaged in a strike against the city in violation of §§ 33.30 through 33.35, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  Whether the employee organization called the strike or made a good faith effort to prevent it; 
(2)  Whether the employee organization made or was making good faith efforts to terminate the strike. 
(Ord. 24224, passed 2-16-72; Am. Ord. 24261, passed 4-12-72) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 33.99. 
Secs. 33.36-33.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 33.40. - Method of determining city employees' salaries. 
    Except for the salaries of the members of the City Commission, which are fixed by the Charter, and the salaries of other officers and employees which are fixed by law or must be fixed by the City Commission by ordinance, the salaries or other rates of compensation of all officers and employees of the city shall be at such rates and in such amounts as may be fixed by the City Manager, acting in conformity with rules and regulations of the Civil Service Board. However, the total of all such salaries fixed for a department of the city shall not be in excess of the total amount appropriated for salaries in that particular department as such appropriation is set forth, and fixed in the annual appropriation ordinance and all amendments or supplements thereto. The City Manager may change the salary or wage of any employee in the classified civil service at any time during a fiscal year if in his discretion it is for the good of the service, fair and proper, or necessary that such change be made, to apply during or for any part of the remainder of the fiscal year. Likewise, the City Manager shall have power to change the salary of any division head or secretary in any department during the course of, or within any fiscal year. Changes so made by the City Manager shall become operative as of or upon the date specified by him in the order issued for the purpose thereof, copies of which order shall be transmitted to the head of the department in which the officer or employee affected is engaged, to the Director of Finance and to the Civil Service Board. 
(Ord. 12711, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 14633, passed 4-16-32) 
Sec. 33.41. - Residence requirements for Directors and other officers. 
    Directors and other officers of the city must be citizens of the United States at the time of their appointment, but, unless otherwise provided by the Charter, need not be electors either of the city or the state. 
(Ord. 17569, passed 11-19-52) 
Sec. 33.42. - Leave of absence; military service. 
    All city employees, who are members of the Ohio National Guard, the Ohio Defense Corps, the Ohio Naval Militia, or other reserve components of the armed forces of the United States, shall be entitled to leaves of absence from their respective duties for such time as they are in the military service on field training or active duty for periods not to exceed 31 days in any one calendar year. If a city employee's military pay during such a period of leave of absence is less than his city pay would have been for such period, he shall be paid by the city the difference between the city pay and his military pay for such period. In determining employee's military pay for the purpose of this section, allowances for travel, food, or housing shall not be considered, but any other pay or allowances of whatever nature, including longevity pay, shall be considered. 
(Ord. 19292, passed 5-6-59) 
Sec. 33.43. - Notaries public; expenditures; reimbursement to city. 
(A)  All members of the Department of Police who shall be required to be commissioned and serve as notaries public for the city shall, upon presenting the proper vouchers covering the cost of application, bond, filing, and recording fees which vouchers must be to the satisfaction of and approved by the Director of Finance, be paid an amount of money equal to the expenditures so approved. 
(B)  All members of the Department of Police hereafter qualified and commissioned as notaries public shall, upon termination of their employment with the city, reimburse the city for the unexpired term of their notary public commission on the basis of 1/36 of the original amount expended by the city for each month remaining of the Commission. 
(Ord. 17227, passed 10-10-51; Am. Ord. 17262, passed 11-28-51) 
Sec. 33.44. - Job-related or degree-related courses; reimbursement by city. 
    Training or educational courses that are job-related or degree-related may be reimbursed by the city upon successful completion of such courses in accordance with the following conditions: 
(A)  Such training or educational courses shall be attended at an approved or accredited college, university, secondary school, or technical institute, business institute, or related educational institute or school. 
(B)  Requests for reimbursement must be approved by the Director of Human Resources or a designee prior to commencing the desired training. 
(C)  Job-related courses are defined as those courses which are directly and specifically related to the employee's present job duties. Degree-related courses are defined as those courses which are required to complete an undergraduate or graduate degree specifically designated by the city as a "critical need", with such designation to be reviewed on a regular basis. 
(Ord. 23141, passed 10-9-68; Am. Ord. 25092, passed 4-7-76; Am. Ord. 26562, passed 7-28-82; Am. Ord. 27025, passed 7-3-84; Am. Ord. 29181-96, passed 3-13-96) 
Sec. 33.45. - Achievement required for reimbursement. 
(A)  The city will reimburse permanent full-time and permanent part-time employees' tuition, enrollment, and laboratory fees after the successful completion of each course providing the employee receives a satisfactory grade. 
(B)  Noncredit courses or institutes will be reimbursed for enrollment fees based upon evidence of satisfactory completion. 
(Ord. 23141, passed 10-9-68; Am. Ord. 25092, passed 4-7-76; Am. Ord. 26562, passed 7-28-82; Am. Ord. 29181-96, passed 3-13-96) 
Sec. 33.46. - Criteria required for reimbursement. 
    Criteria for acceptance under the tuition refund plan shall include one or more of the following: application filing date; availability of funds; and needs of the individual and the city. 
(Ord. 23141, passed 10-9-68; Am. Ord. 25092, passed 4-7-76; Am. Ord. 26562, passed 7-28-82) 
Sec. 33.47. - Obligation to remain on city payroll. 
(A)  An employee who terminates employment with the city within two years after completing a course under the tuition reimbursement program shall refund to the city all money received for courses taken within two calendar years of the employee's termination date. 
(B)  The amount to be refunded may be withheld from any termination pay due such employee. Employees whose services are terminated by the city will not be required to make such refunds. 
(Ord. 23141, passed 10-9-68; Am. Ord. 25092, passed 4-7-76; Am. Ord. 26562, passed 7-28-82; Am. Ord. 27025, passed 7-3-84; Am. Ord. 29181-96, passed 3-13-96) 
Sec. 33.48. - Termination of tuition reimbursement program. 
    The tuition reimbursement program authorized in §§ 33.44, 33.47, and 33.48 will terminate three years from the effective date of this ordinance unless renewed by formal action of the City Commission. 
(Ord. 25092, passed 4-7-76; Am. Ord. 26562, passed 7-28-82; Am. Ord. 27025, passed 7-3-84) 
Sec. 33.49. - Payroll deduction for United Appeal. 
    The Director of Finance is authorized to make payroll deductions from the salary or wage of any public officer or employee of the city for contributions to the Dayton United Appeal. Any public officer or employee desiring to have such deductions made shall file a written request and authorization, signed by the public officer or employee, with the Director of Finance specifying the amount of the deduction to be made. The authorization may be withdrawn in writing by any such public officer or employee at any time. No funds may be withheld from the salary or wage of any public officer or employee for such contribution unless the withholding is specifically, freely and voluntarily authorized by the public officer or employee in writing. 
(Ord. 18849, passed 10-2-57) 
Sec. 33.50. - United Appeal deduction at employee's request. 
    Upon receipt of evidence of such request by the Director of Finance, the Director of Finance is authorized to make the specified payroll deductions authorized by § 33.49. No deductions of less than $0.25 per month shall be made. The Director of Finance shall remit to the Dayton United Appeal the total amount of such deductions not later than the tenth of the month following the month in which such deductions were made. 
(Ord. 18849, passed 10-2-57) 
Sec. 33.51. - Appeals pertaining to residency. 
    Any adverse employment action based upon a violation of the residency requirement set forth in Section 102 of the Charter shall only be appealed to the Civil Service Board. 
(Ord. 30596-06, passed 9-27-06) 
Sec. 33.52. - Sick leave donation. 
    Any city employee whose salary or compensation is fixed by the Commission or the City Manager pursuant to Section 161 of the Charter may, if he or she desires, permanently contribute up to sixteen sick leave hourly credits in any one year period to the Sick Leave Donation Program to help employees who are terminally ill and/or have a catastrophic illness or injury. 
(Ord. 30909-09, passed 8-26-09) 
Secs. 33.53-33.59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CLASSIFICATIONS, SALARY, AND WAGE SCHEDULES 

Sec. 33.60. - Classifications, salary, and wage schedules. 
    Ordinances dealing with classifications, wages, salaries, fringe benefits, etc. are separately maintained. Current copies are on file and open to public inspection at the office of the Clerk of the Commission. 
Secs. 33.61-33.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 33.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any employee organization which violates § 33.35, shall be fined not more than $250.00 for each violation. Each day or part of a day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(B)  Any fine levied under this section against an employee organization shall be enforceable only against the employee organization as an entity and against its assets and is not enforceable against any employee as an individual or his assets. 
(Ord. 24224, passed 2-16-72; Am. Ord. 24261, passed 4-12-72) 
CHAPTER 34. - DEPARTMENT OF POLICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 31126-11, § 1, passed December 21, 2011, amended the title of Ch. 34 to read as herein set out. Formerly, Ch. 34 was entitled "Police Department." 

DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 34.01. - Department of Police. 
(A)  The Department of Police is established. The Department of Police consists of a Director, functioning as a Chief of Police; a Deputy Director, functioning as an Assistant Chief of Police; and such other officers and employees as appointed by the City Manager. The Director shall manage and assign the work of the Department of Police, subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager. A Chief of Staff, functioning as a Division Head, shall manage the day-to-day operations of the Office of the Chief of Police. 
(B)  The Department of Police is divided into the following divisions: 
(1)  The Office of the Chief of Police. 
(2)  Investigations and Administrative Services. 
(3)  Central Patrol Operations. 
(4)  West Patrol Operations. 
(5)  East Patrol Operations. 
(C)  The Department of Police shall provide law enforcement and such other duties and services as required by the Charter, ordinances of the City, Constitution and laws of the State of Ohio, and the Constitution and laws of the United States of America. 
(D)  Where necessary for the efficient operations of the Department of Police, the Chief of Police may reassign or expand the functions of the various divisions, with the advice and consent of the City Manager. 
(E)  The Chief, the Assistant Chief of Police and the heads of the divisions above, shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 17851, passed 12-2-53; Am. Ord. 23742, passed 6-18-70; Am. Ord. 27335, passed 1-29-86; Am. Ord. 27683, passed 12-9-87; Am. Ord. 28786-94, passed 1-19-94; Am. Ord. 29008-95, passed 5-3-95; Am. Ord. 29049-95, passed 8-2-95; Am. Ord. 29611-98, passed 9-30-98; Am. Ord. 29844-00, passed 7-26-00; Am. Ord. 30095-02, passed 5-1-02; Am. Ord. 31017-10, passed 9-15-10) 
Sec. 34.02. - Surrender of badges. 
    Any police officer, upon resignation, discharge, dismissal, or retirement on pension, or on ceasing to be a member of the department in any manner whatever, shall surrender the regular police officer's badge. It is the duty of the Director and Chief of Police to receive all badges so surrendered by police officers, and to see that badges are surrendered as provided in this section. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.03. - Badge of retired police officer. 
    Every police officer who has been or hereafter may be honorably retired from the Police Department and placed on pension shall be entitled to a badge indicating said retirement. However, the retired member shall first surrender the regular police officer's badge to the Director and Chief of Police. The badge intended for retired officers shall be of such design and material as the Director and Chief of Police determines. The badge shall display on its face, in plain letters, the word "retired." 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.04. - Forfeiting badges. 
    A retired police officer who received a badge pursuant to any previous or current sections of the Revised Code of General Ordinances shall be entitled to the possession and the privilege of wearing such badge during good behavior, but on conviction of the violation of any law or ordinance, or being found guilty after a hearing before the Director and Chief of Police of any conduct unbecoming an officer, or which is subversive of the discipline in the Department of Police, or of bad example to the officers on active duty in the department, such badge shall be surrendered to the Director and Chief of Police, whose duty it is to see that the retired member's badge is received promptly thereafter from the retired member. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.05. - Badge of deceased member. 
    It is the duty of the Director and Chief of Police to see that a Police Department's badge in the possession of either an active or retired member is surrendered promptly upon the death of such member. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.06. - Position of parking and traffic enforcement aide established. 
    The position of parking and traffic enforcement aide is established in the Department of Police. Parking and traffic enforcement aides shall be under the control of the Director and Chief of Police and shall wear a prescribed uniform while in the performance of their duties, but shall not be police officers. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.07. - Duties of parking and traffic enforcement aides. 
    Parking and traffic enforcement aides are authorized to perform the following duties: 
(A)  Issue tickets for the violation of parking and nonmoving traffic ordinances or regulations of the city. 
(B)  Order the tow-away and impounding of vehicles in violation of parking and nonmoving traffic ordinances and regulations. Any vehicles so impounded may be released in the manner provided in the Code. 
(C)  Assume traffic posts at intersections or other locations as necessary to direct traffic. 
(D)  Report hazards and potential crime conditions which need attention to the proper authorities. 
(E)  Assist the general public in proper parking and traffic procedures, and dispense information in assigned areas. 
(F)  Perform such other duties as may be determined by the Director and Chief of Police, consistent with and incidental to the foregoing duties. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.08. - Training of parking and traffic enforcement aides. 
    Parking and traffic enforcement aides shall complete a course of training as determined by the Director and Chief of Police before assuming the performance of their duties on the street. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Secs. 34.09-34.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 31126-11, passed 12-21-11, repealed §§ Div. 2, 34-20-34.28, which pertained to human rehabilitation center and derived from Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95. 

Secs. 34.20-34.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITIZENS APPEAL BOARD 

Sec. 34.40. - Membership of the Citizens Appeal Board. 
(A)  The Citizens Appeal Board shall be constituted of five voting members who shall be appointed by the Commission. The Community Police Council may nominate a person to fill any vacancy on the Board by informing the Commission of its nominee within 30 days after a vacancy occurs; however, the Commission may reject any such nomination and appoint a person not nominated by the Council. The members of the Board shall be citizens of the city and of notable knowledge, experience and upstanding community standing. Prior to sitting on the Board, each member shall receive all necessary training. Any person with a criminal conviction shall be ineligible for membership on the Board. All members shall serve without compensation. One member shall be a former member of the legal community. A second member shall be a former peace officer. The remaining three members shall be selected from among members of the community. The five voting members of the Board shall fairly represent the racial mix of the city, shall have a balanced representation of both females and males, and shall also reflect a fair representation of the various geographical areas of the city. 
(B)  Additionally, the Executive Director of the Human Relations Council, the City Manager or a designee, and the Director and Chief of Police shall serve as ex-officio nonvoting members of the Board. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31333-14, passed 9-10-14; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.41. - Term of office. 
    The voting members of the Citizens Appeal Board shall serve for terms of two years. Members of the board serving at the time of amendment to this section shall serve until expiration of the terms for which they were appointed. All voting members of the board shall continue to serve until their successors have been appointed. Voting members of the board may be re-appointed by the Commission to serve an additional term. However, no such member may serve more than three consecutive terms. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31333-14, passed 9-10-14) 
Sec. 34.42. - Removals and vacancies. 
(A)  Any voting member of the Citizens Appeal Board may be removed for incompetence, neglect of duty, misconduct or malfeasance, by the Commission, either of its own initiative and/or at its discretion upon recommendation of a majority of voting members of the board. 
(B)  Voting members of the board may be removed from office for missing two consecutive meetings of the board without appropriate excuses delivered to the chair of the board within a reasonable period of time. Any vacancy occasioned by resignation, death, or removal of a member shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the Commission. Any such replacement shall be appointed within 30 days of the date when the vacancy occurred. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31333-14, passed 9-10-14) 
Sec. 34.43. - Chairmanship of the Board. 
    At the first meeting of the Citizens Appeal Board, the members thereof shall elect a chairperson from among themselves. Thereafter, a new chairperson shall be elected every two years at the meeting of the Board falling closest to the previous chairperson's election date. The chairperson may serve up to two terms. The chairperson shall communicate all of the business of the Board directly to the Commission. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.44. - Quorum. 
    Three members present shall constitute a quorum for purposes of conducting the business of the Citizens Appeal Board. However, a majority vote of five voting members, to-wit: three votes, is required for any action to be taken. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.45. - Conflicts of interest. 
    Should a matter come before the Citizens Appeal Board in which a member of the Board feels that his or her personal interests may influence his or her ability to hear an issue or case in an impartial manner, that member shall abstain from participating therein, including hearing and/or discussing the particular matter. The Board member shall indicate to the chairperson the existence and nature of the conflict, and thereafter that Board member will be excused from hearing and/or participating in the matter. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.46. - Meetings of the Board. 
(A)  The Citizens Appeal Board shall meet once each calendar quarter at a regularly scheduled time and place, with more frequent meetings to be scheduled at the request of the chairperson and/or Commission if necessary to carry on the Board's business. The meetings shall be for the purpose of conducting hearings and/or to conduct any other business necessary to the operation of the Board. The Board may also meet outside their quarterly meetings in order to review evidence in appeals cases before testimony is presented during the formal hearing(s). Quarterly meetings will include briefings by the Professional Standards Bureau. The Board may have access to the entire Professional Standards Bureau file(s) in any case on which the Board is being briefed by the Professional Standards Bureau and/or any case that is pending before the Board on an appeal. Subject to Ohio Revised Code §149.43, the Board also may have access to any closed files reviewed by the Professional Standards Bureau for the purpose of examining the nature, types, and dispositions of complaints made by citizens and also for the purpose of conducting quality assurance. 
(B)  Whenever the Board is dealing with personnel matters, meetings will be closed to the public. However, at the Board's option, meetings can be open for the purpose of receiving input and discussing other police policies and procedures. Nevertheless, the hearings proper shall be open to the public. 
(C)  Members of the Board shall respect the confidential nature of the Board's proceedings and shall not disclose any matter discussed during the meetings with any individual outside the Board membership, except as authorized by ordinance. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 28789-94, passed 2-2-94; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.47. - Function of the Board. 
(A)  The Citizens Appeal Board shall have three basic functions: to hear appeals; to hear, on a quarterly basis, reports from the Dayton Police Department regarding cases under investigation; and to review policies and procedures and make recommendations as directed by the City Manager or the Director and Chief of Police. 
(B)  The Board, with the assistance of staff, may adopt procedures, policies and rules governing its operations, not inconsistent with ordinance, with the approval of the Commission. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.48. - What can be appealed. 
(A)  Citizens who are dissatisfied with the findings of the Dayton Police Department investigation, whether they relate to sworn or unsworn personnel, may appeal their complaint to the Citizens Appeal Board. 
(B)  Because discipline is a personnel matter which lies within the sole discretion of the Director and Chief of Police, the nature of the disciplinary action received by an employee is not appealable to the Board. 
(C)  The Board may also refuse to hear an appeal if in its sound judgment the appeal is without sufficient grounds. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.49. - Legal advisor. 
    The Citizens Appeal Board shall be served by a legal advisor for each appeal, furnished from a pool of advisors retained on contract to provide this service. The function of the advisor shall be to review the facts of the case, and to assist the Board in reaching fact-based conclusions in accordance with law, rules of evidence and contractual obligations. The standard of review to be used by the Board shall be by a preponderance of evidence. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.50. - Review appeal process. 
(A)  Appeals shall be made in writing on forms provided by the Citizens Appeal Board. The forms will be available at, but not limited to, the Board's office, the Human Relations Council, the Professional Standards Bureau, the Safety Building, and the City Manager's office. An appeal form will also be mailed with the letter which informs the complainants of the findings of the investigation of the their original complaint. 
(B)  The appeals forms will be reviewed for sufficiency and completeness. Complainants filing insufficient appeals will be notified by the Board's chair within ten days after the next regular meeting of the Board. 
(C)  Hearings shall be scheduled during the Board's regular quarterly meetings, or at another time agreed upon by the Board or as directed by the Commission. The complainant will sign a formal affidavit prior to the hearing. The complainant will be notified of the Board's meeting time when the appeal is scheduled and may elect to furnish testimony to the Board. Testimony shall be given under oath. Board hearings shall be tape-recorded and tapes shall be maintained in the Board's office. 
(D)  The employees of the Department of Police against whom the complaint is made will be invited to give voluntary testimony to the Board during the appeal hearing. The Board is hereby empowered to, and may at its sole discretion, issue subpoenas for witnesses to the incident. 
(E)  In making its determinations, the Board may or may not concur with the findings of the Dayton Police Department. If the Board does not concur, it may do so with a finding that the complaint should have been sustained, exonerated, or unfounded. 
(F)  A complaint is sustained when the investigation discloses evidence indicating the accused employee has committed all or part of the alleged act(s). A complaint is not sustained when the investigation discloses insufficient evidence to clearly prove or disprove the allegations made. A complaint is exonerated when the investigation indicates that the act did occur, but that it was justified, lawful and proper. A complaint is unfounded when the investigation establishes that the acts complained of did not occur. 
(G)  No action of the Board may affect discipline given as a result of the Dayton Police Department findings in the original complaint. However, while reviewing any appeal before the formal hearing, the Board may request additional information or investigation by the Dayton Police Department. 
(Ord. 28179, passed 9-19-90; Am. Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.51. - Decisions of the Board. 
    The decisions of the Citizens Appeal Board shall be presented in writing to the Commission. The decisions shall contain the Board's findings in each matter considered, along with a summary of the Board's reasoning of the decisions made. Those reports shall be a matter of public record. The Board shall also submit an annual report of its operations to the Commission, which report shall include any recommendations(s) for improving the functions of the Board or any related operations. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
Sec. 34.52. - Communication with the complainants. 
    Decisions of the Citizens Appeal Board shall be mailed to the complainants no later than ten working days following the date when the Board members sign the final decision. 
(Ord. 29072-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 34.53 - Responsibilities of the Executive Director of the Human Relations Council. 
    The authority and responsibility for the execution of the policies of the Citizens Appeal Board is hereby conferred upon the Executive Director of the Human Relations Council. The Executive Director shall be responsible, subject to § 32.19, for the recruitment, selection, training, and supervision of the professional and clerical staff that provide support to the Board. 
(Am. Ord. 31554-17, passed 3-15-17) 
CHAPTER 35. - CONTRACTS 
DIVISION 1. - ADVERTISING CONTRACTS OF CITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 31168-12, §§ 1-3, passed May 9, 2012, amended division 1 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former division 1, §§ 35.01-35.03, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. 11008, passed 11-5-19; Ord. 15990, passed 12-12-45; Am. Ord. 23852, passed 11-11-70. 
Charter reference- Contracts for public advertising, see Charter § 89. 
Cross reference- Municipal journal, see § 30.20 et seq. 

Sec. 35.01. - Legal advertising and publication. 
    All public advertising or publication necessary under the provisions of the Charter or provided for by ordinance or resolution of the Commission in pursuance thereof, shall be published either in a daily newspaper of general circulation within the city to be selected as hereinafter set forth, or posted electronically on a centralized Internet website designated by the city for this purpose. 
(Ord. 31168-12, § 1, 5-9-12) 
Sec. 35.02. - Bids for advertising. 
    The purchasing agent may invite proposals in writing from all the daily newspapers printed in the English language in the city for the publication of all the public advertising and publication during the ensuing year. The proposals must be received by the purchasing agent at his office at such time as he may determine. 
(Ord. 31168-12, § 2, 5-9-12) 
Sec. 35.03. - Contract specifications. 
    Every proposal solicited pursuant to § 35.02 shall offer to enter into a contract in writing with the city for the publication of all the legal advertising and publication of the city for the next ensuing calendar year at a fixed price per agate line, set in a column of at least 11 picas six ems in width, or any fractional part of such line of publication, by use of a type not less than five point nor more than six point in size, set solid, to be used in printing such advertising and publication, and shall be accompanied by a specimen or printing made by using the same type which the bidder proposed to use in the publication of the legal advertising or publication. 
(Ord. 31168-12, § 3, 5-9-12) 
Secs. 35.04-35.09. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTS 

Sec. 35.10. - Public works contracts to comply with §§ 35.10 through 35.23. 
    All contracts for public work, unless otherwise provided herein, or unless the Commission shall otherwise direct, shall be let, executed, and performed in compliance with §§ 35.10 through 35.23. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14) 
Sec. 35.11. - Advertisement for bids. 
    When plans, specifications, estimates, and profiles, where any are necessary, shall have been prepared for the work, the Director of the department having such work shall cause an advertisement for bids for such work to be published for not less than two nor more than four consecutive weeks in the newspaper with which the city has a contract for all public advertising, on all contracts where such estimates amount to more than $2,500.00. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14; Am. Ord. 23026, passed 7-10-68; Am. Ord. 26421, passed 12-30-81) 
Sec. 35.12. - Check or bond to accompany bids. 
    The bids shall be opened by the Director of the department in charge of the work and publicly read by him on the last day for filing such bids and at the time designated by him for so doing. Each bid shall contain the full name of every person or company interested in it, and shall be accompanied by a certified check on a solvent bank, payable to the order of the city, or a bond with sureties approved by the Director, or by bonds issued by the United States or by the city in an amount to be fixed by the Director not to exceed ten percent of the amount of such bid, to indemnify the city against loss by reason of the failure of the bidder to enter into and properly secure the performance of a contract for the work, if such contract shall be awarded to him. If a certified check or bonds are deposited with the bid, the Director shall turn the same over to the city treasurer to be collected or sold and the proceeds passed to the credit of the fund from which the cost of such improvement shall be payable, if the bidder fails to enter into the contract and properly secure the performance of the same within five days after being advised that the contract is ready for signature. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14; Am. Ord. 22848, passed 2-14-68) 
Sec. 35.13. - Contract awarding procedure. 
(A)  Unless the Director of the department in charge of the work rejects all the bids, he shall certify which is the lowest and best bid and transmit the proceedings to the City Manager, who, if he approves the making of a contract upon such bid, shall transmit the proceedings to the City Attorney. In determining which is the lowest and best bid, the Director shall give consideration to the affirmative action program submitted in accordance with § 35.16 with particular attention to the probable effectiveness of such program in insuring minority group representation in all trades and all phases of the bidder's operation. The Director shall further give consideration to whether the bidder qualifies for the provisions of §§ 35.30 through 35.68. 
(B)  The City Attorney shall examine the proceedings, and if he finds the same correct in form shall prepare an appropriate contract and bond, and certify his approval of the form thereof, and return all papers to the City Manager. The City Manager shall present the contract to the Director of Finance, who, if the money is in the treasury to the credit of the fund from which it is to be drawn, and not appropriated for any other purpose, shall so certify in writing. Thereupon, the City Manager shall report the contract to the Commission for its approval. If the Commission approves the making of the contract, the Clerk of the Commission shall so certify and the contract shall be returned to the Director of the department in charge of the work, who shall enter into the contract on behalf of the city. If the City Manager or the Commission disapproves the making of any contract, the papers shall be returned to the Director, with such directions as to further proceedings as he, or it, shall think proper. No contract shall be binding upon the city until signed by the Director on behalf of the city and by the contractor, and the contractor shall have given bond with surety to be approved by the Director in such amount as the Director may specify, in no event to be less than 25 percent of the amount to be paid under the contract, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the contract and the full payment of all claims of subcontractors, material suppliers, laborers, and employees of such contractor, on account of the work covered by such contracts; or in lieu of the bond the contractor may submit in like amount consideration as specified or acceptable to the Director. 
    The Director may waive the requirement of a bond for up to an aggregate amount of $75,000.00 in any contract. If the contract is one to be awarded pursuant to §§ 35.30 through 35.68, the Director may, pursuant to guidelines established by or otherwise with the consent of the Procurement Enhancement Review Board, waive the requirement of a bond in an aggregate amount not to exceed $200,000.00 per contract. The action of the Commission upon all such contracts shall be by yea and nay vote, to be entered upon its minutes, but not published as an ordinance or resolution. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14; Am. Ord. 25270, passed 4-6-77; Am. Ord. 25390, passed 10-5-77; Am. Ord. 26085, passed 10-1-80; Am. Ord. 27534, passed 3-25-87; Am. Ord. 28528, passed 4-8-92) 
Sec. 35.14. - Equal employment opportunity provisions required. 
    The Human Relations Council shall, in its policies and procedures, adopt a policy declaring a threshold dollar amount of expenditure of City of Dayton funds requiring inclusion of equal employment opportunity language. All contracts entered into by the city involving the expenditure of funds which meet or exceed that threshold dollar amount shall incorporate equal opportunity clauses, which shall read as follows: 
(A)  The contractor or vendor shall not discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment because of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. The contractor or vendor shall take affirmative action in accordance with the terms outlined in its proposal and the provisions of this contract to insure that applicants are employed, and that employees are treated during employment, without regard to their race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. Such action shall include, but not be limited to, the following: employment, upgrading, demotion or transfer; recruitment or recruitment advertising; layoff or termination; rates of pay or other forms of compensation; and selection for training, including apprenticeship. The contractor or vendor agrees to post in conspicuous places, available to employees and applicants, notices to be provided by the city setting forth the provisions of the nondiscrimination clauses. 
(B)  The contractor or vendor shall in all solicitations or advertisements for employees placed by or on behalf of the contractor or vendor, state that all qualified applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(C)  The contractor or vendor shall send to each labor union or representative of workers with which he has a collective bargaining agreement or other contract or understanding, a notice to be provided by the city advising the labor union or workers' representative of the contractor's or vendor's commitments, and shall post copies of the notice in conspicuous places available to employees and applicants for employment. 
(D)  The contractor or vendor shall comply with all rules, regulations, and relevant orders promulgated by the Human Relations Council pursuant to its duties created by ordinance. 
(E)  The contractor or vendor shall file, and shall cause each of his subcontractors and material suppliers to file, compliance reports with the Human Relations Council as may be directed. Compliance reports shall be filed within such times and shall contain such information as to the practices, policies, programs, and employment policies, programs and employment statistics of the contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor and shall be in such form as the Human Relations Council may prescribe. 
(F)  The contractor or vendor shall furnish all information and reports required by this contract and by the rules, regulations, and orders of the Human Relations Council pursuant hereto, and shall permit reasonable access to his books, records, and accounts by the Human Relations Council or its representative, as necessary for purposes of investigation to ascertain compliance with this contract and rules, regulations and orders. 
(G)  In the event of the contractor's or vendor's failure to comply with the equal employment opportunity and affirmative action provisions of this contract, including the affirmative action undertaking outlined in its proposal, or with any of the rules, regulations, or orders herein referred to, it is agreed that the city, at its option, may do any or all of the following: 
(1)  Cancel, terminate, or suspend this contract, in whole or in part, except if this contract constitutes a lease of real estate for a period exceeding three years. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the city from enforcing the terms and conditions of any such lease by injunction or other appropriate relief. 
(2)  Declare the contractor or vendor ineligible for further city contracts. 
(3)  Recover from the contractor or vendor by set-off against the unpaid portion of the contract price, or otherwise pursuant to this contract, the sum of $50.00 per day, as liquidated damages and not as a penalty, for each day that the contractor or vendor shall fail to comply with these provisions of the contract, as determined by the Human Relations Council in accordance with its rules and regulations, the said sum being fixed and agreed upon by and between the contractor and the city because of the impracticability and extreme difficulty of fixing and ascertaining the actual damages which the city would sustain in the event of such a breach of contract, and that amount is agreed to be the amount of damages which the city would sustain. 
(4)  Impose such other sanctions as may be imposed by the Human Relations Council pursuant to ordinances passed by the Commission, or seek such other remedies as may be provided by law. 
(H)  The contractor or vendor shall include the provisions of this contract in every subcontract, so that such provisions shall be binding upon each subcontractor. The contractor or vendor shall take such action with respect to any subcontractors as the Human Relations Council may direct as a means of enforcing such provisions, including sanctions for noncompliance. However, in the event the contractor or vendor becomes involved in, or is threatened with litigation with a subcontractor as a result of such direction by the Human Relations Council, the contractor or vendor may request the city to enter into such litigation to protect the interests of the city. 
(Ord. 22510, passed 5-10-67; Am. Ord. 25240, passed 2-9-77; Am. Ord. 26090, passed 10-15-80; Am. Ord. 30698-07, passed 11-21-07; Am. Ord. 31117-11, passed 11-16-11) 
Sec. 35.15. - Enforcement by Human Relations Council. 
    It shall be the duty of the Human Relations Council to administer the provisions of § 35.14 by exercising a continuing review of the employment practices of the contractors and vendors and taking such action as necessary to insure compliance with the section, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(A)  The Human Relations Council by its enforcement officer and/or other authorized representative, shall investigate the employment practices of any contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor to determine whether or not the contractual undertakings in regard to insuring equal employment opportunities and affirmative action have been carried out in accordance with the equal employment opportunity clause. The investigation shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures herein set forth and the investigating officer shall report to the Human Relations Council and the city department for which the contract work is being performed. 
(B)  The Council may, on its own initiative, or upon the request of a contractor or vendor, submit to such contractor or vendor a proposed affirmative action program designed by the Council to prevent or eliminate any discriminatory practices in recruitment and hiring and to assist such contractor or vendor to comply with the terms of the contract and with any ordinance requiring fair employment practices. Acceptance and implementation of such an affirmative action program shall constitute compliance with the contract and with such ordinance. However, the Council may, as circumstances warrant, revise, and modify the affirmative action program from time to time in order to accomplish the purpose of insuring that fair employment practices are followed. 
(C)  The Council shall receive and investigate or cause to be investigated complaints by employees or prospective employees of any city contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor which allege actions contrary to the contractual undertakings of the contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor. 
(D)  The Council shall use its best efforts, directly and through the contracting city departments, other interested federal, state and local agencies, contractors, and all other available instrumentalities, to cause any labor union engaged in work under city contracts or any agency referring workers or providing or supervising apprenticeship or training for or in the course of such work to cooperate in the implementation of the purposes of the equal employment and affirmative action provisions of city contracts. The Council shall, in appropriate cases, notify the United States Department of Justice, Ohio Fair Employment Practices Commission or other appropriate agencies, whenever it has reason to believe that the practices of any labor organization or agency violate Title VI or Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Ohio Fair Employment Practices Act, R.C. Chapter 4112, and § 35.14, and such other relevant legislation as hereafter may be enacted by the Congress of the United States, the general assembly of the state, or the City Commission. 
(E)  The Council may hold such hearings, public or private, as it may deem advisable for compliance, enforcement, or educational purposes. 
(F)  Where the Council finds that a contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor has failed to comply with the equal employment opportunity and affirmative action provisions of its contract, the Council may: 
(1)  Publish, or cause to be published, the names of contractors or unions which it has concluded have failed to comply with the provisions of the contract. 
(2)  Recommend to the Department of Law that, in cases in which there is substantial or material violation or the threat of substantial or material violation of the contractual provisions, appropriate proceedings be brought to enforce those provisions, including the enjoining, within the limitations of applicable law, of organizations, individuals, or groups who prevent, directly or indirectly, compliance with those provisions. 
(3)  Recommend to the Department of Law that criminal proceedings be brought for the furnishing of false information under oath to any city department or the Council, as the case may be. 
(4)  Recommend that the appropriate department cancel, terminate, suspend, or cause to be cancelled, terminated, or suspended any contract, or any portion or portions thereof, for failure of the contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor to comply with the nondiscrimination provisions of the contract. The Council may recommend that a contract be cancelled, terminated, or suspended absolutely or that a continuance of a contract be conditioned upon implementation of a program for future compliance approved by the Contracting Department and the Council. 
(5)  Recommend that any Contracting Department refrain from entering into further contracts, or extensions or other modifications of existing contracts, with any noncomplying contractor, until the contractor has satisfied the Council that the contractor has established and will carry out personnel and employment policies in compliance with the provisions of its contract. 
(G)  Whenever it becomes necessary to cancel or terminate a contract, or whenever a contractor, vendor, material supplier, or subcontractor has been disqualified from further city contracts, because of noncompliance with the contract provisions with regard to affirmative action to provide equal employment opportunity, the Council or the Contracting Department shall promptly notify the Director of Finance. Any such disqualification may be rescinded. 
(Ord. 23465, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24059, passed 7-28-71) 
Cross reference- Discriminatory practices, see Chapter 32. 
Sec. 35.16. - Addendum to information for bidders. 
    All bids on contracts subject to § 35.14 shall include, on the portion of the prepared proposal provided for that purpose, on their own behalf and on behalf of their proposed subcontractors a statement signed by the bidder or bidders: 
(A)  That applicants for employment are hired without regard to their race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(B)  That employees are treated during employment without regard to their race, color, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. 
(C)  That the affirmative action program which the bidder or bidders propose to undertake to insure that there will be minority group representation in all trades and in all phases of their operations, in accordance with § 35.15(B). Bidders are invited to consult with the Human Relations Council contract compliance officer for information, advice, and assistance in the preparation of their proposal. An affirmative action program shall be considered to be in compliance with this section if it includes provisions consistent with the following guidelines: 
(1)  Use minority contractors as subcontractors; 
(2)  Employ representative numbers of minorities in all job classifications, with any increase in the work force resulting from the project bid upon being accompanied by a comparable increase in the number of minority group employees; 
(3)  Establish timetables for achieving employment goals which are directly related to the total work force; 
(4)  Action oriented recruitment using comprehensive manpower center and other recruitment sources where minority applicants can be found; 
(5)  Provide on-the-job training opportunities for recently hired minority employees; 
(6)  Employ residents from the model neighborhood area for projects being performed in the model neighborhood area, whether or not related to comprehensive cities demonstration program; 
(7)  Recruitment sources where minorities are not registered will not be used; and 
(8)  Record total present work force and total minority work force and list minorities by job classification. 
(Ord. 23465, passed 8-20-69; Am. Ord. 24059, passed 7-28-71; Am. Ord. 26090, passed 10-15-80; Am. Ord. 30698-07, passed 11-21-07) 
Sec. 35.17. - Execution and distribution of contracts. 
    All public works contracts and certificates shall be executed in triplicate and each copy thereof shall be considered as an original, and shall have attached thereto as a part thereof a true copy of the specifications for the work and the bid therefor. One copy shall be deposited with the Director of the department having charge of such work, one copy with the Director of Finance and one copy shall be delivered to the contractor. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14) 
Sec. 35.18. - Payments under contracts. 
    The consideration of any contract shall be paid in cash, but no payments shall be made on account thereof, except upon the certificate of the Director of the department having such work in charge that the amount to be paid is justly due under the terms of the contract. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14) 
Sec. 35.19. - Time for completion of work; bonus; liquidated damages. 
    All contracts shall provide for completion by a specified time, and, if so determined by the Director before bids are received, may provide for a bonus to the contractor for completion before such date and liquidated damages to the city in like sum for every day of delay beyond such date. The amount of such sum per day shall be fixed by the Director and the time for completion shall be set forth in the bids and embodied in the contract, and no payments shall be made on account of such contract after the specified day until the contract is completed and the work accepted. However, the Commission may, if satisfied that sufficient reason exists for such action, waive the claim of the city for liquidated damages. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14) 
Sec. 35.20. - Compensation for extra work. 
    Contracts may provide for the performance of such extra work as may be lawfully authorized, upon compensation to be fixed in the manner provided in the specifications and in the contract, and may provide for an abatement of a contract price to be determined in like manner, if changes in the work lawfully authorized shall justify the same. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14) 
Sec. 35.21. - Contracts not in excess of $10,000.00. 
    The City Manager is authorized to approve the awarding of contracts involving an expenditure not in excess of $10,000.00, which contract shall be let in the same manner as provided in this chapter. In any case when the Director of the department shall consider it advisable to dispense with any of the provisions of this chapter as to the manner of letting and entering into any such contract, he shall so report to the City Manager his reasons therefor and he shall thereupon proceed as he is directed by the City Manager. No work involving an expenditure of more than $10,000.00 shall at any time be divided so as to bring it within the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 9583, passed 3-18-14; Am. Ord. 23025, passed 7-10-68; Am. Ord. 26382, passed 11-18-81; Am. Ord. 30709-07, passed 12-19-07) 
Sec. 35.22. - Contracts to collect income tax for other cities. 
    The City Manager is authorized to execute contracts for and on behalf of the city, with the approval of the Commission, with other municipalities providing for the city to collect all income tax monies due to such municipalities. These contracts shall be in such form and contain such provisions as contained in the form of contracts with respect thereto on file in the office of the Clerk of the Commission. The contracts shall provide in part that all costs of collecting income tax monies due such municipalities shall be paid by such municipalities, and that the contracts may be terminated by either party upon not less than three months' written notice to the other party. 
(Ord. 23229, passed 1-2-69) 
Sec. 35.23. - Direct contract authorized for public improvement. 
(A)  Whenever the Director of any municipal department and the City Manager, owing to the conditions surrounding the case, join in recommendations to the Commission that a public improvement be made by the direct employment of the necessary labor and the purchase of necessary materials and supplies, or by such direct employment of labor and direct purchase of supplies and materials together with the hiring of equipment necessary to perform the work, with or without the supervising services of some party or parties specially qualified therefor and not regularly employed by the city, the Commission may authorize the same to be done in the manner so recommended, upon motion spread upon the minutes of the Commission, which motion shall not be published. 
(B)  Public improvement, as used in this section, means any improvement to be made by the city, not an ordinary routine repair of an existing structure or improvement. 
(Ord. 11361, passed 5-4-21) 
Sec. 35.24. - Aggregate bidding. 
    The provisions of Ohio R.C. 153.50 through 153.52 inclusive, shall have no application for any contracts for work and materials on public improvement projects within the city, and the City Manager may, at his/her discretion, determine that such projects may be bid as a whole with aggregate bids accepted only and not bid by each trade separately. 
(Ord. 29523-98, passed 3-11-98) 
DIVISION 3. - EQUIPMENT PURCHASES 

Sec. 35.25. - Joint purchases. 
(A)  The purchasing agent may, where appropriate, participate in joint bidding programs for the purchase of materials, supplies, and equipment conducted by other governmental entities or associations whose membership is composed of governmental purchasing officers. 
(B)  The purchasing agent shall participate in such joint purchasing programs only when it appears that opportunity for competition is afforded, that proposals solicited are upon precise specifications, and that such participation is to the city's advantage. 
(Ord. 27525, passed 3-11-87) 
Sec. 35.26. - Purchase of used equipment. 
    Whenever a requisition submitted to the city purchasing agent specifies that used equipment is acceptable, the purchasing agent shall, if it appears that such equipment may be obtained in satisfactory condition at a cost that is less than the cost of comparable new equipment, take informal bids or compare the prices charged by the vendors of such equipment and recommend to the manager purchase from the vendor offering the equipment at terms most advantageous to the city. If the amount of the purchase does not exceed $2,500.00 it shall be final upon approval by the manager. If the amount of the purchase exceeds $2,500.00, it shall be final upon approval of the Commission by motion adopted in the usual manner. 
(Ord. 26994, passed 5-16-84) 
Sec. 35.27. - Use of off-duty police officers. 
    Whenever the public safety requires the use of police officers in excess of those normally available and the use is at the request of a private person, firm, corporation, or institution, the Director of Police, with the approval of the City Manager, may detail off-duty officers to perform police-related functions such as traffic control, protection of life and property, and security provided that the person, firm, corporation, or institution reimburses the city the cost of providing the additional police officers. Prior to assigning off-duty officers to such duty, the Director shall ascertain the total cost thereof, including overtime, fringe benefits, and use of city equipment, and prepare a contract to be executed by the party requesting the service and by the City Manager or his designee, the terms of which contract shall enumerate the services to be provided, the number of officers to be assigned, and the cost to be paid therefor. 
(Ord. 27093, passed 10-17-84) 
Secs. 35.28, 35.29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROCUREMENT ENHANCEMENT PLAN FOR GOODS, SERVICES, AND CONSTRUCTION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 31023-10, adopted Sept. 29, 2010, repealed the former Div. 4, §§ 35.30-35.52, and enacted a new Div. 4 as set out herein. The former Div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. 30947, passed Dec. 23, 2009. 

Sec. 35.30. - Adoption of the findings and conclusions regarding minority and women-owned business enterprises. 
    The Commission adopts the findings and conclusions of the MGT of America, Inc. Final Report dated August 8, 2008 and entitled "A Second-Generation Disparity Study for the City of Dayton, Ohio" and by this reference incorporates herein the Second-Generation Disparity Study. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.31. - Findings. 
    On the basis of the foregoing and upon full consideration of all relevant facts, the Commission finds that: 
(A)  Minorities and women continue to show disparities in entry into self employment, after controlling for age, wealth, and other variables. 
(B)  Minorities and women that were self employed earned significantly less than non-minority males, after controlling for other factors. 
(C)  Past discrimination in the private sector and in the city's overall contracting process has had the effect of significant underutilization of minority and women-owned business enterprises in contracts awarded by the city and has contributed to the underdevelopment of such businesses. 
(D)  The present effects of such past discrimination continue to impede the development of businesses owned by minorities and women. 
(E)  Certain issues, such as difficulties in the financing and bonding markets, and problems obtaining credit and insurance, impede the development of minority and women-owned businesses as well as certain nonminority small business enterprises. 
(F)  The city has long recognized he importance of small business enterprises to its economic vitality and has adopted several measures and programs in support thereof including, but not limited to, City Wide Development Corporation, the Office of Small Business Ombudsmen, the Small Business Advisory Council, the Minority Contractors Business Assistance Program, the Small business Retention Program and the Small Business Assistance Program. 
(G)  It is in the best interest of the city to continue to promote the equitable utilization of small business enterprises, minority business enterprises and women's businesses enterprises in city contracting in order to eradicate the lingering effects of past discrimination and improve the city's economic viability. 
(H)  The requirements of this division are necessary to overcome the present effects of past discrimination and are designed to achieve the goal of equitable utilization of small businesses and minority and women-owned businesses in contracting with the city. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.32. - Declaration of policy. 
    It is the policy of the city to promote full and equal business opportunity to all persons doing business with the city. The city must ensure that businesses seeking to participate in contracting and procurement activities with the city are not prevented from doing so on the basis of the race or gender of their owners. The city is committed to ensuring that it is not engaged in passive participation in any form of discrimination. This policy will apply to all expenditures of city public funds, irrespective of source, with the exception of noted exclusions. This policy will also apply to all private sector economic development projects, where feasible, in which city public funds and/or tax incentives are utilized, in part or in total. In addition, where feasible, this policy will apply to contracts or agreements between the city and any other political subdivisions, governmental, or quasi-governmental agencies under which entities receive money from or through the city for the purposes of contracting with businesses to perform projects in the city. 
    This policy is enacted pursuant to the home rule powers of the city and supersedes any inconsistent provision of any law or regulation of the State of Ohio. This division shall not apply to any contract to the extent that it is inconsistent with procedures or standards required by any law or regulation of the United States or the State of Ohio, to the extent such inconsistency is not permitted under the home rule powers of the city. In connection with any contract funded in whole or part from state or federal sources which require the imposition of 49 C.F.R. Parts 23 and/or 26, and of goals or by the appropriate Local Participation Agreement (LPA) related to the participation of Disadvantaged Business Enterprises, this division shall not apply to the extent inconsistent with such state or federal requirements. It is not the intent of this program to include federally grant funded contracts subject to a federally promulgated affirmative action program. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.33. - Procurement enhancement plan for small, minority, and women's business enterprises. 
    In order to accomplish the declared policy of the city as set forth to ensure the full and equitable participation by small businesses enterprises ("SBE"), minority business enterprises ("MBE") and women's business enterprises ("WBE") in the provision of goods and services to the city and construction, there is hereby created the Procurement Enhancement Plan ("PEP") which may include but is not limited to the following components: MBE, WBE and SBE Programs for Goods and Services; MBE, WBE and SBE Programs for Construction; Joint Venture/Strategic Partnership Program; Dayton Local Business and MBE, WBE, SBE Preferences; and Dayton Local Small Business Program. The PEP shall be administered and reviewed by the Human Relations Council. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.34. - Duties of the Human Relations Council. 
    The Human Relations Council ("Council") shall have the following duties and responsibilities for the administration and review of the procurement enhancement plan ("PEP"): 
(A)  Administration and enforcement of the PEP. 
(B)  Promulgate, amend, and enforce policies and procedures consistent with this division as may be necessary and appropriate to promote the ethical practice of contracting and subcontracting and to carry out the provisions, intents, and purposes of this PEP. 
(C)  Certification of businesses as MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs in accordance with the standards set forth under the PEP. 
(D)  Development and maintenance of a database of certified MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs. 
(E)  Institution of a pre-qualification process and procedures to establish the capability of those firms eligible for the Small Contract Rotation Program and the Dayton Local Small Business Program. 
(F)  Monitor compliance with the requirements of the PEP. 
(G)  Establishment of written procedures, informal guidelines, and forms as may be necessary to effectuate the PEP and the requirements set forth hereunder. 
(H)  Investigation of alleged violations of this PEP, and the issuance of written statements following any determination of such investigation, stating the reasons therefor and any penalty imposed. 
(I)  Collaboration with various city departments to ensure maximum outreach to MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs. 
(J)  Determination of whether a bidder made good faith efforts as defined and required by the PEP. 
(K)  Provision to businesses of all forms, applications, documents, and papers necessary to comply with the PEP. 
(L)  Provision of information to potential bidders, upon request by the potential bidder, which shall include names and contact information of certified MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs to reinforce and support outreach efforts by potential bidders. 
(M)  Notification to an affected party by certified mail that it has the right to appeal a denial of certification as an MBE, WBE, and/or SBE to the council within seven days of receipt of the notice of refusal to certify the affected party. 
(N)  Notification to the appropriate departments of the city of any determination of noncompliance with the PEP, and of any appeal from any such determination. 
(O)  Provision of ongoing monitoring and oversight functions to determine the degree of compliance maintained by successful bidders and to monitor the utilization of MBEs WBEs, and SBEs on eligible projects. 
(P)  Maintenance of annual statistical data based on availability and utilization of certified MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs. 
(Q)  Tracking and reporting of statistics regarding the effectiveness of this PEP as measured by a review of data indicating expenditures with MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs as required by the PEP policies and procedures. 
(R)  Submission of an annual report and scorecard to the City Commission, the City Manager, and the PEP Oversight Committee reviewing the performance of each department in meeting the goals established under the PEP. 
(S)  Recommendations to the PEP Oversight Committee regarding annual goals for the program. 
(T)  Recommendations to the PEP Oversight Committee regarding any further efforts needed to ensure participation by MBEs, WBEs, and SBEs in contracting with the city. 
(U)  Development and implementation of outreach and technical assistance programs to assist businesses in gaining the ability to compete successfully in the marketplace and to promote equal contracting opportunities for all businesses desiring to conduct business with the city, regardless of MBE, WBE, and SBE status. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.35. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Annual receipts. Total income (or in the case of a sole proprietorship, gross revenue) plus cost of goods sold as these terms are defined and reported on Internal Revenue Service tax return forms. 
    Annual eligible spend for construction. The total amount spent annually on construction projects, excluding money spent from state and federal funds and other funding streams that limit or prohibit local goal setting. Funds excluded from the annual spend for construction include, but are not limited to, those projects that are bid with a federal DBE goal as specified by the Federal Aviation Administration, Federal Highway Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, and Ohio Department of Transportation. The federal and state programs are further clarified in the PEP Policies and Procedures Manual. 
    Annual eligible spend for goods and services. The total amount spent annually for goods and services, excluding funds expended for the following, as further clarified in the PEP Policies and Procedures: payments to governmental entities or governmental agents; payments made because of negotiated settlements and required by the court system or state or federal government; payments made to the following regulated utilities: railroads, telephones, electric and natural gas; those purchases that are not for the following: equipment, materials, supplies, services; payments made because of prompt pay penalties; right-of-way payments made to owner for the purchase of land and/or property, and; sole source expenditures. 
    Award. Legislation or City Manager action authorizing the award of a contract by the city, provided, however, that the contract will not become binding upon the city, and the city will incur no liability under it, until it has been duly executed by the contractor and the city with all required submittals, including insurance and bonding, if applicable. 
    Bid. Written quotations, proposals, or offers by a bidder or contractor to perform or provide labor, materials, equipment, goods, or services to the city for a price submitted in response to a competitive bidding solicitation issued by the city. 
    Bidder. Any individual, business enterprise, partnership, joint venture, or corporation that submits a bid to the city as defied herein. 
    Certification. The criteria and process for participation in the PEP. 
    Certifying agency. A private or public entity designated by the Executive Director or the Human Relations Council as an agency eligible to certify businesses for the city as an MBE, WBE, and/or SBE. 
    City. The City of Dayton, Ohio. 
    Commercially useful function. The execution by a minority or women owned business enterprise, which contracts with the city, or subcontracts with another business enterprise which contracts with the city, of a distinct element of the work of the contract by actually performing, managing, and supervising the work involved, excepting a business enterprise which serves as a conduit for another. 
    Construction. The process of building, altering, repairing, remodeling, improving or demolishing any public structure or building or other public improvements of any kind to any public real property, excepting the routine operation, routine repair or routine maintenance of structures, buildings or real property. 
    Council. The members of the Human Relations Council of the City of Dayton, Ohio, as appointed by the City Commission pursuant to Section 32.13 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances. 
    Contract. Any agreement between the city and a person or business enterprise to provide or procure labor, materials, equipment, goods and/or services to, for, or on behalf of the city. A "contract" shall include an agreement between the city and a person or business enterprise to perform professional, architectural and engineering services, construction related services, or fund the performance of such services. Except as otherwise specifically defined in this section, a "contract" shall not include: 
(a)  Awards made by the city with federal or state grant or city general fund monies to a non-profit entity to which the city offers assistance, guidance, or supervision on a project or program and the recipient of the grant award uses the grant monies to provide services to the community; 
(b)  Sales transactions where the city sells or purchases real or personal property; or, 
(c)  Donations of materials, equipment, goods, or services to or by the city. 
    Contractor. Any person or business entity that shall enter into a contract with the city, including all partners and all joint ventures of such person or entity. 
    Counting towards goals. The procedure for calculation of participation in the PEP as determined by the Program Policies and Procedures. 
    Dayton Local Business. A business located within the corporate limits of the city that has filed or paid a payroll or earnings tax in the most recent calendar quarter and is a taxpayer in good standing with the City of Dayton. 
    Dayton Local Small Business. A business that: 
(a)  Is certified by the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, as an MBE, WBE, and/or SBE; and 
(b)  Is a Dayton Local Business; and 
(c)  Is a general construction contractor, which has annual average gross receipts for each of the preceding three years of not more than $15,000,000.00; or, 
(d)  Is a business engaged in specialty trade and services which has annual average gross revenue for each of the immediately preceding three years of not more than $5,000,000.00. 
    Executive Director of the Council. The individual appointed by the Commission pursuant to Section 32.18 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances of the City of Dayton. 
    Good faith efforts. The steps undertaken, prior to submission of a bid, to obtain MBE, WBE, and/or SBE participation for subcontracting opportunities related to the bid proposal, and submitted as defined in the program policies and procedures. 
    Goods. All things, including specially manufactured goods, which are movable at the time of identification to the contract for sale, other than the money in which the price is to be paid, investment securities and things in action, and excluding land or a permanent interest in land. 
    Joint venture. An association of two or more persons, partnerships, corporations, and any combination of them, whereby they combine their expertise, property, capital, efforts, skills and knowledge, which is also: 
(a)  Comprised of at least one certified MBE, WBE, or SBE; 
(b)  Evidenced by a notarized, written agreement executed by all joint venture partners; 
(c)  Approved by the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee;
