(d)  Compliant with any additional criteria established by the council in its policies and procedures; and 
(e)  Comprised of member businesses that have either different race ownership, different gender ownership, or both. 
    Lower tier subcontractor. A subcontractor who is not in privity of contract with a contractor but is in privity of contract with another subcontractor. 
    Lower tier supplier. A supplier who is not in privity of contract with a contractor but is in privity of contract with a subcontractor or a supplier. 
    Minority group. Any of the following racial or ethnic groups which are referenced in the Second-Generation Disparity Study for the City of Dayton, including: 
(a)  African-Americans or Black Americans; 
(b)  Hispanic Americans; 
(c)  Asian-Americans; and 
(d)  Native Americans. 
    Minority business enterprise ("MBE"). A business: 
(a)  Which is at least 51 percent owned by one or more members of one or more minority groups, or, in the case of a publicly held corporation, at least 51 percent of the stock of which is owned by on or more members of one or more minority groups, whose management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more members of one or more minority groups; 
(b)  Which, in the case of a general construction contractor, has annual average gross receipts for each of the preceding three years of not more than $33,500,000.00; or, in the case of a business engaged in a specialty trade and services has annual average gross revenue over each of the immediately preceding three years of not more than $15,000,000.00; or, in the case of a business engaged in goods and services has an annual average employee count of 100 or less; 
(c)  Which can demonstrate that the personal net worth of each owner whose ownership and control are relied upon for certification does not exceed $750,000.00 exclusive of the value of the owner's interest in the MBE and the individual's equity in his or her primary place of residence; and 
(d)  Which has been certified as an MBE by the Executive Director of the Council or his/her designee. 
    Personal net worth. The net value of the assets of an individual remaining after total liabilities are deducted, not including the individual's ownership interest in an applicant or participating MBE, WBE or SBE firm or the individual's equity in his or her primary place of residence. An individual's personal net worth includes only his or her own share of assets held jointly or as community property with the individual's spouse. 
    Policies and procedures. The policies and procedures adopted by the Commission herein, including any future amendments, additions or deletions made by the Council pursuant to its authority and consistent with this division. 
    Procurement. Buying, purchasing, renting, leasing or otherwise acquiring any goods, services and/or construction, including a description of requirements, selection and solicitation of sources, preparation and award of contracts and all phases of contract administration. 
    Professional services. Those services within the scope of the practices of architecture, investment banking, professional engineering, planning, landscape architecture, land, surveying, the medical arts, management and analysis, accounting or auditing, law, psychology or any other similar kind or type of professional practice. For purposes of this division, professional services shall not include investment management services. 
    Responsive bid. A quotation, proposal, solicitation, or offer that meets specifications, including, if applicable, any project participation goal as set out in the bid packet specifications. 
    Services. Those services within the scope of the practices included within professional services and general services. 
    Small business enterprise ("SBE"). A business that: 
(a)  Is an independent and continuing enterprise for profit, performing a commercially useful function; 
(b)  Has been in existence for not less than one year; 
(c)  In the case of a general construction contractor, has annual average gross receipts for each of the preceding three years of not more than $33,500,000.00; or, in the case of a business engaged in a specialty trade and services has annual average gross revenue over each of the immediately preceding three years of not more than $15,000,000.00; or, in the case of a business engaged in goods and services has an annual average employee count of 100 or less; in determining the average annual gross revenues of a small business enterprise, the Council shall include gross receipts of each of its affiliates. The gross revenue standard shall be adjusted from time to time consistent with the United States Small Business Administration ("SBA") standards for small businesses. 
(d)  Certifies that its individual owner(s) whose ownership and control are relied upon for SBE certification has a personal net worth that does not exceed $750,000.00; and, 
(e)  Which has been certified as an SBE by the Executive Director of the Council or his/her designee. 
    Subcontractor. Any person or business enterprise providing goods, labor, or services to a contractor if such goods, labor or services are procured in fulfillment of the contractor's obligations arising from a contract with the city. Subcontractor includes every level of subcontracting required to fulfill a contract with the city. 
    Women business enterprise ("WBE"). A business enterprise: 
(a)  Which is at least 51 percent owned by one or more women, or, in the case of a publicly held corporation, 51 percent of the stock of which is owned by one or more women, whose management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more women; 
(b)  Which, in the case of a general construction contractor, has annual average gross receipts for each of the preceding three years of not more than $33,500,000.00; or, in the case of a business engaged in a specialty trade and services has annual average gross revenue over each of the immediately preceding three years of not more than $15,000,000.00; or, in the case of a business engaged in goods has an annual average employee count of 100 or less; 
(c)  Which can demonstrate that the personal net worth of each owner whose ownership and control are relied upon for WBE certification does not exceed $750,000.00 exclusive of the value of the owner's interest in the WBE and the individual's equity in his or her primary place of residence; and 
(d)  Which has been certified as a WBE by the Executive Director of the Council or his/her designee. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.36. - Non-discrimination policy for contracting. 
    The city is committed to a policy of non-discrimination pursuant to Section 1 of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Untied States Constitution. It is further the policy of the city that its purchasing and contracting practices not implicate the city as a passive participant in discriminatory practices engaged in by private contractors or vendors who seek to obtain business with the city. In furtherance of these policy objectives, the city seeks to afford to its citizens equal opportunities to do business on city contracts and to ensure that all bidders, proposers, vendors, and contractors doing business with the city provide to businesses owned and controlled by minorities, women, and others whom it considers to be disadvantaged, opportunities to participate on contracts which are paid, in whole or part, with monetary appropriations from the city. 
    The city prohibits discrimination against any person or business in pursuit of these opportunities on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, ancestry, national origin, place of birth, age, marital status, or handicap. The city will conduct its contracting and purchasing programs so as to discourage any discrimination and will vigorously seek to resolve all claims of discrimination. The council shall promulgate, amend and enforce such policies and procedures consistent with the provisions of this section as may be necessary and appropriate to carry out the provisions, intent, and purpose of this section. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.37. - Procurement enhancement programs for goods, services and construction. 
(A)  Statement of Policy: It is the purpose of this program to promote the economic welfare of the people of the City of Dayton, to promote full and equal business opportunity for all persons doing business with the city, and to promote commerce by assisting Minority Business Enterprises and Women's Business Enterprises (MBEs and WBEs) and Small Business Enterprises (SBEs) to actively participate in the city's procurement process for goods, services and construction. 
(B)  The Council shall promulgate, amend and enforce such policies and procedures consistent with the provisions of this section as may be necessary and appropriate to carry out the provisions, intent, and purpose of this section. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.371. - Annual participation goals for goods and services. 
(A)  In an effort to remedy the present effects of past identified discrimination in the City of Dayton marketplace and contracting and procurement with the city, as found in the Second-Generation Disparity Study reported by MGT of America, Inc., August 8, 2008, and in order to provide MBEs, WBEs and SBEs equal opportunity and access to participate in all city procurement of goods and services, including professional services, the council shall annually establish aspirational goals for MBE, WBE and SBE participation in contracting for city goods and services. 
(B)  The following factors shall be utilized as part of the methodology for establishing annual aspirational MBE, WBE and SBE goals for the MBE, WBE and SBE programs for goods and services: 
(1)  The number of minority, women and small businesses in the State of Ohio; 
(2)  The availability of minority, women and small businesses in the State of Ohio willing and able to do business with the city; 
(3)  Annual participation figures for minority, women and small businesses in both city contracting and the private marketplace; 
(4)  Analysis of disparities between the availability and participation of willing and able minority, women and small businesses in both the city and the private marketplace; 
(5)  The findings and conclusions contained in the Second-Generation Disparity Study and other reports undertaken by the city, organizations, and governmental entities relating to the Dayton market area; 
(6)  Review and analysis of the reports generated by the Council or other city departments in accordance with Policies and Procedures for Outreach and Business Assistance to Subcontractors by the Council; and, 
(7)  Other relevant factors. 
(C)  The initial annual aspirational MBE, WBE and SBE goals for goods and services shall be as follows, indicated in percentage of annual eligible spend for goods and services. 
(1)  Goals for goods: ten percent - MBE; five percent - WBE; 15 percent - SBE. 
(2)  Goals for services (including professional services and other services): 12 percent - MBE; three percent - WBE; 20 percent - SBE. 
(D)  These annual aspirational goals shall be reviewed each year by September 15 by the Council. The annual goal setting process shall include consultation with the PEP Oversight Committee. 
(E)  These goals are only intended to be benchmarks for evaluating overall performance of the program on an annual basis. These participation goals are not and shall not be quotas. 
(F)  For purposes of determining or satisfying annual participation goals, only participation of MBEs, WBEs and SBEs certified by the Executive Director of the Council or his/her designee, or a Council-approved certification agency, shall be considered. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.372. - Project and contract goals for goods and services. 
(A)  The Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall set MBE, WBE and SBE contracting goals for each contract and include goals for subcontracting where applicable. The Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, with the purchasing agent, shall establish a process for identifying and monitoring opportunities for subcontracting. 
(B)  Project and contract goals shall be based on the statistical data cited in Section 35.371(B). Under these set for conditions the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall set MBE, WBE and SBE contracting goals on a contract-by-contract basis where new capacity or new annual eligible spend is created after the annual aspirational goals have been set. 
(C)  Where a contract provides a goal for MBE, WBE or SBE participation, the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall indicate a bidder is eligible to be awarded the contract only where bidder has demonstrated good faith efforts to meet the designated goal. 
(D)  Bidders shall be informed at the time of solicitation that, if a waiver is sought, a bidder is required to submit a waiver request with its bid. 
(E)  Agreements between a bidder and an MBE, WBE or SBE in which the MBE, WBE or SBE promises not to provide subcontracting quotations to other bidders shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.373. - Annual participation goals for construction. 
(A)  In an effort to remedy the present effects of past identified discrimination in the City of Dayton marketplace and contracting and procurement with the city, as found in the Second-Generation Disparity Study reported by MGT of America, Inc., August 8, 2008, and in order to provide MBEs, WBEs and SBEs equal opportunity and access to participate in all city procurement of construction, the Council shall annually establish aspirational goals for MBE, WBE or SBE participation in contracting for city procurement of construction. 
(B)  The following factors shall be utilized as part of the methodology for establishing annual aspirational goals for MBE, WBE and SBE programs for construction: 
(1)  The number of minority, women and small businesses in the State of Ohio; 
(2)  The availability of minority, women and small businesses in the State of Ohio willing and able to do business with the city; 
(3)  Annual participation figures for minority, women and small businesses in both city contracting and the private marketplace; 
(4)  Analysis of disparities between the availability and participation of willing and able minority, women and small businesses in both the city and the private marketplace; 
(5)  The findings and conclusions contained in the Second-Generation Disparity Study and other reports undertaken by the city, organizations, and governmental entities relating to the Dayton market area; 
(6)  Review and analysis of the reports generated by the Council or other city departments in accordance with the Policies and Procedures for Outreach and Business Assistance to Subcontractors by the Council; and, 
(7)  Other relevant factors. 
(C)  The initial annual aspirational MBE, WBE and SBE goals for construction shall be as follows, indicated in percentage of Annual Eligible Spend for Construction: 17 percent - MBE; five percent - WBE; 20 percent - SBE. 
(D)  These annual aspirational goals shall be reviewed each year by November 15 by the Council. The annual goal setting process shall include consultation with the PEP Oversight Committee. 
(E)  These overall goals are only intended to be benchmarks for evaluating overall performance of the program on an annual basis. These participation goals are not and shall not be quotas. 
(F)  For purposes of satisfying annual participation goals, only participation of MBEs, WBEs and SBEs certified by the Executive Director of the Council or his/her designee, or a Council-approved certification agency, shall be considered. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.374. - Project and contract goals for construction. 
(A)  The Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall set MBE, WBE and SBE contracting goals for each specific prime construction contract, to include those with subcontracting possibilities, and include goals for subcontracting where applicable. 
(B)  The Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall have the authority to reduce to eliminate such MBE, WBE and SBE goals on a contract-by-contract basis based on the type of contract, the type of subcontracting work that will be required, and the availability of MBEs, WBEs and SBEs. 
(C)  Project and contract goals shall be based on the statistical data cited in Section 35.373(B). 
(D)  Every prime bidder on an eligible project shall be required to submit with its bid submittal the applicable MBE, WBE or SBE Participation Form, which shall include the names, addresses, phone number, Tax I.D. number, certification numbers, if applicable, of certified MBEs, WBEs or SBEs, or businesses that have applied for MBE, WBE or SBE certification at the time of bid submission, and any other information required as set forth in the project's solicitation documents. Bids must also include a proposed schedule of MBE, WBE or SBE participation that lists the names of the MBE, WBE or SBE subcontractors, a description of the work each is to perform, and the dollar value of each proposed MBE, WBE or SBE subcontract. 
(E)  The city shall indicate goals for the MBE, WBEs and/or SBEs in solicitations for contracts that provide opportunities for MBE, WBE or SBE participation. 
(F)  Solicitations for contracts that provide opportunities for MBE, WBE or SBE participation shall require all bidders to submit a written assurance that the MBE, WBE or SBE goals are met in their bids or proposal. 
(G)  Where a contract provides a goal for MBE, WBE or SBE participation, the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall recommend a bidder be awarded a contract only where the bidder has demonstrated good faith efforts to meet the designated goal. A bidder has demonstrated good faith efforts if it does either of the following: 1) document sufficient commitments to meet the goal in accordance with the program policies and procedures; or 2) request a waiver by documenting that it made adequate good faith efforts to meet the goal, even though it did not succeed in obtaining sufficient commitments to do so, in accordance with program policies and procedures. 
(H)  Where a bidder fails to meet MBE, WBE or SBE goals and fails to demonstrate good faith efforts to meet MBE, WBE or SBE goals, as defined in the program policies and procedures, the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall not recommend the bidder be awarded the contract. 
(I)  If a waiver is sought, a bidder is required to submit a waiver request with its bid, and bidders shall be so informed at the time of solicitation. 
(J)  Agreements between a bidder and an MBE, WBE or SBE in which the MBE, WBE or SBE premises not to provide subcontracting quotations to other bidders shall be prohibited. 
(K)  Where the cost differential between the lowest bidder that has not met the goal but is otherwise responsive and a bidder that has either: (1) met the MBE, WBE or SBE goals or (2) been granted a waiver, exceeds the lesser of $100,000.00 or ten percent: i) the lowest bidder may be awarded the contract; or (ii) the city may rebid the project. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.375. - Request for waiver of project or contract goals. 
    If a bidder is unable to meet all or part of the MBE, WBE or SBE project or contract goals, a waiver may be sought by the bidder. The waiver request shall be submitted with the bid and reviewed for approval by the Executive Director of the Council or his/her designee. The bidder who submitted the waiver request shall, within two business days after submission of its bid, submit full commentary evidence of the good faith efforts it used to meet the contract goals, as defined in the program policies and procedures. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.376. - Records and reports for PEP programs. 
(A)  The effectiveness of the MBE, WBE and SBE programs for goods and services, and the MBE, WBE and SBE programs for construction will be measured by a review of expenditures with MBEs, WBEs and SBEs, including an analysis of prime spending and subcontractor spending, where applicable. The Council shall prepare and present a report to the City Commission from time to time, as the program policies and procedures require. 
(B)  The council shall promulgate, amend, and enforce the program policies and procedures for the maintenance of records and reports in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.377. - Review and oversight. 
    The city shall establish the PEP Oversight Committee comprised of the City Manager, the Executive Director of the Council, the Director of the Department of Central Services, and one community representative. The City Commission will appoint a community representative to serve on the PEP Oversight Committee to serve a three-year term. At the expiration of the community representative's term, he/she may be re-appointed if the Commission desires. The PEP Oversight Committee shall: 
(A)  Review annually the results of the program and submit recommendations for improvement as indicated by reports and performance results; 
(B)  Review the recommendations of the Council regarding upcoming annual goals for the program for MBEs, WBEs and SBEs by September 15, for goods and services, and by November 15, for construction, of each year; 
(C)  Review the quarterly reports published by the Council, and provide guidance and direction to encourage improved performance where indicated; 
(D)  Review the policies and procedures promulgated by the Council pursuant to this division. 
(E)  Review the performance of each department in the contracting with MBEs, WBEs or SBEs, and communicate to each department their performance metrics in comparison to the total. 
(F)  Reports its findings to the Commission. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.38. - Duties of the Division of Purchasing. 
    The city considers information distributed and communicated with MBEs, WBEs and SBEs to be an integral part of the city's PEP. The Department of Procurement, Management and Budget, Division of Procurement shall do the following to assist in meeting the outcomes included in this division: 
(A)  The Division of Procurement shall develop, implement and amend policies and standards to assist the city in achieving its aspirational goals. 
(B)  Notify MBEs, WBEs and SBEs of bid opportunities. 
(C)  Division of Procurement staff shall actively participate in trade fairs and association meets for MBEs, WBEs and SBEs. 
(D)  Develop and maintain a record of the number of MBEs, WBEs and SBEs contacted with the quotes received over a period of time. 
(E)  Evaluate the effectiveness and performance of buyers in utilizing MBE, WBE and SBE in purchasing all goods and services. 
(F)  Implement procedures to allow MBEs, WBEs and SBEs equal opportunity and access to participate in all contracts funded by the city, regardless of funding source. 
(G)  Establish a proposal review process that provides feedback upon request to unsuccessful bidders about their proposal. Conduct debriefing sessions with the cooperation of the department involved to explain and analyze why certain bids were unsuccessful. 
(H)  Involve the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, in the development of the procurement bid review process for those projects that have MBE, WBE or SBE goals. 
(I)  Permit MBEs, WBEs and SBEs, upon request, to review and evaluate successful bid summaries of similar procurements. 
(J)  In the event a need arises for the city to execute sole source purchase orders for goods and services, the City Purchasing Agent, or his/her designee, may make such recommendation to the City Manager and/or execute such authority as may have already been granted. 
(K)  The Division of Procurement shall develop a small dollar procurement policy to enhance opportunities for participation by certified entities in competitive procurements administered by the city's Purchasing Division. 
(L)  Blanket purchase orders shall not exceed One Hundred Thousand Dollars and Zero Cents. Blanket purchase order limits do not apply to super blanket purchase orders for utility payments, insurance payments, p-card usage, leases, court-mandated payments and/or reimbursements, indigent burial services or competitive bids. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10; Ord. No. 31659-18, § 1, 8-8-18) 
Sec. 35.39. - Outreach and business assistance by the council. 
    To ensure that opportunities to participate on city contracts are available to the widest feasible universe of interested, available, and qualified businesses, the Council shall develop a written comprehensive outreach program aimed at increasing business participation in the city's contracting and procurement process. The Council shall implement its outreach and business assistance to subcontractors, as defined in the program policies and procedures. From time to time overall evaluation of the effectiveness of the program with regard to non-discrimination in contracting shall be conducted. The Council is authorized to modify, develop and implement such other and further outreach activities and programs as the Executive Director of the Council may from time to time recommend. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.40. - Certification of MBEs, WBEs and SBEs. 
(A)  For purposes of contracting with the City of Dayton under the programs established herein, an MBE, WBE, and/or SBE must be certified as an MBE, WBE or SBE by the city and must be located within the State of Ohio. 
(B)  The Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall be responsible for implementing a system for MBE, WBE, SBE certifications and certification removals on behalf of the city. The Council shall consider appeals from the decision of the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee. For the purposes of this section, the city will consider certifications from other entities. 
(C)  The Council shall promulgate, amend and enforce such policies and procedures regarding certification consistent with the provisions of this section as may be necessary and appropriate to carry out the provisions, intent, and purpose of this section. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.41. - Joint venture program. 
(A)  The city will encourage and promote establishment of joint ventures to ensure prime contracting opportunities for all businesses, including MBEs, WBEs and SBEs. 
(B)  Based upon the scope of work and market availability, the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, will determine and identify, on a project-by-project basis, projects where a joint venture will be required. 
(C)  On such projects where a joint venture is required, no bid shall be accepted unless submitted by a joint venture that has been approved by the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee. 
(D)  The Council shall promulgate, amend, and enforce policies and procedures in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.42. - Dayton Local Business and MBE, WBE or SBE bidder preferences for goods and services. 
(A)  The city may give a preference to a Dayton Local Business, as defined in Section 35.35, in awarding city contracts and making purchases whenever the application of such a preference is reasonable in light of the dollar value of the proposal received in relation to such expenditures. 
(B)  (1)  When the lowest bid is not a Dayton Local Business and a certified MBE, WBE or SBE, the lowest responsive bid by a Dayton Local Business that is a certified MBE, WBE or SBE may qualify to be deemed the lowest if its bid amount is within ten percent of the lowest bid submitted by a responsive non-Dayton Local Business that is a certified MBE, WBE or SBE and the Dayton Local Business that is a certified MBE, WBE or SBE agrees to reduce its bid to match that lowest bid submitted by the business that is not a Dayton Local Business and a certified MBE, WBE or SBE. 
(2)  The Purchasing Agent shall rank all qualifying Dayton Local Businesses that are certified MBE, WBE or SBEs from lowest bid to highest bid, and shall contact the lowest bidder first. If that lowest bidder does not respond within two business days or indicates that it is not willing to meet the low bid price, the purchasing agent shall contact the next lowest qualifying Dayton Local Business that is a certified MBE, WBE or SBE. 
(3)  The purchasing agent shall continue to contact qualifying Dayton Local Business that are certified MBE, WBE or SBEs according to the lowest to highest bid ranking until either: 
(i)  A business agrees to meet the low bid price; or 
(ii)  All qualifying Dayton Local Businesses that are certified MBE, WBE or SBEs fail to respond within two business days or indicate they are not willing to meet the low bid price. 
(C)  (1)  When no Dayton Local Business that is a certified MBE, WBE or SBE is eligible for award or chooses to exercise the preference option created in the prior subsection, and the lowest bid is not a Dayton Local Business, the lowest responsive bid by a Dayton Local Business may qualify to be deemed the lowest bid if its bid amount is within five percent of the lowest bid submitted and the Dayton Local Business agrees to reduce its bid to match that lowest bid submitted. 
(2)  The purchasing agent shall rank all qualifying Dayton Local Businesses from lowest bid to highest bid, and shall contact the lowest bidding Dayton Local Business first. If that lowest bidding business does not respond within two business days or indicates that it is not willing to meet the low bid price, the purchasing agent shall contact the next lowest qualifying Dayton Local Business. 
(3)  The purchasing agent shall continue to contact qualifying Dayton Local Businesses according to the lowest to highest bid ranking until either: 
(i)  A business agrees to meet the low bid price; or 
(ii)  All qualifying Dayton Local Businesses fail to respond within two business days or indicate they are not willing to meet the low bid price. 
(D)  (1)  When no Dayton Local Business is eligible for award or chooses to exercise the preference option created in the prior subsection, and the lowest bid is not an MBE, WBE or SBE, the lowest responsive bid by an MBE, WBE or SBE may qualify to be deemed the lowest bid if its bid amount is within five percent of the lowest bid submitted and the MBE, WBE or SBE agrees to reduce its bid to match that lowest bid submitted. 
(2)  The purchasing agent shall rank all qualifying MBE, WBE or SBEs from lowest bid to highest bid, and shall contact the lowest bidding MBE, WBE or SBE first. If that lowest bidding business does not respond within two business days or indicates that it is not willing to meet the low bid price, the purchasing agent shall contact the next lowest qualifying MBE, WBE or SBE. 
(3)  The purchasing agent shall continue to contact qualifying MBE, WBE or SBEs according to the lowest to highest bid ranking until either: 
(i)  A business agrees to meet the low bid price; or 
(ii)  All qualifying MBE, WBE or SBEs fail to respond within two business days or indicate they are not willing to meet the low bid price. 
(E)  When ranking qualifying businesses, in the event of a tie between two Dayton Local Businesses, the tie shall be broken in favor of a Dayton Local Business that is also SBA HUBZone Certified. In the event of a tie between two or more Dayton Local Business bidders where none are SBA HUBZone Certified, ties will be broken through a lottery method until the winner remains. In the event of a tie between two or more Dayton Local Business bidders that are certified MBE, WBE or SBEs, ties will be broken through a lottery method until the winner remains. In the event of a tie between two or more MBE, WBE or SBE bidders, ties will be broken through a lottery method until the winner remains. 
(F)  The Dayton Local Business and MBE, WBE or SBE bidder preferences shall not apply to purchases or contracts which are funded, in whole or in part, by another governmental entity where the laws, regulations, or policies governing such funding prohibit application of the preference, nor shall the preference apply to purchases made or contracts let under emergency or noncompetitive procurement situations. 
(G)  The preference established herein in no way inhibits the right of the city from giving any other preference permitted by law in addition to the preference authorized herein. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.43. - Dayton local small business program for construction. 
(A)  The Council shall establish a Dayton Local Small Business Program for Dayton Local Small Businesses as defined in Section 35.35, where applicable. 
(B)  The basis for the program is the Pub. L. No. 106-554, which targets businesses that have historically experienced limited participation in the marketplace. 
(C)  The purpose of the Dayton Local Small Business Program is to increase contract opportunities for MBEs, WBEs and SBEs. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.44. - Penalties for noncompliance. 
    A contractor or subcontractor who fails to comply with any portion of this division or the policies and procedures adopted by the Council pursuant to this division, and whose failure to comply continues for a period of 30 calendar days after the contractor or subcontractor receives written notice of such noncompliance from the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, shall be subject to any or all of the following penalties: 
(A)  Withholding of ten percent of all future payments for the eligible project until the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, determines that the contractor or subcontractor is in compliance with this division. 
(B)  Withholding of all future payments under the eligible project until it is determined that the contractor or subcontractor is in compliance with this division. 
(C)  Cancellation of the eligible project. 
(D)  Refusal of all future contracts or subcontracts with the city for a minimum of one year and a maximum of five years from the date upon which this penalty is imposed. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.45. - Retaliation or discrimination. 
    When the Council determines that discrimination or retaliation has occurred in violation of this division, the Council shall order any one or more of the following actions (listed in ascending order of severity): 
(A)  Issuance of a finding that the respondent bidder is not a responsive bidder within the meaning of the bid statutes with respect to specific contracts that the city has put out for bids or intends to put out for bids at the time of such finding; 
(B)  Assessment of a fine at an amount determined by the Council, but at not less than $10,000.00; 
(C)  Exercise of any other rights or remedies available to the city under any current contract between the bidder and the city, other than rescission, suspension or termination of the contract, including but not limited to the assessment of liquidated damages; 
(D)  Rescission, suspension or termination of any current contract between the respondent business and the city under the terms thereof; or 
(E)  Disqualification of the respondent bidder from bidding and receiving contract awards on city projects and from participating in city contracts as a subcontractor, vendor or supplier for a period of not more than two years, provided that the respondent business shall have the right to petition the city for reinstatement of its active bidder status by demonstrating to the city's reasonable satisfaction that the problems for which it was disqualified have been cured; and 
(F)  Referral of the matter for criminal prosecution of fraud and other violations under Ohio law if appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.46. - Sanctions for filing a false or frivolous complaint. 
    If the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, determines that one or more allegations of a complaint of discrimination or retaliation are false, and that the complainant knew them to be false when filed or at the time the complainant requested arbitration, or that one or more of the allegations of a complaint are so frivolous that they are wholly without merit, the Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, may refuse to review or investigate any complaint filed under this policy by the same party for a period of up to three years. The Executive Director of the Council, or his/her designee, may also determine that 1) monetary sanctions be imposed against the complainant in the amount of the costs incurred by the city and/or the bidder in the investigation and review of the false or frivolous complaint, including reasonable attorney's fees; and 2) that MBE, WBE and/or SBE certification may be denied, or revoked, for up to one year for filing a frivolous or false complaint. The Council shall have authority and discretion to impose one or more of such remedies when, in their view, the totality of the evidence reflects such a measure is necessary to deter future abuse of this policy and process. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.47. - Criminal sanction for fraud. 
(A)  The Council shall determine whether substantial evidence is available indicating that fraud or other unlawful activity has been committed by: 
(1)  An MBE, WBE or SBE certification or recertification applicant; 
(2)  A certified MBE, WBE or SBE or majority prime contractor falsely reporting the utilization of MBE, WBE or SBE subcontractors; 
(3)  An individual or firm attempting to benefit from or participate in the MBE, WBE or SBE program through fronting activity or false representation of a commercially useful function; or 
(4)  Whether other fraudulent or unlawful activity has occurred. 
(B)  If the Council determines that substantial evidence exists indicating fraud or other unlawful activity has occurred pursuant to Section 35.48(A), the matter shall be referred to the appropriate legal authorities for criminal prosecution; and, in the event a conviction or guilty plea is obtained stemming from such criminal prosecution, the business entity and its principals shall be barred from participation in city contracts from a minimum of one year and may be barred permanently from participation in city contracts. 
(C)  Fronting activity shall be defined as any occurrence of collusion between an MBE, WBE or SBE and a majority business enterprise for the purpose of exploiting the MBEs, WBEs or SBEs certification status to primarily benefit a majority firm without the performance of any commercially useful function by that MBE, WBE or SBE. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.48. - Prompt payments to subcontractors and suppliers. 
    Any contractor, subcontractor or supplier participating in a City contract agrees to comply with R.C. § 4113.61 regarding prompt payments to subcontractors and suppliers. The text of R.C. § 4113.61, including any subsequent amendments, shall be incorporated herein as if the same were fully rewritten. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.49. - Sunset provision. 
    This division shall expire ten years from the effective date as set forth in § 35.52, unless the Commission, after conducting a public hearing, finds that the purposes identified herein have not yet been achieved, in which case this division may be extended for an additional five-year period subject to the annual review provided for herein. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.50. - Severability. 
    If any provisions of this division or any application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this division which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications, and are to this end declared to be severable. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.51. - Effective date. 
    This division shall become effective immediately upon passage. 
(Ord. 31023-10, passed 9-29-10) 
Sec. 35.52. - Reserved.

DIVISION 7. - PAYMENT OF LIVING WAGES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 31313-14, § 1, passed June 18, 2014, amended Div. 7 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 7, §§ 35-70-35-74, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. 30270-03, passed July 16, 2003, and Ord. 30829-09, passed February 18, 2009. 

Sec. 35.70. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances (R.C.G.O.), the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively, regardless of whether or not the words and phrases are capitalized: 
    Contractor. A party to a service contract with the city, including any subcontractor(s) of such contractor retained to provide services covered under a service contract. 
    Employee. Individuals residing in the State of Ohio who may be required or directed by any contractor or subcontractor, in consideration of direct or indirect financial gain or profit, to engage in any employment, but specifically excluding individuals working less than an average of 36 hours per week and those engaged as a volunteer, temporary employee or intern. 
    Service contract. A contract, or multiple contracts in a single calendar year, between the city and a contractor to provide the city with at least $100,000.00 of services a year, but not including contracts for the lease or purchase of goods or other property, or requiring a license or use of intellectual property, or involving the mixed purchase of materials and services, unless the cost of the services exceeds the cost of the materials and the cost of such services equals at least $100,000.00 a year. 
    Volunteer. Means a person who renders aid, performs a service, or assumes an obligation, without compensation. 
    Temporary employee. An individual who works a certain regular season or period of the year, for a maximum of 32 weeks per calendar year, performing some work or activity limited to that season. 
    Intern. Any full-time student enrolled in a two or four year degree program at a college or university and who works on special projects in connection with his or her field of study, whose work hours do not exceed 1,500 hours per calendar year, and whose internship terminates no later than three months after graduation from the college or university. 
(Ord. 30829-09, passed 2-18-09; Ord. 31313-14, passed 6-18-14) 
Sec. 35.71. - Living wage requirements and exemptions. 
(A)  A contractor shall pay a living wage to its full-time permanent employees, other than volunteers, temporary employees, and interns, providing direct and substantial services to the city pursuant to a service contract. This requirement does not apply to employees performing services that are only ancillary and supportive of other services provided to the city, or which are insubstantial and limited in scope, or which only indirectly benefit the city. 
(B)  A "living wage" is: 
(1)  An hourly wage of not less than 100 percent of the amount set forth as the poverty guideline for the 48 contiguous states and the District of Columbia, for a family unit of four, updated annually in the Federal Register by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services under authority of 42 U.S.C. § 9902(2), divided by the number 2080, if the employee is eligible to receive single coverage health care benefits within 90 days of employment; or 
(2)  An hourly wage of not less than 120 percent of the amount set forth as the poverty guideline for the 48 contiguous states and the District of Columbia, for a family unit of four, updated annually in the Federal Register by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services under authority of 42 U.S.C. § 9902(2), divided by the number 2080, if the employee is not eligible to receive single coverage health care benefits. 
(C)  The city shall pay its full-time permanent employees, other than volunteers, temporary employees, and interns, no less than the living wage. 
(D)  The following contractors are exempt from the requirements of this § 35.71: 
(1)  Non-profit organizations whose sole purpose is to provide cultural, social or educational services; 
(2)  Organizations whose primary mission is to provide job readiness and training services; 
(3)  Federal and state entities, including all departments, agencies and political subdivisions thereof; and 
(4)  Contractors employing fewer than 50 employees. 
(E)  Contractors awarded a service contract that specifically requires compliance with federal or state prevailing wage laws, including the Davis Bacon Act, are exempt from the requirements of this § 35.71, but only with respect to performance of services under that particular service contract. 
(Ord. 30829-09, passed 2-18-09; Ord. 31313-14, passed 6-18-14) 
Sec. 35.72. - Living wage compliance, enforcement and notices. 
(A)  All contractors, which are required to comply with §§ 35.70 to 35.74, shall post a notice stating that its employees may be subject to this ordinance and conspicuously listing the current living wage with and without single coverage medical benefits. This notice shall be written in English and Spanish and shall state the following: 
    "This employer is subject to the payment of living wages pursuant to Revised Code of General Ordinances § 35.71, and must pay eligible Employees 100 percent of the updated federal poverty level for a family of four divided by the number 2080, plus make available single coverage health care benefits within 90 days of employment. If the employer does not make single coverage health care benefits available, the wages paid to those employees must be 120 percent of the updated federal poverty level for a family of four divided by the number 2080." 
(B)  All contractors, which are required to comply with §§ 35.70 to 35.74, also shall inform its employees earning less than $12.00 per hour of their possible right to the federal Earned Income Credit ("EIC") under Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, 26 U.S.C. § 32, and shall make available to its employees forms informing them about the EIC and forms required to secure advance EIC payments. 
(C)  Prior to entering into a service contract, a contractor shall provide the city with such information as is reasonably necessary to enable the city to determine that employees performing services subject to § 35.71 are receiving a living wage. The City Manager, or authorized designee, upon receipt of a complaint or other evidence of a violation, may investigate and determine if a violation of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 has occurred. The city shall notify a contractor of an alleged violation and afford the contractor a reasonable opportunity to respond. Thereafter, the City Manager, or authorized designee, shall determine whether a violation has occurred, and shall notify the contractor in writing of that determination. Upon finding a violation, the City Manager, or authorized designee, may impose such sanctions as are reasonable including, but not limited to, the following: require the contractor to pay all affected employees a living wage, including back-pay, if necessary; suspend or terminate the service contract upon non-compliance; prohibit the contractor from performing service contracts for a fixed period of time or, upon multiple egregious violations, indefinitely. 
(D)  All contractors subject to compliance with the requirements of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 are expressly prohibited from retaliating against any employee who claims a violation of the provisions of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 or reports or testifies against the employer regarding an alleged violation. Affected employees also have the right to sue a contractor to enforce payment of the living wage as provided in this division. 
(Ord. 30829-09, passed 2-18-09; Ord. 31313-14, passed 6-18-14) 
Sec. 35.73. - Living wage review; severablity. 
    If any provision of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 is declared legally invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 30829-09, passed 2-18-09; Ord. 31313-14, passed 6-18-14) 
Sec. 35.74 - Living wage effective dates. 
    The provisions of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 shall apply to all service contracts consummated by the city after the effective date of this division and to existing service contracts that are amended after the effective date of this division, but only if the amendment triggers the requirement for the contractor to pay the living wage to its employees. The provisions of §§ 35.70 to 35.74 shall expire five years from the effective date of this division, unless extended by the Commission. hn0; (Ord. 30829-09, passed 2-18-09; Ord. 31313-14, passed 6-18-14) 
CHAPTER 36. - FINANCE AND TAXATION 
DIVISION 1. - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE 

Sec. 36.01. - Department of Finance. 
(A)  The Department of Finance is created and established, which department shall be organized into an Office of the Director, a Deputy Director and the following divisions: 
(1)  Division of Tax and Accounting Administration; and 
(2)  Division of Revenue Administration. 
(B)  The Office of the Director shall be in the charge of the Director who shall be responsible for and in overall charge of the department and all of its functions, and who shall also have the following powers and duties: the powers and duties as provided by the Charter, the ordinances of the city, and other applicable statutes and laws, but subject to the management and control of the City Manager in all matters. 
(C)  Division of Tax and Accounting Administration. This division shall be responsible for the keeping and supervision of all accounts; the payment of city and Municipal Court payrolls and invoices; the receipt and custody of all public monies of the city; the management of debt, including the sale of bonds and notes; the investment of funds; the promulgation of rules and regulations related to the city's income tax; and all other duties and responsibilities previously assigned by the Charter or ordinances to the Deputy Director of Finance, except those duties that have been specifically assigned by ordinance to any other department and/or division. 
(D)  Division of Revenue Administration. This division shall be responsible for meter reading, billing, customer service and collection of the city's water, sewer and storm tariffs and charges, and the enforcement of the rules and regulations of the Department of Water related thereto; the billing and collection of all moneys due to the city; the making and collection of special assessments; and all other duties and responsibilities previously assigned by the Charter or ordinances to the Revenue Manager, except those duties that have been specifically assigned by ordinance to any other department and/or division. 
(E)  Where necessary for the efficient operation of the Department of Finance, the Director may reassign or expand the functions of the various divisions, with the advice and consent of the City Manager. 
(F)  The Director, Deputy Director and the heads of the divisions above shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 16690, passed 5-25-49; Am. Ord. 24558, passed 8-15-73; Am. Ord. 29070-95, passed 8-30-95; Am. Ord. 29205-96, passed 4-17-96; Am. Ord. 31127-11, passed 12-21-11) 
Secs. 36.02-36.09. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 1A. - GRANT APPLICATIONS 

Sec. 36.10. - City Manager to submit grant applications. 
    The City Manager may apply for grants, loans and advances in furtherance of municipal purposes. The City Manager may execute all documents necessary to accept any grant, loan or advance not in excess of $10,000.00. Any grant, loan or advance in excess of $10,000.00 may be accepted by the City Manager after approval by the City Commission. 
(Ord. 29989-01, passed 7-11-01; Am. Ord. 30765-08, passed 7-30-08) 
Sec. 36.11. - Defining the City Manager's report on general operations. 
(A)  The City Manager's report on general operations (hereinafter "City Manager's report") shall consist of contracts and other ordinary expenses necessary for the efficient operation of the city and may include transfers of cash within a single fund. Items listed on the City Manager's report may be approved by a majority of the Commission, in part or in whole, and, notwithstanding the provisions of Section 42 of the Charter of the City of Dayton, shall take immediate effect. 
(B)  The City Manager's report may include the following items which exceed administrative authority and require the approval of the Commission: 
(1)  Purchase order. A contractual agreement for goods and services needed for municipal operations that are issued by the City Purchasing Agent in accordance with the Code of General Ordinances. 
(2)  Award of contract. Approval for services or public improvements issued as a result of a request for proposals or a competitive bidding process other than by the Purchasing Agent. 
(3)  Agreement. A negotiated contractual agreement between the city and another entity for facilities, equipment, goods, services, or other items. 
(a)  Lease agreement. A negotiated lease of facilities or equipment for city use or from the city to another entity. 
(b)  Service agreement. A negotiated contractual arrangement between the city and a public or private entity to provide public services. 
(c)  Development agreement. A negotiated contractual arrangement between the city and a public or private entity using city resources, assets, or potential tax revenue for the purpose of encouraging job creation or community and economic development. 
(4)  Contract modification. Any renewal, change order, or other amendment to an existing purchase order, contract, or agreement. 
(5)  Other expenses. An internal financial transaction, payment of voucher, travel, membership, grant, contribution, legal settlement, fee, license, permit, or other miscellaneous expense to be paid by the city. 
(Ord. No. 31413-15, passed 7-1-15) 
Secs. 36.12-36.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLAIMS INVOLVING THE CITY 

Sec. 36.20. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of §§ 36.20 through 36.26 the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Claim against the city. Any demand made against the city by any person for the payment of damages for injury or loss to persons or property for which the city is liable according to the laws of the state. 
    Claim of the city. Any demand made by the city against any person for the payment of damages to property of the city for which a claim number has been assigned and an invoice issued by the Department of Finance, and any demand for the payment of money made by the city against any person for which an invoice has been issued by the Department of Finance at the request of the department to which the money is due. 
(Ord. 18695, passed 4-3-57; Am. Ord. 18990, passed 3-12-58; Am. Ord. 26649, passed 11-3-82) 
Sec. 36.21. - Law Director authorized to settle certain claims against city. 
    Claims against the city shall be submitted to the Director of Law. Upon receipt of the claims, the Director of Law shall make an investigation into the facts relating to the claims and into the nature and extent of the injury or loss for which damages are sought. The Director of Law is authorized to settle and adjust all claims where the amount of damages to be paid to the claimant does not exceed $2,500.00. Upon approval of the claims, the Director of Finance shall prepare and submit vouchers therefor which shall be drawn on an appropriate code as determined by the Director of Finance. 
(Ord. 18695, passed 4-3-57; Am. Ord. 26649, passed 11-3-82; Am. Ord. 29193-96, passed 4-3-96; Am. Ord. 30766-08, passed 7-30-08) 
Sec. 36.22. - Recommendation to pay claims against city. 
    The Director of Law shall forward to the City Manager all claims against the city which exceed $2,500.00 together with a recommendation for payment. The City Manager is authorized to settle and adjust all claims where the amount of damages to be paid to the claimant does not exceed $10,000.00. Upon approval of the claims, the Director of Finance shall prepare and submit vouchers therefor which shall be drawn on an appropriate code as determined by the Director of Finance. The Director of Law shall forward to the City Manager all claims against the city which exceed $10,000.00, together with a recommendation for payment, for approval by the City Commission. 
(Ord. 18695, passed 4-3-57; Am. Ord. 26649, passed 11-3-82; Am. Ord. 30766-08, passed 7-30-08) 
Sec. 36.23. - Law Director authorized to settle certain claims of city. 
    The Director of Law is authorized to settle and adjust any claim where the difference between the claim and the settlement is not in excess of $10,000.00 and upon the terms and conditions as the Director of Law deems advisable when liability for a claim is disputed by the person against whom the claim is made, and the Director of Law determines that it is not probable that the city would recover a judgment for the full amount of the claim if suit were filed, or that the judgment as might be obtained is not collectible in full. The Director of Law shall notify the Director of Finance of the approval of the settlement of the claims as herein provided. The Director of Finance shall thereafter remove the claim from the list of accounts receivable. 
(Ord. 18990, passed 3-12-58; Am. Ord. 26649, passed 11-3-82; Am. Ord. 29193-96, passed 4-3-96; Am. Ord. 30766-08, passed 7-30-08) 
Sec. 36.24. - Recommendation to settle claims of city. 
    The Director of Law shall forward to the City Manager all disputed claims of the city where the difference between the claim and the settlement offered is in excess of $10,000.00, together with his recommendation for acceptance of the settlement, for approval or disapproval by the City Commission. 
(Ord. 18990, passed 3-12-58; Am. Ord. 26649, passed 11-3-82; Am. Ord. 30766-08, passed 7-30-08) 
Sec. 36.25. - Membership in municipal and kindred associations. 
    Upon approval of the City Commission or the City Manager, membership in a municipal organization, or a kindred association devoted to a consideration of municipal affairs, city services, or city managerial or professional careers, may be held in the name of the city, a department of the city, a principal officer of the city, or any mid-management or professional, designated by a principal officer, who is a full-time, salaried employee of the city, not governed by a collective bargaining agreement. However, no individual membership shall be paid unless it is consistent with the general policy established by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 18321, passed 10-26-55; Am. Ord. 19568, passed 3-16-60; Am. Ord. 28395, passed 9-18-91; Am. Ord. 29926, 2-13-01) 
Sec. 36.26. - Transfer of materials and supplies. 
    Whenever any material or supplies of any kind have been purchased and are held for any municipal purpose, the City Manager may authorize the transfer of the material or supplies for any other municipal use, if in his discretion it is to the advantage of the city so to do. When the transfer is made the appropriation out of which the material or supplies were or might have been purchased shall be credited with the purchase price thereof and a corresponding charge made to the fund which might be used for the purchase thereof for the use for which it is transferred. 
(Ord. 10158, passed 4-19-16) 
Secs. 36.27-36.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRANSFERS OF CITY PROPERTY 

Sec. 36.40. - Sale of city owned property. 
    All personal property of the city, including personal property grown or produced in city operations, except that set forth in § 36.41, and all real property and interests therein, except that set forth in § 36.47, which is not needed or is unsuitable for public use or which has been condemned as useless by the Director of the department having control and custody thereof, and, in the case of real property which has been declared as not needed or as unsuitable for public use by the Commission, shall be sold by the City Purchasing Agent without further action of the Commission, after opportunity for competition to the best bidder and under the terms and conditions as the City Purchasing Agent, together with the Director of the department, determine. The sales are to be final upon approval by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 17161, passed 5-23-51; Am. Ord. 23211, passed 1-8-69) 
State Law reference- Lease or sale of municipal property, see R.C. § 721.01 
Sec. 36.41. - Trade-ins. 
    The City Purchasing Agent, when purchasing new equipment or vehicles, may trade in on the purchase of new equipment or vehicles such obsolete and worn out municipal equipment, including motor vehicles, not needed or unsuitable for public use or which has been condemned as useless by the director of a department; otherwise the obsolete and worn out municipal equipment, including motor vehicles, shall be sold in the manner herein provided for the sale of other personal property. 
(Ord. 17161, passed 5-23-51; Am. Ord. 23211, passed 1-8-69) 
Sec. 36.42. - Opportunity for competition. 
    Opportunity for competition as provided for in § 36.40, shall be determined by the City Purchasing Agent as the method most likely to produce the best price and the best terms and conditions for the city and shall include: 
(A)  Open competitive bidding after at least one advertisement for bids has been published in the newspaper with which the city has a contract for public advertisement; or 
(B)  Sealed bids after advertisement as provided in subsection (A); or 
(C)  Oral or written bids from any source after failure of the property to sell by competitive bidding as provided in subsections (A) or (B); or 
(D)  The sale of personal property grown or produced in city operations by oral or written bids from any source, without advertisement. Firewood from city property may be sold on the open market to the public for at least a minimum price and upon the terms and conditions as set by the City Purchasing Agent. 
(Ord. 17161, passed 5-23-51; Am. Ord. 23211, passed 18-69; Am. Ord. 28451, passed 12-11-91) 
Sec. 36.43. - Deeds and other documents of conveyance. 
    Unless otherwise restricted, all deeds conveying real property or interests therein, as well as leases, bills of sale, purchase agreements, and other instruments of conveyance, shall be signed on behalf of the city by the City Manager and/or his/her authorized designee. 
(Ord. 17277, passed 12-19-51; Am. Ord. 23211, passed 1-8-69; Am. Ord. 28890-94, passed 9-21-94) 
Sec. 36.44. - Special provision. 
    Unless otherwise provided by the Commission, in the case of a specific sale, exchange, or disposition, the provisions of §§ 36.40, 36.41, 36.42 and 36.43, shall be the procedure for the sale, exchange or disposition of personal property, real property and interests therein of the city not needed or unsuitable for public use or which has been condemned as useless by the Director of a department, and in the case of real property, which has been declared not needed or as unsuitable for public use by the Commission. 
(Ord. 17277, passed 12-19-51; Am. Ord. 23211, passed 1-8-69) 
Sec. 36.45. - Sale of realty previously declared available. 
    Real property which has been declared as not needed for any public use or municipal purpose by the Commission prior to January 8, 1969 and which remains unsold on that date, shall be sold as provided in §§ 36.42, 36.43 and 36.44, notwithstanding the terms, conditions, or methods provided in the ordinance declaring the real estate as not needed for any public use or municipal purpose. 
(Ord. 23211, passed 1-8-69) 
Sec. 36.46. - Certain sales without competition authorized. 
    The sale, exchange, or disposition of city owned real property or interest therein to the state or its subdivisions, or to the federal government or its instrumentalities, or to other public bodies or private corporations having the power of eminent domain, or to any corporation organized or qualified under R.C. Chapters 1724 or 1728, or to any public or private body or corporation to which the laws of the state authorize municipal corporations to sell property at private sale and without competition, or sales for urban renewal purposes, may be sold, exchanged, or disposed of, without opportunity for competition or other requirements except as may be provided by the Commission in the ordinance authorizing the sale, exchange, or disposition. 
(Ord. 23211, passed 1-8-69) 
Sec. 36.47. - Lease of city owned realty. 
(A)  The City Manager, or, upon approval of the City Manager, the Director of the department having control or custody of the premises to be leased, is authorized to negotiate leases of city-owned real estate using methods, by competitive bidding, direct negotiation, or otherwise, as in each case to him may seem best in order to secure the highest rent obtainable. 
(B)  The City Manager is authorized to execute leases on behalf of the city for the premises when the term of the lease is not in excess of three years, not including renewal periods, and the lease provides for termination at the end of any month, and after giving not more than 60 days' notice thereof, if the leased premises are needed for any municipal purpose. 
(C)  The City Manager is authorized to execute leases on behalf of the city upon any other terms and conditions than herein provided upon approval of the Commission by motion adopted in the usual manner and spread upon its minutes. 
(Ord. 13452, passed 12-14-27; Am. Ord. 22534, passed 6-7-67; Am. Ord. 31314-14, passed 6-25-14) 
Sec. 36.48. - Subordination of mortgage. 
    The City Manager is authorized to execute any and all instruments necessary to subordinate any mortgage interest the city may hold in a parcel of real estate used for housing whenever the City Manager determines that such subordination (1) is beneficial to housing within the city, (2) is necessary for the owner of the real estate to (a) obtain financing for improvements to the real estate, or (b) refinance an existing mortgage when the refinancing is for the purpose of securing a more favorable loan, and (3) will not lower the priority of the city's mortgage interest. 
(Ord. 29988-01, passed 7-11-01) 
Sec. 36.49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ASSESSMENTS ON IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 36.50. - Interest on delayed improvement assessment. 
    Whenever assessments have been or may be levied for public improvements and have been or may be paid into the City Treasury pursuant to the requirements of the ordinance levying the assessments, if for any reason the letting of the contract and the beginning of the work thereunder is delayed more than four months after the time of payment fixed in the assessing ordinance has expired, it shall be lawful and the Director of Finance is authorized and directed to pay to the persons as have or shall hereafter pay the assessments and who shall make a demand therefor, the amount of interest which the city receives from the depository of the funds from the date the assessment is paid in to a date within 60 days of the time when the work upon the improvement has been commenced. That date shall be the first date when the assessment is paid in. The date the work is commenced shall be fixed and determined by the certificate of the Director of Urban Development to the Director of Finance. 
(Ord. 10369, passed 11-22-16) 
Cross reference- Improvements and assessments, see Charter §§ 108 through 141. 
Sec. 36.51. - Report on improvement completion. 
    It is made the duty of the Director of Urban Development to report in writing to the Director of Finance the completion of each improvement for which special assessments have been levied as soon as all work to be paid for from the special assessment fund for that improvement has been completed. 
(Ord. 10441, passed 8-14-17) 
Sec. 36.52. - Rebate computed. 
    The Director of Finance, upon receipt of the report on improvement completion from the Director of Urban Development, shall compute the rate of the rebate by the foot front of the property assessed on the foot-frontage plan or proportioned to the amount paid where the assessments are made according to benefits or value, and he shall prepare a list setting forth the amount to be rebated to every person assessed for the improvement. The Director of Finance shall then transmit to the Commission the completion report of the Director of Urban Development and his report showing the rate of the rebate and the rebate list. 
(Ord. 10441, passed 3-14-17) 
Sec. 36.53. - Rebate payments. 
    The Commission upon receipt of the reports on improvement competition shall by vote direct the Director of Finance to proceed with the rebate, or if it be insufficient in amount to justify the expense and difficulty of making the rebate, shall direct that no rebate be made, if being the intention of the Commission, however, that rebate shall be made of all amounts over $0.01. 
(Ord. 10441, passed 3-14-17) 
Secs. 36.54-36.59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OFFICERS OF SINKING FUND TRUSTEES 

Sec. 36.60. - City Treasurer serves as Assistant Secretary of Sinking Fund Trustees. 
    The position of Assistant Secretary of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund of the city is created; and whoever shall serve in the position of City Treasurer, also shall serve ex-officio as Assistant Secretary of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund, for and during the period of his service as City Treasurer, unless otherwise ordered by motion by the Commission, which motion shall be spread upon the minutes of the Commission. 
(Ord. 11753, passed 1-17-23) 
Sec. 36.61. - Duties of Assistant Secretary of Sinking Fund Trustees. 
    It shall be the duty of the Assistant Secretary of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund to keep all the books, registers, records, papers and accounts of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund and to perform all the clerical work, bookkeeping and accounting necessary to properly carry on all the business, affairs and transactions of the sinking fund and keep all necessary and proper records thereof, and to perform any other and further duties as may be required by the trustees of the Sinking Fund or any officer or committee thereof acting within the scope of his or its authority in the premises, and to perform further duties as may be specified hereafter by ordinance. 
(Ord. 11753, passed 1-17-23) 
Sec. 36.62. - Salary of assistant secretary. 
    The salary of the Assistant Secretary of the Sinking Fund Trustees shall be equivalent to one-half the rate of the annual salary of the City Treasurer as shall be specified in the annual appropriation ordinance for each year, and shall be payable in cash in semi-monthly installments out of monies available therefor in the Sinking Fund; provided, that nothing herein shall be construed as an addition to the salary of the City Treasurer at any time, it being the intention thereof that one-half the amount of the rate of annual salary of the City Treasurer, as fixed each year by the annual appropriation ordinance, shall be appropriated by the ordinance and paid out of the General Fund of the city and an amount equal to one-half the rate of the salary, as fixed each year, shall be paid from the sinking fund of the city, the reason being that the experience has been that the City Treasurer has been and is required to divide his time approximately equally between his duties as Treasurer and for the Sinking Fund. 
(Ord. 11753, passed 1-17-23) 
Sec. 36.63. - Special Assessment Auditing Clerk of Sinking Fund Trustees. 
    The position of Special Assessment Auditing Clerk of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund of the city is created and any clerk of the city designated by the Director of Finance so to do shall serve ex-officio as the Special Assessment Auditing Clerk of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund for and during the period of his service as clerk for the city unless otherwise ordered by motion of the Commission, which motion shall be spread upon the minutes of the Commission. 
(Ord. 14215, passed 4-9-30) 
Sec. 36.64. - Duties of Special Assessment Auditing Clerk. 
    It shall be the duty of the Special Assessment Auditing Clerk of the Trustees of the Sinking Fund to audit the records of all paid and unpaid special assessments levied by the city which have been certified to the County Auditor for collection and keep all necessary and proper records of the audit showing the amount of the special assessments collected and paid into the Sinking Fund, and to perform other and further duties as may be required by the Trustees of the Sinking Fund or any officer or committee thereof acting within the scope of his or its authority in the premises, and to perform further duties as may be specified hereafter by ordinance. 
(Ord. 14215, passed 4-9-30) 
Sec. 36.65. - Salary of Special Assessment Auditing Clerk. 
    The salary of the Special Assessment Auditing Clerk is fixed at the rate of $65.00 per month, payable in semi-monthly installments out of money available therefor in the Sinking Fund, which sum shall be treated merely as part payment of the clerk's salary, the balance of which shall be paid as specified in the annual appropriation ordinance for each year or as otherwise provided; provided, that nothing herein contained shall be construed as an addition to the salary of any clerk, it being the intention hereof that provision be made for the payment of a part of one clerk's salary from the Sinking Fund because a great portion of the time of a clerk from the Finance Department is required each year to audit the special assessments for the Sinking Fund Trustees. 
(Ord. 14215, passed 4-9-30) 
DIVISION 6. - RESERVED 

Secs. 36.66-36.99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - INCOME TAX 

Sec. 36.100. - Purpose. 
    To provide funds for municipal purposes, including but not limited to general municipal operations, maintenance, acquisition of new equipment, and the provision of municipal services, facilities, and capital improvements, there shall be and is hereby levied a tax on an annual basis on the income of every person residing in or earning or receiving income in the City of Dayton, which tax is measured by the person's municipal taxable income, all as hereinafter provided. 
    The taxes levied under this chapter shall be levied in accordance with the provisions and limitations set forth in Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code to the fullest extent required for the city to continue to levy those taxes. The required provisions and limitations of Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code are hereby incorporated into this chapter, and those required provisions or limitations of Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code shall control to the extent there is a conflict between a provision or limitation of this chapter and an express provision or limitation of Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 30317-03, passed 12-23-03; Am. Ord. 30414-04, passed 12-22-04; Am. Ord. 30767-08, passed 7-30-08; Am. Ord. 31458-15, passed 11-25-15) 
Sec. 36.101. - Definitions. 
(A)  As used herein, all references in this chapter to provisions or limitations of Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code and to any Section of that Chapter 718 shall include those provisions or limitations of that chapter or section as in effect on January 1, 2016, of any successor statute, and of any subsequent amendment to that chapter or section or a successor statute in effect from time to time to the fullest possible extent required for the city to continue to levy the taxes specified under this chapter. 
(B)  The following terms as used in this chapter (either directly or by reference to Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code) shall have the meanings ascribed to them in Section 718.01 of the Ohio Revised Code: "municipal taxable income"; "income"; "exempt income"; "net profit"; "adjusted federal taxable income"; "Schedule C"; "Schedule E"; "Schedule F"; "Internal Revenue Code"; "resident"; "nonresident"; "taxpayer"; "person"; "pass-through entity"; "S corporation"; "single member limited liability company"; "limited liability company"; "qualifying wages"; "intangible income"; "taxable year"; "tax administrator"; "employer"; "employee"; "other payer"; "calendar quarter"; "Form 2106"; "municipal corporation"; "disregarded entity"; "generic form"; "tax return preparer"; "Ohio business gateway"; "local board of tax review" and "board of tax review"; "net operating loss"; "postal service"; "certified mail," "express mail," and "United States mail"; "postmark date" and "date of postmark"; "related member"; "related entity"; "assessment"; "taxpayer's rights and responsibilities"; "pre-2017 net operating loss carryforward"; "small employer"; "audit"; and "publicly traded partnership." Further, any other term used in this chapter that is not otherwise defined in this chapter and that is defined in Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code shall have the same meaning as is ascribed to it in Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(C)  Any term used in this chapter that is not otherwise defined in this chapter or by reference to Section 718.01 of the Ohio Revised Code shall have the same meaning as when used in a comparable context in laws of the United States relating to federal income taxation or in Title LVII of the Ohio Revised Code, unless a different meaning is clearly required. If a term used in this chapter that is not otherwise defined in this chapter or by reference to Section 718.01 of the Ohio Revised Code is used in a comparable context in both the laws of the United States relating to federal income tax and in Title LVII of the Ohio Revised Code and the use is not consistent, then the use of the term in the laws of the United States relating to federal income tax shall control over the use of the term in Title LVII of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(D)  For purposes of this chapter, references in Chapter 718 of the Ohio Revised Code to "a municipal corporation" shall mean the city, except as and if the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
(E)  As used in this chapter the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except as and if the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning, and except as and if the meaning ascribed in this section to a word conflicts with the meaning ascribed to that same word in Section 718.01 of the Ohio Revised Code, in which case the meaning ascribed to that word by Section 718.01 of the Ohio Revised Code shall control. 
    Business means an enterprise, activity, profession or undertaking of any nature conducted for profit or ordinarily conducted for profit, whether by an individual, pass-through entity, corporation or any other entity, including but not limited to the renting or leasing of property, real, personal or mixed. 
    City means the City of Dayton, Ohio.
