(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74; Am. Ord. 26931, passed 1-4-84; Am. Ord. 27279, passed 10-23-85; Am. Ord. 28195, passed 10-10-90) 
Sec. 36.119. - Investigative powers of Superintendent; penalty for divulging confidential information. 
(A)  The Superintendent, or any authorized employee, is authorized to examine the books, papers, records and copies of federal income tax returns of any employer or of any taxpayer or person subject to, or whom the Superintendent believes is subject to the provisions of this chapter, for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of any return made, or, if no return was made, to ascertain the tax due, if any. Every such employer, supposed employer, taxpayer, or supposed taxpayer, is directed and required to furnish within ten days following a written request by the Superintendent, or his duly authorized agent or employee, the means, facilities and opportunity for making such examinations and investigations as are authorized. 
(B)  The Superintendent is authorized to order any person presumed to have knowledge of the facts to appear before him and may examine such person, under oath, concerning any income which was or should have been returned for taxation or any transaction tending to affect such income. For this purpose he may compel the production of books, papers, records, and copies of federal income tax returns and the attendance of all persons before him, whether as parties or witnesses, whenever he believes such persons have knowledge of such income or information pertinent to such inquiry. 
(C)  The refusal to produce books, papers, records, and copies of federal income tax returns, or the refusal to submit to such examination by any employer or person subject or presumed to be subject to the tax or by any officer, agent or employee of a person subject to the tax or required to withhold tax or the failure of any person to comply with the provisions of this section or with an order or subpoena of the Superintendent authorized by this chapter shall be deemed a violation, punishable as provided in § 36.113. 
(D)  Any information gained as the result of any retainers, investigations, hearings, or verifications required or authorized shall be confidential, except for official purposes, or except when ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction or except in the exchange of tax information with other municipal corporations. Any person divulging such information shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Each disclosure shall constitute a separate offense. 
(E)  In addition to the above penalty, any employee of the city who violates the provisions of this section relative to the disclosure of confidential information shall be guilty of an offense punishable by immediate dismissal. 
(F)  If, but for this section, an individual would have been privileged to withhold any information given, and he complies with subsection (B) of this section compelling him to give an answer or produce any information, he shall not be prosecuted or subjected to any criminal penalty in the courts of the this state for or on account of any transaction or matter concerning which, in compliance with the order he gave an answer or produced any information. 
(G)  An individual granted immunity under this section may be subjected to a criminal penalty for any violation of this chapter, for failing to answer or failing to produce information in compliance with an order of the Superintendent. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74; Am. Ord. 28195, passed 10-10-90; Am. Ord. 28657-93, passed 3-3-93) 
Sec. 36.120. - Board of Adjudication created; composition; officers; quorum. 
(A)  A Board of Adjudication, consisting of the City Manager, or a person designated by him, the Director of Finance, or a person designated by him, and the City Attorney, or an Assistant City Attorney designated by him, is created. 
(B)  The Board shall select, each year for a one-year term, one of its members to serve as chairman and one to serve as secretary. 
(C)  A majority of the members of the Board shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74) 
Sec. 36.121. - Procedural rules; hearings. 
    The Board shall adopt its own procedural rules and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All hearings of the Board shall be conducted privately and the provisions of § 36.119 with reference to the confidential character or information required to be disclosed shall apply to such matters as may be presented to the Board. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74) 
Sec. 36.122. - Authority of Board. 
    The Board shall have the authority, upon request of the Superintendent, to modify in whole or in part, any assessment of tax, penalty or interest. In addition, the Board may authorize the Superintendent to accept partial payments for a period in excess of the time authorized in § 36.118. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74) 
Sec. 36.123. - Board of Tax Appeals created; officers; compensation; quorum. 
(A)  A Board of Tax Appeals, consisting of three representative citizens of the city, not otherwise employed by the city, to be appointed by the City Commission for a term of three years, is created. 
(B)  One of the members of the Board shall be chosen by the members as chairman. 
(C)  All members may receive per diem compensation to be fixed by the City Commission. 
(D)  A majority of the members of the Board shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74; Am. Ord. 26590, passed 8-25-82) 
Sec. 36.124. - Procedural rules; hearings. 
    The Board shall adopt its own procedural rules and keep a record of its proceedings. All hearings by the Board may be conducted privately and the provisions of § 36.119 with reference to the confidential character of information required to be disclosed shall apply to such matters as may be heard on appeal before the Board. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74) 
Sec. 36.125. - Authority of Board. 
    The Board shall, on hearing, have authority to affirm, reverse, or modify any assessment, ruling, or decision, or any part thereof, made by the Superintendent from which an appeal has been filed as provided in § 36.118. 
(Ord. 23542, passed 11-19-69; Am. Ord. 24845, passed 12-11-74) 
Secs. 36.126-36.129. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - HOTEL LODGING EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 36.130. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of §§ 36.130 through 36.143 the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Board of Tax Appeals. The Board created by § 36.123. 
    Hotel. Every establishment kept, used, maintained, advertised, or held out to the public to be a place where sleeping accommodations are offered to guests, in which five or more rooms are used for the accommodation of such guests, whether such rooms are in one or several structures. 
    Occupancy. The use or possession, or right to the use or possession of any room or rooms or space or portion thereof, in any hotel for dwelling, lodging, or sleeping purposes. The use or possession or right to use or possess any room or suite of connecting rooms as office space, banquet or private dining rooms or exhibit, sample, or display space, shall not be considered occupancy within the meaning of this definition unless the person exercising occupancy uses or possesses, or has the right to use or possess all or any portion of such rooms or suite of rooms for dwelling or sleeping purposes. 
    Operator. Any person who is the proprietor of the hotel whether in the capacity of owner, lessee, licensee, or any other capacity. Where the operator performs his functions through a managing agent of any type or character, other than an employee, the managing agent shall be deemed an operator for the purposes of this division and shall have the same duties and liabilities as his principal. Compliance with the provisions of §§ 36.131 through 36.143 by either the principal or the managing agent shall, however, be considered to be compliance by both. 
    Person. Individuals, receivers, assignees, trustees in bankruptcy, estates, firms, partnerships, associations, joint stock companies, joint ventures, clubs, societies, corporations, the state and its political subdivisions, and combinations of individuals of any form. 
    Rent. The consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credit, and property or service of any kind or nature, and also any amount for which the occupant is liable for the occupancy without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
    Superintendent of taxation (also referred to as Superintendent). The Superintendent of Taxation for the city or the person executing the duties of the Superintendent of Taxation. 
    Tax. The tax imposed by § 36.131. 
    Transient guests. Persons occupying a room or rooms for sleeping accommodations for less than 30 consecutive days. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.131. - Imposition of the tax. 
(A)  An excise tax on transactions by which lodging by a hotel is or is to be furnished to transient guests in hereby levied at the rate of three percent on all rents paid or to be paid by transient guests for lodging. 
(B)  This tax constitutes a liability owed by the transient guest to the city, which is extinguished only by payment to the operator as trustee for the city. The tax applies and is collectible when the lodging is furnished regardless of when the price is paid. 
(C)  For the purpose of the proper administration of §§ 36.131 through 36.143, and to prevent the evasion of the tax, it is presumed that all lodging furnished by hotels in the city to transient guests is subject to the tax until the contrary is established. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.132. - Prohibition against false evidence of tax exempt status. 
    No transient guest shall refuse to pay the full and exact tax, or present to the operator false evidence indicating that the lodging as furnished is not subject to the tax. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.133. - Transient guest to pay tax. 
    The tax shall be paid by the transient guest to the operator, and each operator shall collect from the transient guest the full and exact amount of the tax payable on each taxable transaction. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.134. - Tax to be separately stated and charged. 
(A)  The tax to be collected shall be stated and charged separately from the rent, and shown separately on any record thereof, at the time when the occupancy is arranged for or contracted. 
(B)  The tax shall be shown separately upon every evidence of occupancy or any bill or statement or charge made for said occupancy issued or delivered by the operator. 
(C)  The tax shall be paid by the occupant to the operator as trustee for and on account of the city, and the operator shall be liable for the collection thereof and for the tax. 
(D)  No operator shall advertise or state in any manner, whether directly or indirectly, that the tax, or any part thereof, will be assumed or absorbed by the operator, that it will not be added to the rent, or that, if added, any part will be refunded except in the manner provided in § 36.141. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.135. - Registration. 
(A)  On or before October 1, 1976, or within 30 days after commencing business, whichever is later, each operator shall register with the Superintendent upon forms provided by the Superintendent. Such registration shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and addresses of the hotel. 
(2)  The name, residence address, and telephone number of the operator. 
(3)  The name, residence address, and telephone number of the owner of the hotel if different from the operator. 
(4)  Any additional information required by the Superintendent. 
(B)  Upon the filing of such registration, the Superintendent shall issue to the operator a transient occupancy registration certificate to be at all times posted in a conspicuous place in the hotel. This certificate shall, among other things, state the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the hotel. 
(2)  The name of the operator. 
(3)  The date upon which the certificate was issued. 
(4)  This transient occupancy registration certificate signifies that the person named on the face thereof has fulfilled the requirements of § 36.135 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances of the City of Dayton by registering with the Superintendent of Taxation for the purpose of collecting from transient guests the Hotel Excise Tax levied by the city, and remitting said tax to the Superintendent. This certificate does not constitute a permit. 
(C)  The registration provided for in this section shall be renewed on or before October 1 of each year, and a new transient occupancy registration certificate shall be issued by the Superintendent. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.136. - Records; inspection and destruction. 
(A)  Each operator shall keep complete and accurate records of lodging furnished, together with a record of the tax collected thereon, and shall keep all invoices and such other pertinent documents relative thereto. If the operator furnishes lodging not subject to the tax, the operator's records shall show the identity of the exempt transient guest, and the reason such lodging was not subject to the tax. Such records and other documents shall be open during business hours to the inspection of the Superintendent, or his representative, and shall be preserved for a period of three years, unless the Superintendent, in writing, consents to their destruction within that period, or orders that such records be kept for a longer period of time. 
(B)  The Superintendent shall have such investigative powers with respect to §§ 36.130 through 36.143 as provided in § 36.119. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.137. - Reporting and remitting. 
(A)  Each operator shall, on or before the last day of the month following the close of each calendar quarter year, or at the close of any shorter or longer reporting period which may be established by the Superintendent, make a return to the Superintendent, on forms provided by him, of the total rents charged, and the amount of tax due. All claims for exemption from tax filed by occupants with the operator during the reporting period shall be filed with the report. 
(B)  At the time the return is filed, the full amount of the tax due shall be remitted to the Superintendent. 
(C)  The Superintendent may establish shorter or longer reporting periods for any operator if he deems it necessary in order to insure collection of the tax. The Superintendent may require further information in the return if such information is pertinent to the collection of the tax. Returns and payments are due immediately upon cessation of business for any reason. 
(D)  All of the tax collected by any operator shall be held in trust for the city until payment thereof is made to the Superintendent. 
(E)  All returns and payments submitted by an operator shall be treated as confidential by the Superintendent, and shall not be released by him except upon order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(F)  Any person divulging such information shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.138. - Penalties and interest. 
(A)  Any operator who fails to remit the tax within the time required shall pay a penalty equal to ten percent of the amount of the tax per month, in addition to the tax. 
(B)  If the Superintendent determines that the nonpayment of any remittance due under this division is due to fraud, a penalty equal to 25 percent of the tax shall be added thereto in addition to the other penalties stated in this section. 
(C)  In addition to the penalties herein provided, any operator who fails to remit the tax shall pay interest at a rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof, on the amount of the tax, exclusive of penalties, from the date on which the remittance first became delinquent until paid. 
(D)  No penalty as herein provided shall be imposed during the pendency of any appeal as provided in § 36.140. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.139. - Powers and duties of the Superintendent. 
(A)  The Superintendent is charged with the enforcement of §§ 36.130 through 36.143, and with respect thereto, shall have the powers, duties, and investigative powers provided in §§ 36.118 and 36.119. 
(B)  The Superintendent shall, subject to the approval of the Commission by motion, adopt, promulgate, and enforce rules and regulations providing for the administration and enforcement of §§ 36.130 through 36.143. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.140. - Appeal. 
    Any operator aggrieved by any decision of the Superintendent with respect to the amount of such tax, interest, and penalties, if any, may appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals as provided in § 36.118. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.141. - Collection of unpaid taxes and refunds. 
(A)  In addition to any criminal penalties which may be imposed by § 36.142, any tax required to be paid by a transient guest under the provisions of § 36.133, and any such tax collected by an operator which has not been paid to the city shall be collectible, together with any interest and penalties thereon, by civil suit. 
(B)  Tax, penalties, or interest erroneously paid, paid more than once, or overpaid shall not be refunded unless a claim for refund is made within three years from the date which such payment was made or the return was due. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.142. - Prohibitions. 
    Any person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree if he shall: 
(A)  Fail, neglect, or refuse to make any return; or 
(B)  Make an incomplete, false, or fraudulent return; or 
(C)  Knowingly fail or refuse to pay the tax, penalties, or interest; or 
(D)  Knowingly fail or refuse to collect the tax from transient guests and remit such tax to the Superintendent; or 
(E)  Refuse to permit the Superintendent or any duly authorized agent or employee to examine his records relating to the rental receipts of the operator; or 
(F)  Fail to appear before the Superintendent and to produce his records relating to the rental receipts of the operator upon orders or subpoena of the Superintendent; or 
(G)  Refuse to disclose to the Superintendent any information with respect to the rental receipts of the operator; or 
(H)  Fail to comply with the provisions of §§ 36.130 through 36.143, or any order or subpoena of the Superintendent; or 
(I)  Attempt to do anything whatsoever to avoid payment of the whole or any part of the tax, penalties, or interest imposed pursuant to § 36.131. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Sec. 36.143. - Allocation of funds. 
    There is established a special fund to be known as the Exhibition Center Fund. The funds collected under the provisions of §§ 36.130 through 36.142 shall be placed in the Exhibition Center Fund of the city, and used for such purposes as determined by the Commission. Provided, however, not less than 50 percent of such funds shall be used for the promotion and marketing of the city as a location for conventions, trade shows, and similar events. 
(Ord. 25147, passed 8-18-76) 
Secs. 36.144-36.200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - LIMITATIONS OF LIABILITY 

Sec. 36.201. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of §§ 36.201 through 36.209, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Action in tort. Claims, demands, actions, or suits based upon negligence, errors and omissions, nuisance, malpractice, intentional tort, products' liability, strict liability, and includes, but is not limited to the following theories of recovery: false arrest, false imprisonment, wrongful eviction, wrongful detention, malicious prosecution, discrimination, humiliation, invasion of privacy, libel, slander, defamation of character, false light, piracy and infringement of copyright or of property, erroneous service of civil or criminal papers, violation of civil rights, assault and battery, disparagement of property, inverse condemnation, and also includes, but is not limited to, claims, demands, actions, or suits, wherein the injuries include property damage, bodily injury, mental injury, mental anguish, emotional distress, shock, sickness, disease, disability, loss of wages, and loss of earning capacity, and also includes wrongful death and survival-type actions. 
    Nonstatutory basis. Based upon case-made law. 
    Occurrence. An accident or happening or event or a continuous or repeated exposure to conditions which results in personal injury, or damage to property. All such exposure to substantially the same general conditions existing at or emanating from one location shall be deemed one occurrence. 
    Public employee. Any employee, officer, official, whether elected or appointed, including any judicial officer, clerk of court, or employee thereof, and any paid or unpaid employee, representative, or agent of the city, whether or not identifiable by name. 
    Statutory basis. Based upon any enacted law, whether state, federal, or municipal, whether or not the law is expressed as a statute, ordinance, code, rule, regulation, or directive. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.202. - Application. 
(A)  All actions in tort against public employees, while acting in the scope of their authority, and the city for death, personal injury, or property damage shall be subject to the provisions of this division. 
(B)  All statutory and nonstatutory law, substantive or procedural, concerning claims against the city or public employee shall continue with full force and effect except as otherwise provided by this law. 
(C)  In the event any provisions of this law shall be determined to be unconstitutional, ultra vires or otherwise unenforceable as a matter of law, the remaining provisions shall to the extent possible continue with full force and effect. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.203. - Payments of claims and judgments; partial payments; priority of payments. 
    Subject to the limitations imposed by the provisions of § 36.205, the payments of claims, and judgments, approved for payment in accordance with the Charter or the Code, where the city or a public employee is or may be liable, shall be limited to available, unencumbered funds that have been specifically appropriated on an annual basis for payment of claims and judgments. Partial payments of claims or judgments may be made over successive years from funds subsequently appropriated. Priority of payment of carried over claims shall be given based on the date of the occurrence giving rise to liability. Priority of payment of carry over judgments shall be given to the filing date of the judgment. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.204. - Appropriation for payment of claims and judgments. 
    The City Manager shall annually submit to the City Commission a recommended appropriation for payment of claims and judgments. In making such recommendation, the following nonexclusive information may be considered: 
(A)  The past judgments and claims payments by the city; 
(B)  The monetary risk of all litigation against the city; 
(C)  The reasonable value of known unasserted claims and litigation; 
(D)  Necessary reserves to promote financial stability of the city; 
(E)  Priorities of city service delivery; 
(F)  Projected expansion or contraction of city income; 
(G)  Comparative data relative to payment of claims and judgments of the eight most populous cities of the state; 
(H)  Unsatisfied judgments and claims approved for payment in previous years; and 
(I)  Overall financial stability of the city. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.205. - Limitation of liability. 
    The amount of damages recoverable against the city and any public employee for death, personal injury, or property damage arising out of a single occurrence, or sequence of occurrences shall be limited as follows: 
(A)  When the city or public employee has insurance coverage for an occurrence or sequence of occurrences, payment of claims and judgments in which the city or a public employee is or may be liable and obligated to pay may be made to the extent insurance proceeds or insurance indemnification is available and payable, in addition to any deductibles or self-insurance retention required by applicable insurance contracts. 
(B)  When the city or public employee has no insurance coverage relative to an occurrence or sequence of occurrences the extent to which the city and public employee are obligated to pay damages shall be as follows: 
(1)  When the city and public employee is or may be, jointly or severally, liable for actions in tort under R.C. § 723.01 and § 701.02, or other statute, or combination of statutory and nonstatutory basis, a sum not in excess of $250,000.00 per person and $500,000.00 per occurrence, provided unencumbered funds are available and have been appropriated for such payment; 
(2)  When the city or public employee is or may be, jointly or severably, liable for actions in tort based solely on a nonstatutory basis, a sum not in excess of $250,000.00 per person and $500,000.00 per occurrence, provided unencumbered funds are available and have been appropriated for such payment; or 
(3)  The aggregate liability of the city for a single accident or occurrence, or sequence of accidents or occurrences, shall be apportioned equitably among all claimants and judgment holders therefor. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.206. - Acquisition of insurance. 
    Sections 36.201 through 36.209 shall not be construed to prevent the City Commission from authorizing the purchase of liability insurance for the city and public employees as named insureds and persons insured, or to authorize payment of any agreed deductibles, self-insurance retention or amounts subject to indemnification required by the applicable insurance contracts. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.207. - Punitive damages. 
    Regarding any occurrence in which the city or public employee is or may be liable, the city shall not pay, nor be obligated to pay any amount for punitive or exemplary damages whatsoever. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.208. - Other rights and remedies. 
    Nothing in §§ 36.201 through 36.209 shall be construed to abrogate or restrict any immunity or right of indemnification of the city or public employee, whether by insurance or otherwise, or to confer a right of action upon any person against the city or public employee, nor shall anything in such sections be construed to impose liability on the city or public employee for any neglect or wrongful act or omission. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Sec. 36.209. - Effective date. 
    The limitations set forth in this division shall apply to all occurrences which give rise to actions in tort after the effective date of the ordinance enacting this section. 
(Ord. 27141, passed 1-30-85) 
Secs. 36.210-36.300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - TREASURY INVESTMENT BOARD 

Sec. 36.301. - Treasury Investment Board created; purpose; membership; officers. 
    A Treasury Investment Board ("the Board") consisting of the City Manager, the Deputy City Manager, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Director of Finance, is created for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of §§ 36.301 through 36.322. Each year in January, the Board shall elect a president, vice-president and secretary. The Board may prescribe rules and regulations pertaining to investment of public monies, the transaction of business coming before the Board, and other incidental matters and shall keep minutes of its meetings and proceedings. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.302. - Investment of city funds. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee is authorized to invest public monies in the City Treasury as specified in §§ 36.301 through 36.322. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.303. - Investment procedure. 
(A)  The Director of Finance or his/her designee shall prepare and keep current a cash budget the form of which shall be approved by the Board. 
(B)  Based upon estimated cash flow requirements as shown in the cash budget, the Director of Finance or his/her designee may purchase securities in accordance with §§ 36.301 through 36.322 as is in the interest of the city. Such purchases will not be made at a price in excess of the current market value of the securities. 
(C)  Whenever it is necessary to convert any investment into cash, the Director of Finance or his/her designee may sell securities for no less than their current market value. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.304. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36.305. - The treasury investment account. 
(A)  The Director of Finance or his/her designee shall establish and maintain an account to be known as "The Treasury Investment Account," in which he/she shall enter all transactions relating to all interest earned and any gains or losses sustained through the sale of investments. 
(B)  The Director of Finance or his/her designee may transfer funds in the treasury investment account to the various funds of the city as calculated according to the requirements of this section with the approval of the City Manager. The Director of Finance shall report semi-annually to the City Manager and the Treasury Investment Board all such transfers made. 
(1)  All interest earned or other revenues derived from the investment of water, sewer, airport, golf or other enterprise funds, or of the proceeds obtained from or through the issuance of related bonds, payable from the fund(s), shall be transferred to the respective fund(s); 
(2)  All interest earned or other revenues derived from the investment of federal revenue sharing or forfeiture funds, or other such funds from which interest earned or other revenues derived from the investment thereof is required by law to be allocated thereto or proceeds obtained from or through the issuance of such bonds, shall be transferred to such funds; 
(3)  The remaining interest earned or other revenues derived from the treasury investment account shall be transferred to the general fund; 
(4)  Notwithstanding the above, any portion of interest earned on invested bond proceeds which are determined to be excess interest and therefore subject to the federal arbitrage law shall be transferred to the United States Treasury. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27392, passed 5-21-86; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.306. - Custodian of city securities. 
(A)  All securities belonging to the Treasury of the City of Dayton may be placed in the custody of any member of the federal reserve banking system, and such member shall issue its custodian receipt or other statement of account to the Director of Finance or his/her designee of the City of Dayton. 
(B)  Certificates of deposit, notwithstanding the above, may be kept by the Director of Finance or his/her designee in a vault on city premises. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.307. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36.308. - Deposit of public monies. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee shall deposit all public monies in financial institutions with depository agreements in accordance with policies adopted by the Treasury Investment Board or shall invest public monies in authorized securities. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.309. - Cash on hand retained by Director of Finance or his/her designee. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee of the city may keep in the vaults of his/her office as cash on hand, an amount of money not to exceed $20,000.00. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.310. - Prudent investment guideline. 
(A)  The primary objective of the city's investment activities is the preservation and protection of investment principal. 
(B)  Investments shall be made with the exercise of that degree of judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the conservative management of their own affairs, not for speculation but for investment, considering the safety of their capital as well as the expected income to be derived. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.311. - Maturity. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee may invest public monies in authorized securities which mature within five years from the date the investment was completed except as follows: 
(A)  Repurchase agreements shall not exceed 30 days; 
(B)  Money market mutual funds shall not have an average portfolio maturity which exceeds 90 days; 
(C)  The portfolio shall be sufficiently liquid to meet all operating obligations of the city; 
(D)  City of Dayton notes or bonds up to 20 years maturity; 
(E)  Sixty percent of the portfolio may be invested in U.S. Treasury notes and bonds or obligations of any federal government agency or government sponsored enterprise or corporate obligations or obligations of any of the states of the United States or any of their political subdivisions with maturities of greater than three years and less than or equal to five years. The percentage limitation of 30 percent shall be determined and calculated by the Finance Director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.312. - Investment limitations. 
(A)  Authorized Investments. The Treasury Investment Board may set a limit on the percentage of the portfolio which may be invested in each of the securities listed in § 36.314. The Treasury Investment Board may set limitations and restrictions of eligible investments and investment transactions. Such limitations and restrictions shall be detailed and defined within an investment policy, approved by the Treasury Investment Board. 
(B)  Institutions. With regards to certificates of deposit no single institution having a depository agreement with the City of Dayton shall hold more than five percent or such higher limit, not to exceed 20 percent of the city's portfolio, as may be permitted by the Director of Finance based on the institution's credit worthiness as determined by the Director. The Director of Finance or his/her designee shall not be required to liquidate securities solely to comply with this section. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.313. - Authorized financial institutions and dealers. 
(A)  For Certificates of Deposit. The Director of Finance or his/her designee may purchase certificates of deposit from financial institutions located within the State of Ohio which have a current depository agreement with the city. 
(B)  For Authorized Securities other than certificates of deposit. The Director of Finance or his/her designee may purchase authorized securities other than certificates of deposit only through financial institutions/dealers licensed to sell securities in the State of Ohio. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.314. - Authorized investments. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee may invest in the following securities: 
(A)  U.S. Treasury bills, notes and bonds; 
(B)  Obligations of any U.S. government agency, instrumentality, or government sponsored enterprise; 
(C)  Certificates of deposit; 
(D)  Repurchase agreements with institutions having a signed master repurchase agreement on file with the Director of Finance. Repurchase agreements shall have as collateral items listed in (A) or (B) of this section or as otherwise agreed to in the master repurchase agreement. Repurchase agreements shall be limited to primary United States Government securities dealers as recognized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for which eligible collateral pledged to secure such repurchase agreements is held in safekeeping by a third-party custodian bank as agreed to by the City of Dayton and its repurchase agreement counterparties; 
(E)  Securities lending agreements with institutions having a signed securities lending agreement on file with the Director of Finance. Securities lending agreements shall have as collateral any combination or amount of items listed in (A), (B), (K), or (L) of this section or as otherwise agreed to in the securities lending agreement; 
(F)  Banker's acceptances; 
(G)  Interest bearing demand deposit accounts; 
(H)  No-load money market mutual funds consisting exclusively of obligations described in (A) or (B) and repurchase agreements secured by such obligations; 
(I)  State of Ohio Treasurer's Investment Pool. (STAR Ohio) or any other investment alternative offered by, or sponsored by, the State Treasurer of Ohio; 
(J)  Securities of any of the states of the United States or any of their political subdivisions. Except for obligations of the City of Dayton, all such securities of any of the states of the United States or any of its political subdivisions shall be rated at least "AA" or the equivalent by a nationally recognized rating agency at the time of purchase; 
(K)  Commercial paper rated in the highest categories by at least two nationally recognized rating agencies; certain limitations and restrictions apply as defined under Chapter 135.35(A)(8)(a) of the Ohio Revised Code; and 
(L)  Corporate notes rated at least AA, or the equivalent, by a nationally recognized rating agency at the time of purchase. Purchases of corporate obligations may not exceed 15 percent of the portfolio. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.315. - Collateralization of certificates of deposit and savings accounts. 
(A)  All deposits of public monies in certificates of deposit made by the city and all savings accounts or interest bearing demand deposit accounts of the city shall be secured by pledged collateral as specified by R.C. § 135.18, or if the public depository has established a pool of collateral for its public deposits as specified by R.C. § 135.181. 
(B)  The requirements imposed by subsection (A) of this section shall constitute the minimum security for repayment of public deposits. The Treasury Investment Board may impose additional requirements on public depositories if deemed in the best interests of the city. 
(C)  The Director of Finance shall review the trustee agreements of depository banks annually. 
(D)  The Director of Finance shall to the extent practical conduct an audit at least annually of the collateral. 
(E)  Failure of the depository to abide by any of the provisions of this section for either individually pledged or pooled collateral is cause for immediate suspension of the institution as a qualified depository for any city funds. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.316. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36.316.1. - Delivery. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee shall require the delivery of purchased securities, on a delivery versus payment basis as follows: 
(A)  All securities and investments issued in Federal Reserve Bank book entry form or other electronic form shall be delivered to the city's designated custodian bank. All other investment assets not issued in electronic form shall be held under safekeeping arrangements as authorized and instructed by the Director of Finance or his/her designee. 
(B)  For securities described in R.C. § 36.314, delivery shall be in accordance with the terms of the master repurchase agreement which shall include custodian arrangements as agreed to by the Director of Finance. 
(Ord. 27578, passed 7-15-87; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.317. - Competitive bidding. 
(A)  Investment assets of the city shall be purchased and sold on a competitive basis. 
(B)  The Director of Finance or his/her designee may negotiate a certificate of deposit with the minority institution(s) located inside the city limits. For the purposes of this division the term "minority institution" shall have the same meaning as the term "minority bank" as defined by R.C. § 135.04(G)(1). 
(C)  The Finance Director or his/her designee may execute investment transactions through qualified minority broker/dealer firms. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.318. - Reserved. 
Sec. 36.319. - Reporting. 
    The Director of Finance or his/her designee will provide monthly reports to the Treasury Investment Board which shall include an inventory of all obligations and securities. The inventory shall include a description of each obligation or security, including type, cost, par value, maturity date, settlement date, and any coupon rate. Such monthly reports shall also include a complete record of all purchases and sales of the obligations and securities as defined in R.C. § 36.314. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.320. - Pooling of funds. 
    The Director of Finance is authorized to pool cash balances from the different funds of the city for investment purposes. 
(Ord. 27235, passed 8-14-85; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.321. - Custodian agreements. 
(A)  Notwithstanding the provisions of §§ 36.301 through 36.322, where funds are received by the Director of Finance or his/her designee derived from the sale of bonds by the city, which funds are dedicated and restricted by the bond indenture and the cash flow requirements are specified, the Director of Finance or his/her designee may enter into an agreement with a bank or trust company for the investment of such funds, pending their use for the purpose to which dedicated. 
(B)  Any agreements entered into pursuant to this section shall be upon such terms and conditions as approved by the Commission and as are consistent with the appropriate bond indenture. 
(Ord. 27325, passed 1-15-86; Am. Ord. 27743, passed 5-4-88; Am. Ord. 28064, passed 2-7-90; Am. Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Sec. 36.322. - Investment management agreements. 
(A)  Notwithstanding the provisions of §§ 36.301 through 36.322, the Finance Director may enter into an agreement with a bank, trust company or investment advisor registered with the S.E.C. for the investment of city funds. 
(B)  Any agreements entered into pursuant to this section shall be upon such terms and conditions as approved by the Commission. 
(Ord. 28968-94, passed 12-28-94; Ord. 31419-15, passed 7-29-15) 
Secs. 36.323-36.399. - Reserved. 
[DIVISION 11. - SOCIALLY RESPONSIBLE BANKING] 

Sec. 36.400. - Socially responsible banking. 
(A)  The Director of Finance, in selecting qualified depositories for city moneys per § 36.317, shall: 
(1)  Require that prospective bidders provide the city with data on their socially responsible banking practices; 
(2)  Utilize socially responsible banking performance as a factor in determining the winning bid; 
(3)  Accept bids for depository services only from financial institutions that have received a minimum rating of "Satisfactory" in their most recent Community Reinvestment Act review by the Office of the U.S. Comptroller of the Currency or the U.S. Federal Reserve Bank, or the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC); the Director may waive this requirement, with written notice to the City Commission, in the event that no qualified bidders apply, the federal program is no longer applicable, or to satisfy a compelling city need; 
(4)  Require prospective bidders to provide the city with an affidavit certifying that neither it, nor any of its affiliates is, and none will become, a high cost lender or a predatory lender as defined in Chapter 112, Division 3A, Predatory Lending. The affidavit shall be in a form prescribed by the City Attorney and shall be sworn by one or more of the officers of the depository; and 
(5)  Include in contracts for depository services a statement of work that provides a framework for socially responsible banking; and 
(6)  Establish relevant reporting criteria and timeframes to validate the statement of work; and 
(7)  Convene an Evaluation and Selection Committee. 
(i)  This committee may be comprised of representatives from the Department of Finance, Human Relations Council, Central Services (Purchasing and Information and Technology Divisions) and any other city agency that may be necessary; further, the committee will include one member of the Dayton community who is well versed in banking services and community banking issues and who shall be recommended by the Human Relations Council and approved by the City Commission. 
(ii)  The committee will meet to evaluate submitted banking services bid proposals, facilitate getting public input through various means on the responsible banking plans submitted in the banking services bid proposals, and make recommendations based on stated criteria for vendor selection. 
(B)  Socially responsible banking criteria shall be included in the Banking Services Request for Proposal. The criteria shall address, but are not limited to, the following areas: community involvement and reinvestment; meeting community banking needs; supporting small business lending and community development; providing for home ownership and consumer credit; assisting distressed homeowners; and allowing for products and services that are advantageous for the city and its residents. 
(Am. Ord. 31389-15, passed 4-22-15) 
Sec. 36.401. - Statement of work. 
    The statement of work for socially responsible banking tasks shall include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(A)  Community Involvement and Reinvestment. 
(1)  The bank will report to the city on its efforts to invest in low- and moderate- income areas and minority census tracts. 
(2)  The bank, through its community investment program or other similar program, will collaborate and support annually at least one designated non-profit organization focused on providing financial services, education, and asset building for low-income people in Dayton. 
(3)  The bank, through its community investment program or other similar program, will collaborate with and support annually at least one organization that provides free tax preparation services in Dayton that target lower-income workers to help them take advantage of the Earned Income Tax Credit and other tax credits. 
(4)  The bank will report annually on its community development activities (such as lending, and services) to demonstrate the bank's response to the credit, financial and banking needs of low- to moderate- income individuals and small businesses in the Dayton area. 
(5)  The bank will provide the city, through its Human Relations Council and City Manager's Office, with at least 90 days notice of branch closures and openings, including the reasons for any closures. 
(B)  Community Banking Needs. 
(1)  The bank will continue to support and participate in programs that strive to reach traditionally underserved populations as described in the Community Reinvestment Act. These may include unbanked, under-banked, and low-income populations. The bank will provide free or low-cost services and products and increase access to these underserved populations. 
(2)  The bank will provide easy-to-understand fee schedules and make a reasonable effort to offer fair, responsible, and affordable small-dollar loans. 
(3)  The bank will take action to account for other community banking needs identified in the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Analysis of Impediments to Fair Housing Choice. 
(C)  Small Business Lending and Community Development. The bank will provide a single point of contact for business lending and partnership, and will participate as agreed in small business trade fairs, outreach, or educational opportunities. 
(D)  Home Ownership and Consumer Credit. 
(1)  The bank will provide a single point of contact in its loan servicing group. 
(2)  The bank will participate in outreach and educational opportunities aimed at salvaging distressed home mortgages, will collaborate with HUD-certified housing counseling services, and will inform customers who do not qualify for home loans or other products about local non-profit credit and debt counseling services. 
(E)  The Director of Finance may propose exceptions to this scope of work, subject to commission approval by resolution, in future contract cycles. 
(Am. Ord. 31389-15, passed 4-22-15) 
Sec. 36.402. - Reporting. 
(A)  Any banking contract must include a requirement that the bank provide the following reporting on an annual basis: 
(1)  Residential lending information. The bank will provide the total number and the total dollar amount of residential loans for one- to four-family dwellings applied for and originated during the previous calendar year. The data shall be provided for the entire city by zip code. For home loans, fixed-rate loans shall be reported separately from adjustable-rate loans. 
(i)  Home purchase loans, both federally insured and conventional loans; 
(ii)  Refinancings of home loans; 
(iii)  Home improvement loans; 
(iv)  Home equity loans; 
(v)  Multi-family loans; 
(vi)  Loans to non-occupant owners of single-family housing; 
(vii)  Modifications of distressed loans and the type of modification, including interest rate reductions, forbearance, principal reduction, or repayment plans in which the outstanding loan amount increases, and an indication of whether the modification was executed under the federal Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP), another federal program, or the institution's own modification program; 
(viii)  Short sales, deeds in lieu, and other mechanisms besides loan modifications that avoid foreclosure; and 
(ix)  Defaults and delinquencies on home loans. 
(2)  Small business lending information. The bank will provide the total number and the total dollar amount of small business loans originated during the previous calendar year for the entire city by zip code, and for minority- and women-owned business enterprises in the entire city. Loans to small businesses with annual revenues above $1,000,000.00 shall be reported separately from loans to small businesses with annual revenues under $1,000,000.00. The bank may use data reporting procedures mandated by the federal Community Reinvestment Act for reporting small business loans. 
(3)  Community development loans and investments. The bank will provide the number and dollar amount of community development loans including loans and investments for affordable housing, small business development, economic development, and community facilities for the entire city by zip code or neighborhood. The bank may use definitions of community development found in federal Community Reinvestment Act regulations. For each loan and investment, the bank will indicate if the loan or investment was for affordable housing, small business development, economic development, community facilities, and other such categories requested by the Director. 
(4)  Consumer loan data. The number and dollar amount of consumer loans for the entire city by zip code. Price information shall be reported in a manner similar to Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) data. 
(5)  Checking, savings, and loan products. Information on selected checking, savings, prepaid card, small dollar loan, and other products marketed to residents, including information on fees, interest, and features. 
(6)  Other. Narrative descriptions will be required to describe efforts to meet all other items set forth in the Statement of Work. 
(B)  The Director of Finance, along with the Director of the Human Relations Council, will convene an annual review committee to review the Responsible Banking Statement of Work and Annual Report for the Banking Services selected vendor, which must include, at a minimum, representatives from the following departments: Human Relations Council, Planning and Community Development, Law and Finance. In addition, the community member appointed to the Evaluation and Selection Committee shall sit on the Annual Review Committee. The Committee may propose exceptions to these reporting elements, subject to Commission approval by resolution, in future contract cycles. 
(Am. Ord. 31389-15, passed 4-22-15) 
CHAPTER 37. - DEPARTMENT OF AVIATION 

Sec. 37.01. - Department of Aviation. 
(A)  A Department of Aviation is established. The Department of Aviation consists of a Director, Deputy Director and such other officers and employees as appointed by the City Manager. The Director shall manage and assign the work of the Department of Aviation, subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager. 
(B)  The Department of Aviation is divided into the following divisions: 
(1)  Airport Administration and Finance; 
(2)  Airport Operations and Facilities Maintenance; 
(3)  Airport Police; and 
(4)  Aircraft Rescue and Firefighting (ARFF). 
(C)  The Department of Aviation and its divisions are responsible for the management of all airport leases and concession agreements; airport marketing, air service and economic development; planning, development and maintenance of airport physical assets; and performance of such other duties as required by the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(D)  Where necessary for the efficient operation of the office, the Director may substitute, reassign, modify or expand the functions of the Department of Aviation, with the advice and consent of the City Manager. 
(E)  The Director and Deputy Director shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 15338, passed 11-22-39; Am. Ord. 24834, passed 11-20-74; Am. Ord. 29042-95, passed 8-2-95; Am. Ord. 29792-99, passed 12-29-99; Am. Ord. 30656, passed 6-20-07; Am. Ord. 31128-11, passed 12-21-11) 
Secs. 37.02-37.04. - Reserved. 
Sec. 37.05. - Rules and regulations for the airport. 
    It shall be the duty of the Director of Aviation and he shall have power, subject to the approval of the City Commission, to make rules and regulations for the management, maintenance, and operation of the James M. Cox Dayton International Airport, and other airports under the control of the department, for controlling landings, take-offs, and flights at the airports and while flying within three miles horizontally of the centers thereof, for qualifying users of the airports and establishing just and equitable rates, charges, permits, and landing fees to be paid by them for such privileges or uses. The rules and regulations shall be in force and effect immediately upon being approved by the Commission, which approval shall be made by motion and shall be entered upon the minutes of the Commission but need not be published. 
(Ord. 19299, passed 5-13-59; Am. Ord. 27026, passed 7-3-84) 
Sec. 37.06. - Off-airport businesses; off-airport taxi services; commercial ground transportation company; transportation network companies. 
(A)  Fees and charges shall be imposed on certain off-airport business and operators using the airport. The Director of the Department of Aviation shall be authorized to establish operating agreements or permits with off-airport businesses and operators. Such agreements or permits shall establish, at a minimum, operating rules, regulations, and procedures to be followed when operating courtesy vehicles/service on the airport, insurance requirements and fees. 
(B)  A designated drop-off and pick-up area for passengers that arrive in a courtesy vehicle shall be established for off-airport businesses to the charges set forth in § 37.07. 
(C)  Off-airport taxi services. No off-airport taxi services, other than those services which have a nonexclusive or exclusive operating agreement or permit with the city, shall be permitted to loiter or pick-up passengers at the airport, unless the pick-up or drop-off has been prearranged by the passenger and taxi service operator. For purposes of this division, "off-airport taxi services" shall include limousine services or any other service that is used to transport people for hire and not specifically identified elsewhere. 
(D)  Commercial ground transportation company. No commercial ground transportation company, other than those which have a nonexclusive or exclusive operating agreement or permit with the city, shall be permitted to loiter or pick-up passengers at the airport. For purposes of this division, commercial ground transportation company shall be buses and vans designed and used to transport passengers and operating between the airport and any commercial establishment or private residence within or without the city, and excluding any authorized vehicles or courtesy vehicles. The Director of the Department of Aviation shall be authorized to establish operating agreements or permits with commercial ground transportation companies. Such agreements or permits shall establish, at a minimum, operating rules, regulations, and procedures to be followed when operating passenger shuttle service vehicles on the airport, insurance requirements and the maximum fees to be charged for such services. 
(E)  No transportation network company or transportation network company driver, other than those who have a non-exclusive or exclusive transportation network company operating permit with the city shall be permitted to loiter, pick-up or drop-off passengers at the airport. 
(Ord. 28689-93, passed 7-7-93; Am. Ord. 30068-02, passed 3-13-02; Am. Ord. 30119-02, passed 6-26-02; Am. Ord. 31511-16, passed 9-7-16; Am. Ord. 31542-16, passed 12-21-16) 
Sec. 37.07. - Schedule of fees and charges. 
(A)  Effective July 1, 2015, all off-airport rental car businesses shall be charged a fee of ten percent of gross revenues for the privilege of using Dayton International Airport facilities. Gross revenues shall mean, as determined in the reasonable discretion of the city, all amounts charged to its customers by company for or in connection with agreements it secures through its operations and business at the airport, regardless of whether such amount is actually paid to or received by company. Gross revenues shall include all monies or other consideration of whatsoever nature paid or payable to company by customers for all sales made and services performed for cash, credit or consideration in connection with automobile and vehicle rentals or other products or services provided to persons through company's operations at the airport, without regard to the ownership, area, fleet, or location assignment of vehicles and without regard to the manner in which or place at which the vehicles or other products or services are furnished to company's customers and without regard to whether the vehicles or other products are returned to the airport or to some other location. Gross revenues shall include anything and everything that is not specifically excluded. The only exclusions from gross revenues permitted shall be the specific exclusions set forth below: 
(1)  Federal, state, county, city or municipal sales, use, or excise taxes now in effect or hereinafter levied on company's operations which are separately stated on customers' rental contracts and collected from customers of company; 
(2)  Amounts received as insurance proceeds for loss of or damages of vehicles or other property of company; 
(3)  Amounts received from the sale of vehicles off-airport premises; provided, however, any amounts paid in connection with automobile and vehicle rentals or other products or services provided to persons through company's operations that are applied to or otherwise reimbursed as a result of the sale of a vehicle shall not be excluded from gross revenues. 
(B)  Off-airport parking services. 
(1)  A fee of ten percent of the gross revenue generated shall be charged to off-airport parking service operators for the privilege of using Dayton International Airport facilities. "Gross revenues" as used herein means any and all charges made as a direct or indirect consequence of transactions originating from or relating to the Dayton International Airport, for the rental of parking space, without regard to ownership of the automobile or vehicle. Off-airport parking service operators shall furnish auditable proof of the exact amount of gross revenues in its reports to the Department of Aviation or may assume, for ease of reporting, accounting and payment to the city, that 100 percent of the total amount revenues obtained from the operation of the off-airport parking services were generated as a direct or indirect consequence of transactions originating from or relating to the Dayton International Airport. 
(2)  Except for properly marked personal cars of handicapped persons transportation onto the Dayton International Airport property of personal cars of persons using off-airport parking services is prohibited. A courtesy car, van, or bus (i.e., shuttle bus) shall be used. 
(C)  Off-airport hotels/motels. Effective January 1, 1994, all off-airport hotels/motels with limousine, courtesy car, van, or bus (i.e., shuttle bus) service that make regular pick-ups and drop-offs of passengers at the airport shall be charged a fee of $100.00 each six months per courtesy vehicle for the privilege of using airport facilities. 
(D)  Commercial ground transportation companies. Commercial ground transportation companies shall furnish auditable proof of the exact amount of gross revenues in its reports to the Department of Aviation or may assume, for ease of reporting, accounting and payment to the city, that 100 percent of the total amount revenues obtained from the operation of the off-airport parking services were generated as a direct or indirect consequence of transactions originating from or relating to the Dayton International Airport. 
(E)  Payment of fees and charges. All permits and fees shall be paid to the city. Fees may be prorated by the Director of the Department of Aviation or his/her appointee to establish a convenient calendar date. In the event a single off-airport business operates two or more of the activities affected by §§ 37.06 through 37.10 of this chapter, the Director of the Department of Aviation shall assess fees on only one category of activity which shall permit access for the business as if it was paying for all applicable activity. 
(Ord. 28689-93, passed 7-7-93; Am. Ord. 29658-98, passed 12-16-98; Am. Ord. 30102-02, 5-15-02; Am. Ord. 30385-04, passed 9-8-04; Ord. 31409-15, passed 6-24-15; Am. Ord. 31542-16, passed 12-21-16) 
Sec. 37.08. - Vehicle permits. 
(A)  The Director of the Department of Aviation or his/her appointee shall establish an authorized vehicle/courtesy vehicle permit system to be used by all off-airport operators authorized to conduct business activities at the airport. 
(B)  Only authorized vehicles/courtesy vehicles that have obtained such permits may conduct commercial activity on the airport grounds. 
(C)  Off-airport operators shall obtain a Department of Aviation permit by completing and submitting a written application. Permits will be issued only after the application is submitted and approved along with evidence that requirements for any license, other permits, insurance, safety inspections or authorizations required by any other government agency, such as local, state and/or federal, have been met. An administrative fee to cover the costs of the permit system may be charged and collected by the Department of Aviation. 
(D)  Each authorized vehicle/courtesy vehicle being used on the airport by an operator in the conduct of business in accordance within §§ 37.06 through 37.10 of this chapter shall have an indicator of the permit displayed on the vehicle as specified by the Director of the Department of Aviation. 
(E)  The permit is not transferable and does not extend to any area of the airport nor any other zone except those designated in the permit. 
(F)  All authorized vehicles/courtesy vehicles authorized under those permits shall be kept clean and maintained in good working order. 
(G)  The Director of Aviation or his/her appointee may immediately revoke, temporarily or permanently, a permit for violation of any provision of §§ 37.06 through 37.10 of this chapter or of any federal, state and/or local law or ordinance or of any other aviation rules, regulations, or policies. 
(H)  Emergency vehicles and vehicles of governmental agencies including, but not limited to, city, state, and federal shall be exempt from purchasing vehicle permits and payment of fees and charges required by §§ 37.06 through 37.10 of this chapter. 
(I)  Permits shall be obtained for the following vehicles: Off-airport parking courtesy vehicles; off-airport hotel/motel courtesy vehicles; off-airport rental car courtesy vehicles; commercial ground transportation company vehicles; and transportation network company vehicles. 
(Ord. 28689-93, passed 7-7-93; Am. Ord. 31542-16, passed 12-21-16) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 10.99. 
Sec. 37.09. - Insurance. 
    All authorized vehicle/courtesy vehicle permits shall require the owner, operator, driver, or chauffeur of any authorized vehicle/courtesy vehicle to procure and file with the Department of Aviation a liability insurance policy issued by a good and responsible surety company in an amount to be determined by the Department of Aviation. Should a vehicle at any time cease to be covered by a policy of insurance, that vehicle at any time shall be prohibited from operating on airport property. A 30-day notice of cancellation by the insurance company shall be provided to the Department of Aviation. 
(Ord. 28689-93, passed 7-7-93) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 10.99. 
Sec. 37.10. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of §§ 37.06 through 37.09, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Authorized vehicle. Any vehicle including courtesy vehicles operating under a valid lease agreement, permit, or contract with the Department of Aviation/city under which such a vehicle is permitted to operate on airport streets and roads. 
    Commercial ground transportation company. Shall mean a company which operates any limousine, charter, shuttle, bus, car or other owned or leased vehicle by operator for business purposes and operated by operator's personnel for the sole purpose of transporting customers to and from the airport. 
    Courtesy service. The operation of an off-airport business involving the transportation of persons and/or property to and from the airport via courtesy vehicle, regardless of whether or not there is a fee for such service. 
    Courtesy vehicle. Any motor vehicle (including electrically-powered vehicles) of any carrying capacity that is operated by a motel, hotel, parking lot, automobile rental agency, limousine service, shuttle bus service, or other off-airport business for the transportation of persons and/or property to and from the airport regardless of whether or not there is a fee for such service. 
    Off-airport business. Any commercial business that enters upon the airport or otherwise uses airport facilities to serve airport passengers. 
    Off-airport operator. The owner/operator of any off-airport business. 
    Transportation network companies. Any corporation, partnership, association, limited liability company, proprietorship, or any other entity lawfully operating pursuant to Ohio Revised Code Chapter 4935 that uses a digital network to connect transportation network company riders to transportation network company drivers who provide transportation network company services. 
    Vehicle permit. Any type of authorization system implemented by the Department of Aviation to appropriately identify those vehicles authorized to operate upon the airport streets and roads. 
(Ord. 28689-93, passed 7-7-93; Am. Ord. 31511-16, passed 9-7-16; Am. Ord. 31542-16, passed 12-21-16) 
Sec. 37.11. - Customer facility charge. 
(A)  For purposes of § 37.11, the following definitions shall apply: 
    On-Airport Rental Car Company. Any rental car company or business that enters into an agreement or is otherwise authorized to operate a rental car concession at and from the James M. Cox Dayton International Airport. 
    Transaction Day. Shall mean a 24-hour period or fraction thereof for which a rental car customer is provided the use of a rental vehicle for compensation or otherwise, and regardless of the duration or length of the rental term. 
(B)  Effective January 1, 2018, all persons entering into a rental car transaction with an on-airport rental car company, which originates at the James M. Cox Dayton International Airport, shall be charged a Customer Facility Charge ("CFC"). The amount of the CFC shall be set at $5.50 per transaction day. 
(C)  Each on-airport rental car company shall: 
(1)  Impose and collect the CFC authorized by the city; 
(2)  Hold such CFCs collected in trust for the benefit of the city, and that the city, or a trustee on its behalf, has complete possessory and ownership rights to such CFCs; 
(3)  Remit the CFCs collected to the city, without offset, in the manner described in an agreement with the on-airport rental car company or as the city may otherwise direct; and 
(4)  Comply with all city rules or requirement(s), as established by the Director of Aviation from time to time or included within the agreement with the on-airport rental car company, regarding the collection and remittance of CFCs. 
(D)  In addition to all other remedies available to the city, any on-airport car rental company who fails to collect and/or remit the CFC shall be barred from using the James M. Cox Dayton International Airport or its facilities for conduct of any commercial activity whatsoever. 
(Ord. 30204-03, passed 1-22-03; Ord. 31424-15, passed 8-5-15; Am. Ord. 31600-17, passed 12-13-17) 
CHAPTER 39. - DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES 

Sec. 39.01. - Department of Human Resources. 
(A)  A Department of Human Resources is established. The Department of Human Resources consists of a Director, Deputy Director and such other officers and employees as appointed by the City Manager. The Director shall manage and assign the work of the Department of Human Resources, subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager. 
(B)  The Department of Human Resources and its divisions shall develop and administer personnel policies and program, including the following major functional areas: compensation and benefits, employee relations, organizational development, employee training, and safety and workers compensation; and perform such other duties as required by the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(C)  Where necessary for the efficient operation of the office, the Director may substitute, reassign, modify or expand the functions of the Department of Human Resources, with the advice and consent of the City Manager. 
(D)  The Director and Deputy Director shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 31135-11, passed 12-21-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. 31135-11, passed December 21, 2011, amended § 39.01 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 39-01, pertained to Department of Central Services, and derived from Ord. 29046-95, passed 8-2-95; Am. Ord. 30663-07, passed 7-25-07. 
Sec. 39.02. - Background checks. 
(A)  The City believes that hiring qualified individuals to fill positions contributes to its overall strategic success. Background checks serve as an important part of the selection process. This type of information is collected as a means of promoting a safe work environment for current and future employees. Background checks also help the city obtain additional applicant related information that helps determine the applicant's overall employability, ensuring the protection of the current people, property, and information of the organization. 
(1)  Types of background checks. 
All offers of employment at the city may be contingent upon passing all necessary background checks. Background checks will be conducted on all newly hired staff members and on all employees who are promoted, as deemed necessary. 
(2)  Background checks may include: 
(a)  "Social security check" validates the applicant's social security number, date of birth and former addresses. 
(b)  "Prior employment verification" confirms applicant's employment with the provided companies, including approximate dates of employment, position held and additional information available pertaining to salary, wages, performance rating, reasons for departures and eligibility for rehire. 
(c)  "Local criminal history" checks Ohio or other state courts for any crimes committed in violation of state law by the applicant. 
(d)  "Federal criminal history" checks district courts for any crimes committed in violation of federal law by the applicant. 
(e)  "Personal and professional references" check will result in calls placed to individuals listed as references by an applicant by the receiving department. 
(f)  "Educational verification" confirms the applicant's claimed educational institution, including the years attended and the degree/diploma received from an accredited university. 
(g)  "Drug screen" confirms that the candidate is not abusing any illegal or prescription drugs. 
(3)  The following additional searches may be required if applicable to the position: 
(a)  "Motor vehicle" check provides a report on an individual's driving history in the state requested. This search will be run when driving is an essential requirement of the position. 
(b)  "Credit history" check confirms a candidate's credit history. This search will be run for positions that involve management of funds and/or handling of cash. 
(4)  Civil Service shall conduct necessary background checks, and the department may verify qualifications. 
(B)  Background check procedure. 
(1)  Except for police and fire positions, Civil Service will not conduct a background check until a contingent offer of employment is extended by the city. 
(2)  After a contingent employment offer is made, the chosen candidate must complete all necessary pre-employment paperwork and return these to Civil Service. Civil Service will notify the department upon receipt of the signed release and/or forms. The chosen candidate is not to begin work prior to the department receiving approval from Civil Service and the Department of Human Resources. 
(3)  Civil Service will order the necessary background checks upon receipt of the signed release and/or forms. A designated Civil Service representative will review all results of any and all background checks. 
(4)  Civil Service will notify the department regarding the results of the background checks. In instances where negative or incomplete information is obtained, Civil Service will assess the potential risks and liabilities related to the job's requirements and determine whether the individual should be hired. 
(5)  Background check information will be maintained by Civil Service in a file separate from an employee's personnel file. 
(C)  Criminal checks. 
(1)  A criminal history record check is required for all positions. All applicants must authorize in writing the background investigation using the appropriate release and/or forms. The city will inquire only about convictions and probation status, if any, and not about arrests unless required by applicable laws. 
(2)  The following factors may be considered by Civil Service for those applicants with a criminal history in determining whether to hire the external applicant or transfer or promote the internal applicant: 
(a)  The nature of the crime, and whether the conviction of a felony or misdemeanor adversely bears on the employee's suitability for employment. 
(b)  The time since the conviction. 
(c)  Evidence of rehabilitation by the applicant since the conviction. 
(d)  The number (if more than one) of convictions and whether hiring, transferring or promoting the applicant would pose an unreasonable risk to the City and/or its employees or citizens. 
(e)  The applicant for a classified position will be given an opportunity to contest his/her removal from an eligible list due to the outcome of a criminal records check. 
(f)  If any applicant is found to have falsified any information regarding conviction history, the applicant will not be considered for employment. If an employee seeking a transfer or promotion to a position requiring a criminal history record check is found to have falsified any information regarding conviction history, the employee will be immediately discharged. 
(D)  Current employees criminal conviction. 
(1)  Employees must notify their Department Director within one working day of any arrest and/or conviction for any crime. Failure to comply with this requirement will result in disciplinary action, up to, and including, termination. 
(2)  Determination of which crimes will affect continued employment will be evaluated by HR, the Law Department, and Civil Service.
