DIVISION 3. - CITY PLAN BOARD 

Sec. 44.10. - City Plan Board established. 
    The City Plan Board is established. 
(Ord. 12061, passed 2-20-24; Am. Ord. 21017, passed 12-18-63) 
Sec. 44.11. - Membership of Board; appointment; term. 
    The City Plan Board shall consist of seven voting members appointed by the City Commission. All members shall be actual residents of and physically live in the city during the term of their appointment. Members of the Board shall serve for a term of office of three years or until their successor(s) have been appointed, qualified and have begun to serve the unexpired term of office. They shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 12061, passed 2-20-24; Am. Ord. 21017, passed 12-18-63; Am. Ord. 26728, passed 3-2-83; Am. Ord. 28035, passed 11-1-89) 
Sec. 44.12. - Advisory member of Board. 
    In addition to the membership of the City Plan Board, as provided for by § 44.11, the City Manager or the Director of Planning may meet and serve, at their discretion, as advisory members of the Board, but without the right to vote. 
(Ord. 16256, passed 8-6-47; Am. Ord. 28035, passed 11-1-89) 
Sec. 44.13. - Removals and vacancies. 
    The voting members of the City Plan Board shall be subject to removal for cause by the City Commission. Any vacancy on the Board shall be filled by the City Commission for the unexpired term. Three consecutive absences unexcused by the Board, or failure to attend a majority of meetings of the Board in any six-month period, or loss of the residency referred to in § 44.11, shall constitute and have the effect of a resignation from the Board. 
(Ord. 12061, passed 2-20-24; Am. Ord. 28035, passed 11-1-89) 
Sec. 44.14. - Organization of Board. 
    The City Plan Board shall annually elect a president and vice president. The secretary shall maintain the records and minutes of all proceedings, prepare plans, act as a hearing officer, communicate the decisions of the Board to the City Commission and the City Manager, and perform all other duties lawfully assigned by the Board or provided by ordinance. 
(Ord. 12061, passed 2-20-24; Am. Ord. 25035, passed 12-31-75; Am. Ord. 28053, passed 12-25-89; Am. Ord. 29078-95, passed 8-30-95) 
Sec. 44.15. - Meetings; rules. 
    Meetings of the City Plan Board shall be set at such time and place as the Board may determine. A majority of all the appointed voting members shall constitute a quorum and it may adopt such rules of procedure as it may deem necessary. In the absence of our adopted rule, Robert's Rule of Order shall prevail. 
(Ord. 12061, passed 2-20-24; Am. Ord. 16167, passed 2-19-47; Am. Ord. 28035, passed 11-1-89) 
Sec. 44.16. - Powers and duties of Board. 
    The City Plan Board shall perform such duties and functions with respect to planning and zoning, platting, or other duties as presently provided or may hereafter be provided by state law or by city ordinance. 
(Ord. 12061, passed 2-20-24; Am. Ord. 25035, passed 12-31-75) 
Sec. 44.17. - Downtown comprehensive plan. 
    The City Plan Board shall prepare for consideration by the City Commission a comprehensive plan for the central business district which includes appropriate land uses, urban design, and transportation standards. Within the scope of the adopted plan, the Board shall review the following: 
(A)  All modifications to the thoroughfare and circulation system, the location of on-street parking facilities and bus stops, pedestrian sidewalks and corridors, and other transportation elements. 
(B)  All proposed plans and capital projects requiring the use of public rights-of-way, publicly owned property, tax abatement, special assessments, special privilege permits, or the eminent domain or urban renewal powers of the city. 
(Ord. 28035, passed 11-1-89) 
Sec. 44.18. - Urban design standards. 
    The City Plan Board shall recommend urban design standards to the City Commission for streets, sidewalks, lighting, utilities, signs, parking lots, building rehabilitation and construction, trees, landscaping, open spaces, street furniture, public art and other physical amenities. Within the scope of the adopted standards and procedures, the Board shall review plans and capital projects requiring the use of public rights-of-way, publicly owned property, special assessments, special privilege permits or the eminent domain or urban renewal powers of the city. 
(Ord. 28234, passed 12-12-90) 
Sec. 44.19. - Public commons. 
    The City Plan Board shall prepare for consideration by the City Commission a public commons master plan in consultation with the various departments of the city. The plan shall identify needs for each section and neighborhood of the city and list all public open space, green space, and parks. Within the scope of the adopted plan, the City Plan Board shall review proposals to sell or convert to a nonrecreational use a listed public commons. Prior to rendering a recommendation to the City Commission, the City Plan Board shall provide 30 days' public notice and hold a public hearing on the proposal. 
(Ord. 28234, passed 12-12-90) 
Sec. 44.20. - Real property tax exemption. 
    Any real property tax exemption shall be established or modified in accordance with the provisions of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(Ord. 28718-93, passed 9-8-93; Am. Ord. 30898-09, passed 8-5-09) 
Secs. 44.21-44.24. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SISTER-CITY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 44.25. - Sister-City Committee established. 
    A Sister-City Committee is hereby established. 
(Ord. 21341, passed 8-12-64) 
Sec. 44.26. - Membership of committee. 
    The Sister-City Committee shall consist of a chairman to be appointed by the City Commission for a term of five years and such members as the City Commission may appoint, but not less than 15 nor more than 30. In addition, the members of the City Commission, and the Clerk of the Commission, as liaison officer, will serve as ex-officio members. 
(Ord. 21341, passed 8-12-64) 
Sec. 44.27. - Term of office. 
    The term of office of the members of the Sister-City Committee shall be five years, except that the term of an official or employee of the city shall continue only so long as he remains an official or employee of the city in the position which he occupied at the time of such appointment. 
(Ord. 21341, passed 8-12-64) 
Sec. 44.28. - Organization of committee. 
    The committee shall organize by annually electing a chairman and vice-chairman from its membership and shall adopt its rules of procedure and hold such meetings, either regular or special, as it may deem necessary to carry on its work. 
(Ord. 21341, passed 8-12-64) 
Sec. 44.29. - Duties of committee. 
    It shall be the duty of the committee to study, formulate and develop plans to set in motion a program for an active mutual exchange between the city and the cities of Augsburg, Germany; Oiso, Japan; Monrovia, Liberia; Holon, Israel; Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Rushmoor, United Kingdom, and such additional foreign city or cities as may from time to time be approved by the Commission by motion; and to join hands with the people of Augsburg, Germany; Oiso, Japan; Monrovia, Liberia; Holon, Israel; Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina; and, Rushmoor, United Kingdom, and with the people of such additional foreign city or cities as may from time to time be approved by the Commission as aforesaid, in carrying out a program of mutual interest in international friendship and understanding. 
(Ord. 21341, passed 8-12-64; Am. Ord. 22891, passed 3-6-68; Am. Ord. 27728, passed 3-30-88; Ord. No. 31737-19, § 4, 5-15-19) 
Sec. 44.30. - Members to serve without compensation. 
    Members of the committee shall be honorary and shall serve without remuneration other than the regular city salary provided for the city employees or officials. 
(Ord. 21341, passed 8-12-64) 
Secs. 44.31-44.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ENVIRONMENTAL ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 44.40. - Environmental Advisory Board established. 
    An Environmental Advisory Board is established. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85) 
Sec. 44.41. - Membership of Board. 
    The Environmental Advisory Board shall be constituted of nine members who shall be designated by the City Commission, and each member should possess a high level of interest, expertise, educational background, or work experience in environmental protection. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85; Am. 31471-16, passed 2-3-16) 
Sec. 44.42. - Term of office. 
    The term of office of members of the Environmental Advisory Board shall be three years. No member shall be appointed to more than three consecutive terms. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85; Am. 31471-16, passed 2-3-16) 
Sec. 44.43. - Organization of Board. 
    The Environmental Advisory Board shall organize by annually electing a chairperson and vice-chairperson from its membership and shall adopt rules of procedure not inconsistent with this division and hold meetings, not less than once per month, as it deems necessary to carry on its work. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85) 
Sec. 44.44. - Duties of Board. 
    The Environmental Advisory Board shall identify environmental issues and advise the City Commission, Manager and appropriate city departments, boards, and agencies. The Board shall also review environmental matters referred to it by the City Commission, Manager, departments, boards and agencies. The Board shall have the power to call before it any officer or employee as the Board shall deem appropriate to provide information necessary for the exercise of its duties. The Board shall develop procedures for hearing requests for the exemption of regulated substances from regulation by the well field protection program pursuant to § 53.22. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85; Am. Ord. 29093-95, passed 10-4-95) 
Sec. 44.45. - Staff support. 
    The City Manager's office will provide staff and clerical support to the Environmental Advisory Board. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85) 
Sec. 44.46. - Members to serve without compensation. 
    Members of the Environmental Advisory Board shall serve without pay. 
(Ord. 27302, passed 11-27-85) 
Secs. 44.47-44.49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - LANDMARK COMMISSION AND TRUST ACCOUNT 

Sec. 44.50. - Landmark Commission established. 
    The Landmark Commission is established. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Sec. 44.51. - Membership of the Landmark Commission. 
    The Landmark Commission shall consist of nine qualified members to be appointed by the City Commission. Two members shall be registered architects, three members shall be residents of a historic district, and one member shall represent the Montgomery County Historical Society. In addition, all members shall be city residents or have their principal place of business located in the city, and shall have demonstrated a positive interest in historic preservation. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Sec. 44.52. - Terms of office. 
    The terms of office of the members of the Landmark Commission shall be three years or until their successors have been duly appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Sec. 44.53. - Removal and vacancies. 
    The members of the Landmark Commission shall be subject to removal with cause by the City Commission after a public hearing. Any vacancy shall be filled by the City Commission for the unexpired term. Three consecutive unexcused absences, failure to attend a majority of the meetings in a 12-month period, or loss of original qualifications shall constitute resignation. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Sec. 44.54. - Organization and rules. 
    The Landmark Commission shall annually elect a chairperson and vice-chairperson. Meetings shall be set at such time and place as the Landmark Commission shall determine. A majority of the appointed members shall constitute a quorum. The Landmark Commission shall adopt such rules of procedure as are deemed necessary by a majority of the Landmark Commission. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Sec. 44.55. - Powers and duties. 
(A)  The Landmark Commission shall review and act upon all modifications to any structure, site, or area listed on the National Register Of Historic Places whenever those modifications involve the use of funds entrusted to the city, the use of the city's eminent domain or urban renewal powers, or the use of the city's tax abatement authority. 
(B)  The Landmark Commission shall classify all structures and sites listed as eligible for or on the National Register Of Historic Places outside of historic districts in accordance with § 150.245, and shall act upon all demolition permits for those structures or sites in accordance with § 150.246 of this Code. 
(C)  In addition to the powers and duties set forth above and in the zoning code, the Landmark Commission shall: 
(1)  Recommend to the City Plan Board legislation and programs designed to encourage and promote historic preservation and historic district revitalization; 
(2)  Prepare an annual report on its performance and plans; 
(3)  Be entitled to legal representation whenever its decisions are appealed to the Board of Zoning Appeals or a court of law; 
(4)  Prepare an annual budget for the Landmark Trust Account; and 
(5)  Perform such other duties as may be requested by the City Commission. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Sec. 44.56. - Landmark Trust Account. 
(A)  The Landmark Trust Account is established to promote historic preservation through public education, publication, and distribution of guidelines and standards, training, architectural assistance, and other preservation activities consistent with the purposes set forth in §§ 150.230 through 150.256 of this Code. 
(B)  Expenditures shall be authorized in a manner prescribed for all city expenditures upon signature of the Director of Planning. However, no expenditure shall be made without the approval of the Landmark Commission. 
(C)  Upon approval of the City Commission, the trust may receive income, contributions, grants, and other tangible and intangible assets. In addition, all performance bonds and mitigation fees as set forth in §§ 150.230 through 150.256 of this Code shall be entrusted to and deposited in the Landmark Trust Account. 
(Ord. 27816, passed 9-21-88) 
Secs. 44.57-44.59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - PUBLIC ACCESS FACILITATING BOARD 

Sec. 44.60. - Public Access Facilitating Board created. 
(A)  A Public Access Facilitating Board is hereby created and established in the city consisting of nine members who shall be residents of the city, and who shall serve without remuneration. Each of the following named organizations or agencies shall appoint one member to said Board, who shall be a member of such organization: 
(1)  The Commission of the City of Dayton. 
(2)  The Board of Education of the Dayton City School District. 
(3)  City-Wide Development Corporation. 
(4)  Our Common Heritage, Inc. 
(5)  League of Women Voters of Greater Dayton. 
(6)  Metropolitan Churches United. 
(7)  Miami Valley Consortium of Colleges. 
(8)  The combined priority boards of the city. 
(9)  Senior Citizens Center of Greater Dayton area. 
(B)  The members initially appointed by the Miami Valley Consortium of Colleges, the combined priority boards, and Senior Citizens Center of Greater Dayton area shall serve until December 31, 1978. The members initially appointed by the City Commission, the Board of Education, and City-Wide Development Corporation shall serve until December 31, 1977. The members initially appointed by our Common Heritage, Inc., the League of Women Voters and by Metropolitan Churches United shall serve until December 31, 1976. Thereafter, the term of all members of the Board shall be three years. 
(C)  Any member who misses three consecutive regular meetings or who ceases to be a resident of the city, or who ceases to be a member of the organization by which he or she was appointed shall have their membership on the Facilitating Board terminated, and the appropriate appointing organization shall appoint a replacement for the remainder of their term. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75; Am. Ord. 25043, passed 1-14-76; Am. Ord. 25163, passed 9-29-76) 
Sec. 44.61. - Duties. 
    The duties of the Facilitating Board shall be as follows: 
(A)  To do all within its power to oversee and be responsible for development of policies and administration of local public access channels. 
(B)  To promote basic and experimental uses, and to furnish equipment, set up training programs, and do all things deemed necessary to encourage and promote citizen, business, and all private and commercial uses that may be related thereto. 
(C)  The Facilitating Board shall not control the educational and local government channels, but may do all other things within its power to promote and assist in their uses, including funding. 
(D)  Promote and endeavor to make Dayton a television training center and a center for educational and government cable television research and demonstration. 
(E)  Resolve any disputes over first-come, first-served time allocations, or other questions of equal treatment of access users. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75) 
Sec. 44.62. - Officers. 
    The officers of said Facilitating Board shall be a chairman, vice-chairman, secretary and treasurer, who shall be elected annually by the Board from within its membership. No chairman shall serve more than three successive terms. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75) 
Sec. 44.63. - Rules of procedure. 
    The Facilitating Board shall adopt its own rules of procedure, and shall hold such meetings, either regular or special, as it may deem necessary to carry on its work. Such rules of procedure shall be filed with the City Commission. The Facilitating Board shall provide copies of minutes of all its meetings to the City Commission, and to the person designated by the city to be responsible for administration of the city's cable television franchise. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75) 
Sec. 44.64. - Executive Director and employees. 
    The Facilitating Board may create such professional, clerical and other positions as may be necessary in order to properly carry on its duties; provided, however, that any position so created, before being filled, shall be approved by the City Commission by a vote spread upon its minutes. Except for the appointment of an executive director, if one is needed, all positions created by the Facilitating Board shall be filled by a person whose name is taken from an appropriate civil service list prepared under the civil service section of the Charter of the city. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75) 
Sec. 44.65. - Budget. 
    No commitments for employees, equipment, services, programming or related funding shall ever exceed the budget of the Facilitating Board, a copy of which shall be provided to the City Commission for approval at least 60 days prior to the commencement of the Facilitating Board's fiscal year. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75) 
Sec. 44.66. - Funds. 
    The Facilitating Board will receive 40 percent of the funds from the cable television franchises which are provided for in section 7 of the franchise document for public uses as determined by the Board. The Board may receive funds from other sources such as federal, state or foundation grants of subsidies, or may receive funds from private contributors. All applications for grants of subsidies shall be in the name of the city, and receive the approval of the City Commission. All funds, from whatever source, shall be accounted for in the budgeting process. An audit shall be performed annually by an independent certified public accountant, with a copy of the report being furnished to the City Commission and to the person designated by the city to be responsible for administration of the city's cable television franchise. 
(Ord. 24937, passed 7-2-75) 
Secs. 44.67-44.69. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - PRIORITY BOARDS 

Secs. 44.70-44.75. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. 31308-14, passed April 30, 2014, repealed §§ 44.70-44.75. The previous §§ 44.70-44.75 pertained to Priority Boards established; Priority Board area of representation; Purpose, powers and duties; Elections, members and terms of office; Composition of the Priority Board; and Priority Board staffing, respectively, and derived from Ord. 30022-01, passed October 3, 2001. 
CHAPTER 45. - URBAN RENEWAL[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 30722-08, §§ 1 and 2, adopted Feb. 20, 2008, repealed the former Ch. 45, §§ 45.01-45.99, and enacted a new Ch. 45 as set out herein. The former Ch. 45 pertained to data access control and derived from Ord. 24963, passed Aug. 13, 1975; Ord. 25213, passed Dec. 15, 1976; Am. Ord. 25244, passed Feb. 16, 1977; and Am. Ord. 26160, passed Feb. 4, 1981. 

Sec. 45.01. - Necessity of urban renewal. 
    It is found and determined that there exists within the city blighted and deteriorated areas of the nature defined in this chapter that substantially impair and arrest the sound growth of the community; that constitute an economic and social liability; and that are detrimental to the public peace, property, health, and safety in their present condition and use; and that the elimination and prevention of recurrence by the city, in whole or in part, of blighted and deteriorated areas by urban renewal as provided herein is necessary for the public welfare and is a public use and purpose for which public money may be expended and private property acquired by purchase, by donation, and if necessary by eminent domain, and are governmental functions of concern to the city, and require the exercise of the powers of government granted to the city by the provisions of Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution, and that the necessity in the public interest and general welfare for the provisions of this chapter is hereby declared as a matter of legislative determination. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.02. - City Commission policy on urban renewal. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the Commission of the city to promote and encourage the sound development, including renewal and redevelopment where necessary, of the entire city in accordance with the comprehensive plan and program for the city. The commission realizes that the city will be unable to carry out coordinated and effective programs for renewing the city without the cooperation and support of the public as a whole. Therefore, the Commission stands ready to cooperate with private enterprise, civic groups, neighborhood agencies, and governmental agencies in developing and carrying out urban renewal projects to promote the sound development of new areas, to eliminate and prevent the recurrence or spread of blighted and deteriorated areas in the city. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.03. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Blighted area. An area within the corporate limits of the city in which there are a majority of structures or other improvements, which, by reason of dilapidation, deterioration, age or obsolescence, inadequate provision for ventilation, light, air, sanitation, or open spaces, high density of population and overcrowding, unsafe and unsanitary conditions, or the existence of conditions that endanger life or property by fire or other hazards and causes, or any combination of such factors, and an area with overcrowding or improper location of structures on the land, excessive dwelling unit density, detrimental land uses or conditions, unsafe, congested, poorly designed streets, or inadequate public facilities or utilities, all of which substantially impairs or retards the sound growth and planning of the city, constitutes an economic or social liability, and is detrimental to the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare. 
    Deteriorated area. An area, whether predominantly built up or open, that is not a blighted area, but that because of the existence in the area of deteriorated structures or other improvements, structures or improvements evidencing a lack of maintenance and repair or conditions of age or obsolescence, building vacancies, vacant or under-utilized structures, or structures that involve an under utilization of the land, or violations of building, sanitation or other city codes, or nonconforming uses under applicable zoning codes, or because of the existence in the area of vacant, underdeveloped or under utilized parcels, faulty lot layout in relation to size, adequacy, accessibility, or usefulness, incompatible land uses or land use relationships, obsolescence or nonconformance with respect to the requirements of modern building codes, unsafe, congested or deteriorated streets, poorly designed, defective or inadequate streets or street layout, deteriorated or inadequate public utilities or other public improvements, unsanitary or unsafe conditions, deterioration of site or other improvements, diversity of ownership, tax or special assessment delinquencies, defective or unusual conditions to title, vacant and undeveloped parcels in a state of nonproductive use, conditions that are impediments to land assembly and new development for productive uses of the land in conformance with applicable zoning codes or consistent with the requirements of modern building codes, or the existence of environmentally hazardous materials, or the existence of other conditions that adversely affect or are detrimental to life or property, or any combination of the foregoing, and that substantially impairs or retards the sound growth of the city, or constitutes an economic or social liability, and is detrimental to the public health, safety, morals or welfare in its present condition and use. 
    Comprehensive plan and program. A broad and general guide and pattern for the future growth and development of the city, including maps, plats, charts, and descriptive, interpretive, and analytical narratives, as may be appropriate and as may be adopted by the Commission or the City Plan Board from time to time. 
    Project area. A blighted or deteriorated area or any combination or part thereof that the City Commission designates as of a character and size appropriate for urban renewal and for which an urban renewal or redevelopment plan has been approved by the City Commission. 
    Rehabilitation or conservation or reconditioning . Includes those efforts and actions identified in items (3), (4), (5), (6), (8), and (9) of the definition for urban renewal. 
    Clearance or redevelopment. Includes those efforts and actions identified in items (1), (2), (3), (4), and (7) of the definition for urban renewal. 
    Urban renewal. The city's efforts and actions, including planning and other acts connected therewith, of the city, with or without federal or state aid or assistance, for developing, undertaking, and carrying out the elimination and prevention of the development or spread of blighted or deteriorated areas, and may involve clearance and redevelopment, or rehabilitation and conservation, or any combination or part thereof, in accordance with an urban renewal plan to the full extent of and in accordance with the rights, powers, and authority of the city, whether derived from the applicable provisions of the federal or state Constitution or statutes, or the city Charter and city ordinances. Such actions may include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Acquisition of realty, including the acquisition of air rights. 
(2)  Demolition and removal of buildings and improvements. 
(3)  Installation, construction, or reconstruction of streets, utilities, parks, playgrounds, and other improvements necessary for carrying out an urban renewal plan. 
(4)  Disposition of property for uses in accordance with an urban renewal plan. 
(5)  Encouraging and assisting interested citizens in a private program of voluntary repair and rehabilitation of buildings or other improvements in accordance with an urban renewal plan, with or without aid and assistance by Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance or special support for mortgage financing through the Federal National Mortgage Association or similar organizations. 
(6)  Acquisition of any real property where necessary to: 
(a)  Eliminate unhealthful, unsanitary, or unsafe conditions, 
(b)  Lessen lot occupancy or population density that creates such conditions, 
(c)  Eliminate uses incompatible with the general character of a neighborhood and detrimental to the public welfare, 
(d)  Remove or prevent the spread of blight or deterioration, 
(e)  Assemble land required for redevelopment necessary to carry out a renewal plan, or 
(f)  Provide land for needed public facilities; 
and disposition of property, so acquired in accordance with this item (6), for voluntary repair and rehabilitation of buildings or other improvements in accordance with an urban renewal plan. 
(7)  Construction of foundations and platforms necessary for the appropriate provisions of air right sites in accordance with an urban renewal plan. 
(8)  Acquisition and repair or rehabilitation, and resale, of structures by the city under controls established by the city for dwelling use or related facilities. 
(9)  Relocating within a project area a structure that the city determines to be of historic value and that will be disposed of to a public body or a private nonprofit organization that will renovate and maintain such structure for historic purposes. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.04. - City Manager to supervise urban renewal. 
    The City Manager is responsible for supervising the urban renewal of this city, coordinating the activities of the city departments, officers, employees, commissions, and boards concerned with such projects, and executing on behalf of the city, as its authorized representative, all applications to the federal government for grants, loans, and advances. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.05. - Preparation of urban renewal studies and plans. 
(A)  The City Manager, with Commission approval as required, shall enter into such contracts on behalf of the city with engineers, architects, and other professional services as necessary to provide the necessary inspections, studies, plans, surveys, and reports in connection with the preparation of urban renewal plans, and in connection with the urban renewal activities to be undertaken by the city. 
(B)  Urban renewal plans, studies, surveys, and reports prepared pursuant to § 45.05(A) shall be submitted and filed with the Commission. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.06. - Contents of urban renewal plan or supporting documentation. 
(A)  Any urban renewal plan hereafter prepared shall be prepared in such detail as to clearly set forth sufficient information to permit the City Plan Board to render its approval or disapproval thereof and in any event such plans may include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  A description of the boundaries of the project area; 
(2)  A land use plan showing the location, character, and extent of public and private land ownership, use, and occupancy proposed within the area; 
(3)  A delineation of areas of land acquisition, demolition, and removal of structures, or of rehabilitation, conservation, or reconditioning of existing structures, if any, as may be proposed to be carried out in the project area; 
(4)  A statement indicating the controls and the use, development, and building restrictions to be placed on the property in the project area to prevent a recurrence of blighted conditions; 
(5)  A report showing the proposed changes, if any, in the building, housing, or zoning ordinances or maps, and in the layout of streets or utilities; 
(6)  A statement of the relationship of the plan to such definite objectives of the city respecting appropriate land uses, improved traffic conditions and transportation, public utilities, recreation, and community facilities and other public improvements. 
    In addition to the foregoing, reports and studies in support of an urban renewal plan may be prepared and presented for review together with the proposed plan, including without limitation a report showing the estimated city portion of urban renewal project costs and potential sources of funding therefor. 
(B)  A relocation plan shall be prepared if required by applicable federal and/or state (if any) funding programs or federal or state law, or in the absence of such requirement may be prepared if the city deems such plan appropriate based upon the urban renewal project contemplated. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.07. - Action by City Plan Board. 
    When an urban renewal plan and the supporting documentation therefor is filed with the Commission, the Commission shall refer such plan and supporting documentation to the City Plan Board for its review and recommendations including its approval or disapproval thereof and its certification as to whether or not the plan is in conformity with the comprehensive plan and program of the city, by causing a copy of such plan and supporting documentation to be delivered to the person charged with the preparation and custody of the record of proceedings of the City Plan Board. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.08. - Public hearing and commission action. 
(A)  The Commission, before approving an urban renewal plan, shall hold a public hearing on the plan at which an opportunity shall be provided to all persons interested to be heard either in person or by counsel, which hearing may be adjourned from time to time. Notice of the date, time, and place of such hearing will be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city once a week for two consecutive weeks on the same day of the week, and at least seven full days shall elapse between the second publication and the date set for the public hearing. The notice shall also contain a description of the project area by its location in relation to highways, streets, watercourses, or other natural or artificial boundaries, and shall also designate the place at which the plan, maps, plats, and other materials describing the project area are and will be available for public inspection. 
(B)  Following the completion of such public hearing, the Commission may either approve or reject the urban renewal plan, or make modifications and approve such plan as modified. Such urban renewal plan as modified shall be resubmitted to the Plan Board, for its written approval or recommendations pursuant to the provisions of § 45.07 whenever the following conditions obtain: 
(1)  The boundaries of the project area are extended to include any land (except land contained within the right-of-way lines of a dedicated street or alley) not included in the urban renewal plan upon which the public hearing was held pursuant to § 45.08(A) and which land is proposed to be acquired by the city, or if there is added a type of urban renewal not included in the urban renewal plan upon which the public hearing was held pursuant to § 45.08(A) that requires the acquisition of additional property not previously designated in the plan for acquisition, or if there is any change deemed by the Commission to be substantial in land use or redevelopment restrictions contained in the urban renewal plan upon which the public hearing was held pursuant to § 45.08(A). 
(2)  Such modifications are other than in accordance with the recommendations of the City Plan Board. 
    Whenever these conditions obtain, a public hearing shall be held on such urban renewal plan as modified prior to approval thereof by the Commission in accordance with the provisions of § 45.08(A). 
(C)  When the Commission wishes to approve an urban renewal plan, it shall do so by ordinance passed by not less than a majority vote, pursuant to the city Charter. 
(D)  The ordinance of the Commission approving an urban renewal plan shall include the following findings: 
(1)  That the project area is a blighted or deteriorated area. 
(2)  That the size and character of the area and the location of elements of blight and deterioration in the area make it appropriate for urban renewal. 
(3)  That the plan conforms to the existing comprehensive plan and program for the overall development of the city. 
(4)  Approval of the relocation plan, if any. 
(5)  Such additional findings as may be required if federal and/or state funding assistance will be utilized, and such other findings as are necessary or appropriate based upon the proposed urban renewal project. 
(E)  Reserved. 
(F)  The Clerk of the Commission shall certify as true and correct and deliver to the City Manager a copy of the aforesaid ordinance of the Commission approving the plan for appropriate further action, and any documents that were submitted to the Commission to support findings made in the ordinance shall be filed with a copy of the ordinance. 
(G)  The taking effect of the ordinance approving an urban renewal plan shall constitute authority to spend moneys of the city appropriated for carrying out urban renewal in accordance with the plan, as well as the proceeds of bonds or notes issued for such purpose, and to accept advances, gifts, donations, and grants from the federal government, the state, any entity, instrumentality, or subdivision of either, or from any other entity or person for such purpose. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.09. - Modification of urban renewal plans. 
    An approved urban renewal plan may be amended, modified, or changed by ordinance of the Commission from time to time; however, if the boundaries of the project area are extended to include any land (except land contained within the right-of-way lines of a dedicated street or alley) not previously included therein and that will result in the acquisition of additional property by the city not previously designated in the plan for acquisition, or if there is added a new type of urban renewal that requires the acquisition of property not previously designated for acquisition, or if there is any change in the land use or redevelopment restrictions deemed by the Commission to be substantial, or if there is a change in the proposed location, extent, or character of a public improvement or utility within the project area or in any other matter directly within the jurisdiction of the City Plan Board to approve or disapprove, or if such amendment, modification, or change is deemed by the Commission to be a substantial change in the urban renewal plan, then all of the proceedings provided for in §§ 45.07 and 45.08 shall be carried out in connection with such amendment, modification, or change, except that the findings to be made in the ordinance approving the urban renewal plan shall be altered to fit the then circumstances. The land use or redevelopment restrictions directly applicable to any land previously conveyed by the city may not be amended, modified, or changed in a manner that would adversely affect the use of such land without the consent of the property owner thereto. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Sec. 45.10. - Execution of urban renewal projects. 
(A)  Acquisition of property. When authorized by the Commission, the city shall cause the necessary steps to be taken to acquire the parcels of land in the project area in accordance with an urban renewal plan, including but not limited to, the negotiation for such parcels, obtaining appraisals, title examinations and reports, executing contracts for any of such services and appropriate documents to transfer title to the city; however, in the event that appropriation of property is necessary, the Commission shall initiate and carry out, with the appropriate assistance of the several officers, employees, boards, and commissions of the city, the proceedings in accordance with the city Charter and R.C. Chapter 163. 
(B)  City activities preparing property for disposition. The city shall make the contracts, purchase the supplies and materials, and provide the labor, pursuant to and in accordance with applicable provisions of the city Charter and ordinances, and initiate such city activities as may be necessary to carry out an urban renewal project, including but not limited to the demolition, rehabilitation, or repair of structures (whether voluntarily by the private owners thereof or by the city), the removal of pavement, sidewalks, lighting and trees, capping, removal, and relocation of city-owned utility lines, grading, construction of site improvements and supporting facilities, and the temporary lease, rental, or permission to let others use structures or parcels of land while owned by the city, relocation activities and the enforcement of any applicable provisions of law or redevelopment agreements relative to building, zoning, platting, and the repair or rehabilitation of property and structures remaining in private ownership. 
(C)  Disposition of property. After its determination that real property is not needed for any municipal use because continued public ownership thereof will not be necessary to the carrying out of the purpose of eliminating conditions of blight and deterioration and because the lease or sale thereof is necessary to carry out the purpose of preventing the occurrence or recurrence of the conditions of blight and deterioration, the Commission may authorize by ordinance the transfer, lease, or conveyance of any real property in accordance with and for the purposes of the plan, subject to such lawful terms, conditions, restrictions, and covenants (including covenants running with the land) to assist in carrying out the purposes of the plan. All dispositions of real property shall be at such consideration as is set out in the disposition agreement approved by the Commission. The manner of disposition may be by negotiation or such other method as is determined appropriate by the Commission based upon the applicable facts. The financial and legal ability of those proposing to acquire or lease such real property shall be considered in all dispositions. The City Manager shall execute, on behalf of the city, such instruments as may be necessary to transfer, lease, or convey such real property in the form approved by the City Attorney and authorized by the Commission, which form shall include all covenants running with the land, including any portions of the plan incorporated by reference. The City Manager or designee shall execute, on behalf of the city, any certificates of completion of improvements or other appropriate instruments that may be necessary in accordance with any covenants in such instruments of lease or conveyance. 
(D)  In the execution of urban renewal projects, the Commission may authorize, as to any appropriate projects or parts of projects, the employment of community improvement corporations, community redevelopment corporations, limited divided housing corporations, and metropolitan housing authorities, as defined by the statutes of Ohio, and when authorized by ordinance of the Commission may grant leases, make conveyances and enter into agreements with such corporations related to appropriate aspects of such projects to the full extent of the powers possessed by such corporations. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
Secs. 45.11-45.19. - Reserved. 
Sec. 45.20. - Community development area. 
(A)  "Deteriorating area" means an area, whether predominately built up or open, that is not a blighted area or a deteriorated area, but that is an area in which at least 25 percent of the structures are deteriorated or deteriorating, or at least two of the major elements of the public infrastructure improvements are deteriorated, and because there exists in the area conditions involving lack of or inadequate investment in new housing, commercial or industrial facilities, decline in property values, significant residential or commercial vacancy rates, or a substantial number or proportion of abandoned, undeveloped or underutilized parcels, or incompatible land uses, inadequate community and public utilities, abandoned railways, closed schools, or other abandoned or vacant facilities. 
(B)  "Community development area" means an area designated by the City Commission that contains a majority of residents who are low or moderate income persons, or is located in an area that qualifies as a deteriorating area, and which a Community Development Plan has been approved by the City Commission. 
(C)  For the purpose of using Community Development Block Grant funds in areas that do not meet the definition of "deteriorated area" in § 45.03, the City Commission may identify an area for redevelopment and designate such area a community development area. 
(Am. Ord. 30722-08, § 1, 2-20-08) 
CHAPTER 46. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 46.01. - Department of Fire established. 
    The Department of Fire is created and established. It shall have the control and management of the fire prevention, fire investigation, fire suppression, and emergency medical forces of the city. 
(Ord. 17771, passed 7-8-53; Am. Ord. 22988, passed 5-29-68; Am. Ord. 25324, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78; Am. Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.02. - Director of Fire; appointment. 
    The Department of Fire shall be under the charge of a Director of Fire, who may also be referred to as the Fire Chief. The Director of Fire shall be appointed by the City Manager, and shall serve until removed by the City Manager or until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. 17771, passed 7-8-53; Am. Ord. 22988, passed 5-29-68; Am. Ord. 25324, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.03. - Duties of Director of Fire. 
    The Director of Fire shall perform such duties and functions as are provided by the Charter and ordinances of the city, subject to the management and control of the City Manager in all matters. 
(Ord. 17771, passed 7-8-53; Am. Ord. 22988, passed 5-29-68; Am. Ord. 25324, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.04. - Divisions of Department of Fire. 
    The Department of Fire shall be divided and organized into the following divisions: 
(A)  Division of Emergency Services. This division shall be responsible for providing fire and rescue activities for all major fires and related emergencies and disasters 24 hours a day. In addition, this division shall direct the city's emergency medical activities and coordinate program responsibilities with other departments and agencies to ensure effective and efficient services. 
(B)  Division of Support Services and Resource Management. This division shall be responsible for efficiently directing the internal administration operation, communication center, information and technology records management operation, and building and vehicle maintenance components of the Department of Fire. 
(C)  Division of Strategic Programs and Safety. This division shall be responsible for efficiently directing the Department of Fire's training function, fire prevention and life safety services, emergency and strategic planning functions, including coordination of the city's emergency operations and disaster planning initiatives, and internal employee risk management functions. 
(Ord. 17771, passed 7-8-53; Am. Ord. 22988, passed 5-29-68; Am. Ord. 25324, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78; Am. Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80; Am. Ord. 27881, passed 1-25-89; Am. Ord. 29813-00, passed 3-15-00) 
Sec. 46.05. - Duties of Department of Fire. 
    The Department of Fire shall have the authority to enforce or assist in the enforcement of all laws and ordinances relating to fire prevention, including, but not limited to the following: 
(A)  The construction, protection, and occupancy features of buildings to minimize danger to life from fire, smoke, fumes, or panic. 
(B)  The number, size, and arrangement of exit facilities. 
(C)  The installation and maintenance of automatic and other private fire alarm systems and fire extinguishing equipment. 
(D)  The conditions which are liable to cause or contribute to the spread of fire in or on the premises, building, or structure or endanger the occupants thereof. 
(E)  The storage and use of explosive, combustible, and flammable materials, compounds, and gases. 
(F)  The investigation of the cause or origin and circumstances of fires. 
(G)  The conditions which may interfere with the efficiency and use of any fire protection equipment. 
(H)  The conditions arising from defective or improperly used or installed electrical wiring, equipment, or appliances. 
(I)  The determination of the general safety of all buildings, structures, and premises within the city. 
(Ord. 16147, passed 12-18-46; Am. Ord. 17228, passed 10-17-51; Am. Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Secs. 46.06-46.09. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 46.10. - Enforcement officer. 
    The Director of the Department of Fire, or his duly authorized representative, shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of Chapters 46 and 92 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances and the Unified Building Code, relating to fire prevention or life safety. The Revised Code of General Ordinances and the Unified Building Code are hereinafter referred to as R.C.G.O. and UBC, respectively. The designated Enforcement Officer of these provisions is hereinafter referred to as the fire official. 
(Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.11. - Inspections. 
(A)  The fire official shall have the authority to inspect all structures and premises as often as may be necessary for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire, contribute to the spread of fire, interfere with fire fighting operations, endanger life, or any violations of the provisions or intent of the R.C.G.O. or any other law, rule, or regulation affecting fire safety. 
(B)  The interior areas of privately occupied dwelling units may be inspected only with the consent of either an occupant or owner, or upon the authority of a search warrant. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority to inspect common areas of two-family or multi-family dwellings. 
(Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80; Am. Ord. 29280-96, passed 9-18-96) 
Sec. 46.12. - Right of entry. 
    Whenever necessary for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of the R.C.G.O., or whenever the fire official has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any structure or on any premises, any condition which makes such structure or premises unsafe, the fire official may enter such structure or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed on the fire official by the R.C.G.O., provided that if such structure or premises be occupied, he shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such entry is refused, the fire official shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.13. - Investigation of fires. 
    The Department of Fire shall have the authority to investigate, or cause to be investigated, every fire or explosion occurring within the jurisdiction that is of a suspicious nature or which involves the loss of life or serious injury or causes destruction or damage to property. Such investigation shall be initiated immediately on the occurrence of such fire or explosion, and if it appears that such an occurrence is of a suspicious nature, the fire official shall take charge immediately of the physical evidence, and in order to preserve any physical evidence relating to the cause or origin of such fire or explosion, take means to prevent access by any person or persons to such building, structure, or premises until such evidence has been properly processed. The fire official shall notify such persons designated by law to pursue investigations into such matters and shall further cooperate with such authorities in the collection of evidence and prosecution of the case. 
(Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.14. - Powers of investigators. 
(A)  The Director of Fire shall have the authority to designate one or more members of the Department of Fire who have received the required training to become law enforcement officers and have been duly sworn in as law enforcement officers to serve the function of fire investigator. Fire investigators shall have the power and duty to investigate the cause of all fires, to issue subpoenas to compel the attendance of witnesses to testify in relation to any matter which is a proper subject of inquiry and investigation, and to issue subpoenas for the production of any book, paper, or document. The fire investigator may administer an oath to any person appearing as a witness before him, he may examine witnesses, and may do and perform all other acts necessary to the effective discharge of such duties. 
(B)  The fire investigator may make arrests, bear firearms, and enter for the purpose of examination any building which, in his opinion, is in danger from fire. 
(Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80; Am. Ord. 26117, passed 1-28-81) 
Sec. 46.15. - Failure to cooperate. 
(A)  No witness shall refuse to be sworn or refuse to testify, or disobey an order of the fire investigator, or fail or refuse to produce a book, paper, or document concerning a matter under examination. 
(B)  No witness shall engage in contemptuous conduct after being summoned by such officer to appear before him to give testimony in relation to a matter or subject under investigation. 
(C)  Whoever violates any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense, for each subsequent offense of the same provision, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(D)  Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(E)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as to grant the fire investigator the right to abridge the civil rights of a witness. 
(Ord. 26117, passed 1-28-81) 
Sec. 46.16. - Response to motor vehicle accidents. 
    The city may assess a fee to recover the costs of Fire Department personnel and equipment dispatched in response to a motor vehicle accident. The city shall assess the person responsible for the accident, regardless of what services are provided by the Fire Department in responding to the accident. The city shall establish a fee assessed pursuant to this section based upon the actual personnel and equipment costs of the city in responding to a motor vehicle accident. The city may periodically adjust the fee assessed pursuant to this section as needed to recover its actual costs. The city may recover fees assessed pursuant to this section by collection or other lawful means. 
(Ord. 30390-04, passed 9-22-04) 
Secs. 46.17-46.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 46.20. - Records of fire and emergency medical service. 
    The Director of Fire shall maintain records of fires and emergency medical service as required by law. 
(Ord. 16147, passed 12-18-46; Am. Ord. 17228, passed 10-17-51; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78; Am. Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 46.21. - Fire zones. 
(A)  No vehicle shall approach any fire to which the Department of Fire has responded or is called, and come to a stop or park at a point nearer than 1,000 feet of such fire unless otherwise ordered by the police to do so. 
(B)  Vehicles of the Departments of Police and Fire, and emergency vehicles belonging to the Dayton Power and Light Company or the City Water Department shall be excepted from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.22. - Authority at fires and other emergencies. 
    The Director of Fire or his duly authorized representative who is in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency involving the protection of life or property, is empowered to direct such operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any suspected or reported fires, gas leaks, or other hazardous conditions or situations or to take any other legal action necessary in the reasonable performance of his duty. The fire official may prohibit any person, vehicle, or object from approaching the scene and may remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle, or object which may impede or interfere with the operation of the Fire Department. The fire official may remove or cause to be removed any person, vehicle, or object from hazardous areas. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.23. - Hazardous areas. 
(A)  All persons ordered to leave a hazardous area shall do so immediately and shall not reenter the area until authorized to do so by the fire official. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.24. - Interference with Fire Department operations. 
(A)  No person shall interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct, or restrict the mobility of, or block the path of travel of any Fire Department emergency vehicle, or interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct, or hamper any Fire Department operation. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.25. - Vehicles crossing fire hose. 
(A)  No vehicle shall be driven or propelled over any unprotected fire hose of the Fire Department when laid down on any street, alleyway, private drive, or any other vehicular roadway without the consent of the fire official in command of the operation. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.26. - Vehicles following fire apparatus. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, to follow closer than 300 feet from any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive any vehicle within the block or immediate area where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to fire alarm. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.27. - Unlawful boarding or tampering with Fire Department emergency equipment. 
(A)  No person shall without proper authorization from the fire official in charge of the Fire Department emergency equipment, cling to, attach himself to, climb on or into, Board, or swing on any Fire Department emergency vehicle, whether the same is in motion or at rest, or sound the siren, horn, bell, or other sound-producing device thereon, or to manipulate, or tamper with, or attempt to manipulate or tamper with any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, brakes, pumps, or any equipment or protective clothing on, or a part of, any Fire Department emergency vehicle. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.28. - Damage, injury to Fire Department equipment or personnel. 
    No person shall damage or deface, or attempt, or conspire to damage or deface any Fire Department emergency vehicle at any time, or to injure, to attempt to injure or conspire to injure Fire Department personnel while performing departmental duties. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.29. - Street obstruction preventing access of fire apparatus. 
    No person shall construct, place, or maintain any bumps, fences, gates, chains, bars, pipes, wood or metal horses, or any other type of obstruction in or on any street within the boundaries of the city without first having obtained a permit therefor. The word "street" as used in this chapter shall mean any roadway or alley accessible to the public or vehicular traffic including, but not limited to, private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets, alleys, and highways within the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
DIVISION 4. - OUTSIDE CITY FIRE SERVICE 

Sec. 46.30. - Fire protection outside city authorized. 
    Any municipality, governmental subdivision, agency of the federal government, private corporation, or individual owning property located outside the corporate limits of the city and desiring to enter into a contract with the city for the furnishing of fire protection to property may submit a written application to the Director of Fire. The application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the location of the property for which protection is desired, the current real estate tax duplicate valuation including land, buildings, and improvements of the property, the period for which fire protection is desired, and the name of any person other than the applicant to be authorized to issue a call for fire protection. If the applicant is a municipality or other governmental subdivision, the application shall be accompanied by an accurate map of such municipality or other governmental subdivision showing all streets and roads therein with the approximate location of all buildings and especially indicating factories, office buildings, apartment buildings, and other types of large building construction, and shall designate the person authorized to issue a call for fire protection. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.31. - Fire protection outside city restricted. 
    No fire service shall be rendered outside the city by the Department of Fire except in the following cases: 
(A)  To protect property within the city threatened by fire outside the city; 
(B)  To protect city property located outside the city or the operating property of a public utility serving the city; 
(C)  To protect property of municipalities, other governmental subdivisions, private corporations, and individuals who enter into contracts with the city for the furnishing of fire protection in accordance with the provisions of §§ 46.30 through 46.37; 
(D)  To go to the aid of any surrounding city or other governmental subdivision which is threatened by a large conflagration, catastrophe, or emergency. 
(E)  To go to the scene of any aircraft crash or other accident involving a carrier which has resulted in a fire and where life or property is endangered. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.32. - Contract provisions for outside fire protection. 
(A)  The Director of the Department of Fire may with the approval of the City Manager enter into a contract with an applicant provided the city may reasonably provide the fire protection desired by the applicant. However, the payment of the standby or minimum charge must be paid either for the remainder of the calendar year in which the application is filed or for the entire term for which protection is desired if less than one year so long as the payment is at least $10.00. No advance payment shall be required from any agency of the federal government or from any other agency or political subdivision of the state. If the application is not approved, the amount of such deposit in excess of $10.00 shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(B)  The contract shall be for a period of not more than three years, but shall in every case expire on the last day of the calendar year, and shall provide for the following: 
(1)  If the applicant is a municipality, it shall maintain a Fire Department adequate for its ordinary fire protection purposes, and shall call on the city for additional fire service only for a fire too large to be handled by its Fire Department, or when its Fire Department is already engaged at a fire. 
(2)  The Department of Fire shall answer any call for fire service in the same manner and with personnel and equipment of the same kind as used for similar fires within the city, provided, that, in the opinion of the Director of Fire, or person authorized to act in his absence, such personnel and equipment are not needed to protect property within the city from a fire then in progress, or from the threat of fire or general conflagration. 
(3)  The contract shall in no event confer a right of action for damages either on the contracting property owner, or any resident of a municipality or other governmental subdivision with whom a contract is made, for operation or failure to operate thereunder. 
(4)  The amount payable by the applicant under the terms of the contract. 
(5)  The amount and time of payment of the standby charge or minimum charge. 
(6)  No fire service shall be required to be furnished while the applicant is in default for payment of any amount due under the contract. 
(7)  The manner by which the applicant will designate any person other than himself authorized to issue a call for fire protection. 
(8)  The contract may be terminated by either party by giving written notice thereof 15 days prior to the termination. 
(9)  Other provisions that may be agreed on. 
(C)  The applicant shall also be required to provide a bond with good and sufficient sureties in favor of the city in a sum of not less than $1,000.00 conditioned on the applicant's payment for fire protection furnished according to the terms of the contract, or procure and furnish satisfactory evidence that he has obtained and is keeping in full force and effect during the term of his contract a policy of insurance an amount of not less than $1,000.00 guaranteeing the payment to the city for any service which it may render under the terms of the contract. Provided, however, that no such bond or proof of insurance shall be required of any agency of the federal government, or of any agency or political subdivision of the state. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.33. - Charges for fire protection outside city. 
    The applicant for fire protection outside the city shall pay an annual standby charge, which may be prorated on a monthly basis where the contract period is less than the calendar year, to be determined according to the following schedule: 
(A)  The applicant maintaining a paid, full-time Fire Department which is, in the opinion of the Director of Fire, adequate to meet the normal fire protection requirements of the applicant, shall pay an amount equal to .3 of one mill of the current real estate tax duplicate valuation, including land, buildings, and improvements, of the property of the applicant for which protection is desired. 
(B)  All other applicants except agencies of the federal government, any single institution operated by a county or other governmental subdivision, which institution is used for benevolent or charitable purposes, and any semipublic or privately owned institution for benevolent, charitable, or religious purposes, shall pay an amount equal to one mill of the current real estate tax duplicate valuation, including land, buildings, and improvements of the property for which protection is desired. However, if the annual standby charge shall be less than the following minimum charges such applicant shall pay the appropriate minimum charge for each property for which protection is to be furnished, instead of the annual standby charge as above determined: 
(1)  If the property for which protection is to be furnished is used for residential purposes, not for profit, the annual minimum charge shall be $50.00. 
(2)  If the property for which protection is to be furnished is used for the operation of a business for profit, the annual minimum charge shall be $150.00. 
(3)  If the applicant is a municipality or other governmental subdivision, the annual minimum charge shall be $300.00. 
(C)  If the applicant is an agency of the federal government, the annual standby charge or minimum charge shall be determined by the Director of Fire with the approval of the City Commission. 
(D)  If the applicant is a single institution operated by a county or other governmental subdivision, which institution is used for benevolent or charitable purposes, or if the applicant is a semipublic or privately owned institution for benevolent, charitable, or religious purposes, the annual standby charge shall be $50.00. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.34. - Additional charges for fire protection outside city. 
    In addition to the annual standby charge or minimum charge as established in § 46.33 above, the applicant shall pay the following amount for each call for fire service answered by the city: 
(A)  For the first hour or fraction thereof, the charge shall be as follows: 
(1)  One hundred dollars for each engine called. 
(2)  One hundred fifty dollars for each ladder truck called. 
(3)  Twenty-five dollars for each chief officer or other service required such as a motor mechanic or hydrant mechanic. 
(B)  For each additional hour or fraction thereof, the charge shall be as follows: 
(1)  Sixty dollars for each engine called. 
(2)  Ninety dollars for each ladder truck called. 
(3)  Fifteen dollars for each chief officer or other service required. 
(C)  In those instances where an alarm has been instituted by the malfunction of a mechanical alarm system, an amount less than that provided in subsection (A) above, may be made by the Director of Fire based on the cause of such false alarm and the frequency of false alarms involving the protected property, however, such amount shall not be less than the following: 
(1)  Ten dollars for each engine called. 
(2)  Fifteen dollars for each ladder truck called. 
(3)  Ten dollars for each chief officer or other service required, such as a motor mechanic or hydrant mechanic. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.35. - Contract renewals. 
    Renewals of contracts of fire protection service made in accordance with the provisions of §§ 46.30 through 46.37 shall be made as in the case of the original application. Applications for renewal shall be made not less than 30 days before the expiration date of the existing contract. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.36. - Mutual assistance contracts. 
    The provisions of §§ 46.30 through 46.37 shall not apply to fire protection contracts calling for mutual assistance between parties thereto in the event of fire or disaster, and based on the comparability of the personnel and equipment which may be furnished by the respective parties to such contracts. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 46.37. - Exceptions to contract requirements. 
    As a public service, the Director of Fire, or person authorized to act in his absence, may send trucks, equipment, and personnel of the Department of Fire to surrounding cities, villages, or communities in the event of a large conflagration, catastrophe, or to the scene of the emergency, or to the scene of any aircraft crash or other accident involving a carrier which has resulted in a fire and where life or property is endangered, without charge, when, in his discretion, he believes such trucks, equipment, and personnel will be of assistance to the stricken area. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
CHAPTER 47. - DEPARTMENT OF LAW 

Sec. 47.01. - Department of Law established. 
    A Department of Law is established in the municipality. 
(Ord. 25781, passed 5-30-79) 
Sec. 47.02. - Director of Law; appointment. 
    The Department of Law shall be under the charge of a Director, who shall serve as City Attorney. The Director shall be appointed by the City Manager, and shall serve until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. 25781, passed 5-30-79) 
Sec. 47.03. - Duties of the Director. 
(A)  The Director of Law, who shall also be known as the City Attorney, shall be the head of the Department of Law. He shall be the legal advisor of, and attorney and counselor for the city and for all officers and departments thereof in matters relating to their official duties. 
(B)  The Director shall prosecute and defend all suits for and in behalf of the city, and shall prepare all contracts, bonds, and other instruments in writing in which the city is concerned, and shall endorse on each his approval of the form and correctness thereof. 
(C)  The Director of Law shall be the prosecuting attorney in the Municipal Court, and shall provide for the prosecution of all cases brought before such court; and he shall perform when appropriate the same duties as are required of the prosecuting attorney of the county, so far as they are applicable thereto. 
(D)  The Director shall prosecute or defend, for and in behalf of the city, all complaints, suits, and controversies in which the city is a party, and such other suits, matters, and controversies as he shall be legally directed to prosecute or defend. 
(E)  The Director shall render legal opinions upon any question of law involving the respective powers and duties of the City Commission, the City Manager, the Director of any department, or any officer or Board not included within a department. 
(F)  The Director shall perform all other duties as required by the Charter, ordinance, or other appropriate legal authority, and shall perform the duties which are imposed upon city solicitors or Directors of Law by the general law of the state beyond the competence of the Charter to alter or require. 
(G)  The Director shall be subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager or his designee in all matters. 
(Ord. 25781, passed 5-30-79) 
Sec. 47.04. - Divisions of the department. 
(A)  The Department of Law is organized into an Office of the Director, a Deputy Director and the following additional divisions: 
(1)  Civil Division. 
(2)  Prosecutor Division. 
(B)  The Director of Law is responsible for the overall operation and performance of the Department of Law. A Deputy Director shall assist the Director in managing the day-to-day operations of the Department of Law. The Office of the Director shall perform the following duties and functions: 
(1)  Provide fiscal, policy and operational planning and other administrative support functions for the Department of Law; 
(2)  Approve and administer any and all contracts, agreements, purchase orders or other arrangements for outside counsel representing the City of Dayton or city officials or employees; 
(3)  Oversee the operation of the Civil Division and Prosecutor Division; and 
(4)  Perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as assigned to the City Attorney by the Charter and ordinances of the city, and other applicable statutes and laws. 
(C)  Civil Division. This division is responsible for managing all legal matters involving civil litigation, collective bargaining, labor relations and personnel actions. This division is responsible for contract review, legislation, real property acquisitions and dispositions, other instruments, and all other general civil matters. 
(D)  Prosecutor Division. This Division is responsible for managing and prosecuting all legal matters involving criminal and misdemeanor traffic offenses and the enforcement of city ordinances. 
(E)  The Director, the Deputy Director and the heads of the Civil and Prosecutor Divisions serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. 
(Ord. 27781, passed 5-30-79; Am. Ord. 27198, passed 5-1-85; Am. Ord. 30445-05, passed 5-18-05)
