No penalty prescribed in this division shall be imposed on any vehicle combination if the overload on any axle does not exceed 1,000 pounds, and if the immediately preceding or following axle, excepting the front axle of the vehicle combination, is underloaded by the same or a greater amount. For purposes of this division, two axles on one vehicle less than eight feet apart, shall be considered as one axle. 
(Ord. 25496, passed 4-5-78; Am. Ord. 26731, passed 2-16-83; Am. Ord. 26782, passed 4-27-83; Am Ord. 29817-00, passed 4-5-00) 
CHAPTER 72. - PARKING, STOPPING, AND STANDING 

Sec. 72.01. - Manner of parking. 
(A)  The traffic engineer may indicate by markings on the curb, pavement, or otherwise in what manner and where vehicles may be halted, whether by parallel parking or diagonal parking. 
(B)  Every vehicle stopped or parked on a roadway, except where angle parking is permitted or where there is an adjacent curb shall be halted with the right-hand wheels of such vehicle parallel with and not more than 12 inches from the right-hand curb unless it is impossible to approach so close to the curb, and in such case, the stop shall be as close to the curb as possible, except that on all streets or parts of streets on which trolley coaches operate, all vehicles shall be parked not over six inches from the curb. On a one-way street halting may be permitted with the left-hand wheels adjacent to and within 12 inches of the left-hand curb. 
(C)  No vehicle or trackless trolley shall be stopped or parked on a road or highway with the vehicle or trackless trolley facing in a direction other than the direction of travel on that side of the road or highway. 
(D)  When diagonal standing is indicated by sign, a series of parallel lines marked on the highway, or another appropriate method, a stopped vehicle shall stand with the right or left front wheel at the curb. The vehicle shall be placed wholly within the established space for one vehicle. 
(E)  Any vehicle of a tenant occupying a wholesale market stand on the wholesale street market during the market hours of a market day shall be parked thereat according to the requirements of the ordinance regarding wholesale market stands, and not pursuant hereto. 
(F)  No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle, except a public safety or emergency vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, effectively setting the parking brake, and when the vehicle is standing on any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway. 
(G)  (1)  On any highway not having a curbed roadway, no person shall stop, park, or leave standing any vehicle whether attended or unattended on the paved or main traveled part of the highway if it is practicable to stop, park, or so leave such vehicle off the paved or main traveled part of the highway. In every event a clear and unobstructed portion of the highway opposite such standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and for pedestrians on the sidewalk area and a clear view of such stopped vehicle shall be available from a distance of 200 feet in each direction on such highway. 
(2)  This division does not apply to the driver of any disabled vehicle while on the paved or improved or main traveled portion of a highway in such manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving the disabled vehicle in such position. 
(H)  When any police officer finds a vehicle standing on a highway in violation of division (G) such officer may move such vehicle; require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to move the same, to a position off the paved or improved or main traveled part of such highway; or impound the vehicle. 
(I)  Air compressors, tractors, trucks, and other equipment while being used in the construction, reconstruction, installation, repair, or removal of facilities near, on, over, or under a highway may stop, stand, or park where necessary in order to perform such work, provided a flagman is on duty or warning signs or lights are displayed as may be prescribed by the Director Ohio Department of Transportation. 
(J)  Notwithstanding any of the above provisions to the contrary, two-wheeled motorcycles may be parked at an angle (diagonally with the rear wheel being the closest to the curb and not more than 12 inches from the curb) instead of parallel with the curb. Where the parking spaces are marked, only one motorcycle shall be permitted to occupy a parking space at one time, and shall be centered as closely as possible between the markings. Where parking spaces are not individually marked, motorcycles shall not park any closer than two feet from the rear point of any vehicle in front nor any closer than two feet from the front point of any vehicle behind. 
    Motorcycles with more than two wheels shall comply with the parking regulations applicable to other motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 17178, passed 6-27-51; Am. Ord. 17246, passed 10-31-51; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 29297-96, passed 11-13-96) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.02. - Parking length of vehicles. 
    No person shall park any vehicle diagonally as provided by § 72.01 if such vehicle is more than 18 feet, six inches in length. Vehicles more than 18 feet, six inches in length shall be parked parallel to the curb, and no person shall park any such vehicle parallel to the curb on any of the streets whereon diagonal parking is required by § 72.01. 
(Ord. 12883, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.03. - Standing prohibited in specified places. 
    No person shall stand or park a trackless trolley or vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or with the provisions of this title, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or a traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(A)  On a paved or unpaved sidewalk of a curbed roadway except a bicycle or electric transportation device, unless otherwise permitted by either R.C. §§ 70.09 or 70.11; 
(B)  In front of a public or private driveway or alley. In front shall include the area within five feet of the driveway or alley width projected to the curb line or roadway edge, or the point along the curb or roadway edge where the driveway or alleymouth intersects whichever is greater; 
(C)  Within an intersection; 
(D)  Between the curb and street right-of-way line on a curbed street unless a temporary use permit has been issued by the city; 
(E)  Within ten feet of a fire hydrant; 
(F)  On a roadway or shoulder if on or within twenty feet of a crosswalk; 
(G)  On a roadway or shoulder if within thirty feet on the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic-control signal; 
(H)  Within fifty feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(I)  Within twenty feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five feet of the entrance when properly sign-posted; 
(J)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(K)  On a roadway or shoulder if alongside any vehicle stopped or parked parallel to the curb or to the rear of vehicles parked diagonally to the curb; 
(L)  At any place opposite or alongside a curb or roadway edge where signs have been erected prohibiting delivery, standing, or stopping; 
(M)  On a roadway or shoulder if within one foot of another standing vehicle; and/or, 
(N)  On any bridge or elevated structure on a highway. 
(Ord. 17246, passed 10-31-51; Am. Ord. 17675, passed 4-6-53; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 29330-97, passed 1-15-97; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.04. - Night parking and commercial vehicle parking restrictions. 
(A)  (1)  For the purpose of this section, "residential zone" shall mean those districts classified and regulated as R-1 through R-8 Residential Districts by §§ 150.100 through 150.149. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, "wrecker" or "tow truck" means every motor vehicle which is designed to tow or transport any other motor vehicle by means of pulling or dragging or carrying the other vehicle behind the wrecker or tow truck which is doing such pulling or dragging or carrying. Said towed vehicle can be self supporting, carried on a dolly type platform, or be supported on any other item necessary to facilitate such towing. 
(B)  No person shall park or permit any motor vehicle having motor power designed and used for carrying merchandise or freight to remain parked on any street in a residential zone in the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(C)  No person shall park or permit any motor vehicle having motor power and used as a commercial tractor to be parked at any time on any street in a residential zone in the city. 
(D)  No person shall park or permit to remain parked, a trailer, semi-trailer, travel trailer, house trailer, recreational vehicle, camper, truck camper, boat, boat trailer, or mobile home on any street in a residential zone in the city except when continuously and actively engaged in loading or unloading goods from such equipment or vehicle, but in no event longer than permitted by any regulation in force at the site. 
(E)  No person shall park or permit to remain parked, a wrecker or tow truck on any street in a residential zone in the city except when continuously and actively engaged in loading or unloading another vehicle or performing emergency vehicle repair service, but in no event longer than permitted by any regulation in force at the site. 
(Ord. 12883, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 24608, passed 11-21-73; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 27118, passed 11-21-84; Am. Ord. 27148, passed 2-13-85; Am. Ord. 29114-95, passed 11-15-95) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.05. - Vehicle entering traffic from parking position. 
    Any vehicle attempting to reenter traffic while halted parallel or diagonal with the curb shall yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic in the street approaching from the rear. The parked vehicle shall proceed into the line of traffic only after the driver has given the appropriate signal which indicates his intention of turning from the curb and into the line of traffic. The vehicle shall in no event enter the line of traffic until the driver has ascertained that no hazard exists. 
(Ord. 12883, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 14557, passed 7-29-31; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.06. - Parking in alleys prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall be parked in any alley within the city. 
(Ord. 12883, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 14066, passed 8-28-29; Am. Ord. 14066, passed 8-28-29; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.07. - Parking in same square prohibited. 
    If a vehicle has been parked on one of the streets or parts of streets named in the schedule of parking regulations provided for by § 70.11 for a longer period of time than is provided for in the schedule, no person shall move the vehicle from such place of parking directly to and there to park such vehicle in another parking space on either side of the street in the same square thereof. For the purpose of this section "square" shall mean all that part of any street lying wholly between two intersecting or cross streets. 
(Ord. 12882, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 14843, passed 12-26-34) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.08. - Parking unused motor vehicle. 
(A)  No person shall store, maintain, or park any motor or other vehicle upon the streets, alleys, or public places in the city when such vehicle is either in such mechanical condition that it cannot be operated by the power regularly intended for that purpose or is separated therefrom, or is so placed for the purpose of advertising the same for sale or disposal, or not being in use is so placed as a matter of convenience to the person so doing. 
(B)  Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the parking of a vehicle, which is in use, upon the streets, alleys, or public places of the city according to the ordinances thereof, in such cases made and provided, during such time as the user thereof may be temporarily absent therefrom, and nothing in this section shall be construed as a limitation upon the provisions of § 95.10. 
(Ord. 11011, passed 12-3-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.09. - Parking motor vehicle for sale. 
    No person shall park or leave standing on the streets, alleys, or public places of the city any motor or other vehicle for the purpose of offering the same for sale. 
(Ord. 11011, passed 12-3-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.10. - Belmont off-street parking lot. 
    In order to facilitate the movement of traffic on the streets, lots numbered 57775, 57776, and 57777 are established as a place for the off-street parking of motor vehicles to be controlled or regulated in accord with the provisions of the schedule of traffic regulations. 
(Ord. 20870, passed 8-7-63; Am. Ord. 21481, passed 12-30-64; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.11. - Parking for handicapped persons. 
(A)  Special parking meters, locations and privileges for persons with disabilities that limit or impair their ability to walk, also known as handicapped parking spaces or disability parking spaces, shall be provided as required by Section 4511.69 of the Ohio Revised Code. Handicapped parking spaces or disability parking spaces shall be designated by at least one of the following: the posting of an elevated sign, or the posting of an emblem affixed to the meter, or a meter painted a specific color of blue, or a meter imprinted with the international symbol of handicap access, whether permanently affixed or movable. No person shall stop, stand or park any motor vehicle at handicapped parking spaces or disability parking spaces, unless one of the following applies: 
(1)  The motor vehicle is being operated by or for the transport of a person with a disability that limits or impairs their ability to walk and is displaying a valid removable windshield placard or special license plates; or 
(2)  The motor vehicle is being operated by or for the transport of a handicapped person and is displaying a parking card or special handicapped license plates. 
(B)  Any motor vehicle that is parked at a special marked parking meter or location and is in violation of § 72.11(A) may be towed or otherwise removed from the parking meter or location by the city. A motor vehicle that is so towed or removed shall not be released to its owner until the owner presents proof of ownership of the motor vehicle, proof of insurance and pays all towing and storage fees normally imposed by the city for towing and storing motor vehicles. If the motor vehicle is a leased vehicle, it shall not be released to the lessee until the lessee presents proof that person is the lessee of the motor vehicle, presents proof of insurance and pays all towing and storage fees normally imposed by the city for towing and storing motor vehicles. 
(C)  If a person is charged with a violation of § 72.11(A), it is an affirmative defense to the charge that the person suffered an injury not more than 72 hours prior to the time the person was issued the ticket or citation and that, because of the injury, the person meets at least one of the criteria contained in Section 4503.44(A)(1) of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(D)  No owner of an office, facility, or parking garage where special parking locations are required to be designated shall fail to properly mark the special parking locations in accordance with § 72.11(A) or fail to maintain the markings of the special locations, including the erection and maintenance of the fixed or movable signs. 
(Ord. 30150-02, passed 9-25-02) 
Sec. 72.12. - Citation of standing violation. 
(A)  The Director of Police is authorized and directed to provide police officers and traffic enforcement aides with tags which shall be used for the purpose of giving due notice to owners, chauffeurs, and drivers of automobiles and vehicles, of violations of this chapter; and any such owner, chauffeur, or driver, when a tag, as herein provided, is attached to the vehicle which he has left parked on the streets of the city contrary to the provisions of this chapter, shall appear at the place or places designated on the tag and according to the directions thereon shall comply with the instructions and directions appearing on the tag, and no person shall fail or refuse so to do. The tag citation, when attached to a vehicle in a conspicuous place, shall be legal and sufficient summons and legal and sufficient service thereof upon the owner, chauffeur, or driver of the vehicle to appear at the designated place, date, and time and for purposes as specified thereon. However, this section shall not abridge the power of the police officers to arrest for crimes and misdemeanors. 
(B)  Attaching a citation tag to a vehicle pursuant to this section shall not be construed as a bar to impounding the vehicle pursuant to the provision of this title. 
(Ord. 12882, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 25504, passed 4-19-78; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Sec. 72.13. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. 
    In any hearing in the municipal court, testimony that a vehicle bearing a certain license tag was found unlawfully parked as prohibited by this chapter, and further testimony that the records of the Registrar or Deputy Registrar of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles of the state show that the license tag was issued to the defendant, shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle which was unlawfully parked was so parked by the defendant. A certified copy showing such fact from the registrar or deputy registrar shall be proof of such ownership. 
(Ord. 15362, passed 2-21-40) 
Sec. 72.14. - Parking restrictions inapplicable under certain cases. 
    The parking restrictions provided in §§ 72.01 through 72.13 shall not apply in the following cases: 
(A)  Cases in which the owner or user of a vehicle is compelled to park the same on the street during the period when any improvement or repair work in a street, alley, or other public way makes it impossible to place such vehicle in the garage or other place where the same is regularly kept when not in use, nor prevent the allowance of a reasonable period of time to remove a vehicle from the streets, alleys, or other public ways in case the same has become disabled while in use thereon. 
(B)  Cases in which vehicles of public utility companies are being used in conjunction with the installation, maintenance, repair, or replacement of public utility facilities when it is not feasible to park at any other place because of the type of work that is being done, or in the case of an emergency involving the public utility facilities, and provided a flagman is on duty or warning signs or lights are displayed as may be prescribed by the Director of the Ohio Department of Transportation. 
(Ord. 11011, passed 12-3-19; Am. Ord. 27517, passed 2-25-87) 
Sec. 72.15. - Standing prohibited on snow plow routes. 
(A)  Whenever requested by the Director of Public Works, the Director of Police shall act under the authority of § 70.04 to proclaim and announce snow emergency traffic-control regulations and the effective time thereof. On and after the snow emergency regulation effective time no vehicle shall stand or be left standing on any street or portion thereof where snow emergency regulation signs are posted until after the announced end of the emergency, less stringent traffic-control regulations notwithstanding. If a snow emergency regulation is announced between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. it shall not become effective less than one hour after announcement. If an announcement is made after 11:00 p.m. and before 6:00 a.m. the regulation shall not become effective before 6:00 a.m. 
(B)  Whenever the Director of Public Works finds that conditions giving rise to the snow emergency regulation no longer exist, he shall act to withdraw the regulation. Whenever requested by the Director of Public Works, the Director of Police shall act under the authority of § 70.04 to terminate snow emergency regulation. 
(C)  Maximum feasible use shall be made of news media to announce the start or end of snow emergency regulations. 
(Ord. 17241, passed 10-31-51; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.16. - Delivery of goods or merchandise. 
(A)  No vehicle shall stand on any highway except an alley for the purpose of receiving or discharging merchandise, materials, or goods at a commercial establishment unless the vehicle is in a designated delivery zone and is a commercially licensed vehicle, or there is placed in the windshield of the driver's side of the vehicle, a commercially printed sign that is not less than 12 inches by 12 inches in size, identifying it as a commercial vehicle engaged in delivery, and the driver is actively engaged in loading or unloading the vehicle. 
(B)  No vehicle making a delivery shall stop in an alley in such a manner to halt the flow of traffic in the alley. 
(Ord. 12883, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 16524, passed 9-22-48; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 27517, passed 2-25-87) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 72.17. - Legal parking in metered parking space. 
(A)  When any vehicle is parked on a street, during the hours of the day when limited-time parking is in effect on the street, in any space alongside of or next to which there is located under this provision a parking meter, the owner, operator, manager, or driver of the vehicle shall, on entering the parking space for the purpose of parking, immediately deposit in the meter such proper coin of the United States as is required for the parking meter and as is designated by proper directions on the meter alongside of or next to the parking space. The parking space may then be used by the vehicle during the period of time which the coin or coins deposited will so entitle its use. The deposit of the coin or coins as designated by the directions on the meter will entitle the person to use or occupy the adjacent parking space for such a period of time only as will conform to the parking limit now or hereafter provided by law for the part of the street on which the meter is located. In no event will the deposit of any coin or coins permit a person to park for a period of time in excess of that permitted by law for that part of the street on which the parking space is located. However, nothing contained in this provision shall prohibit the temporary use of any street for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading or in receiving or discharging passengers. If the vehicle shall remain parked in any parking space beyond the period of time during which the coin or coins deposited entitles the person to occupy the parking space, or if the vehicle shall remain parked in the parking space beyond the parking limit fixed by law for that portion of the street, then the vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the time fixed by law. The parking of a vehicle overtime, or otherwise contrary hereto, on any street or part thereof where any meter is located shall be a violation of this provision and punishable as hereinafter set out. 
(B)  The front bumper of any vehicle which is parked at a meter parallel to a street shall not extend beyond the location of the meter closest to the front quarter panel of the vehicle. This meter shall control the use of the parking space adjacent to and directly behind it up to the next meter or any terminus of permitted parking. Where a vehicle is parked in such a manner and the length of the vehicle exceeds the allotted distance within a single parking space, the owner, operator, manager, or driver of the vehicle shall, upon entering the parking space for the purpose of parking, immediately deposit in the meters governing all spaces or portions of spaces used such proper coin of the United States as is required for the parking meters and as is designated by proper directions on the meters adjacent to and directly behind the parking spaces or portions of spaces used. 
(C)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit, or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to be parked overtime or beyond the lawful period of time as above described. 
(Ord. 25504, passed 4-19-78; Am. Ord. 26999, passed 5-23-84) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 72.99. 
Sec. 72.18. - Permit parking; special regulations. 
(A)  Exemption from downtown transportation plan and bus stop parking meter location plan. Cooper Place East, Cooper Place West, and Cooper Place South are hereby exempted from the provisions of the Downtown Transportation Plan and Bus Stop and Parking Meter Location Plan. 
(B)  Geographical boundaries. Vehicular parking on the following residential streets will require a parking permit: 
(1)  Cooper Place East; 
(2)  Cooper Place West; and 
(3)  Cooper Place South. 
(C)  Application standards. To insure equitable application of this section to all parties, the following standards will be applied in all cases: 
(1)  Permit parking. On the affected streets parking shall be by permit only at all times. 
(2)  Existing parking regulations. All existing traffic and parking controls will remain valid. This section is intended to be an additional regulation and does not substitute or replace existing legislation. 
(D)  Signs. The Division of Traffic Engineering shall cause official parking restriction signs to be erected indicating the following: 
PERMIT 
PARKING 
ONLY VIOLATORS 
WILL BE TICKETED 
AND/OR TOWED  
(E)  Permit distribution. 
(1)  The assignment proceeding and issuance of permits will be administered and issued by the Cooper Place Owners' Association, under guidelines developed and approved by the city Department of Community Development. Any denial of a permit or any problems resulting from the issuance or nonissuance shall be resolved by the Director of Community Development or his/her designee. No fees shall be charged for the issuance of permits. Furthermore, permits will be renewed annually during the month of January. 
(2)  Persons eligible to acquire permits shall be actual residents of the Cooper Place area at the time of acquiring the permit and shall maintain such residency in order to continue to possess such permits. 
(3)  Each household shall be eligible for two parking permits; however, due to space limitations, issuance shall not guarantee a parking space for the household's occupants. 
(4)  Proof of residency in the Cooper Place area, such as motor vehicle registration, operator's license, rent receipt, or other documents shall be provided by the applicant for the permit. 
(5)  Each permit issued will be identical in design for ease of enforcement. Each permit will be valid only in that designated area. The permit shall be five inches by seven inches in size and placed in the lower left corner of the front windshield, unobstructed from view. 
(6)  When a person ceases to reside in the Cooper Place area, all permits issued to that person shall become null and void and shall be collected by the issuing authority. 
(F)  Cancellation. In the event that the association or organization responsible for self-administering the permit parking disbands, this section and all agreements contained herein shall become null and void. All residents of Cooper Place shall receive written notice 60 days prior to such cancellation. 
(Ord. 29382, passed 5-7-97) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 72.99. 
Sec. 72.19. - Valet parking zones. 
(A)  For the purposes of this section only, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Attendant means a person who drives a patron's motor vehicle while providing valet parking services. 
    Motor vehicle means any vehicle as defined in R.C. § 4511.01. 
    Valet parking operator means a business that employs one or more attendants for the purpose of providing valet parking services to the patrons of a business. 
    Valet parking zone means any area designated by the Bureau of Traffic Engineering for the purpose of providing valet parking services. 
(B)  No attendant or valet parking operator shall provide valet parking services without obtaining a required permit. 
(C)  A property owner, or lessee with the written permission of the property owner, may apply for a valet parking permit by filing a completed application on a form provided by the Bureau of Traffic Engineering with Department of Public Works. The permit application shall clearly identify the days of the week and the times during the day when the designated area will be used as a valet parking zone and the location and size of the valet parking zone. 
(D)  On receipt of an application for a valet parking permit, the Director of Public Works, upon review of the study and report of the Bureau of Traffic Engineering, shall determine whether the proposed location complies with this section. Within 14 days of receipt of the application, the Director of Public Works shall notify the applicant whether the proposed location complies with this section. 
(1)  The study of the Bureau of Traffic Engineering shall consider all relevant traffic engineering issues. Following the review of the study and report of the Bureau of Traffic Engineering, the valet parking zone shall not be established if the Director of Public Works determines that any of the following are true: 
(a)  Establishing the proposed valet parking zone would create a traffic flow or traffic congestion problem. 
(b)  The proposed valet parking zone is in an area already experiencing traffic congestion, adequate off-street areas for standing or parking vehicles exist, and the proposed valet parking zone cannot be implemented by resolving, accommodating, or decreasing the traffic congestion problem. 
(c)  The proposed valet parking zone is presently a restricted parking area and the investigation of the Bureau of Traffic Engineering does not reveal that it is desirable to remove or change the restriction(s). 
(E)  To obtain a permit for operation of an approved valet parking zone, the valet parking operator shall pay the Department of Public Works a fee in the amount of $300.00 if the valet parking zone does not include any on-street metered parking space. If a valet parking zone includes any existing on-street metered parking space, the valet parking operator shall pay an additional fee in the amount of $480.00 for each existing on-street metered parking space included in the valet parking zone. 
(F)  Upon notification by the Director of Public Works of compliance of the application with this section, the Bureau of Traffic Engineering shall issue a permit to operate a valet parking zone. The permit shall state the following: 
(1)  Length and width of the valet parking zone. 
(2)  Precise location of the valet parking zone by reference to landmarks, distance from intersections or other reasonable method. 
(3)  Days and times of operation. 
(4)  That the permit is valid for one year from the date of issuance unless revoked sooner for violation of the terms of the permit or this section. 
(5)  That the permit may be suspended due to construction or street closure as authorized by the Director of Public Works. 
(G)  Operation of valet parking zone. 
(1)  Valet parking operator shall at all times: 
(a)  Staff, at its own expense, any valet services offered. 
(b)  Park all vehicles in a legal off-street parking lot or garage. 
(c)  Pay any costs related to parking in a public or private lot or garage. 
(d)  Pay for any damages or fines related to a motor vehicle within its control. 
(e)  Display a permanent valet parking sign posted by the city. 
(f)  Provide a portable structure to demarcate valet parking zone (e.g. street pylons or posts and roping). 
(g)  Maintain insurance coverage as follows: 
i.  Comprehensive general liability insurance with a minimum of $2,000,000.00 for each occurrence combined single limit bodily injury and property damage, including contractual liability and personal injury and naming the city as an additional insured. 
ii.  Comprehensive automobile liability insurance with a minimum of $2,000,000.00 each occurrence combined single limit bodily injury and property damage, including owned, non-owned, and hired auto coverage and naming the city as an additional insured. 
iii.  Garage keeper's legal liability insurance with a minimum of $1,000,000.00 including coverage for fire and explosion, theft of entire motor vehicle, riot, civil commotion, collision, malicious mischief and vandalism and naming the city as an additional insured. 
iv.  Workers' compensation coverage in accordance with the Revised Code. 
(h)  Employ as an attendant only such person as: 
i.  Has a current driver's license, 
ii.  Is over 18 years of age, 
iii.  Does not have a conviction in the previous five years for any of the following offenses: burglary, robbery, theft, receiving stolen property, vandalism, criminal damaging, driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs (DUI), or driving with a prohibited concentration of alcohol in bodily substances (BAC). 
iv.  Does not have more than six points or more on his or her operator's license. 
(2)  Attendants shall at all times: 
(a)  Wear visible identification tags with name, employee number and business name. 
(b)  Present every patron who leaves a motor vehicle in attendant's control a numbered receipt specifying: 
i.  Name of the business, 
ii.  Address of the business, 
iii.  Telephone number of the business, 
iv.  License plate number of the motor vehicle, 
v.  Hours of operation of the business, 
vi.  Lot where the motor vehicle will be parked, 
vii.  Date and time when the motor vehicle was taken into control, and 
viii.  Upon return of motor vehicle to patron, time of said return. 
(c)  Move all motor vehicles from the approved valet parking zone to a permanent parking location from which motor vehicle can be returned within ten minutes. 
(d)  Park all motor vehicles from a valet parking zone in a legal off-street parking lot or garage that is approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(3)  Attendants shall not park any motor vehicle from a valet parking zone in an existing on-street parking space or area. 
(4)  No motor vehicle shall occupy a valet parking zone for more than 20 minutes in an eight-hour period. 
(5)  The Director of Public Works may, if necessary to avoid traffic congestion or risk to the public, suspend the valet parking zone permit due to construction or street closure. 
(6)  Within 30 days of the issuance of permit to operate a valet parking zone, the Bureau of Traffic Engineering shall post signs which mark the area of the valet parking zone, the days of the week and the hours of the days of operation of the valet parking zone. Such signs shall be of sufficient size, and number, and shall be situated in such location, as to apprise the ordinarily observant person of the existence of the valet parking zone. Any such signs shall have the force and effect of law until the corresponding permit is suspended or revoked by the Director of Public Works. 
(Ord. 31157-12, passed 3-21-12) 
Sec. 72.20. - Downtown business delivery parking permit. 
(A)  Any person lawfully using real property in the Central Business District ("CBD") or the Urban Business District ("UBD") for office, service, entertainment or retail purposes is eligible to apply for a downtown business delivery parking permit. 
(B)  The operator of any vehicle displaying a downtown business delivery parking permit may park the vehicle in a designated delivery zone or in a metered on-street parking space in the CBD or the UBD without charge for a period not to exceed 30 minutes. Any vehicle displaying a downtown business delivery parking permit and parked anywhere except a designated delivery zone or a metered on-street parking space in the CBD or the UBD, or for a period exceeding 30 minutes, shall be subject to all applicable parking regulations and penalties for violation thereof. 
(C)  A person eligible to apply for a downtown business delivery parking permit pursuant to subsection (A) above may submit an application to the Director of the Department of Public Works on a form provided by the Director. The application shall describe the use of the real property and state the reason or necessity for the permit. The Director shall issue a permit upon (1) verification of the applicant's eligibility and (2) determination that a permit is necessary. A permit issued in accordance with this section shall be valid until January 1 of the following year and may be renewed, but a permit is not transferable and may be revoked if the holder at any time becomes ineligible. 
(Ord. 31486-16, passed 4-27-16) 
Secs. 72.21-72.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 72.99 - General penalty for chapter 72. 
    Whoever violates any provision of section 72.01(B), (C) or (D), 72.11(A) or (D), 72.17, 72.18, or 72.19 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 29382, passed 5-7-97; Am. Ord. 30150-02, passed 9-25-02; Am. Ord. 31157-12, passed 3-21-12) 
CHAPTER 73. - ACCIDENTS 

Sec. 73.01. - Stopping after accident; exchange of identity and vehicle registration. 
(A)  In case of accident to or collision with persons or property on any of the highways, park roads, airport roads, or bikeways of the city, due to the driving or operation thereon of such vehicle or trackless trolley, the person so driving or operating such vehicle or trackless trolley, having knowledge of such accident or collision, shall immediately stop his vehicle or trackless trolley at the scene of the accident or collision and shall remain at the scene of the accident or collision until he has given his name and address, and, if he is not the owner, the name and address of the owner of such vehicle or trackless trolley, together with the registered number of such vehicle or trackless trolley, to any person injured in such accident or collision or to the operator, occupant, owner, or attendant of any vehicle or trackless trolley damaged in such accident or collision, or to any police officer or a special policeman, at the scene of such accident or collision. 
(B)  In the event the injured person is unable to comprehend and record the information required to be given by this section, the other driver involved in such accident or collision shall forthwith notify the Police Department concerning the location of the accident or collision and his name, address, and the registered number of the vehicle or trackless trolley he was operating, and then remain at the scene of the accident or collision until a police officer or special policeman arrives, unless removed from the scene by an ambulance or other emergency vehicle. 
(C)  If such accident or collision is with an unoccupied or unattended vehicle or trackless trolley, the operator so colliding with such vehicle or trackless trolley shall securely attach the information to be required to be given in this section, in writing, to a conspicuous place in the unoccupied or unattended vehicle or trackless trolley. (R.C. § 4549.02) 
(Ord. 15657, passed 4-1-42; Am. Ord. 20954, passed 10-30-63; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 73.99. 
Sec. 73.01.1. - Stopping after accident involving injury to persons or property on private property and certain public property. 
(A)  In case of accident or collision resulting in injury or damage to persons or property on any public or private property other than enumerated in §§ 73.01 or 73.03, due to the driving or operation thereon of any vehicle or trackless trolley, the person so driving or operating such vehicle or trackless trolley, having knowledge of such accident or collision, shall stop, and on request of the person injured or damaged, or any other person, shall give such person his name and address, and, if he is not the owner, the name and address, of the owner of such vehicle or trackless trolley, together with the registered number of such vehicle or trackless trolley, and if unavailable, exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(B)  If the owner or person in charge of such damaged property is not furnished such information, the driver of the vehicle or trackless trolley involved in the accident or collision shall within 24 hours after such accident or collision, forward to the Police Department the same information required to be given to the owner or person in control of such damaged property and give the date, time, and location of the accident or collision. 
(C)  If such accident or collision is with an unoccupied or unattended vehicle or trackless trolley, the operator so colliding with such vehicle or trackless trolley, shall securely attach the information required to be given in this section, in writing, to a conspicuous place in or on the unoccupied or unattended vehicle or trackless trolley. (R.C. § 4549.021) 
(Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 73.99. 
Sec. 73.02. - Duty to report striking safety or traffic-control devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle or the operator of any trackless trolley involved in an accident resulting in damages, however slight they may appear, to any fire hydrant, or traffic signal light and its controlling mechanism, or to the fixture or pole on which any of these devices are mounted, or any other traffic-control device, shall, in addition to complying with the provisions of § 73.01 as soon as possible, and in no event later than 24 hours after such accident, make or cause to be made a report of the accident to the office of the Fire Chief or Chief of Police or at one of the fire houses, together with his name, address, and the registration number of the vehicle or the number of the trackless trolley he was operating. 
(Ord. 14843, passed 12-26-34; Am. Ord. 20597, passed 12-19-62; Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 73.99. 
Sec. 73.03. - Duty of driver in accident involving property damage. 
(A)  The driver of any vehicle or trackless trolley involved in an accident resulting in damage to real property, or personal property attached to such real property, legally upon or adjacent to a street or alley of the city shall immediately stop and take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner or person in charge of such property of such fact, of his name and address, and of the registration number of the vehicle he is driving, or the number of the trackless trolley, and shall, upon request and if available, exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(B)  If the owner or person in charge of such property cannot be located after reasonable search, the driver of the vehicle or operator of the trackless trolley involved in the accident resulting in damage to such property shall, within 24 hours after such accident, make or cause to be made a written report of the accident to the Chief of Police which report shall contain the same information required to be given to the owner or person in control of such property and give the location of the accident and a description of the damage insofar as is known. (R.C. § 4549.03) 
(Ord. 20597, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 73.99. 
Sec. 73.04. - Accident reports to be kept confidential; exceptions. 
(A)  All written accident reports made by drivers, owners or occupants of vehicles involved in accidents shall be without prejudice to the individual so reporting and shall be for the confidential use of the Police Department or other governmental agencies having use for the records for accident prevention purposes. 
(B)  The Police Department may disclose the identity of person involved in an accident when the identity is not otherwise known or when a person denies his presence at the accident. 
(C)  No report shall be used as evidence in any trial, civil or criminal, arising out of an accident except that the department shall furnish upon demand of any person who has, or claims to have, made a report or upon demand of any court, a certificate showing that a specified accident report has or has not been made to the Police Department solely to prove a compliance or a failure to comply with the requirements that such a report be made to the department. 
Secs. 73.05-73.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 73.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Whoever violates any provision of §§ 73.01, 73.011, or 73.03 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(B)  Whoever violates any provision of § 73.02 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(Am. Ord. 26392, passed 12-9-81) 
CHAPTER 74. - BICYCLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles and motorcycles, see R.C. §§ 4511.52-4511.56. 

Sec. 74.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Bicycle. Includes motorized bicycle and electric bicycle except where specifically excluded. 
    Bike lane. A portion of a roadway set aside for bicycle and electric transportation device travel and designated visually by signs or roadway marking. 
    Bike route. A roadway or system of roadways with signs denoting them as a "bike route." "Bike routes" imply roadways in mixed vehicular usage. 
    Bike trail. A bikeway or portion thereof specifically designated for bicycles and electric transportation devices but where pedestrians are permitted, unless specifically excluded. A bike trail may be a specifically designated portion of a sidewalk or sidewalk area of a highway or a separate facility. 
    Bikeway. A generic term encompassing all facilities or types of traffic operation treatment provided specifically for bicycle and electric transportation device travel. A bikeway includes a bike route, bike lane, sidewalk bike path, and a bike trail. 
    Electric transportation device. Excludes electric bicycle. 
    Sidewalk bike path. A bikeway or portion thereof specifically designated and located on a sidewalk or sidewalk area, of a highway, where mixed use with pedestrians having the right-of-way is expected. 
(Ord. 4562, passed 6-5-1896; Am. Ord. 21373, passed 9-16-64; Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 74.02. - Bicyclist's and electric transportation device operator's rights and duties. 
    Every person operating a bicycle or electric transportation device on the highways, bikeways, park roads, or other public property within the city where bicycles or electric transportation devices are permitted, shall be subject to the provisions of all portions of this title, applicable to the operation of vehicles, except those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 74.03. - Lights while operating bicycle or electric transportation device required. 
    No person shall operate any bicycle or electric transportation device on the streets or public highways of the city during any of the time between one hour after sunset until one hour before sunrise unless such bicycle or electric transportation device or its operator is equipped with or wearing all of the following: 
(A)  A lamp pointing to the front that emits a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet to the front; 
(B)  A red reflector facing the rear that is visible from all distances from one hundred feet to six hundred feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle; and, 
(C)  A lamp emitting either flashing or steady red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the rear. If the red lamp performs as a reflector in that it is visible as specified in division (B) of this section, the red lamp may serve as the reflector required by division (B) of this section and a separate reflector is not required. 
(Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.04. - Bicycle and electric transportation device brake system required. 
    No person shall operate any bicycle or electric transportation device on the highways, bikeways, or other public property within the city unless such bicycle or electric transportation device is equipped with a brake system adequate to stop the bicycle or electric transportation device within 25 feet from a speed of ten miles per hour on a clear, dry, and level pavement. Such brake system shall be maintained in good working order at all times. 
(Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.05. - Bicycle bell required; siren or whistle prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least 100 feet. 
(B)  A bicycle or electric transportation device shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use on a bicycle or electric transportation device any siren or whistle. 
(Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.06. - Bicycle and electric transportation device regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle or electric transportation device on highways, bikeways, or other public property within the city to: 
(A)  Fail to ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, except where compliance with vehicular law requires another position and except where reasonably necessary to avoid conditions including but not limited to fixed or moving objects, parked or moving vehicles, pedestrians, animals, or surface hazards. 
(B)  Ride on a roadway more than two abreast in a single lane except on bikeways or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles and electric transportation devices. 
(C)  Cling or attach one's self, bicycle, or electric transportation device to any other vehicle. 
(D)  Ride on a bicycle while not sitting astride the seat, facing forward with one leg on each side of the bicycle. 
(E)  Tow or draw any coaster, sled, person on roller skates or a skateboard, toy vehicle, electric transportation device, or similar device or objects. This division shall not prohibit attaching a bicycle trailer or bicycle semi-trailer to a bicycle if that trailer or semi-trailer has been designed for such attachment. 
(F)  If the vehicle is equipped with handlebars, carry any package, bundle, or article that prevents the operator from keeping at least one hand on the handlebars. 
(G)  If the vehicle is equipped with an attached permanent and regular seat, fail to ride on such attached seat or carry any other person other than on a firmly attached and regular seat. 
(H)  Ride to the left of center on a two-way sidewalk bike path, bike trail, or bike lane when bicycle, electric transportation device, or pedestrian traffic is approaching closely from the opposite direction. 
(Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.07. - Bicycle and electric transportation device operation location limited. 
(A)  Bicycles and electric transportation devices shall not be operated: 
(1)  On sidewalks and sidewalk areas of highways of the city except when immediately leaving or accessing a parking location, unless established by the traffic engineer as a sidewalk bike path in accord with § 70.11, provided the bikeway is properly signed; 
(2)  On publicly held or owned lands not open as streets or highways unless established as a bike trail by the traffic engineer in accord with the provisions of § 70.11; 
(3)  On publicly held or owned lands not open as streets or highways or as vehicle parking areas unless permitted by the Director of the department in charge of such lands and then only on that part designated for general vehicle or specifically for bicycle or electric transportation device use; and/or, 
(4)  On closed streets and highways. 
(B)  The provisions of divisions (A)(1), (A)(2), and (A)(3) of this section shall not apply to children under the age of fourteen years when operating a bicycle or an electric transportation device on a sidewalk. This exclusion does not extend to motorized bicycles or class 3 electric bicycles. 
(C)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to Police Department personnel in the performance of their duties, and other persons trained by the City Police Department and authorized by the Chief of Police to operate a non-motorized bicycle or an electric transportation device on city sidewalks or other publicly-owned property. 
(Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 28674-93, passed 4-28-93; Am. Ord. 30650-07, passed 5-16-07; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 74.99. 
Sec. 74.08. - Bicycle and electric transportation device operation special conditions. 
    The operator of a bicycle or electric transportation device on a sidewalk bike path, on a bike trail, or on a sidewalk for the limited purpose of immediately leaving or accessing a parking location shall observe the following additional vehicle rules: 
(A)  At or when approaching a street or highway intersection the operator shall cross the street or highway at the intersection observing rules applying to pedestrians, however, the operator need not dismount; 
(B)  If closer than ten feet from the curb line or roadway edge at a signalized intersection at the time pedestrian movement is first permitted in the direction of travel the bicycle or electric transportation device operator shall not enter the intersection from the curb so as to cause a hazardous approach to or collision with any other vehicle on the roadway legally utilizing the intersection; 
(C)  Before overtaking and passing a pedestrian, the operator of a bicycle or electric transportation device shall give an audible signal; and, 
(D)  The operator of a bicycle or electric transportation device shall yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians. 
(Ord. 15167, passed 12-7-38; Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.09. - Bicycle and electric transportation device rental agency to comply with all regulations. 
    No rental agency shall rent or offer any bicycle or electric transportation device for rent unless the bicycle, electric transportation device, or operator is equipped as required by §§ 74.03, 74.04, and 74.05. 
(Ord. 4562, passed 6-5-1896; Am. Ord. 17303, passed 1-23-52; Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 74.99. 
Sec. 74.10. - Unlawful to mutilate frame, device, or serial number. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate, or alter the number of any bicycle frame or the device or serial number on any electric transportation device. However, this section shall not prohibit anyone designated by the Director of the Department of Police from stamping numbers on frames of bicycles or otherwise labeling electric transportation devices on which no serial number can be found or on which the number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes, nor shall this section prohibit the owner of a bicycle or electric transportation device from stamping or otherwise affixing an identification number, name, or symbol thereon. 
(Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.11. - Bicycle parking. 
(A)  No person shall park a bicycle on a sidewalk so as to impede the normal and reasonable movement of pedestrians or other traffic. 
(B)  A bicycle may be parked on the roadway at any angle to the curb or edge of the roadway at any location where parking is allowed. 
(C)  A bicycle may be parked on a roadway abreast of another bicycle near the side of a roadway where parking is allowed except in any metered parking zone. 
(D)  A person shall not park a bicycle on a roadway in such a manner as to obstruct the movement of a legally parked motor vehicle. 
(E)  In all other respects bicycles parked anywhere on a highway shall conform to the provisions of this title regulating parking of vehicles. 
(Ord. 4562, passed 6-5-1896; Am. Ord. 15167, passed 12-7-38; Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.11.1. - Electric transportation device parking. 
(A)  When upon public property or private property open to the public, no person shall park an electric transportation device other than as follows: in an upright position; upon on a paved surface; and 
(1)  In the furniture zone of the sidewalk; 
(2)  Beside a bicycle rack; 
(3)  In an area specifically designated for bicycle or electric transportation device parking; or, 
(4)  Upon a roadway or shoulder when permitted under division (C) of this section and when in compliance with all other provisions of this title. 
(B)  No person shall park an electric transportation device in such a manner as to block the pedestrian clear zone area of the sidewalk to less than 48 inches or in any manner that would create any violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). 
(C)  No person shall park an electric transportation device upon a roadway or shoulder except in the following circumstances: 
(1)  When marked parking spaces are officially designated for such devices; 
(2)  Where the furniture zone is less than three feet wide; 
(3)  Where there is no furniture zone; 
(4)  In neighborhoods with inadequate sidewalk space; or, 
(5)  In marked parking spaces designed for motorcycles. 
(D)  No person shall park an electric transportation device in such a manner that would impede vehicular traffic on a street, highway, alley, or driveway. 
(E)  No person shall park and leave unattended an electric transportation device on a floodway or levee. 
(F)  No person shall park an electric transportation device directly adjacent to or within the following areas, such that access or use is impeded: 
(1)  Any fire hydrant, call box, or other emergency facility; 
(2)  Access to or from any building; 
(3)  Transit zones including, but not limited to, bus stops, shelters, passenger waiting areas and bus layover and staging zones, except at existing bicycle racks; 
(4)  Commercial or passenger loading zones; 
(5)  Valet parking service areas; 
(6)  Railroad tracks or crossings; 
(7)  Disabled parking zones; 
(8)  Street furniture that requires pedestrian access including, but not limited to, benches, parking pay stations, parking meters, bus shelters, and transit information signs; 
(9)  Curb ramps; 
(10)  Utility access points including, but not limited to, utility poles, utility boxes, manholes or other doors or hatches on the ground; 
(11)  The reasonable use of any commercial window display; 
(12)  Bicycle racks; 
(13)  Bikeways; 
(14)  News racks; 
(15)  Building entryways; and, 
(16)  Driveways. 
(G)  In all other respects electric transportation devices parked anywhere on a highway shall conform to the provisions of this title regulating the parking of vehicles. 
(H)  All of the offenses established by this section are strict liability offenses. 
(I)  "Floodway" has the same definition as found in § 152.63 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances. 
(Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 74.12. - Speed restriction. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle or electric transportation device at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing but in no event at a speed in excess of that provided in § 71.50. 
(Ord. 15167, passed 12-7-38; Am. Ord. 26248, passed 7-1-81; Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 31713-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 74.13. - Bicycle helmet requirement. 
(A)  No person under the age of 13 shall operate a bicycle or ride as a passenger on a bicycle equipped with a passenger seat on bikeways, streets, highways or other public property, unless such person is wearing a protective bicycle helmet on his or her head, with the chin strap fastened under the chin. Such bicycle helmet shall be fitted to the size of the operator and shall meet or exceed the standards set by the American National Standards Institute or Snell Memorial Foundation for helmets manufactured prior to March, 1999, and shall meet or exceed the standards set by the Consumer Product Safety Institute after said date. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section shall be fined not more than $25.00; provided, however, that nothing herein prevents a police officer from only issuing a warning for a first offense. 
(C)  This § 74.13 shall remain in effect until May 31, 2009. 
(Ord. 30337-04, passed 3-24-04) 
Secs. 74.14-74.99. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 31713-19, §, 21, adopted April 10, 2019, repealed § 74.99, which pertained to penalty and derived from Am. Ord. 26248, passed 7-l-81; Am. Ord. 26393, passed 12-9-81. 
CHAPTER 75. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 75.01. - Pedestrians subject to traffic-control signals. 
    Whenever special pedestrian control signals exhibiting the words "walk" or "don't walk," or the symbol of a walking person or an upraised palm are in place, such signals shall indicate the following instructions: 
(A)  "Walk" or the symbol of a walking person: Pedestrians facing such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right of way by the operators of all vehicles, streetcars, and trackless trolleys. 
(B)  "Don't walk" or the symbol of an upraised palm: No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of the signal. 
(C)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to invalidate the continued use of pedestrian control signals utilizing the word "wait" if those signals were installed prior to the effective date of this act. 
(Ord. 15891, passed 2-28-45; Am. Ord. 20579, passed 11-28-62; Am. Ord. 26394, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 28041, passed 11-15-89) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.02. - Use of walks by pedestrians. 
(A)  Where usable walks or paths parallel a street or highway, pedestrians shall not travel in, along, or on the vehicular traveled portion of such street or highway, except to cross the roadway in the manner provided by law. 
(B)  Where sidewalks are not provided any pedestrian traveling along the highway shall travel only on the shoulder as far as practicable from the roadway edge. 
(C)  Where neither a sidewalk nor shoulder is available, any pedestrian traveling along or on a highway shall travel as near as practicable to the outside edge of the roadway and if on a two-way roadway only on the left facing traffic and shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles or trackless trolleys approaching on the roadway. 
(Ord. 15891, passed 2-28-45; Am. Ord. 20579, passed 11-28-62; Am. Ord. 26394, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.03. - Pedestrians to use right half of crosswalk. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. (R.C. § 4511.49) 
(Ord. 15891, passed 2-28-45) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.04. - Pedestrians' right-of-way at crosswalk. 
(A)  When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation the driver of a vehicle, trackless trolley, or streetcar shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. This subsection does not apply under the conditions stated in § 75.05 (B). 
(B)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle, trackless trolley, or streetcar which is so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(C)  Whenever any vehicle, trackless trolley, or streetcar is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle, trackless trolley, or streetcar approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass the stopped vehicle. (R.C. § 4511.46) 
(Ord. 20992, passed 12-4-63) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.05. - Right-of-way yielded by pedestrian. 
(A)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles, trackless trolleys, or streetcars upon the roadway. 
(B)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all traffic upon the roadway. 
(C)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(D)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally unless authorized by official traffic-control devices; and, when authorized to cross diagonally, pedestrians shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic-control devices pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(E)  This section does not relieve the operator of a vehicle or trackless trolley from exercising due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway. (R.C. § 4511.48) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.06. - Yield right-of-way to blind; prohibition against use of white or metallic cane by others. 
(A)  For the purpose of this section "blind person" or "blind pedestrian" shall mean a person having not more than 20/200 visual acuity in the better eye with correcting lenses or visual acuity greater than 20/200 but with a limitation in the fields of vision such that the widest diameter of the visual field subtends an angle no greater than 20 degrees. 
(B)  The driver of every vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to every blind pedestrian guided by a dog, or carrying a cane which is predominantly white or metallic in color with or without a red tip. 
(C)  No person, other than a blind person, while on any public highway, street, alley, or other public thoroughfare shall carry a white or metallic cane with or without a red tip. 
(Ord. 26394, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.07. - Intoxicated pedestrians on public highway. 
    A pedestrian who is under the influence of alcohol or any drug of abuse, or any combination thereof, to a degree which renders the pedestrian a hazard shall not walk or be on a highway. 
(Ord. 26394, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.08. - Use of highway for soliciting; riding on outside of vehicle. 
(A)  No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting rides, employment, business, or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle. No person shall hang onto, or ride on the outside of any motor vehicle, streetcar, or trackless trolley while it is moving on a roadway, except mechanics or test engineers making repairs or adjustments. 
(B)  No operator shall knowingly permit any person to hang onto, or ride on the outside of, any motor vehicle, streetcar, or trackless trolley while it is moving on a roadway, except mechanics or test engineers making repairs or adjustments. 
(Ord. 26394, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.09. - Pedestrians on railroad crossings. 
    No pedestrian shall pass through, around, over, or under any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing while the gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(Ord. 26394, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 70.99. 
Sec. 75.10. - Entering or staying upon specified highways restricted. 
(A)  No pedestrian shall approach within three feet of any vehicle in operation upon a specified highway unless that vehicle is lawfully standing or parked at the curb or shoulder. 
(B)  No pedestrian shall be present upon a median, channelizing island, or rotary traffic island of a specified highway unless that pedestrian is in the process of lawfully crossing that specified highway. 
1.  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of division (B) if a pedestrian stays upon a median, channelizing island, or rotary traffic island through two consecutive opportunities to cross the specified highway in a lawful manner as provided in this Chapter or as provided by state law. An opportunity to cross includes, but is not limited to, a change in the traffic control signal at the intersection that controls the flow of traffic for that portion of a specified highway, the lack of traffic, or a break in traffic of sufficient length that a person could cross in a lawful manner. 
2.  A pedestrian that stays upon a median, channelizing island, or rotary traffic island of a specified highway through two consecutive opportunities to cross that specified highway shall not be considered to be "in the process of lawfully crossing that specified highway." 
(C)  No operator of a vehicle on a specified highway shall suddenly decrease the speed of a vehicle or deviate from a traffic lane for the purpose of approaching a pedestrian violating divisions (A) or (B). 
(D)  Divisions (A), (B), and (C) do not apply to persons who are: 
1.  On the sidewalk, 
2.  Using a crosswalk to lawfully cross a specified highway, 
3.  Engaged in law enforcement or rescue activities, including providing assistance to an injured or disabled vehicle or person, 
4.  Entering a vehicle as an invited passenger where it is lawful to do so, 
5.  Engaged in delivery, 
6.  Engaged in repair, construction, or maintenance activities on the specified highway under the direction or authority of the City of Dayton or State of Ohio, or 
7.  Upon a specified highway, or portion thereof, that has been closed pursuant to a permit or other express authorization from the City of Dayton or State of Ohio. 
(E)  Divisions (A) and (B) are strict liability offenses. 
(F)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of entering or staying upon a specified highway, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(G)  For the purpose of this section, the term "median" means "the area dividing a street or highway that separates lanes of traffic traveling in opposite directions. This area may be paved, unpaved, curbed, or painted." 
(H)  For the purpose of this section, the term "channelizing island" means "a defined area between traffic lanes of a street or highway used to control and direct vehicular movement, typically turning movement. This area may be paved, unpaved, curbed, or painted." 
(I)  For the purpose of this section, the term "rotary traffic island" means "a defined circular area at the center of an intersection around which vehicles travel. This area may be paved, unpaved, curbed, or painted." 
(J)  For the purpose of this section, a vehicle is "in operation" if it has an "operator" as that term is defined in R.C. 4511.01 (Y). 
(K)  For the purpose of this section, a "specified highway" is any street or highway, or portion thereof, described in divisions (1) or (2) below: 
1.  The following are "specified highways" for the purpose of this section: 
Brandt St.
