In addition to the streets and highways listed in division (K)(1), any portion of a street or highway that intersects with a street or highway listed in division (K)(1) that is within 250 feet of that intersection, as measured along the center line of the intersecting street or highway away from the point the intersecting street or highway touches the right-of-way of the street or highway listed in division (K)(1), is a "specified highway" for the purpose of this section. 
(Ord. No. 31645-18, § 1, 5-23-18) 
CHAPTER 76. - ABANDONED AND JUNK VEHICLES 

Sec. 76.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle. 
(1)  Any motor vehicle which is left on private property for more than 48 hours without the permission of the person having the right to the possession of the property; 
(2)  Any motor vehicle which is left on public property for 48 hours or longer without permission of the Director of Police of the city. 
    Inoperative motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle not moved for 30 consecutive days shall be presumed inoperative. 
    Junk motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle meeting any three of the following criteria: 
(1)  Three years old or older; 
(2)  Disabling damage, such damage including, but not limited to, any of the following: 
(a)  Missing wheel; 
(b)  Missing or deflated tire; 
(c)  Missing motor; 
(d)  Missing transmission; 
(3)  Fair market value less than $400.00; 
(4)  Inoperative; 
(5)  Unlicensed, or improperly licensed. 
    Motor vehicle. Any device, including major parts thereof, in, on, or by which any person or property is or may be transported, including devices used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks, and devices designed to be pulled, drawn, or towed by a motor vehicle, but not including devices moved by human or animal power. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, company, unincorporated association, or corporation. 
    Private property. Any real property within the city which is privately owned or operated. 
    Public property. Public streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, boulevards, bikeways, and the right-of-way thereof. Any property open to the public for the purpose of vehicular travel or parking and any right-of-way thereof. Any other property which is owned or operated by the city, and any right-of-way thereof. 
    Vehicle, and motor vehicle are used synonymously. However, their respective meaning is the same as in R.C. § 4511.01(A), (B), and (C). (R.C. §§ 4513.63, 4513.65) 
(Ord. 21676, passed 5-26-65; Am. Ord. 23450, passed 7-30-69; Am. Ord. 25505, passed 4-19-78; Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 28668-93, passed 4-14-93) 
Sec. 76.02. - Storing, parking, or leaving junked or abandoned motor vehicle prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall store, park, or have any motor vehicle which is in a junked, abandoned, inoperative, dismantled, or partially dismantled condition, whether attended or not, within the city upon any public or private property for a period of time of 48 hours or longer. 
(B)  The presence of a junked, abandoned, inoperative, dismantled, or partially dismantled motor vehicle, on private or public property, is a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(C)  This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle on private property which is stored in conformity with city zoning laws contained in R.C.G.O. Chapter 150. (R.C. § 4513.64) 
(Ord. 21676, passed 5-26-65; Am. Ord. 25505, passed 4-19-78; Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
Cross reference- Penalty see § 76.99. 
Sec. 76.03. - Disposition of junked vehicle. 
(A)  No person in charge or control of any private property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, shall allow junked, inoperative, dismantled, or partially dismantled motor vehicle to remain on such property longer than seven days after notice is served, in any manner provided by the Ohio Rules of Civil Procedure for service of summons in civil actions, to remove the motor vehicle from such property. A copy of said notice shall also be conspicuously affixed to the motor vehicle if the surrounding facts and circumstances make it practicable to do so. 
(B)  If no person in charge or control of any such property can be found, notice to such persons may be published once in a daily newspaper for general circulation within the city. Such motor vehicle shall be removed within seven days after publication. 
(C)  This section shall not apply with regard to any motor vehicle described in § 76.02(C). 
(D)  The person in charge or control of the private property upon which the motor vehicle is located and the registered owner of the vehicle shall have the duty to abate the nuisance by removing the vehicle from the premises. 
(E)  The notice required by this section shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The motor vehicle is considered junked; 
(2)  The motor vehicle will be removed seven days thereafter, impounded, and subsequently disposed of; 
(3)  The person in charge or control of the private property upon which the motor vehicle is located and the registered owner of the motor vehicle will be held jointly and severally responsible for all costs incidental to the removal, storage, and disposal; 
(4)  The person in charge or control of the private property upon which the motor vehicle is located and the registered owner of the motor vehicle may avoid fines and costs by removing the motor vehicle from the city or enclosing such vehicle in an appropriate structure; 
(5)  The date and the address and telephone number of the city department to contact for information; 
(6)  Any person to whom the notice is directed may file within the seven-day period of compliance a written request for a hearing. 
(F)  The movement of a vehicle from private property to any public right-of-way, or to another location under circumstances constituting a violation of this chapter, shall not constitute compliance with a notice prescribed by this section. 
(Ord. 21676, passed 5-26-65; Am. Ord. 25158, passed 9-15-76; Am. Ord. 27583, passed 8-5-87; Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
Sec. 76.04. - Request for hearing. 
    Any persons to whom notices are directed pursuant to § 76.03, or their duly authorized agents, may file a written request for a hearing before the Superintendent of the Division of Neighborhood Development, or his designee, within the seven-day period of compliance for the purpose of defending against the charges by the city. 
(Ord. 21676, passed 5-26-65; Am. Ord. 23450, passed 7-30-69; Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
Sec. 76.05. - Procedure for hearing. 
(A)  A hearing requested pursuant to § 76.04 shall be held as soon as practicable after the filing of the request. Persons requesting a hearing shall be advised of the time and place of said hearing. The scope of said hearing shall be limited to the following issues: 
(1)  Whether the person requesting the hearing is in charge or control of the private property as charged; and 
(2)  Whether the motor vehicle is junked or inoperative as charged. 
(B)  At any such hearing the city and the persons to whom notices have been directed may introduce such witnesses and evidence as each party deems necessary. The Superintendent of the Division of Neighborhood Development, or his designee, shall then either affirm, reverse, or modify the order. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
Sec. 76.06. - Purpose and effect of impoundment and immobilization provisions. 
(A)  The impoundment of vehicles under authority of the provisions of this chapter shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for the protection of the public peace, safety, and welfare, and for the safeguarding of property. 
(B)  Impoundment shall be used generally for: 
(1)  Prevention and removal of traffic and fire hazards; 
(2)  Prevention and abatement of public nuisances; 
(3)  Protection of public rights in the use of city streets, highways, and roadways from obstructions placed and left in derogation of those rights; 
(4)  Safeguarding and protecting recovered stolen vehicles; 
(5)  Amelioration of urban blight; 
(6)  Enforcement of the law. 
(Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 31083-11, passed 6-29-11) 
Sec. 76.07. - Authority of police to impound or immobilize vehicles. 
    Members of the Department of Police are authorized, within the limits set forth in this chapter, to impound or immobilize vehicles under the circumstances enumerated in § 76.08. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 31083-11, passed 6-29-11) 
Sec. 76.08. - Circumstances authorizing impoundment or immobilization. 
    Members of the Department of Police are authorized to impound, immobilize, remove, or direct the removal of a vehicle under any of the following circumstances: 
(A)  Disabled vehicles. If left unattended and improperly parked; if left on freeway right-of-way in excess of the time provided in § 71.73, or if the person in charge of the vehicle is physically incapacitated to such extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(B)  Vehicles on bridge. An unattended vehicle left on any bridge, viaduct, causeway, tunnel, or within the structure of a grade separation. 
(C)  Arrest and detention of driver. Whenever the driver or person in charge of any vehicle is placed under arrest and taken into custody and detained by police under circumstances which leaves or will leave a vehicle unattended. 
(D)  Vehicles creating traffic hazard or safety hazard. A vehicle left unattended and so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(E)  Vehicles abandoned on public property. Any vehicle which is left on public property for 48 hours or longer without the permission of the Director of Police. 
(F)  Vehicles stopped in a prohibited zone. Any unattended vehicle halted at the street curb or edge of roadway where stopping or standing is prohibited. 
(G)  Vehicles blocking fire exits or hydrants. Any vehicle illegally parked in such a manner that it blocks a fire escape ladder, device, or exit or blocks ready access to a fire hydrant. 
(H)  Vehicles parked in intersection. Any unattended vehicle parked in any street intersection. 
(I)  Stolen vehicles recovered by police. 
(1)  Whenever a stolen vehicle is located by police and the registered owner cannot be found within a reasonable time not exceeding one hour, or cannot be determined from the registration papers or other identifying media in the vehicle or from records or information available from reports of stolen cars, the vehicle may be removed to the nearest authorized place of impoundment. 
(2)  If the registered owner is identified, located, and notified of the recovery of the stolen vehicle, the owner shall be given the right to make his own arrangement for the removal of the vehicle within the period of one hour from the time he is actually notified of its recovery. If the owner is unable or unwilling to effect the removal within the time specified the vehicle may be impounded. 
(J)  Vehicles owned or leased by any person or entity to which two or more tags have been attached or notices of liability have issued pursuant to sections 72.12 or 70.121 of the City of Dayton's Revised Code of General Ordinances and a person or entity registered as the owner or lessee of the vehicle with the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles (or with any other state vehicle registration office) has failed or refused to comply with the civil penalties assessed within 30 days from the date of the second violation or failed or refused to enter an appearance or post bail. 
(K)  A vehicle which has been tagged pursuant to section 72.12 and remains for four hours or longer thereafter at the place where tagged. 
(L)  Vehicles abandoned on private property. Any motor vehicle which is left on private property for more than 48 hours without the permission of the person having the right to the possession of the property. 
(M)  Vehicles junked on private property. 
(1)  If a violation of § 76.03 has not been remedied within the seven-day period of compliance, or in the event that a request for a hearing is filed as prescribed in § 76.04, a hearing is held, and the existence of the violation is affirmed, the vehicle may be impounded. 
(2)  The movement of a vehicle from private property to any public right-of-way, or to another location under circumstances constituting a violation of this chapter shall not remedy a violation of § 76.03, and a vehicle so moved remains subject to impoundment by police. 
(N)  Vehicles removed by fire official pursuant to section 92.80. 
(O)  License plates: Any vehicle which does not display valid and unexpired front and rear license plates registered to that vehicle or which displays a license plate not registered to that vehicle. 
(P)  Evidence/Investigation: Any vehicle operated by a person while engaged in, or connected with, the commission of a crime. 
(Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 31083-11, passed 6-29-11; Ord. No. 31629-18, 1, 3-21-18) 
Sec. 76.09. - Place of impoundment. 
    Every vehicle that is impounded under the provisions of this chapter shall be removed to the nearest place of safekeeping designated by the Police Department, and to no other place. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
Sec. 76.10. - Duration of impoundment. 
(A)  Except as otherwise provided, any vehicle impounded under authority of this chapter shall be stored and held safely until released pursuant to a written order signed by the Police Chief, or and authorized agent of the Police Chief. 
(B)  The order of release is conditioned upon the payment by the person to whom the release is issued of all impoundment costs and accrued storage charges assessed against the vehicle. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 30394-04, passed 10-27-04) 
Sec. 76.11. - Notice of removal. 
    Within 72 hours of the towing, immobilization, or impoundment of a vehicle in accordance with chapters 70 and 76 of the Revised Code of General Ordinances, the City of Dayton Police Department or its designee shall send a notice by ordinary mail, or certified mail if the Police Chief or his/her designee desires, to the owner at the address as given on the motor vehicle registration from the Bureau of Motor Vehicles of the state registered. The notice shall include: 
(a)  The name and address of the registered owner of the vehicle towed, impounded, or immobilized; 
(b)  The license plate number of the vehicle towed, impounded, or immobilized; 
(c)  The reason for the towing, impoundment, or immobilization; 
(d)  The location, date and time where the vehicle was towed, impounded, or immobilized; 
(e)  The contact information for the entity to obtain release of the vehicle; and 
(f)  The time, place, and manner in which a hearing to contest the towing, impoundment, or immobilization can be initiated. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 31171-12, § 1, 5-23-12) 
Sec. 76.12. - Options for release of towed, impounded, or immobilized vehicles. 
(A)  An owner whose vehicle is towed, impounded, and/or immobilized as a result of failure to pay civil penalties may do any of the following: 
(1)  Pay the outstanding civil penalties, associated fees, and costs, in accordance with instructions on the notice of liability or notice of impoundment; and/or 
(2)  Within 20 calendar days of receiving a notice of impoundment or, at most, 25 calendar days after the vehicle has been towed, impounded, and/or immobilized, file a written request for hearing with the Dayton Police Department or its designee. Additionally, valid hearing requests must include payment in the amount of $50.00, which shall serve as a bond for the hearing. An individual desiring a hearing must post this $50.00 bond before a hearing will be scheduled. The failure to give notice of request for hearing with bond within this time period shall constitute a waiver of the right to contest towing, impoundment, and/or immobilization. A hearing, conducted by a hearing officer, shall be held within ten business days of the city's receipt of the request for review unless the City of Dayton shows good cause for delay. The Dayton Police Department or its designee will send written notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing by ordinary mail, or certified mail if the Police Chief or his/her designee desires, to the owner no later than five calendar days before the date of the hearing. The owner's failure to appear at the hearing shall be deemed to waive his or her right to contest the validity of the tow, impoundment, or immobilization. 
(a)  The Hearing Officer shall determine whether a preponderance of evidence establishes that a vehicle was properly towed, impounded, and/or immobilized pursuant to the law. Copies of the notice of violations or citations and a signed statement from the City of Dayton's Finance Director or designee shall be admissible and establish prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein and also create a rebuttable presumption that the towing, impoundment, or immobilization was proper and in accordance with the law. Unless the owner timely requested a hearing and prevailed at that hearing on the underlying notices of violation or citations, the owner has waived his or her right to contest the underlying notices of liability or citations at this hearing. 
(b)  If the Hearing Officer, after consideration of the evidence, finds that the tow, impoundment, or immobilization was proper and in accordance with the law, the Hearing Officer shall uphold the tow, impoundment, and/or immobilization and condition the release of the vehicle upon payment of all fines and fees accruing thereto. If bond has been posted, said bond shall be forfeited to the City of Dayton. Any fines or fees shall be ordered to be paid by the owner of the vehicle to the City of Dayton. Where the Hearing Officer finds that the tow, impoundment, or immobilization was not proper and in accordance with the law, an order releasing the vehicle shall be entered, the bond shall be returned to the owner, and the owner shall not be liable for the tow or storage fees. The City of Dayton or its designee shall mail the owner a copy of the Hearing Officer's order within ten days from the date of the hearing. 
(c)  All hearings are open to the public. 
(d)  Storage fees for towed, impounded, or immobilized vehicles shall continue to accrue during the pendency of the appeal. 
(e)  All decisions of the Hearing Officer, shall be final except as subject to court review. Unless prohibited by law, the City of Dayton may seek judicial review of decisions by the Hearing Officer. 
(f)  Presentation of an order of release at the place of impoundment shall entitle the owner or lessee presenting the release to obtain possession of the vehicle. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 31171-12, § 2, 5-23-12) 
Sec. 76.13. - Release of impounded vehicles. 
(A)  The Police Department, subject to the provisions of this chapter, is authorized to release impounded vehicles and to accept, on behalf of the city and as applicable, agreements to save and hold the city harmless signed by the person to whom the vehicle is released. 
(B)  The Department of Police will release an impounded vehicle to a registered owner or the registered owner's representative upon presentation of the following: 
(1)  Personal identification containing a photograph, such as a valid drivers license or a state issued identification card; 
(2)  A certificate of title for the impounded vehicle, which is not a "jumped" or "signed over" title; and 
(3)  A notarized power of attorney from the registered owner, if the person claiming the vehicle is not the registered owner and does not have a secured interest in the impounded vehicle. The power of attorney document must be on a form prepared by the Department of Law. 
(C)  The Department of Police will release an impounded vehicle to a party having a secured interest in an impounded vehicle upon presentation of the following: 
(1)  Proof of a secured interest in the impounded vehicle, such as the certificate of title with the interest noted thereon; and 
(2)  A signed release holding the city and its elected officials, officers and employees harmless from all liability for release of the impounded vehicle. Such release shall be on the form prepared by the Department of Law. 
(D)  If the person obtaining the release of an impounded vehicle pursuant to this section cannot satisfy all applicable federal, state and local laws for the operation of a vehicle, the vehicle must be removed from the impound facility by an insured towing service. 
(E)  The Police Department shall retain a copy of the instruments and documents required by this section. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90; Am. Ord. 30394-04, passed 10-27-04) 
Sec. 76.14. - Disposal of unclaimed vehicles. 
(A)  The Police Department shall dispose of unclaimed motor vehicles in accordance with R.C. § 4513.62. 
(B)  All affidavits used to facilitate the disposal of unclaimed motor vehicles shall be approved by the registrar of motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
Secs. 76.15-76.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 76.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Whoever violates §§ 76.02 or 76.03 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor, and shall also be assessed any costs incurred in the removal, impoundment, and disposal of the motor vehicle, less any money accruing to the city from such, if any, disposal. 
(B)  Every day during which a violation of §§ 76.02 or 76.03 is found to exist shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(Ord. 25505, passed 4-19-78; Am. Ord. 28227, passed 11-14-90) 
CHAPTER 77. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE 

Sec. 77.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Ambulance attendant. The person who is physically in charge of a vehicle being used to provide emergency medical service. 
    Emergency medical service. A public or private organization using EMT-A's or paramedics, or a combination of EMT-A's and paramedics, to provide emergency medical care to victims of serious illness or injury prior to the victim's receiving professional medical care or hospitalization. 
    Emergency medical technician-ambulance or EMT-A. A trained or qualified person certified under R.C. §§ 4731.86(A) or 4731.87 who is responsible for the operation of an ambulance and care of patients, and who, in an emergency, determines the nature and extent of illness or injury and establishes priority for required emergency care; renders emergency care, such as opening and maintaining an airway, giving positive pressure ventilation, cardiac resuscitation, controlling a hemorrhage, treatment of shock, immobilization of fractures, bandaging, assisting in childbirth, management of mentally disturbed patients, and initial care of poison and burn patients. Where patients must be extricated from entrapment, assesses the extent of injury and gives all possible emergency care and protection to the entrapped patient; provides light rescue service if an ambulance has not been accompanied by a specialized unit; and after extrication, provides additional care in sorting of the injured in accordance with standard emergency procedures. 
    Emergency medical technician-paramedic or EMT-P. A person specially trained beyond the emergency medical technician ambulance level, who is certified under R.C. §§ 4731.86(B) or 4731.87 who, in addition to performing those functions described in subsection (A) of that section, renders rescue and emergency medical services, and, in conjunction with a cooperating licensed medical doctor, doctor of osteopathic medicine and surgery, or a physician advisory board, may perform the following life-support or intensive care techniques: 
(1)  Cardiac monitoring. 
(2)  Defibrillation. 
(3)  Airway or gastric intubation. 
(4)  Relief of pneumothorax. 
(5)  Administration of appropriate drugs and intravenous fluids. 
    Hospital. Any of the following: 
(1)  Children's Medical Center; 
(2)  Good Samaritan Hospital; 
(3)  Grandview Hospital; 
(4)  Miami Valley Hospital; 
(5)  St. Elizabeth Medical Center; 
(6)  Such other hospitals or other medical facilities as may be designated as such by the Director of Fire or his designated agent or representative. 
(Ord. 24205, passed 2-2-72; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78) 
Sec. 77.02. - Emergency medical service within the city. 
    The Department of Fire, under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the Director of Fire or a designated and qualified Emergency Medical Technician-Ambulance or Emergency Medical Technician-Paramedic, may furnish emergency medical service to any individual in need of that service from any point of origin within the city limits to a hospital, as the ambulance attendant deems appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. 24205, passed 2-2-72; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78) 
Sec. 77.03. - Emergency medical service outside the city. 
    The Department of Fire, under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the Director of Fire and to the extent of its facilities, may furnish emergency medical service from a point of origin outside of the city limits to any employee of the city who is injured or becomes sick during the hours of employment and while performing city duties; and, in addition, the director may furnish emergency medical service in responding to any catastrophe or natural disaster, or in mutual aid of any surrounding communities. 
(Ord. 24205, passed 2-2-72; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78) 
Sec. 77.04. - Emergency medical and/or ambulance service; charges. 
    The City Manager, or his or her designate, is authorized to review, consider, and recommend a schedule of levels and/or types of services and charges or fees therefor to be billed to the benefiting party, insurance carrier, or other responsible third party for the use of the city's emergency medical and/or ambulance services. Such schedule of charges shall be approved by the City Commission on a periodic basis as needed. 
(Ord. 24205, passed 2-2-72; Am. Ord. 24446, passed 2-28-73; Am. Ord. 25593, passed 8-30-78; Am. Ord. 28807-94, passed 4-20-94) 
Sec. 77.05. - Bond or insurance required for private ambulance. 
(A)  Before any private ambulance shall be operated as an "emergency vehicle," the owner thereof shall file with the Chief of Police a good and sufficient indemnity bond payable to the city for the benefit of any person injured in person or property, which bond shall be to the approval of the Chief of Police, in a sum equal to $100,000.00 for each person damnified, with a total liability of $300,000.00 for any one accident, conditioned on the safe and lawful operation of the ambulance or ambulances owned by the applicant. The indemnity bond shall be kept and maintained at this amount at all times and until every claim against the owner of the ambulance for damages, injuries, or claims arising from death or injury incurred or suffered by person or property through the neglect or wrongful act of the ambulance owner, his agent, or employees, in the operation of said ambulance has been settled. The bond shall be conditioned that any judgment rendered in any court against such ambulance owner arising out of any damage or injury to any person or property caused by the operation of the ambulance due to the wrongful act of his agent or employees shall be paid. Such bond shall contain express provisions to the effect that the bond shall not become void on first recovery but may be sued on and recovery be had from time to time until the full amount is exhausted. In case of the payment of damages by the surety on such bond, the principal shall at once give an additional bond in the amount paid to the end that there shall be at all times the principal sum specified available for compensation as aforesaid. 
(B)  In lieu of giving a bond such ambulance owner may, at his discretion, file with the Chief of Police a liability insurance policy in the sum and under all the terms, stipulations, and conditions hereinbefore set forth for indemnity bonds. This policy shall be acceptable to and subject to the approval of the Chief of Police. The policy shall provide in addition to the aforesaid provisions that no notice of any acts creating any liability thereunder will be required from the city; that the policy shall not be canceled before five days written notice of intention to cancel has been given to the Chief of Police, and that the policy shall not be cancelable but remain in full force and effect until five days have elapsed from the date of service of such written notice. The bond or policy shall be renewed annually to the satisfaction of the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. 14967, passed 3-3-37; Am. Ord. 15621, passed 10-29-41) 
CHAPTER 78. - OTTAWA STREET YARDS 

Sec. 78.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Highway. That portion of public land set aside and maintained by the city as a thoroughfare open to the public for traffic use in connection with the utilization of the Ottawa Street yards or golf course facilities. 
    Ottawa Street yards. Any part of the property owned or under the control of the city in its management and operation of the facility known as the Ottawa Street yards. 
    Public safety and emergency vehicles. All vehicles defined as public safety and emergency vehicles in R.C. § 4511.01(D) and (E). 
    Roadway. Has same meaning as in R.C. § 4511.01(DD). 
    Stop. The halting of a vehicle for whatever period of time or whatever purpose except when necessary to avoid a conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer, security officer, or traffic-control device. 
(Ord. 23836, passed 10-14-70; Am. Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81) 
Sec. 78.02. - Traffic rules and regulations at Ottawa Street yards and golf course facilities. 
(A)  The Director of Public Works is authorized and directed to promulgate rules and regulations necessary for the regulation and control of traffic at Ottawa Street yards and city golf courses by erecting traffic-control signals and signs, establishing speed limits, designating parking areas and controlling parking, standing, or stopping of vehicles, creating loading zones and safety zones, and designating the route of vehicles; and by making all other needed rules and regulations for the regulation and control of traffic as aforesaid, not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  All rules and regulations promulgated under the provisions of this chapter shall be incorporated in the traffic schedule required by § 70.11 within 120 days of issuance. Traffic speeds established and control devices installed shall conform to the requirements of city ordinance, state law, and regulations, and the recommendations of the traffic engineer. 
(C)  The provisions of chapters 70, 71, 72, 73, 74, 75, 76, and this chapter shall apply to all persons and vehicles on or within the Ottawa Street yards and golf course facilities unless specifically modified by the Director of Public Works by published rule or regulation. 
(Ord. 23836, passed 10-14-70; Am. Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81) 
Sec. 78.03. - Exemptions to authorized emergency and public safety vehicles. 
(A)  In addition to the exemptions provided in chapters 70 through 76, regulating the operating, parking, and standing of vehicles, authorized emergency and public safety vehicles while in actual use for emergency purposes, may park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  The foregoing exemptions shall not protect the driver of any such authorized emergency vehicle from the consequence of his reckless disregard of the property and safety of others. 
(Ord. 23836, passed 10-14-70; Am. Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 78.99. 
Secs. 78.04-78.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 78.99. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be penalized as provided in § 70.99. 
(Am. Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81) 
CHAPTER 79. - JAMES M. COX DAYTON INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT

    Stop. The halting of a vehicle for whatever period of time or whatever purpose except when necessary to avoid a conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer, security officer, or traffic-control device. 
(Ord. 22601, passed 8-9-67; Am. Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81)

Cox Dayton International Airport and General Airport South, the Director of Aviation is authorized and directed to promulgate rules and regulations necessary for the regulation and control of traffic by establishing speed limits, designating the location of traffic-control signals and signs, controlling parking, standing or stopping of vehicles, creating loading zones and safety zones, creating taxicab and limousine stands, designating emergency vehicles, designating route of vehicles through the airport, designating the maximum weight of any vehicle permitted on any roadway or other traveled area on the airport; or by making all other necessary rules and regulations for the regulation and control of traffic as aforesaid, not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  All rules and regulations promulgated under the provisions of this chapter shall be incorporated in the traffic schedule required by § 70.11 within 120 days of issuance. Traffic-control device installed shall conform to city ordinance, state law, and regulations and the recommendations of the traffic engineer. A current copy of rules and regulations shall be on file in the office of the Director of Aviation. 
(C)  The provisions of chapters 70, 71, 72, 73, 74, 75, 76, and this chapter shall apply to all persons and vehicles on or within the airport grounds unless specifically modified by the Director of Aviation by published regulation or rule.

CHAPTER 80. - WATERCRAFT 

Sec. 80.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Anchorage. A designated position where vessels or watercraft may anchor or moor. 
    Aquatic event. Any organized water event of limited duration which is duly sanctioned by the city at least 30 days prior to the start of such event and includes Marine Regattas and Marine Parades, which by their nature, circumstances, or location will introduce extra or unusual hazards to the safety of life on navigable waters. 
    Boat number. A series of letters and numerals assigned to the owner by the Division of Watercraft of the state. The number will be designated on a certificate of number issued to each boat owner in accordance with a system of numbering which will be uniform throughout the United States and its territories. 
    Coast Guard approved equipment. Equipment which has been approved by the commandant of the United States Coast Guard, or a duly appointed agency. 
    Emergency watercraft. Any watercraft designated and/or identified as Police Department, Fire Department or State Patrol Watercraft or any watercraft commandeered by police officers. 
    Operator. Any person who navigates, or has under his control, a watercraft, or watercraft and detachable motor on the waters of this city. 
    Owner. Any person who claims lawful possession of a watercraft by virtue of legal title or equitable interest therein which entitles him to such possession. 
    Pier. Any pier, wharf, dock, flat, gridiron, or other structure to promote the convenient loading or unloading or other discharge of vessels or watercraft, or the repair thereof. 
    Port. Left, where reference is to the left side of a watercraft when looking forward on such watercraft. 
    Powercraft. Any watercraft propelled by machinery, fuel, rockets, or similar device up to but not more than 65 feet in length. Motor boats of class "A" are those less than 16 feet in length, measured from end to end in a straight line from the foremost part of the vessel to the aftermost, measured parallel to the centerline. Bowsprits, rudders, outboard motors and brackets and similar fittings or attachments are not to be included. Length shall be stated in feet and inches. Motor boats of class "1" shall be 16 feet to less than 26 feet in length. Motor boats of class "2" shall be 26 feet to less than 40 feet in length. Motor boats of class "3" shall be 40 feet to not more than 65 feet in length. 
    Restricted area. Any designated and appropriately marked area that shall be closed to certain activities such as swimming, skiing, fishing, and aquatic events, and wherein watercraft speed limits shall be a maximum of six miles per hour, as well as certain designated areas which shall be restricted to nonpower craft. Such restricted areas shall be marked pursuant to R.C. Chapter 1547. 
    Sailboat. Any watercraft equipped with mast and sails, dependent upon the wind to propel such watercraft in the normal course of operation of such watercraft. 
(1)  Any sailboat equipped with an inboard engine is deemed a powercraft with auxiliary sail. 
(2)  Any sailboat equipped with a detachable motor is deemed a sailboat with auxiliary power. 
(3)  Any sailboat being propelled by mechanical power, whether under sail or not, is deemed a powercraft and subject to all laws and rules and regulations governing powercraft operation. 
    Starboard. Right, where reference is to the right side of a watercraft when looking forward on such watercraft. 
    Visible. Visible on a dark night with clear atmosphere. 
    Wake. The track, waves, path, or disturbance left in the water by a watercraft, either by means of its movement through the water or by its power, exhaust, or propeller, whether such watercraft is actually moving or not. 
    Watercraft. Any contrivance used or designed for navigation on water including, but not limited to, any vessel, boat, motor vessel, steam vessel, vessel operated by machinery either permanently or temporarily affixed, scow, tugboat, or any marine equipment which is capable of carrying passengers, excepting ferries, as referred to in R.C. Chapter 4583. 
    Water ski. All forms, manners, means, or contrivances used by a person or persons being towed behind a watercraft. 
    Water traffic-control devices. All signs, signals, markers, placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning, or guiding marine water traffic including mooring, docking, and launching signs at public piers, wharfs, docks, floats, etc. 
    Waters of Dayton. Any waters within the jurisdiction of the city in which any watercraft is or may be operated. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Sec. 80.02. - Authority and enforcement. 
(A)  The Director of Human Resources of the city is authorized to make effective and enforce rules and regulations, in conformity with the state watercraft laws, in relation to the use of waters of Dayton for the safety of the public and public or private property adjacent thereto. 
(B)  The Superintendent of Park Maintenance shall manage, control, and supervise all waters of Dayton, pursuant to rules and regulations established and approved by the Director of Human Resources and the city, in conformity with the laws of the state. 
(C)  The Patrol Supervisor shall be designated by the Superintendent of Park Maintenance as his representative who shall have police authority and supervision over all waters of Dayton. He shall be empowered to enforce established and approved rules and regulations as well as make and enforce temporary rules and regulations to cover boating emergencies or special conditions. 
(D)  No person shall refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction given by the Patrol Supervisor or law enforcement officer as defined in R.C. Chapter 1547, in connection with the operation of watercraft in the waters of the city. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Sec. 80.03. - Release from arrest on notice to appear. 
    Whenever any person is arrested for any violation of rules and regulations made pursuant to § 80.02, the arresting officer may serve upon him a citation and notice to appear in court. The arrested person, in order to secure release and when permitted by the arresting officer, must give his written promise to appear in court, as required by the citation and notice served by the arresting officer. Upon the arrested person's failure or refusal to sign such written promise, he may be taken into custody of such arresting officer and so remain or be placed in confinement. The arrestee's watercraft may be taken into a place of impoundment at the expense of the arrestee. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Sec. 80.04. - Watercraft number regulations. 
(A)  Every watercraft operated on the waters of this city shall be numbered pursuant to the state numbering system, or an approved numbering system of another state, provided such watercraft has not operated in the city in excess of 90 days, or in accordance with federal law, except: 
(1)  Vessels documented by the United States Bureau of Customs; 
(2)  Watercraft owned by the United States or by a state or political subdivision thereof; 
(3)  A boat belonging to a class exempted from numbering by the State Division of Watercraft. 
(B)  Each watercraft shall be required to have its own identification number, and the number is not transferable to any other watercraft. The letters and numerals must be in block characters and at least three inches in height. They must be of a color or substance that contrasts with the background color of the boat and must provide clear legibility. The numbers and letters shall read from left to right as they appear on the certificate of award and the letter group shall be separated from the numerals by hyphens or by equivalent spaces. 
(C)  The number must be displayed on the bow of each side of the watercraft or as close to it as practicable, depending on the design of the watercraft. The original certificate of number award must be available on board the watercraft for inspection at all times when the boat is in use. In addition, the metal or plastic tag indicating the license year of the number award shall be securely affixed to the stern of said watercraft prior to operation. 
(D)  A dealer's number may be transferred from one watercraft to another in the case of bona fide dealers or manufacturers and when watercraft are used for demonstration and testing purposes in accordance with the provisions of dealer's or manufacturer's permits. 
(E)  The responsibility of having a watercraft numbered rests upon the person or persons who own the watercraft, and does not include the person or persons who rent or lease the watercraft, or one who holds a mortgage on a watercraft. 
(F)  Each certificate of number shall expire on January 1 of each succeeding year; application for renewal may be made to any authorized agent of the Division of Watercraft, who shall issue to the applicant a metal or plastic tag with the certificate of number award. 
(G)  The owner of any watercraft already covered by a number in full force and effect which has been awarded to it pursuant to the operative federal law of a federally approved numbering system to another state shall record said number with the Chief of Watercraft prior to operating the watercraft on the waters of this city in excess of 90 days. 
(H)  Whenever the ownership of a watercraft changes, a new application form together with the prescribed fee shall be filed with the State Division of Watercraft and a new certificate of number shall be assigned in the same manner as provided for in the original assignment number. 
(I)  The owner shall furnish the Division of Watercraft notice of the transfer of all or any part of his interest other than the creation of a security interest in watercraft in this state, or of the destruction or abandonment of such watercraft; however, in the case of a transfer of a part interest which does not affect the owner's right to operate such watercraft, such transfer shall not terminate the certificate of number. 
(J)  Any holder of a certificate of number shall notify the Chief of the Division of Watercraft within 15 days, if his address no longer conforms to the address appearing on the certificate and shall, as a part of such notification, furnish the chief with his new address. 
(K)  No person shall operate an outboard motor on a watercraft required to be numbered or on a bailed, or rented boat, in any waters of the city, without first obtaining an outboard motor license from the Chief of the Division of Watercraft or an authorized agent. The metal or plastic license tag bearing the date of the license year for which issued shall be securely attached to the outboard motor for which issued, prior to its operation on any waters of this city. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.05. - Equipment. 
(A)  Excessive power. No watercraft shall be equipped with any motor or other propulsion machinery beyond its safe power capacity, taking into consideration the type and construction of the watercraft and other existing operating conditions. 
(B)  Mufflers. All watercraft operating in city waters shall be equipped with a suitable muffler or silencer of sufficient size and capacity to effectually muffle and prevent excessive or unusual noise from the exhaust of any engines installed or aboard such watercraft. This division shall not apply when such watercraft is operating in a regularly scheduled and duly authorized race, regatta, or other aquatic event. 
(C)  Whistles and lights. No master, owner, or any other person in charge of any watercraft, while lying at any pier, or at anchor, or while navigating in city waters, shall unnecessarily cause any whistle or siren to be blown or sounded, nor shall any person flash the rays of a searchlight or other blinding light onto the bridge or pilot house of any watercraft under way for any purpose other than those authorized by law. 
(D)  Lights for watercraft. Light requirements on all watercraft shall be those prescribed by R.C. Chapter 1547, under the inland rules and those prescribed under international rules. 
(E)  Flashing lights. The installation and use of intermittently flashing lights of any type or color is prohibited, except in an emergency to attract attention for aid and relief in such emergency, and except that a blue colored revolving or flashing horizontal beam of low intensity located at any effective point on the forward exterior of the watercraft may be displayed by authorized patrol boats when engaged in law enforcement duties day or night on waters of this state. 
(F)  Life jackets. Any watercraft in operation on the waters of this state shall carry the following equipment. 
(1)  Watercraft 16 feet or greater in length, shall carry one type 1, 2, or three personal flotation device for each person on board and one type 4 personal flotation device; 
(2)  Watercraft less than 16 feet in length, including canoes, shall carry one type 1, 2, 3, or 4 personal flotation device for each person on board. 
(3)  Each personal flotation device shall be coast guard approved and in good and serviceable condition, of appropriate size for the wearer and shall be readily accessible to each person aboard such watercraft at all times. 
(G)  Flame arrestors. The carburetors on inboard internal combustion engines must be equipped with coast guard approved backfire flame arrestop securely attached to the carburetor and in proper working order. 
(H)  Fire extinguishers. 
(1)  All powercraft, except those propelled by an electric motor, shall carry fire extinguishers capable of extinguishing a burning gasoline fire and such fire extinguisher shall be so placed as to be readily accessible and in such condition as to be ready for immediate and effective use. 
(2)  Any fire extinguisher carried or used on watercraft in this state shall comply with minimum or higher standards for such extinguishers then prevailing as prescribed by the United States coast guard. 
(3)  Class A and class 1 powercraft shall carry at least one B-1 fire extinguisher. 
(4)  Class 2 powercraft shall carry at least two B-1 fire extinguishers. 
(5)  Class 3 powercraft shall carry at least three B-1 fire extinguishers. 
(6)  A B-1 fire extinguisher is one containing one and three-quarters gallons foam, four pounds carbon dioxide, or two pounds dry chemical. 
(I)  Anchor. All watercraft, except sailboats less than 16 feet long having a cockpit depth of less than 12 inches and except canoes shall carry an anchor and line of sufficient weight and length to anchor the watercraft securely. The Chief of the Division of Watercraft may, by rule, exempt other types of watercraft from this section if he determines that carrying such anchor and line would constitute a hazard. 
(J)  Ventilation. All powercraft using gasoline or other liquid fuel having a flashpoint of less than 110°F. shall be provided with ventilation as follows: 
(1)  At least two ventilators fitted with cowls or their equivalent for the purpose of properly and efficiently ventilating the bilges of every engine and fuel tank compartment in order to remove any inflammable or explosive gases; 
(2)  Any type of ventilating system approved for use by the united states coast guard; 
(3)  The ventilation of the boat is not required where the greater portion of the bilges of the engine and fuel tank compartment is open to the natural atmosphere. 
(K)  Equipment. All watercraft shall carry the equipment required by any applicable United States laws and state laws as now or hereafter amended and a violation of the same shall be deemed a violation of this division. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.06. - Rules of the road. 
    The following rules for preventing collisions shall be followed in the navigation of all public and private watercraft operating upon the waters of Dayton: 
(A)  Every watercraft which is under way propelled by sail alone shall be considered a sailboat. Every watercraft which is under way propelled by sail and machinery shall be considered a powercraft. Every watercraft shall be considered under way when she is not at anchor or made fast to the shore or aground. In addition to any other situation, "risk of collision", shall be determined to exist whenever the compass bearing of the approaching watercraft remains substantially the same. 
(B)  When two sailboats are approaching one another so as to involve the risk of collision one of them shall yield the right-of-way to the other, as follows, namely: 
(1)  A sailboat which is running free shall yield the right-of-way to the sailboat which is close-hauled. 
(2)  A sailboat which is close-hauled on the port tack shall yield the right-of-way to a sailboat which is close-hauled on the starboard tack. 
(3)  When both sailboats are running free, with the wind on different sides, the sailboat which has the wind on the port side shall yield the right-of-way to the other. 
(4)  When both sailboats are running free, with the wind on the same side, the sailboat which is to the windward shall yield the right-of-way to the sailboat which is to the leeward. 
(C)  When two powercrafts are meeting end on, or nearly end on, so as to involve the risk of collision, each shall alter her course to starboard, so that each shall pass the other on the port side of the other. 
(D)  When two powercraft are crossing at right angles or obliquely, so as to involve the risk of collision, the powercraft which has the other on her own starboard side shall yield the right-of-way to the other. 
(E)  When a powercraft and a sailboat are proceeding in such directions as to involve the risk of collision, the powercraft shall yield the right-of-way to the sailboat, except when the sailboat is overtaking the powercraft. 
(F)  Every watercraft which is directed by these rules to yield the right-of-way to another watercraft shall, on approaching such other watercraft, if necessary, slacken her speed, stop, reverse, or alter course. Where, by any of the rules prescribed by R.C. Chapter 1547, one of two watercraft shall yield the right-of-way, the other shall keep her course and speed. 
(G)  Notwithstanding anything contained in these rules, every watercraft overtaking another shall yield the right-of-way to the overtaken watercraft. Every watercraft coming up with another watercraft from any direction more than 221/2° abaft the other's beam, that is, at such a position with reference to the watercraft which she is overtaking that at night she would be unable to see either of the other's side or combination bow lights is an overtaking watercraft; and no subsequent alteration of bearing between the two watercraft shall make the overtaking watercraft a crossing watercraft within the meaning of these rules, or relieve her of the duty of keeping clear of the overtaken watercraft until she is finally passed and clear. If the overtaking watercraft is in doubt as to whether she is forward of or abaft this direction from the other watercraft, she should assume that she is an overtaking watercraft and yield the right-of-way. 
(H)  In rivers and streams or other areas in which there is a water current, the descending watercraft shall have the right-of-way over a watercraft which is ascending. 
(I)  When a powercraft and a rowboat are proceeding in such direction as to involve the risk of collision such powercraft shall yield the right-of-way to such rowboat. 
(J)  Watercraft leaving a dock, boat slip, or tie-up space shall yield the right-of-way to all watercraft approaching such dock, boat slip, or tie-up space. 
(K)  At all times the operator of a watercraft shall maintain a proper lookout required by the ordinary practice of seamen and by the special circumstances of the case. 
(L)  In obeying and construing these rules, due regard shall be had to all dangers of navigation and collision and to any special circumstances which may render a departure from the above rules necessary in order to avoid immediate danger. (R.C. § 1547.05) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.07. - Reckless operation. 
(A)  No person shall operate a watercraft in a reckless manner or at a speed greater or less than is reasonable or proper, having due regard to other watercraft, waves, weather, wind, and any other condition then existing, or at a speed greater than will permit him to bring it to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead, or shall operate a watercraft in such a manner as to cause a wake, so as to endanger any person, canoeist, swimmer, or property of a person, having due regard to the presence of other watercraft, or persons or other objects in or on the waters of Dayton. 
(B)  No operator of a watercraft shall operate the same at a speed exceeding six miles per hour within any state approved buoyed launch or mooring area or in or on any city waters between the hours of sunset and sunrise. 
(C)  Nothing in the provisions of this section shall be construed to mean that the operator of a watercraft competing in a race or regatta, or trials therefor which have been duly authorized by the city and by the Chief of the Division of Watercraft, shall be prohibited from attempting to attain high speeds on a duly designated and indicated racing course. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.08. - Persons under influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(A)  No person who is under the influence of alcoholic beverages, narcotic drugs, opiates, or drugs of abuse shall operate or be in actual physical control of any watercraft under way, or manipulate any water skis, aquaplane, or similar device upon the waters of Dayton. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any watercraft or any person having such in charge or in control to authorize or knowingly permit the same to be operated by any person who is under the influence of alcohol, narcotic drugs, opiates, or drugs of abuse. 
(B)  In any hearing in the municipal court of the city on a charge of operating a watercraft under the influence of alcohol or narcotic drugs or opiates or hypnotics, testimony that a watercraft bearing a certain number award was found to be in violation hereunder and further testimony that the records of the state show that such number award was issued to the defendant and further testimony that the defendant was found on the watercraft or immediate vicinity when the violation occurred, shall be prima facie evidence of unlawful operation of such watercraft by the defendant. A certified copy showing such facts from the State Division of Watercraft shall be proof of such ownership. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.09. - Following too closely. 
    The operator of a watercraft shall not follow another watercraft more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard to the speed of such watercraft and other marine traffic in the immediate vicinity. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.10. - Interference to navigation. 
    No person shall operate any watercraft or vessel in a manner which will unreasonably or unnecessarily interfere with other water-craft or vessels or with the free and proper navigation of the waterways of the city. Anchoring or mooring under bridges or in a heavily traveled channel shall constitute such interference if unreasonable under the prevailing circumstances. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.11. - Overloading. 
    No person shall operate a watercraft to which a capacity plate required by R.C. § 1547.39 is attached, if the total load exceeds the weight capacity indicated on the capacity plate, or if the number of persons aboard exceeds the occupant capacity indicated on the capacity plate, or if the horsepower of any attached outboard motor exceeds the maximum horsepower indicated on the capacity plate. (R.C. § 1547.42) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.12. - Collision; operator's duties to assist and report. 
(A)  It shall be the duty of the operator of watercraft involved in a collision, accident, or other casualty, so far as he can do so without serious injury to his own watercraft, crew and passengers, to render to other persons affected thereby such assistance as may be practicable and as may be necessary in order to save them or minimize any danger caused thereby, and also to give his name, address, and identification of his watercraft in writing to any person injured and to the owner of any property damaged in the collision, accident or other casualty, or to any person who requests such information; provided, that such person is duly authorized by law or a witness to such collision, accident, or other casualty. 
(B)  In the case of collision, accident, or other casualty involving watercraft, which results in death or injury to a person and/or damage to property in excess of $100.00, the operator shall file with the Police Department and the Chief of the Division of Watercraft of the state a full description of the collision, accident, or other casualty, within 24 hours, on the form so prescribed by the Chief of the State Division of Watercraft. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.13. - Exemptions to emergency watercraft. 
(A)  The provisions of this chapter regulating the operation of watercraft shall apply to authorized emergency watercraft, except that an operator of such emergency watercraft in an emergency may: 
(1)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he operates with due regard for the safety of all persons in the area and sounds audible signals by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle. 
(2)  Anchor, stop, moor, or dock notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to persons, barges, derricks, tugs, work watercraft, and other equipment while actually engaged in work within an area designated by the city or other state and federal government agencies. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Sec. 80.14. - Obedience to federal and state marine rules of the road. 
    The operator, owner, or person in charge of a watercraft in the waters of the city shall obey the rules of the road as promulgated by the United States coast guard in the Department of Treasury and all laws approved by the Chief of the Division of Watercraft, Department of Natural Resources, and rules and regulations adopted or promulgated by the Chief of the State Division of Watercraft. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.15. - Anchoring. 
    No person shall anchor a watercraft for fishing, or anchor or stop or allow a watercraft to drift for any purpose other than an emergency in any city waters in such a position as to obstruct a passageway or channel ordinarily used by other watercraft. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.16. - Interference with or mooring to navigation buoys. 
    No person shall without lawful authority climb on, swim and hang on, dive off, tie a watercraft to or attempt to tie a watercraft to, injure, sink, disconnect from its anchor, damage, deface, or interfere with any buoy or other aid to navigation which is placed, anchored or erected by the United States Coast Guard. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.17. - Launching ramps. 
    No person shall use a public launching ramp in the city for any other purpose than to launch, retrieve, or recover a watercraft as expeditiously as possible without prejudice to other person or persons waiting to use such ramp. It shall be unlawful to use a ramp for the purpose of repairing a watercraft or its engine or to refuse to move a watercraft or trailer when ordered by a police officer, patrol supervisor or person designated to supervise the proper use of such public launching ramps. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.18. - Incapacity of operator. 
(A)  No person shall let, loan or rent, with or without hire, any watercraft to any person who is under the influence of alcohol, or any other intoxicant, who may be incompetent to take charge of the management of a watercraft. 
(B)  No owner of any watercraft or any person having such in charge or in control shall authorize or knowingly permit the same to be operated by any person who, by reason of physical or mental disability, is incapable of operating such watercraft under the prevailing circumstances. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.19. - Age limit of operators. 
(A)  No person under 12 years of age shall operate any watercraft upon the waters of Dayton unless such person is under the direct visual and audible supervision, during such operation, of a parent, guardian or other person over the age of 16 years. No supervising parent, guardian, or other person over 16 years of age shall permit any person under 12 years of age operating a watercraft upon the waters of the state to violate any section of R.C. Chapter 1547. (R.C. § 1547.06) 
(B)  No person shall let, loan, or rent, with or without hire, any watercraft to any person or persons under 12 years of age; however, any person may let, loan, or rent a watercraft to persons under 12 years of age when accompanied in the use of such watercraft by a competent person over 16 to take charge of and manage it. This division shall not apply to regular training programs conducted by competent instructors, sea scout groups or persons under the jurisdiction of their parents or guardians. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.20. - Water skiing. 
(A)  No watercraft which shall have in tow or shall be otherwise assisting a person on water skis, aquaplane, surfboard, or similar contrivances shall be operated in the city waters unless such watercraft shall be occupied by at least two competent persons, one who shall be the operator and one who shall be the observer; however, this division shall not apply to watercraft used in duly authorized ski exhibitions, tournaments, or other aquatic events. Further, the observer must be 12 years of age or older. (R.C. § 1547.15) 
(B)  No person shall water ski or tow or otherwise assist anyone on water skis, aquaplane, surfboard, or similar contrivance within the buoyed launching and mooring areas or channel entrances; however, this division shall not apply to watercraft used in duly authorized ski exhibitions, tournaments, or other aquatic events. 
(C)  No watercraft shall have in tow or shall otherwise assist a person on water skis, aquaplane, surfboard, or similar contrivance from sunset to sunrise; however, this division shall not apply to watercraft used in duly authorized ski exhibitions, tournaments, or other aquatic events. (R.C. § 1547.16) 
(D)  no watercraft shall have in tow or shall otherwise assist a person on water skis, aquaplane, surfboard or similar contrivance in a reckless or dangerous manner, and any person on water skis, aquaplane, surfboard, or similar contrivance shall conduct himself in a careful and prudent manner and shall remain at all times a reasonable and prudent distance from the person and property of others; however, this division shall not apply to watercraft used in duly authorized ski exhibitions, tournaments, or other aquatic events. 
(E)  No person who operates a watercraft to tow other persons riding upon water skis, aquaplane, surfboard, or similar contrivance, shall tow more than two such persons simultaneously except during duly authorized ski exhibitions, tournaments, or other aquatic events. (R.C. § 1547.17) 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.21. - Riders on watercraft. 
    No occupant of a watercraft shall allow any person to ride or sit on either the gunwale or the decking over the bow of the watercraft while under way, except when immediately necessary for the safe and reasonable navigation or operation of such watercraft. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 31654-18, § 1, adopted July 18, 2018, repealed § 80.22, which pertained to operating unsafe watercraft and derived from Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65. 
Sec. 80.23. - Throwing objects at watercraft. 
    No person shall throw at or attempt to throw any stone, stick, or other missile with intent to injure anyone or damage any property. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.24. - Aquatic events. 
    It shall be the duty of any yacht club, boat club or other organization to notify the city, and acquire and fill out Form WC-23, Application to Hold Special Aquatic Event, at least 30 days in advance of such event which will take place in city waters and which might in any way interfere with the normal use of said waters by other persons or watercraft. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Sec. 80.25. - Nuisances. 
(A)  Sunken vessels or watercraft, refuse of all kinds, structures or pieces of any structure, dock sweeping, dead fish or parts thereof, dead animals or parts thereof, timber logs, piles, sticks, lumber, boxes, empty containers of all kinds, and oil of any kind floating on the water, and all other substances or articles of any similar nature are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(B)  No person shall throw or place in or cause or permit to be thrown or placed, any of the above named articles or substances in waters of the city or upon the shores thereof or in such a position that it may or can be washed into such waters. 
(C)  Any person causing or permitting nuisances to be placed as aforesaid shall remove the same, and upon his failure to do so, the same may be removed by the city and the expense thereof shall be paid by and recoverable from the person creating the nuisance. 
(D)  In all cases such nuisances may be abated in the manner provided by law. The abatement of any such public nuisances shall not excuse the person responsible therefor from prosecution hereunder. 
(Ord. 21692, passed 6-9-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 80.99. 
Secs. 80.26-80.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 80.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Whoever violates a provision of this chapter or rule or regulation adopted thereunder, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  Whoever violates § 80.07 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor on a first offense; on a violation of a section within one year after the first offense, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree; on each subsequent violation of a section within one year after a violation of either section, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(C)  Whoever violates § 80.08 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
CHAPTER 81. - PARK LANDS 

Sec. 81.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Highway. That portion of public land set aside and maintained by the city as a thoroughfare open to the public for traffic use in connection with the utilization of city park lands. 
    Stop. The halting of a vehicle for whatever period of time or whatever purpose except when necessary to avoid a conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer, security officer, or traffic-control device. 
(Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81) 
Sec. 81.02. - Traffic regulation at city park lands. 
(A)  The Director of Public Works is authorized and directed to promulgate rules and regulations necessary for the regulation and control of traffic at city park lands by erecting traffic-control signals and signs, establishing speed limits, designating parking areas and controlling parking, standing, or stopping vehicles, creating loading zones and safety zones, designating the route of vehicles and by making all other needed rules and regulations for the regulation and control of traffic as aforesaid, not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  All rules and regulations promulgated of this chapter shall be incorporated in the traffic schedule required by § 70.11 within 120 days of issuance. Traffic speeds established and control devices installed shall conform to the requirements of city ordinance, state law, and regulation, and the recommendations of the traffic engineer. 
(C)  The provisions of chapters 70, 71, 72, 73, 74, 75, 76, and this chapter shall apply to all persons and vehicles on or within the city park lands unless specifically modified by the Director of Public Works by published rule or regulation. 
(Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81; Am. Ord. 28830-94, passed 6-8-94) 
Secs. 81.03-81.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 81.99. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be penalized as provided in § 70.99. 
(Ord. 26396, passed 12-9-81)
