    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in damages, however slight the same may appear, to any fire hydrant, shall as soon as possible, and in no event later than 12 hours after such accident, make or cause to be made a written report of the accident at the office of the Director of Fire, or Director of Police, which report shall include his name and address and the registration number of the vehicle he was operating. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Sec. 92.21. - Hydrant use approval. 
    No person shall use or operate any city-owned fire hydrant intended for use of the Fire Department for fire suppression purposes unless such person first secures authorization from the Director of Fire or the Director of the Water Department or their duly authorized representatives. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Sec. 92.22. - Reporting of hydrant damage or impairment. 
    Any person authorized to use a city-owned fire hydrant in accordance with the provisions of § 92.21 shall report to the Director of Fire or the Director of the Water Department, or their duly authorized representatives, any damages or impairments to any city-owned fire hydrant noted or caused during such authorized use immediately upon discovery of the conditions. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 92.23. - Blocking hydrants and Fire Department connections. 
(A)  No person shall obscure from view, damage, deface, obstruct, or restrict the access to any fire hydrant or any Fire Department connection for pressurization of fire suppression systems, including fire hydrants and Fire Department connections that are located on public or private streets and access lanes, or on private property. 
(B)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(C)  If on demand of the fire official, obstructions or encroachments are not removed, the fire official shall proceed to remove the same. Costs incurred in the performance of necessary work shall be paid from the general fund on certificate of the fire official and with the approval of the City Manager, and the City Attorney of the municipality shall institute appropriate action for the recovery of such costs. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 92.24. - Transfer of gasoline. 
    No person shall transfer gasoline from a tank, wagon, truck, or other vehicle to the fuel supply tank of any other motor truck, automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle in any street, alley, or other public way or place by draining it into an open receptacle from which gasoline is then poured into the fuel supply tank of the other motor truck, automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle. However, it shall not be a violation of this section to transfer gasoline from one vehicle to another by means of a hose securely attached to the tank or other receptacle containing the gasoline on the tank, wagon, truck, or other vehicle, which hose is extended therefrom to and enters the fuel tank to which gasoline is being transferred on the other vehicle, and it shall not be a violation hereof to transfer gasoline from one vehicle to another in any public way or place, provided the same is contained in a closed receptacle and is not in excess of one gallon in quantity. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Sec. 92.25. - Smoking in places of public assembly prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall, in any theater, auditorium, gymnasium, tent, or any other place of public assembly, designed and arranged to accommodate 50 or more persons, or in any carpeted hallway leading thereto, smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or match, or use any spark, flame, or fire-producing device not specifically authorized for use in such places by the Director of Fire, or his duly authorized agent, however, the provisions herein shall not apply to designated smoking areas, restrooms, or executive offices located in such places of public assembly. 
(B)  No person shall smoke above any theater stage, backstage, or in any motion picture projection booth. 
(C)  This section shall not apply to restaurants, bars, and nightclubs. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Sec. 92.26. - Smoking in retail stores prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall, in any retail store designed and arranged to accommodate more than 25 persons, or in which more than four persons are employed, smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or match, or use any spark, flame, or fire-producing device not specifically authorized for use in such places by the Director of Fire, or his duly authorized agent, however, the prohibition as herein set forth shall not apply to any designated smoking areas, restrooms, restaurants, executive offices, or beauty parlors located in such retail stores. 
(B)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of acetylene, propane or blow torches, or electric arc welders in construction or remodeling of the premises if proper safety precautions are taken. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Sec. 92.27. - Careless smoking; notice posting. 
(A)  No person shall in any hotel, motel, lodging house, convalescent home, hospital, child care facility, or any similar facility through carelessness, neglect, or negligence in smoking, set fire to or cause burning to any bedding, furniture, rug, curtain, drape, or other household furnishing, or fitting, or any other part of the building or premises. 
(B)  The manager, owner, or lessee of any hotel, motel, or lodging house shall post the provisions of this section in a conspicuous place in each room occupied by guests and the manager, owner, lessee, operator, or administrator of any convalescent home, hospital, child care facility, or any similar facility shall post the provisions of this section in conspicuous places on the premises. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Sec. 92.28. - Maintenance of fire protection equipment. 
    All fire protection systems, devices, units, and service equipment which were installed in compliance with any law, ordinance, or order, shall be maintained in an operative condition at all times, and no person shall reduce the effectiveness of the protection so required; except that this shall not prohibit the owner or occupant from temporarily reducing or discontinuing the protection where necessary to make tests, repairs, alterations, or additions. The fire official shall be notified before disconnection or interruption of protection, and before tests, repairs, alterations, or additions are started and upon their completion, and shall be advised of the extent of and reason for such work. The restoration of the protection shall be diligently pursued. 
(Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.999. 
Secs. 92.29-92.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - APPEAL 

Sec. 92.40. - Right of appeal. 
(A)  Any person aggrieved by a decision or interpretation by the fire official made under the provisions of chapters 46 and 92 of this Code may appeal the decision to the Director and Chief of the Department of Fire. 
(B)  A written notice of appeal must be filed with the Director and Chief of the Department of Fire within 15 days of the date of the notice or order of the fire official. The appeal shall be based on one or both of the following grounds: 
(1)  That the interpretation, filing, or order is erroneous or constitutes an erroneous application of the particular provisions of the Dayton Fire Prevention Code or related laws and ordinances involved, or is otherwise contrary to law. 
(2)  That a modified application or alternative arrangement is available and feasible whereby the strict application of a particular provision or provisions may be modified with the alternatives consistent with the public safety, health and general welfare, purpose and intention of the provisions of the fire code. 
(C)  The hearing shall be conducted by the Director and Chief of the Department of Fire, or his designee. 
(D)  The notice of appeal shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of $25.00. 
(E)  There shall be no right of appeal from the issuance of a minor misdemeanor citation tag pursuant to § 92.13 of this Code. 
(Ord. 25925, passed 2-6-80; Am. Ord. 28423, passed 10-30-91) 
Secs. 92.41-92.109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - FIRE ALARM DETECTION SYSTEMS AND SMOKE DETECTORS 

Sec. 92.110. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 92.110 through 92.121 the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Alarm. Any audible or visible signal indicating existence of a fire or emergency requiring response and emergency action on the part of the fire fighting service. 
    Approved. Means accepted or approved for its intended use by a nationally recognized testing laboratory listed in Appendix A of the Ohio Basic Building Code, 1990 Edition, hereinafter referred to as OBBC. 
    Audible signal. A device capable of producing a noise or sound, either coded or noncoded, or reproducing or conveying the sound of the human voice, for the purpose of warning building occupants of an event of fire. An audible signal may be incorporated into devices used for other purposes (i.e. smoke detector, visible signal, public address speaker). 
    Automatic detecting device. An approved device which automatically detects heat, smoke, or other products of combustion. 
    Automatic fire alarm system. A manual fire alarm system containing automatic detecting device(s) which activates a fire alarm signal of such character and so located as to alert all occupants or inhabitants of the building or section thereof endangered by fire. 
    Business buildings. Includes all buildings or parts thereof, which are used for the transaction of business, or the rendering of professional services, or for other services that involve stocks of goods, wares, or merchandise in limited quantities for use incidental to office uses or sample purposes; including among others, offices, banks, civic administration activities, firehouses, outpatient clinics, and similar establishments. 
    Dwelling unit. A single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation. 
    Factory and industrial buildings. Includes all buildings or structures, or parts thereof, in which occupants are engaged in performing work or labor in the fabricating, assembling, or processing of materials, including, among others, factories, assembling plants, industrial laboratories, and all other industrial manufacturing uses. 
    Fire official. The Director of the Fire Department, or the fire protection engineer, or their duly authorized representatives. 
    Manual fire alarm system. An interior alarm system composed of sending stations and signaling devices in a building, operated on an electric circuit, so arranged that the operation of any one station will initiate an alarm. 
    Mercantile buildings. Includes all buildings or structures, or parts thereof, which are used for displays or sales purposes involving stocks of goods, wares, or merchandise incidental to such purposes and accessible to the public; including, among others, retail stores, shops, salesrooms and markets. 
    Owner. The owner or owners of the premises, contract buyer, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, receiver, executor, administrator, trustee, lessee, or other person, firm, or corporation in control of a building, or their duly authorized agents. Any such person thus representing the owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of §§ 92.111 to 92.121, inclusive, to the same extent as if such person were the owner. 
    Private operating mode. Audible or visible signaling only to persons directly concerned with the implementation and direction of emergency action initiation and procedure in the area protected by the automatic or manual fire alarm system. 
    (Public) assembly buildings. Includes buildings which are used or designed for places of assembly as defined by the 1989 Ohio Basic Building Code, and are classified therein as Assembly-Use Groups: A-1 Structures, A-2 Structures, and A-3 Structures. 
    Public operating mode. Audible or visible signaling to occupants or inhabitants of the area protected by the automatic or manual fire alarm system. 
    Residential buildings. Includes all buildings in which sleeping accommodations are provided for normal residential purposes, and includes all buildings designed to provide sleeping accommodations. For the purposes of §§ 92.110 to 92.121, inclusive, "residential buildings" include the following: 
(1)  Hotels and motels. 
(2)  Apartment buildings, which shall include three-family dwellings and larger. 
(3)  Dormitories. 
(4)  Lodging and rooming houses. 
(5)  One- and two-family dwellings. 
    Smoke detector. An approved detection device, capable of sensing visible or invisible particles of combustion and emitting an audible and/or visual signal of such detection. 
    Sprinkler alarm system. An alarm activated by water flow from an automatic sprinkler system. 
    Visible signal. A device capable of warning building occupants of an event of fire by direct viewing of an illuminated element. Such a device shall produce an intermittent or flashing signal (i.e. a strobe, flashing light, or rotating beacon). 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 27807, passed 9-7-88; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 92.111. - Applicability. 
    All new and existing residential, business, assembly, mercantile, factory, and industrial buildings shall provide fire alarm equipment capable of signaling the presence of a fire and notifying the occupants in danger of the fire. Such protection equipment shall be in accordance with §§ 92.111 to 92.121, inclusive, of this chapter. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84) 
Sec. 92.112. - Responsibility. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner of each new and existing building to comply with the provisions of §§ 92.111 to 92.121, inclusive. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.121. 
Sec. 92.113. - Automatic fire alarm systems required. 
(A)  An automatic fire alarm system shall be installed and maintained in full operating condition in accordance with National Fire Protection Association, Standard 72A 1987 Edition in the following buildings: 
(1)  Buildings having an occupancy of hotel, motel, dormitory, lodging, or rooming house. 
(2)  Buildings having an occupancy or use of business, mercantile, residential, factory, or industrial when more than six stories in height or 75 feet above the lowest level of fire department access. 
(3)  Buildings having an occupancy or use of public assembly and having a use classification of A-1, A-2, or A-3 under the Ohio Basic Building Code and having a posted occupancy load greater than 300 persons. 
(B)  In public assembly buildings having an occupancy load exceeding 1,000 persons, and in all hotels and motels regardless of occupancy capacity, the automatic fire alarm system required by this ordinance shall be electronically monitored by an approved central station, or proprietary monitoring system, in accordance with National Fire Protection Association standards. 
(C)  Lodging or rooming houses with an occupancy of six or less persons shall be deemed to be in compliance with this section if, in lieu of an automatic fire alarm system, there is installed a system consisting of 110 volt powered multiple station detectors on a dedicated circuit, located in each sleeping room, and in the immediate vicinity but outside each sleeping room, and at or near each stairway leading to an occupied area. Each detector in the system shall be so interconnected that when one detector is activated, all shall emit alarms. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 27807, passed 9-7-88; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.121. 
Sec. 92.114. - Exemptions. 
    The following are exempt from the provisions of § 92.113: 
(A)  Buildings, or the portions thereof, that are protected by an approved sprinkler system. 
(B)  Buildings having an occupancy of hotel, motel, dormitory, lodging, or rooming house, in which all rooms exit directly to the outside, and in which no public corridor is provided, and the building is not more than three stories in height. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 92.115. - Manual fire alarm systems required. 
    A manual fire alarm system shall be installed and maintained in full operating condition in accordance with National Fire Protection Association, Standard 72A, 1987 Edition in the following buildings: 
(A)  Buildings having four or more stories of occupancy of apartment use. 
(B)  Buildings having three or more stories of occupancy of business, mercantile or factory and industrial use. 
(C)  Buildings having more than one story of occupancy of public assembly type A-1, A-2, or A-3 use, regardless of occupant load classification. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.121. 
Sec. 92.116. - Automatic and manual fire alarm systems; power supply, signals. 
    All automatic fire alarm systems and manual fire alarm systems required to be installed under the provisions of §§ 92.110 to 92.121, inclusive, shall: 
(A)  Be equipped with both primary and secondary power supplies. 
(1)  The primary power supply shall be from the building 110 Volt AC service. 
(2)  The secondary (standby) power supply shall automatically supply the energy to the system within 30 seconds whenever the primary (main) power supply is incapable of providing the minimum voltage required for proper operation. The secondary (standby) power supply shall not supply energy as long as the primary power supply voltage remains above 85 percent of rated voltage. The secondary (standby) power supply shall be capable of operating the system under maximum normal load for 24 hours and then be capable of operating the system for five minutes in the alarm condition. The secondary (standby) power supply shall consist of one of the following: 
(a)  A storage battery with 24 hours capacity arranged in accordance with 2-3.9., NFPA 72A, 1987 Edition. 
(b)  An engine-driven generator arranged in accordance with section 2-3.8., NFPA 72A, 1987 Edition. 
(B)  Be equipped with both audible and visible signals of fire, located as described below: 
(1)  In places of public assembly: 
(a)  Both audible and visible signals shall be installed throughout; 
(b)  A minimum of one visible signal shall be installed in the direct viewing path of the occupants (that is, adjacent to the stage or screen in theaters); and 
(c)  The private operating mode may be used in places of public assembly with an occupant load greater than 1,000, when additional signals are installed for general evacuation, or a public address and voice evacuation system are provided conforming with NFPA 72F, 1985 Edition. 
(2)  In residential occupancies: 
(a)  A minimum of one audible signal shall be installed in each dwelling unit, sleeping room or guest room; 
(b)  A minimum of one visible signal shall be installed in the dwelling unit, sleeping room or guest room of all hearing impaired occupants, but not less than one unit in each 75, or fraction thereof, shall be so supplied; and 
(c)  Audible and visible signals shall be installed in the public and common areas conforming with § 92.116(C). 
(3)  In all other occupancies audible and visible signals shall be installed conforming with § 92.116(C). 
(C)  Audible and visible signals, required by § 92.116(B), shall be installed as follows, except as modified herein: 
(1)  Audible signals shall be installed to operate as follows: 
(a)  Signals operating in the public mode shall produce an alarm signal through the protected area of not less than 15 dBA above the average ambient noise level. 
(b)  Signals operating in the private mode shall produce an alarm signal in a constantly attended location, staffed by persons responsible for directing or initiating emergency procedures, of not less than ten dBA above the average ambient noise level. 
(2)  Visible signals shall be installed as follows: 
(a)  Not less than 80 inches nor more than 108 inches above the finished floor. 
(b)  Not less than six inches below the ceiling. 
(c)  Not to exceed 100 feet between devices. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 27807, passed 9-7-88; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 92.117. - Smoke detectors required. 
    Single station smoke detectors shall be installed and maintained in full operation in all of the following: 
(A)  Hotels and motels. In each guest room or suite. 
(B)  Lodging or rooming houses. In each guest room or suite. 
(C)  Dormitories. In each sleeping room except where such room is protected by an automatic fire alarm system in accordance with § 92.113 of this Code. 
(D)  Apartments. Shall include three-family dwellings and larger. 
(1)  In the immediate vicinity but outside all sleeping rooms. Alarm signaling devices shall be clearly audible in all bedrooms within the dwelling unit when all intervening doors are closed; and 
(2)  At or near the top of each stairway leading to an occupied area. 
(E)  One- and two-family dwellings. 
(1)  In the immediate vicinity but outside all sleeping rooms. Alarm signaling devices shall be clearly audible in all bedrooms within the dwelling unit when all intervening doors are closed. 
(2)  At or near the top of each stairway leading to an occupied area. 
(F)  Assembly, business, mercantile, factory, and industrial buildings. Where due to the physical arrangement of a building the fire official determines that in consideration of the life safety of the occupants, that at least one detector shall be provided at or near the top of each stairway leading to an occupied area. 
(G)  Standard for installation. The number of all smoke detectors in uses regulated by this section shall be determined exclusively by the provisions of this section, notwithstanding any provision of National Fire Protection Association Standard #74, 1989 Edition to the contrary. The method in which the smoke detectors shall be installed and maintained shall be in conformity with National Fire Protection Association Standard #74, 1989 Edition. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 27807, passed 9-7-88; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.121. 
Sec. 92.118. - Smoke detectors; approval; power supply; new construction; visual and audible signals required. 
(A)  All smoke detectors installed in compliance with §§ 92.110 to 92.121, inclusive, shall be approved by a nationally recognized testing laboratory. 
(B)  All smoke detectors installed in compliance with §§ 92.110 to 92.121, inclusive, shall be powered by the 110 volt AC building electrical system; provided, however, that smoke detectors installed in one- and two-family dwellings that were constructed prior to July 27, 1984 may be approved battery-operated detectors. 
(C)  Where battery-operated smoke detectors are permitted by this section, it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property to install the required detectors, and it shall be the responsibility of the occupant of the property to maintain the battery, so that the detector will be operative at all times. 
(D)  Single station smoke detectors required for buildings with the occupancy use as hotels and motels shall be capable of providing a visual and audible signal of a fire condition. This protection shall not be less than one such detector for each 75 guest rooms in the building. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 27807, passed 9-7-88; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 92.121. 
Sec. 92.119. - Occupancy of nonconforming building prohibited. 
    No owner or other person shall occupy or let or permit to be occupied any building or structure not in compliance with the requirements of §§ 92.110 through 92.121, inclusive. 
(Ord. 27807, passed 9-7-88) 
Sec. 92.120. - Enforcement. 
(A)  Housing and building inspectors are authorized to enforce the applicable sections of this chapter to buildings used wholly or in part for residential purposes, where such inspectors inspect such buildings in the ordinary course of their duties. 
(B)  The Director of Fire, or an authorized designee, is authorized to enforce all sections of this ordinance. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Sec. 92.121. - Penalty. 
    A violation of the provisions of §§ 92.111 to 92.120, inclusive, shall constitute a minor misdemeanor, punishable as provided in § 130.99, of this Code, and each day such violation is continued shall constitute a separate offense. If the offender has previously been convicted of a violation of any of the above sections, then a subsequent violation shall constitute a fourth degree misdemeanor, punishable as provided in § 130.99, and each day such subsequent violation is continued shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 27023, passed 6-27-84; Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
Secs. 92.122-92.129. - Reserved. 
Sec. 92.130. - Definitions. 
    As used in § 92.131, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Alarm. Any audible or visible signal or intelligence indicating existence of a supposed fire, medical, or other emergency requiring response and emergency action on the part of the Fire Department. Also, the alarm devices or device by which fire, medical or other emergency signals are received. 
    Alarm business. The business by any individual, partnership, corporations, or other entity of maintaining, servicing, repairing, or installing any alarm in or on any building, structure, facility or equipment. 
    Alarm user. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure, or facility wherein an alarm system is installed and/or maintained. 
    Medical alarm. A manual emergency alarm system containing a switch, button, pad, or similar device which causes the transmission of a medical emergency device. 
    Nuisance alarm. The activation of an alarm through mechanical failure, electrical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system, or of the owner's or lessee's employees or agents or any other response for which the fire department personnel are unable to determine the apparent cause of the alarm activation. 
(Ord. 30801-08, passed 10-8-08) 
Sec. 92.131. - Excessive nuisance alarms. 
(A)  If any fire or medical alarms produces three nuisance alarms in any 12 consecutive month period, then written notice of that fact shall be given by regular mail, delivery to the alarm user, or via attaching a false alarm warning notice (sticker) to the front of the premises. New alarm installations shall have an exemption period, as determined by the fire code official, but shall not exceed 90 days. 
(B)  An alarm causing a nuisance alarm shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The alarm shall be serviced by an Ohio qualified or certified fire alarm contractor. If more than three nuisance alarms are received, in addition to a fee, the alarm shall be reviewed by the Dayton Fire Director and/or the Dayton Fire Prevention Bureau. 
(2)  Upon the third nuisance alarm produced by any alarm within any 12 consecutive month period, the subscriber will have committed a civil offense and be liable for a fine specified in § 61.99. Upon the fourth nuisance alarm, and each nuisance alarm thereafter, produced by any alarm system within any 12 consecutive month period, the subscriber shall be deemed a repeat offender and is liable for twice the civil fine in accordance with §§ 61.02(B) and 61.99. 
(3)  The alarm user of an alarm, other than an alarm required per the Ohio Building Code may be required by the Fire Department to disconnect a nuisance alarm immediately in such fashion that signals are not transmitted so as to notify the Fire Department either directly or indirectly. 
(a)  Any alarm user who fails to disconnect as required above shall be deemed to be in violation of this Code. 
(b)  An alarm may be reconnected only if satisfactory evidence is provided to the Bureau of Fire Prevention that the alarm system has been repaired so that it does not emit further nuisance alarms and upon payment of all delinquent charges assessed for nuisance alarms. 
(Ord. 30801-08, passed 10-8-08) 
Secs. 92.132-92.998. - Reserved. 
Sec. 92.999. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter for which a penalty is not otherwise specifically provided shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense, and for each subsequent offense of the same section of this chapter, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(B)  Each day that a violation continues after the service of a citation tag or notice, as provided in chapter 92 of this Code, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(C)  In addition, in case of fire resulting directly or indirectly from any omission or neglect to properly comply with the lawful written order of the Director of Fire as provided in §§ 92.01 through 92.26 (unless the order has been appealed from and until the appeal has been disposed of), the person or persons named in the order shall be liable in a civil action for the payment of all costs and expenses of the Department of Fire incurred in and about the use of employees, apparatus, and materials in the extinguishment of any fire resulting from such cause, the amount of such costs and expenses to be fixed by the City Manager, and when collected to be paid into the general fund. 
(Am. Ord. 28561, passed 7-1-92) 
CHAPTER 93. - HOUSING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 93.01. - Citation of chapter. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Housing Ordinance. 
Sec. 93.011. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to every building and its premises which may be used in whole or in part for residential purposes. 
(Ord. 29187-96, passed 3-20-96) 
Sec. 93.02. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively. Where terms are not defined herein and are defined in the uniform building code or zoning code, they shall have the meaning ascribed to them as in either the Unified Building Code or the Zoning Code, Chapters 152 and 150 respectively: 
    Accessory structure. A building or structure the use of which is incidental to that of the main building or structure and which is located on the same lot. 
    Apartment. A dwelling unit. 
    Approved. Accepted as satisfactory by the Superintendent of Business Services pursuant to the Uniform Building Code, by the City Engineer pursuant to applicable construction standards, by the Superintendent, Division of Administration of the Fire Department, pursuant to statutes and local fire ordinances, by the health officer, pursuant to the state health code and local health regulations, or by the Superintendent of Neighborhood Development, pursuant to rehabilitation requirements for federally assisted urban renewal and code enforcement project areas. 
    Basement. A portion of the building partly underground, but having less than one-half its clear height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. A basement which is used for a use other than storage shall be considered a story. 
    Bathroom, complete. A room or rooms affording privacy equipped with a flush water closet, lavatory and bathtub or shower in good working condition and properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
    Ceiling. The surface suspended from or attached to the underside of floors or roofs which does not form a structural part of a floor or roof or shall mean the underside of exposed floor or roof construction. 
    Ceiling height. The clear distance between the floor and the ceiling directly above. 
    Cellar. A portion of a building located partly or wholly underground and having one-half or more than one-half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Dwelling. Any building or structure, or part thereof, except a trailer as defined in § 112.220, which contains dwelling and/or rooming units. 
    Dwelling unit. Any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single family habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, storing food or eating purposes, commonly known as an apartment. 
    Exit, in general. The way out from any point in a building along continuous and unobstructed line of travel which leads to a street or open space or court communicating with a street or other public thoroughfare. 
    Extermination. The control and elimination of insects, rodents, or other pests by eliminating their harborage places, by removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food, by poisoning, spraying, fumigating or trapping, by blocking their access to a dwelling, or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by a health officer. 
    First story. The one whose floor is not more than five feet above the average level of ground surrounding the building. 
    Garage. A structure which was originally constructed or which was, at any time, used or equipped for use as a fully enclosed housing for a motor vehicle or carriage. 
    Garbage. Putrescible wastes, including every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, used or intended for food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
    Habitable room. A room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, toilet rooms, laundries, pantries, foyers or communicating corridors, storage rooms, laundry and utility rooms or spaces in attics, basement or cellars. 
    Housing inspector. The Superintendent of the Division of Neighborhood Development of the Department of Urban Development of the city or his or her authorized representatives. 
    Housing ordinance. This chapter and all amendments thereto. 
    Infestation. The presence, within or around a dwelling or in or near waste disposal containers, of any insects, rodents, or other pests. 
    Maintenance. The servicing, repairing, or altering of any building, structure, appliance, apparatus, or equipment to perpetuate the use or purpose for which such building, structure, appliance, apparatus, or equipment was originally intended. 
    Multifamily dwelling. Any dwelling containing three or more dwelling units. 
    Occupant. Any person living, sleeping, cooking or eating in or having possession or use of a dwelling unit or rooming unit. 
    Operator. Any legally responsible person who has charge, care or control of a building, or part thereof, in which dwelling units or rooming units are leased or let or offered for occupancy, and shall include a lessee, sublessee, any vendee in possession, or any other person otherwise managing or operating such building or part thereof. 
    Owner. The owner or owners of the deed or freehold of the premises or lesser estate therein, contract buyer, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, administrator, trustee, lessee, or other person, firm, or corporation in control of a building; or their duly authorized agents. Any such person thus representing the owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of this chapter to the same extent as if he were the owner. 
    Plumbing. All of the following supplied facilities and equipment: water pipes, mechanical garbage disposal units, waste pipes, water closets, sinks, installed dishwashers, and clothes washing machines, lavatories, bathtubs, shower baths, catch basins, drains, vents, and any other similar supplied fixture including all connections to water or sewer lines. 
    Premises. A lot, plot, or parcel of land, including the building or structure thereon or any part thereof, and adjacent land occupied by public rights-of-way, to the median point between adjoining properties, except boulevard or roadway medians, which will not be the responsibility of the owner or occupant. 
    Rooming house. Any dwelling or dwelling unit containing one or more rooming units, with no more than four roomers in any one rooming unit, which may include common cooking, food storage and/or eating facilities not located within the rooming unit in which space is let for compensation by the resident owner or resident operator to three or more persons, none of whom are related to the owner or operator by blood or marriage; but not including a hotel, rest, convalescent or nursing home. Dwellings in which space is let to two or less persons shall not be deemed a rooming house nor shall hotels licensed under R.C. § 3731.01, et seq. Institutional dormitories or buildings or portions of buildings designed, arranged, intended, maintained for or occupied by 50 or more persons which are let for occupancy by religious, benevolent, charitable or other nonprofit organizations shall not be deemed a rooming house. 
    Rooming unit. Any room or group of rooms in a rooming house, dwelling or dwelling unit forming a single habitable unit for no more than four persons used or intended for use for living or sleeping but does not include facilities for cooking or sorting food or eating purposes. 
    Supplied. Paid for, arranged for, furnished, or provided by or under control of the owner or operator. 
    Toilet room. A room affording privacy equipped with a flush water closet or urinal and a lavatory basin in good working condition and properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
    Trash. All combustible and noncombustible waste material, except garbage. 
    Waste containers. Any containers having handles and close-fitting lids, with a capacity of not less than ten gallons, nor more than 32 gallons, or containers provided by the city for semi-automated or automated waste collection, or as otherwise specified by the Director of Public Works. Plastic containers must resist fracturing at temperatures of 32°F. or lower. Use of quality plastic bags that are not torn or ripped is acceptable, such bags to be presented at the curb or alley on collection day only. Baskets, wooden or cardboard boxes, crates, paper bags, except for newsprint to be recycled, sacks, paper mache barrels, or wood or steel barrels are not acceptable waste containers. No container shall weigh more than 75 pounds filled. 
    Waste. All trash, rubbish, garbage, and other refuse or discarded material required to be removed from private or public places, exclusive of recyclables or recyclable materials, recognized industrial by-products, or any highly explosive material, or any poisonous substance whatsoever. 
(Ord. 18603, passed 11-28-56; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68; Am. Ord. 25739, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 28963-94, passed 12-14-94) 
Sec. 93.03. - Rules and regulations. 
    The Superintendent of Housing Conservation is authorized to make and adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the proper enforcement of the provisions of this chapter provided that such rules and regulations shall not be in conflict with the provisions or intent of this chapter. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Sec. 93.04. - Entry and inspection of dwellings. 
(A)  Subject to applicable provisions of law, the housing inspector in enforcing provisions of the housing code, is authorized to enter any structure or premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections and performing duties under this Code. 
(B)  If permission cannot be obtained, or if for any other reason an inspector is unable to enter or obtain free access to a structure for the purpose of inspection, the inspector may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an appropriate warrant or other court order, or the inspector may make the inspection in any other manner authorized by law. 
(C)  Every occupant of a dwelling shall give the owner thereof or his agent or employee access to any part of such dwelling or its premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter or any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(D)  No officer, agent, or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this chapter. Any suit brought against any officer, agent, or employee of the city as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this chapter shall be defended by the City Attorney until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(E)  Inspections are made by the city solely for the public purpose of enforcing the ordinances of the city. No representation is made that any order issued pursuant to this chapter contains a complete list of all violations which exist on the premises, nor shall the city accept any responsibility whatsoever to any person, firm, or corporation for any damage done or injury suffered as a result of poor workmanship or unserviceability of any work done or materials used pursuant to such order, or as a result of the failure of any person, firm, or corporation to correct the violations listed therein, or for any reason whatsoever. All owners, occupants, invitees, guests, or other persons using any premises which are subject to the provisions of this chapter shall do so at their own risk, without remedy against the city, its officers, agents, or employees. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 26847, passed 7-27-83) 
Sec. 93.05. - Notice of violations. 
(A)  Whenever the housing inspector determines that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, except violations of § 93.04, violations of §§ 93.60 through 93.69, and except where a housing violation citation tag has been issued pursuant to § 93.051, he shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible therefor and order compliance with this chapter as hereinafter provided. Such notice and order shall: 
(1)  Be put in writing on an appropriate form; 
(2)  Include a list of violations, refer to the section or sections of this chapter violated and order remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter; 
(3)  Specify a reasonable time for performance; 
(4)  Advise the owner, operator, or occupant of the procedure for appeal, except emergency orders issued pursuant to § 93.09. 
(5)  Be served on the owner, occupant, or agent in person. However, this notice and order shall be deemed to be properly served upon the owner, occupant, or agent if a copy thereof is sent by registered or certified mail to his last known mailing address, residence, or place of business, and a copy is posted in a conspicuous place in or on the dwelling affected. If a registered or certified mail envelope is returned with an endorsement showing that service was refused, the notice may be served by ordinary mail to his last known mailing address, residence, or place of business. The mailing shall be evidenced by a certificate of mailing, and service shall be deemed complete on the date of mailing. If the registered or certified mail envelope is returned with an endorsement showing that service was unclaimed, the notice may be served by ordinary mail to his last known mailing address, residence, or place of business. The mailing shall be evidenced by a certificate of mailing, and service shall be deemed complete on the date of mailing, provided that the ordinary mail envelope is not returned by the postal authorities with an endorsement showing failure of delivery. 
(a)  The notice and order may, in the alternative, be served by leaving it at his last known residence or place of business in the presence of a family member or other responsible person of suitable age and discretion who shall be informed of the general nature of the contents thereof. 
(b)  If service is not accomplished by any of the above means, then a notification of the existence of the notice and order may be published at least once in a local newspaper of general circulation. 
(B)  Any person failing to comply with the order served pursuant to this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68; Am. Ord. 25739, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 27256, passed 9-18-85) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.05.1. - Housing violation citation tags. 
    The Superintendent of Inspectional Services is authorized and directed to provide housing inspectors with citation tags which may be used for the purpose of giving due notice and summons to the person responsible, for violations of § 93.46(B), (C), (D), or (E), or for violations of § 93.47(A), (B), or (C). 
(A)  Such citation tag shall be put in writing on an appropriate form, describe the offense charged, refer to the section of the chapter violated, order the defendant to appear at a stated time and place, and it shall be made on oath before any person authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(B)  The citation tag shall be served on such person in accordance with the provisions of § 93.05(A)(5). 
(C)  The citation tag shall inform the defendant that, in lieu of appearing at the time and place stated, he may, within that stated time, appear personally at the office of the Clerk of Court and on signing a plea of guilty and a waiver of trial pay a stated fine and stated costs, if any. The citation shall inform the defendant that he may be arrested if he fails to appear either at the clerk's office or at the time and place stated in the citation. 
(D)  When the defendant fails to appear within the stated time, a warrant may be issued for the arrest of that person. 
(E)  When a defendant appears, but does not sign a guilty plea and waiver of trial, the court shall proceed in accordance with Rule 5 of the Ohio Rules of Criminal Procedure. 
(F)  The citation tag as herein provided, shall be sufficient notice, summons, and legal service thereof for the purpose specified thereon, provided that the use of such tags shall not prohibit the issuance of either additional citation tags or a legal notice of violation as provided by § 93.05, in the event such violation is continued or repeated. 
(Ord. 25739, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 26371, passed 11-4-81) 
Sec. 93.05.2. - Duty to timely remediate and enforcement costs. 
(A)  A person served with a notice of violation pursuant to § 93.05 shall: 
(1)  Remediate the violations listed therein within the time specified in the notice, or any extension of time granted in writing by the Housing Inspector, or the Housing Appeals Board; and 
(2)  Schedule and pass a final inspection with the Housing Inspector verifying compliance with the notice of violation. 
The final inspection required by (A)(2) of this section is in addition to any other inspections required by law for work performed in remediating the violations listed in the notice of violation. 
(B)  Except as hereinafter provided, and in addition to other requirements or penalties imposed by law, a person who fails to comply with paragraph (A)(1) and (A)(2) of this section shall pay all administrative and other costs incurred by the city in remediating, or causing the remediation of, the violations listed in the notice of violation served upon the person. These costs include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  A fee of $75.00 for each reinspection; 
(2)  Boarding and securing costs; 
(3)  Repair, removal or demolition costs; and 
(4)  Any other costs reasonably related to remediating, or causing the remediation of, the hazardous or unsafe condition created by any unremediated violation. 
(C)  Each notice of violation issued pursuant to § 93.05 shall include the following wording: 
It is the responsibility of the person served with this notice of violation to timely remediate the violation(s) listed in this notice and to schedule a final inspection by the City's Housing Inspector to verify compliance with this notice. This final inspection is in addition to any other inspections required by law for work performed in remediating the violations listed in this notice. Failure to timely remediate the violation(s) listed in this notice, and/or to schedule and pass a final inspection may subject you to administrative and other costs incurred by the city in remediating, or causing the remediation of, the violations listed in the notice of violation served upon the person. These costs include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  A fee of $75.00 for each reinspection; 
(2)  Boarding and securing costs; 
(3)  Repair, removal or demolition costs; and 
(4)  Any other costs reasonably related to remediating, or causing the remediation of, the hazardous or unsafe condition created by any unremediated violation. 
(D)  The City's Housing Inspector may reinspect property monthly until all violations are corrected or more frequently, but not more than once weekly, as needed to enforce emergency orders or to abate a nuisance caused by a dangerous dwelling. 
(E)  Upon written application, the City's Housing Inspector may suspend, reduce, or waive costs charged pursuant to this section which impose an undue financial hardship; result from noncompliance caused by climatic conditions; or for other good cause shown to the reasonable satisfaction of the Housing Inspector. Any such suspension, reduction or waiver is subject to reasonable conditions imposed by the Housing Inspector. Failure to fully meet such conditions shall result in all such charges being reimposed. 
(F)  The city shall bill any person responsible for costs imposed by this section and may thereafter collect or assess all such costs in any manner authorized by law. 
(G)  Any person aggrieved by a decision made by the Housing Inspector pursuant to this section may appeal that decision to the Housing Appeals Board. 
(Ord. 30563-06, passed 5-31-06) 
Sec. 93.06. - Hearings. 
(A)  Any person affected by any notice and order, revocation, or denial or permit which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of the housing chapter and authorized herein may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Housing Appeals Board provided that such person shall file in the office of the housing inspector a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth the name, address, and phone number of the petitioner and a brief statement of the grounds for such hearing or for the mitigation of any item appearing on any order of the housing inspector. Petition shall be filed within ten days after the date of the notice and order, revocation, or denial of permit. On receipt of such a petition, the housing inspector shall set a time and place for hearing before the Housing Appeals Board and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. The hearings shall be commenced within a reasonable time after a petition has been filed. At such hearing the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why any item appearing on such notice and order should be modified or withdrawn. The failure of the petitioner or his representative to appear and state his case at such hearing shall have the same effect as if no petition were filed. 
(B)  After a hearing, the Housing Appeals Board shall sustain, modify, or withdraw any item appearing on the notice and order by majority vote, depending on its findings as to whether the provisions of this chapter have been complied with, and the petitioner and the housing inspector shall be notified in writing of such findings. 
(C)  When any item appearing on a notice and order relating to a licensed rooming house has been modified or sustained by the Housing Appeals Board after a hearing, the permit shall be revoked if compliance is not effected within the time period specified for any item appearing on such notice and order or as determined by the Housing Appeals Board. 
(D)  The proceedings at such hearings, including the findings and decision of the Housing Appeals Board and reasons therefor shall be summarized and reduced to writing and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the housing inspector. Such record shall also include a copy of every notice and order issued in connection with the matter. 
(E)  The provisions herein shall not be effective in the case where a housing violators citation tag has been issued, pursuant to § 93.051, by those responsible for the enforcement of §§ 93.02 through 93.99. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 24215, passed 2-16-72; Am. Ord. 25739, passed 4-18-79) 
Sec. 93.07. - Housing Appeals Board created; membership. 
    There is created a Housing Appeals Board to conduct hearings authorized by this chapter. The Appeals Board shall: 
(A)  Be composed of five members to be appointed by the City Commission for a term of three years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. To be eligible for appointment to the Board, a person shall be a citizen of the United States and resident of the city. 
(B)  Adopt rules of procedure not inconsistent with this chapter and elect officers as the Board sees fit. No member of the Board shall take part in any hearing or determination in which he has a personal or financial interest. Three members of the Board in attendance at any meeting shall constitute a quorum. 
(C)  Interpret the intent of this chapter in specific cases where, upon appeal, it clearly appears that, by reason of special conditions, undue hardship would result from a literal application of any section of this chapter. Where such undue hardship is clearly demonstrated, the Board may permit a variance from the applicable section if the dwelling will vary only a reasonable minimum from the literal provision of this chapter, but will comply with the spirit and intent of the chapter with respect to sanitation, safety, and rehabilitation. All decisions to permit a variance under this section shall be by a majority vote of the total membership of the Board. 
(D)  Approve the issuance of vouchers to eligible low and moderate income homeowners to obtain paint products from vendors under contract with the city. The vouchers are conditioned upon the homeowners making agreed upon improvements to their residences, which improvements conform to the requirements of this chapter and benefit housing within the city. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68; Am. Ord. 29969-01, passed 5-23-01) 
Sec. 93.08. - Vacation of structures. 
    Where a notice of violation and order to comply has been served pursuant to § 93.05, and, upon reinspection at the end of the time specified for compliance, or any extension thereof granted in writing by the Housing Appeals Board, it is found that the violation or violations have not been remedied, the housing inspector may order the dwelling, or parts thereof affected by the continued violation(s), vacated in accordance with the following procedure: 
(A)  Dwellings shall be vacated within a reasonable time as may be prescribed by the housing inspector, with due regard given to the health, safety and general welfare of the occupants and of the public, as well as the preservation of the property; 
(B)  Vacated dwellings and accessory structures (hereinafter referred to in this section as "structures") shall have all outer doors securely locked or boarded, and basement, cellar and first story windows securely barred, locked, or boarded to prevent entry by persons or animals, and to make them weathertight. Cistern covers shall be securely affixed; 
(C)  Any vacated and unsecured structure is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, regardless of whether it was vacated pursuant to any order of the housing inspector, or by the voluntary action or sufferance of the property owner, and the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee may cause a vacant and unsecured structure to be immediately secured whenever it is found open to entry at doors, windows, or other points accessible to persons or animals. The Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee shall be authorized at any time to enter on the premises to secure the structure, and the owner shall permit such entry. In securing the structure, the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee may call on any department, division, or bureau of the city for whatever assistance may be necessary, or may, by private contract, secure the structure. Photographs or electronically recorded images of the structure shall be taken prior to securing it, and those photographs and/or images shall be filed with the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee; 
(D)  Either before, or as soon as practicable after the securing of a vacant structure, the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee shall cause a written notice to be served on the owner in the manner provided in § 93.05(A)(5). The notice shall inform the owner of the date on which the structure was found open to entry and of the securing of the structure, and shall advise the owner that the costs incurred in securing the structure shall be recovered by the city in the manner prescribed by § 93.08(I), and that the owner has a right to appeal the said notice to the Housing Appeals Board by making a demand therefor in writing to the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager within ten days after receipt of the notice. 
(E)  Vacated structures shall not again be used for human habitation or occupancy until written approval is secured from the housing inspector. 
(F)  The Housing Appeals Board may: 
(1)  Sustain the action of the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee; or 
(2)  Find that the action of the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee was unsupported by the facts, or unreasonable. 
(G)  If the Housing Appeals Board does not sustain the action of the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee, the costs incurred in securing the structure shall be paid from the city funds specifically authorized by the City Commission to be used for such purpose. 
(H)  Buildings, structures, dwellings, or dwelling units, or premises which are secured or boarded by the order of the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee shall have a placard and/or stencil applied to them which reads "Presence on these premises prohibited without written consent of the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager," and no owner or other person shall enter or be present in or on any building or premises that has been posted in this manner without first having obtained authorization in writing from the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manger and/or his/her designee, and having such written authorization on his/her person at the time. 
(I)  Except as provided in subsection (G) of this section, the cost of securing any structure in the manner hereinabove provided shall be recovered in the following manner: 
(1)  The owner or owners shall be billed directly by certified mail for the cost of securing or boarding the structure or premises. The bill for the cost thereof shall be paid within 60 days after receipt of the bill. 
(2)  If the costs are not so recovered, the city may collect the costs by any of the following methods: 
(a)  The city may cause the costs of securing or boarding such structure to be levied as an assessment and recovered in accordance with R.C. § 715.261. 
(b)  The city may commence a civil action to recover the costs from the owner, as provided in R.C. § 715.261. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68; Am. Ord. 29187-96, passed 3-20-96) 
Sec. 93.08.1. - Unauthorized entry upon placarded premises. 
(A)  No owner or other person shall enter or be present in or on any building, structure, dwelling, dwelling unit, or premises that has been posted with a notice identifying them as a public nuisance, without first obtaining written authorization from the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee, and having such written authorization on his/her person at the time. 
(B)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation of this section that the person was the owner, or was authorized by the owner to be present on the said premises, and that one of the persons present had the required written authorization referred to in subsection (A) above, on his/her person at the time. 
(C)  The officers, agents and employees of the city, state or federal government, or any political subdivision, or of any public utility, shall be exempt from the requirements of this section while in the course of their employment. 
(D)  Written authorization, as provided in this section, shall be issued by the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager to any person who provides documentation which, on its face, indicates that such person is either an owner of the premises or is authorized by the owner to be present, or to any person who makes application and pays for any permit to do work on the premises. 
(E)  Written authorization, as provided in this section, shall not be issued in connection with any property which has been declared a public nuisance as provided in § 152.04(B), unless all parties have complied with all applicable requirements of § 152.061. 
(F)  The issuance of an authorization provided herein shall not be construed to create a privilege, as that term is used in R.C. § 2911.21 or § 133.05, nor shall this section be deemed to have any affect whatsoever on the interpretations or application of those sections. 
(G)  No person shall deface or remove the notice or placard from any building, structure, dwelling, dwelling unit, or premises which has been posted with a notice identifying them as a public nuisance without first obtaining the written authorization of the Code Enforcement and Rehabilitation Manager and/or his/her designee. Written authorization may be given after the owner or his/her agent has made adequate provision for securing the building, structure, dwelling, dwelling unit, or premises, thereby preventing it from again becoming a public nuisance. 
(Ord. 29187-96, passed 3-20-96) 
Sec. 93.09. - Emergency orders. 
    Whenever the housing inspector finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the health and safety of the residents or of the public, he shall proceed forthwith to issue an order reciting the existence of the emergency and order such remedial action necessary to meet the emergency. If necessary to protect the health and safety of the residents of the public health or safety, the housing inspector shall order that the premises be vacated forthwith and further that they shall not be reoccupied until the order is complied with or executed. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter any such order or orders shall be effective immediately and complied with in the time and manner prescribed in the emergency order. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Sec. 93.10. - Rooming house permit required. 
    No person shall operate a rooming house unless he has a valid rooming house permit issued by the housing inspector in the name of the operator for the specific rooming house. The operator shall apply to the housing inspector for such permit submitting the required form and paying the required fee. The permit shall be issued by the housing inspector as soon as feasible after he has an opportunity to determine that the rooming house complies with the applicable provisions of this chapter. This permit shall be protected and displayed in a conspicuous place within the rooming house at all times and shall state the maximum occupancy permitted under the provisions of this chapter. Every person holding such a permit shall return such permit to the housing inspector within ten days after having sold, transferred, given away, or otherwise disposed of the ownership, interest, control, or operation of any rooming house. Every rooming house permit shall expire at the end of one year following the date of issuance unless sooner revoked as hereinafter provided. Upon application therefor, a rooming house permit may be reissued to another operator without charge. No permit shall be transferable from one rooming house to another. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.11. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for a rooming house permit as required by § 93.10 shall be $125.00 plus $10.00 for each sleeping room in excess of three. If the annual inspection of a rooming house results in a legal order for violations, the fee for each additional inspection to confirm compliance shall be $75.00. The permit fee and any reinspection fee shall be paid prior to issuance of a permit. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68; Am. Ord. 30094-02, passed 5-1-02; Am. Ord. 30822-09, § 1, passed 1-7-09) 
Sec. 93.12. - Denial of permit. 
    Any person whose application for a permit has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter pursuant to § 93.06. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65) 
Sec. 93.13. - Rooming or boarding house violations. 
    Whenever, upon inspection of any rooming or boarding house, the housing inspector finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this chapter, the housing inspector shall give notice in writing to the operator of such rooming or boarding house pursuant to § 93.05. At the end of the time period specified in the notice, the housing inspector shall reinspect the rooming or boarding house and if he finds that such conditions or practices have not been corrected and if no petition for hearing has been filed, he shall give notice in writing to the operator and owner that the permit has been revoked. Upon receipt of such notice the operator shall immediately cease operation of such rooming or boarding house and no person shall let for occupancy or occupy for sleeping or living purposes any rooming unit therein. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 21766, passed 8-25-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.14. - Revocation of permit; request for hearing. 
    Any person who has received notice that his permit is to be revoked unless existing conditions or practices at the rooming or boarding house are corrected, may within ten days after the date of such notice, request and shall be granted a hearing upon the matter pursuant to § 93.06. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Sec. 93.15. - Dangerous dwellings defined. 
    All dwellings or parts thereof which have any of the following defects shall be deemed "dangerous dwellings" and shall be condemned as unfit for human habitation: 
(A)  Those whose interior or exterior bearing walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such an extent as to weaken the structural support it provides; 
(B)  Those which, exclusive of the foundation, show approximately one-third or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting member or members, or approximately one-half or more of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering; 
(C)  Those which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs or in which the same are overloaded, or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used; 
(D)  Those which have been damaged by fire, wind, or other causes so as to no longer provide shelter from the elements and have become dangerous to life, safety, or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the city; 
(E)  Those which have become or are dilapidated, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary or vermin infested or which are likely to cause sickness or disease, or injury to the health, safety, or general welfare of those living therein or of the people at large; 
(F)  Those lacking light, air, sanitation, or other mechanical facilities as required by this chapter to protect the health, safety, or general welfare of human beings who live or may live therein; 
(G)  Those lacking facilities required by this chapter for egress in case of fire or panic or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes, or other means of communication required herein; 
(H)  Those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall and injure occupants or the public or property. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Sec. 93.16. - Declaration of nuisance and orders. 
    All dangerous dwellings or parts thereof within the terms of § 93.15, are declared to be public nuisances, and shall be vacated and repaired as hereinafter provided: 
(A)  If the dangerous dwelling is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health, safety, or general welfare of its occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated and shall be vacated in accordance with the provisions of § 93.08, and shall not be occupied after vacation until approval is given in writing by the housing inspector; 
(B)  If the dangerous dwelling is vacated and not repaired by the owner as ordered by the housing inspector, the housing inspector shall cause such repairs to be made in accordance with the provisions of § 93.18, or shall refer the dangerous dwelling to the Superintendent of the Division of Building Inspection for processing in accordance with the provisions of §§ 152.10 to 152.16. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.17. - Dangerous dwelling placarded; condemned. 
    Whenever the housing inspector determines that a dwelling is a dangerous dwelling, as defined in § 93.15, he shall: 
(A)  Affix to the dwelling or portion thereof, upon the door or entrance thereto, a placard on which shall be printed a declaration that the dwelling or portion thereof is unfit for human habitation and ordered vacated. No person shall deface or remove the placard from any dwelling or part thereof which has been condemned as unfit for human habitation and placarded as such. The housing inspector shall remove such placard whenever the defect or defects upon which the condemnation and placarding section were based have been eliminated; 
(B)  Serve the notice and order pursuant to § 93.05, on the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, and other person having an interest in the building, as shown by the records of the county recorder of any building found by him to be a dangerous building within the standards set forth in § 93.15, that: 
(1)  The owner must vacate and repair said building in accordance with the terms of the notice and this chapter; 
(2)  The occupant or lessee must vacate said building or, with the consent of the owner, may have it repaired in accordance with the notice and order and remain in possession; 
(3)  The mortgagee, or other persons having an interest in the building, as shown by the land records of the county recorder may, at his own risk, vacate and repair said building or have such work done. 
(C)  Service of the notice shall be made in accordance with § 93.05. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.18. - Vacation and repair of dwellings. 
    If the owner, occupant, mortgagee, or lessee fails to comply with the order of the housing inspector provided for in § 93.17, or the ruling of the Housing Appeals Board after hearing, where a hearing has been requested, the housing inspector shall cause the dwelling or part thereof to be vacated and may cause it to be repaired if the facts indicate that any delay will be dangerous to the health, safety, or general welfare of the people and shall cause the costs of such repair to be charged against the land on which the building exists as a municipal lien or to be recovered in a civil suit against the owner. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.19. - Emergency vacation and repair. 
    In cases where it reasonably appears that there is immediate danger to the life or safety of any person unless a dangerous dwelling is immediately vacated and/or repaired by the owner in accordance with the order issued pursuant to § 93.09, the housing inspector shall cause the immediate vacation and/or repair of the dangerous dwelling. The costs of such emergency repair of the dangerous dwelling caused by the housing inspector shall be charged or recovered in the same manner as provided in § 93.18. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Sec. 93.20. - Occupation of nonconforming dwelling prohibited. 
    No owner or other person shall occupy or let or permit to be occupied or let by another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house, or rooming unit for the purpose of living, cooking, eating, or sleeping therein which does not comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.21. - Kitchen equipment and facilities for dwellings. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain a room or portion of a room in which food may be stored, prepared, and/or cooked and consumed and which shall be equipped with the following: 
(A)  A kitchen sink in good working condition which shall be connected to both hot and cold water lines and to an approved water and sewer system. A lavatory basin shall not be considered a kitchen sink; 
(B)  Cabinets and/or shelves for the storage of eating, drinking and cooking equipment and utensils and of food that does not require refrigeration for safekeeping. These cabinets and/or shelves shall be adequate for the permissible occupancy of the dwelling unit and shall be of sound construction finished with surfaces that are easily cleanable and that will not impart any toxic or deleterious effect to food; 
(C)  A stove, range, or similar device for cooking food, properly installed with all necessary connections for safe and efficient operation. However, the stove, range, or similar device need not be installed when the dwelling is not occupied. The use of gasoline stoves or similar fuel burning appliances using highly flammable fuels and the use of portable kerosene stoves or other similar fuel burning portable appliances for cooking is prohibited; 
(D)  A refrigerator or similar device, for the safe storage of food at a temperature less than 45°F, but more than 32°F, properly installed with all necessary connections for safe, sanitary, and efficient operation; provided, that such refrigeration or similar equipment need not be installed when the dwelling is not occupied. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.22. - Flush water closet, lavatory basin, and bathtub or shower in dwellings other than rooming houses. 
(A)  Every dwelling unit shall contain a room or rooms affording privacy and equipped with a flush water closet properly connected to a cold water line, a lavatory basin, and a bathtub or shower properly connected to both hot and cold water lines with each of the facilities properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
(B)  A toilet room may be located within a different room from wherein the bathtub or shower facility is located. A flush urinal may not be substituted for a flush water closet. Such required sanitary facilities shall not be located in a basement or cellar. 
(Ord. 18099, passed 11-10-54; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.23. - Bathrooms in buildings containing dwellings and business. 
    No bathroom shall be shared by the occupants of a dwelling unit and business establishment unless the business is operated entirely by the occupants. Otherwise the business establishment shall be provided with separate sanitary facilities as required by Chapter 152 the Uniform Building Code of the city. 
(Ord. 21766, passed 8-25-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.24. - Flush water closet, lavatory basin, and bathtub or shower in rooming houses. 
    There shall be at least one flush water closet properly connected to a cold water line, one lavatory basin and one bathtub or shower properly connected to both hot and cold water lines with each of the facilities properly connected to an approved water and sewer system and in good working condition within every rooming house for each six persons or fraction thereof, including members of the operator's family, except that in a rooming house where rooms are let only to males, flush urinals connected to cold water lines and an approved water and sewer system and in good working condition may be substituted for not more than one-half the number of required water closets. A toilet room may be located in a different room from wherein the bathtub or shower facility is located. Such required sanitary facilities shall not be located in a basement or cellar. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.25. - Type of flush water closets. 
    No water closet shall be of the flush hopper, frostproof hopper, or similar type nor shall privies be permitted. Flush hopper or frostproof type water closets which are removed or ordered removed shall have the sewer and water line capped in an approved manner. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.26. - Access to bathrooms and toilet rooms. 
    No dwelling or rooming house shall be so arranged that access to a bathroom or toilet room requires passage through a sleeping room, bathroom, or toilet room of another dwelling unit or rooming unit. Bathrooms or toilet rooms are to be located so that all travel thereto from each occupied room is through an enclosed area or areas. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.27. - Floors of kitchens, bathrooms, and toilet rooms. 
    Every kitchen, bathroom, and toilet room floor surface shall be constructed so as to be reasonably impervious to water and so as to be maintained in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(Ord. 21788, passed 9-22-65; Am. Ord. 23095, passed 8-28-68) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 93.99. 
Sec. 93.28. - Ventilation of bathrooms and toilet rooms.
