No person shall cause or permit noise levels from the operation of a stationary noise device or from any other source in excess of 55 dB(A) in any areas or districts of the city that are zoned residential, office-residential, and university in the zoning code between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or in excess of 61 dB(A) in any such areas or districts between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. All noise measurements shall be made on the property line where the noise originates. 
(C)  In any criminal prosecution for a violation of this section the court may admit evidence of a noise level as tested by any sound level meter which meets or exceeds the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) specifications for Type II equipment. 
(D)  Any emission of noise from any stationary noise device in excess of the limitations established by this section shall be deemed and is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. 26607, passed 9-8-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 94.99. 
Sec. 94.12. - Sound amplification systems in motor vehicles. 
(A)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle on a street or highway if the sound from any sound amplifying equipment located inside of, outside of but attached to, or held by a person inside, the motor vehicle, is discernible at a distance of 25 feet or more from the vehicle. 
(B)  This section does not apply to any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The sound amplifying equipment of the motor vehicle is being operated to request medical or vehicular assistance or to warn others of a hazardous road, vehicle operating, or traffic safety condition. 
(2)  The motor vehicle is an emergency vehicle or public safety vehicle and is on an emergency run. 
(3)  The motor vehicle is owned and operated by the state, a political subdivision, or a public utility. 
(4)  The motor vehicle is participating in a parade for which the sponsors of the parade have obtained the proper permits. 
(5)  The sound amplifying equipment of the motor vehicle is being operated as a requirement of federal or state law. 
(6)  Vendors of ice cream and related products in accordance with § 112.05(B)(6) between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(Ord. 28926-94, passed 10-26-94) 
Secs. 94.13-94.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 94.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any person who violates § 94.05(B) or § 94.12 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor; for a second offense committed within one year after the commission of the first offense, the person shall be guilty of a fourth degree misdemeanor; for a third and/or subsequent offenses committed within one year after the commission of the first offense, the person shall be guilty of a third degree misdemeanor. 
(B)  Any person who violates any other provision of this chapter, other than those cited in subsection (A) above, shall be guilty of a fourth degree misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 28926-94, passed 10-26-94) 
CHAPTER 95. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 95.01. - Sidewalk openings prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person owning, occupying, or using any cellar, or any coal hole, vent, or other opening which may be in any street or sidewalk of the city, shall cause or allow the cellar door, coal hole, vent, or other opening to remain open except as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 12633, passed 10-28-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.02. - Barriers on street openings. 
    A cellar door or other opening in the street or sidewalk may be left open in the daytime. However, guards and barriers must be placed above the opening to prevent persons lawfully on, and using, the street or sidewalk from injury by reason of the cellar door or other opening being left opened. 
(Ord. 12633, passed 10-28-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.03. - Danger lights required. 
    A cellar door other opening in the street or sidewalk shall not be left open in the night time unless the barriers provided for in § 95.02 are properly placed and, in addition thereto, red lights are placed on two sides of the openings. 
(Ord. 12633, passed 10-28-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.04. - Barriers along water course or highway. 
    No person shall take down, remove, or injure any fence or barrier, or any part thereof, or cause the same to be done, which has been erected either by the city or by any person, along or in the neighborhood of any water course, either natural or artificial, or any dangerous place, and in the vicinity of any highway or public place in the city, for the purpose of, or which has the effect of, preventing persons using such highways or public places from being precipitated into such water course or injured by such dangerous place and which warns persons using such highways or public places of danger. 
(Ord. 5897, passed 12-19-02) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.05. - Encroachment on streets prohibited. 
    No person being the owner or lessee of any lot or parcel of ground in the city shall encroach upon, or in any way obstruct or occupy any street, alley, avenue, sidewalk, public grounds, or land dedicated to the public use, or any part thereof, in the city by placing, building, erecting, or causing to be placed, built, or erected thereon any building or other structure or suffer the same to remain thereon when placed or built as aforesaid by any person. 
(Ord. 12634, passed 10-28-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.06. - Abatement of encroachments. 
    It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to see that the streets, alleys, avenues, sidewalks, public grounds, or land dedicated to the public use in the city are maintained free and clear of any and all encroachments prohibited by § 95.05. It shall be the duty of the engineer, when he has cause to believe that any person is violating the provisions of § 95.05, to cause the true line of any such street, alley, avenue, sidewalk, public grounds, or land dedicated to the public use to be determined, and if from this determination it is found that the owner or lessee of any lot or parcel of ground in the city has encroached upon the public way in violation of this section, the City Engineer shall notify the person in writing, by delivering a true copy of the notice to him, either by handing it to him or by leaving it at his usual place of residence, or in the event he is a nonresident of the city, by mailing a copy by registered or certified mail to the owner or lessee or by serving a copy thereof upon any agent located in the city who manages such property, rents, or collects rents of tenants for such owner or lessee. Thereupon, it shall be the duty of the owner or lessee or both of such lot or parcel of land encroaching upon the public way, within five days after service of notice or within such additional time as may be specified therein, to abate the encroachment and to remove back of the line established by the City Engineer all structures erected by him or by any other person. 
(Ord. 12634, passed 10-28-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.07. - Excavation barriers. 
    It is the duty of every person erecting any building or making any improvement on or near any sidewalk, street, or alley in the city, whereby an excavation is made or material accumulated, to place around the same a substantial rail or guard which will prevent any danger from accidents, and to place conspicuously and maintain thereat during the night a red light. 
(Ord. 2 G.O. 32, passed 8-6-1875; Am. Ord. 2 G.O. 82, passed 10-18-1878) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.08. - Loads falling from vehicles. 
    No person hauling trash, refuse, ashes, dirt, gravel, stone, brick, boxes, bales, bags, paper, scrap metals and shavings from all metals, or any other materials over the streets or alleys of the city shall do so in such a manner that any of these articles on the dray, truck, wagon, or other vehicle, fall from the vehicle to the street or alley. It is made the duty of every driver of such vehicles to load securely any articles he is engaged in transporting so as to prevent the articles from being scattered on the streets and alleys of the city, and it shall further be his duty to cover all loads of trash, refuse, or other material likely to fall or be blown from the vehicle with a tarpaulin or other suitable covering which will prevent such load or any part thereof from falling, blowing, or otherwise being cast upon the streets or alleys of the city. 
(Ord. 12707, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 16847, passed 2-1-50) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.09. - Removal of fallen load from street. 
    No person being the driver of a dray, truck, or wagon, or other vehicle in the city shall knowingly permit any of the articles enumerated in § 95.08 or any other materials of whatsoever nature which he is hauling and which have fallen from his vehicle to the street or alley, to remain on the street or alley for a longer time than will permit such person immediately after notice or knowledge thereof to remove such fallen article from the street or alley. 
(Ord. 12707, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 15845, passed 7-26-44) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.10. - Repair of motor vehicle during emergency. 
    No person shall park or maintain or cause the same to be done, any motor vehicle on the streets of the city in waiting for or while any repair or installation work is being done on such motor vehicle or any part thereof or accessory thereto or to the tires or electric battery thereof, except a minor repair, which shall consist of changing a tire casing, changing inner tubes, putting on a tire, testing an electric battery with the hydrometer or filling an electric storage battery with water, or doing such other minor repair or adjusting on the motor vehicle for which the car shall not remain parked on the street in waiting for such work and during the time in which the work is being done a total of more than one hour. However, such repair shall be made only during emergencies and these exceptions shall not apply to any location where a parking limitation of less duration exists or where standing or stopping is prohibited. 
(Ord. 11011, passed 12-3-19; Am. Ord. 26398, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.11. - Broken glass in streets. 
    No person shall purposely, willfully, or maliciously throw or place any glass, tacks, metal, stone, earthenware, or other substances likely to cause injury to pedestrians, animals, carriages, bicycles, automobiles or other vehicles, or likely to puncture or injure the tires of bicycles, automobiles, or other vehicles, in or upon any street, alley, lane, avenue, or public place in the city. 
(Ord. 8203, passed 4-25-10) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.12. - Snow removal. 
    No person removing snow or other form of frozen precipitation from private property shall push, plow, shovel, blow or otherwise deposit that snow or other form of frozen precipitation onto any public street or sidewalk within the city, except the tree lawn area immediately in front of the private property from which the snow or other form of frozen precipitation is removed. No person shall remove snow or other form of frozen precipitation from private property in such a manner as to block or obstruct the use of a public street or sidewalk, or to conceal or obstruct the use of a fire hydrant or street sign. 
(Ord. 30496-05, passed 11-9-05) 
Sec. 95.13. - Underground wires. 
    Within the territory bounded on the north by the Great Miami River; on the east by Webster Street from Monument to Third and by Bainbridge from Third to Fifth; on the south by Fifth, the Miami and Erie Canal, Sixth Street, and the railroad tracks; from the west end of Sixth Street to the Great Miami River, and on the west by the Great Miami River, all wires used for conducting electricity or for communication by means of electricity shall be placed underground when renewed or remain underground except as provided in § 95.15. 
(Ord. 10277, passed 7-26-16; Am. Ord. 26398, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.14. - Reserved. 
Sec. 95.15. - Conduits installed. 
    Whenever any street or portion of a street, within the area described in § 95.13 on which there are any such overhead wires, is to be paved or repaved, the Director of Urban Development shall notify the owners of all such wires, of such proposed improvement, and demand of them that all such wires shall be laid in underground conduits except trolley wires and such service and connecting wires as shall be approved by the Director of Urban Development. On receipt of such notice the owners of such wires shall in connection with the paving or repaving of such street, alley, or part thereof, and in such manner as not to interfere with or delay such work, provide, and install conduits for such wires which shall be located in such portion of the street or alley and installed in such manner as shall be approved by the Director of Urban Development. 
(Ord. 10277, passed 7-26-16; Am. Ord. 26398, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.16. - Installing underground wires after paving prohibited. 
    After any of the streets in the area described in § 95.15 shall have been paved or repaved, and the owners of wires have been ordered to place them underground as provided in § 95.15 hereof, no person shall install, maintain, repair, replace, or use any overhead wires, except trolley wires or connecting or service wires, approved by the Director of Urban Development on, along, or across the portions of such street or alley so paved or repaved, and no person shall open such street paving for the purpose of installing underground conduits for wires. 
(Ord. 10277, passed 7-26-16; Am. Ord. 26398, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.17. - Removal of snow and ice. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or of the occupant of each and every parcel of real estate in the city abutting upon any sidewalk, to keep the sidewalk abutting his premises free and clear of snow and ice, and to remove therefrom all snow and ice accumulated thereon within a reasonable time, which will ordinarily not exceed 12 hours after the abatement of any storm during which the snow and ice may have accumulated. 
(Ord. 9712, passed 9-30-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.18. - Assessment for removal of snow and ice. 
    If within a reasonable time, after the abatement of any storm during which snow or ice shall have accumulated on any sidewalk, the occupant or owner of the premises abutting thereon shall not have removed the snow and ice therefrom as is required by § 95.17, then the city may remove the snow and ice and the cost thereof shall be assessed against the lots and lands abutting the sidewalk thus cleaned. Notice of the assessment shall be given to the owners of the lots and lands charged therewith either by mail or by publication in the newspapers with which a contract for advertising shall have been made by the city, and all assessments not paid within ten days after the giving of notice shall be certified, together with a penalty of five percent by the City Accountant to the County Auditor for collection. 
(Ord. 9712, passed 9-30-14) 
Sec. 95.19. - Barriers on street improvements. 
(A)  It shall be the duty of a person contracting with the city to construct or repair any sidewalk, street, or public highway, to place on and about the same a railing, which will prevent public travel thereon, and to put in a conspicuous place a signboard notifying all persons that the street is blocked, and to keep the same so placed until all obstructions are removed. 
(B)  It shall, without any special agreement therein, be an implied part of every contract made by the city for improvements, that such contractor and his sureties upon the contract, shall be responsible for and hold the city harmless from all damages, resulting in any part from the failure on the part of such contractor to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 2 G.O. 32, passed 8-6-1875) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.20. - Tampering with barriers and lights prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall take down, remove, or in any manner tamper with any bar obstruction or barrier placed in a city street, alley, or other public place or part thereof by the city, or any person for the protection of any part of the pavement or other improvement in progress on the street. 
(B)  No person shall take down, remove, or tamper with any lighting device placed in a street as a warning of a dangerous condition therein. 
(Ord. 12697, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 26398, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.21. - Depositing material in streets. 
    No person shall throw, cast, or dump, or cause to be thrown, cast, or dumped, any earth, dirt, gravel, sand, rubbish, or any other material whatsoever, in or upon any street, lane, alley, avenue, river bank, levee, or any other public place whatsoever, within the corporate limits of the city, without first having obtained the consent of the City Commission. 
(Ord. 2 G.O. 128, passed 2-11-1881) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.22. - Fruit paring on sidewalk. 
    No person shall throw or place any banana or orange paring, or any paring of any other kind of fruit, on the public sidewalk of the city. 
(Ord. 2380, passed 12-21-1888) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.23. - Playing in streets prohibited. 
    No person shall participate in any game of play or athletic exercise on any roadway in the city. 
(Ord. 23488, passed 10-8-69; Am. Ord. 26398, passed 12-9-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.24. - Riding of skateboards in central business district. 
(A)  No person shall ride a skateboard on any sidewalk, street, alley, or public ground in the Central Business District. 
(B)  For the purpose of this section, the Central Business District shall be that area as defined in § 112.103. 
(Ord. 27559, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 95.25. - Dead animals in streets. 
    No person shall place, or cause to be placed, in any street, lane, alley, lot, common, or water course within this city the carcass of any dead animal or parts or fragments thereof, or any putrid or unsound beef, pork, fish, or other substance, tending to corrupt the atmosphere, and shall leave the same exposed or unburied. 
(Ord. 1 G.O. 51, passed 9-16-1842) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.26. - Operation of small motorized vehicles on public sidewalks. 
(A)  Notwithstanding any contrary provision in this Code, the Miami Valley Regional Transit Authority may operate up to five small motorized vehicles not to exceed 1,000 pounds gross weight and/or ten horsepower each upon public streets and sidewalks in the Central Business District upon approval by and subject to the terms and conditions as set forth by the Director of Urban Development. 
(B)  Such terms and conditions shall set forth the times such vehicles may be operated on public sidewalks, the length, width, and weight of said vehicle, and insurance and indemnification provisions. 
(C)  Such approval may be withdrawn for any reason by the Director of Urban Development. 
(Ord. 28363, passed 8-21-91) 
Secs. 95.27-95.29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREET PRIVILEGES 

Sec. 95.30. - Permits for privileges in streets. 
(A)  The Director of Public Works is charged with the construction, maintenance and repair of streets, sidewalks, sidewalk spaces, alleys, public ways and places and no person, whether an abutting owner or not, shall do or permit to be done by his agents, servants, or employees without having first obtained from the Director of Public Works a permit so to do any of the following acts: 
(1)  Make any excavation or dig into any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, public way or place; 
(2)  Remove, break or make holes in any pavement of the roadway or sidewalk or in any sidewalk space or any curb; 
(3)  Place or store any personal property upon any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place, except in the course of the usual and customary traffic on and over the public highways of the city; 
(4)  Construct, build, erect, or place any thing or structure in, upon, over, or under a street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place; 
(5)  Make an improvement to the surface of any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place by grading or graveling or paving, or construct or repair sidewalks or curb, or place or paint any sign or advertising matter on the surface of any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place, or on the surface of any overhead bridge or structure erected over or across any street, alley or public place, or make any other improvement therein; 
(6)  Operate, park, or move upon any street, alley, or public way any vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the maximums which can be moved without a permit as specified in the state statutes; 
(7)  Maintain for use as a permanent driveway any area over a sidewalk or sidewalk space within the public right-of-way whether such driveway is constructed by or under the direction of the owner of the abutting property or by the city incident to a street improvement project; 
(8)  Vend, or sell, or place or set out for sale, offer for sale, or display on or above any public sidewalk or other pedestrian way in the city any goods, wares, or merchandise of any kind or description whatsoever. Sales conducted pursuant to a permit issued by the Director of Public Works shall be in compliance with standards promulgated by and on file in the office of the City Manager, and such permit, unless renewed monthly, shall expire 30 days after issuance, provided, however, that a casual sales permit may be issued for a period of six months for sales to occur not more than two days a week during such six-month period. Regardless of renewals, a permit terminates one year after issuance and a new application must be submitted for a new permit. 
(B)  No permit from the Director of Public Works shall be required for planting shade trees or grading or sodding tree lawn space located as such space may be between the property line and the curb, or for the repair of sidewalk or driveway when such repair performed by the property owner does not exceed ten square feet in area, or for the repair of curb when such repair does not exceed two lineal feet. 
(C)  Nothing herein shall control as against the express terms of a franchise granted to a public utility to occupy the streets and public ways of the city. 
(D)  Nothing herein shall control in the improvement of streets or alleys or in the construction of sewers, or other public improvements by or under contract with the city, unless otherwise provided in the contract. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 23713, passed 5-13-70; Am. Ord. 26530, passed 5-19-82; Am. Ord. 26574, passed 8-4-82; Am. Ord. 31025-10, 9-6-10) 
Sec. 95.31. - Application for permit; contents. 
(A)  The person desiring to exercise any license or privilege for which a permit is required by § 95.30, shall apply in person or by a duly authorized representative to the Director of Public Works, who will supply a blank form of application for the permit desired, which shall state the conditions under which the permit shall be granted. This application shall run in the name of and be signed by the person for whom the privilege is desired, or in his name by an agent thereunto fully authorized, and if the applicant is not the owner of the abutting property in connection with which the privilege or license in the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place is desired, the owner is required to join in and sign the application; and when a request under this section is granted, the application therefor and the permit signed by the Director of Public Works shall constitute the agreement between the applicant and/or the abutting owner on the one hand and the city on the other, under the terms of which the applicant is permitted to occupy or do the things or acts specified in, upon, over, or under the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place of the city. However, permits for sewer, water, gas and electric services shall be issued only to the persons duly authorized by special license or franchise to make such installations, and the owner of the abutting property will not be required to join in the application. The licenses and privileges designated in § 95.37 as special licenses and privileges shall be applied for and granted in the manner hereinafter set forth for the granting of such special licenses and privileges. 
(B)  All applications for permits designated in § 95.33 shall be accompanied by a plat or print drawn to scale showing the location in the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place where the license or privilege is desired and, also, showing street lines, curb lines, and the dimensions of the portion of the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place to be occupied. The plat or print shall also show the location of all poles, fire hydrants, trees, manholes, catch basins, or any other public or privately owned structures. 
(Ord. 16480, passed 8-4-48; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 31025-10, 9-6-10) 
Sec. 95.32. - Liability insurance required. 
    The Director of Public Works may, if he deems it proper to do so, require the applicant applying for a permit to procure and furnish satisfactory evidence that he is keeping full force and effect a liability insurance policy containing a contractual liability coverage endorsement and completed operations coverage, furnishing to himself and the city protection against claims arising out of the performance of the work covered under the permit applied for, or in any way connected therewith, in an amount of $100,000.00 for any one person injured in any accident, and with a total liability of $300,000.00 for all persons injured in any one accident, and the amount of $100,000.00 for compensation for damages caused to the property of any person other than the belonging to the applicant. Insurance is required for a permit issued under Section 95.30(A)(8). 
(Ord. 16480, passed 8-4-48; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 31025-10, 9-6-10) 
Sec. 95.33. - Issuance of permits for street privileges; fees. 
    Upon receipt of an application therefor, together with the permit fees provided in this section, the Director of Public Works may, if he deems it proper so to do, grant permits for any of the following named licenses in a street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place: 
(A)  Placing or setting a newspaper vending machine or box, per machine or box (after a trial period) annual charge ..... $40.00 
(B)  Installation of passenger benches and/or passenger shelters by public transportation companies ..... No fee 
(C)  Excavation for footer or footers for a passenger shelter ..... 153.60 
(D)  Installation of portable planter box ..... No fee 
(E)  Excavation for new or repair of existing water service, sanitary lateral, gas service, telephone service or other service connection ..... 153.60 
(F)  Excavation for downspout drain ..... 10.00 
(G)  Making test hole or boring, each ..... 38.40 
(H)  Any other excavation in a street, sidewalk, alley, or public way or place not specifically mentioned above ..... 153.60 
(I)  Condenser water, well water or any other clean process water discharged into the storm sewer ..... 40.00 
(J)  Wells (test wells) ..... 40.00 
(K)  Any canvas awning, canopy, sign or similar structure extending more than five feet into a street or alley right-of-way ..... 40.00 
(L)  Construction, reconstruction, or relocation of any public utility conduit, line, or main per 100 lineal feet or fraction thereof including any manholes constructed with the above-mentioned line or main and being an integral part thereof, a manhole being defined as an underground chamber of less than 72 square feet of interior floor area ..... 172.80 
(M)  Construction, reconstruction, or relocation of any public utility manhole, tank, vault manhole, pullbox, regulator pit, or similar structure having an interior floor area of 72 square feet or less and which is not part of any current utility or main construction ..... 172.80 
(N)  Temporary storage of building material and/or personal property, except metered parking areas (see § 95.36 beyond 30-day period including a temporary fence during building operations or dumpster) ..... 40.00 
(O)  Temporary storage of building material and/or personal property per parking meter (see § 95.36 beyond 30-day period) ..... 40.00 
(P)  Any other temporary construction or erection. Partial street blockage (see § 95.36 beyond 30-day period) ..... 153.60 
(Q)  Complete blockade of a street, alley, or public way or place (per day or fraction thereof) ..... 76.80 
(R)  Setting a pole or pole anchor, per hole or anchor ..... 38.40 
(S)  Erecting a directional sign on a post or on an existing utility pole ..... 10.00 
(T)  Constructing or reconstructing sidewalk, driveway, and/or curb. (Each driveway requires a separate construction permit) ..... 20.00 
(U)  Owner's permit for a permanent widening, relocation and/or new driveway: 
(1)  Driveway 12 feet or less in width ..... 20.00 
(2)  Driveway over 12 feet in width but not over 30 feet in width per lineal foot or width ..... 3.00 
(3)  For widening an existing driveway to total width of not over 30 feet; per lineal foot of widening ..... 3.00 
(4)  Driveways over 30 feet in width, $10.00 per lineal foot in width; widening driveways from less than to more than 30 feet in width, $7.00 per lineal foot of existing driveway, plus $10.00 per lineal foot for the additional widening; to widen driveways greater than 30 feet in width, $10.00 per lineal foot for additional widening. 
(V)  Constructing a temporary driveway over curb and sidewalk ..... 20.00 
(W)  Moving an excess load (other than a building) of greater width, height, length, or weight than is permitted under state statutes ..... 30.00 
(X)  Moving any building of greater width, height, length, or weight than is permitted under state statutes ..... 100.00 
(Y)  Conducting sales of merchandise on the public sidewalks (contingent upon letter of approval from abutting property owner): 
(1)  0-100 square feet sidewalk space used, per month ..... 20.00 
(2)  101-300 square feet sidewalk space used, per month ..... 30.00 
(3)  301-500 square feet sidewalk space used, per month ..... 40.00 
(4)  Over 500 square feet sidewalk space used, per month ..... 60.00 
    Any permit granted hereunder may be revoked at anytime upon order of the City Manager or the City Commission and the permit holder shall remove or relocate any improvement at no expense to the city. 
(Am. Ord. 28060, passed 1-24-90; Am. Ord. 28779-94, passed 1-12-94; Am. Ord. 29815-00, passed 3-29-00; Am. Ord. 30319-03, passed 12-31-03; Am. Ord. 31025-10, § 1, 9-6-10) 
Sec. 95.34. - Issuance of permit for street privileges by agents authorized. 
    The Director of Urban Development may, if he deems it proper, designate any bureau or office in any other department of the city as his agent to issue permits as provided in § 95.30 where the convenience of the public makes such action advisable. 
(Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 24819, passed 10-30-74) 
Sec. 95.35. - Additional charges. 
(A)  In addition to the permit fee, the city shall collect from the grantee of any such permit all costs and expenses incurred by the city for labor, equipment, materials, excavations, installation of sewer, water, gas, electrical, steam, or other services, including pipe, taps, laterals, saddles, and all materials incident thereto, restoration, and maintaining an inspector or inspectors on any construction or improvement of a sewer, street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or place as a result of and in connection with the issuance of the permit. The city may require the estimated amount thereof to be deposited in advance of granting the permit, or in lieu of depositing the estimated amount in advance for each job, a surety bond to the city as obligee, in the amount of $10,000.00 by a surety company licensed by the State of Ohio and having an office in Montgomery County may be filed with the city. 
(B)  The bond shall be approved by the City Accountant and conditioned on payment by the permit grantee to the city of all costs and expenses incurred by the city for labor, equipment, materials, excavations, installation of sewer, water, gas, electrical, steam, or other services, including pipe, taps, laterals, saddles, and all materials incident thereto, restoration, and maintaining an inspector or inspectors on any construction or improvement of a sewer, street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or place, furnished to or for the benefit of the permit grantee, and further conditioned on compliance by the permit grantee of all ordinances and rules and regulations of the city pertaining to the permit. 
(C)  Whenever public sewers have been constructed and the expense thereof paid in whole or in part out of funds of the city, or if for any reason the assessment thereof on an abutting or benefited property has not been paid or has been released or no assessment made, no permit for tapping into any such sewer for connection with the property shall be granted until the owner of the abutting or benefited property shall have paid or caused to be paid into the city treasury an amount equal to the assessment of the amount properly assessable on the property, which amount, in case it has not been previously determined, shall be determined by the Director of Urban Development. 
(D)  Where a permit is required for a particular type of work and the type of work is commenced before taking out a permit, the director of urban development shall collect an additional amount equal to the fee for the permit. The payment of the additional fee shall in no way relieve any person from fully complying with all requirements of §§ 95.30 through 95.49. 
(E)  In the case of an emergency where a street opening is made when the city offices are closed, a permit shall be taken out as soon as the city offices are opened. No extra fee shall be charged in such cases. 
(Ord. 16480, passed 8-4-48; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 25485, passed 3-8-78) 
Sec. 95.36. - Permit renewal; fee. 
(A)  A permit for the temporary storage of building materials and/or personal property, a partial street blockage, other temporary construction or erection, including a temporary fence during building operations or a dumpster, in a street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place, shall expire and be fully terminated 30 days after date of issue, but may be renewed from month to month at the discretion of the Director of Public Works upon the payment of a monthly fee at the rate of $10.00 per 100 square feet, or fraction thereof, but in no case less than $40.00, of the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley or public way or place so occupied. 
(B)  A permit for temporary storage of building materials and/or personal property per parking meter, shall expire and be fully terminated 30 days after date of issue, but may be renewed from month to month at the discretion of the Director of Public Works upon the payment of a monthly fee at the rate of $40.00 per month or fraction thereof. 
(C)  All other permits shall expire at the end of 90 days from the date of issue unless the work to be done thereunder shall have been begun and shall be carried to completion with reasonable dispatch. 
(D)  No refund of the fee paid shall be made on the expiration of a permit. 
(Ord. 16480, passed 8-4-48; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 28060, passed 1-24-90; Am. Ord. 28779-94, passed 1-12-94; Am. Ord. 29815-00, passed 3-29-00) 
Sec. 95.37. - Permits for special licenses and privileges in streets; fees. 
    The following licenses and privileges in streets, sidewalks, sidewalk spaces, alleys, or public ways or places, by reasons of their inherent nature or duration are hereby declared and defined to be "special licenses and privileges" and use thereof may be issued by the Director of Public Works in the manner hereinafter set forth upon the payment of the following enumerated fees: 
(A)  Areaway under a sidewalk, a cellar door, ventilating grate or other sidewalk opening, $5.00 per square foot and in no case less than $200.00. 
(B)  Overhead bridge, conveyor tunnel or other structure of like nature, $2.00 per square foot, and in no case less than $200.00. 
(C)  Tank, vault, or other underground receptacle greater than 72 square feet in floor area, $7.68 per square foot, and in no case less than $768.00. 
(D)  Building encroachments above or below ground, $5.00 per square foot. Each type encroachment and each public way figured separately, in no case less than $200.00. 
(E)  Retaining walls, steps, ramps, planter boxes, or the private use of land areas, $1.00 per square foot, but in no case less than $200.00. 
(F)  Any canvas awning, canopy, sign or similar structure supported within a street or alley right-of-way, $200.00. 
(G)  Well (Water Extraction Well), $200.00. 
    The special licenses and privileges in the streets also require a construction permit prior to the construction or installation where excavation is involved. 
    Any special permit granted hereunder may be revoked at anytime upon order of the City Manager or the City Commission and the special permit holder shall remove any improvement at no expense to the city. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 24805, passed 10-9-74; Am. Ord. 28060, passed 1-24-90; Am. Ord. 28779-94, passed 1-12-94; Am. Ord. 29815-00, passed 3-29-00; Am. Ord. 30319-03, passed 12-31-03) 
Sec. 95.38. - Issuance of permits for special licenses and privileges by agents authorized. 
    The Director of Urban Development may, if he deems it proper, designate any bureau or office in any other department of the city as his agent to issue permits as provided in § 95.37 where the convenience of the public makes such action advisable. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 24805, passed 10-9-74) 
Sec. 95.39. - Application for special licenses and privileges in streets; contents. 
    Special licenses and privileges as set forth in § 95.37 may be granted to the owner or owners of abutting property by the Director of Urban Development in the following manner: 
(A)  Application in writing shall be filed in triplicate with the Director of Urban Development, setting forth the privilege desired and the reasons for requesting same. 
(B)  Each application shall be accompanied by a plat or print drawn to scale showing the location in the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place where the license or privilege is desired and also showing street lines, curb lines, lot lines, lot numbers and the dimensions of the portion of the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place to be occupied. The plat or print shall also show the location of all poles, fire hydrants, trees, manholes, catch basins, or any other publicly or privately owned structures. The Director of Urban Development may, where he deems it necessary, require that the plat or print shall be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect. 
(C)  The application shall also contain an agreement holding the city harmless from any and all damages resulting from the license or privilege desired. 
(D)  Upon the filing of such application and the deposit of the fee indicated, which fee is sufficient to include the cost of advertising such application, the Director of Urban Development shall advertise same in the newspaper having the contract for legal advertising of the city or in the journal published by the city, as the case may be, by setting forth the fact that the application has been made, the name of the applicant, the license or privilege prayed for, the proposed location of same in the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place, and that any objection thereto should be filed with the Director of Urban Development on or before a certain date, not less than three days after the last publication of said advertisement; said advertisement shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks. 
(Ord. 16480, passed 8-4-48; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 26574, passed 8-4-82) 
Sec. 95.40. - Investigation by Director of Urban Development. 
(A)  Before publication is made the Director of Urban Development shall investigate the application, and after the expiration of the time fixed for the filing of objections shall forward the application together with all objections and a report of his own investigation thereon to the City Manager, who shall place such application, objections and report before the City Commission, and the Commission shall be vote upon motion, take such action as it deems proper regarding the application, which motion and vote shall be entered upon the minutes but not be published. Thereafter, the Clerk of the Commission shall endorse upon the application the action taken by the Commission and notify the City Manager thereof, and, in cases of approval of the application, the City Manager shall send it so endorsed to the City Attorney, who shall approve the application as to form, which application upon approval shall constitute a contract under which said license or privilege shall be granted, which contract shall contain the conditions hereinafter set forth, and shall forward same to the City Manager who shall have a permit issued therefor by the Director of Urban Development. 
(B)  Both the application and the contract shall be prepared and executed in triplicate to provide a copy for the applicant and one each for filing in the offices of the Director of Urban Development and the Clerk of the Commission. It shall be the duty of the City Manager to see that the copy of the application and the contract, which are intended for the office of the Clerk of the Commission, are so delivered, and it shall be the duty of the Clerk of the Commission to file and index all such applications and contracts and upon such record to make reference to the minutes of the Commission where the action of the Commission is recorded. 
(Ord. 16480, passed 8-4-48; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Sec. 95.41. - Conditions upon which permits are issued. 
    The conditions upon which permits may be granted by the Director of Urban Development and which shall be included in the application for license or privilege and in the contract granting the same, shall be as follows: 
(A)  The license or privilege may be revoked after notice and hearing by the City Manager or by order of the City Commission except such licenses or privileges as are granted to a utility company for the construction, installation, maintenance, and use of an underground network, transformer vaults, manholes, and handholes within or under a street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place in the city, and except such licenses or privileges that may be granted to the United States Government, which may be granted or issued without payment of the required fees, and which shall not contain any provision for revocation. 
(B)  All laws of the state and the ordinances of the city shall be obeyed by the grantee of said permits. 
(C)  The acts and things done under the permit shall be subject to the supervision and control of the Director of Urban Development. 
(D)  All construction and improvements pertaining to building shall comply with requirements of the Uniform Building Code in use by the city. 
(E)  The street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place shall be restored within a certain specified time, which time in all cases shall be fixed at the discretion of the Director of Urban Development. 
(F)  Such street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place shall be restored in accordance with the general construction and material specifications for streets and sewers of the city then in effect. 
(G)  The grantee of said privilege shall assume and pay, saving the city free of all expense for such restoration of the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place, or arising in any other manner out of or incident to the grant or exercise of such license or privilege which shall be at the sole risk of the grantee. 
(H)  The grantee shall see to and be responsible for the safeguarding of all excavations and obstructions in any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place by placing and maintaining barricades about same, and, in addition thereto, warning lights during the nighttime. 
(I)  The grantee, his heirs, successors or assigns shall save the city free from any and all liability for damages to person or property in any way connected with or arising out of or incident to the granting and exercise of said privilege, and shall pay all expense for any change in such privilege incident to any improvement or change of grade in any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place rendering such change necessary and will not make any claim for damages therefor against the city. 
(J)  Any additional conditions which the City Commission may require. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Sec. 95.42. - Exhibiting permits. 
    Any person to whom a permit is issued under the terms of §§ 95.30 through 95.43, shall place the same in the possession of the person in charge of the work to be done, at the time the thing or act to be done is being carried on. Such permit shall be exhibited to any police officer or other proper public official demanding to see the same, and it is made the duty of every police officer upon observing work being carried on or anything being done in or on the street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place of the city for which a permit is required to demand an inspection of and examine such permit. 
    No person in charge of such work shall refuse to exhibit the permit, and in case of any failure or refusal to exhibit such permit the officer shall order the work discontinued until the permit is exhibited to him and he has had the opportunity to examine it. 
(Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65; Am. Ord. 23464, passed 8-20-69) 
Sec. 95.43. - Existing special privileges. 
    All special licenses and privileges as defined in §§ 95.30, 95.41, and 95.44, heretofore granted and in use on March 3, 1965, shall be continued in force and enjoyed, subject to the conditions upon which the same were granted and amended by §§ 95.30, 95.41, and 95.44, until such special license or privilege is either revoked or surrendered. 
(Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Sec. 95.44. - Ditch obstruction or culvert construction; permit required. 
    No person shall obstruct, or cause the obstruction of any ditch, drain, or watercourse of any kind, natural or artificial, in the city, by constructing or erecting therein a culvert, dam, or other obstruction of any kind without first obtaining a permit so to do from the Director of Urban Development. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.45. - Application for obstruction permit; contents. 
    The person desiring such permit shall apply in person or by a duly authorized representative to the Director of Urban Development. The application shall be accompanied by a drawing showing the location of the intended culvert, dam, or other obstruction of any kind and the property upstream which would be affected thereby. The Director of Urban Development may, where he deems necessary, require that the drawing be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect. No permit shall be granted by the director for the construction or erection of a culvert, dam, or other obstruction of any kind which would cause the water to flow back and flood any public street or alley or to become stagnant in a way prejudicial to the public health, or which would not be of sufficient size and capacity to accommodate the flow of water resulting from a storm occurring with a frequency of once in ten years, as determined by the rational method of design taking into consideration the upstream drainage area as being fully developed. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Sec. 95.46. - Permit fee. 
    A fee of $6.00 shall be charged for each permit. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Sec. 95.47. - Notice to remove culvert, dam, or other obstruction. 
(A)  The Director of Urban Development shall serve notice upon the owner or upon the person having the care and control of any lot or parcel of land through which any ditch, drain, or watercourse of any kind, natural or artificial, passes to remove, within 15 days after the service of such notice, any culvert, dam, or other obstruction of any kind which causes water to flow back and flood any public street or alley or to become stagnant in a way prejudicial to the public health and is not of sufficient size and capacity to accommodate the flow of water, as determined by § 95.46. 
(B)  If the owner or the person having the care and control of such lot or parcel of land fails or refuses to comply with the notice, the Director of Urban Development may also authorize the work required by such notice to be done at the expense of the city, and the amount of money so expended shall be recoverable from the person upon whom said notice was served by a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 11298, passed 1-26-21; Am. Ord. 21567, passed 3-3-65) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.48. - Authorized uses; permits. 
    No person shall place anything or cause anything to be placed upon, in, over, or under, or use otherwise than in the usual and customary manner for traffic or transportation purposes any street, sidewalk, sidewalk space, alley, or public way or place, unless such activity is specifically authorized by §§ 95.30 through 95.49 and a permit as provided for in these sections has been issued. 
(Ord. 23464, passed 8-20-69) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.49. - Defraying cost of special privileges. 
    Whenever any person shall apply to the Commission requesting action by that body of any kind whatever, for the benefit of such person, and it shall be necessary before such request can be granted that any advertisement shall be published or notice served, or that other expense of any kind shall be incurred, such person shall be required to defray such cost or expense in advance, and no obligation to pay the same shall be entered into by the city. 
(Ord. 2340, passed 8-8-1888) 
Sec. 95.50. - Bond and liability insurance. 
(A)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of constructing concrete sidewalks in the city shall, prior to the issuance of a permit, file a bond in the penal sum of not less than $3,000.00 with the Director of Urban Development. Such bond shall be conditioned to the effect that the permit holder in the building of concrete sidewalks in the city, whether under contract with the city or a property owner, shall comply strictly with all the laws and ordinances applicable thereto, shall construct all such sidewalks according to established grade and in accordance with specifications adopted by the city as contained in the construction and materials specifications promulgated by the Division of Engineering, and shall remove all debris after the completion of the work covered by a contract, shall pay all damages which may accrue because of defective or inferior workmanship or materials in such work, or repair or replace same; provided, such defective conditions become evident prior to the expiration of the guarantee period expressed in such contract, shall indemnify and save harmless the city and the property owner with whom he contracts, and both or either of them, from all claims, charges, losses, costs, damages, suits, and actions of every kind against either or both, for or on account of any injury or damage to person or property, or both, because of, arising out of, or incident to the construction of the work in any such contract specified to be done and shall pay any and all claims for labor, materials, machinery, or equipment furnished for the work specified in any such contract. Nothing herein shall be construed as requiring that the bond be in the express terms of this section. A substantial compliance shall be sufficient. 
(B)  The bond shall be executed by sureties to the satisfaction of the Director of Urban Development, and, if personal surety is offered, he shall be entitled to require that each such surety make affidavit that he is the owner of real property in Montgomery County, Ohio, and worth over and above all exemptions, debts, or other obligations including all other obligations of guaranty or suretyship whether a surety or guarantor on bonds, on promissory notes, or other obligations, an amount equal to or in excess of the penal sum of such bond. 
(C)  In addition to furnishing the bond required herein, the sidewalk contractor shall furnish satisfactory evidence, before a permit is issued to him, that he has procured public liability and property damage insurance which shall protect him, his subcontractors, and the city from all claims for damages for personal injuries, including accidental death, in the sum of $300,000.00 for any one person injured, with an aggregate of $500,000.00 for any one accident, and which shall protect them from claims for property damages in the sum of $300,000.00, which claims may arise from his operations as a sidewalk contractor and referred to above. 
(Ord. 26689, passed 12-22-82) 
DIVISION 3. - MANAGEMENT, ADMINISTRATION AND CONTROL OF THE USE OF THE CITY'S PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 95.51. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 95.51 through 95.71, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively, regardless of whether or not the words and phrases are capitalized: 
    Affiliate. Each person who falls into one or more of the following categories: (i) each person having, directly or indirectly, a controlling interest in a provider, (ii) each person in which a provider has, directly or indirectly a controlling interest, (iii) each officer, director, general partner, limited partner or shareholder holding an interest of 15 percent or more, joint venturer or joint venture partner, of a provider, and (iv) each person, directly or indirectly, controlling, controlled by, or under common control with the provider; provided that affiliate shall in no event mean any limited partner or shareholder holding an interest of less than 15 percent of such provider, or any creditor of such provider solely by virtue of its status as a creditor and which is not otherwise an affiliate by reason of owning a controlling interest in, being owned by, or being under common ownership, common management, or common control with, such provider. 
    Applicant. Any person who seeks to obtain a certificate of registration and/or a permit. 
    Application. The process by which an applicant submits a request to obtain certificate of registration and/or a permit. 
    Application fee. The fee paid to the city for application for a Certificate of Registration pursuant to § 95.53(A). 
    Bankruptcy Act. The regulations promulgated by Title 11 of the United States Code. 
    Best effort(s). The best reasonable efforts under the circumstances, taking into consideration, among other appropriate matters, all applicable laws, regulations, safety, engineering and operational codes, available technology, human resources, and cost. 
    Cable Franchise. Has the same meaning as "franchise" in the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 98 Stat. 2779, 47 U.S.C.A. 522. 
    Cable operator. Has the same meaning as in the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 98 Stat. 2779, 47 U.S.C.A. 522. 
    Cable service. Has the same meaning as in the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 98 Stat. 2779, 47 U.S.C.A. 522. 
    Certificate of registration. The document issued to each provider and its unique system to occupy the rights-of-way within the city that outlines the terms of that occupancy of the rights-of-way. 
    City. The City of Dayton, Ohio. 
    City Commission. The governing body of the city. 
    City Manager. The administrative head of the municipal government known as the City of Dayton, Ohio. 
    Construct. Shall mean, but not be limited to, digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing wires, installing conduit, installing pipes, installing transmission lines, installing poles, installing signs or installing Facilities, other than landscaping, ornamental plantings in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construct shall also include the act of opening and/or cutting into the surface of any paved or improved surface that is any part of the right-of-way. 
    Construction. Shall mean, but not be limited to, the act or process of digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing wires, installing conduit, installing pipes, installing transmission lines, installing poles, installing signs or installing Facilities, other than landscaping, ornamental plantings in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construction shall also include the act of opening and/or cutting into the surface of any paved or improved surface that is part of the right-of-way. 
    Construction Bond. A bond posted to ensure proper and complete construction and/or repair of a facility and the affected rights-of-way pursuant to a permit. 
    Construction and Major Maintenance Plan. A written plan including maps of the expected location, design, other related equipment and facilities of a provider which describes in full the construction intended to be accomplished by the provider in the rights-of-way over the next calendar year. 
    Construction permit. The permit specified in § 95.30 et seq. and further defined by § 95.65 which must be obtained before a person may construct in, locate in, occupy, maintain, move or remove facilities from, in or on a rights-of-way. 
    County. Montgomery County, Ohio (except for the purpose of the provision of sewer and water service within or through the city). County specifically excludes any and all contractors, agents or other persons acting on behalf of said county. 
    Credible. Worthy of being believed. 
    Design Guidelines-Creating a Quality Environment. The urban design standards promulgated by the Plan Board under § 44.18. 
    Department of Public Works. The Department of Public Works of the city. 
    Director of Public Works. The Director of the Department of Public Works, or his or her designee. 
    Emergency. A condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life or health, or of a significant loss of property. 
    Facility(ies). Any tangible thing located in any rights-of-way within the city; but shall not include boulevard plantings, ornamental plantings or gardens planted or maintained in the rights-of-way between a person's property and the street edge of pavement. 
    FCC. The Federal Communications Commission, or any successor thereto. 
    Full. Unable to accommodate any additional facilities as determined by the Director of Public Works in accordance with the principles of public health, safety and welfare, following a reasonable analysis taking into consideration: all applicable law; commonly accepted industry standards; and routine engineering practices. 
    GDRTA. The Greater Dayton Regional Transit Authority or its corporate successor for the limited purposes of providing public transportation. 
    In. When used in conjunction with rights-of-way, means in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through a rights-of-way. 
    Inspector. Any person authorized by the Director of Public Works to carry out inspections related to the provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71. 
    Law. Any local, state and/or federal legislative, judicial or administrative order, certificate, decision, statute, constitution, ordinance, resolution, regulation, rule, tariff or other requirement in effect either at the time of execution of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 or at any time during the location of, and/or while a provider's facilities are located in the public rights-of-way. 
    Minor maintenance permit. A permit, which must be obtained before a person can perform minor maintenance, as set forth in § 95.67, in or on the rights-of-way. 
    Ohio Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. The uniform system of traffic control devices promulgated by the Ohio Department of Transportation pursuant to O.R.C. § 4511.09. 
    O. R.C. The Revised Code of the State of Ohio. 
    Ohio Utility Protection Service. The utility protection service as defined in O.R.C. § 153.64 and/or § 3781.26 or a statutory successor thereto. 
    Open video service. Any video programming services provided to any person through the use of rights-of-way, which person is certified by the FCC to operate an open video system pursuant to § 651 et seq. of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 (codified at 47 U.S.C. Title VI, Part V), regardless of the facilities used. 
    Permit. A construction permit, a minor maintenance permit or a special privilege permit, as the context requires. 
    Permit cost. All direct, incidental and indirect costs actually incurred or realized by the city for permit issuance, permit oversight and pavement degradation resulting from construction activity. 
    Permit fee. Money paid to the city for a permit to construct in the rights-of-way as required by § 95.33 (C, E, G, H, L, M, P, Q and R) and 95.37(C) of this Code. 
    Permitee. Any person to whom a construction permit, minor maintenance permit and and/or special privilege permit has been granted by the city and not revoked. 
    Person. Any natural or corporate person, business association or other business entity including, but not limited to, a partnership, a sole proprietorship, a political subdivision, a public or private agency of any kind, a utility, a successor or assign of any of the foregoing, or any other legal entity. 
    Plan Board. The Plan Board of the City of Dayton created pursuant to § 151.0144. 
    Provider. A person who owns or operates a system and has a valid certificate of registration. The city, county and cable television operators operating pursuant to a valid Cable Franchise, shall also be considered providers. 
    PUCO. The Public Utilities Commission of Ohio as defined in O.R.C. § 4901.02. 
    R.C.G.O. The Revised Code of General Ordinances of the City of Dayton. 
    Registration maintenance fee. The money paid to the city to maintain a certificate of registration and compensate the city for all actual costs incurred by the city in the management, administration and control of the rights-of-way of the city, and which are not reasonably recoverable by the city through construction permit fees or other approved recovery mechanisms. 
    Removal Bond. A bond posted to ensure the availability of sufficient funds to remove a provider's facilities upon abandonment or disuse, or discontinuance of a provider's use or occupation of the rights-of-way. 
    Restoration. The process and the resultant effects by which a rights-of-way is returned to a condition as good as or better than its condition immediately prior to the construction. Restoration shall occur in accordance with the Rules and Regulations for Making Openings in a Public Way as amended from time to time. 
    Right(s)-of-way. The surface and space in, above, within, over below, under or through any real property in which the city has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public, including, but not limited to any public street, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, river, tunnel, viaduct, bridge, conduit, or any other place, area, or real property owned by or under the legal or equitable control of the city that, consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated, may be used for the purposes of constructing, operating, repairing, or replacing a system. Rights-of-way shall not include buildings, parks, or other public property or easements that have not been dedicated to compatible uses, except to the extent the use or occupation of such property is specifically granted in a permit or by law. 
    Right(s)-of-way cost. All direct, incidental and indirect costs borne by the city for the management and administration of the rights-of-way and §§ 95.51 through 95.71 of this Code. 
    Rules and regulations for making openings in a public way. The rules and regulations governing the making and restoration of openings in streets, alleys, sidewalks, public ways or places of the city drafted under the authority of Chapter 95 of this Code and currently on file in the Department of Public Works. 
    Service(s). The offering of any service for a fee directly to the public, or to such classes of users as to be effectively available directly to the public. 
    Special privilege permit. The permit for special licenses and privileges that must be obtained from the Director of Public Works pursuant to § 95.30 et seq. 
    Supplementary application. Any application made to construct on or in more of the rights-of-way than previously allowed, or to extend a permit that had already been issued. 
    Surety fund. A formal pledge made to secure against loss, damage or default. 
    System. Any system of conduit, cables, ducts, pipes, wires, lines, towers, antennae wave guides, optic fiber, microwave, laser beams and any associated converters, equipment or facilities or utilities designed and constructed for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying, delivering or distributing services within the city. A system shall specifically include, but not necessarily be limited to: electric distribution and/or transmission systems, natural or artificial gas distribution and/or transmission systems, water distribution systems, storm sewer systems, sanitary sewer systems, cable television systems, telecommunications systems (whether voice, video, data, or other), fiber optic systems, wireless communications systems, and transit electrification systems. 
    System representative. The specifically identified agent/employee of a provider who is authorized to direct field activities of that provider and serve as official notice agent for system related information. Any such system representative shall be required to be available at all times to receive notice of and immediately direct response to system related emergencies or situations. 
    Transfer. The disposal by the provider, directly or indirectly, by gift, assignment, voluntary sale, merger, consolidation or otherwise, of 51 percent or more at one time of the ownership or controlling interest in the system, or 51 percent cumulatively over the term of a certificate of registration of such interests to a corporation, partnership, limited partnership, trust, or association or person or group of persons acting in concert. 
    Trenchless technology. Shall mean, but not be limited to, the use of directional boring, horizontal drilling, microtunneling and other techniques in the construction of underground portions of facilities which result in the least amount of disruption and damage to rights-of-way as possible. 
    Underground facility(ies). All lines, cables, conduits, pipes, posts, tanks, vaults and any other facilities which are located wholly or partially underneath rights-of-way. 
    Unused facility(ies). Facilities located in the rights-of-way which have remained unused for 12 months and for which the provider is unable to provide the city with a credible plan detailing the procedure by which the provider intends to begin actively using such facilities within the next 12 months, or that it has a potential purchaser or user of the facilities who will be actively using the Facilities within the next 12 months, or that the availability of such facilities is required by the provider to adequately and efficiently operate its system. 
    Utility(ies). Any water, sewer, gas, drainage, sprinkler or culvert pipe and any electric power, telecommunication, signal, communication, or cable television conduit, fiber, wire, trackless trolley wires, cable, or operator thereof. 
    Utility corridor(s). Those specific areas of the rights-of-way designated as such by the Director of Public Works pursuant to § 95.53(F)(1). 
    Working day. Any Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday, but excluding legal holidays observed by the city. 
(Ord. 30188-02, passed 12-4-02; Am. Ord. 30318-03, passed 12-31-03) 
Sec. 95.52. - Rights-of-way administration. 
(A)  Administration. The City Manager shall be the principal city official responsible for the administration of §§ 95.51 through 95.71, except as otherwise provided herein. The City Manager may delegate any or all of the duties hereunder to the Director of Public Works or other designee. 
(B)  Rights-of-Way Occupancy. Each person who occupies, uses or seeks to occupy or use the rights-of-way to operate a system located in the rights-of-way, or who has, or seeks to have, a system located in any rights-of-way, shall apply for and obtain a certificate of registration pursuant to §§ 95.51 through 95.71. Any person owning, operating or maintaining a system in the rights-of-way without a certificate of registration, including persons operating under a permit, license or franchise issued by the city prior to the effective date of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 shall apply for and obtain a certificate of registration from the city, unless exempted by § 95.52(D). Application will consist of providing the information set forth in § 95.53 and as reasonably required by the City Manager. 
(C)  No Construction Without a Certificate of Registration. Following the effective date of §§ 95.51 through 95.71, no person shall construct or perform any work on or in, or use any system or any part thereof located on or in any rights-of-way without first obtaining a certificate of registration. Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree as provided for in § 95.99. 
(D)  Exceptions. 
(1)  The following entities are not obligated to obtain a certificate of registration: the city (exclusive of its enterprise fund agencies which shall be required to obtain and maintain a certificate of registration); the county; and resellers of services that do not own any system or facilities in the rights-of-way. 
(2)  The following entities are required to participate in the certificate of registration process, but shall be exempt from the financial obligations of the application fee required by § 95.53(A) and the registration maintenance fee required by § 95.55(A): cable operators for the purpose of providing only cable service and operating pursuant to a valid cable franchise; and GDRTA. In addition, cable operators shall be exempt from any requirement of the certificate of registration process that is in direct conflict with the requirements of, and/or specifically exempted by, a valid cable franchise with the city. 
(E)  Systems in Place Without a Certificate of Registration. Any system or part of a system found in a rights-of-way for which a certificate of registration has not been obtained shall be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities and/or noncomplying portion of such system; and/or prosecuting the violator. 
(F)  Future Uses. In allowing providers and permittees to place facilities in the rights-of-way, the city shall not be liable for any damages caused thereby to any provider's facilities that are already in place or that shall be placed in the rights-of-way unless those damages arise out of the sole negligence, gross negligence, willful misconduct, or fraud of the city. No provider is entitled to rely on the provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 as creating a special duty to any provider. 
(G)  Discontinuance of Operations, Abandoned and Unused Facilities. 
(1)  A provider who has discontinued or is discontinuing its operations of any system in the city shall: 
(a)  Provide information satisfactory to the city that the provider's obligations for its system in the rights-of-way under this section and any other sections in this Code have been lawfully assumed by another applicant and/or provider; or 
(b)  Submit a written proposal to re-use its facilities in a manner that promotes the city's goals of providing innovative and economic solutions to efficiently and economically utilize limited rights-of-way capacity. Such proposal must be approved by the Director of Public Works; or 
(c)  Submit a written proposal for abandonment of facilities in place indicating why good engineering practice would support this type of solution. The director of public works must approve said proposal; or 
(d)  Completely remove all specifically identified portion(s) of its system in a manner acceptable to the city within a reasonable amount of time if the city believes that there exists a reasonable justification for such removal; or 
(e)  Submit to the city within a reasonable amount of time and in accordance with O.R.C. § 4905.20 and 4905.21, a proposal for transferring ownership of its facilities to the city. If a provider proceeds under this clause, the city may, at its option where lawful: 
(i)  Purchase the facilities; or 
(ii)  Unless a valid removal bond has already been posted pursuant to § 95.69(B), require the provider to post a bond in an amount sufficient to reimburse the city for reasonably anticipated costs to be incurred in removing the facilities. 
(2)  Facilities of a provider who fail to comply with this section and which remain unused facilities shall be deemed to be abandoned. Abandoned facilities are deemed to be a nuisance. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to: 
(a)  Abating the nuisance; 
(b)  Taking possession of the facilities and restoring them to a useable condition subject to a finding of the PUCO pursuant to the requirements of O.R.C. § 4905.20 and 4905.21; or 
(c)  Requiring removal of the facilities by the provider or by the provider's surety. 
(3)  If the city requires a provider to remove unused facilities in any rights-of-way, the city shall use reasonable efforts to direct that this removal occur in conjunction with other scheduled excavations of the rights-of-way. If the city abates the nuisance it may take all action necessary to recover its costs and to abate said nuisance, including but not limited to, those methods set forth in O.R.C. § 715.261. 
(H)  Nature of Issuance. A certificate of registration shall not convey equitable or legal title in the rights-of-way. A certificate of registration is only the nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way in the city, for the limited purposes and for the limited period stated in the certificate of registration and in accordance with Chapter 95 of this Code. The rights to occupy the right-of-way may not be subdivided or subleased; provided, however, that two or more providers may collocate facilities in the same area of the rights-of-way so long as each such provider complies with the provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71. Collocating providers may file a joint application for a construction permit. A certificate of registration does not excuse a provider from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before collocating its facilities on facilities of others, including the city's facilities. A certificate of registration does not prevent a provider from leasing space in or on the provider's system, so long as the sharing of facilities does not cause a violation of law, including the provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71. A certificate of registration does not excuse a provider from complying with any provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 or other applicable law. 
(I)  Other Approvals, Permits, and Agreements. In addition to a certificate of registration, providers shall obtain any and all regulatory approvals, permits, authorizations, or licenses necessary for the offering or provision of such services from the appropriate federal, state and local authorities and upon the city's reasonable request, shall provide copies of such documents to the city. Further, a certificate of registration issued pursuant to §§ 95.51 through 95.71 shall not entitle a provider to use, alter, convert to, or interfere with, the facilities, easements, poles, conduits, lines, pipelines, wires, fiber, cable or any other real or personal property of any kind whatsoever under the management or control of the city. 
(Ord. 30188-02, passed 12-4-02; Am. Ord. 30318-03, passed 12-31-03) 
Sec. 95.53. - Certificate of registration applications. 
(A)  Certificate of Registration Applications. To obtain a certificate of registration to construct, own, or maintain any system within the city, or to obtain a renewal of a certificate of registration issued pursuant to §§ 95.51 through 95.71, an application must be filed with the city on the form adopted by the Department of Public Works which is hereby incorporated by reference. All applications shall be accompanied by a $2,000.00 application fee, which shall be used to pay for the actual costs incurred by the city that are associated with receiving, processing and granting of an application. At the time of its decision to either grant or deny an application the city shall assess the costs involved and either credit or debit an applicants application fee for the appropriate amount. If the application is approved and a certificate of registration is granted, any remainder balance of the aforementioned $2,000.00 application fee will be credited against and shall be an offset to the applicant's required annual registration maintenance fees until such time as the entire application fee balance is exhausted. If the application is not approved and a certificate of registration is denied, any balance of the aforementioned $2,000.00 application fee remaining after the city debits the actual costs associated with the application process, will be returned to the applicant within 60 days of denial. Should the application review and administration process incur actual costs in excess of $2,000.00, the city shall require the applicant to remit such additional amounts as necessary to properly compensate the city for those added costs within 60 days following issuance or denial of a certificate of registration.
