(iii)  Arising out of provider or permittee's failure to comply with the provisions of law applicable to provider or permittee in its business hereunder. 
(2)  The foregoing indemnification is conditioned upon the city: 
(a)  Giving provider or permittee prompt notice of any claim or the commencement of any action, suit or proceeding for which indemnification is sought; and 
(b)  Affording the provider or permittee the opportunity to participate in any compromise, settlement, or other resolution or disposition of any claim or proceeding subject to indemnification; and 
(c)  Cooperate in the defense of such claim and making available to the provider or permittee all pertinent information under the city's control. 
(3)  The city shall have the right to employ separate counsel in any such action or proceeding and to participate in the investigation and defense thereof, and the provider or permittee shall pay all reasonable fees and expenses of such separate counsel if employed. 
(Ord. 30188-02, passed 12-4-02) 
Sec. 95.71. - General provisions 
(A)  Non-Exclusive Remedy. The remedies provided in §§ 95.51 through 95.71 are not exclusive or in lieu of other rights and remedies that the city may have at law or in equity. The city is hereby authorized at any time to seek legal and equitable relief for actual or threatened injury to the public rights-of-way, including damages to the rights-of-way, whether caused by a violation of any of the provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 or other provisions of this Code. 
(B)  Severability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. If a regulatory body or a court of competent jurisdiction should determine by a final, non-appealable order that any permit, right or any portions of this section are illegal or unenforceable, then any such permit or right granted or deemed to exist hereunder shall be considered as a revocable permit with a mutual right in either party to terminate without cause upon giving 60 days' written notice to the other. The requirements and conditions of such a revocable permit shall be the same requirements and conditions as set forth in the permit, right or registration, respectively, except for conditions relating to the term of the permit and the right of termination. If a permit or right shall be considered a revocable permit as provided herein, the permittee must acknowledge the authority of the city to issue such revocable permit and the power to revoke it. 
(C)  Reservation of Regulatory and Police Powers. The city, by the granting of a permit or by issuing a certificate of registration pursuant to §§ 95.51 through 95.71, does not surrender or to any extent lose, waive, impair, or lessen the lawful powers and rights, which it has now or may be hereafter vested in the city under the Constitution and Laws of the United States, State of Ohio and under the Charter of the City of Dayton to regulate the use of the rights-of-way. The permittee by its acceptance of a permit, or provider by applying for and being issued a certificate of registration, is deemed to acknowledge that all lawful powers and rights, regulatory power, or police power, or otherwise as now are or the same as may be from time to time vested in or reserved to the city, shall be in full force and effect and subject to the exercise thereof by the city at any time. A permittee or provider is deemed to acknowledge that its rights are subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to such powers. 
(D)  Method of Service. Any notice or order of the Director of Public Works or City Manager shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is: 
(1)  Delivered personally; or 
(2)  Successfully transmitted via facsimile transmission to the last known fax number of the person to be served; or 
(3)  Left at the usual place of business of the person to whom it is to be served upon and with someone who is 18 years of age or older; or 
(4)  Sent by certified, preposted U.S. mail to the last known address; or 
(5)  If the notice is attempted to be served by certified, preposted U.S. mail and then returned showing that the letter was not delivered, or the certified letter is not returned within 14 days after the date of mailing, then notice may be sent by regular, preposted, first-class U.S.; or 
(6)  If the notice is attempted to be served by regular, first class U.S. mail, postage prepaid, and the letter is then returned showing that the letter was not delivered, or is not returned within 14 days after the date of mailing, then notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure, building, premises or property affected by such notice. 
(E)  Applies to All Providers. Sections 95.51 through 95.71 of this Code shall apply to all providers and all permittees unless expressly exempted. 
(F)  Police Powers. All persons' rights are subject to the police powers of the city to adopt and enforce ordinances necessary to the health, safety and welfare of the public. All persons shall comply with all applicable laws enacted by the city pursuant to its police powers. In particular, all persons shall comply with city zoning and other land use requirements pertaining to the placement and specifications of facilities. 
(G)  Compliance. No person shall be relieved of its obligation to comply with any of the provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 by reason of any failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance. 
(H)  Foreclosure and Receivership. 
(1)  Upon the filing of any voluntary or involuntary petition under the Bankruptcy Act by or against any provider and/or permittee, or any action for foreclosure or other judicial sale of the provider and/or permittee facilities located within the rights-of-way, the provider and/or permittee shall so notify the Director of Public Works within 14 calendar days thereof and the provider and/or permittee's certificate of registration or permit (as applicable) shall be deemed void and of no further force and effect. 
(2)  The city shall have the right to revoke, pursuant to the provisions of this Code, any certificate of registration or permit granted pursuant to §§ 95.51 through 95.71, subject to any applicable provisions of law, including the Bankruptcy Act, 120 days after the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over and conduct the business of the provider and/or permittee, whether in receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy or other action or proceeding, unless such receivership or trusteeship shall have been vacated prior to the expiration of said 120 days or unless: 
(a)  Within 120 days after election or appointment, such receiver or trustee shall have fully complied with all the provisions of the relevant certificate of registration, any outstanding permit, Chapter 95 of this Code, and remedied all defaults thereunder; and 
(b)  Said receiver or trustee, within said 120 days, shall have executed an agreement, duly approved by a court having jurisdiction over the facilities, whereby such receiver or trustee assumes and agrees to be bound by each and every provisions of the relevant certificate of registration, permit and §§ 95.51 through 95.71. 
(I)  Choice of Law and Forum. This Chapter 95 and the terms and conditions of any certificate of registration or permit shall be construed and enforced in accordance with the substantive laws of the city, State of Ohio and United States, in that order. As a condition of the grant of any permit or issuance of any certificate of registration all disputes shall be resolved in a court of competent jurisdiction in Montgomery County, Ohio. 
(J)  Force Majeure. In the event any person's performance of any of the terms, conditions or obligations required by §§ 95.51 through 95.71 is prevented by a cause or event not within such person's control, such inability to perform shall be deemed excused and no penalties or sanctions shall be imposed as a result thereof. For the purpose of this section, causes or events not within the control of a provider shall include, without limitation, acts of God, strikes, sabotage, riots or civil disturbances, failure or loss of, explosions, acts of public enemies, and natural disasters such as floods, earthquakes, landslides, and fires. 
(K)  No Warranty. The city makes no representation or warranty regarding its right to authorize the construction of facilities on any particular rights-of-way. The burden and responsibility for making such determination shall be upon the person installing facilities in the rights-of-way. 
(L)  Continuing Obligation and Holdover. In the event a provider or permittee continues to operate all or any part of the facilities after the termination, lapse, or revocation of a certificate of registration, such provider or permittee shall continue to comply with all applicable provisions of §§ 95.51 through 95.71 and other laws throughout the period of such continued operation, provided that any such continued operation shall in no way be construed as a renewal or other extension of the certificate of registration, nor as a limitation on the remedies, if any, available to the city as a result of such continued operation after the term, including, but not limited to, damages and restitution. Any conflict between the issuance of a certificate of registration or of a permit and any other present or future lawful exercise of the city's regulatory or police powers shall be resolved in favor of the latter. 
(M)  Appeals. All appeals provided for by this chapter and any notification to the city required by §§ 95.51 through 95.71 shall be in writing and sent via certified U.S. mail to the City Manager or Director of Public Works as specified in this Chapter 95. 
(N)  City Standards. As part of city required standards wherever rights-of-way are under construction, if deemed advisable and practicable by the Director of Public Works, the city may install all such facilities deemed necessary to accommodate future provider needs. Any such installed facilities shall be city property and may be conveyed to any person under such terms and conditions as are deemed advisable by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 30188-02, passed 12-4-02) 
Sec. 95.72. - Authority to establish design guidelines, fees, charges, regulations and/or procedures for wireless facilities and support structures located in the city's public rights-of-way. 
    In accordance with Substitute Ohio House Bill 478 as codified in ORC Chapter 4939, the City Manager, or their designee, shall have the authority to establish and revise as needed, design guidelines, fees, charges, and other regulations and/or procedures for wireless facilities and support structures located in the city's public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 31655-18, § 1, 7-18-18) 
Secs. 95.73-95.79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STREET VACATION 

Sec. 95.80. - Petition required for street vacation; exceptions. 
(A)  No street or alley, or part thereof, shall be vacated except upon petition therefor signed by all of the owners of property abutting upon the portion or portions of any such street or alley sought to be vacated. 
(B)  This section shall not apply in the case of a vacation of a street or alley, or part thereof, in order that a public improvement may be made by the city or to enable a municipal department to carry on its usual and ordinary operations or for any other municipal purpose. 
(C)  The State of Ohio shall not be required to sign or cause to be signed, any petition to vacate a street or alley when the state is an abutting property owner. 
(Ord. 12335, passed 12-31-24; Am. Ord. 23533, passed 11-12-69) 
Sec. 95.81. - Filing of petition. 
    The petition shall be filed with the Clerk of the Commission for consideration by the Commission and such further procedure as is required by law. All or any portion of the streets or alleys, or parts thereof, sought to be vacated at any one time for a certain purpose may be included in one petition. 
(Ord. 12335, passed 12-31-24; Am. Ord. 23533, passed 11-12-69) 
Sec. 95.82. - Fee for vacating streets. 
    Before filing a petition for street vacation, the petitioner or petitioners shall first pay to the City Accountant a fee of $150.00 for which the Director of Finance shall issue his receipt and note upon the petition that such fee has been paid, whereupon the petition may be filed with the Clerk of the Commission. 
(Ord. 12335, passed 12-31-24; Am. Ord. 24174, passed 1-5-72) 
Sec. 95.83. - Payment of improvement costs prerequisite to street vacation. 
    No ordinance for the vacation of any street or alley in the city shall be passed until the costs of any improvement to said street or alley paid by the city shall be ascertained and such cost so paid by the city, together with the cost of publication of the vacating ordinance, shall be paid by the property owners petitioning for such vacation. 
(Ord. 8407, passed 10-10-10) 
Sec. 95.84. - Clerk to certify vacated property. 
    The Clerk of the Commission is directed to certify to the County Auditor a description of all property vacated under and by authority of an ordinance passed by the Commission of the city within 30 days after the passage of such ordinance to vacate. 
(Ord. 8406, passed 10-10-10) 
Secs. 95.85-95.89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SIDEWALK NUISANCES 

Sec. 95.90. - Sidewalk nuisances specified. 
    The following conditions are hereby declared to be nuisances when they render any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip dangerous or unsafe in any manner: 
(A)  All stop boxes in streets, alleys, sidewalks, or park strips which are broken or which extend above or below the surface of the street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip; 
(B)  All cellar doors, area way doors, coal hole or manhole covers in any street, alley, sidewalk or park strip which are either wholly or partly, or the hinges of which are above or below the surface of such street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip, or which have become smooth and slippery; 
(C)  Any cellar or area way under any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip, the cover of which or the structure or support of which is insecure; 
(D)  All downspouts, drain tile, or drains extending from any building which in any manner, discharge water upon, over, or across any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip; 
(E)  All hitching posts, stepping stones, or other similar obstructions located in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip; 
(F)  All trees, hedges, or shrubbery hanging over or obstructing any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip; 
(G)  All mud, dirt, or other debris deposited in any manner upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip. 
(Ord. 12709, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 17608, passed 1-28-53) 
Sec. 95.91. - Abatement of nuisances; notice. 
    The owner of premises to which any of the nuisances under, over, or across any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip is appurtenant and which according to § 95.90 is a nuisance, shall within ten days after being notified so to do by the Director of Urban Development, abate such nuisance by: 
(A)  Making stop boxes, cellar doors, area way doors, coal hole or manhole covers flush with the surface of the street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip, or by removing same and by carrying the sidewalk across the aperture with such construction as the Director of Urban Development shall prescribe; 
(B)  In the case of a cellar or area way which is a nuisance, by strengthening the construction or support sustaining the street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip; 
(C)  In the case of downspouts, drain tile, or drains which are nuisances, by removing said spouting, drain tile, or drain entirely or by reconstructing it so as to cause the water to flow, conveyed in a suitable spouting or drain tile under the street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip; 
(D)  In the case of all hitching posts, stepping stones, or other similar obstructions which are nuisances, by removing same; 
(E)  In the case of all trees, hedges, or shrubbery hanging over or obstructing any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip, by trimming or cutting back said trees, hedges, or shrubbery as the Director of Urban Development may prescribe; 
(F)  In the case of mud, dirt, or other debris deposited in any manner in any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip by removing said mud, dirt, or other debris in a manner satisfactory to the Director of Urban Development. 
(Ord. 12709, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 17608, passed 1-28-53) 
Sec. 95.92. - Placing nuisance in street prohibited. 
    No person shall place any stop box, cellar door, area way door, coal hole or manhole cover, any cellar door or area way, any downspout, drain tile, or drain from any building, or any hitching post, stepping stone, or any similar obstruction or any other special privilege declared by § 95.90 to be a nuisance, in any street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip otherwise than flush with the surface of such street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip. 
(Ord. 12709, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 17608, passed 1-28-53) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.93. - Notice and abatement. 
    The owner of any stop box or manhole cover or other person having charge or control of any stop box, manhole cover or other special privilege which, according to § 95.90, is a nuisance, shall, within ten days after being notified so to do by the Director of Urban Development, abate such nuisance by adjusting such stop box or manhole cover so that it will be flush with the surface of the street, alley, sidewalk, or park strip as the case may be. 
(Ord. 12709, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 17608, passed 1-28-53) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Secs. 95.94-95.99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PARADES AND STREET MEETINGS 

Sec. 95.100. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 95.100 through 95.108, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Meeting or street meeting. A coming together of persons; an assembly; an assembling of a number of persons for the purpose of discussing and acting upon such matter or matters in which they have a common interest, in, on, or about any public way or place. This definition shall not include any form of lawful picketing. 
    Parade or street parade. An informal or formal march or procession of two or more individuals, vehicles, or animals moving on the public ways from one point to another point in an organized manner so as to unduly interfere with the public's free and uninterrupted use of a street, alley, lane, park, or other public place. This definition shall not include any form of lawful picketing. 
(Ord. 12701, passed 12-30-25) 
Sec. 95.101. - Street meeting permit required. 
    No person shall hold or participate in a meeting in any public street, alley, lane, park, or other public place within the city for any purposes not named herein whereby a number of people are, or are likely to be, gathered together so as to interfere unduly with the public's free and uninterrupted use of the street, alley, lane, park, or other public place in the city without a permit therefor having first been issued by the Director of Police in accordance with the provisions of §§ 95.103 through 95.108. 
(Ord. 12701, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.102. - Street parade permit required. 
    No person shall use any public street, alley, lane, park, or other public place within the city for the purpose of staging in any street, alley, lane, or other public place, a parade, or participating therein, for any purpose whatsoever without a permit therefor having first been issued by the Director of Police in accordance with provisions of §§ 95.103 through 95.108. 
(Ord. 12701, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 95.999. 
Sec. 95.103. - Procedure and standards for permit. 
(A)  Any person desiring a permit either to hold a public meeting as provided in § 95.101, or for staging a parade as provided in § 95.102, shall apply therefor to the Director of Police for a permit so to do, in accordance with the procedures herein set forth; provided, however, that any person intending to prepare or distribute food, clothing or toiletries in a public place within the central area of the city while holding the public meeting or staging the parade shall also apply for a permit under § 137.21. A public place within the central area of the city is the area of the city defined in § 137.21(E). 
(B)  The application shall be in writing and submitted and received in the office of the Director of Police at least ten calendar days before the public meeting or parade is to be held or staged, and shall state the nature or the object for which the permit is desired, the location of the meeting or the route of the parade, the dates and hours when it is desired to hold such meeting or stage such parade, the number of people, vehicles, and animals, if any, that it is anticipated will be involved therein, and the purpose thereof. The Director of Police shall cause an investigation to be conducted to determine whether the public meeting or parade will unduly interfere with the public use of the public street, alley, lane, park, or other public place to be so used. If the director finds such interference shall not occur, he shall issue a permit in writing to the applicant granting permission for holding of such meeting or parade according to the terms of said application or with such modifications as to time, place, and purpose as may be made by the director which he may deem necessary to prevent undue interference with the public use of the public street, alley, lane, park, or other public place to be so used. 
(C)  The decision of the Director of Police to issue, or not to issue such permit shall be made not less than seven calendar days before the date upon which such meeting or parade is to be held or staged. 
(Ord. 12701, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71; Am. Ord. 30471-05, passed 8-17-05) 
Sec. 95.104. - Parade Permit Board created. 
    If the Director of Police shall refuse to issue a permit to any person, said person may appeal the said decision. The appeal must be in writing and submitted and received in the Office of the City Commission at least five calendar days before such meeting or parade is to be held, to a board to be known as the Parade Permit Board, which is hereby created. 
(Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71) 
Sec. 95.105. - Membership of Board; decision of Director of Police reviewed. 
    The Parade Permit Board shall consist of the Director of Public Works, or authorized designee, the Director of Finance, or authorized designee, and the Director of Recreation and Youth Services, or authorized designee. The board shall determine whether or not the decision of the Director of Police not to grant the permit because it would result in interfering unduly with the public use of the public street, alley, lane, park, or other public place in the city, or that the convenience of the public in the use of the streets or sidewalks would thereby be disturbed unduly, is valid. If the board feels the standards for the issuance of a public meeting or parade permit have not been met, it shall affirm the decision of the Director of Police; otherwise, the board shall order the Director of Police to issue a permit forthwith to the person who submitted the application. 
(Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71; Am. Ord. 30471-05, passed 8-17-05) 
Sec. 95.106. - Rules and regulations of Parade Permit Board. 
    The Parade Permit Board shall make its own rules and regulations regarding the method of hearing appeals brought before it, but shall hear and decide all appeals within a reasonable time before the date upon which such meeting or parade is to be held or staged. In any event it shall make its decision known at least 48 hours before such meeting or parade is to be held or staged. 
(Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71) 
Sec. 95.107. - Revocation of permit. 
    The Director of Police may revoke any permit issued hereunder upon satisfactory evidence that the provisions of §§ 95.100 through 95.108 have been violated. Such revocation of any permit may be appealed in the same manner as provided in §§ 95.104 through 95.106, except the requirement that the appeal shall be heard before the date of the meeting or parade, will not be applicable. 
(Ord. 12701, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71) 
Sec. 95.108. - Act constituting violation. 
    If any person who constitutes a part of the parade or public meeting should, during such meeting or parade, cause a disturbance which results in a breach of the peace, the permit for such meeting or parade shall become null and void and the participants of such meeting or parade shall immediately disperse. 
(Ord. 23934, passed 3-10-71) 
Secs. 95.109-95.199. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - DOWNTOWN NEWSRACK DISTRICT 

Sec. 95.200. - Downtown Newsrack District. 
    A Downtown Newsrack District is established within the city. The Downtown Newsrack District encompasses an area of the City of Dayton bounded on the north by the north right-of-way line of Monument Avenue, on the east by the east right-of-way line of Jefferson Street, on the south by the south right-of-way line of Fifth Street, and on the west by the west right-of-way line of Ludlow Street. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.201. - Purpose of modular newsracks. 
    The city shall place modular newsrack containers within the Downtown Newsrack District to accomplish the following purposes: 
(A)  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety and convenience; 
(B)  Restrict unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including ingress into and egress from any residence or place of business, or from the street to the sidewalk by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles; 
(C)  Provide for the safety of the public and property during windstorms and other inclement weather; 
(D)  Provide reasonable access to locations used for public transportation purposes and for the use and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, and mailboxes; 
(E)  Remove from public rights-of-way private newsracks that interfere with the maintenance and cleaning, including snow removal, of public sidewalks and that contribute to the visual blight and detract from the aesthetics of adjacent businesses, landscaping and other improvements within the District; 
(F)  Maintain and protect the values of surrounding properties; 
(G)  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the public to personal injury and property damage; and 
(H)  Provide reasonable alternative means for the display, sale and distribution of publications within the District. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.202. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 95.200 to 95.211, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them respectively, regardless of whether or not the words and phrases are capitalized: 
    Abandon means a modular newsrack without current publications for sale or distribution to the public for a period of at least ten consecutive days and the owner, after written notice from the city, fails to stock the modular newsrack with current publications for sale or distribution to the public. 
    Director means the Director of the Department of Public Works for the city, or his or her authorized representative. 
    District means the Downtown Newsrack District. 
    Private newsrack means a privately owned newsrack, other than a modular newsrack within a modular newsrack container, used to display, sell or distribute a publication from a public street, place or right-of-way within the city. 
    Modular newsrack container means a metallic, box-like container provided by the city with no more than 12 compartments designed to contain modular newsracks and accommodate, at any one time, the display, sale or distribution of multiple and distinct publications. 
    Modular newsrack means a newsrack designed to fit in a compartment within a modular newsrack container, including the door, coin return mechanism, if any, and associated hardware. 
    Permit means an annual license issued by the Director to the owner of a publication to install, maintain and use a modular newsrack within a modular newsrack container for the display, sale or distribution of a publication to the public within the District. 
    Publication means any written or printed material, including, but not limited to, newspapers, periodicals, advertising circulars, and magazines distributed through the use of a newsrack. 
    Newsrack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the display, sale or distribution of a publication. 
    Owner means the person or legal entity responsible for selling, displaying or distributing a publication. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.203. - Private newsracks prohibited. 
    No owner or other person shall place, or allow to remain in place, a private newsrack on a public street, place or right-of-way within the District. Upon giving the owner seven days' written notice to remove a private newsrack found in violation of this section, the Director shall remove the private newsrack from public property within the District and notify the owner in writing that the city will store the private newsrack for the owner for a period of 30 days, after which the city shall destroy or otherwise dispose of the unclaimed private newsrack. The city may charge a reasonable storage fee for any private newsrack stored pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.204. - Modular newsrack permit required. 
    No person, other than the owner of a publication issued a permit pursuant to § 95.208, shall display, sell or otherwise distribute a publication from a newsrack on a public street, place or right-of-way within the District. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.205. - Placement of modular newsrack containers. 
(A)  Subject to § 95.206, the Director shall place modular newsrack containers at locations convenient to pedestrian use within the District; however, the Director shall not place more than one modular newsrack container at any one location or two modular newsrack containers at any one intersection. The Director shall announce, at least 30 days in advance, the location or relocation of each modular newsrack container placed within the District. 
(B)  The Director shall not place additional modular newsrack containers within the District, except in response to a written petition signed by the owners of at least six separate publications requesting the placement of a modular newsrack container at a specific location within the District. 
(C)  The Director may remove from the District, or relocate within the District, a modular newsrack container with one-half or more of its compartments unoccupied, but only at the end of the current permit year and only after providing at least 30 days' written notice to each owner of a publication issued a permit to install, maintain and use a modular newsrack within the modular newsrack container to be removed or relocated. 
(D)  The addition, removal or relocation of a modular newsrack container within the District shall comport with the purposes set forth in § 95.201. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.206. - Number of modular newsracks permitted. 
    The number of modular newsracks permitted within the District shall initially equal the number of newsracks within the area of the District with valid special privilege permits issued pursuant to § 95.30 in effect upon establishment of the District. Thereafter, the number of modular newsracks permitted within the District shall equal the number of modular newsracks with valid permits issued pursuant to § 95.208 in effect at the end of the preceding year. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.207. - Application for permit. 
(A)  The owner of a publication applying for a permit to install, maintain and use a modular newsrack within a modular newsrack container for the display, sale or distribution of a publication to the public shall, on an application form furnished by the Director: 
(1)  Identify, by location, the modular newsrack container; 
(2)  Identify, by name, the publication; 
(3)  Identify, by frequency of issuance, the type of publication (e.g., daily, twice weekly, monthly); and 
(4)  Identify, by name and address, the person authorized to receive notices sent pursuant to §§ 95.203, 95.205, 95.210 and 95.211. 
    Each application for a permit shall contain a notarized statement signed by or on behalf of the owner agreeing to abide by the terms of §§ 95.200 to 95.211. 
(B)  The owner of a publication shall apply for a permit no sooner than 90 days and no later than 45 days prior to the effective date of the permit. 
(C)  Subject to § 95.207(D), the owner of a publication may apply for more than one permit issued pursuant to § 95.208; however, a separate application is required for each permit. 
(D)  The owner of a publication may not apply for a permit to display, sell or distribute the same publication from more than one modular newsrack within the same modular newsrack container. 
(E)  A sixty-five dollar processing fee shall accompany each application for a permit submitted pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.208. - Modular newsrack permit. 
(A)  For each modular newsrack container within the District, the Director shall proceed as follows: 
(1)  Based on frequency of issuance, assign all applications submitted in accordance with § 95.207 to one of the following three categories of publications: 
a.  Publications issued at least five or more times a week; 
b.  Publications issued one to four times a week; or 
c.  Publications issued less frequently than weekly. 
(2)  Issue permits by randomly selecting an application from each category of publications, starting with category a, and continuing to category b, then category c. Continue selecting applications in this order until permits equaling compartments within the modular newsrack container are issued. 
(B)  Each permit issued pursuant to this section shall take effect on January 1 and expire on December 31 of the year for which it is issued. 
(C)  The Director shall issue annual permits pursuant to this section at least ten days prior to the effective date of the permit. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.209. - Maintenance and use of modular newsracks. 
    The owner of a publication issued a permit pursuant to § 95.208 shall: 
(A)  Maintain the modular newsrack door and coin return mechanism in good working order and promptly repair any defective or malfunctioning part or replace the defective or malfunctioning part with equipment of like kind and appearance; 
(B)  Permanently affix a label, inconspicuous in size and color, to the modular newsrack door at a readily visible location, which label shall provide the name, address and 24-hour-operable telephone number of a person or service that customers may call to report a problem or receive a refund in the event of a coin-return malfunction; 
(C)  Not place any advertising materials, signs or publicity on the modular newsrack door, other than an advertisement or sign identifying the publication contained within the modular newsrack; and 
(D)  Notify the Director 30 days prior to the owner's voluntary abandonment of the modular newsrack. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.210. - Revocation of permit. 
    Pursuant to this section, the Director shall revoke the modular newsrack permit of a publication violating any requirement of § 95.209 or § 95.211. The Director shall give ten days' advance written notice to the owner informing the owner of the violation and specifying a time for taking corrective action. The notice shall also inform the owner that the owner may contest the violation by filing a written appeal with the Director within seven days of receiving the notice, and warn the owner that failure to timely correct the violation or file an appeal with the Director shall result in revocation of the permit issued to the owner. The Director shall hear any appeal timely filed pursuant to this section within ten days of its filing and promptly issue a written decision. The decision of the Director is final, subject to judicial review. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Sec. 95.211. - Abandonment of modular newsrack. 
(A)  The owner of a publication issued a permit to install, maintain and use a modular newsrack shall not abandon the modular newsrack. 
(B)  The Director shall revoke the modular newsrack permit of any modular newsrack abandoned the owner. 
(Ord. 30583-06, passed 8-2-06) 
Secs. 95.212-95.299. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - CHANGING NAME OF PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 

Sec. 95.300. - Implementation of a permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way. 
(A)  The Director of Public Works is charged with maintaining the permanent official names of public rights-of-way. 
(B)  A person may request a permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way provided the person has obtained approval for said naming from the City Plan Board in accordance with established city policies and procedures. 
(C)  If the permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way is part of a platting or subdivision process, the procedures set forth in the Subdivision Regulations of this Code shall apply. 
(Ord. 30721-08, passed 2-20-08) 
Sec. 95.301. - Application for a permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way. 
(A)  Upon receipt of approval from the City Plan Board, a person may submit an application to the Director of Public Works, on an application form furnished by the Director, for the implementation of a permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way, with the following fees: 
(1)  Application fee ..... $1,000.00 
(2)  Implementation of name change, per city block requested ..... 750.00 
(B)  Upon the filing of an application pursuant to subsection (A) and the deposit of the applicable fees, the Director of Public Works shall forward the application to the Secretary of the City Plan Board, who shall request the Clerk of the Commission to place the application in the form of an ordinance before the City Commission for approval. The fees described in subsection (A) shall be refundable to the applicant in any case where the City Commission does not approve the ordinance. 
(Ord. 30721-08, passed 2-20-08) 
Sec. 95.302. - Implementation of a permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way. 
(A)  Following approval by the City Commission of a permanent change to the official name of a public right-of-way, the Director of Public Works shall initiate the permanent change in all public records for the City of Dayton and Montgomery County, Ohio, including the installation of street name signs in each block of the affected right-of-way. 
(B)  A change to the official name of a public right-of-way that has the written concurrence of the owners of a majority of the abutting properties shall not be effective for at least 90 days after the passage of the ordinance approving the application. 
(C)  A change to the official name of a public right-of-way that does not have the written concurrence of the owners of a majority of the abutting properties shall not be effective for at least 12 months after the passage of the ordinance approving the application. 
(Ord. 30721-08, passed 2-20-08) 
Secs. 95.303-95.399. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - USE OF THE CITY'S RIGHT-OF-WAY BY ELECTRIC TRANSPORTATION DEVICE SERVICE PROVIDERS AND OTHER USERS OF ELECTRIC TRANSPORTATION DEVICES 

Sec. 95.400. - Use of the right-of-way by electric transportation devices. 
    The City Manager, or their designee, shall have the authority to establish, amend, and revise, as necessary, guidelines, fees, charges, rules, and other regulations concerning the use of the right-of-way by users of electric transportation devices, as defined by § 70.01. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.401. - Rules and regulations for electric transportation devices. 
    That the City Manager, or their designee, shall have the power and authority to promulgate rules and regulations for the use of the right-of-way by users of electric transportation devices and operators of electric transportation device services. These rules and regulations ("Rules and Regulations") shall be subject to the approval of the City Commission and shall be in full force and effect immediately upon their approval by the Commission. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.402. - Identifying the owner or operator. 
    The City Manager, or their designee, shall make a reasonable effort to identify the owner or operator of an electric transportation device that is in violation of this Code, the Rules and Regulations, or creates a hazard in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.403. - Notification of impoundment. 
(A)  If the City Manager, or their designee, impounds an electric transportation device then the City Manager, or their designee, will make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner and/or operator of the electric transportation device of the violation and issue a notice of impoundment. 
(B)  A notice of impoundment will be placed on the City's website and if an owner or operator of the Electric Transportation Device is readily ascertainable then the Notice of Impoundment will be sent via regular U.S. Mail or certified mail too. 
(C)  The notice of impoundment shall contain the following: 
(1)  The location of the violation; 
(2)  The violation that occurred; 
(3)  That the owner or operator of the electric transportation device will be held jointly and severally responsible for all costs incidental to the removal, storage, and disposal of the electric transportation device; 
(4)  The time and date of the violation; 
(5)  The location of the impounded electric transportation device; 
(6)  The address and telephone number of the Public Works Department holding the electric transportation device; and, 
(7)  The period of time in which a person may appeal the impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.404. - Hearing concerning the impoundment of electric transportation devices. 
    Any person or owner notified of an impoundment may file a written request for a hearing, within ten days of the issuance of the notice of impoundment or ten days after the notice of impoundment is placed on the City's website, whichever is later, before a designee of the Director of Public Works. 
(A)  The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable, preferably within seven days of the city receipt of the appeal. 
(B)  The scope of the hearing will be limited to whether the electric transportation device was in violation of the Rules and Regulations or of this Code and whether the impoundment was done lawfully. 
(C)  At the hearing, the city and operator and/or owner may introduce such witnesses and evidence as each party deems necessary. 
(D)  At the hearing, the city and operator and/or owner may cross-examine witnesses. 
(E)  The hearing will be open to the public. 
(F)  All decisions of the Director of Public Works shall be final, expect as subject to court review. 
(G)  A failure by the owner or operator to request a hearing within the ten days shall be deemed to waive their right to contest the validity of the impoundment and/or removal. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.405. - Purpose and effect of impoundment. 
(A)  The impoundment of electric transportation devices under the authority of this chapter shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for the protection of the public peace, safety, and welfare, and for the safeguarding of the public's right-of-way. 
(B)  Impoundment shall be used generally for: 
(1)  Prevention and removal of traffic and fire hazards; 
(2)  Prevention and abatement of public nuisances; 
(3)  Protection of public rights in the use of city streets, highways, roadways, sidewalks, and other types of public right-of-way from obstructions placed and life in derogation of those rights; and, 
(4)  Enforcement of the law. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.406. - Circumstances authorizing impoundment of electric transportation devices. 
    The City Manager, or their designee, may impound electric transportation devices under the following circumstances: 
(A)  Violation the Rules and Regulations or this Code. If an electric transportation device is left on the right-of-way in violation of the Rules and Regulations or this code. 
(B)  Unattended and abandoned electric transportation device. If an electric transportation device is left unattended, abandoned, parked, stored, or in a manner that causes the right-of-way to be unusable or impedes the normal use of the right-of-way. 
(C)  Arrest or detention of the owner. If the driver, operator, or person in charge of any electric transportation device is placed under arrest and taken into custody and detained by police under circumstances which leaves or will leave an electric transportation device unattended. 
(D)  Electric transportation devices creating a traffic or safety hazard. If an electric transportation device is left unattended, stored, abandoned, or parked in a manner that constitutes a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic or normal use of the right-of-way. 
(E)  Electric transportation device blocking fire exits or hydrants. If an electric transportation device is parked, stored, abandoned, or left unattended in a manner that it blocks a fire escape ladder, device, exit or hampers access to a fire hydrant. 
(F)  Electric transportation devices parked in the right-of-way. If an electric transportation device is parked, stored, abandoned, or left unattended in a manner that is prohibited by § 74.11 or 74.11.1. 
(G)  Electric transportation devices removed by fire official. If an electric transportation device is in violation of any provision of the Ohio Fire Code. 
(H)  Evidence/investigation. If an electric transportation device is operated or used by a person while engaged in, or connected with, the commission of a crime. 
(I)  Immediate health or safety risk. If an electric transportation device is parked, abandoned, stored, or left unattended in a manner that causes or may cause an immediate risk to public safety or other users of the right-of-way. 
(J)  Impedes normal use of the right-of-way. If an electric transportation device is parked, stored, abandoned, or left unattended in a manner that impedes the normal use of the right-of-way. 
(K)  Left unattended. If an electric transportation device is parked, stored, abandoned, or left unattended anywhere within the city for 24 hour period. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.407. - Storage fees and impoundment cost. 
    The City Manager, or their designee, may determine reasonable impoundment fees and storage fees for the impoundment of electric transportation devices pursuant to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.408. - Options for the release of impounded electric transportation devices. 
(A)  An owner or operator whose electric transportation device is impounded may do any of the following: 
(1)  Pay the impoundment fee and all other costs associated with impoundment, removal, and storage of the electric transportation device; and/or, 
(2)  Request a hearing as provided under § 95.405. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.409. - Release of impounded electric transportation devices. 
(A)  The City Manager, or their designee, is authorized to release impounded electric transportation devices and to accept, on behalf of the city and as applicable, agreements to save and hold the city harmless signed by the owner or operator to whom the electric transportation device is released. 
(B)  The City Manager, or their designee, will release an impounded electric transportation device to the owner or operator upon presentation of the following: 
(1)  Proof of ownership of the electric transportation device; 
(2)  Personal identification of the owner or operator for the electric transportation device; 
(3)  The payment of any impoundment and storage fees; 
(4)  A release from the Director of Public Works; and, 
(5)  If after a hearing held pursuant to this Code then a release from the Director of Public Works stating the final determination of the hearing. 
(C)  The City Manager, or their designee, shall retain copies of the instruments and documents required in this section. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Sec. 95.410. - Disposal of unclaimed electric transportation devices. 
    The City Manager, or their designee, shall dispose of any unclaimed electric transportation device in accordance with the applicable state law concerning unclaimed property. 
(Ord. No. 31714-19, passed 4-10-19) 
Secs. 95.411-95.998. - Reserved. 
Sec. 95.999. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates Section 95.30(A)(8) of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Any person who violates any other provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(Am. Ord. 31025-10, 9-6-10) 
CHAPTER 96. - NUISANCES; TREES AND TRASH 

Sec. 96.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Premises. A lot, plot, or parcel of land, including the building or structure thereon or any parts thereof, and adjacent land occupied by public right-of-ways, to the median point between adjoining properties. 
    Trees. Trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation, but shall not include shrubs or bushes which do not grow higher than 15 feet. 
    Trash. Litter and debris, including but not limited to any garbage, waste, peelings of vegetables or fruits, rubbish, ashes, cans, bottles, wire, paper, cartons, boxes, parts of motor vehicles and machinery of whatever nature and design, wagons, furniture, glass, oil of an unsightly or unsanitary nature, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 25323, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25923, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 96.02. - Overhanging trees. 
    The owner of every lot or parcel of land within the city upon which a tree stands with any part of said tree upon or overhanging a public thoroughfare, and the owner of every such lot or parcel of land abutting a public thoroughfare upon which thoroughfare and in front of which lot or parcel of land a tree stands, shall conform to the following regulations: 
(A)  The owner shall trim, or cause to be trimmed, the tree so that it shall not obstruct the free passage of light from any street light to the immediately subjacent street or sidewalk. 
(B)  The owner shall trim, or cause to be trimmed, the tree so that a clear height of 13 feet between the lowest branches and the street, alley, or sidewalk is maintained. 
(C)  The owner shall trim or remove, as the case may require, every dead, decayed, or broken tree or part thereof hereinabove described so that it shall not fall to the street or sidewalk. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 16087, passed 8-14-46) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.03. - Certain trees prohibited. 
    The following trees shall not be used for street planting or be planted thereon: Fruit trees, berry trees of any description, poplars, willows, birches, catalpas, box elder, silver maple, horse chestnut, tree of Heaven, European Mountain ash, Chinese elm, and American elm. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 16306, passed 11-12-47) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.04. - Moving building or heavy machinery along streets. 
(A)  No person, whether a licensee by the Division of Building Inspection or otherwise, shall move any building or heavy machinery along the street in such a way as to interfere with, injure, or destroy any tree or shrub in any street or public ground, parks, and parkways in the city. 
(B)  A special permit from the Director of Urban Development shall be required for the moving of buildings and heavy machinery along the streets of the city. 
(C)  The application for such permit shall specify the building or machinery and proposed route over which it is desired to remove such building or machinery, and shall be accompanied by the written consent of the majority of the property owners along the proposed route having trees or shrubs within the highway. 
(D)  If the moving of said buildings or heavy machinery herein permitted will in any way interfere with, injure, or destroy any tree or shrubbery along said route in the opinion of the Director of Urban Development, such tree shall be removed or otherwise protected until after the passage of said building or heavy machinery, and replanted or restored under the supervision and direction of the Director of Urban Development and at the expense of the person moving the building or heavy machinery. Before such permit is granted for such moving of a building or heavy machinery, the applicant therefor shall deposit $10.00 per tree with the director, or as much more as the director may deem necessary, to cover the actual expense of removing and replanting or otherwise protecting such trees, which deposit shall be retained until such trees are safely replanted or restored, when such action is deemed advisable or necessary by the Director of Urban Development. Every permittee under this section shall be liable to pay to the owner of every tree so removed and replanted herein, if any such tree dies by reason thereof, the actual value of such tree, which shall be recoverable by the owner of such tree in a civil action. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.05. - Removal of tree guards prohibited. 
    No person shall remove or misuse any guard or other device placed or intended to protect from injury any tree or shrub in any street in the city. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.06. - Gas main leaks prohibited. 
    No person owning, maintaining, or operating any gas pipe or mains laid beneath the surface of any street, alley, or sidewalk in the city shall permit any leak to occur within such pipe or mains within a radius of 40 feet of any tree in any street or public place within the city. In the event that a leak occurs in any such pipe or mains it shall be the duty of such person owning or using such defective pipe to repair the same forthwith and to stop the leak in such manner as will prevent recurrence of the same trouble, after receiving notice from the Director of Public Works that such leak exists. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.07. - Guards around trees required. 
    No owner or contractor shall erect, alter, or repair any building or structure without first placing or causing to be placed around any tree located in a street, alley, or public place, and likely to be damaged by such operations, such guards as shall effectually prevent injury to any such tree. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.08. - Protection of trees from electric wires. 
    Every person having or maintaining in the city streets any wires charged with electricity, shall take whatever steps the Director of Urban Development may deem practicable to protect trees from injury by reason of such wires. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.09. - Interference with tree planting by city prohibited. 
    No person shall prevent, delay, or interfere with the Director of Urban Development or any of his assistants in the lawful planting, pruning, trimming, or removing of any tree, plant, or shrub in any street, alley, or public highway or place in the city. However, nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction, for the protection of property rights, by the owner of any tree in the city. 
(Ord. 12885, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.10. - Weed cutting and trash removal required. 
    The owner, occupant, or any person having the care, control, or possession of any premises within the city shall cut down and remove therefrom all offensive, noxious, or unsightly weeds, vines, and grass, and maintain the premises clear of trash. 
(Ord. 16749, passed 8-24-49; Am. Ord. 22600, passed 7-26-67; Am. Ord. 25323, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25923, passed 2-6-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 96.99. 
Sec. 96.11. - Notice of violation. 
    The Director of Housing and Neighborhood Affairs or the Director of Public Works shall cause written notice to be served in the manner provided by the Ohio Rules of Civil Procedure for service of summons in civil actions on any person found to be in violation of the provisions of § 96.10, ordering such person to mow any weeds, vines, and grass, or clear such premises of trash within five days from the service of such notice. If the owner, occupant, or person having the care, control, or possession of such premises cannot be found, the notice shall be published once in a daily newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(Ord. 16749, passed 8-24-49; Am. Ord. 25085, passed 3-17-76; Am. Ord. 25923, passed 2-6-80) 
Sec. 96.12. - Weed cutting, spraying, and trash removal by city. 
    If the owner, occupant, or person having the care, control, or possession of any such premises shall fail to mow the weeds, vines, or grass, or remove all trash as provided in §§ 96.10 and 96.11, the Director of Human and Neighborhood Resources may cause such premises to be mowed, or sprayed with a vegetation growth retardant, and cleared of trash. The owner, occupant, or person having the care, control, or possession of such premises shall be billed directly by mail for the cost incurred by the city in mowing, spraying, or clearing such property. The bill for the costs thereof shall be paid within 30 days after mailing of the bill. If the costs are not so recovered, then the city may certify the costs thereof to the county auditor for addition to the tax duplicate as provided by general law. 
(Ord. 16749, passed 8-24-49; Am. Ord. 25085, passed 3-17-76; Am. Ord. 25323, passed 6-22-77; Am. Ord. 25923, passed 2-6-80; Am. Ord. 26294, passed 8-5-81) 
Secs. 96.13-96.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 96.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any person who violates any provisions of any section of this chapter for which a penalty is not otherwise specifically provided shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  Any person who violates § 96.10 of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(Ord. 25923, passed 2-6-80) 
CHAPTER 97. - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES 

Sec. 97.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    By-product. A chemical substance produced without separate commercial intent during the manufacturing or processing of another chemical substance or mixture. 
    Chemical substance. Any organic or inorganic substance of a particular molecular identity, including: 
(1)  Any combination of such substances occurring in whole or in part as a result of a chemical reaction or occurring in nature, and 
(2)  Any element or uncombined radical. 
(3)  Such term does not include: 
(a)  Any mixture, 
(b)  Any pesticide (as defined in the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act) when manufactured, processed, or distributed in commerce for use as a pesticide. 
(c)  Tobacco or any tobacco product, 
(d)  Any source material, special nuclear material, or by-product material as such terms are defined in the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended, and regulations issued under such act, and the Energy Reorganization Act of 1974 and any regulations issued under such act. 
(e)  Any article the sale of which is subject to the tax imposed by Section 4181 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (determined without regard to any exemptions from such tax provided by section 4182 or 4221 or any provisions of such code), and 
(f)  Any food, food additive, drug, cosmetic, or device (as such terms are defined in Section 201 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act) when manufactured, processed, or distributed in commerce for use as a food, food additive, drug, cosmetic, or device. 
    Chemical waste landfill. A landfill at which protection against risk of injury to health or the environment from migration of hazardous substances to land, water, or the atmosphere is provided from hazardous substances deposited therein by locating, engineering, and operating the landfill in accordance with federal and state law. 
    Curie. An expression of the quantity of radiation in terms of the number of atoms which disintegrate per second; a curie is that quantity of radioactive materials which decays such that 37 billion atoms disintegrate per second. 
    Hazardous substances. Any of the following: 
(1)  Any hazardous waste. 
(2)  Any radioactive material. 
(3)  Any chemical substance or mixture containing any PCB (polychlorinated biphenyl). 
    Hazardous substance disposal site. Any chemical waste landfill or incinerator used to dispose of hazardous substances. 
    Hazardous waste. Any substance, combination of substances, or mixtures defined as "hazardous waste" in 40 CFR, Part 261, Subpart A § 261.3 which is not specifically excluded under § 261.4 (b) under that title or this chapter. The provisions of 40 CFR Part 261, Subpart A §§ 261.2, 261.3 and 261.4, and corresponding sections of subparts C and D and appendices cited therein, which define, describe, and identify hazardous waste are incorporated by reference into this section and made a part hereof the same as if each were set forth fully herein. All subsequent amendments to the provisions of subparts C and D and appendices cited therein which define, describe and identify hazardous waste, and the sections of subpart B specifically delineated herein, automatically become a part of this section as of the effective dates of each amendment, subject to the provisions of this section. Hazardous wastes do not include chemical substances or mixtures listed in § 97.01 (A) (3) or any radioactive material. 
    Microcurie. One millionth of a curie. 
    Mixture. Any combination of two or more chemical substances if the combination does not occur in nature and is not, in whole or in part, the result of a chemical reaction, except that such term does include any combination which occurs, in whole or in part, as a result of a chemical reaction if none of the chemical substances comprising the combination is a new chemical substance and if the combination could have been manufactured for commercial purposes without a chemical reaction at the time the chemical substances comprising the combination were combined. 
    PCB. Any chemical substance that is limited to the biphenyl molecule that has been chlorinated to varying degrees or any combination of substances, or mixture which contains chlorinated biphenyl molecules. 
    PCB article. Any manufactured article other than a PCB container that contains PCBs and whose surface has been in direct contact with PCBs. "PCB article" includes capacitors, transformers, electric motors, pumps, pipes, and any other manufactured item which: 
(1)  Is formed to a specific shape or design during manufacture. 
(2)  Has end use function dependent in whole or in part on its shape or design during end use, and 
(3)  Has either no change of chemical composition during its end use or only those changes of composition which have no commercial purpose separate from that of the PCB article. 
    PCB container. Any package, can, bottle, barrel, drum, tank, or other device exclusive of a PCB article or PCB equipment that contains PCB article and whose surface has been in direct contact with PCBs. 
    PCB equipment. Any manufactured item, other than a PCB container or a PCB article container, which contains a PCB article or other PCB equipment, and includes microwave ovens, electronic equipment, and fluorescent light ballasts and fixtures. 
    Person. Any natural or legally created artificial person including any individual, corporation, partnership, or association, also any individual, partnership, association, or corporation engaged in the transportation of passengers or property, as common, contract, or private carrier, or freight forwarder, as those terms are used in the Interstate Commerce Act, as amended. 
    Radioactive material. Any material or combination of materials, which spontaneously emits ionizing radiation. Materials in which the estimated specific activity is not greater than 0.002 microcuries per gram of material, and in which the radioactivity is essentially uniformly distributed, are not considered to be radioactive materials. 
    Store for disposal. To store, confine, or contain for or incidental to discarding, destroying, decontaminating, degrading, reprocessing, or recycling of substances whose useful life has been terminated or completed, or which have otherwise been taken out of service. 
    Use. Putting into service to attain an end other than disposal. 
    Waste oil. Used products primarily derived from petroleum, which includes, but are not limited to, fuel oils, motor oils, gear oils, cutting oils, transmission fluids, hydraulic fluids, and dielectric fluids. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Sec. 97.02. - Disposal of hazardous waste. 
(A)  No person shall knowingly discard, dispose, discharge, deposit, inject, dump, spill, leak, spray, place, or otherwise cast into or on any land, whether improved or unimproved, on any public or private street, roadway, or highway, into any drain, gutter, sewer, or culvert, into any lake or pond, water course or ditch, into any pit or excavation, or into or atop of any aquifer, any hazardous waste within the corporate limits of the city. 
(B)  No person shall knowingly cause any other person by contract or otherwise to discard, dispose, discharge, deposit, inject, dump, spill, leak, spray, place or otherwise cast into or on any land, whether improved or unimproved, on any public or private street, roadway, or highway, into any drain, gutter, sewer, or culvert, into any lake, pond, water course, or ditch, or into any pit or excavation, or into or atop of any aquifer, any hazardous waste within the corporate limits of the city. 
(C)  No person shall negligently discard, dispose, discharge, deposit, inject, dump, spill, leak, spray, place or otherwise cast into or on any land, whether improved or unimproved, on any public or private street, roadway, or highway, into any drain, gutter, sewer, or culvert, into any lake, pond, water course, or ditch, or into any pit or excavation, or into or atop of any aquifer, any hazardous waste within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 97.99. 
Sec. 97.03. - Disposal and storage of PCB. 
(A)  No person shall knowingly discard, dispose, discharge, deposit, inject, dump, spill, leak, spray, place, or otherwise cast into or on any land, whether improved or unimproved, on any public or private street, roadway, or highway, into any drain, gutter, sewer, or culvert, into any lake, pond, water course, or ditch, or into any pit or excavation, or into or atop of any aquifer, any PCB, either in liquid, crystalline, or solid resin form, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(B)  No person shall knowingly cause any person by contract or otherwise to discard, dispose, discharge, deposit, inject, dump, spill, leak, spray, place or otherwise cast into or on any land, whether improved or unimproved, on any public or private street, roadway, or highway, into any drain, gutter, sewer, or culvert, into any lake, pond, water course, or ditch, or into any pit or excavation, or into or atop of any aquifer, any PCB, either in liquid, crystalline, or solid resin form, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(C)  No person shall negligently discard, dispose, discharge, deposit, inject, dump, spill, leak, spray, place or otherwise cast into or on any land, whether improved or unimproved, on any public or private street, roadway, or highway, into any drain, gutter, sewer, or culvert, into any lake, pond, water course, or ditch, or into any pit or excavation, or into or atop of any aquifer, any PCB, either in liquid, crystalline, or solid resin form, within the corporate limits of the city. 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 97.99. 
(D)  After March 15, 1981, no person shall store for disposal any PCB, regardless of form, in one or more PCB containers, within the corporate limits of the city at any of the following locations: 
(1)  Within any floodplain, atop any aquifer, or within any drainage basin of any aquifer, lake, or pond; 
(2)  Any other location not enumerated in § 97.03(D)(1). 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 97.97 
(E)  After March 15, 1981, no person shall cause any other person by contract or otherwise to store for disposal any PCB, regardless of form, in one or more PCB containers, within the corporate limits of the city at any of the following locations: 
(1)  Within any floodplain, atop any aquifer, or within any drainage basin of any aquifer, lake, or pond; 
(2)  Any other location not enumerated in § 97.03(E)(1). 
(F)  (1)  The term PCB as used in § 97.03 refers to any chemical substance, combination of substances, or mixture that contains 50 parts per million (on a dry weight basis) or greater of PCB, as defined in § 97.01(C) including any by-product, intermediate or impurity manufactured at any point in the process. 
(2)  Substances that are regulated by § 97.03 include, but are not limited to, dielectric fluids, contaminated solvents, waste oils, heat transfer fluids, hydraulic fluids, paints, sludges, slurries, dredge spoils, soils, materials contaminated as a result of spills, and other chemical substances or combination of substances, or mixtures of substances, including impurities and by-products, provided, such chemical substances, or combination of substances or mixtures, regardless of form, contain PCB. 
(G)  Storage or use of PCB in PCB articles, or PCB equipment is not in violation of this section. Disposal of PCB articles or PCB equipment containing any measurable amount of PCB therein is not a violation of this section. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 97.99. 
Sec. 97.04. - Use of PCB. 
(A)  No person shall use any PCB other than its use in the manufacturing or processing of other substances or mixtures, or its use in PCB articles, PCB equipment, or its use incidental to placing into service or continuing service of PCB articles or PCB equipment, unless the permitted uses are restricted or prohibited by federal or state law. 
(B)  The prohibitions of § 97.04(A) shall be subject to the exemptions set forth in § 97.07(B) and (C) of this chapter. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 97.99. 
Sec. 97.05. - Transportation and shipment or radioactive material. 
    No person shall ship or transport into, within, through, or out of the city any radioactive material contrary to the applicable federal regulations of the United States Department of Transportation and the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission in effect at date of shipment or transport. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 97.99. 
Sec. 97.06. - Application of other regulatory provisions. 
    Regardless and notwithstanding the provisions of § 97.03 of this chapter, any and all applicable provisions, ordinances, and regulations requiring permits for the storage of any hazardous materials are still in full force and effect unless otherwise specifically repealed. 
Sec. 97.07. - Exemptions. 
(A)  The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the storage or disposal of hazardous waste, and PCB in any hazardous substance disposal site specifically approved by either the United States Environmental Protection Agency or the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency and which comport to federal and state law. 
(B)  A person may petition the City Manager or his designee for an exemption from the requirement of § 97.04(A), and the City Manager or his designee may grant in writing an exemption, where not precluded by state or federal law, if he finds that: 
(1)  Unreasonable risk of injury to health or environment would not result, 
(2)  Good faith efforts have been made to develop a chemical substance which does not present an unreasonable risk of injury to health or the environment and which may be substituted for such PCB, and 
(3)  The best interest of the city would be served by granting the exemption. 
(C)  The provisions of §§ 97.03 and 97.04 of this chapter shall not apply to the use of waste samples of PCB, samples of other substances, or material containing PCB or PCB reference samples for or in conducting analytical tests to determine the composition or characteristics of the sample. 
(D)  The provisions of § 97.02 of this chapter shall not apply to the discharge of waste water or waste water derivatives authorized under a valid national pollution discharge elimination system permit, or otherwise authorized to be discharged into a publicly-owned water treatment works. 
(E)  The provisions of § 97.03(D) shall not apply to the temporary storage of PCB or PCBs taken out of service, provided: 
(1)  The temporary storage does not exceed 60 days from the date that the PCB or PCBs are taken out of service. 
(2)  The PCB or PCBs being temporarily stored were previously placed into use and taken out of service within the corporate limits of the city. 
(3)  The PCB or PCBs being temporarily stored remain in the possession, custody, control or ownership of the person who used the PCBs. 
(4)  The previous use of the PCBs being temporarily stored was in conformance with § 97.04 of this chapter. 
(5)  The PCB or PCBs being temporarily stored are separately containerized according to the date removed from service. 
(6)  The date that the PCB or PCBs are taken out of the service and an indication that the containerized substance or mixture is PCB is clearly and indelibly marked on each respective storage container utilized whether a PCB container, or other container, or receptacle. The date so marked shall be prima facie evidence of the date the PCB or PCBs were taken out of service. 
(F)  Notwithstanding the provisions of § 97.07(E) above, the provisions of § 97.03(D) of this chapter shall not apply to the temporary storage or temporary accumulation of PCB or PCBs taken out of service and being temporarily stored or temporarily accumulated, on or after March 15, 1980, and prior to the effective date of this chapter, which storage or accumulation is prior to the movement of the PCB or PCBs off site for disposal at another location outside the corporate limits of the city, provided: 
(1)  The incidental temporary storage or accumulation does not exceed 60 days from the date that respective PCB or PCB were taken out of service; and 
(2)  Effective may 15, 1981, the dates the PCB or PCBs were taken out of service are clearly and indelibly marked on each respective storage container, whether a PCB container, or other container or receptacle in which the PCB or PCBs are being temporarily stored or temporarily accumulated, together with a clear and indelible indication that the particular containerized substance or mixture is PCB or PCBs. The dates so marked shall be prima facie evidence of the date or dates the PCB or PCBs were taken out of service. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80; Am. Ord. 26225, passed 4-29-81) 
Sec. 97.08. - Inspections. 
    The Fire Chief, or his designated representative, any law enforcement officer, or building, housing, or zoning inspector shall have the authority to inspect all structures and premises, as often as may be necessary for the purpose of ascertaining or causing to be corrected, any condition which may be a violation of this chapter, or otherwise enforcing any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Sec. 97.09. - Right of entry. 
    Whenever necessary for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, or whenever the Fire Chief or his designated representative, any law enforcement officer, or any building, housing, or zoning inspector has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any structure or on any premises, any condition which constitutes a violation of this chapter, the officials may enter such structure or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same, or to perform any duty imposed on any of the respective officials by law, provided that if such structure or premises be occupied, he shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such entry is refused, the official seeking entry shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
Secs. 97.10-97.96. - Reserved. 
Sec. 97.97. - Civil penalties. 
(A)  Any person who knowingly violates any of the provisions of § 97.03(D) shall be subject to a civil penalty of $1,000.00 for each such violation. 
(B)  If any violation of the provisions of § 97.03(D) is a continuing one, each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense, except that the maximum civil penalty shall not exceed $25,000.00 for any related series of violations. 
(C)  The City Attorney shall have the authority to commence an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the penalty provisions of this section. 
(D)  Any civil penalty under this section may be compromised by the City Manager with approval of the City Commission. In determining the amount of such penalty or whether it should be remitted or mitigated and in what amount, the appropriateness of such penalty to the size of the business of the person charged and the gravity of the violation shall be considered. 
(E)  Any individual director, officer, or agent of a corporation who knowingly authorizes, orders, or performs any of the acts constituting in whole or in part a violation of § 97.03(D) shall be subject to the penalties under this section without regard to any civil penalties to which the corporation may be subject. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Sec. 97.98. - Injunctive relief. 
    Violation of the provisions of §§ 97.02 and 97.03 shall constitute a public nuisance.
