The City Attorney shall have the authority to commence any action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin the actions of any person who violates any of the provisions of §§ 97.02 and 97.03 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Sec. 97.99. - Criminal penalties. 
(A)  Any person who violates § 97.02(A) shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(B)  Any person who violates § 97.02(B) shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(C)  Any person who violates § 97.02(C) shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor. 
(D)  Any person who violates § 97.03(A) shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(E)  Any person who violates § 97.03(B) shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(F)  Any person who violates § 97.03(D) shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor. 
(G)  Any person who violates § 97.03(D)(1) shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. If any violation of § 97.03(D)(2) is a continuing one, each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(H)  Any person who violates § 97.03(D)(2) shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor. If any violation of § 97.03(D)(2) is a continuing one, each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(I)  Any person who violates § 97.03(E)(1) shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(J)  Any person who violates § 97.03(E)(2) shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor. 
(K)  Any person who violates § 97.04 shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(L)  Any person who violates § 97.05 shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(M)  Any individual director, officer, or agent of a corporation who knowingly and willfully authorizes, orders or performs any of the acts constituting a violation of any of the provisions of §§ 97.02, 97.03, 97.04, or 97.05 shall be subject to the penalties under this section without regard to any penalty to which that corporation may be subject for violation of §§ 97.02, 97.03, 97.04, or 97.05. 
(Ord. 26110, passed 11-19-80) 
Cross reference- Classification of penalties, see § 130.99. 
CHAPTER 98. - LITTER CONTROL 

Sec. 98.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Aircraft. Any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used, or designed for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Bulk waste. Any large item of waste, including, but not limited to, appliances, furniture, mattresses, box springs, toys, carpet, draperies, parts of motor vehicles and machinery of whatever nature or design, junk motor vehicles, and scrap metal, 
    Construction sites. Any private or public property upon which repairs to existing buildings, construction of new buildings, or demolition of existing structures is taking place. 
    Demolition matter. Those items removed from a structure under construction, repair or demolition, such as brick, concrete, stone, glass, wallboard, framing and finishing lumber, roofing materials, plumbing, plumbing fixtures, wiring and insulation material. 
    Deposit. To bring onto, leave behind, throw, drop, discard or place. 
    Handbill. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed matter of literature which is not delivered by United States mail, including but not limited to items such as: 
(1)  Items which advertise for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, or thing; 
(2)  Items which direct attention to any business, mercantile, or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or 
(3)  Items which direct attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit. 
    Hazardous waste. That which is defined in Ohio Revised Code Section 3734.01. 
    Infectious waste. That which is defined in Ohio Revised Code Section 3734.01. 
    Litter. Includes trash, debris, cans, bottles, waste paper and plastic, sweepings, droppings, garbage, refuse, waste vegetative matter, feces, waste wood, ashes, rubbish, garbage bags, cartons, boxes, and anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature, but not including bulk waste, demolition matter, hazardous waste, infectious waste or used oil. 
    Private property. All privately-owned property including, but not limited to, vacant land or any land, building or other structure designed or used for residential, commercial, business, industrial, institutional or religious purposes, together with any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, fence, porch, steps, vestibule, mailbox and other structure appurtenant thereto. 
    Public property. Any publicly-owned street, sidewalk, boulevard, alley or other public way, lake, river, watercourse or fountain, and any public park, square, space, ground, or building. 
    Used oil. That which is defined in Ohio Revised Code Section 3734.01. 
    Vehicle. Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon land or water, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Waste container. A metal or hard plastic, watertight, container of sufficient strength to support the weight of the contents, and covered with a tight, close fitting lid or cover of a type sufficient to prevent animals from gaining access thereto. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82; Am. Ord. 30065-02, passed 1-30-02) 
Sec. 98.02. - Waste and litter disposal. 
(A)  No person shall deposit a single item of litter, or cause a single item of litter to be deposited, on private property or public property within the city, except in a waste container or at a licensed disposal facility. 
(B)  No person shall deposit more than a single item of litter, or cause more than a single item of litter to be deposited, on private property or public property within the city, except in a waste container or at a licensed disposal facility. 
(C)  No person shall deposit, or cause to be deposited bulk waste, demolition matter, hazardous waste, infectious waste or used oil on public property or private property within the city, except at a licensed disposal facility. 
(D)  No person shall deposit bulk waste, demolition matter or used oil into a waste container collected by the city. 
(E)  No person shall deposit hazardous waste or infectious waste into a waste container collected by the city. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82; Am. Ord. 30065-02, passed 1-30-02) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.03. - Prevention of scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.04. - Upsetting or tampering with receptacles. 
    No person shall upset or tamper with a public or private receptacle designed or used for the deposit of litter or cause or permit its contents to be deposited or strewn in or upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.05. - Sidewalks and alleys to be kept free from litter. 
    Persons owning, occupying or in control of any public place or private premises shall keep the sidewalks and alleys adjacent thereto free of litter, and shall maintain such receptacles as may be required by the regulations issued promulgated by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.06. - Owner to maintain private premises. 
(A)  The owner or person in control of any private premises shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. 
(B)  The owner or person in control of private premises shall, if public receptacles are unavailable, maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.07. - Littering from vehicles. 
(A)  No person, while the operator of or passenger in a vehicle, shall deposit litter upon any public place or private premises. 
(B)  No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any public place or private premises. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any public place or private premises, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter, or foreign matter of any kind. 
(C)  It shall be the responsibility of both the owner of the real property and general contractor in charge of a construction site from which the truck or vehicle is driven, along with the owner, driver or person in charge of such truck or vehicle to cause any accumulated mud, dirt, litter, sticky substances or debris to be removed from the tires of such truck or other vehicle before it is operated upon any street, alley, roadway or other public place. Failure to remove such accumulated mud or debris shall constitute a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82; Am. Ord. 28531, passed 4-29-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.08. - Littering from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop, or deposit within the city any litter. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.09. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall deposit litter in any park within the city except in receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried, or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any other public place or private premises. Where receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be removed from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere in a lawful manner. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.10. - Handbills. 
(A)  Public places. No person shall deposit or unlawfully sell any handbill in or upon any public place. Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any public place for any person to hand out or distribute without charge to the receiver, any handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
(B)  Private premises. No person shall deposit or unlawfully distribute any handbill in or upon private premises, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the occupant of such private premises. Provided, however, that in case of private premises which are not posted against the receiving of handbills or similar material, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so may securely place any such handbill in such a manner as to prevent such handbill from being deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises, except mailboxes may not be so used when prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(C)  Placing handbills on vehicles. No person shall deposit any handbill in or upon any vehicle unless the occupant of a vehicle is willing to accept it. 
(D)  Clean-up. It shall be the responsibility of any person distributing handbills to maintain the area which they are utilizing free of any litter caused by or related to any handbill distribution. 
(E)  Exemptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution upon private premises only of newspapers, official publications of governmental agencies, or political literature; except that newspapers and political literature shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.11. - Posting notices prohibited. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster, or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public upon any public place or private premises, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.12. - Construction sites. 
(A)  Each contractor shall be responsible for the job site in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(B)  Litter or other debris, including dirt and mud, deposited as the result of normal construction process upon any public place or private premises, shall be removed. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.13. - Loading and unloading docks 
    The person owning, operating, or in control of a loading or unloading dock shall maintain authorized private receptacles for collection of litter, and shall at all times maintain the dock area free of litter in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.14. - Parking lots. 
(A)  Litter receptacles required. Any public place or private premises containing any provision for parking vehicles shall be equipped with litter receptacles in compliance with this section and the regulations promulgated by the Director of Public Works. Such premises shall include but not be limited to such places as shopping centers, outdoor theaters, drive-in restaurants, gasoline service stations, apartment developments, parking lots, and any other place where provision is made for vehicles to stop or park in a designated area for any purpose. In lieu of compliance with the receptacle requirements, the City Manager may approve a plan for litter control through an authorized sweeping program or other means. 
(B)  Number of receptacles. All premises having parking lots shall provide in an easily accessible location, a minimum of two refuse containers for up to 20 spaces and at least one additional refuse container for every 50 additional parking spaces. 
(C)  Specifications. Litter receptacles shall have tight fitting lids or tops and shall be weighted or attached to the ground or other fixed structures as necessary to prevent spillage. A minimum litter container size of 20 gallons shall be used with all containers being an easily identifiable color with proper markings indicating litter receptacles. 
(D)  Cleanliness. Premises used for the purpose designated herein shall be kept in a litter free condition and all litter shall be removed periodically from the receptacles. 
(E)  Obligation to use receptacles. It shall be the duty and obligation of all persons using parking areas to use such litter receptacles as hereinabove provided for the purposes intended and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to deposit upon any such parking lot any litter. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Sec. 98.15. - Rules and regulations. 
    The City Manager shall adopt rules and regulations for the enforcement of §§ 98.01 through 98.15. Such rules and regulations shall become effective when approved by motion of the Commission. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 98.99. 
Secs. 98.16-98.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 98.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any person who violates § 98.02(A) is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  Any person who violates §§ 98.05, 98.06, 98.10, 98.11, 98.12, 98.13 or 98.14 shall be fined not more than $500.00. 
(C)  Any person who violates § 98.02(D) is guilty of a fourth degree misdemeanor. 
(D)  Any person who violates §§ 98.02(B), 98.03, 98.04, 98.07, 98.08, or 98.09 is guilty of a third degree misdemeanor. 
(E)  Any person who violates § 98.02(C) or (E) is guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(F)  The sentencing court may, in addition to the penalty provided in this section, require a person who violates any provision of this chapter to remove and lawfully dispose of litter, bulk waste, hazardous waste, infectious waste, used oil and demolition matter from any public property or private property within the city, or pay the cost thereof. 
(Ord. 26603, passed 9-1-82; Am. Ord. 26998, passed 5-23-84; Am. Ord. 30065-02, passed 1-30-02) 
CHAPTER 99. - NONRESIDENTIAL BUILDING MAINTENANCE 
DIVISION 1. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 99.01. - Title. 
    These regulations shall be known as the Nonresidential Building Maintenance Code of the City of Dayton, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.02. - Scope. 
    Provisions of this code shall apply to every building and its premises which may be used in whole or in part for nonresidential purposes. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.03. - Purpose. 
    This code establishes minimum standards for the maintenance of the exterior of nonresidential buildings and the grounds surrounding such buildings. This code does not replace or modify standards otherwise established by law for the construction, replacement, repair, or use of such buildings and their grounds, but is cumulative of such standards and shall apply in addition to them. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.04. - Application of building code. 
    Any repairs or alterations to a structure, or changes of use herein, which may be caused directly or indirectly by the enforcement of this code shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the building code and the zoning code. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.05. - Existing remedies. 
    The provisions in this code shall not be deemed to abolish or impair existing remedies of the jurisdiction or its officers or agencies relating to the removal or demolition of any buildings which are deemed to be dangerous, unsafe, or unsanitary. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.06. - Validity. 
    If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code shall be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, such decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this code which shall continue in full force and effect, and to this end the provisions of this code are hereby declared to be severable. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.07. - Enforcement authority. 
    The Superintendent of Inspectional Services or his or her employees or agents shall have the authority to enforce all the provisions of this code relative to the maintenance of structures and premises. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.08. - Disclaimer. 
(A)  No officer, agent, or employee of the city shall render himself or herself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his or her duties under this chapter. 
(B)  Inspections are made by the city solely for the public purpose of enforcing the ordinances of the city. No representation is made that any order issued pursuant to this chapter contains a complete list of all violations which exist on the premises, nor shall the city accept any responsibility whatsoever to any person, firm, or corporation for any damage done or injury suffered as a result of poor workmanship or unserviceability of any work done or materials used pursuant to such order, or as a result of the failure of any person, firm, or corporation to correct the violations listed therein, or for any reason whatsoever. All owners, occupants, invitees, guests, or other persons using any premises which are subject to the provisions of this chapter shall do so at their own risk, without remedy against the City of Dayton, its officers, agents, or employees. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.09. - Notices and orders. 
    The Division of Inspectional Services may issue all necessary notices and orders to abate illegal or unsafe conditions to insure compliance with the code requirements for the safety, health, and general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.10. - Entry and inspection of premises. 
(A)  Subject to applicable provisions of law, the nonresidential building maintenance inspector, in enforcing provisions of this code, is authorized to enter upon any premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections and performing duties under this code. 
(B)  If permission cannot be obtained, or if for any other reason an inspector is unable to enter or obtain free access to a structure for the purpose of inspection, the inspector may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an appropriate warrant or other court order, or the inspector may make the inspection in any other manner authorized by law. 
(C)  Every occupant of a nonresidential structure shall give the owner thereof or his or her agent or employee access to any part of such structure or its premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter or any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.11. - Rule making authority. 
    The Superintendent of Inspectional Services shall have power as may be necessary in the interest of public safety, health and general welfare, to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations to interpret and implement the provisions of this code to secure the intent thereof and to designate requirements applicable because of local climatic or other conditions; but such rules shall not have the effect of waiving working stresses or fire protection requirements specifically provided in this code or violating accepted engineering practice involving public safety. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.12. - Notice of violation. 
    Whenever the nonresidential building maintenance inspector determines that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, the division shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible therefor and order compliance with this chapter as hereinafter provided. Such notice and order shall: 
(A)  Be put in writing on an appropriate form; 
(B)  Include a list of violations, refer to the section or sections of this chapter violated and order remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter; 
(C)  Specify a reasonable time for performance; 
(D)  Advise the owner, operator, occupant, or agent of the procedure for appeal; 
(E)  Be served on the owner, operator, occupant, or agent in person. However, this notice and order shall be deemed to be properly served upon the owner, operator, occupant, or agent if a copy thereof is sent by registered or certified mail to his or her last known mailing address, residence, or place of business, and a copy is posted in a conspicuous place in or on the structure affected. If a registered or certified mail envelope is returned with an endorsement showing that service was refused, the notice may be served by ordinary mail to his or her last known mailing address, residence, or place of business. The mailing shall be evidenced by a certificate of mailing, and service shall be deemed complete on the date of mailing. If the registered or certified mail envelope is returned with an endorsement showing that service was unclaimed, the notice may be served by ordinary mail to his or her last known mailing address, residence, or place of business. The mailing shall be evidenced by a certificate of mailing, and service shall be deemed complete on the date of mailing, provided that the ordinary mail envelope is not returned by the postal authorities with an endorsement showing failure of delivery. 
    The notice and order may, in the alternative, be served by leaving it at his or her last known residence or place of business in the presence of a family member or other responsible person of suitable age and discretion who shall be informed of the general nature of the contents thereof. If service is not accomplished by any of the above means, then a notification of the existence of such notice and order may be published at least once in a local newspaper of general circulation. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.13. - Failure to comply. 
    Any person failing to comply with an order served pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a third-degree misdemeanor, punishable as provided by §§ 99.99 and 130.99 of this Code. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87; Am. Ord. 30795-08, passed 9-24-08) 
Sec. 99.14. - Nonresidential buildings appeal. 
(A)  The Nonresidential Building Maintenance Board is authorized and empowered to conduct hearings authorized by this chapter, and to interpret the intent of this chapter in specific cases where, upon appeal, it clearly appears that, by reason of special conditions, undue hardship would result from a literal application of any section of this chapter. Where such undue hardship is clearly demonstrated, the board may permit a variance from the applicable section if the building or premises will vary only a reasonable minimum from the literal provision of this chapter but will comply with the spirit and intent of the chapter with respect to sanitation, safety, and rehabilitation. 
(B)  The Nonresidential Building Maintenance Board shall consist of five members to be appointed by the Commission. All members of the board shall be citizens of the United States and residents of the city. One member shall be a licensed real estate broker or salesman, one member shall be engaged in the construction business, one member shall be an owner or supervisory employee of a business which furnishes goods or services to the consumer, one member shall be the city's Chief Building Official or his designee, and one member shall be the city's Chief Neighborhood Conservation Officer or his designee. 
    Each member shall serve for a term of three years or until his successor has been duly appointed. The board shall elect a president and vice-president to serve for a term of one year. The Superintendent of Inspectional Services shall designate an employee of that division to act as secretary to the board, who shall maintain its records and minutes of all proceedings. The City Commission has the power to remove any member of the board for cause upon written charges and after a public hearing. Vacancies upon the board shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has become vacant in the manner herein provided for the appointment of such member. The members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(C)  All decisions and findings of the Nonresidential Building Maintenance Board on an appeal shall be final, but in all instances shall be subject to judicial review in the manner provided in R.C. Chapter 2506. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.15. - Hearings. 
(A)  Any person affected by any notice and order which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this chapter and authorized herein may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Nonresidential Building Maintenance Board provided that such person shall file with the Superintendent of Inspectional Services a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth the name, address, and phone number of the petitioner and a brief statement of the grounds for such hearing or for the mitigation of any item appearing on any order of the Division of Inspectional Services. The petition shall be filed within 20 days after the date of the notice and order, and shall be accompanied by an appeal fee in the amount of $110.00. On receipt of such a petition, a time and place for the hearing shall be set and the petitioner shall be given written notice thereof. The hearings shall be commenced within a reasonable time after a petition has been filed. 
    At such hearing the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why any item appearing on such notice and order should be modified or withdrawn. The failure of the petitioner or his or her representative to appear and state his or her case at such hearing shall have the same effect as if no petition were filed. 
(B)  After a hearing, the board shall sustain, modify, or withdraw any item appearing on the notice and order, depending on its findings as to whether the provisions of this chapter have been complied with, and the petitioner shall be notified in writing of such findings. 
(C)  The proceedings at such hearings, including the findings and decision of the board and reasons therefore shall be summarized and reduced to writing and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the Division of Inspectional Services. Such record shall also include a copy of every notice and order issued in connection with the matter. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87; Am. Ord. 30822-09, § 2, passed 1-7-09) 
Sec. 99.16. - Transfer of ownership. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any structure who has received a compliance order or upon whom a notice of violation has been served to sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of such premises to another until the provisions of the compliance order or notice of violation have been complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee a true copy of any compliance order or notice of violation issued by the code official and shall furnish to the code official a signed and notarized statement from the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such compliance order or notice of violation and accepting the responsibility for making the corrections or repairs required by such compliance order or notice of violation. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.17. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this chapter are defined in the building code (chapter 152 of this Code) and the housing code (§ 93.02 of this Code). Where terms are not defined by either the building code or housing code they shall have ascribed to them their ordinarily accepted meanings or such as the context herein may imply. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.18. - Responsibility of owner for facilities. 
    Every owner of a nonresidential building shall be responsible for the provision of all facilities, services, or conditions required by this chapter, except where such responsibility is assumed by an operator or occupant by written agreement. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Secs. 99.19-99.29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PREMISES CONDITIONS 

Sec. 99.30. - Sanitation. 
    All exterior property areas and premises shall be maintained in a clean, safe and sanitary condition free from any accumulation of rubbish, trash, garbage or other noxious or offensive materials. This shall include but is not limited to the following: Brush; weeds; broken glass; stumps; roots; obnoxious growths; debris; inoperative machinery or parts thereof; dead or dying trees and limbs; holes; excavation; breaks; projections; obstructions; and excretions of pets and other animals. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.31. - Containers. 
    Approved containers with close fitting covers shall be provided which are capable of storing all waste materials until removed from the premises for disposal. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.32. - Landscaping. 
    Lawns, hedges and bushes shall be cut or pruned in order to prevent them from encroaching upon streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways, or from becoming a public nuisance or a blighting factor which depreciates adjoining property. Exterior open spaces shall be maintained or improved so as to provide for grass, plantings, or other suitable ground cover to prevent soil erosion which is or may become detrimental to the structures, lot use, or adjacent lots and structures. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.33. - Grading and drainage. 
    All premises shall be graded and maintained so as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or within any structure located thereon. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.34. - Loading areas. 
    All loading areas, automobile service stations and drive-in food establishments shall be paved with bituminous, concrete or equivalent hard surfacing and shall be kept in good repair. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.35. - Insect and pest control. 
    All premises shall be maintained so as to prevent infestation by insects, rodents, pigeons, or other pests. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.36. - Public areas. 
    All sidewalks, steps, driveways, parking spaces and similar paved areas shall be of sound construction and maintained free of defects or objects, materials, or conditions which create a health, safety, or fire hazard, or which are a public nuisance. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.37. - Noxious weeds. 
    All areas shall be kept free from weeds or plant growth which are noxious or detrimental to the public health and welfare. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.38. - Storage areas. 
    Except as provided in the zoning code (chapter 150 of this Code), all open salvage yards and open storage areas shall be completely obscured from surrounding property by a solid screen not less than six feet in height. Used or salvaged materials such as doors, scrap lumber and metal shall not be utilized as screening materials. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.39. - Accessory structures. 
    All accessory structures, including detached garages, fences and walls shall be maintained structurally sound or such structures shall be removed from the premises. The exterior of such structures shall be made weather resistant. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.40. - Motor vehicles. 
    Except as provided in the zoning code (chapter 150 of this Code), no unregistered motor vehicle shall at any time be stored on the premises nor shall any motor vehicle be in a state of major disassembly or disrepair, nor shall it be in the process of being stripped or dismantled. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Secs. 99.41-99.49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXTERIOR STRUCTURE 

Sec. 99.50. - General. 
    The exterior of a structure shall be maintained structurally sound and sanitary so as not to pose a threat to the health and safety of occupants and so as to shelter occupants from the elements. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.51. - Structural members. 
    All supporting structural members of all structures shall be kept structurally sound, free of deterioration and maintained capable of safely bearing the dead and live loads imposed upon them. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.52. - Foundation walls. 
    Foundations shall support the building at all points and shall be free of all holes and cracks which admit rodents, water or dampness to the interior of the building or lessen the capability of the foundation to support the building. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.53. - Exterior surfaces. 
    Every exterior surface shall be free of holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timbers, and any other conditions which might admit rain or dampness to the interior portions of the walls or to the occupied spaces of the building. All exterior surface materials, including wood, composition, or metal, shall be maintained weatherproof and shall be properly surface coated when required to prevent deterioration. All painted surfaces shall be maintained free of peeling or flaking paint. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.54. - Roofs. 
    The roof shall be structurally sound, tight, and not have defects which might admit rain, and roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent rain water from causing dampness in the walls or interior portion of the building. Rain gutters, downspouts and leaders, when provided to collect, conduct and discharge water from the roof, shall be maintained so as not to leak or cause dampness in the walls, ceilings, or basements or adversely affect the adjacent properties or public ways. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.55. - Decorative features. 
    All cornices, entablatures, belt courses, corbels, terra cotta trim, wall facings and similar decorative features shall be maintained in good repair with proper anchorage and in a safe condition. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.56. - Signs, marquees, and awnings. 
    All canopies, marquees, signs, metal awnings, stairways, porches, fire escapes, standpipes, exhaust ducts, air conditioners, and similar overhanging extensions shall be maintained so as to be free of missing, defective, rotting or deteriorated foundations, supports, floors, other members, and steps thereto, so as to be safe to use and kept in sound condition and in good repair. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.57. - Chimneys. 
    All chimneys, cooling towers, smoke stacks, and similar appurtenances shall be maintained structurally safe, sound, and in good repair. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.58. - Weathertight and secure. 
    Every window and exterior door shall be fitted reasonably in its frame and be weathertight, or, the openings shall be secured with exterior grade plywood so as to keep out intruders. Where windows and/or doors have been boarded, the boards shall closely fit the openings and be painted to match the color of surrounding walls. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.59. - Glazing. 
    Every window sash which is not boarded shall be fully supplied with approved glass or other glazing materials which are without open cracks and holes. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.60. - Display windows. 
    All display windows shall be kept free of foreign substances, except when necessary in the course of changing displays. No storage or materials, stock or inventory shall be permitted in window display areas or other areas ordinarily exposed to public view unless such areas are first screened from public view by drapes, by venetian blinds, or by other rendering of the windows to make them opaque to the public view. All such screening of interiors shall be maintained in a clean and attractive manner and kept in a good state of repair. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Sec. 99.61. - Facades. 
    All facades shall be kept in good repair, and shall not constitute a safety hazard or a nuisance. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87) 
Secs. 99.62-99.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 99.99. - Penalty. 
    A violation of any provision of this chapter, or the failure to comply with any of the requirements contained therein, constitutes an offense of a misdemeanor of the third degree, punishable as provided by § 130.99. No culpable mental state is required to commit an offense; it being the express intent of this section to impose strict criminal liability for each offense. Each day a violation continues is a separate offense. 
(Ord. 27557, passed 6-10-87; Am. Ord. 30795-08, passed 9-24-08) 
Title XI - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
Chapter 
110. Advertising 111. Amusements 112. Businesses 113. Electricity 114. Plumbing and Heating 115. Public Transportation 116. Totalink Cable Television Franchise 117. Electric Franchise 118. Gas Franchise 119. Steam Franchise 120. Video Service Authorizations  
CHAPTER 110. - ADVERTISING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 110.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of §§ 110.01 through 110.17, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Cost. The invoice cost of merchandise less all trade discounts, except customary discounts for cash, plus any excise tax imposed on such merchandise or the sale thereof, other than excise taxes collected from the purchaser. 
    In stock readily available. Displayed in plain sight in a person's store or capable of being obtained on request at that store. 
(Ord. 24472, passed 4-4-73) 
Sec. 110.02. - Sales practices prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall advertise for sale food, grocery products, or other merchandise of any kind as being sold at a certain price unless the advertised food, grocery products, or other merchandise are in stock and readily available and marked for sale at the advertised price in all of that person's stores located within the area in which the food, grocery products, or other merchandise is advertised. If the merchandise is not in plain sight, adequate notice must be given in the store that the merchandise is available on request at the advertised price. 
(B)  There shall be no violation of this section if the person clearly, conspicuously, and specifically discloses in all such advertisements all exceptions, limitations, or restrictions with respect to stores, products, or prices otherwise included within the advertisements. General disclaimers, including, but not limited to, "not available at all stores," do not comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. 24472, passed 4-4-73) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.03. - Advertised items available. 
    No person shall fail to make items advertised for sale below cost conspicuously and readily available for sale at or below the advertised price. 
(Ord. 24472, passed 4-4-73) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.04. - Bait advertising prohibited. 
    No person shall in any manner, or by any means of advertisement, or other means of communication, offer for sale any food products, merchandise, commodity, or service as part of a plan or scheme with the intent, design, or purpose not to sell the food products, merchandise, commodity, or service so advertised, but to induce the buyer to buy instead, food products, merchandise, commodity, or service represented to be materially better than the food products, merchandise, commodity, or service so advertised. 
(Ord. 24472, passed 4-4-73) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.05. - False or misleading advertising prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall, with intent, directly or indirectly, dispose of real or personal property, or perform services, professional or otherwise, or do any thing of any nature whatsoever, or induce the public to enter into any obligation relating thereto, make or disseminate or cause to be made or disseminated before the public in any newspaper or other publication, or any advertising device, or by public outcry or proclamation or in any other manner or means whatsoever, any statement, concerning such real or personal property or services, professional or otherwise, or concerning any circumstances or matter of fact connected with the proposed disposition thereof, which is untrue, deceptive, or misleading. 
(B)  No person shall make or disseminate or cause to be made or disseminated any false or misleading statement as part of a plan or scheme with intent not to sell such real or personal property; or services, professional or otherwise, so advertised at the price stated therein, or as so advertised. 
(Ord. 24472, passed 4-4-73) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.06. - Consent orders. 
    The consumer advocate is vested with authority to enter into consent orders with any alleged violator of §§ 110.02 through 110.05, setting forth the terms on which the alleged violator shall cease and desist the alleged violations. No further action shall be taken in connection with the violation if the alleged violator abides by the terms of the consent order. 
(Ord. 24472, passed 4-4-73) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.07. - Misleading advertisements of optometrists. 
    No person, engaged in or connected with the sale of eyeglasses, lenses, eyeglass frames, or mountings shall include in any advertisement, by newspaper, radio, television, display, or otherwise, any statement which in any manner misrepresents any such items, or other material, the price of lenses, or of complete eyeglasses, including lenses, either with or without professional services, or credit terms, installment payments, or price plans, or the price of any frames or mountings, unless in conjunction therewith the words "without lenses" appear. 
(Ord. 15658, passed 4-8-42) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.08. - Advertising vehicles. 
    The driving of a vehicle upon the streets of the city solely for the purposes of advertising is prohibited. 
(Ord. 12883, passed 6-23-26) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.09. - Streamers across streets. 
    No person shall erect or maintain any streamer or advertising sign of any description which extends across any street of the city either from one building to another or from a pole or other support to some building or support on the opposite side of the street. 
(Ord. 12623, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 17496, passed 8-27-52) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.10. - Advertising matter on structures across streets prohibited. 
    No advertising material of any kind or character shall be put or placed, by affixing, painting, or otherwise, upon any building or structure crossing any of the streets or public ways of the city whether on or above the surface thereof. 
(Ord. 20010, passed 7-5-61) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.11. - Existing signs to be removed. 
    Any signs in violation of § 110.10 now in existence in the city, whether on railroad bridges or on any other structures on or above the City Streets are declared to be a nuisance and shall be removed within 30 days from the receipt of a request in writing by the Director of Public Works so to do. 
(Ord. 20010, passed 7-5-61) 
Sec. 110.12. - Cost of removal of sign, paid. 
    That in the event of noncompliance with § 110.11, the Director of Public Works may, in addition to instituting a prosecution for the violation of this section, cause any such sign to be removed or painted out as the need may be; that he shall thereupon notify the person, firm, or corporation affected thereby, by notice to either the owner or agent of the cost of such removal and said sum shall be paid to the city within 60 days thereafter. 
(Ord. 20010, passed 7-5-61) 
Sec. 110.13. - Advertising on public property. 
(A)  No person shall place any placard, notice, or advertisement of any kind on any public property situated in any park or on any boulevard or levee in the city. 
(B)  This section shall not be construed to prohibit the placing of appropriate advertising signs by the park management of articles for sale in the park or signs containing the necessary notices of the park management in any park within the city upon permission first received from the Director of Human Resources. 
(Ord. 12693, passed 12-30-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.14. - Handbills not to be thrown on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in distributing handbills or other advertising matter to throw, cast, or deposit, or cause such handbills to be thrown, cast, or deposited in or upon any yard, doorstep, porch, street, alley, lane or public place within the city. 
(Ord. 9677, passed 8-5-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.15. - Disturbing citizens by distributing handbills. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person distributing handbills or other advertising matter to ring the doorbell, sound the door-knocker, or otherwise to call the inmates of any residence to the door for the purpose of receiving such handbills or other advertising matter which he, or any person with him may be distributing. 
(Ord. 9677, passed 8-5-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.16. - Handbills in motor vehicles. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to place any handbills, circulars, cards, papers, or other advertising matter or novelties in or hang the same on any part of any motor vehicle or cause the same to be done, while such motor vehicle is in use on the streets or standing parked on the streets of the city. 
(B)  This section shall not be construed to prevent the officers or employees of the city from so doing for any municipal purpose. 
(Ord. 11067, passed 2-25-20) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.17. - Jurisdiction; venue. 
(A)  In the prosecution of any violations of §§ 110.02, 110.03, 110.04, 110.05, or 110.07, any advertisement containing the name, identity, or the geographic location of a person or persons shall constitute prima facie evidence that such advertisement was placed by or with the knowledge of or with the consent of such person or persons. 
(B)  In the prosecution of any violation of §§ 110.02, 110.03, 110.04, 110.05, or 110.07, the element of the advertisement or advertising for the purpose of establishing jurisdiction or venue may be determined by, among other means, any of the following: 
(1)  The location or locations enumerated in the advertisement at which the items or services are advertised as being available. 
(2)  The actual location or locations where the items or services enumerated in the advertisement are available, if the advertisement does not list specific locations. 
(3)  The location or locations where the advertisement was actually distributed to or received by a potential consumer, when the defendant acted recklessly with regard to such distribution or reception. 
(Ord. 25619, passed 10-4-78) 
Secs. 110.18, 110.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADVERTISING ON HIGHWAYS 

Sec. 110.20. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of §§ 110.20 through 110.26 the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Advertising device. Any outdoor sign, display, device, figure, painting, drawing, message, placard, poster, billboard, or any other contrivance designed, intended, or used to advertise or to give information in the nature of advertising, or any part thereof, which advertisement is visible from the traveled way of any highway on the interstate system or primary system in this state. 
    Erect. To construct or allow to be constructed, except as an incident to the change of an advertising message or normal maintenance of a sign or sign structure. 
    Interstate system. The system of highways as defined in subsection (e)(1), 23 U.S.C.A. 103, 84 Stat. 1716 (1970) or amendments thereof. 
    Maintain. To preserve, keep in repair, continue, allow to exist, or restore if destroyed by an act of God, vandalism, or other means. 
    National policy. The provisions relating to control of advertising signs, displays, and devices adjacent to the interstate system and primary system contained in the "National Highway Beautification Act of 1965", 79 Stat. 1028, 23 U.S.C.A. 131, and the national standards, criteria, and rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to such provisions. 
    Primary system. That portion of the state highway system as designated or as may hereafter be designated by the state, which has been approved by the Secretary of Transportation of the United States pursuant to subsection (b), 23 U.S.C.A. 103, 70 Stat. 374 (1956). 
    Visible. Capable of being seen, whether or not legible, without visual aid by a person of normal acuity. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Sec. 110.21. - Location of advertising devices along interstate highways. 
    No advertising device shall be erected or maintained within 660 feet of the edge of the right-of-way of a highway on the interstate system, except the following: 
(A)  Directional or other official signs or notices that are required or authorized by law; 
(B)  Signs advertising the sale or lease of the property on which they are located; 
(C)  Advertising devices indicating the name of the business or profession conducted on such property or which identify the goods produced, sold, or services rendered on such property. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.22. - Location of advertising devices along primary highways. 
    No advertising device shall be erected within 660 feet of the edge of the right-of-way of a highway on the primary system, except the following: 
(A)  Directional and other official signs and notices, required or authorized by law, signs and notices pertaining to natural wonders or scenic and historical attractions, which shall conform to regulations promulgated by the Ohio Director of Highways consistent with the national policy; provided that no such sign or notice shall be erected until a permit is obtained as provided for in § 150.371 of the zoning code; 
(B)  Signs advertising the sale or lease of the property on which they are located; 
(C)  Advertising devices indicating the name of the business, activities, or profession conducted on such property, or which identify the goods produced, sold, or services rendered on such property; 
(D)  Precautionary signs relating to the premises; 
(E)  Signs, displays, or devices which locate, identify, mark, or warn of the presence of pipe lines, utility lines, or rail lines, and appurtenances thereof, including, but not limited to, markers used in the maintenance, operation, observation and safety of said lines. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Sec. 110.23. - Regulation of advertising devices along interstate and primary highways. 
(A)  The Superintendent of Building Inspection shall promulgate and enforce regulations consistent with customary use in outdoor advertising and national policy governing any or all aspects of the advertising devices to be erected or maintained within 660 feet of the edge of the right-of-way of a highway on the interstate or primary systems, and coming within the exceptions contained in §§ 110.21 and 110.22. These regulations shall include, but not be limited to, size, lighting, spacing, and such other conditions as may be necessary to affect the national policy. The superintendent shall furnish a copy of such regulations to any person making a request therefor. 
(B)  The Superintendent of Building Inspection may adopt such amendments to such regulations as are necessary and consistent with customary use in outdoor advertising and the national policy. 
(C)  Such regulations shall be in addition to the provisions of any city ordinance regulating advertising devices. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Sec. 110.24. - Prohibition of advertising devices. 
    Sections 110.21 and 110.22 shall not be construed to allow the erection of an advertising device in an area zoned to exclude such devices. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Sec. 110.25. - Nonconforming advertising devices. 
    Any advertising device lawfully in existence prior to July 28, 1972, or lawfully on any highway made a part of the interstate or primary system on or after July 28, 1972, the erection of which would be illegal under §§ 110.21 and 110.22, is nonconforming. Any such nonconforming advertising device may be maintained and shall not be ordered removed by the Superintendent of Building Inspection, but such advertising devices are subject to the permit provisions of § 150.371. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Sec. 110.26. - Permits required. 
    No private off-premises advertising device shall be erected or a conforming advertising device maintained within the areas covered by §§ 110.21 and 110.22, without the permit required by § 150.371. No nonconforming advertising device may be maintained without such permit. 
(Ord. 24301, passed 6-14-72; Am. Ord. 24308, passed 6-28-72) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 110.99. 
Secs. 110.27-110.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 110.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Whoever violates §§ 110.14, 110.15, or 110.16 of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  Whoever violates any other provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
CHAPTER 111. - AMUSEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - BILLIARD ROOMS AND BOWLING ALLEYS (Reserved) 

Secs. 111.1-111.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOXING COMMISSION 

Sec. 111.20. - Boxing Commission created. 
    There is created a City Boxing Commission consisting of not less than three members to be appointed by the City Commission. 
(Ord. 16176, passed 3-12-47; Am. Ord. 26485, passed 3-31-82) 
Sec. 111.21. - Adoption of the Ohio Boxing Law by reference. 
(A)  The Ohio Boxing Law, being particularly R.C. §§ 3773.31 through 3773.58, and the administrative rules of the State Boxing Commission are incorporated and adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter with the same force and effect as though set out in full herein. 
(B)  A copy of the Ohio Boxing Law and the administrative rules of the State Boxing Commission shall be on file and open for inspection in the office of the Clerk of the City Commission, the Division of Recreation and Parks, the Department of Human and Neighborhood Resources, and in the Montgomery County Law Library. The Clerk of the City Commission shall also keep copies of the Ohio Boxing Law and the administrative rules of the State Boxing Commission available for distribution to the public at cost. 
(Ord. 26485, passed 3-31-82) 
Secs. 111.22-111.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DANCE HALLS AND PUBLIC DANCES 

Sec. 111.40. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 111.40 through 111.59, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Dance hall. Any room, place or space in which a public dance shall be held, or in which classes in dancing are conducted, or instruction in dancing given for hire, except the hall or quarters of a bona fide religious, charitable, or fraternal organization when in use by its own members, and not sublet to any person or organization for the purpose of giving a public dance or for conducting a class in dancing or giving instruction in dancing for hire. 
    Known public character. Known to the manager, owner, or lessee of a public dance hall or to the person conducting a public dance or conducting a class or classes in dancing, or to the police, or the dance hall inspector, or to other officers or authorities whose duty it may be to regulate or supervise dance halls and public dances, to be one of the persons named or who has the reputation or character or has plead guilty or been convicted of being a public character, a male or female procurer, or vagrant, or of a crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
    Public dance. Any dance to which admission may be had by the payment, directly or indirectly, of a fee, or any dance to which the public generally may gain admission with or without the payment of a fee, including any dance conducted or permitted in connection with the operation of a restaurant, hotel, beer garden, or other place where food or drinks are sold for consumption on the premises. A dance given by a bona fide religious, charitable, or fraternal order, for its members only and their families, shall not be included. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23; Am. Ord. 14920, passed 5-20-36) 
Sec. 111.41. - Public dance hall license required. 
    No person shall hold or conduct any public dance, or hold or conduct classes in dancing for hire, or give instruction in dancing for hire, in any dance hall or place within the city, until the dance hall or place has first been duly licensed. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.42. - Requirements for license. 
(A)  A license may be issued by the City Accountant to the owner or lessee of a dance hall upon application therefor and payment of the fee fixed herein. However, application must be approved by the Police Department after investigation by the appropriate police investigative unit as designated by the Director of Police. 
(B)  Approval shall not be given if a license of the applicant has been revoked pursuant to § 111.53 within the six months prior to the application, or if the applicant, within the six months preceding, has been convicted of any of the violations enumerated. 
(C)  The building, room, or place to be licensed must comply with the requirements of all the laws, ordinances, and regulations applicable to health, sanitation, building inspection, and fire protection and prevention. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.43. - Inspection of premises. 
    The General Health District, the Superintendent of Building Inspection, and the Director of Fire, shall make inspections of buildings, structures, and places sought to be licensed hereunder, and report findings to the City Accountant, and render such further assistance as may be necessary to enable the City Accountant to determine the propriety of issuing a license. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.44. - Floor space for dancing. 
    All persons who apply for dance hall licenses shall have floor space for dancing in their potential dance hall site equal to the booth or table space used therein, with a minimum of 1,200 square feet of clear floor space for dancing. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.45. - Lighting. 
(A)  Minimum horizontal lighting intensity. All parts of all floor areas in rooms operated or used as dance halls shall be illuminated to a minimum horizontal lighting intensity of not less than three foot candles at all times such areas or parts thereof are utilized by or available to the public or patrons for dancing. 
(B)  Authorization of light meter readings by City Inspector. Lighting intensities shall be determined by a duly authorized agent of the city from readings with a standard light meter. Light meter readings shall be taken with the light sensitive cell in an approximately horizontal position at any unobstructed and unshaded point not less than 30 inches nor more than 40 inches above the floor in the areas considered. 
Sec. 111.46. - Obstruction of view into dance hall prohibited. 
    No dance hall operating in this city shall cover its windows or doors with any material that obstructs a clear view from the outside into and through the dance hall. 
Sec. 111.47. - Sanitary regulations. 
    All dance halls must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and comply strictly with all applicable regulations promulgated by the General Health District. 
Sec. 111.48. - Toilets. 
(A)  Requirements and specifications. In all dance halls, there shall be separate toilet rooms for men and women. In each such room for women there shall be at least one toilet and one lavatory. In each such room for men there shall be at least one toilet, one lavatory, and one urinal. If the rooms are separated only by a partition wall, the wall shall be constructed of soundproof material. There shall be plainly marked about or on the entrance of the toilet rooms, the sex for which it is intended to be used. 
(B)  Entry of public forbidden if noncompliance with requirements. No person shall permit the public to enter any dance hall which has not been equipped as provided in this section. 
Sec. 111.49. - License fee. 
(A)  The fee for a dance hall license shall be $50.00 per year. 
(B)  The fee for a dancing school which does not hold general, public dances and which does not permit dancing except by students of the school, shall be $10.00 per year. 
(C)  In subsection (A) or subsection (B) a license may be issued for a semi-annual period expiring on June 30 or December 31 of any calendar year, and in that case, the fee shall be one-half of the required annual fee. 
(Ord. 16317, passed 12-3-47) 
Sec. 111.50. - Provisions of dance hall license. 
    A dance hall license shall authorize the licensee to conduct public dances and give instruction in dancing in classes or individually and to sublet such hall for like purposes. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.51. - Display of license. 
    Each licensee hereunder shall post his license in a conspicuous place in the dance hall covered by such license. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.52. - Transfer of license. 
    A dance hall license shall not be transferred except in the following cases. Upon application to and with the approval of the City Accountant, the license may be transferred by the holder thereof from one location to any other location which has been previously inspected and approved, or such license may be transferred by the holder to another approved person for use at any location which has been previously inspected and approved as provided in §§ 111.42 and 111.43. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23; Am. Ord. 14862, passed 3-27-35) 
Sec. 111.53. - Revocation of license. 
(A)  Any license issued hereunder may be revoked, after notice and hearing, by the City Accountant upon conviction of the owner, manager, or other person having the management, supervision, or control of such dance hall, or upon the conviction of any person who may be conducting a public dance or classes in dancing in such dance hall, of the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or any other ordinance or law regulating, relating, or appertaining to dance halls or public dances in any respect whatsoever, or for the violation of any law or ordinance regulating the sale, possession, dispensing, or trafficking in intoxicating liquors or beverages, or for the violation of any law or ordinance, which violation amounts to moral turpitude. 
(B)  Upon the revocation of a dance hall license hereunder, no subsequent dance hall license or permit to hold a public dance or conduct classes in dancing shall be issued to such licensee, or to any person acting for such licensee, within six months of the date of such revocation. 
(C)  Upon such revocation of a license, no part of the fee paid therefor shall be returned. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.54. - Public dance permit; approval; fee. 
(A)  No person, not the holder of a public dance hall license, shall hold or conduct a public dance or conduct a class in dancing for hire without first having obtained a permit to do so from the City Accountant. 
(B)  The City Accountant shall not issue any permit pursuant to this section unless the applicant therefor is approved by the Police Department after investigation by the appropriate police investigative unit as designated by the Director of Police, and which approval must be issued at least 48 hours prior to the time when the dance or instruction to a class in dancing is to be given. 
(C)  The Police Department shall not approve the application of any person whose license has been revoked pursuant to § 111.53 within the six-month period immediately preceding, or who, within the preceding six months, has been convicted of any of the violations enumerated. 
(D)  The fee for such permit shall be $5.00 for each public dance, or for each period of instruction given a class in dancing. However, such public dance or instruction must be given in a public dance hall licensed under §§ 111.40 through 111.59. 
(E)  The fee for such permit shall be $10.00 each, if the same is held in a hall or place not licensed under §§ 111.40 through 111.59. 
(F)  The City Accountant shall issue the permit provided for in this section without the payment of any fee when an application for a free permit is made and he is satisfied that the dance or dancing instruction will be conducted for bona fide charitable or philanthropic purposes only. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23; Am. Ord. 16809, passed 11-23-49) 
Sec. 111.55. - Permits not transferable. 
    Permits issued pursuant to § 111.54 shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.56. - Persons under influence of alcohol prohibited in dance halls. 
    No person under the influence of intoxicating liquors shall be permitted to enter any public dance hall. 
Sec. 111.57. - Disorderly conduct in dance halls. 
    No person to whom a dance hall license is issued, his employees, agents, officers, or representatives, and no person acting pursuant to a permit issued under § 111.54, shall countenance or knowingly permit any disorder, any conduct or act of a gross, vile, vulgar, or indecent character or nature in the public dance hall, or at the public dance or class in dancing. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-24-23) 
Sec. 111.58. - Prohibited acts. 
    No person shall do or permit to be done any of the following things: 
(A)  Conduct a public dance later than 1:00 a.m., with the exception of Sunday nights, when the closing time shall be 12:00 midnight, except upon approval of the City Commission, by motion regularly passed and spread upon the minutes of the Commission; 
(B)  Make any discrimination between the sexes in the amount of admission fee charged to a public dance or to a class of dancing; 
(C)  Allow any known male or female procurer, or vagrant to be present at any public dance or any class in dancing; 
(D)  Charge, collect, or receive any separate or individual fee in addition to the regular admission fee for participation in any individual dance at a public dance, since the admission fee entitles each person, paying the same and being legally admitted, to participate in all dancing conducted at the dance; 
(E)  Issue, pass out, or return checks or readmit persons who have left the dance hall and its anterooms, except upon repayment of the regular admission fee; 
(F)  Permit any person under the age of 18 years to attend or remain at any public dance unaccompanied by a parent or his legal guardian. Further, no person shall represent himself as being 18 years of age, or over, when in fact his age is less than 18 years, and no person shall falsely represent himself as a parent or the legal guardian of any person in order that such person may attend or remain at a public dance; 
(G)  Give a public dance under the guise and name of a class in dancing or for instruction in dancing when it is in fact a public dance. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
Sec. 111.59. - Order to vacate premises. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer, or other properly constituted authority of the city, to cause a dance hall to be vacated whenever any provision of this chapter or any other law, ordinance, or regulation appertaining to dance halls is being violated, or whenever any indecent act shall be committed, or any disorder or conduct of a gross, violent, or vulgar character shall take place therein. 
(Ord. 11808, passed 4-25-23) 
DIVISION 4. - SHOOTING GALLERIES 

Sec. 111.60. - Shooting gallery certificate and permit required. 
    No person shall keep or possess, maintain, or use within the city any shooting gallery, shooting range, rifle range, gun club, or other place used for the purpose of shooting in, upon, or over the same at a target, mark, bird, clay pigeon, or other objects, or for testing firearms without first obtaining from the Director of Police a certificate, and from the City Accountant a permit authorizing the establishment and use of the shooting gallery, shooting range, gun club, or other place to be used for any of the purposes enumerated in this section. 
(Ord. 12632, passed 10-28-25) 
Sec. 111.61. - Application for certificate and permit. 
(A)  Any person desiring to maintain, use, or operate a place for any of the purposes enumerated in § 111.60 shall make written application to the Director of Police setting forth the location, character, and use proposed, together with such other and further statement of facts as may be required by the director. The director shall inspect the premises together with the plans for any changes, alterations, remodeling, or new construction which the applicant contemplates making or which may be found necessary by the director in order to properly promote and protect the public safety, and when the Director of Police is satisfied that it will not be detrimental to the public safety to keep, maintain, or use the shooting gallery, range, or club he shall issue a written certificate to the applicant, directed to the City Accountant, authorizing the keeping, maintenance, and use thereof. The certificate so issued by the Director of Police shall include in detail all requirements laid down by the Director in that particular instance in order that the gallery, range, or club may be made safe, and shall refer to the application upon which it is based and both the application and copy of the certificate shall be kept on file in the office of the Director of Police. 
(B)  Upon receipt of the certificate, the written consents required by § 111.63, and the payment of the fee, the City Accountant shall issue a permit to the applicant, which shall expire on December 31 of the year in which issued. 
(C)  Nothing in this section shall be construed or deemed to be in conflict with any of the provisions of chapter 152, the building code, or any lawful orders of the Superintendent of Building Inspection. 
(Ord. 12632, passed 10-28-25) 
Sec. 111.62. - Permit fee. 
(A)  The fee for a permit issued pursuant to §§ 111.60 through 111.64 shall be $50.00 per year. 
(B)  The fee for the renewal of a permit for any year or part thereof shall be $50.00. 
(Ord. 12632, passed 10-28-25) 
Sec. 111.63. - Isolated location required. 
    No person shall erect any shooting range, shooting gallery, or gun club, or maintain or use the same within the city limits unless it shall be so isolated or enclosed within the walls of such thickness, character, and height, and so guarded as to make the shooting gallery, shooting range, or gun club secure, in the opinion of the Director of Police, from glancing balls, or other device used for shooting, passing through or over the walls to the danger of persons or property in the locality of the gallery, range, or club so located. 
(Ord. 12632, passed 10-28-25) 
Sec. 111.64. - Consent of property owners required. 
    No person shall establish, erect, maintain, or use a shooting gallery, shooting range, gun club, or other place described in § 111.60 until he has filed with the City Accountant the written consents of a majority of the owners of property, situated upon the square, or abutting the property when not in a square, in which the person proposes to erect or maintain a shooting range or other place as described in § 111.60. 
(Ord. 12632, passed 10-28-25) 
DIVISION 5. - THEATRICAL PERFORMANCES AND OTHER AMUSEMENTS (Reserved) 

Secs. 111.65-111.99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CANVAS STRUCTURES 

Sec. 111.100. - Permit required. 
    No person shall erect or cause to be erected, any temporary or permanent structure composed wholly or partly of canvas or similar material for the following purposes: circus, carnival, side show, outdoor social or athletic event, religious services, or shelters during construction work, temporary shelters for storages or commercial enterprises, except under a permit from the Director of Fire. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 111.999. 
Sec. 111.101. - Application for permit. 
    Application for a permit hereunder shall be made on proper form and, when deemed necessary by the Director of Fire, shall include plans drawn to scale, showing exits, aisles, seating arrangements, details of structural support of tent, seats, platforms, and any other information which the Director of Fire may require. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.102. - Conditions for permit issuance. 
    No permit shall be issued until the provisions of §§ 111.100 through 111.116 have been complied with and approval has been obtained from the Superintendent of Building Inspection, the Director of Police, and, when tents are used for places of assembly, from each and every department having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.103. - Term of permit. 
    The permit shall not be issued for a period exceeding 30 days and shall be revocable for cause. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.104. - Location of tents. 
(A)  Tents shall not be erected, placed or used in the closely built-up portions of the city and no tent shall be erected to cover more than 75 percent of the premises; nor shall any tent be erected closer than ten feet to other structures except as hereinafter provided. Stake lines of adjacent tents shall be sufficiently distant from each other to provide an area to be used as a means of emergency egress. 
(B)  Concession or other tents need not be separated from each other and may be erected less than ten feet from other tents or structures if the Director of Fire deems such closer spacing safe from hazard to the public. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 111.999. 
Sec. 111.105. - Structural requirements. 
(A)  All supporting members shall be of sufficient size and strength to support the structure. 
(B)  Tents shall be adequately guyed, supported and braced to withstand a wind pressure or suction of ten pounds per square foot. The poles and their supporting guys, stays, stakes, fastenings, shall be of sufficient strength and attached so as to resist wind pressure of 20 pounds per square foot of projected area of the tent. 
(Ord. 15926, passed 7-5-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.106. - Flame resistance. 
(A)  All tents used for assembly, or in which animals are stabled and which exceed 2,400 square feet in area, and all tarpaulins and decorative materials in connection with any of these, shall be of flameproof material, or treated with an approved chemical solution rendering them flameproof. A test shall be made of the tent by the Department of Fire prior to the erection and on the decorative or other materials before they are attached to or placed therein. In lieu of such tests, the Director of Fire may accept a certificate from the manufacturer that the material has been tested by Underwriters Laboratories, Incorporated, or meets the requirements as specified in the federal specification for fire, water and weather resistant cotton duck, CCC-D-746, or he may accept the reports of tests made by other administrative officials or a recognized testing laboratory as evidence that the tents, tarpaulins and decorations have the required resistance to fire. 
(B)  All tents used for assembly or in which animals are stabled and which do not exceed 2,400 square feet in area, need not be of flameproof materials. During all times of occupancy such non-flameproofed tents shall have not less than 20 percent of the side curtain area removed on either side or either end of the tent or otherwise arranged to provide the required open area. The aggregate open area shall be not less than 40 percent of the total side curtain area. 
(C)  All tents used for assembly or in which animals are stabled and which are of less than 1,200 square feet in area need not be of flameproof materials and need not have the required open side curtain area as prescribed in subsection (B). During times of occupancy such tents shall be provided with means of egress as contained in § 111.108 (A).
