(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.107. - Fire hazards. 
(A)  The ground enclosed by any tent used for public assembly, and for a reasonable distance but not less than ten feet outside of such tent, shall be reasonably cleared of all flammable material or vegetation which will carry fire. This work shall be accomplished to the satisfaction of the Director of Fire, prior to the erection of such tent. The premises shall be kept free from such flammable materials during the period for which the premises are used by the public. 
(B)  No hay, straw, shavings or similar combustible materials other than that necessary for the current feeding and care of animals shall be permitted within any tent used for public assembly except that sawdust and shavings may be used when approved by the Director of Fire; provided, such materials are used in reasonable amounts and maintained thoroughly dampened with water. 
(C)  No smoking, fireworks, or unapproved open flame of any kind shall be permitted in any tent while occupied by the public. "No Smoking" signs shall be conspicuously posted in any tent open to the public. 
(D)  Tents shall not be used for the display of motion pictures unless safety film is used. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.108. - Exits. 
(A)  A minimum of two exits shall be provided where a tent is used as a place of public assembly with a capacity of 100 or more persons, and if the capacity exceeds 600, there shall be not less than four exits. 
(B)  The aggregate clear width of exit openings shall be determined on the basis of not less than one unit of 22 inches for each 100 persons accommodated. Exit openings as required shall not be less than 42 inches in clear width, nor less in width than the required width of aisles or passageways serving such exit openings as contained in § 111.109, and where capacities exceed 600 persons, exit openings as required shall not be less than five feet in clear width. 
(C)  The line of exit travel to exits shall not be greater than 100 feet. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.109. - Aisles and passageways. 
(A)  Within any tent used for assembly, aisles from grandstands or other seating arrangements that do not lead directly to an exit shall discharge into an unobstructed space leading directly to one or more exits, and so arranged as to be conveniently accessible to every occupant; and such space shall have a clear width not less than the required width of the exit to which it leads, but in no case less than five feet. 
(B)  If required exits from places used for assembly do not discharge directly into a street or open space leading to a street, unobstructed lanes not less than 20 feet in width shall be maintained from such exits to the street at all times while such tents are occupied for places of assembly. 
(C)  No aisle, passageway, or other way of ingress or egress in any tent used for assembly shall be obstructed in any manner while such tent is occupied by the public. No tent stake, guy wire, or guy rope shall be permitted in any aisle or in any other way of ingress or egress, nor shall any guy wire or guy rope cross any aisle or other way of ingress or egress at a height of less than seven feet. Tent stakes adjacent to any way of ingress or egress to any tent open to the public shall be railed off, capped, or covered in such manner as not to present a hazard to the public. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.110. - Seating arrangement must provide aisles. 
(A)  Any grandstand or seating arrangement within a tent having seats with backs or a railing guard along the front shall be provided with aisles so located that no seat in a row shall have more than seven seats between it and the nearest aisle. 
(B)  Aisles provided in compliance with § 111.109 shall be of not less than 42 inches in clear width. 
(C)  Trailer mounted seating on noncombustible decking not exceeding 300 capacity each shall provide aisleways not less than 36 inches in clear width. 
(D)  The horizontal distance back to back of seats shall be not less than 30 inches for seats having backrests or not less than 22 inches for bleacher type seats. When the same level is used for both seats and footrests these levels shall be not less than 22 inches in width. There shall be a space of not less than 12 inches between the back of each seat and the front of the seat immediately behind it. 
    All measurements shall be taken between plumb lines. 
(E)  The width of footboards (footrests) in grandstands shall be not less than nine and one-half inches and that of seat boards not less than seven and one-half inches. Where the same level is not used for both seat foundations and footrests, footrests independent of seats shall be provided. 
(F)  Bleacher type seats and footrests of grandstands shall be securely supported in such manner that they cannot be displaced inadvertently. Footrests which are lapped shall be provided with some positive means to prevent displacement of one piece on the other. 
(G)  Individual seats or chairs shall be permitted only if firmly secured in rows in an approved manner, except that seats if not more than 16 in number, on level floors, and within railed-in enclosures, such as boxes, need not be fastened. 
(H)  Spaces underneath grandstands or bleacher seating arrangements shall be kept free of extraneous flammable materials and shall not be occupied for other than protective or exit purposes. 
(I)  Railings or guards not less than 42 inches high above the aisle surface or platform tread, whichever is adjacent, shall be provided along those portions of the backs and ends of all grandstands where the seats are more than four feet above the ground. Where the front footrest of any grandstand is more than two feet above the ground, railings or guards not less than 33 inches high above such front footrests shall be provided. Openings between the top railing or guard and walkway surface below, if more than 18 inches in height, shall be not more than 11 inches wide. Railings or guards shall be capable of sustaining a vertical load of 100 pounds per linear foot and a horizontal thrust of 50 pounds per linear foot. When grandstands are used adjacent to a wall, railings or guards may be omitted from those portions where such wall affords equivalent safeguard. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.111. - Electrical installations. 
(A)  The electrical installation in tents used as places of assembly shall conform to the requirements of the National Electric Code, see § 113.35. 
(B)  The electrical system shall be installed, maintained, and operated in a safe and workmanlike manner. If portable and in use, it shall be inspected daily by a qualified person representing the owner and any defects found shall be corrected before the public is admitted to the show or performance involved. 
(C)  The electrical system and equipment shall be isolated from the public by proper elevation or guarding, and all electrical fuses and switches shall be enclosed in approved enclosures. Cables on the ground in areas traversed by the public shall be placed in trenches or protected by approved covers. 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.112. - Exit lighting and signs. 
(A)  Exits, and aisles and passageways leading to them, in tents used as places of assembly, shall be kept adequately lighted at all times when such tents are occupied, and artificial light shall be provided whenever natural light is inadequate. 
(B)  In tents used as places of assembly, where capacities exceed 200 persons or more, there shall be placed over each exitway an electrically illuminated, standard, approved exit sign, having plain block transparent green letters not less than five inches in height imposed over a light background of the word "exit." 
(Ord. 15893, passed 3-7-45; Am. Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.113. - Blocking exits. 
    No person shall in any way block or obstruct any exit or any aisle or passageway leading thereto. 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 111.999. 
Sec. 111.114. - Equipment using gasoline. 
    All automobiles, trucks, tractors, lighting equipment and other equipment using gasoline shall be filled with approved safety cans or by hose from fixed pumps, from wheeled tanks with pumps, or pump from a tank wagon located not closer than 25 feet to any tent. 
(Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.115. - Fire appliances required. 
(A)  The Director of Fire shall survey, or cause to be surveyed, each tent for which a permit has been granted, after it is erected and, if it is to be used as a place of assembly, before it is occupied. He shall require the installation of such fire appliances as are deemed necessary, and designate their location. Such fire appliances may consist of water tanks, pumps, hose, water buckets, extinguishers, and fireproof blankets. 
(B)  All fire appliances shall be kept in working condition and all pumps and hose, when used in connection with tank wagons, shall be inspected and tested, if deemed necessary, prior to the occupancy of the tent. Portable extinguishers and similar appliances shall be properly distributed and readily accessible. It shall be the duty of the owner or manager of each exhibition to properly train sufficient responsible employees in the use of fire equipment so that it can be quickly put in operation, and the Director of Fire may require these employees to prove their fitness. 
(Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Sec. 111.116. - Fire inspection. 
    Ushers, special police, attendants or other responsible persons shall familiarize themselves with fire protection facilities, fire prevention features and with the condition of exits; they shall patrol the entire area of the tent during the time it is occupied; they shall further see that the area is not overcrowded, that the aisles and exitways are kept open, and that the no-smoking rules are observed. The Director of Fire shall inspect at intervals during the time that the tent is erected and/or occupied to ascertain if all rules and regulations have been complied with. 
(Ord. 18605, passed 11-28-56) 
Secs. 111.117-111.998. - Reserved. 
Sec. 111.999. - Penalty. 
(A)  Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  Penalties for violations of the Ohio Boxing Law, being R.C. §§ 3773.31 through 3773.58, which has been adopted by reference as § 111.21 of this chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  Whoever violates R.C. §§ 3773.32, 3773.40, 3773.44, 3773.45, 3773.46, or 3773.47, 3773.54 (A) or 3773.33 (B) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
(2)  Whoever violates R.C. §§ 3773.48 or 3773.49 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(3)  Whoever violates R.C. § 3773.37 (B) or 3773.50 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(C)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of §§ 111.100 through 111.116 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(Am. Ord. 26485, passed 3-31-82) 
CHAPTER 112. - BUSINESSES 
DIVISION 1. - AUCTIONS 
Subdivision (A). - General Provisions 

Sec. 112.01. - Public auctions on streets prohibited. 
    No auctioneer or other person shall hold or carry on or attempt to hold or carry on a public auction on any street, alley, sidewalk, lane, or other public way or place, or on any public park or grounds in this city. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 14367, passed 11-5-30) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.02. - Auction with reserve. 
    The seller's right to bid in his own behalf, or to receive bids made by others in his behalf at a public auction may be expressly reserved; provided that a plain, undisguised announcement that such right is reserved is made in a clear loud voice immediately prior to and at the time of offering for sale each article which is offered for sale with such right reserved. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 14367, passed 11-5-30) 
Sec. 112.03. - Bids for seller of auctioneer. 
    Unless the provisions of § 112.02 have been fully complied with, no bid at a public auction shall be knowingly given, or accepted, when such bid is made by or on behalf of the seller or auctioneer, or by a person interested in the sale in behalf of the seller or auctioneer, or by a person employed or procured to bid in behalf of such seller or auctioneer. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 14367, passed 11-5-30) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.04. - Reserved. 
Subdivision (B). - Jewelry Auction 

Sec. 112.05. - License required. 
    No person by himself, or by or through any agent or servant, except an officer or person, executing a process or order of any court having jurisdiction within the state for selling property directed by law or court order or legal process to be sold at public auction, and except licensed pawnbrokers selling or offering for sale unredeemed pledges in the manner provided by law, shall sell or offer for sale at public auction any gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks or jewelry, whether it be his property or whether he sells or offers it for sale as the agent, servant, or employee of another, unless such person shall first procure a license so to do. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.06. - Application for license. 
    Any person desiring to hold an auction sale of the goods described in § 112.05, shall file with the City Accountant a sworn written application for a license, stating the name and address of the applicant, the place where the sale is to be conducted, the name and address of the person who for at least six months previous to this sale has owned the goods proposed to be sold, and shall attach to it a sworn inventory of the stock on hand, setting out the quality, quantity, kind, or grade of each item, and the wholesale market value thereof, and shall file with the City Accountant a certified copy of the auctioneer's license required by the laws of Ohio. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Sec. 112.07. - Bond required. 
    Every applicant for a license shall execute and file with the City Accountant a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $2,500.00 with two or more sureties thereon who shall be freeholders within the city, or with the surety thereon a surety company authorized to do business in the state, and which shall be conditioned upon the faithful observance of all the conditions of §§ 112.05 through 112.14, and shall also indemnify any purchaser at said public auction who suffers any loss by reason of misrepresentations in the sale. Any purchaser claiming to have been damaged by misrepresentation in the auction sale may maintain an action at law against the license making such misrepresentations and may join as party defendant the surety or sureties on the bond as herein provided. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.08. - Refusal of license. 
    No license shall be issued: 
(A)  For the sale or offering for sale at public auction of the stock on hand of any person who shall not for the period of six months next preceding such sale or offering for sale, have been continuously engaged in the city in the business of a wholesale or retail merchant, of gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks, or jewelry; 
(B)  For the sale or offering for sale at public auction of the stock on hand or any addition thereto, as hereinafter provided, by any purchaser, from a person who shall not for the period of six months next preceding any such purchase, have been continuously engaged in and upon the same premises wherein the sale or offering for sale is to be held, in the business of a wholesale or retail merchant of gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks or jewelry; 
(C)  If a sale at public auction of such stock shall have been conducted within the period of one year next preceding such sale. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Sec. 112.09. - License fee; term. 
(A)  A license fee of $50.00 for a public auction as provided in §§ 112.01 to 112.14 shall be paid to the City Treasurer before a license is issued. 
(B)  The license shall be in force for 30 days, Sundays and holidays excepted, from the date of issue. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Sec. 112.10. - Days of sale. 
    The sale or offering for sale at public auction by the merchant or purchaser described in § 112.08 shall be held on successive days, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, and shall not continue for more than a total of 30 days within the period of any one year. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999 
Sec. 112.11. - Fill-in stock. 
(A)  In addition to the stock on hand which shall consist of such gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks or jewelry, which a merchant usually and ordinarily carries, the licensee may sell and offer for sale at public auction additional gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks or jewelry, as may be added to the stock on hand, such added stock being described as "fill-in" stock; provided that the total whole-sale market value of such "fill-in" stock shall not exceed 50 percent of the wholesale market value of the stock on hand set forth in the sworn inventory filed with the application for license. 
(B)  No such fill-in stock shall be sold or offered for sale until there be filed with the City Accountant a sworn statement setting out the quality, quantity, kind, or grade of each item, together with the wholesale market value thereof, and until the City Accountant shall first have granted written permission to do so. 
(Ord. 12884, passed 6-23-26; Am. Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.12. - False statement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee, his agents, or employees to make any statements which are false in any particular, or which have a tendency to mislead or to make any misrepresentations whatsoever with reference to any article sold or offered for sale during the auction, and it shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any article hereinbefore described as "fill-in" unless in each and every advertisement of whatsoever kind with reference to the auction, there be contained a clear and unequivocal statement of the fact that goods and merchandise herein described as "fill-in" have been added to the "stock-on-hand", together with a statement of the total wholesale market value thereof, and provided such statements shall be in type or writing of equal prominence with each and every other statement of the advertisement. 
(Ord. 15296, passed 4-24-40) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.13. - Announcement of fill-in sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person acting as auctioneer to sell or offer for sale any article hereinbefore described as "fill-in" without first stating such fact in a clear and audible tone of voice to any and all persons present at such auction. 
(Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.14. - Revocation of license. 
    The City Accountant may revoke the license of any licensee under the terms of §§ 112.05 to 112.13, who is found guilty of violating any of the provisions hereof. Any person whose license is revoked shall not be issued another license before the expiration of one year from the date of the revocation. 
(Ord. 15396, passed 4-24-40) 
Secs. 112.15-112.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BAIL BONDS 

Sec. 112.20. - License required. 
    No person, other than a surety company duly licensed under the laws of the state, shall demand or receive, directly or indirectly, any compensation for becoming surety or providing surety on any bail bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bond, or any other court bond required to be filed in any criminal case, or criminal proceeding in the municipal courts of the city, unless such person has first been properly licensed in accordance with the provisions of §§ 112.20 to 112.30. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.21. - Application for license. 
(A)  Any person, except those mentioned in § 112.20, of good moral character, who has not been convicted of any offense involving theft, fraud, personal violence, or moral turpitude, desiring to be licensed pursuant to the provisions of §§ 112.20 to 112.30, shall make an application in writing to the Clerk of the Municipal Court of the City, duly verified, on a form prepared by the Law Director of the City, containing facts disclosing satisfactory proof of applicant's financial responsibility in unencumbered or encumbered real estate, located in Montgomery County, Ohio; or the power of attorney of a reputable insurance, surety, or bonding company together with a certificate of authority from the state department of insurance, and a true copy of its financial statement; or if the applicant elects to use cash, the application shall contain all the facts required by R.C. § 2937.24 and such other facts as the Clerk of the Municipal Court may require. 
(B)  In the event applicant is a partnership, the names of all partners shall be listed; and if a corporation, the names of all officers, including the president, vice-president, secretary, and treasurer shall be set forth in the application. 
(C)  The application shall be accompanied by the affidavits of at least two reputable citizens of the city attesting to the good moral character of the applicant. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Sec. 112.22. - Certain persons not eligible for license. 
    No attorney, no husband or wife of any attorney, no employee of any attorney, association of attorneys, or law firm, nor the associate of any attorney, or member, or partner, of any law firm, shall be eligible to obtain a license under the provisions of §§ 112.20 to 112.30, nor may any of the above mentioned persons furnish or lend to a person licensed under these provisions any money, bonds, or other securities, which are to be used as bail or bond. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62; Am. Ord. 20369, passed 5-29-62) 
Sec. 112.23. - License fee; issuance of license. 
    Upon filing the application and the payment of a license fee of $100.00 by any person who is eligible to become a surety, and upon the written approval of the Clerk of the Municipal Court, a license may be issued by the Director of Finance authorizing such person to become surety upon any bail bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bond, or other court bond required to be filed in the municipal court of the city. Such license shall state the total amount for which the licensee may be accepted as surety, which amount shall not exceed the tax value of the real estate or the tax value of the equity therein owned by the licensee and/or the total amount granted by the power of attorney of a reputable insurance, surety, or bonding company and/or the market value of bonds and other securities deposited by the licensee, pursuant to R.C. § 2937.24. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Sec. 112.24. - Term of license. 
    A license issued pursuant to the provisions of §§ 112.20 to 112.30 shall be for a period of one year commencing on the date the license is issued. A license shall not be renewed to a person who is in default for satisfaction upon a defaulted bond or recognizance. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Sec. 112.25. - Maximum fees allowable. 
    No person shall charge, demand, or receive as compensation for becoming surety or providing surety on any bail bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bond, or other court bond of any kind required to be filed in any criminal proceeding in the municipal court of the city, a sum in excess of ten percent of the amount of such bond; except, that a minimum charge of $10.00 may be made on bonds in amounts of $100.00 or less. No additional fee, security, service charge, or interest charge shall be assessed and the bond shall not be cancelled until the case is finally disposed of unless such cancellation is approved by the court. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.26. - Receipt to be furnished. 
    Every person accepting compensation for becoming surety on any bail bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bond, or other bond of any kind in any criminal case or criminal proceeding in the municipal court shall furnish the person paying such compensation a receipt showing the full amount of the compensation charged, demanded, or received. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.27. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    The Director of Finance shall, after notice and hearing, suspend or revoke any license pursuant to §§ 112.20 to 112.30 or refuse to renew the license of any licensee within the period of one year after suspensions or revocation for any one or more of the following acts or omissions on the part of the licensee: 
(A)  Becoming surety or providing surety on any bail bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bonds, or other court bonds required to be filed in any criminal case or criminal proceedings in the municipal court of the city, the penalty of which, either of itself or when added to the penalty or penalties of any other bond or bonds signed by such licensee as surety, is in excess of the amount of surety permitted to be executed by the licensee; 
(B)  Failing to furnish to any person paying compensation to such licensee for becoming or providing surety on any bail bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bonds, or other bonds of any kind in any criminal case or criminal proceedings, in the municipal court, a receipt showing the amount of the compensation charged; 
(C)  Charging, receiving, or demanding an amount as compensation for becoming a surety on a bail bond or court bond of any kind in any criminal case or proceedings in the municipal court, in excess of the amount permitted to be charged, demanded, or received by §§ 112.20 to 112.30; 
(D)  Soliciting, bargaining, or enticing, professional bond or bail services to any person charged with a violation of any section of the Revised Code or any section of this Code, anywhere in or about the premises of the Safety Building, 335 West Third Street, Dayton, Ohio; 
(E)  Recommending, suggesting, or referring persons, for whom he is executing a bond, to any lawyer or law firm; 
(F)  Failing to satisfy, within 20 days after the same accrues, any obligation of such licensee as surety arising from a forfeited bond; 
(G)  Violating any of the provisions of §§ 112.20 to 112.30 or any of the statutes of the state relating to bail, bond, recognizance bond, appeal bond, supersedeas bond, or other bonds of any kind in any criminal case or proceedings in the municipal court. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Sec. 112.28. - Presumption of doing business. 
    If any person is shown to have signed bail bonds or surety bonds in any criminal case regularly or, in any event, in the total sum of $2,000.00 in any calendar year, it shall be presumed that he has received compensation, and he shall have the burden of proving by the preponderance of evidence that no compensation was received by him. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Sec. 112.29. - Compliance with state requirements. 
    Nothing in §§ 112.20 through 112.30 shall be construed to conflict with, supersede, or dispense with any of the requirements of this Code relating to bail or bond, but it shall be the duty of the officers of the municipal court to require the qualifications for bail or bond prescribed by this Code and to enforce the recognizance bails or bonds in all cases where the conditions thereof have not been complied with. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
Sec. 112.30. - Enforcement of recognizance bond. 
    When a person under a recognizance in a criminal prosecution is ordered to appear, answer, or to testify in court, and fails to perform the conditions thereof, his default shall be recorded and such recognizance forfeited in open court; and thereupon such proceedings shall be had to enforce such recognizance as are prescribed by law. The prosecuting attorney in the municipal court shall represent the interests of the public in such proceedings and shall secure the enforcement of the recognizance bond in every case as fully and as promptly as possible. 
(Ord. 20323, passed 4-25-62) 
DIVISION 3. - BARBER SHOPS (Reserved) 

Secs. 112.31-112.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3A. - PREDATORY LENDING 

Sec. 112.40. - Definitions. 
    Affiliate. Any company that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control related to or associated with another company, as set forth in the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 (12 U.S.C. § 1841 et seq.), as amended from time to time. 
    However, an "affiliate" shall not include any entity whose predominant business is the providing of tax deferred, defined contribution, pension plans to public employees in accordance with Section 403(b) and 457 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
    Annual percentage rate. The annual percentage rate for the loan calculated according to the provisions of the federal Truth-in-Lending Act (15 U.S.C. § 1601, et seq.), and the regulations promulgated thereunder by the Federal Reserve Board (as said Act and regulations are amended from time to time). 
    Bona fide loan discount points. Discount points knowingly paid by the borrower for the purpose of reducing, and which in fact result in a bona fide reduction of, the interest rate or time-price differential applicable to the credit transaction or loan. For purposes of this provision, it shall be presumed that a point is a bona fide loan discount point if it reduces the interest rate by a minimum of 35 basis points or three-eighths of a point, provided all other terms of the loan remain the same. 
    City. The City of Dayton. 
    City agency. The City of Dayton, its departments, boards and commissions. 
    CRA Compliant Lender. Any person, party, institution, business entity, or affiliate who might otherwise be a lender within the meaning of § 112.40(H), if such person, party, institution, business entity, or affiliate has received a CRA (Community Reinvestment Act) rating of satisfactory or above from any one of the federal review agencies, including but not limited to the Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), the Office of Thrift Supervision (OTS), the Office of Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), or any similar agency. 
    High cost loan. A loan that is secured by residential real property located within the City of Dayton on which there is situated a dwelling for not more than four families or a condominium unit, if: 
(1)  At any time over the life of the loan, the annual percentage rate of the loan equals or exceeds by more than nine percentage points, or the current annual percentage rate limitation included within the Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act ("HOEPA"), whichever is less, the yield on Treasury securities having comparable periods of maturity to the loan maturity as of the fifteenth day of the month immediately preceding the month in which the application for the extension of credit is received by the creditor; or, 
(2)  The total points and fees financed in such loan equal or exceed the: 
(a)  Points and fees limitation included with the Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act ("HOEPA"), or,; 
(b)  Five percent of the total loan amount; or, six percent of the loan amount if the total transaction amount is $20,000.00 or more and the loan is a purchase money loan guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration or the Veterans Administration, whichever is less. 
    However, "high cost loan" shall not include a loan that is made primarily for a business purpose unrelated to the residential real property securing the loan, or any loan, which exceeds $250,000.00. 
    Lender: 
(1)  Any person, party, institution, business entity, or affiliate (not including an individual acting in the capacity of an employee of any of the foregoing) that actively transacts business involving the placement, origination, purchasing or selling of loans; or, 
(2)  Any person, party, institution, business entity, or affiliate (not including an individual acting in the capacity of an employee of any of the foregoing) that actively assists a borrower in obtaining a high cost or predatory loan, when the person, party, institution, or affiliate charges or receives money or other valuable consideration for providing this assistance. 
    Points and fees: 
(1)  All items required to be disclosed under sections 226.4(a) and 226.4(b) of Title 12 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as amended from time to time, except the interest rate or the time-price differential; 
(2)  Subject to the exclusions provided below in this section, all charges for items listed under section 226.4(c)(7) of Title 12 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as amended from time to time, but only if the lender receives direct or indirect compensation in connection with the charge or the charge is paid to an affiliate of the lender; otherwise, the charges are not included within the meaning of the phrase "points and fees"; 
(3)  All compensation paid directly or indirectly to a mortgage broker, including a broker that originates a loan in its own name in a table funded transaction, not otherwise included in paragraph (1) or (2) of this section; 
(4)  The premium of any single premium credit life, credit disability, credit unemployment, or any other life or health insurance that is financed directly or indirectly into the loan, unless the disclosures and acknowledgment described in predatory loan practice in § 112.40(L)(10) have been made. 
    "Points and fees" shall not include any charges or fees excluded by paragraphs (c) through (e) of Regulation Z of the Truth in Lending Act, Section 226.4 of Title 12 of the Code of Federal Regulations. 
    Predatory lender. A lender that, through itself and/or an affiliate has made, issued or arranged, or assisted others in so doing, within any 12-month period, predatory loans, within the City of Dayton, Ohio, that comprise either: 
(1)  Five percent of the total annual number of loans made, issued or arranged, or five percent of the total annual number of loans which the lender has assisted others in so making, using or arranging; or, 
(2)  Twenty-five individual loans; whichever is less. 
    Table funded transaction. A settlement at which a high cost or predatory loan is funded by an advance of funds and there is a subsequent assignment of the loan from the person or entity identified as the lender in the loan transaction documents to the person or entity advancing the funds. 
    Predatory loan. A high cost loan that was made under circumstances that involve any of the following acts and practices, or a high cost loan that contains any of the following loan terms: 
(1)  Fraudulent or deceptive acts or practices, including fraudulent or deceptive marketing and sales efforts to sell high cost loans. Fraudulent or deceptive acts and practices shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(a)  A lender may not knowingly include in a loan terms that are substantially unfavorable to the borrower because of the borrower's inability to reasonably protect his interests because of his physical or mental infirmities, or illiteracy; 
(b)  A lender may not negotiate any terms in a loan which were less favorable to the borrower than could otherwise have been obtained in similar transactions by like consumers within the city, where the lender receives any benefit, direct or indirect, from the business entity who provided the funds for the loan in exchange for the inclusion of the less favorable terms within the loan; 
(c)  A lender may not charge a fee and/or costs for a loan transaction as a whole, or for any service performed in connection with the loan transaction, where the fees and/or costs exceed the fees and/or costs available in similar transactions by like consumers in the city by more than 20 percent; 
(d)  A lender may not charge a borrower points, fees, or other charges in connection with a loan transaction, if the proceeds of the loan transaction are used to refinance an existing loan held by the same lender; 
(e)  A lender may not knowingly or recklessly make a false statement of fact and/or opinion to the borrower, on which the borrower justifiably relies to his detriment, in order to induce the borrower to accept terms in a loan transaction that were unfavorable to the borrower; 
(f)  A lender may not misrepresent, in connection with a loan application, the income, assets or expenses of the borrower; 
(g)  A lender may not procure an appraisal of the value of the secured property under circumstances where the appraisal unreasonably overstates the value of the property; 
(2)  "Loan flipping", "flipping": A loan is the making of high cost loan to a borrower that refinances an existing loan, when the new loan does not have a reasonable, tangible net benefit to the borrower considering all of the circumstances. 
(3)  "Balloon payments": A loan that has a payment schedule with regular periodic payments that, when aggregated do not fully amortize the outstanding principal balance, unless the lender, at least three business days before the borrower signs the loan agreement, makes to the borrower a separate oral disclosure, and a separate clear and conspicuous written disclosure to which the borrower agrees in writing, containing the following information, all of which must be true: 
"WARNING-BALLOON PAYMENT LOAN: This loan will not be fully paid off by the regular periodic payments. At [insert the date at which the balloon payment is due] you will still owe a payment of [insert the amount of the balloon payment]. If you do not have this amount of money, you will have to get another loan to pay it. Otherwise, this loan will be in default, and you may lose your home in foreclosure." 
In addition, the written disclosure shall contain a signed and dated acknowledgement by the borrower that the oral disclosure was made and a signed and dated acknowledgement by the lender that the oral disclosure was made. 
(4)  "Negative Amortization": A loan that contains a payment schedule with regular periodic payments that cause the principal balance to increase and/or remain constant. 
(5)  "Increased Interest Rate": A loan that contains a provision that increases the interest rate after default. Interest rate increases do not constitute a predatory loan practice in variable rate loans where the increase is otherwise consistent with the provisions of the loan documents, provided that the event of default or the acceleration of the indebtedness does not trigger the change in the interest rate. 
(6)  "Advance Payments": A loan which includes terms under which more than two periodic payments required under the loan are consolidated and paid in advance from the loan proceeds provided to the borrower. 
(7)  "Modification or Deferral Fees": A loan which includes terms under which the lender may charge a borrower any fees or other charges to modify, renew, extend, or amend a loan product or to defer any payment due under the terms of a loan product. 
(8)  "Mandatory Arbitration": A loan which contains a mandatory arbitration clause that limits in any way the right of the borrower to seek relief through a court of law or equity. 
(9)  "Prepayment Penalties": A loan which imposes prepayment fees or penalties on the borrower that apply to a prepayment of the loan made after the expiration of the 60-month period following the date the loan was originated. 
(10)  "Financing of Credit Insurance": The financing of any credit life, credit disability, credit unemployment or any other life or health insurance, directly or indirectly, in a high cost loan unless the lender, at least three business days before the borrower signs the loan agreement, makes to the borrower a separate oral disclosure, and a separate clear and conspicuous written disclosure containing the following information, all of which must be true: 
(a)  The total costs of the insurance premium; 
(b)  The total amount of interest that will charged for the financing of the insurance premium over the life of the loan; 
(c)  The fact that the insurance will be prepaid and financed at the interest rate provided for in the loan; 
(d)  The amount that the lender or its affiliates will receive as direct or indirect commissions in connection with the insurance; 
(e)  That the borrower may terminate the insurance at any time and receive a refund of the unearned premium, and that the borrower will receive a refund of the entire premium if the borrower cancels the insurance within 90 days after the policy goes into effect; 
(f)  The term of the insurance coverage. 
In addition, the written disclosure shall contain a signed and dated acknowledgement by the borrower that the oral disclosure was made and a signed and dated acknowledgement by the lender that the oral disclosure was made. 
(Ord. 29990-01, passed 7-11-01) 
Sec. 112.41. - Predatory lending practices prohibited. 
(A)  Prohibited Conduct. 
(1)  Issuing Predatory Loans. No lender shall make, issue, or arrange a predatory loan or assist others in doing so. A lender who, when acting in good faith, fails to comply with this section will not be deemed to have violated this section if the person establishes that either: 
(a)  Within 30 days of the loan closing and prior to institution of any action under § 112.43 the borrower is notified of the compliance failure, appropriate restitution is made, and whatever adjustments are necessary are made to the loan to either, at the choice of the borrower: 
(1)  Make the predatory loan satisfy the requirements of § 112.40; or, 
(2)  Change the terms of the loan in a manner beneficial to the borrower so that the loan will not longer be considered a predatory loan subject to the provisions of § 112.40; or, 
(b)  The compliance failure was not intentional and resulted from a bona fide error notwithstanding the maintenance of procedures reasonably adapted to avoid such errors, and within 60 days after the discovery of the compliance failure and prior to the institution of any action under § 112.43, the borrower is notified of the compliance failure, appropriate restitution is made, and whatever adjustments are necessary are made to the loan to either, at the choice of the borrower: 
(1)  Make the predatory loan satisfy the requirements of § 112.40; or, 
(2)  Change the terms of the loan in a manner beneficial to the borrower so that the loan will no longer be considered a predatory loan subject to the provisions of § 112.40. Examples of a bona fide error include clerical, calculation, computer malfunction and programming, and printing errors. An error of legal judgment with respect to a lender's obligations under § 112.40 are not bona fide errors. 
(2)  Lending Without Due Regard to Repayment. No lender shall make, issue or originate any high cost loan if the lender does not reasonably believe at the time the loan is consummated that the borrower or borrowers will be able to make the scheduled payments to repay the obligation based upon a consideration of their current and expected income, current obligations, employment status, and other financial resources (other than the borrower's equity in the dwelling which secures repayment of the loan). A borrower shall be presumed to be able to make the scheduled payments to repay the obligation if, at the time the loan is consummated, or at the time of the first rate adjustment in the case of a lower introductory interest rate, the borrower's scheduled monthly payments on the loan (including principal, interest, taxes, insurance and assessments), combined with the scheduled payments for all other debt, do not exceed 50 percent of the borrower's documented and verified monthly gross income, and the borrower has sufficient "residual income" as defined in the guidelines established in 38 C.F.R. §36.4337(e) and VA form 26-2393 to pay essential monthly expenses after paying the scheduled payments and any additional debt. 
(3)  Payments to Home Improvement Contractors. A lender shall not pay proceeds of a high cost loan to any home improvement contractor, and a home improvement contractor may not receive the proceeds of a high cost loan, other than: 
(a)  By an instrument payable solely to the borrower or jointly to the borrower and the contractor; or, 
(b)  At the election of the borrower, by a third party escrow agent in accordance with terms established in a written agreement signed by the borrower, the lender, and the home improvement contractor before the disbursement date. 
(Ord. 29990-01, passed 7-11-01) 
Sec. 112.42. - Exclusions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of §§ 112.40 through 112.44 of this Code, a CRA Compliant Lender, as that term is defined in § 112.40(F) shall not be subject to any of the provisions of §§ 112.40 to 112.44 of this Code prohibiting predatory lending practices. Any affiliate of the CRA Compliant Lender will only be exempted from the application of §§ 112.40 through 112.44 of this Code, if the CRA Compliant Lender's CRA rating incorporates the affiliate and any and all of its activities. 
(Ord. 29990-01, passed 7-11-01) 
Sec. 112.43. - Penalties. 
(A)  Fines. 
(1)  Any lender who violates § 112.41 shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00 per day of violation. 
(2)  Each day in which a borrower is assessed with interest on the principal loan amount of a high cost or predatory loan shall constitute a separate violation of § 112.41. 
(B)  Loss of City Contracts. No person or business entity shall be awarded a contract with the city or a city agency, if the person, business entity, or any of its affiliates is a predatory lender. 
(C)  Unfair or Deceptive Lending Practice. 
(1)  The making, issuing, or arranging of a high cost or predatory loan transaction in violation of any provision of § 112.41 is hereby declared an unfair or deceptive lending act or practice under the Ohio Revised Code, and is unlawful. 
(2)  The provisions of § 112.41 shall apply to any lender who in bad faith attempts to avoid the application of these sections by: 
(a)  Dividing any high cost or predatory loan into separate parts for the purpose and with the intent of evading any provision of § 112.40; or, 
(b)  Any other such subterfuge. 
(D)  Private Right of Action. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the provisions of §§ 112.43(A) through 112.43(C), any individual who becomes obligated on a high cost or predatory loan may bring an action for damages and/or equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction against any lender who violates § 112.41. Judgment shall be entered for actual damages, but in no case less than the amount of home equity the individual has lost as a result of the high cost or predatory loan, as determined by the court, rescission of the high cost or predatory loan, in accordance with the rescission provisions of the federal Truth in Lending Act, reasonable attorneys fees and court costs. 
(2)  Nothing in § 112.43 limits the rights of the injured person to recover damages or seek equitable relief under any other applicable laws or legal theory. 
(Ord. 29990-01, passed 7-11-01) 
Sec. 112.44. - Severability. 
    The provisions of §§ 112.40 to 112.43 are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, or provision is declared to be invalid or is preempted by federal or state law or regulation, the validity of the remaining provisions of §§ 112.40 to 112.43 shall not be affected thereby. If any provision of §§ 112.40 to 112.43 is declared inapplicable to any specific category, type, or kind of loan transaction, the provision shall nonetheless continue to apply with respect to all other loan transactions. 
(Ord. 29990-01, passed 7-11-01) 
Secs. 112.45-112.54. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DEALERS IN SECONDHAND VEHICLES 

Sec. 112.55. - Reports required; contents. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaged in the business of buying or selling secondhand vehicles to make or cause to be made daily reports to the Chief of Police of each secondhand vehicle bought, purchased, obtained by trade, exchanged, or otherwise secured, or left in his possession for sale. The reports shall be made in the form furnished by the Chief of Police and shall include the following information: the name, place of residence, and the personal description of each person from whom a secondhand vehicle is obtained, the date and hour received, a description of the secondhand vehicle, which shall include the make, factory number, motor number, style of body, color, and license number, and the name and address of the dealer. The reports shall be legibly filled out in English, and the full and complete information required shall be supplied. 
(Ord. 10716, passed 5-29-18; Am. Ord. 23943, passed 3-17-71) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.56. - Time and place for filing reports. 
    The reports covering the secondhand vehicles received by a dealer in any day shall at or before 12:00 noon of the day following be delivered to the Chief of Police or to an officer designated by him to receive the reports at the safety building of the city. 
(Ord. 10716, passed 5-29-18; Am. Ord. 23943, passed 3-17-71) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.57-112.59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FUEL DEALERS 

Sec. 112.60. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of §§ 112.60 to 112.79, the term "solid fuel" shall mean any anthracite, semi-anthracite, bituminous, semi-bituminous, or lignite coal, briquettes, boulets, coke, gas house coke, petroleum coke, petroleum carbon, or any other manufactured or patented fuel, not sold by liquid or metered measured, except firewood and packaged fuel sold with weight indicated on the package. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 21467, passed 12-16-64) 
Sec. 112.61. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the retail business of selling, offering or causing to be advertised for sale, or delivering solid fuel in the city without having first applied for and obtained from the City Accountant and having in full force and effect a license so to do. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 1-28-25; Am. Ord. 21467, passed 12-16-64) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.62. - Application for license; contents. 
(A)  Every applicant for a license pursuant to § 112.61 shall file in writing a verified application on a form to be furnished by the City Accountant, and shall set forth the legal nature of the applicant, whether a natural person, firm, partnership, or corporation, the full name of the corporation and the names of its officers, or the names and residences of the partners, if a partnership, or the name and residence of each person interested in the business of the applicant and the exact nature of such interest; and the location of the office or place of business for which the license is sought. 
(B)  Each applicant shall file with the application written evidence satisfactory to the City Accountant of applicant's right to use the scale proposed to be used in his business, together with the certificate of the consumer advocate that such scales have been examined, found correct, and duly stamped or branded by the consumer advocate. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.63. - Scales required. 
    No person shall have or be granted a license to engage in the business of selling, offering for sale, or delivering solid fuel within the city who does not possess or have the right to use scales of sufficient size and capacity and maintained in a condition accurately to weigh the quantity of fuel for which it is proposed to be utilized and such other reasonable unloading, storage and service facilities as are deemed necessary to the proper conduct of his business and commensurate with the nature of the business. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.64. - Term of license. 
    The license shall bear on its face the number thereof; it shall state that it expires on December 31 of the year in which issued, and that it shall be valid only so long as its holder shall pursue his business of retailer of solid fuel in accordance with all applicable ordinances, state and federal laws, and codes of fair competition authorized by law; and it shall contain all the information required by § 112.62 to be contained in the application therefor. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.65. - Cause for revocation of license. 
    Conviction of violation of any ordinances, laws, or codes regulating the solid fuel industry, shall be sufficient cause for the revocation after notice and hearing by the City Accountant of the license issued. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.66. - Record of licenses and revocations. 
    The City Accountant shall keep a full and proper record of all licenses and revocations of licenses. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.67. - Transfer of license restricted. 
    The license shall authorize the carrying on of business only by the licensee at the place specified. The license shall not be transferable, except as to place, should the business licensed be moved to a new location. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.68. - Separate license for each location. 
    Whenever the business is carried on at more than one location in the city, a separate license shall be required for each such location. 
(Ord. 12638, passed 10-28-25; Am. Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.69. - License year; fee. 
(A)  The term of the license shall be from January 1 to December 31. 
(B)  The annual license fee shall be $25.00, and there shall be no deductions in the fee collected for a part of a year. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35; Am. Ord. 14886, passed 11-13-35) 
Sec. 112.70. - Display of license. 
    Every licensee shall cause his license to be conspicuously displayed at all times in the office or place of business for which it was issued. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.71. - Delivery ticket required. 
(A)  No person, by himself or by his agent or servant, or as the agent or servant of another, shall sell, offer for sale, or deliver at retail any solid fuel unless each such delivery, continuously from the time it leaves the seller's yard, is accompanied by a delivery ticket or certificate and a duplicate thereof, upon each of which tickets and duplicates thereof shall be written or otherwise indicated: 
(1)  The name, address, and license number of the person selling and delivering or attempting to sell or deliver such commodity. 
(2)  The gross weight of the load; the tare weight of the vehicle, and the net weight of the load. 
(3)  The name or identifying initials of the party who weighted it. 
(B)  One of the delivery tickets or the duplicate thereof shall be delivered or surrendered by the person in charge of the delivery of such load or solid fuel to the purchaser thereof or to his agent or representative, and another ticket or duplicate shall be retained by the seller for period of not less than 12 months from the date of sale. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.72. - Fuel weigher; designation; certificate. 
    Every person weighing solid fuel as required by §§ 112.60 to 112.79 shall be designated a fuel weigher. He may be either the proprietor or some other person designated by such proprietor as such. 
    The fuel weigher, before entering on his duties, shall take an oath before the Clerk of the Commission that he will well and truly perform the requirements of these sections, and the City Accountant shall issue to such fuel weigher a certificate that he is regularly qualified to perform such duties upon payment to said City Accountant a fee of $0.50 for the certificate so issued. The certificate shall be good during the current calendar year in which it is issued ending and determining on December 31 of that year. No person shall perform the duties of fuel weigher without being in possession of a fuel weigher's certificate as herein provided. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.73. - Weight check by purchaser. 
    Any purchaser may require the driver or person in charge of a load of solid fuel being delivered to him to weigh the same on any suitable scales which have been stamped or branded as correct by the consumer advocate and shall pay to the person in charge of the scales the sum of $0.25. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.74. - Weight checked by consumer advocate. 
    Upon the demand of the consumer advocate or his deputy, or of any police or law enforcement officer, the person in charge of any load shall deliver to such officer all delivery tickets in his possession, and shall proceed at the direction of this officer to any suitable scale for the purpose of weighing the load to verify the correctness of the delivery ticket, and to return to the same scale to verify tare weight after delivery has been made. The consumer advocate shall issue to the owner of the scales used in such case an order for $0.25 payable to the owner of the scales by the City Treasurer, said amount to be paid out of the general fund. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.75. - Misrepresentation of weight. 
    No person, being a dealer in solid fuel, who sells or causes to be sold or delivered any load of solid fuel, shall present a certificate of weight which represents the load of solid fuel to be of greater net weight than it in fact is. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.76. - Name on vehicle required. 
    Upon both sides of all delivery vehicles shall be displayed a sign with letters not less than three inches in height, showing the name of the person delivering or attempting to deliver solid fuel therein. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.77. - License plates on vehicle; fee. 
(A)  Every person engaged in the retail solid fuel business shall procure from the City Accountant a set of two license plates for each truck or delivery vehicle used in the business; his dealer's license fee shall entitle him to a set for one vehicle, but for the license plates for each additional vehicle he shall pay the additional sum of $3.50. 
(B)  All such license plates shall bear the number of the dealer's license, with the year of issuance stamped thereon in such plain and unmistakable letters and figures as to be readily distinguishable, and shall be displayed on both sides of the body or cab of each truck or delivery vehicle so operated. The license plates shall expire on December 31 at the same time as the dealer's license expires, and the color of such plates shall be changed yearly. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.78. - False advertising; size defined; abbreviation. 
(A)  No person, by himself or by his agent or servant, or as agent or servant of another, shall represent or advertise by any false statement, either oral or written, or publish or display any false sign, printing, or writing concerning the grade, size, quality, trade name, or origin of any solid fuel sold, offered for sale, or delivered by him. 
(B)  For the purpose of this section the term "size", where used in reference to coal, shall be construed as follows. The general size of block or lump shall be not less than four inches in diameter; the general size of egg shall be not less than two inches in diameter; the general size of nut shall be not less than one inch in diameter; the general size of pea shall not be less than three-eighths-inch in diameter; mine run shall be coal as it is received from mines without any variation or alteration thereof; and slack shall be such other coal as is not heretofore specifically designated. 
(C)  No abbreviations of words, terms, or phrases describing the size, preparation, or origin of coal or coke shall be included in any such representation or advertisement. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Sec. 112.79. - Prosecution for violation. 
    It shall not be necessary, in any prosecution under the provisions of §§ 112.60 through 112.78, to show the knowledge of the principal to convict for the acts of the agent, servant, clerk, or employee. These sections shall be liberally construed as remedial in character. 
(Ord. 14853, passed 1-23-35) 
Secs. 112.80-112.89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - HAWKERS, PEDDLERS, AND HUCKSTERS 

Sec. 112.90. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of §§ 112.90 through 112.102 the terms "hawker," "peddler," and "huckster" shall be considered synonymous, and shall be deemed to designate a person engaged in the business of making retail sales of provisions, goods, wares, or merchandise of any description upon the streets of the city, whether by personal solicitation or by supplying a purchaser with the goods without solicitation. A hawker, peddler, and huckster shall be deemed to be such within the meaning of this definition when he has no established place of business and carries his goods with him for the purpose of selling same. 
(Ord. 12719, passed 12-30-25) 
Sec. 112.91. - License required. 
(A)  No hawker, peddler, or huckster shall sell, or offer to sell, whether through himself or others, on any of the highways or public grounds within the city, any fruits, vegetables, meat, poultry, fish, ice, coal, provisions, goods, wares, or merchandise of any description until he shall first have obtained from the City Accountant a license to do so. This license shall be issued for a term not to exceed six consecutive calendar months. 
(B)  The fee for such license shall be $25.00. 
(Ord. 12719, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 25399, passed 10-12-77; Am. Ord. 26574, passed 8-4-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.92. - Application for license. 
(A)  Every applicant for a license pursuant to § 112.91 shall file in writing an application on a form to be furnished by the City Accountant and shall set forth the name and residence of the applicant, the articles he intends to sell. 
(B)  If the articles to be sold are such as are usually sold by weight or measure, the applicant shall file with his application the certificate of the consumer advocate that his scales, weights, and measures within 30 days prior to the filing of such application have been examined, found correct, and duly sealed by the Consumer Advocate. 
(C)  The City Accountant may require any applicant to make oath or solemn affirmation to the facts stated in the application. 
(Ord. 12719, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 25399, passed 10-12-77; Am. Ord. 26574, passed 8-4-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.93, 112.94. - Reserved. 
Sec. 112.95. - Terms of license. 
(A)  Upon receipt of the application, together with compliance with all requirements which the City Accountant may find necessary to impose in order to make certain that all requirements of the laws have been met, and upon determining that the applicant does meet and comply with all of said requirements, the City Accountant shall issue a license to such applicant. 
(B)  The license shall state upon its face the articles which the licensee is authorized to sell, and no licensee shall sell any article not enumerated upon the face of his license. 
(Ord. 12719, passed 12-30-25; Am. Ord. 15379, passed 3-27-40; Am. Ord. 25399, passed 10-12-77; Am. Ord. 26574, passed 8-4-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.96-112.100. - Reserved. 
Sec. 112.101. - Scales and measures. 
    No licensee herein shall at any time use any scales, weights, or measures which have not been examined and sealed by the consumer advocate. The licensee shall conform to all the provisions of §§ 112.90 through 112.102 and the ordinances of the city. Upon conviction of the violation of the provisions of any law or ordinance regulating the weighing, measuring, or sale of any article or commodity, or upon conviction of the violation of any of the terms of §§ 112.90 through 112.102, the City Accountant may after notice and hearing revoke or suspend the license. 
(Ord. 12719, passed 12-30-25) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.102. - Nonapplicability of §§ 112.90 through 112.101. 
    Sections 112.90 through 112.101 shall not apply to or require the owner of any product of his own raising, or the manufacturer of any article manufactured by him, to obtain a license to vend and sell in any way, by himself or agent, any such article or product. 
(Ord. 12719, passed 12-30-25) 
DIVISION 7. - VENDING FROM MOTOR VEHICLES IN PUBLIC STREETS 

Sec. 112.103. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Mobile food truck. Any motor vehicle registered and licensed in accordance with Title 45 of the Ohio Revised Code and used for the preparing, displaying, storing, transporting, and offering of food, beverage, or merchandise for sale. 
    Mobile food truck vendor. Any person engaged in the selling, or offering for sale, food, beverage, or merchandise in a mobile food truck sales zone from a motor vehicle. 
    Mobile food truck sales zone. Any area designated by the Department of Public Works for the purpose of allowing the sale, or offering for sale, food, beverage, or merchandise by a mobile food truck vendor. 
(Ord. 26523, passed 5-19-82; Am. Ord. 31245-13, passed 5-8-13) 
Sec. 112.104. - Permits for vending in a mobile food truck sales zone. 
(A)  No person shall provide food, beverage, or merchandise vending services from a motor vehicle without obtaining a permit pursuant to this section. 
(B)  The Department of Public Works shall promulgate rules and regulations under which a permit may be granted to provide vending services in a mobile food truck sales zone. 
(C)  A mobile food truck vendor may apply for a mobile food truck vending permit by filing with the Department of Public Works a completed application on a form provided by the Division of Civil Engineering. 
(D)  Upon receipt and approval by the Director of Public Works of an application for a mobile food truck vending permit, the Director of Public Works shall grant to the applicant a permit valid for a period of 30 days. 
(Ord. 26523, passed 5-19-82; Am. Ord. 31245-13, passed 5-8-13) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.105. - Prohibited conduct. 
(A)  The prohibitions in subsection (B) of this section shall apply to vending from motor vehicles on all streets and alleys within the city. 
(B)  No vendor vending from a motor vehicle shall: 
(1)  Conduct his business in such a way as would restrict or interfere with the ingress or egress of the abutting property owner or tenant, or create or become a public nuisance, increase traffic congestion or delay, or constitute a hazard to traffic, life or property, or an obstruction to adequate access to fire, police, or sanitary vehicles. 
(2)  Stop, stand, or park his vehicle upon any street, or permit it to remain there except on the roadway at the curb for the purpose of vending therefrom. 
(3)  Stop, stand, or park his vehicle upon any street for the purpose of selling, or sell on any street under any circumstances during the hours when parking, stopping or standing has been prohibited by signs or curb markings or is prohibited by statute or ordinance. 
(4)  Remain in any one place for a period longer than necessary to make a sale after having been approached or stopped for that purpose. 
(5)  Stop, stand or park his vehicle within 30 feet of any intersection, except that vehicles vending products likely to attract children as customers shall park curbside when stopping to make a sale. 
(6)  Sell or offer for sale any ice cream, popsicles, ice sherbets, prepared ice cream drinks, frozen desserts, and other similar products on any public street, sidewalk or public area in the city, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m., and 8:00 p.m. 
(7)  Sell or offer for sale any ice cream, popsicles, ice sherbets, prepared ice cream drinks, frozen desserts, and other similar products to any person when such person is within any public street or right-of-way normally used by motor vehicles. 
(8)  Leave any motor vehicle unattended. 
(9)  Park any motor vehicle other than in a lawful parking place, in conformance with city parking regulations. 
(10)  Sell food or beverages for immediate consumption unless he has available for public use his own or a public litter receptacle which is available for his patrons' use. 
(11)  Leave any location without first picking up, removing, and disposing of all trash or refuse remaining from sales made by him. 
(12)  Allow any items relating to the operation of the vending business to be placed anywhere other than in or under the motor vehicle. 
(13)  Solicit or conduct business with persons in motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 26523, passed 5-19-82) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.106-112.109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - HOME IMPROVEMENT CONTRACTORS 
Subdivision (A). - Home Improvement Contractor 

Sec. 112.110. - Home Improvement Contractor Review Board created. 
    A Home Improvement Contractor Review Board, which shall also be referred to as the Review Board, is created. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.111. - Membership of board; vacancy; quorum; rules of procedure. 
(A)  The Review Board shall consist of the Director of Economic Development who shall be the Chairperson, the Director of Community Development and the Director of Police, or their designees. The Review Board shall also consist of two representatives of the home improvement industry, a representative of the Better Business Bureau of Dayton/Miami Valley and a resident of the city, all of whom shall be appointed by the Commission annually for a term of one year beginning January 1 of each year, or until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(B)  In the event of a vacancy in the seats of the representatives of the home improvement industry, the Better Business Bureau of Dayton/Miami Valley, or a resident of the city, a successor shall be appointed by the Commission for the remaining portion of his term. 
(C)  A majority of the members of the Review Board shall constitute a quorum. 
(D)  The Review Board shall appoint a secretary for itself, adopt its own rules of procedure, and keep a record of its proceedings and transactions. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.112. - Enforcement of §§ 112.110 to 112.130. 
(A)  It is hereby made the duty of the Review Board to enforce, or aid in enforcing, §§ 112.110 to 112.130. 
(B)  The Review Board is empowered to issue orders granting, renewing, suspending, or revoking any registration provided for in accordance with the provisions of these sections. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Secs. 112.113, 112.114. - Reserved. 
Subdivision (B). - Home Improvement Contractors 

Sec. 112.115. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of §§ 112.115 to 112.130, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Contractor. Any person, other than a bona fide employee of the owner, who engages in the business of making home improvements, and who undertakes or offers to undertake or agrees to perform any home improvement, whether or not such person is registered, or subject to the registration requirements of § 112.116, and whether or not such person is a general contractor. 
    Home improvement. The repair, replacement, remodeling, alteration, conversion, modernization, improvement, or addition to any land or building, or that portion thereof which is used or designed to be used as a private residence or dwelling place for not more than two families; including, but not restricted to, the construction, replacement, or improvement or driveways, swimming pools, porches/decks, rooms, basements, windows/doors, roofs, siding, chimneys, garages, and other improvements to structures or upon land which is adjacent to a dwelling house. "Home improvement" shall not include the construction of a new home building or work done by a contractor in compliance with a guarantee of completion of a new building project, or the sale of goods or materials by a seller who neither arranges to perform nor performs directly or indirectly any work or labor in connection with the installation of or application of the goods or materials. 
    Home improvement contract. A written agreement contained in one or more documents between a contractor and an owner for the performance of a home improvement, including all labor, services, and materials furnished and performed thereunder, and the entire cost of same. 
    Registered contractor. A person licensed as a home improvement contractor as required by the provisions of § 112.116. 
    Owner. Any homeowner, tenant, or any other person who orders, contracts for, or purchases the home improvement services of a contractor, or the person entitled to the performance of the work of a contractor pursuant to a home improvement contract. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.116. - Registered required. 
    No person shall act as a home improvement contractor, whether personally, by agents or employees, singly, or along with some other business or enterprise, without first having registered in accordance with the provisions of §§ 112.115 to 112.130, or while such registration is under suspension or revocation as provided in § 112.128. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.117. - Registration application. 
    An application to become a registered contractor shall be made on an application form obtainable from the Department of Economic Development or from any other source so designated to distribute such applications. The form shall be filed with the Chairperson of the Review Board or other person designated to accept said applications, together with the required fee. The application shall be signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, or by the president or chief officer of a corporation or other organization. The application shall be sworn to by each of its signers before a notary public or other officer authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(Ord. 24799, passed 10-2-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.118. - Contents of registration application. 
    A home improvement contractor application for registration shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(A)  The name, residence address of each individual owner, partner, or, if a corporation, each officer thereof, and the name and residence of the manager or person to be responsible for the operation of the business if different from such individual owner, partners, or officers, and the federal identification number if incorporated, or social security number or other tax payer identification number of individuals; 
(B)  Any other trade name(s) or business name(s) used during the previous five years by the applicant or such person signing the application, along with the location of other business establishments operated in the state currently or during the previous five years; 
(C)  Names and addresses of employers during the previous five years of each person signing the application; 
(D)  The trade name, business address, and telephone number from which the business and/or contractor will operate; 
(E)  A copy of the contract form which will be used when scheduling jobs or agreeing to provide the services; 
(F)  The name and address of the applicant's bank and the number assigned by the bank to its business account; 
(G)  The names, addresses and phone numbers of a business/vendor reference and two customers references; 
(H)  A listing of professional/trade affiliations, certificates or designations; 
(I)  A disclosure of the convictions of any criminal offenses other than traffic violations; 
(J)  A certification that the applicant will participate in, and abide by, any alternative dispute resolution process, including mediation/binding arbitration, which the Review Board may designate to investigate and resolve complaints regarding the applicant; and 
(K)  Such other information as the review board may determine to be reasonably necessary and incidental to carrying out the provisions of § 112.115 to 112.130. 
(Ord. 24799, passed 10-2-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.119. - Public liability insurance required. 
(A)  Applicants for registration as home improvement contractor shall submit with their applications evidence that they have in full force and effect public liability insurance coverage in the following minimum amounts: 
(1)  Personal injury: 
$100,000.00 each person. 
$300,000.00 each occurrence. 
$300,000.00 completed operations. 
(2)  Property damage: 
$50,000.00 each occurrence. 
$50,000.00 aggregate for completed operations liability. 
(B)  Such insurance shall protect persons or property against loss arising out of negligence of the insured, his agents or employees, shall be for the term of the registration, and shall contain an endorsement that the insurance shall not be cancelled without giving the Chairperson of the Review Board 30 days' written notice prior to cancellation. 
(Ord. 24799, passed 10-2-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.120. - Surety bond required. 
(A)  An applicant for registration as home improvement contractors shall also submit with their applications a surety bond executed by a corporate surety authorized to do business in this state in an amount of not less than $10,000.00 running to the benefit of the owner, and conditioned upon the faithful completion by the home improvement contractor of all of the terms and conditions of all home improvement contracts entered into pursuant to the provisions of § 112.127. The liability of the surety on the bond shall be for the amount thereof for all claims in the aggregate arising during the term of the bond, which shall be the term of the registration.
