(B)  Home improvement contractors who certify on their applications that all contracts entered into by the contractor will not exceed a total of $2,500.00 for all home improvement work performed on a single residence or dwelling place may submit a surety bond executed by a corporate surety, authorized to do business in this state in the amount of not less than $5,000.00 running to the benefit of the owner, and conditioned upon the faithful completion by the home improvement contractor of all the terms and conditions of all home improvement contracts entered into pursuant to the provisions of § 112.127. The liability of the surety on the bond shall be for the amount thereof for all claims in the aggregate arising during the term of the bond, which shall be the term of the registration. 
(Ord. 24799, passed 10-2-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.121. - Registration fee. 
    The annual fees to be paid for registration and renewal shall be as follows: 
(A)  For home improvement contractors who register in accordance with § 112.120(B), this registration fee shall be $100.00 annually; 
(B)  For all other home improvement contractors registration fee shall be $200.00 annually; 
(C)  A duplicate registration for any registration card lost, destroyed, or mutilated, shall be provided for a fee of $10.00; 
(D)  One-half of the registration fee shall be refunded to the applicant in the event of the denial of issuance of any registration. A 25 percent late charge may be added to the renewal fee if it is received more than 30 days after the due date. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.122. - Issuance of registration. 
(A)  (1)  Upon receipt of an application for registration the Chairperson of the Review Board shall cause such investigation as he or she deems necessary to determine the accuracy of the information contained in the application, and shall request the Director of Police to determine whether any of the persons listed in the application have been convicted of any crime that was punishable by death or imprisonment in excess of one year in accordance with the law under which the applicant was convicted, or any crime relating to or reflecting on the business of home improvement contractor, such as, but not limited to, fraud, embezzlement, larceny by trick, forgery, or similar crime. 
(2)  The Director of Police shall submit a report to the Chairperson of the Review Board within ten days after receipt of the request therefor. The Chairperson of the Review Board shall also determine whether the proposed place of business of an applicant for home improvement contractor registration is in a proper zone for the conduct of such business, and that a valid certificate of occupancy has been issued therefor in accordance with the building code and zoning codes of the city. 
(B)  The Chairperson of the Review Board shall notify the Department of Economic Development to issue the registration applied for within 30 days after the receipt of such application. However, such notification shall not be made and such registration shall not be issued if the Chairperson of the Review Board finds: 
(1)  That the applicant has knowingly attempted to register through any fraud, misstatement, or omission of material fact; 
(2)  That the applicant, if the applicant is an individual, any partner, if the applicant is a partnership, any officer, if the applicant is a corporation, or any manager or responsible person named in the application has been convicted of any offense as provided in subsection (A); 
(3)  That, in the case of an application for renewal, the business or activity is being operated or carried on in any unlawful manner; 
(4)  That the applicant has failed to correct work which does not comply with applicable codes/regulations governing such work including, but not limited to, the Ohio basic building code and the Revised Code of General Ordinances of the city; or 
(5)  The business or activity is no longer being operated or carried on. 
(C)  All registered home improvement contractors shall conduct business in a responsible manner, including responding to customer complaints and abiding by compliance requirements established by the city. 
(D)  In the event of the denial of an application for registration or the renewal thereof, the Chairperson of the Review Board shall notify the applicant of such denial, and the reason therefor, in the manner provided in § 112.128(B)(3). The Chairperson shall keep a record of all registrations and applications. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.123. - Display of registration. 
    Each registration issued to a home improvement contractor shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the principal place of business. In addition, during such time as the contractor is performing any home improvement work, the contractor shall display a copy (no smaller than eight inches by 11 inches) of registration in a conspicuous place clearly visible from outside the residence or dwelling place wherein the home improvement work is being performed. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.124. - Period of registration; renewal. 
(A)  An application for registration shall be treated as a temporary registration for a period not to exceed 60 days. Application for a renewal of registration shall be filed with the Chairperson of the Review Board not less than 60 days prior to the date of expiration. 
(B)  Any registration or renewal thereof shall be effective as of the date of its issuance, and shall expire on December 31 next following the issuance of such registration. 
(C)  Any applicant for renewal of registration shall file with the Chairperson of the Review Board a written application, signed and sworn to in the same manner as required in the case of an original application, together with the required fee. The application shall contain such information about the applicant and his or her conduct in operating the registered business during the preceding registration period as is reasonably necessary to enable the Chairperson of the Review Board to determine the applicant's eligibility for renewal of registration. 
(Ord. 24723, passed 6-5-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.125. - Registration not transferable. 
    No registration issued under the provisions of § 112.122 shall be transferred or assigned or used by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.126. - Exceptions to registration requirements. 
    Registration of a home improvement contractor shall not be required of any person when acting in any of the following capacities: 
(A)  An individual who performs labor or services for a registered contractor for wages or salary; 
(B)  A plumber, electrician, architect, professional engineer, or any other such person who is required by state or local law to attain standards of competency or experience as a prerequisite to engaging in such craft or profession, and who is acting exclusively within the scope of the craft or profession for which he is currently registered pursuant to such law; 
(C)  Any retail clerk, clerical, administrative, or other employee of a registered contractor, as to a transaction on the premises of such contractor. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.127. - Contract provisions. 
    Every home improvement contract entered into by a registered contractor shall be in writing and shall include the following: 
(A)  The entire agreement between the owner and the registered contractor; 
(B)  The names and addresses of all parties, the date when executed by the parties, a full and complete description of the work to be performed and/or the goods or services to be furnished, the terms of payment, the date by which performance is to begin, and the date performance is to be completed; 
(C)  The contract shall be completed in full without blank spaces to be filled in after the contract has been executed, except for serial numbers or identifying marks which are not available for the description of the goods at the time of execution, and the due date of the first installment, if the same has been left blank because work has not been completed, if the contract provides for deferred payments. The contract shall be executed in duplicate, one of which will be retained by the owner; 
(D)  The contract shall incorporate by reference the conditions of the surety bond submitted by the registered contractor in accordance with the provisions of § 112.120. 
(Ord. 24799, passed 10-2-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.128. - Suspension and revocation of registration. 
(A)  The registration of registered contractor may be suspended or revoked by the Review Board for any of the following causes: 
(1)  That the license was knowingly obtained through any fraud, misstatement, or omission of material fact; 
(2)  Violation of § 112.123; 
(3)  Violation of § 112.127; 
(4)  The business transactions of the registered contractor have been marked by a practice of failure to appropriately perform contracts, or the manipulation of assets or accounts, or by fraud or bad faith; 
(5)  Such other breach of duty by the registered contractor as the Review Board may deem contrary to the intent and purpose of §§ 112.115 to 112.130. 
(B)  The suspension or revocation shall not take place until the Chairperson of the Review Board shall have notified the registered contractor in writing of the cause or causes for such revocation or suspension, which notice shall: 
(1)  Contain a brief statement of the facts relating to the revocation or suspension; 
(2)  Advise the registered contractor of the procedure for appeal; 
(3)  Be served upon the registered contractor in person by leaving it at his address as stated in the application for registration, or at the address on file with the Chairperson of the Review Board, or by certified or registered mail addressed to the contractor at such address. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 26919, passed 12-14-83; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.129. - Appeal procedure. 
(A)  Any person aggrieved by the denial of registration or the renewal thereof as provided in § 112.122, or by a notice of suspension or revocation as provided in § 112.128, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Review Board. However, such person shall file in the office of the Chairperson of the Review Board a written request for such hearing and set forth the name, address, and telephone number of the registered contractor, and a brief statement of the grounds for the appeal. This written request shall be filed within ten days after the service of the notice appealed from. Upon receipt of such a request, the Chairperson of the Review Board shall set a time and place for hearing before the Review Board, and shall give the appellant written notice thereof in the manner provided in § 112.128. The hearing shall be commenced within a reasonable time after a request has been filed. At such hearing, the appellant shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why the notice appealed from should be modified, or withdrawn. The failure of the appellant or a legal representative to appear and participate in the hearing shall have the same effect as if no request was filed. 
(B)  After a hearing, the Review Board may sustain, modify, or withdraw the notice appealed from by a majority vote, and the appellant shall be notified in writing of such action. 
(C)  The proceedings at such hearings, including the findings and decisions of the Review Board, and the reasons therefor, shall be summarized and reduced to writing and entered as a matter of public record of the Review Board. This record shall also include a copy of every notice in connection with the matter. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Sec. 112.130. - Preemption by state or federal law; limitation of registration; power of city to regulate. 
(A)  Where any provision of §§ 112.115 to 112.130 conflicts with any federal or state law, the federal or state law shall obtain. 
(B)  A registration granted pursuant to these sections shall not be construed to authorize the registered contractor to perform any particular type of work or kind of business which is reserved to qualified licensees under separate provisions of state or local law; nor shall any license or authority other than that granted under these sections be construed to authorize the grantee to engage in the home improvement business. 
(C)  Nothing in §§ 112.115 to 112.130 shall be construed to limit or restrict the power of the city to regulate the quality, performance, or character of work of contractors, including a system of permits and inspections which are designed to secure compliance with and aid in the enforcement of applicable state and local building laws, or to enforce other laws necessary for the protection of the public health and safety. 
(D)  Nothing in §§ 112.115 to 112.130 shall limit the power of the city to adopt any system of permits requiring submission to and approval by the city of plans and specifications for an installation prior to the commencement of construction of the installation or of inspection of work done. 
(Ord. 24711, passed 5-8-74; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95) 
Secs. 112.131-112.149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - ITINERANT PHOTOGRAPHERS 

Sec. 112.150. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of §§ 112.150 to 112.153 "itinerant photographer" shall mean any person, his agents and employees, who, for a consideration, solicit orders for photographs, photographic enlargements, or photographic reproductions, but who do not maintain regularly and permanently a bona fide studio in the city for the taking, enlargement, or reproduction of pictures or photographs. 
(Ord. 18067, passed 9-15-54) 
Sec. 112.151. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of itinerant photographer within the city without first having obtained and kept in full force and affect a license so to do. 
(Ord. 18067, passed 9-15-54) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.152. - Application for license; license fee. 
    Application for an itinerant photographer's license shall be made to and upon forms to be furnished by the City Accountant, who, if he shall be satisfied that the applicant is of good moral character, shall issue a license for the calendar year, or any part thereof, upon payment of the license fee of $200.00. 
(Ord. 18067, passed 9-15-54) 
Sec. 112.153. - Separate license for each person. 
    When more than one person is employed in soliciting orders for photographs or in taking photographs, a separate license shall be obtained for each person. 
(Ord. 18067, passed 9-15-54) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.154-112.159. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - ITINERANT WHOLESALE PRODUCE DEALERS 

Sec. 112.160. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of §§ 112.160 to 112.168, "itinerant wholesale produce dealer" shall mean any person who sells or offers for sale from a cart, wagon, truck, automobile, or other vehicle upon the streets, thoroughfares, or public grounds of the city, or from any such vehicle otherwise temporarily located anywhere within the city, any fruits, vegetables, garden produce, butter, eggs, cheese, meat, or live or dressed poultry, not grown, produced, or manufactured by such seller, to any person engaged in the business of resale at wholesale or retail of the same within the city. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Sec. 112.161. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of or make any sale or offer to sell as an itinerant wholesale produce dealer within the city without first obtaining a license. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.162. - Application for license; contents. 
(A)  Application for a license required herein shall be made at the office of the Director of Finance on a form to be provided by the director. 
(B)  The application under oath shall set forth the name and a brief description of any employee of the licensee who is authorized by the licensee to use the license, and such other pertinent information as the director may deem necessary to the administration and enforcement of §§ 112.160 to 112.168. 
(C)  Changes in the names of employees of the licensee authorized by the licensee to use the license may be made from time to time under such rules as the Director of Finance may prescribe. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Sec. 112.163. - Bond required. 
    Accompanying the license application, the applicant shall deposit with the Director of Finance a bond, approved as to form by the City Attorney, with surety or sureties thereon satisfactory to the Director of Finance, which shall run to the city and shall be in the penal sum of $500.00, and shall be conditioned that the applicant, if the license is issued to him, will comply with all of the terms, conditions, and provisions of the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state governing the merchandising and handling of such produce as is dealt in by the applicant, and, also, so drawn and conditioned as to indemnify any person buying from the licensee against any loss or injury occasioned to that person by reason of any misrepresentation or deception which may have been practiced on such person by the licensee while carrying on the licensed business under the said license, or occasioned by any violation of law or ordinance by the licensee; and further conditioned that recovery under the bond may be prosecuted and recovery had by such person in the name of the city, for use or benefit of such person. However, before any action is taken on the bond, such person shall be required to deposit with the Director of Finance a sum of money or other security which, in the opinion of the City Attorney, will be sufficient to assure payment of the costs of such action by such person should costs be assessed against the plaintiff. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Sec. 112.164. - Issuance of license; metal tags. 
(A)  The license provided for herein shall be issued by the Director of Finance to all applicants who comply with the terms and conditions of §§ 112.160 to 112.168. 
(B)  At the time of issuance of the license, the Director of Finance shall provide the licensee with two metal tags, not less than six inches wide and nine inches long upon which shall be conspicuously inscribed: "Wholesale Produce Vendor's License, Dayton, Ohio, No. _______, from _______ to _______," giving in the blank spaces the number of the license and the date from and to which the same shall be in force. Such metal tags shall be securely fastened, in plain view, on either side of the vehicle used by the licensee whenever he or an authorized employee is operating under the license. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Sec. 112.165. - Terms of license. 
    The license shall expire on June 1 following the date of issue. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Sec. 112.166. - License fee; no refund allowed. 
(A)  The fee for the license required herein shall be $1,500.00 which sum shall be deposited with the Director of Finance at the time application for license is made. 
(B)  No refund shall be made to any licensee because of failure to use the license during all or a part of the term for which it was granted, and no license shall be granted for a sum less than that specified in subsection (A) hereof for any portion of the year. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Sec. 112.167. - Display of license. 
    The license must be carried by the licensee or his employee named and described therein at all times while such licensee, either personally or by such employee, is operating thereunder, and must be exhibited to any police officer or other officer or employee of the city properly authorized to enforce §§ 112.160 to 112.168 at any time upon demand of such officer or employee. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.168. - License not transferable. 
    The licenses shall not be transferable, shall be consecutively numbered, beginning with number one on June 1 of each year, and shall not be used by any person other than the licensee or an employee of the licensee, whose name and description is set forth in the application for the license, as provided in § 112.162, and whose name and description is also set forth on the face of the license. 
(Ord. 14741, passed 4-26-33) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.169-112.179. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - SPECIAL POLICE 

Sec. 112.180. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of §§ 112.180 to 112.195, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    Direct employer of special police officers. A person, firm, business, or corporation who employs licensed special police officers directly, rather than through a special police agency, to perform any of the duties ascribed to an "in-house security agent." 
    In-house security agent. A person, not licensed as a special police officer and therefore has no police powers nor authority to carry or wear a firearm, and who is not employed by or acting on behalf of a private investigation and security agency, whose duties include any of the following: 
(1)  Investigates matters pertinent to the business of his/her employer. 
(2)  Protects persons on the property of his/her employer. 
(3)  Protects the property of his/her employer. 
    Institution. A governmental entity, educational or medical facility which owns or has possession of not less than five acres of land which are utilized in the administration and operation of its functions or mission. 
    Institutional special police officer. A person, except a correctional officer employed solely as such, who: 
(A)  Is licensed by the city; 
(B)  Is commissioned with the power of arrest by the city; 
(C)  Is employed directly by an institution as defined herein, and is not employed by, or their services provided to the institution by any agency or security guard provider as defined in R.C. § 4749.01; 
(D)  Has authority to carry or wear a firearm while employed by and performing any of the following duties and functions while on the premises of the employing institution; 
(1)  Investigate matters pertinent to the function or mission of the institution; 
(2)  Protects persons on the premises of the institution; 
(3)  Protects the property of the institution; 
(4)  Enforces the rules and regulations of the institution relating to the safety and protection of persons and property. 
    Private investigation and security agency. A business licensed by the State of Ohio that provides private investigators, or security agents for hire. 
    Private investigation and security agency operator. A person who engages in the business of private investigation and security, as an individual, a partner, or the managing officer of a corporation, and who possesses a valid private investigator's license issued by the State of Ohio. 
    Private investigator. A person, not licensed as a special police officer and therefore has no police powers nor authority to carry or wear a firearm, who is employed by a private investigation and security agency and who engages in conducting any investigation relevant to any of the following: 
(1)  Any crime or wrong done or threatened. 
(2)  To obtain information on the identity, habits, conduct, movements, whereabouts, affiliations, transactions, reputation, credibility, or character of any person or firm. 
(3)  To locate and recover lost or stolen property. 
(4)  To determine the cause of or responsibility for any libel, slander, fire, accident, or damage to property. 
(5)  To secure evidence for use in any legislative, administrative, or judicial investigation or proceedings. 
    Security agent. A person, not licensed as a special police officer and therefore has no police powers nor authority to carry or wear a firearm, employed by a private investigation and security agency whose assigned duties are performed primarily on the premises of the customer of the private investigation and security agency, and such duties include any of the following: 
(1)  Watchman. 
(2)  Alarm sounder. 
(3)  Nonuniformed or uniformed guard. 
(4)  Nonuniformed or uniformed security escort. 
    Special police agency. A private investigation and security agency that is issued a special police agency license by the city to provide the services for hire of special police officers. 
    Special police officer. A person licensed by the city as a special police officer commissioned with the powers of arrest and has authority to carry or wear a firearm who performs any of the duties and functions ascribed to a "private investigator," "security agent" or an "in-house security agent" as defined in this section. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84; Am. Ord. 28024, passed 10-4-89) 
Sec. 112.181. - License required. 
(A)  No person shall perform any service as a special police officer within the city without first obtaining and maintaining in full force and effect a valid special police officer license. 
(B)  No person shall manage or operate a special police agency within the city without first obtaining and maintaining in full force and effect all of the following: 
(1)  A valid private investigator's license issued by the state. 
(2)  A valid special police agency license. 
(3)  A valid special police officer license. 
(C)  A person not licensed as a special police officer shall not perform any service as an armed private investigator or armed security agent within the city. 
(D)  No person shall wear a special police officer badge, or represent or hold himself out to be a special police officer unless he is duly licensed as such by the city. 
(E)  Members of the Police Department are authorized to enforce the provisions of §§ 112.180 to 112.195 of this Code. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.182. - Application for license. 
(A)  Every person desiring to perform the duties of a special police officer, or to operate a special police agency, shall submit an application for the appropriate license to the Director of Police on a form provided for that purpose. The applicant shall answer all questions in the application, and in the case of a firm or corporation, include the names and addresses of all officers thereof, and in the case of a partnership, the names and addresses of all partners with the trade name under which they intend to operate. 
(B)  Upon receipt of the application, the Director of Police shall cause to be made such investigation of the application as is necessary to determine whether the applicant meets the requirements set forth in this division. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.183. - Requirements for special police officer license. 
    An applicant for the initial issuance or renewal of a special police officer license shall meet the following requirements: 
(A)  Be an American citizen. 
(B)  Be 21 or more years of age. 
(C)  Be in sound physical condition, have good eyesight, and not subject to any infirmity, defect, or disorder of mind or body which might reasonably render him unfit for the safe carrying out of the duties of an armed special police officer, as determined by the Director of Police from all reliable medical, psychological, or health information supplied by the applicant or other persons concerning the applicant's physical or mental condition. Where such facts indicate that an applicant is suffering from any such infirmity, defect, or disorder of mind or body, the Director of Police may require the applicant, at his expense, to be examined by a licensed physician, psychologist, or psychiatrist and to submit such physician's, psychologist's, or psychiatrist's written report of such examination to the Director for use in determining the applicant's fitness. 
(D)  Possess a training certification from an Ohio Peace Officers Training Council approved school indicating successful completion of the basic police school, including a satisfactory firearms range qualification score on a practical pistol course with a service firearm. The requirement of a training certification shall be implemented as follows: 
(1)  Persons who apply for a license in 1984 after the effective date of this division but prior to September 1, 1984, must obtain the certification within four months after the issuance of the license. 
(2)  Persons who apply for a license in 1984 after September 1, 1984, must obtain the certification prior to renewal of the license for 1985. 
(3)  All applicants for licenses for the year 1985 and thereafter, both initial issuance and renewal of license, must obtain the certification prior to the issuance of the license. 
(E)  Beginning on January 1, 1986, every applicant for renewal of a special police officer license shall submit with the application for renewal, a certificate issued within the previous 12 months from a qualified range instructor certifying that the applicant has satisfactorily re-qualified with his service firearm. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.184. - Requirements for special police agency license. 
    An applicant for the initial issuance or renewal of a special police agency license shall meet the following requirements: 
(A)  Possess a current private investigator's license or watch guard license issued by the state. A copy of the license shall be submitted with the application. 
(B)  Possess a current special police officer's license issued by the city. An application for a special police officer's license may be processed simultaneously with an application for a special police agency license. 
(C)  Provide a 24-hour contact telephone number which will enable the Police Department to have person-to-person contact with a representative of the agency within 60 minutes of a completed telephone call to the contact number. 
(D)  Pass a written examination given by the Police Department to determine knowledge of appropriate ordinances of the city and police rules and regulations relative to special police agencies and special police officers. 
(E)  Possess a current Ohio Workers Compensation certificate or a copy of an application on file with the state, which covers all employees of the agency. A copy of the certificate shall be submitted with the application. The agency must maintain workers compensation insurance during the entire licensing period and provide proof thereof to the Police Department Licensing Unit. 
(F)  The liability insurance specified in § 112.189 shall be kept in full force and effect during the entire licensing period. 
(G)  The requirements in this section shall become effective on the effective date of this chapter as to all special police agencies for licenses that are initially issued and for licenses that are renewed; provided, however, that the provisions of subsection (D) above shall only apply to agencies that are initially licensed after the effective date of this chapter, and to previously licensed agencies at the time when there is a change in the operator of the agency. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.185. - Denial of license; Appeals Licensing Board created; appeal procedure. 
(A)  A special police officer license or a special police agency license shall not be issued to any person who: 
(1)  Has been adjudged mentally incompetent and not legally restored to competency. 
(2)  Is awaiting court action for any criminal offense, except minor traffic violations. 
(3)  Is subject to an infirmity, defect, or disorder of mind or body which might reasonably render him unfit for the safe carrying out of the duties of an armed special police officer as determined by the Director of Police pursuant to the provisions in § 112.183(C). 
(B)  In addition to the grounds for denial set forth above neither a special police officer license nor a special police agency license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted, pled guilty to, or forfeited bond for any of the following within the last 20 years: 
(1)  Any offense constituting a felony. 
(2)  A misdemeanor involving public disorder, violence, theft, or public indecency. 
(3)  Two or more misdemeanors, other than minor misdemeanors, neither of which involved public disorder, violence, theft, or public indecency. 
(C)  If a license is denied or refused, the Director of Police shall cause written notification of such denial or refusal to be given to the applicant by certified mail at the address in the application, and said written notification shall include the basis for such denial or refusal, and shall advise the applicant of the procedure for appeal. 
(D)  An Appeals Licensing Board is hereby created and shall consist of the Director of Finance, who shall be the Chairman, the Director of Law, or their duly authorized representatives, and a designee of the City Manager. A majority of the members of the Appeals Licensing Board shall constitute a quorum. 
(E)  Any applicant who has been denied or refused a special police officer license or a special police agency license may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Appeals Licensing Board by submitting a written request for such hearing to the Director of Police within ten days after the service of the notice of denial or refusal. The written request for a hearing shall set forth the name, address, and telephone number of the applicant, and a brief statement of the grounds for appeal. Upon receipt of a request for a hearing the director of police shall immediately deliver a copy thereof to the Chairman of the Appeals Licensing Board who shall set a time and place for the hearing before the Appeals Licensing Board, and shall give the applicant written notice thereof by certified mail at least ten days prior to the date set for the hearing. The hearing shall be commenced within a reasonable time after a request has been filed. 
(F)  At such hearing, the applicant shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why he believes the license should be issued. The Director of Police, or his designee shall also be given an opportunity to be heard and to state the reasons why he believes the license should not be issued. The failure of the applicant or his representative to appear and state his case at such hearing shall have the same effect as if no request for a hearing was filed. 
(G)  After the hearing, the Appeals Licensing Board may, by a majority vote, sustain or deny the appeal, and the applicant shall be notified in writing of such decision and the reasons therefor. 
(H)  The proceedings at such hearings, including the decisions of the Appeals Licensing Board, and the reasons for the decision shall be summarized and reduced to writing and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the Director of Police. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.186. - Issuance of license; expiration. 
(A)  Upon approval of the application the Director of Police shall issue a license to the applicant authorizing that person to perform the duties of a special police officer or to engage in the business of operating a special police agency, as the case may be. 
(B)  Special police agency licenses issued to a corporation or a partnership shall be issued in the name of the corporation or partnership and the name of the operator or manager of the agency. 
(C)  All licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year, unless sooner revoked. 
(D)  All applications for renewal of licenses must be filed with the Director of Police not less than 30 days prior to December 31 of each year. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.187. - Fee schedule. 
(A)  The initial application and annual fees for special police officer and special police agency licenses, and the charges to direct employers of special police officers shall be as follows: 
Effective

    The initial application fees set forth above for special police agency licenses are in addition to the annual license fees. 
(B)  All initial special police agency licenses issued between July 1 and December 31 in any year shall be one-half of the amounts set forth above. There shall be no reduction of the initial application fees for special police officer and special police agency licenses regardless of when the application is filed, and no portion of the fees will be refunded if a license is not issued for any reason. 
(C)  All fees shall be payable into the city treasury and credited to the general fund. 
(D)  Direct employers of special police officers shall pay the annual charge set forth above to the city for conducting background investigation and administrative processing of applicants to be employed by the direct employer. The charge shall be paid at the time the direct employer requests the Police Department to provide this service or renew the license. The background investigation, administrative processing, or renewals will not be commenced until this charge has been paid by the direct employer. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.188. - Exemption from license. 
    No license shall be required nor shall any provisions of §§ 112.180 through 112.195 apply to any person or employee thereof engaged exclusively in the following businesses or occupations: 
(A)  The protection of persons, passengers, or property being transported in interstate or intrastate common carriers. 
(B)  Regular insurance business. 
(C)  Attorney or counselor-at-law in the regular practice of the legal profession. This exemption shall not inure to the benefit of an employee or representative of an attorney who is not employed solely, exclusively, and regularly by the attorney. 
(D)  Bureaus or agencies whose business is exclusively the furnishing of information as the business and financial standing and credit responsibility of persons, or as to personal habits and financial responsibility of applicants for insurance, indemnity bonds, or commercial credit, or of claimants under insurance policies. 
(E)  Any officer belonging to a police force of the United States, the state or any county, city, or village appointed or elected by due authority of law, in any matter related to or arising from their employment as such. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.189. - Insurance required. 
(A)  Every applicant for a special police officer's license or a special police agency license shall, prior to the license being issued, submit proof of comprehensive general liability insurance coverage in such form as is satisfactory to the Director of Police, but not less than $100,000.00 for each person and $300,000.00 for each occurrence for bodily injury and personal injury liability, and $100,000.00 for property damage liability and naming the city and its officers and employees as additional insured parties in any claim arising out of the applicant's activities as a special police officer or special police agency. The policy shall remain in full force and effect during the entire licensing period. 
(B)  The policy shall further provide that the insolvency or bankruptcy of the licensee shall not release the insurance company from payment required to be made by the policy otherwise, but shall remain in full force and effect, and available to any person damaged the same as though the licensee was not insolvent or bankrupt. 
(C)  The policy shall provide in addition to the aforesaid provisions, that no notice of any acts creating any liability thereunder will be required from the city; that the policy shall not be cancelled before ten days written notice of intention so to cancel has been given the Director of Police; and that the policy shall not be revocable, but shall remain in full force and effect until ten days have elapsed from the date of service of the written notice. 
(D)  The policy shall be renewed annually to the satisfaction of the Director of Police. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.190. - Reports to police required. 
(A)  Every special police agency shall notify the Director of Police in writing of the hiring or termination, within ten days thereof, of any employee performing service as a special police officer. 
(B)  Any property found or recovered by any special police officer employed by a special police agency shall be reported to the Director of Police immediately. Direct employers of special police officers shall make available to the Director of Police upon demand records of property found or recovered by such special police officers. Any misconduct of any special police officer shall be reported to the Director of Police immediately. In the event misconduct of a special police officer is known to the person operating a special police agency, the person in charge of such agency must submit a report immediately to the Director of Police; and, if necessary, appear and bring action against the special police officer. 
    Failure to comply with the submission of any information as provided for herein shall be deemed a violation of this section and considered as just cause to revoke the license of the person or agency. 
(C)  If a special police officer engages in improper conduct and this conduct is known to a city police officer, the police officer shall report such conduct to his commanding officer who shall take the proper action and submit a report which will be forwarded to the Director of Police and then in turn to the person operating the agency. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.191. - Powers and duties of special police officers. 
    The powers and duties of all persons licensed under the provisions of §§ 112.180 through 112.195 shall be: 
(A)  To obey the orders of the Director of Police. 
(B)  To be permitted to carry arms and have the power of arrest only when on duty and in the scope of his employment and then only in compliance with R.C. § 2923.12. 
(C)  To obey and comply with all rules and regulations for special police officers and special police agencies as set forth by the Director of Police. 
(D)  When on duty and in the scope of his employment a special police officer: 
(1)  May work in uniform or not in uniform; provided, however, that any uniform that is worn shall be approved as to color and style by the Director of Police. 
(2)  When in uniform shall wear a shoulder patch on the left sleeve, bearing the name of the agency by whom employed, the color and design to be approved by the Director of Police. 
(3)  When in uniform shall wear the special police badge issued by the city on the left breast of the outermost garment. 
(4)  May drive a vehicle in the course of his employment only after the color, equipment, and apparatus have been approved by the Director of Police. 
The Director of Police may waive the uniform and badge requirements for any industrial manufacturer or other private business concern which employs its own guard or security force and requires them to be licensed special police officers. 
(E)  A special police officer who notifies the Department of Police of the commission of a crime shall not, after such notification, conduct an investigation into the matter without the consent of the Department of Police. During an investigation of any crime, the Department of Police reserves the right to stop a special police officer from investigating or interfering in any way with the Department of Police. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.192. - Badge; termination of employment. 
(A)  At the time of appointment as a special police officer, a badge shall be issued by the Department of Police. Upon termination of employment as a special police officer it shall be the responsibility of such special police officer to surrender the badge to the Director of Police within five days of such termination. 
(B)  Upon termination of employment as a special police officer it shall be the joint responsibility of the officer and the agency by whom employed to report such termination to the Department of Police, as specified in § 112.190(A). 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999 
Sec. 112.193. - Special police officer not to qualify for police benefits. 
    Any police service rendered as a special police officer shall not qualify such person or assist to qualify such person in any way for participation in any of the emoluments, privileges, or benefits of the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund, or any of the benefits or emoluments received by city police officers or other employees of the city. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.194. - Oath required. 
    Before entering upon the duties as a special police officer, every person so appointed shall take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation similar to the oath or affirmation administered to the police officers of the city, which oath or affirmation shall be filed and kept in the office of the Director of Police. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Sec. 112.195. - Suspension/revocation of license. 
    The Director of Police shall have the right and authority to suspend or revoke, after notice and hearing, any license and badge issued under the provisions of §§ 112.180 to 112.195, inclusive, whenever just cause exists. The following shall be considered just cause: 
(A)  If such licensee or an employee of the licensee has violated any of the provisions of §§ 112.180 to 112.194, inclusive. 
(B)  If any employee of the licensee shall have violated any of the provisions of these sections with knowledge, permission, or instructions of the licensee to do so. 
(C)  Conviction of any offense, except minor traffic violations, as specified in § 112.185(B)(1), (B)(2), and (B)(3). 
(D)  Violation of the rules and regulations for special police officers and special police agencies as set forth by the Director of Police. 
(E)  Displaying a special police officer badge issued by the city in any employment as a special police officer or private investigator outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(F)  If such licensee's physical or mental condition becomes such as to render him unfit for the safe carrying out of the duties of an armed special police officer, as determined by the Director of Police pursuant to the provisions in § 112.183(C). 
(G)  The provisions in § 112.185 regarding written notification, procedure for appeal, a hearing before the Appeals Licensing Board, and a decision rendered by the board, shall apply to any action taken by the Director of Police under this section. 
(Ord. 27003, passed 5-30-84) 
Secs. 112.196-112.199. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - SALVAGE YARD OPERATORS AND ITINERANT SALVAGE DEALERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 30580-06, § 1, adopted July 5, 2006, amended Div. 12 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 112-200-112-214, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. 12034, passed Jan. 23, 1924; Ord. 14743, passed June 14, 1933; Ord. 23671, passed Apr. 8, 1970; and Ord. 26690 passed Dec. 22, 1982. 

Sec. 112.200. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 112.200 to 112.214, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively, regardless of whether or not the words and phrases are capitalized: 
    Bulk salvage material. Salvage with a cumulative weight in excess of 25 pounds, or a total area in excess of ten square feet, or a total volume in excess of one cubic yard. 
    Business premises or premises. The area of a salvage yard as described in a salvage yard operator's license or application for license, as provided for in §§ 112.200 to 112.214. 
    Licensing Board. The Salvage Yard Operator Licensing Board established pursuant to § 112.203. 
    Salvage or salvage materials . Ferrous and non-ferrous metals, scrap iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead, aluminum or other base metals; old cordage, ropes, rags, fibers, or fabrics; old bottles or other glass; bones, paper, plastic, discarded construction materials, and other waste or discarded material used for recycling or reclamation, or processed for reuse in some other form; motor vehicles, no longer used as such, to be used for scrap metal or stripping of parts; and those materials commonly or customarily referred to as "junk." 
    Salvage yard. Any facility where salvage or salvage materials, in whole units or by parts, for a business or commercial purpose, or for personal use, is purchased, kept, stored, dismantled, sold, exchanged, traded, or offered for sale, processed or prepared for sale, or reuse for any purpose. 
    Salvage yard operator. Any person, sole proprietor, partnership, corporation, and any employee thereof, that operates a salvage yard. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.201. - License required; exceptions. 
    No person shall act as a salvage yard operator whether personally, by agents, or employees, or along with some other business or enterprise, without a valid license. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.202. - Separate license for each salvage yard. 
    A salvage yard operator who operates more than one salvage yard within the city is required to have a separate license for each salvage yard. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06) 
Sec. 112.203. - Salvage Yard Operator Licensing Board. 
    A Salvage Yard Operator Licensing Board is created. The members of the Licensing Board shall consist of the Director of Finance, the Director of Building Services, the Director of Police, and the Director of Fire or their duly authorized representatives. The Director of Building Services shall serve as the Chairman of the Licensing Board. Except where otherwise provided, a majority of the members of the Licensing Board shall constitute a quorum. The Licensing Board shall appoint a secretary for itself from among the employees of the city, adopt its own procedural rules, and keep a record of its proceedings and transactions. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.204. - Enforcement of §§ 112.200 to 112.214. 
    The Licensing Board is empowered to issue orders granting, renewing, suspending, or revoking any license provided for in accordance with the provisions of §§ 112.200 to 112.214. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06) 
Sec. 112.205. - Application for license; contents. 
(A)  An applicant for a salvage yard operator license shall obtain an application from the Department of Finance. The application shall be completed by the applicant and filed with the Department of Finance together with the required fee. The application shall be signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners, if a partnership, or by the president or chief officer, if a corporation or other organization. The application shall be sworn to by each of its signers before a notary public or other officer authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(B)  All salvage yard operator applications shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and residence address of each individual owner, partner or, if a corporation, each officer, and the name and residence address of the manager or person responsible for the operation of such salvage yard if different from the individual owner, partner, or officer; 
(2)  Trade names used during the previous five years by the applicant and each person signing the application, along with the locations of prior business establishments in the state during the previous five years; 
(3)  Names and addresses of employers during the previous five years of each person signing the application; 
(4)  The trade name, business address and telephone number of the business on behalf of which application is made; 
(5)  A plot plan, drawn to scale, showing the location of all buildings on the business premises, together with a description of the type of construction of such buildings and their uses, and showing adjoining streets, roads, and property lines; and 
(6)  Such other information as the Licensing Board shall find reasonably necessary to effectuate the purposes of §§ 112.200 to 112.214 and to arrive at a fair determination of whether the requirements of these sections are met. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.206. - Investigation, approval and issuance of salvage yard operator license. 
(A)  Upon receipt of an application for a salvage yard operator's license, the Chairman of the Licensing Board shall furnish a copy of the application to each of the other members of the Licensing Board. The proposed or existing premises and equipment with which the salvage yard is being or is to be operated shall be examined by the other members of the Licensing Board. 
(B)  The Director of Police shall investigate whether any of the persons listed in the application have been convicted of a violation of § 112.201, or other crime related to the business of salvage yard operator within a period of five years preceding the filing of such application, and shall recommend that the license be issued only if he finds that there have been no such convictions. 
(C)  The Director of Building Services shall investigate whether the property on which the salvage yard is located and any existing or proposed buildings or equipment which the salvage yard is being or is to be operated conform to the requirements of §§ 112.200 to 112.214, the building code, the zoning code and chapters 152 and 150, respectively. 
(D)  The Director of Fire shall investigate whether the existing or proposed premises and equipment conform to the requirements of §§ 112.200 to 112.214 and all applicable fire prevention laws and ordinances of the city. 
(E)  No salvage yard operator license shall be issued unless all members of the Licensing Board recommend that the license be issued. If any member of the board recommends that a license not be issued, the Chairman shall notify all of the members of the Licensing Board and shall also notify the applicant, in writing, of such disapproval and the grounds therefor, and simultaneously therewith the Chairman shall set the matter for a hearing before the Licensing Board on the question of whether or not the license should be issued. The Chairman shall give notice in writing of the date, time, and place of such hearing to the members of the Licensing Board and to the applicant, and such hearing shall be held within 45 days after the filing of the application. 
(F)  If all of the members of the Licensing Board recommend that a license be issued, the Chairman shall notify the Department of Finance within 30 days after the filing of the application, and request the Department of Finance to issue a salvage yard operator's license to the applicant if: 
(1)  The applicant obtained from the Division of Building of Inspection a certificate of occupancy to the effect that the salvage yard will not be in violation of the building code and the zoning code; and 
(2)  The applicant paid the fees, if any are due, provided for in the building and zoning codes. 
(G)  A salvage yard operator license shall not be issued if: 
(1)  The applicant knowingly attempted to obtain his license through any fraud or misstatement; or 
(2)  In the case of an application for a renewal license, the business or activity is being operated or carried on in any unlawful manner; or 
(3)  The business or activity is no longer being operated or carried on. 
(H)  All salvage yard operator licenses issued by the city shall bear the following language on its face: 
"IMPORTANT. This license applies only to the premises indicated herein and authorizes the licensee to operate a salvage yard in a lawful place and manner only; it is not a substitute for, nor is it in lieu of, any Certificate of Occupancy, building permit, or any other certificate or permit that is now or may hereafter be required by law or ordinance, and it does not relieve the licensee of the responsibility to have all such required permits or certificates at all times and comply with all laws and ordinances affecting the above described business." 
(I)  The Department of Finance shall keep a record of all applications filed and all licenses issued in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06) 
Sec. 112.207. - Investigation, approval and issuance of itinerant salvage dealer license. 
(A)  Upon receipt of an application for an itinerant salvage dealer license, the Chairman of the Licensing Board shall furnish a copy of the application to each of the other members of the Licensing Board. 
(B)  The Director of Police shall investigate whether the applicant has been convicted of a violation of § 112.201 or any other crime related to the business of an itinerant salvage dealer within a period of five years preceding the filing of such application, and shall recommend that the license be issued only if finds that there have been no such convictions. 
(C)  If the Licensing Board finds that there have been no such convictions, the Chairman of the Licensing Board shall notify the Department of Finance within 30 days after the filing of the application and request the Department of Finance to issue an itinerant salvage dealer license to the applicant bearing the applicant's photograph taken at the time the application is submitted. 
(D)  If the Licensing Board finds that there have been any such convictions, the Chairman of the Licensing Board shall, within 30 days after the filing of the application, notify the applicant that the application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. Upon request, he shall furnish the applicant with a brief written statement of the grounds upon which the application was disapproved. 
(E)  The Department of Finance shall keep a record of all applications filed and all licenses issued in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06) 
Sec. 112.208. - Period of license; renewal procedure. 
(A)  All applications for a license or renewal of a license to be issued under the provisions of §§ 112.206 shall be filed with the Department of Finance not less than 60 days prior to the date the applicant desires the license to become effective. 
(B)  Any license or renewal of a license issued hereunder shall be effective as of the date of its issuance and shall expire on December 31 next following the issuance of the license. 
(C)  An applicant for renewal of a license shall file with the Department of Finance an application on forms provided by the Department of Finance, signed and sworn to in the same manner as required in the case of an original application, together with the required fee. The application shall contain such information about the applicant and the conduct and operation of the licensed business during the preceding license period as is reasonably necessary to enable the Licensing Board to determine the applicant's eligibility for renewal of the license. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.209. - License fees. 
(A)  The annual fees for licenses issued under §§ 112.200 through 112.214, are as follows: 
(1)  For a salvage yard operator license: 
(i)  One hundred twenty-five dollars for each salvage yard containing less than 50,000 square feet of land area; 
(ii)  One hundred seventy-five dollars for each salvage yard containing 50,000 or more square feet of land area; 
(iii)  Of the fees stated in (A)(1) and (2) above, the sum of $50.00 will be treated as an "application fee" and shall be paid by the applicant at the time the application for a license or renewal of a license is filed with the Chairman of the Licensing Board. This application fee will be used by the city to defray the costs of investigation and processing the application and is not refundable. The balance of the fees stated in (A)(1) and (2) above shall be paid at the time a license is issued to the applicant. 
(B)  If the license is issued, or is to become effective on or after July 1 in any given year for the remainder of that year, the license fee shall be one-half of the above stated fees, but in all cases the application fees shall remain as set forth herein and shall not be abated or proportionately reduced. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.210. - License not transferable. 
    No license issued under § 112.206 shall be transferred or assigned or used by any person other than the one to whom it was issued, and no salvage yard operator's license shall be used for any premises other than those described in the application upon which it was issued. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.211. - Prohibited acts. 
(A)  No person shall use a public sidewalk to carry, move or transport bulk salvage materials within the city. Section 112.211(A) is intended to impose strict criminal liability. No culpable mental state is required to commit an offense of § 112.211(A). 
(B)  No person shall knowingly use, display, furnish or present the identification of another as proof of identification required by § 112.212(A)(17). 
(C)  No person shall use, display, furnish or present proof of identification required by § 112.212(A)(17) knowing the same to be fictitious or altered. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.212. - General operating requirements. 
(A)  The following general operating requirements shall apply to all salvage yards and salvage yards operators: 
(1)  The license required by § 112.201 shall be plainly displayed on the business premises at all times; 
(2)  The salvage yard, together with things kept therein, shall at all times be maintained so as not to create a public nuisance; 
(3)  Any space of land area not described in the license shall not be used in the licensed business; 
(4)  No water shall be allowed to stand in any place on the premises in such manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes; 
(5)  Weeds and vegetation on the premises, other than trees, shrubs, or other ornamental vegetation, shall be kept at a height of not more than six inches; 
(6)  No garbage or other waste liable to give off a foul odor or attract vermin shall be kept or permitted to remain on the premises; nor shall any refuse of any kind be kept on the premises, unless such refuse is salvage as defined in § 112.200 and is used in the licensed business; 
(7)  No salvage shall be allowed to rest upon or protrude into any public right-of-way or become scattered or blown off the business premises; 
(8)  All salvage, when in open storage, shall be stored in piles in such a manner as to insure that none of the material will fall outside of the salvage yard in the event of the collapse of the pile; 
(9)  No combustible material of any kind not necessary or beneficial to the licensed business shall be kept on the premises nor shall the premises be allowed to become a fire hazard; 
(10)  Gasoline and oil shall be removed from any scrapped engines or vehicles on the premises; 
(11)  No salvage shall be burned on the premises except in an incinerator approved by the appropriate air pollution control agency; 
(12)  No processing of salvage in the normal and customary course of business shall be carried on in connection with the licensed business between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; 
(13)  The area on the premises where salvage is kept (other than indoors) shall be enclosed with a nontransparent wall or fence of uniform material and uniform height with a minimum height of six feet measured from ground level. This wall or fence shall be maintained so as to obscure the salvage in the enclosure from the ordinary view of persons passing the salvage yard upon any public street or highway upon which the salvage yard abuts. The wall or fence shall be kept in good order and repair, and no advertisement shall be permitted thereon other than the name of the person under whose name the license has been issued and the nature of the business conducted therein. Entrances and exits shall not be wider or more numerous than reasonably necessary for the conduct of the licensed business; 
(14)  The licensee shall permit inspection of the business premises and the inspection of any salvage materials on the premises by any member or representative of a member of the Licensing Board at any reasonable time; 
(15)  No salvage yard operator licensed under § 112.201, or his agent or employee, shall knowingly purchase or receive any salvage for use in the licensed business from any person under the age of 18 years without the written consent of a parent or guardian of such person. Such written consent shall be held available for inspection by any member, or representative of a member of the Licensing Board, for a period of at least one year from the date of purchase or receipt; 
(16)  Every transaction for the purchase or receipt of salvage shall be recorded in English in a permanent pre-numbered electronic or written register. The salvage yard operator shall record the following information in the register: 
(i)  The person's name, address or residence; 
(ii)  The person's driver's license number or government issued photo identification number; 
(iii)  A description of the salvage; 
(iv)  The date and time of the transaction; and 
(v)  The person's vehicle license plate number, when reasonably obtainable. This register shall be retained on the business premises of the salvage yard operator for a period of two years from the date of the transaction and made available for inspection by any member or representative of a member of the Licensing Board. 
(17)  For each transaction for the purchase or receipt of salvage, the salvage yard operator shall require the person to provide the following: 
(i)  His or her name, address or residence; 
(ii)  A valid driver's license or government issued photo identification; 
(18)  The salvage yard shall be operated in such a manner that all loading, unloading, and working of the salvage piles, and the equipment involved therein, shall be done entirely within the confines of the salvage yard. 
(B)  The Director of Police or his representative, with the assistance of the director of such other department or departments as may be appropriate, shall conduct inspections to insure compliance with the general operating requirements herein provided. Upon request the operator shall provide to the Director of Police or his representative a written or electronic copy of the pre-numbered register. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.212.1. - Stolen property. 
(A)  No salvage yard operator, agent or employee, shall knowingly purchase or receive stolen property as salvage for use in the licensed business. It shall be prima facie evidence that the salvage yard operator knew or should have known the property is stolen at the time of the purchase or receipt of the property where the police department informed the salvage yard operator in writing and provided a description of the stolen property and the name of the true owner 72 hours prior to the time of the transaction. 
(B)  No salvage yard operator licensed under § 112.201, nor his agent or employee, shall knowingly change, alter, deface, recycle or reclaim property after written notification of stolen property for a law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.213. - Suspension and revocation of license. 
(A)  In addition to any other penalties provided by this chapter, the license of a salvage yard operator may be suspended or revoked by the Licensing Board for failure to comply with the provisions of § 112.212. However, such suspension or revocation shall not take place until the Chairman of the Licensing Board shall have first notified the salvage yard operator calling specific attention to the infractions of § 112.212 and affording a reasonable time and opportunity to correct said infractions. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be put in writing on an appropriate form; 
(2)  Include a list of violations, referring to the subsections violated, and order remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of said section; 
(3)  Specify a reasonable time for compliance, except in the case of an emergency order as hereinafter provided; 
(4)  Advise the salvage yard operator of the procedure for appeal; and 
(5)  Be served upon the salvage yard operator in person. Such notice and order shall be deemed to be properly served upon such operator or dealer if a copy thereof is sent by certified or registered mail to said operator or dealer at the address on file with the Chairman of the Licensing Board or as stated in his application and, in the case of a salvage yard operator, a copy of said notice is posted in a conspicuous place in or on the salvage yard premises. 
(B)  Whenever the Chairman of the Licensing Board finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the health and safety of the public or of the employees of a salvage yard operator, he may issue an order reciting the existence of the emergency and suspend forthwith the license of a salvage yard operator. Notwithstanding any other provision hereof, any such order or orders shall be effective immediately and complied with in the time and manner prescribed in the emergency order. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
Sec. 112.214. - Hearings. 
(A)  Any salvage yard operator whose license is suspended or revoked as provided in § 112.213 may request and shall be granted a hearing before the Licensing Board. However, such person shall file in the office of the Chairman of the Licensing Board a written request for such hearing and set forth the name and address and telephone number of the operator and a brief statement of the grounds for such hearing or for the mitigation of any item appearing on any order of the Chairman of the Licensing Board. The written request shall be filed within ten days after the date of the notice and order of the Chairman of the Licensing Board. Upon receipt of such a request, the Chairman of the Licensing Board shall set a time and place for hearing before the Licensing Board and shall give the operator written notice thereof. The hearing shall be commenced within a reasonable time after a request has been filed. At such hearing, the operator shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why any item appearing on such notice and order should be modified or withdrawn. The failure of the operator or his representative to appear and state his case at such hearing shall have the same effect as if no request was filed. 
(B)  After a hearing, the Licensing Board may sustain, modify or withdraw any item appearing on the notice and order by majority vote, depending upon its findings as to whether the provisions of § 112.212 have been complied with, and the operator shall be notified in writing of such findings. 
(C)  The proceedings at such hearings, including the findings and decisions of the Licensing Board, and reasons therefor, shall be summarized and reduced to writing and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the Director of Finance. Such record shall also include a copy of every notice and order issued in connection with the matter. 
(Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30886-09, passed 7-1-09) 
DIVISION 13. - SECONDHAND DEALERS 

Sec. 112.215. - Secondhand merchandise must be specified. 
    No person shall, in any newspaper, magazine, circular, form letter, or any open publication, published, distributed, or circulated in the city, or on any billboards, car, label, or other advertising medium, or by means of any other method of advertising of offering for sale, advertise, offer for sale, call attention to or give publicity to the sale of any merchandise, which is secondhand, used, or rebuilt, or which is defective in any manner, or which consists of articles or units or parts known as "second" or blemished merchandise, or which has been rejected by the manufacturer thereof as not first class, unless there be issued or conspicuously displayed directly in connection with the name and description of such merchandise and each specified article, unit or part thereof, a direct and unequivocal statement, phrase, or word which will clearly indicate that such merchandise or each article, unit or part thereof so advertised or offered for sale is secondhand, used, rebuilt, defective, or consists of "seconds" or is blemished merchandise or has been rejected by the manufacturer thereof, as the fact shall be. 
(Ord. 15764, passed 5-19-43) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.99. 
Sec. 112.216. - General operating requirements. 
(A)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Police officer. Any police officer of the Dayton Police Department. 
    Secondhand dealer or dealer . For the purpose of this section the terms "secondhand dealer" and "dealer" shall be considered synonymous, and shall be deemed to designate any person, firm, or corporation that purchases, receives, or exchanges secondhand articles of any kind, including furniture, electrical or gas appliances, lawn equipment, bicycles, articles made of or containing gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metals or jewels, or currency of any kind, for the purpose of selling or exchanging the article or articles, and who maintains a fixed place of business for such transactions in the city. 
(B)  Signs. All dealers shall post in a conspicuous place in or upon their shop, store, or other place of business, a sign having the full name and occupation of the dealer legibly inscribed thereon. All dealers shall also post in a conspicuous place in or upon the front of the business, a sign having the name, address, and hours of operation of the business. 
(C)  Book or record. All dealers shall keep and preserve a separate book or record in which the dealer shall enter, in the English language, at the time of each purchase, receipt, or exchange of articles the name, address, social security number or date of birth, and a description of the person from whom the article was purchased or received, and the date and time of the transaction. The dealer shall also enter a complete and accurate description of the article purchased, received, or exchanged, including the name of the maker or manufacturer, initials, serial numbers, or other identifying features, and the price the dealer paid for each article. The dealer shall require the seller of any article to sign his name on the page on which that person's transaction is recorded. The book or record shall be open to inspection by any police officer during normal business hours. 
(1)  Each page of the book or record shall consist of one or more sequentially and consecutively numbered forms which shall contain appropriate blanks for furnishing all the aforementioned information required. The pages containing these forms shall be permanently bound into the book. The numbering of the forms shall begin with the number one and all numbers thereafter shall be accounted for. 
(2)  The dealer shall preserve the book or record for a period of not less than one year after making the final entry on any purchase or exchange of property recorded therein. 
(D)  Identification. Prior to purchasing, receiving, or exchanging any articles the dealer shall demand to examine the seller's driver's license, State of Ohio identification card, or other valid photo identification card typically used for identification purposes. The dealer shall enter in the book or record of the transaction the number and type of driver's license and identification card used by the seller. 
(E)  Minors. No dealer shall purchase any articles from a person under 18 years of age without the express written consent of the person's parent or guardian. Evidence of the written consent shall be retained with the numbered record pertaining to the seller's identification and the transaction. No person under 18 years of age shall sell or exchange any articles to or with a dealer without the express written consent of the minor's parent or guardian. 
(F)  Intoxication; drugs. No dealer shall purchase or receive any article from any person that he knows or has reason to believe is intoxicated or under the influence of drugs, or who is a known alcoholic, or drug user or drug dealer, or from any person who is known or believed by the dealer to be a thief or associate of a thief. 
    No dealer shall purchase or receive any articles between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(G)  Inspection by officer. All dealers shall permit inspection of any article in their possession upon request of a police officer. 
(H)  Retention of articles. All dealers shall retain all articles purchased, received, or exchanged by them for a minimum of five working days and shall not resell or release from their possession these articles until this time has expired. 
(1)  If a police officer has probable cause to believe that an article is stolen property the officer shall notify the dealer in writing of that probable cause. Upon receipt of the notice, the dealer shall retain the article until the expiration of 30 days after the day of the written notification, unless the police officer notifies the dealer in writing that he is not required to retain the article. 
(2)  As used in this section, "retain" means that a dealer does not change, alter, or deface any articles or voluntarily release possession of any goods purchased by him. 
(I)  Stolen articles. 
(1)  If a police officer determines the identity of the true owner of stolen articles held by a secondhand dealer and informs the dealer of the true owner's identity, the dealer may restore the stolen goods to the true owner directly. The true owner may reimburse the dealer for the exact amount the dealer paid for the stolen article. 
(2)  The secondhand dealer shall post a notice in a conspicuous place in the dealer's place of business visible to all patrons and reading: "The dealer at this establishment has no right to retain stolen property and the true owner may recover such property or its value from the dealer in a legal action." 
(J)  Articles forfeited. If a dealer in secondhand articles purchases or receives any article in violation of the provisions of this section and that article is found to be stolen property, the dealer will forfeit the article to the true owner directly without reimbursement from the true owner. 
(Ord. 27257, passed 9-25-85) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.217-112.219. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - TRAILERS, TRAILER PARKS AND PORTS 

Sec. 112.220. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of § 112.221, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively: 
    House trailer and travel trailer. Have the meanings set forth in R.C. § 4501.01.
