    House trailer park, travel trailer park, and travel trailer overnight port. Have the meanings set forth in R.C. § 3733.01, and must be licensed pursuant to the provisions of R.C. §§ 3733.01, et seq. 
Sec. 112.221. - Location of house trailer and travel trailer. 
    No person shall use for human habitation within the city any house trailer or travel trailer unless it be located in a licensed house trailer park, travel trailer park, or travel trailer overnight port, and unless it be used in strict compliance with the regulations promulgated pursuant to the authority granted in R.C. § 3733.02. 
(Ord. 15186, passed 2-15-39) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Secs. 112.222-112.239. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - GASOLINE AND LUBRICANTS 

Sec. 112.240. - Operation and maintenance of gasoline pumps; conforming to specifications. 
    No person shall operate or maintain any pump or device, the principal purpose of which is dispensing gasoline, unless said pump or device shall conform to the requirements and specifications contained in §§ 112.240 through 112.247. 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.241. - Inspection. 
    The Consumer Advocate shall initiate a thorough inspection of each gasoline pump in each filling station and all other apparatus used in dispensing gasoline, oils and greases. Such inspection shall be made as often as once each six months and at such other times and as often as may be necessary to assure strict compliance with all the terms of §§ 112.240 through 112.247. 
Sec. 112.242. - Sealing and condemning gasoline pumps. 
(A)  Conforming gasoline pumps to be sealed. If a gasoline pump is found to comply with the state standards, it shall be sealed by attaching a lead seal to each stop in such a way that its position cannot be changed without destroying the seal, or if the pump is such a one that the stops are not separately sealable then it may be sealed with one lead seal. 
(B)  Nonconforming gas pumps to be condemned and closed for repair. If state standards are not complied with, or if any deliveries are incorrect, the pump shall be condemned and closed for repairs. The inspector shall sign and attach a sign to the pump or equipment which reads as follows: "This pump (or equipment) is closed for repair by order of the consumer advocate." 
(C)  Sign removed after repair of gasoline pumps. When the pumps are properly repaired, the inspector shall immediately inspect and release them by removing the above sign. 
Sec. 112.243. - Gasoline; sold as represented. 
    No person shall sell or offer for sale any gasoline of a gravity, end point, composition or quality different than it is represented to be either by advertisement or any other representation. 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.244. - Interference with inspection. 
    No person shall: 
(A)  Hinder or resist the consumer advocate or his authorized representative who is making an inspection as required by §§ 112.240 through 112.247. 
(B)  Remove or deface any repair sign or "closed" sign placed on any pump or equipment by the consumer advocate or his authorized representative. 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.245. - Misrepresentation of quality of lubricants unlawful. 
    No person shall sell or offer for sale any lubricant of a different quality than the same is represented to be. If oil is sold on specifications, it shall conform to such specifications. Used oil which has been subjected to refining processes shall be labeled and sold as such. 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.246. - Lubricant inspection fee levied. 
    For purposes of enforcement of the regulations and performance of the inspection and other services required by the provisions pertaining to the retail sale of oils and greases there is levied an inspection fee. The amount of the fee shall be as set forth in § 38.69. 
Secs. 112.247-112.249. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 16. - SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES AND PERMITS 

Sec. 112.250. - Suspension or revocation; refusal to issue licenses or permits. 
(A)  The city may refuse to issue a license or permit or the licenses or permits issued pursuant to this Code, unless otherwise provided, may be suspended or revoked by the city or such other authorized official, department, board or agency where applicable, after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentations or false statements contained in the application for permit or license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares, merchandise, and services; 
(3)  Any violations of this Code and/or any ordinance of the city having a reasonable relationship to the purpose and scope of the license or permit; 
(4)  Conviction of the applicant, licensee, or permittee of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or a violation of any law of the state, or any law of the United States having a reasonable relationship to the purpose and scope of the permit or license; 
(5)  Conducting the activity under this Code and/or any ordinance of the city in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, morals or general welfare of the public. 
(B)  Notice of hearing for the suspension or revocation of a license or permit shall be in writing given by the proper city official, department, board or agency, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Service of such notice shall be made by either personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant, licensee or permittee at the last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(C)  In case of refusal to issue a permit or license or the suspension or revocation of a license or permit as herein provided, no portion of the application, license or permit fee shall be returned to the applicant, licensee or permittee unless otherwise provided in this Code and/or any ordinance of the city. 
(D)  Any suspension or revocation hereunder may be either in addition to or instead of any penalty or fine as prescribed in this Code and/or any ordinance of the city. 
(E)  The order of the city or such other authorized official, department, board, or agency where applicable, shall be the final municipal action for the purpose of judicial review. 
Secs. 112.251-112.259. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 17. - ALARMS 

Sec. 112.260. - Purpose and scope. 
(A)  The purpose of this division is to protect the emergency services of the Police Department from misuse by responding to defective alarm systems and excessive false alarms. 
(B)  This division governs and regulates alarm systems, alarm users, and alarm businesses. It provides for the licensing of alarm businesses, establishes fees, provides for the suspension and revocation of licenses, and provides penalties for violations and penalties for excessive false alarms. 
(C)  This division shall not have any application to fire alarm systems. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.261. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Alarm business. The business by any individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, monitoring, administering, servicing, repairing, and/or installing any alarm system in or on any building, structure, or facility. 
    Alarm site. A single premises or location served by an alarm system or systems. Each tenancy, if served by a separate alarm system in a multi-tenant building or complex, shall be considered a separate alarm site. 
    Alarm system. Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, designed to signal the occurrence of a robbery, attempted robbery, burglary, or an attempted burglary or other life hazard at the protected premises, requiring urgent attention, and to which the police are expected to respond. For the purposes of this division, the term "Alarm System" includes all systems which are designed to attract the attention and response of the police, including bells, horns, sirens, and lights, which are either audible or visible beyond the lot limits of the protected premises. "Alarm system" does not include a vehicle alarm, equipment to which the Fire Department is expected to respond, or any equipment signaling a medical emergency. 
    Alarm user. The individual or entity of any kind who or which is: 
(1)  An owner (or lessee) and also the user of an alarm system, as the occupant of the premises where the system is installed (the "premises"); 
(2)  The owner (or lessee) of such premises which is occupied by another person or entity, if there is no written contract stating that the occupant (rather than the owner or lessee of the premises) is to be responsible for the alarm system; 
(3)  The occupant of such premises if there is a written agreement stating that the occupant is responsible for the alarm system; 
(4)  Individual or entity of any kind which is in control of any building, structure, or facility wherein an alarm system is maintained. 
    Automatic dialing device. A device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and transmit by a voice message or code signal an emergency message indicating the need for an emergency response. 
    Emergency alarm button or panic/holdup switches. An alarm system device that requires purposeful activation (tripping) for signaling and alerting the police of a robbery, burglary/attempted robbery, attempted burglary, or serious life hazardous criminal activity. 
    False alarm. 
(1)  The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improperly installed or improperly maintained alarm system equipment, or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or his employees or agent. False alarms shall not include those resulting from causes identified and determined to be beyond the control of the owner or lessee (force majeure). An alarm cancelled by the operator or user within five minutes of activation shall not be considered a false alarm. 
(2)  An alarm system that is activated multiple times within a 12-hour period when the premises are unoccupied shall be deemed one false alarm if: 
(a)  Access to the building is provided to the alarm system contractor; and 
(b)  An alarm system contractor or an employee of the contractor responds. 
(3)  Failure to comply with items (2)(a) and (b) of this definition shall result in each subsequent alarm being counted as a false alarm. 
    Interconnect. To connect an alarm system, including an automatic dialing device, to a telephone line, either directly or through a mechanical device that utilizes the telephone, for the purpose of using the telephone line to transmit a message upon the activation of the alarm system. 
    Local alarms. Those alarm systems which activate an audible signal within the proximity of the protected premises only, which are designed to directly or indirectly attract the attention of the police. 
    Panic alarm. An automatic alarm system signaling a robbery, attempted robbery, burglary, attempted burglary, or medical or fire emergency. 
    Police alarm administrator. An employee of the city, designated by the Chief of Police, who is assigned the responsibility to coordinate the administration and documentation of the alarm business and alarms systems performance as it relates to the effective enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
    Police Chief. Chief of Police of the city or her or his designee. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97; Am. Ord. 30984-10, passed 5-5-10) 
Sec. 112.262. - Alarm business license and certification. 
(A)  No person shall engage in the alarm business within the city, whether personal, by agents, or employees, singularly or along with some other business or enterprise, without having first obtained a license to do so in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(B)  In addition to the license requirements, all alarm installers and salespersons shall have obtained and must maintain a basic alarm installer certification through either the National Burglar and Fire Alarm Association, the National Alarm Association of America, or a substantially similar certification as may be determined by the Chief of Police or his/her designee. Persons who have been newly hired by an alarm business must obtain their certification within one year of the date of hire and may not perform any alarm-related installation or sales prior to certification unless supervised by a duly certified alarm installer or salesperson. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.263. - Application for license. 
    An application for an alarm business license shall be made on an application form obtainable from the Police Department. The license shall expire on the 30th day of November in the year following the year of issuance. All renewal licenses shall be for a period of two years and shall expire on the 30th day of November of the second year following issuance. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.264. - Contents of license application. 
(A)  An alarm business application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, residence address, telephone number, date of birth, and social security number of each individual, owner, partner, or if a corporation, each officer thereof, and the name, residence address, and telephone number of the manager or person to be responsible for the operation of the business if different from such individual owner, partner, or officers. Each applicant shall also attach to the application a list of names, addressees, telephone numbers, and social security numbers of every employee of the business who will engage in the installing, repairing, servicing, selling, leasing, or maintaining of any alarm system. It shall be the responsibility of the alarm business to keep such list current, providing updated lists to the alarm administrator. 
(2)  A description of the alarm systems and/or devices offered for sale or lease to the public and description of any services relating to alarm devices offered to the public. Each alarm system shall comply with any and all applicable building codes, including any then current city ordinances for electrical wiring and alarm installation. Equipment and supplies used in the installation and service systems must: 
(a)  All equipment must be approved by Underwriter Laboratories; or 
(b)  Be equal to or better than the standards set by Underwriters Laboratories. The burden of proof for such lies with the alarm business. 
(3)  Trade names used during the previous five years by the applicant or such person signing the application along with the location of other business establishments operated during the previous five years in the State of Ohio. 
(4)  A list of all felony and misdemeanor convictions of individual proprietors, partners, or directors, principal officers, and employees of the applicant business. The date and location of each conviction shall also be included. 
(5)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been denied a license or permit in any jurisdiction to engage in the alarm business or has had such license or permit revoked and the reason for revocation. 
(6)  A statement as to the length of time the applicant has been engaged in the alarm business and where engaged. 
(7)  The trade name, business address, and telephone number on behalf of which the application is made. 
(8)  A bond in the amount of $5,000.00 made payable to the city for faithful performance of the terms and conditions of this division. 
(9)  Proof of professional liability insurance, including "errors and omissions," or substantially similar coverage in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00. 
(10)  A statement that the applicant agrees to update the above information by written notice within ten days after substantial change to any of the information required by this section of this division. 
(B)  License applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee equal to the amount then currently established and set by the City Manager. 
(C)  Any alarm business engaged in providing services and/or alarm system equipment in the city prior to the effective date of this division shall submit an application for a license no later than 60 calendar days after such effective date. Said applicant may continue to do business while the license application is being processed. 
(D)  The Chief of Police shall review each application for a license and may conduct an investigation to determine whether the facts set forth in the application are true. He or she shall, within 15 calendar days after receipt of an application for such license, either approve or deny issuance of same. The applicant shall be notified in writing of such approval or denial. Any written notification of denial shall include the basis for said finding and if the grounds for denial are subject to correction, the applicant shall be given ten calendar days after receipt of such notice within which to make the required correction. The notice of denial shall in clear and concise language inform the applicant that she/he may appeal the denial. 
(E)  The Chief of Police shall deny the application for an alarm business license if she/he finds that the applicant or the individual having the authority and the responsibility for the management and operation of the applicant's alarm business within the city or any of the applicants, owners, partners, or principal corporate officers have: 
(1)  Committed any act which, if committed by a licensee, would be grounds for revocation of a license under this division; or 
(2)  While unlicensed, knowingly and willfully committed or aided and abetted in the commission of any act for which a license is required by this division; or 
(3)  Been convicted in any jurisdiction of a felony or misdemeanor if the Chief of Police finds that such conviction reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the applicant to engage in the alarm business. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.265. - Renewal of alarm business license. 
(A)  Any license for alarm businesses shall not be renewed by the Chief of Police in the manner hereinafter set forth if the licensee or any of the owners, partners, principal corporate officers, or any individual having the authority and the responsibility for the management and operation of the alarm business within this city are: 
(1)  Found to have violated any of the provisions of this division or any rule or regulation as set forth by the Chief of Police which violation the Chief of Police determines to reflect unfavorably upon the fitness of the licensee to engage in the alarm business; or 
(2)  Found to have knowingly and willfully given any false information or information of a material nature in connection with any application for a license or a renewal or reinstatement of a license; or 
(3)  Found to have been convicted in any jurisdiction of a felony or a misdemeanor, and the Chief of Police determines that such conviction reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the applicant to engage in the alarm business; or 
(4)  Found to have committed any act while the license was not in effect which would be cause for revocation of such license. 
(B)  Any application for renewal of an alarm business license shall be due on September 1 of the year in which the current license will expire and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable administrative fee as set and established by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.266. - License not transferable. 
(A)  No license issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferred. 
(B)  No license issued under the provisions of this division shall be used by any person or entity other than the person or entity to which it was issued. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.267. - Confidentiality of alarm business customers and/or subscribers. 
    An alarm business shall maintain, to the extent permitted by law or court order, the confidentiality of its customers and/or subscribers. The database of customers and/or subscribers shall not be sold or otherwise transferred for any commercial purpose. This provision of confidentiality, however, shall not prohibit the city or any other duly authorized governmental agency from requesting and receiving such information when necessary to that governmental agency's functions or duties. Information contained in permit applications shall be held in confidence by all employees or representatives of the city with access to such information, unless otherwise required by law or court order. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.268. - Suspension and revocation of license. 
(A)  An alarm business license may be suspended or revoked by the Chief of Police for any of the following causes: 
(1)  The license was knowingly obtained through any fraud or misstatement; 
(2)  The business transactions of the alarm business have been marked by practice of failure to perform contracts; 
(3)  Licensee fails to comply with any provision of this division which the Chief of Police deems consistent with the intent and purpose of this division. 
(4)  Conviction of any owner, partner, corporate officer or director, or a manager of the licensee of any felony or any misdemeanor when the Chief of Police determines such conviction materially reflects negatively on suitability for a license. 
(B)  The suspension or revocation shall not take place until the Chief of Police has notified the licensee in writing of the cause or causes for such revocation or suspension, which notice shall: 
(1)  Contain a brief statement of the facts relating to the revocation or suspension; 
(2)  Advise the licensee of the procedure for appeal; 
(3)  Be served upon the licensee in person or by leaving it at her/his address as stated in the application for a license or at the business address on file with the Chief of Police or by regular U.S. Mail addressed to the licensee at such address. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.269. - Creation of Alarm Permit Review Board. 
    An Alarm Permit Review Board is hereby created consisting of the Chief of Police, or his/her designee, the Director of Finance, or his/her designee, and the Director of Law or his/her designee. In addition, the Alarm Permit Review Board may select a nonvoting representative of the alarm business industry to serve as an advisor/consultant in matters before the Alarm Permit Review Board. An alternate member of the alarm business industry may be selected to serve as a nonvoting advisor/consultant for those matters in which the regular alarm business representative may have a conflict of interest. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.270. - Appeal procedure. 
(A)  Any person aggrieved by the denial of application or renewal or by notice or suspension or revocation as provided in this division, may appeal and shall be granted a hearing on the matter by submitting a written request to the Chief of Police within 15 calendar days after the date of service of the denial, suspension, or revocation notice. 
(1)  If a hearing is requested, written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on the user by regular U.S. Mail at least ten calendar days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(2)  The hearing shall be before the Alarm Permit Review Board. 
(a)  The Police Alarm Administrator or her/his designee and the applicant shall have the right to present written and oral evidence. In addition, witnesses may be presented by either party. 
(b)  The failure of the applicant or her/his representatives to appear and state her/his case at such hearing shall have the same effect as if no appeal was filed. 
(B)  Within 15 calendar days after the conclusion of the hearing, the Alarm Permit Review Board shall in writing either sustain, modify, or reverse the decision from which the appeal was taken. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.271. - Alarm user's or subscriber's permit. 
(A)  Within 90 calendar days after the effective date of this division, every alarm user shall obtain from the Police Department an alarm user permit for each alarm system within this city. 
(B)  (1)  (a) 
An alarm user's permit application shall contain: 
1.  Names and addresses of the alarm user(s) and of the residence or business or businesses in or upon which the alarm system has been or will be installed and telephone number. 
2.  The type of alarm system (local, central station monitoring), the company name, address, and telephone of the alarm business installing, monitoring, inspecting, responding to, or maintaining the alarm system. 
3.  The names, addresses, telephone numbers of three persons who can be contacted 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to turn off or deactivate the alarm system when the alarm user cannot be contacted. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility and obligation of the alarm user to keep the above information current and accurate by notifying the Police Department in writing within ten days after a change occurs in such information. 
(2)  Each alarm user shall pay to the city, upon application for permit, a one-time alarm user fee in the amount then currently established and set by the City Manager. 
(3)  No permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferred. 
(4)  No alarm system shall be made operational until an alarm user's permit has been properly obtained. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.272. - Excessive false alarms. 
(A)  If any alarm system produces two false alarms in any 12 consecutive month period, written notice of that fact shall be given by regular mail or delivery to the subscriber. 
(B)  (1)  Notice of false alarm; administrative fees. 
(a)  Police officer(s) who answer a false alarm shall attach a false alarm warning notice (sticker) to the front of the premises or give the notice to the alarm system user. 
(b)  Upon the third false alarm produced by any alarm system within any 12 consecutive month period, an administrative fee of $50.00 shall be assessed. 
(c)  Upon the fourth false alarm produced by any alarm system within any 12 consecutive month period, an administrative fee of $100.00 shall be assessed. 
(d)  Upon the fifth false alarm produced by any alarm system within any 12 consecutive month period, an administrative fee of $150.00 shall be assessed. 
(e)  Upon the sixth false alarm produced by any alarm system within any 12 consecutive month period, an administrative fee of $200.00 shall be assessed. 
(f)  Upon the seventh false alarm and each successive false alarm thereafter produced by any alarm system within any 12 consecutive month period, an administrative fee of $250.00 shall be assessed and a disconnect order may be issued. 
(2)  A person who fails to pay the appropriate fine within 30 days of the violation shall be in default, and the fine deemed delinquent. An additional $25.00 penalty shall be added for delinquent fines. 
(3)  These fees shall be in addition to any criminal penalties imposed under this division. The question of whether a false alarm has occurred may be appealed by the alarm user under the applicable procedures set forth in this division. The police alarm administrator may indicate in the false alarm records the existence of mitigating or moderating circumstances relative to any false alarm. 
(C)  The permit issued to an alarm user may be revoked with the result that the alarm user may be required to disconnect the alarm system in such fashion that signals are not emitted so as to notify the Police Department either directly or indirectly. The procedure for such orders to disconnect is set forth in this division. 
(D)  An alarm system may be reconnected only if satisfactory evidence is provided to the Alarm Permit Review Board that the alarm system has been repaired so that it does not emit further false alarms, upon payment of all fines and delinquent charges assessed for false alarms, and the alarm user has taken appropriate measures to insure against negligent or accidental activation of the alarm system. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97; Am. Ord. 30801-08, passed 10-8-08; Am. Ord. 30984-10, passed 5-5-10) 
Sec. 112.273. - Specific alarm provisions. 
(A)  Entrance/exit devices. All alarm installations incorporating an entrance/exit device must permit a minimum delay of 30 seconds before actual activation of the system. 
(B)  Local alarm. A local alarm shall not resemble the sound of any emergency vehicle signal or civil defense alarm or siren. All local alarms shall reset themselves within 15 minutes from the time it was activated. 
(C)  Instructions. Every alarm business selling, leasing, or furnishing to any user an alarm system which is installed on any premises located within the city shall furnish the user with instructions that provide information to enable the user to operate the alarm system properly, including false alarm cancellation procedures, and to obtain service for the alarm system at any time. 
(D)  Emergency alarm buttons. Emergency alarm buttons are to be used only to send an automatic alarm to signal a robbery or other life-threatening activity. 
(1)  The activation of a panic alarm is intended to signal the Police Department of an emergency situation. Therefore, through the use of such device, the user grants to the Police Department the right to conduct any form of investigation deemed necessary to verify the authenticity of the alarm. Panic alarm users shall execute waivers to be submitted to the Chief of Police which will allow the Police Department the right to enter onto the premises of the alarm user to verify the alarm. The contents of such waiver shall be specified by the City Attorney. No panic alarm shall be installed in a premises where alcoholic beverages are sold and consumed on-site. 
(2)  It shall be deemed a violation of this division if a panic device is activated for anything other than that specified in this section. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.274. - Application of standards to existing and future alarm systems. 
    Every new system installed after the effective date of this division shall comply with the applicable standards of this division. Every alarm system existing before the effective date of this division shall be placed in compliance with the applicable standards of this division no later than 60 calendar days after such effective date. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 112.999. 
Sec. 112.275. - Limitation of liability. 
    The city and its officials, agents, representatives, and employees shall not be liable for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such a device, nor for the failure or neglect of any person with a license issued pursuant to this division, or with a franchise, in connection with the installation and operation of equipment, nor for the failure of the transmission of alarm signals and prerecorded alarm messages, or the relaying of such signals and messages. In the event that the city finds it necessary to disconnect a defective automatic dialing system or signaling device, the city shall incur no liability by such action. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.276. - Surrender of license. 
    If any license is revoked pursuant to this division, such licensee shall surrender said license to the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.277. - Exception. 
    Any property, facility, or installation of the federal, state, or county government which satisfactorily demonstrates to the Chief of Police that the city is required to allow an alarm system at such installation, facility, or property to be interconnected to the Police Department shall be exempt from the revocation and disconnect order provisions of this division, but shall be subject to the administrative fee assessments as described in this division, to the extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.278. - Separability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this division is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this division. The City Commission hereby declares that it would have passed this division and each section, subsection, sentence, clause, and phrase hereof, notwithstanding any one or more of the sections, subsections, sentences, clauses, or phrases that might be declared invalid. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Sec. 112.279. - Order to disconnect. 
(A)  In addition to the administrative fees described herein and in addition to any criminal penalties imposed herein, an alarm user who has seven or more false alarms in any 12 consecutive month period shall be issued an order to disconnect the alarm system so that signals are not emitted to notify the Police Department either directly or indirectly. An order to disconnect shall be issued to any alarm user who has failed to deliver to the city full payment for any administrative fee levied for excessive false alarms within 30 calendar days after written notice of that fee has been mailed or otherwise delivered to the last known address of the alarm user or to the address at which the alarm system is located. A disconnect order shall be issued to any alarm user who has failed to obtain a user's permit as required by this division. 
(B)  The disconnection is to be completed by the alarm user within ten calendar days after the written disconnect order is mailed or otherwise delivered to the last known address of the alarm user or to the address at which the alarm system is located. 
(C)  An alarm user subject to an order to disconnect has the right to appeal under the procedures set forth below in this division. Any disconnect order must refer to this right to appeal. If such an appeal is filed, the disconnection is to be completed within ten calendar days after similar delivery of notice of the appellate decision, if that decision sustained the disconnect order. 
(D)  Once disconnected, an alarm system may be reconnected only if so ordered by the Chief of Police in a decision on an appeal or if a preponderance of the credible evidence available to the police alarm administrator shows that: 
(1)  The alarm system has been repaired so that it will not emit further false alarms; or 
(2)  If the disconnect order was based on failure to pay assessments when due and all delinquent false alarm fees have been paid in full; or 
(3)  The alarm user has taken appropriate measures to ensure against negligent or accidental activation of the alarm system. 
(E)  An order to disconnect shall be effective for one year from the date of disconnection. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97; Am. Ord. 30984-10, passed 5-5-10) 
Sec. 112.280. - Appeals and disconnect orders. 
(A)  The following persons may appeal under this section: 
(1)  An alarm user subject to an order to disconnect for failure to make reasonable efforts toward correction of a false alarm situation may appeal the determination that such reasonable efforts were not made. 
(2)  An alarm user subject to an order to disconnect for failure to obtain a user's permit as required may appeal the issue of whether or not that user had a permit in effect for the location in question or was required by this division to have such a permit. 
(3)  An alarm user subject to an order to disconnect for failure to pay when due an administrative fee assessed for excessive false alarms may appeal the issue of whether or not such payment was timely made. 
(B)  (1)  A written request for an appeal must be submitted to the Chief of Police within 30 calendar days after notice of the disconnect order was mailed or otherwise delivered to the last known address of the alarm user or to the address at which the alarm system is located. The alarm user-appellant shall have the right to present written and oral evidence to the Alarm Permit Review Board at a hearing on the appeal and shall have the burden of proving his or her case by a preponderance of the credible evidence. Notice of the hearing date, hour, and place shall be mailed or otherwise delivered to the last known address of the appellant or to the address at which the alarm system is located at least ten calendar days prior to the hearing. 
(2)  The Alarm Permit Review Board may sustain, modify, or reverse the decision appealed from, and the decision of the Alarm Permit Review Board shall be made in writing and shall constitute a final administrative order. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97; Am. Ord. 30801-08, passed 10-8-08) 
Sec. 112.281. - Enforcement and penalty. 
(A)  Enforcement of any of the provisions of this division may be by civil action and/or criminal prosecution. 
(B)  Failure or omission to comply with any section or provision of this division shall be deemed a violation. Each day that such a failure or omission continues to exist after written notice of that failure or omission is mailed or otherwise delivered to the last known address of the alarm user or to the address at which the alarm system is located shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97) 
Secs. 112.282-112.998. - Reserved. 
Sec. 112.999. - Penalty. 
(A)  A person who violates any provisions of §§ 112.01 through 112.14, 112.55, 112.56, 112.90 through 112.104, 112.150 through 112.153, 112.160 through 112.168, 112.215, or 112.221 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(B)  A person who violates § 112.212 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. If the offender previously has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of § 112.212, each subsequent violation is a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(C)  A person who violates any of the provisions of §§ 112.20 through 112.30 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree for the first offense, a misdemeanor of the second degree for any subsequent offense and, in the case of a licensee under these sections, the license shall be cancelled and revoked for a second or subsequent offense. 
(D)  A person who violates any of the provisions of §§ 112.60 through 112.79 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and a misdemeanor of the third degree for a second or subsequent offense, and, in addition, the registration under which such person operates may be revoked either on a first or subsequent offense and such person declared ineligible for a period of not more than one year following such conviction. 
(E)  A person violating any provisions of §§ 112.115 through 112.130 or 112.135 through 112.148 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(F)  A person violating any provisions of §§ 112.200 through 112.211, 112.213, 112.214, 112.240 through 112.246, or 112.261 through 112.281 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. 
(G)  A violation of the provisions of §§ 112.181(A), (B), (C), and (D) and §§ 112.191 and 112.192(A) constitutes a misdemeanor of the fourth degree, punishable as provided in § 130.99, and each day such violation is continued constitutes a separate offense. 
(H)  A person who violates any of the provisions of § 112.216 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for the first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for second and subsequent offenses. 
(Ord. 27256-97, passed 9-18-95; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95; Am. Ord. 29383-97, passed 5-14-97; Am. Ord. 30580-06, 7-5-06; Am. Ord. 30801-08, passed 10-8-08; Am. Ord. 30886-09 passed 7-1-09; Am. Ord. 31245-13, passed 5-8-13) 
CHAPTER 113. - ELECTRICITY 
DIVISION 1. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 113.01. - Electrical contractor defined. 
    As used in this chapter, an "electrical contractor" means any individual, partnership, corporation, association, or other organization who or which contracts for, proceeds with, or employs others for the construction, installation, alteration, repair, or addition to any electrical wiring, apparatus, or fixed electrical equipment for the purpose of furnishing heat, light, or power within the city. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 27582, passed 7-29-87; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 113.02. - Electrical contractor's registration required; exceptions. 
(A)  No electrical contractor shall proceed with or employ others for the construction, alteration, repair, or addition to any electrical wiring, apparatus, or fixed electrical equipment for the purpose of furnishing heat, light, or power within the city unless the electrical contractor shall first file an application and obtain a registration as herein provided. Such individual, partnership, or corporation acting as an electrical contractor shall be responsible for the installation as herein required, and shall be subject to the penalties as herein provided. 
(B)  If the member of a firm to whom the registration is granted should at any time terminate his or her business connection with the partnership or corporation he or she represents, no new electrical work which requires a permit shall be performed and no permits shall be issued to the partnership or corporation unless and until another member of the partnership or designated employee of such corporation shall file an application for and obtain an electrical contractor's registration. A new registration will be granted to the partnership or corporation for the unexpired portion of the term for which such registration was issued, after a fee has been paid as prescribed in § 113.08. No electrical contractor shall lend his or her registration to others, or procure permits in his or her name for others, when he or she is not the electrical contractor for such work. 
(C)  No electrical contractor's registration shall be required for the following: 
(1)  Minor repairs, such as, replacement of lamps, repair or replacement of portable electric equipment, replacement of fuses, repair or replacing of flush or surface switches and wall receptacles; 
(2)  Installation of, or repairs to automotive equipment or railway cars; 
(3)  Installation or repairs by communication companies or their agencies in connection with the generation, transmission, or distribution of electricity for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence; 
(4)  Installations or repairs by a railway or public transit utility to its equipment employed in the exercise of its functions as a utility; and 
(5)  Work done or caused to be done by the United States, or any agent or authority thereof. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 21951, passed 2-23-66; Am. Ord. 27582, passed 7-29-87; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 29136-95, passed 12-13-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 113.99. 
Sec. 113.03. - Contents of application for registration. 
    All applications for an electrical contractor's registration shall be made upon blank forms furnished for such purpose by the Department of Building Services. The application shall contain, in addition to other requested information, the following: 
(A)  Name, age, and address of applicant; 
(B)  Proof of valid and unexpired electrical contractor's specialty license issued pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Revised Code; 
(C)  If the applicant is a corporation: 
(1)  The full and accurate corporate name; 
(2)  When and where incorporated; 
(3)  The full names and addresses of the officers of the corporation; and 
(4)  The name of the person applying for the registration. 
(D)  If applicant conducts business under a trade or fictitious name, or is a partnership, the following additional information: 
(1)  The full and accurate trade name; 
(2)  The correct business address; 
(3)  The name of the person or persons doing business under such trade or fictitious name; and 
(4)  The name of the person applying for the registration. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 24233, passed 3-l-72; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.04. - Reserved. 
Sec. 113.05. - Bond required. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall engage in business as an electrical contractor without first having filed with the Chief Building Official a good and sufficient surety bond to the city as oblige, in the principal sum of $10,000.00 by a surety company licensed by the state. The bond shall be approved by the City Accountant and conditioned upon the faithful observance of all ordinances of the city relating to such business. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 113.99. 
Sec. 113.06. - Insurance required. 
(A)  Every person, firm, corporation, or business organization engaged in the business of electrical contracting shall, on each application for, or renewal of his or her registration, show evidence that he or she is the owner of a public liability insurance policy having a minimum of the following coverage: 
Bodily injury: 
$100,000.00-each person 
$300,000.00-each accident 
$300,000.00-aggregate for completed operations liability 
Property damage: 
$50,000.00-each accident 
$100,000.00-aggregate for operation liability 
$100,000.00-aggregate for completed operations liability 
(B)  This insurance shall protect people or property against damage arising out of any negligent act of the insured or any agent or employee of the insured. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25724, passed 3-28-79; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.07. - Registration fees. 
    Electrical contractor. The fee for an electrical contractor's registration shall be $400.00 biennially, effective from January 1 through December 31 of the succeeding year. If the registration is for a period of one year or less, the fee shall be $250.00. No part of any fee shall be refunded for any cause. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 21951, passed 2-23-66; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.08. - Registration renewal. 
    An electrical contractor's registration shall be renewable biennially, on January 1 of the year the registration expires, at the fee set forth in § 113.07(A). An electrical contractor's registration shall be renewable annually, on January 1 of the year the registration expires, for $250.00, effective from January 1 through December 31. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 21951, passed 2-23-66; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.09. - Certification required to renew expired registration. 
(A)  Any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business as an electrical contractor who shall fail to procure a renewal of registration within 30 days from the date of its expiration, shall, before such registrant is issued such registration, be required to show proof of an electrical contractor's specialty license issued pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Revised Code, payment of the registration fee and completed application therefor, as in the original instance. 
(B)  Upon payment of the registration fee as prescribed in § 113.07 and determination that the applicant still meets the requirements of §§ 113.01 through 113.11, such registration may be renewed for successive years, unless otherwise revoked or terminated as herein provided. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 24233, passed 3-l-72; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.10. - Reserved. 
Sec. 113.11. - Exemptions from §§ 113.01 to 113.11. 
    The provisions of §§ 113.01 to 113.11 shall not apply to: 
(A)  Public utilities engaged in the production, transmission, and/or distribution of electric energy, gas, and/or steam. The contractors and/or agents of such public utilities, when engaged in the construction, maintenance, and/or repair of the production, transmission, distribution, and/or communication facilities of such public utilities shall also be exempt; 
(B)  An actual and regular hourly employee of an industrial, commercial, or business enterprise, as long as this industrial, commercial, or business enterprise is not engaged in the construction business or is not an electrical contractor or regular hourly employee of the state, the county, the city, or any agency or authority of any of them, while engaged in the course of his or her employment with such industrial, commercial, or business enterprise, or the state, county, or city; 
(C)  Any individual performing electrical work in accordance with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city for his own use on premises owned and occupied by him or being built by him or her for his or her own personal occupancy. Such person shall be granted a permit for such work upon making an affidavit that such work is not for hire and is in or on premises so used and occupied or to be so used or occupied as aforesaid; 
(D)  Any work involved in the installation, testing, servicing, altering, or repairing of electrical equipment and apparatus, except that this exemption shall not include any interference with, alteration or addition to the permanent wiring system of any structure, not otherwise authorized by the ordinances of the city; 
(E)  Installations of, or alterations or repairs to any warm air furnace, automatic, mechanically or manually operated coal stoker, any type of conversion burner, thermostat, internal or external blower equipment in or to any warm air heating system, space heater, gas heating plant, or air conditioning cooling unit, not to exceed five tons single phase when such installation, alteration or repair work relates only to work from the main distribution panel of the building to the unit. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 21951, passed 2-23-66; Am. Ord. 27582, passed 7-29-87; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Secs. 113.12-113.19. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF EXAMINERS OF ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 113.20. - Board of Examiners of Electrical Contractors created. 
    A Board of Examiners of Electrical Contractors is created. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25170, passed 9-29-76; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 113.21. - Membership of board; quorum. 
(A)  The Board of Examiners of Electrical Contractors shall consist of the Director of Building Services, the Manager of the Division of Building Inspection, the Chief Building Inspector, the Director of the Department of Fire, or their duly authorized representatives, and three registered electrical contractors. The three registered electrical contractors shall be appointed annually by the City Manager for a term of one year, taking office on said board on January 1 of each year. In appointing the three registered electrical contractors as members of the board, the City Manager shall receive three lists of persons recommended for appointment to the board, one list being from the National Electrical Contractors Association, one list being from the Master Electrical Contractors Association, and one list from the Chief Building Inspector; one person from each of the three lists submitted shall be appointed to membership on the board. 
(B)  The presence of four members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25170, passed 9-29-76; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.22. - Officers of board. 
    The Director of Economic Development, or his or her duly authorized representative, shall be Chairman of the board. The Chief Building Inspector shall be the secretary of the board who, nevertheless, shall exercise full power of membership, and such secretary shall act as a general secretary and also as a recording secretary, and be charged with the keeping of all records of the board as provided hereinafter. Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the board shall be filled by appointment to be made by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25170, passed 9-29-76; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 113.23. - Oath of office. 
    Each person, before serving as a member of the board, shall take an oath before the Clerk of the Commission to properly perform the duties required of a member of the board. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25170, passed 9-29-76; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 113.24. - Powers of board. 
(A)  The Board of Examiners of Electrical Contractors, shall have authority to do the following things, and to perform the following functions: 
(1)  To make, adopt, amend, supplement, or rescind rules of procedure for the conduct of its meetings and proceedings. 
(2)  To suspend or revoke the registration of electrical contractors who shall be found to have violated any provision of this chapter and/or who have failed to take out proper permits as provided by law for the work of electrical construction, installation or repair or who have been shown, after proper hearing, to be a persistent and habitual violator of the laws of the state, ordinances of the city, or the National Electrical Code, relating to the construction installation or repair of buildings, structures and premises within the city; or of the laws of the state or ordinances of the city relating to the inspection and approval of such work. Such hearing is to be conducted as provided in subsection (C). For purposes of this section a "PERSISTENT AND HABITUAL VIOLATOR" shall mean an electrical contractor who has been found guilty of a violation of this chapter by the board on three or more separate and distinct complaints. 
(B)  Any electrical contractor whose registration is revoked, shall not be entitled to apply for the issuance of a new registration for a period of six months after the date of such revocation; and not until such former registered electrical contractor has corrected or compensated for the violation for which said registration was revoked. 
(C)  Upon receiving a complaint in writing, subscribed and sworn to affirmatively by the complainant before an officer or magistrate authorized to administer oaths, stating facts indicating that a registered electrical contractor has been guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, the Board of Examiners shall cause a notice of revocation or suspension to be served upon the registration holder at least 15 days in advance of the proposed hearing date, and this notice shall be sent by certified mail to the address stated in the application for registration or renewal of registration. The notice shall indicate the time and place of the hearing, the general grounds of said suspension or revocation, and shall advise the registration holder of his right to appear at the hearing in person and by counsel for the purpose of presenting his defense therein. The registration holder shall have the right to interrogate witnesses at said hearing and be heard orally upon the merits of his defense. The board shall have the power to subpoena and compel the attendance of witnesses, to administer oaths, to punish for contempt, compel the production of records and other documentary evidence, and do all lawful things essential to a full hearing of the case before it. It shall make a complete record of such cases, and may, at its discretion, keep a stenographic record of the testimony produced in such hearing. It may request legal advice from the Department of Law. After the hearing, the board shall determine the truth or falsity of the matters charged in the complaint, and it shall also determine whether any violation of the provisions of this chapter has occurred. If the board shall determine that the complaint is not true or that the testimony fails to show any violation of the provisions of this chapter, it shall forthwith dismiss said complaint. If, however, the board finds that a violation has been committed, the Board of Examiners shall have the authority to revoke the electrical contractor's registration, or it may suspend said registration for a period not to exceed six months. The decision of the board shall be the final administrative hearing provided by this chapter. A revocation of registration shall not entitle the registration holder to a refund of any part of the registration fee that may have been paid. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25170, passed 9-29-76; Am. Ord. 27582, passed 7-29-87; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 113.25. - Duties of board. 
(A)  It shall be the duty of the board to hear complaints arising against any registered electrical contractor, and to judge all work alleged to be in violation of this chapter. It shall keep accurate records of all applications for a registration. The Board shall keep accurate minutes of all of its meetings, and keep all such other records as may be required by this chapter. It shall make a complete annual written report to the City Manager each year. 
(B)  The board shall meet each month if necessary, for the purpose of transacting such business as may properly come before it. A special meeting may be held by the board by giving at least 15 days' written notice of the special meeting to the board members. A special meeting may be called upon the request of the secretary or any two members of the board. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 25170, passed 9-29-76; Am. Ord. 25724, passed 3-28-79; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Secs. 113.26-113.29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROPERTY OF ELECTRIC COMPANIES 

Sec. 113.30. - Definitions. 
(A)  For the purposes of § 113.31 the word "company" shall mean and include any person, firm, or corporation engaged in either the manufacture or distribution or sale of electricity for light, heat, power, or other similar purposes. 
(B)  For the purposes of § 113.32 the word "company" shall mean and include any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of distributing electricity for any of the purposes enumerated in this section. 
(Ord. 12199, passed 6-25-24; Am. Ord. 12200, passed 6-25-24; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 113.31. - Defacing electric company property. 
    No person shall willfully or maliciously injure or destroy, or intentionally permit to be injured or destroyed, or disconnect, displace, cut, break, tap, ground, or make a connection with, or willfully or maliciously interfere with the poles, cables; or wires legally erected, installed, or strung, electrical apparatus, appliances, or machinery used in the construction or operation of an electric light plant, or plants used in producing or generating electricity for light, heat, power, or other purposes, or a meter, pipe, conduit wire, line, post, lamp, burner, machine, motor, or other appliance or apparatus belonging to a company engaged in the manufacture, distribution, or sale of electricity for light, heat, power, or other purposes; or willfully or maliciously prevent an electric meter belonging to a company furnishing electricity for light, heat, power, or other purposes from duly registering the quantity of electricity supplied by such company; or interfere with the proper action or just registration by such meter; or alter the index in such meters; or, without the consent of such company, willfully or maliciously divert an electric current from a wire or wires, equipment or apparatus of such company; or otherwise willfully or maliciously use, or cause to be used without the consent of such company, electricity manufactured or distributed by such company. 
(Ord. 12200, passed 6-25-24; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 113.99. 
Sec. 113.32. - Jumpers around electric meters. 
    No person being a customer of a company distributing electricity for light, heat, power, or other purposes and having in his or her possession or under his or her control or upon premises owned or occupied by him or her, or of which he or she is the lessee, a meter belonging to such company, shall willfully and knowingly and without the consent of such company disconnect, change, alter, or interfere with wires, or any of them, running to or from such meter, or shall willfully and knowingly and without the consent of such company install any wire or device; or do anything that diverts the electric current supplied by such company, or any part thereof, from going through such meter and prevents such meter from duly registering the quantity of electricity supplied by such company and which ought to pass through and be registered by such meters; or willfully, maliciously, and knowingly aid, agree, employ or conspire with another or others to do any of the acts aforementioned. 
(Ord. 12199, passed 6-25-24; Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 113.99. 
Secs. 113.33-113.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 113.99. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(Am. Ord. 29117-95, passed 11-22-95) 
CHAPTER 114. - PLUMBING AND HEATING 
DIVISION 1. - PLUMBING 

Sec. 114.01. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of §§ 114.01 through 114.20, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Apprentice or plumber's apprentice. Any person who is engaged in learning the trade of and assisting in the installation of plumbing as his or her principal occupation, and who is registered as an apprentice as required by §§ 114.01 through 114.20. 
    Business of plumbing. The installation, alteration, maintenance, removal, replacement, and repair of all drainage systems, plumbing systems, water supply systems, gas fitting, and all parts thereof, inside any building or structure or the walls thereof; done on the premises thereof. 
    Journeyman plumber. A person who has sufficient practical knowledge and mechanical competency to do plumbing, gas fitting, and drain laying. 
    Plumbing contractor. An individual or business entity, that contracts for, proceeds with, or employs others for the business of plumbing. Such person acting as a plumbing contractor shall be issued a registration in the name of the business and shall be responsible for the design and installation as herein required, and shall be subject to the penalties as herein provided. No person shall be issued more than one plumbing contractor's registration, and the termination of his or her employment shall cause such registration to be cancelled. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.02. - Board of Examiners of Plumbers created. 
    There is created a Board of Examiners of Plumbers. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 114.03. - Membership of board. 
    The Board of Examiners of Plumbers shall consist of the Director of Building Service, the Director of Water, the Plumbing Inspector, the Manager of the Division of Building Inspection, or their duly authorized representatives, one plumbing contractor who is a member of the Dayton Association of Plumbing Contractors at the time of his or her appointment, one journeyman plumber, and one independent plumbing contractor. The three last named members shall be appointed annually by the City Manager for a term of one year, taking office January 1 of each year. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 26308, passed 8-12-81; Am. Ord. 26604, passed 9-l-82; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.04. - Officers of board. 
    The Director of Building Services shall be the President of the Board, and the board shall annually select a secretary, either from its own membership, in which case the secretary shall exercise full power of membership, or from without its membership. The secretary shall perform the usual duties of his office, acting as a general secretary and a recording secretary, keeping all records of the board as provided hereinafter. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.05. - Oath of office. 
    Before assuming office, each member of the board shall take an oath before the Clerk of the Commission to perform properly the duties of his office as a member of the board. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95) 
Sec. 114.06. - Rules and regulations of board. 
    The Board of Examiners of Plumbers shall make such rules and prescribe such procedure as may be necessary for its operation in conformity with §§ 114.01 through 114.20. Four members of the board shall concur its decisions. It shall have complete control over the examination of applicants for apprentice certificates under these sections, and shall decide upon the certificates under these sections, and shall decide upon the qualification of apprentice and journeyman applicants. Examinations of applicants shall be conducted at least once each calendar quarter or at such times during the calendar quarter as necessary, at such times and places as the board may designate; such examinations may be oral or written, or both, at the discretion of the board. The board may make such rules and regulations governing examinations as it may see fit. However, all rules and regulations shall be uniformly applied. It shall keep an accurate record of all applications for examinations, examinations given, and the results thereof. The board shall certify to the Department of Building Services the names of all successful applicants, with recommendations for the issuance of registration or apprentice certificates. It shall keep accurate minutes of all its meetings, and keep such other records as may be required hereinafter. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 24232, passed 3-l-72; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.07. - Plumber's registration or apprentice certificate required. 
    All persons, firms, corporations, or business organizations engaged in the business of plumbing in the city, regardless of residence, shall be required to secure necessary registrations or certificates before engaging in such work. No permit for such work shall be issued by the Department of Building Services to any person who is not a plumbing contractor who has not complied with the provisions of §§ 114.01 through 114.20. No plumbing contractor shall lend his registration or procure permits for others when he is not the plumbing contractor for such work. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 25277, passed 4-6-77; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Cross reference- Exception to above licensing requirement, see § 50.50; penalty, see § 114.99. 
Sec. 114.08. - Classes of registration. 
    There shall be three classes of registration. 
(1)  An apprentice certificate, for which a fee of $30.00 shall be charged biennially or $20.00 shall be charged annually. 
(2)  A journeyman plumber's registration, for which the fee of $50.00 shall be charged biennially or $30.00 shall be charged annually. 
(3)  A plumbing contractor's registration, for which a fee of $600.00 shall be charged biennially or $350.00 shall be charged annually. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 25277, passed 4-6-77; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 25799, passed 7-5-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.081. - Contents of application for registration. 
(A)  All applications to obtain a plumbing contractor's registration shall be made upon blank forms furnished for such purpose by the Department of Building Services. 
(B)  Any person applying for a registration or renewal under the provisions of §§ 114.01 through 114.20, shall be required to pass any examination administered by the Ohio Construction Industry Examining Board and show proof of a valid and unexpired plumbing contractor's specialty license issued pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Revised Code. 
(Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.09. - Examination required for registration. 
    Before any person shall be issued a journeyman plumber's registration under the provisions of §§ 114.01 through 114.20, he or she shall be required to pass an examination administered by the Board of Examiners of Plumbers, and receive from that board a certificate to the effect that he or she is duly qualified as a journeyman plumber. The examination fee for a journeyman plumber's registration shall be $25.00. No part of any of the above fees shall be refunded on account of the failure of the applicant to qualify for a registration. However, any plumbing contractor with an active plumbing contractor's specialty license issued pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Revised Code need not take any examination, test or demonstrate technical skills to obtain a plumbing contractor's registration. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.10. - Insurance required of registrant. 
(A)  On each renewal or issuance of a plumbing contractor's registration as required by § 114.07, the registrant who engages in the business of plumbing as defined in § 114.01 shall furnish evidence to the Secretary of the Board of Examiners of Plumbers that the registrant has in full force and effect insurance coverage containing the following minimum amounts: 
(1)  Public liability: 
$100,000.00-each person 
$300,000.00-each accident 
$300,000.00-completed operation 
(2)  Property damage: 
$50,000.00-each accident 
$100,000.00-aggregate for operations liability 
$100,000.00-aggregate for completed operations liability 
(B)  Such insurance shall protect people and/or property against loss arising out of any negligent act of the insured or any of his or her agents or employees, and shall contain an endorsement that the same shall not be cancelled before giving the city written notice ten days prior to cancellation. 
(Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.11. - Bond required. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall engage in the plumbing business in the city without first having filed with the Secretary of the Board of Examiners of Plumbers a good and sufficient surety bond to the city as obligee, in the principal sum of $10,000.00 by a surety company licensed by the State of Ohio. This bond shall be approved by the City Accountant and conditioned upon the faithful observance of all ordinances of the city relating to such business. 
(Ord. 19997, passed 7-5-61; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 114.99. 
Sec. 114.111. - Registration issuance. 
    Upon payment of the registration fee as prescribed in § 114.08 and determination that the applicant meets the requirements of §§ 114.01 through 114.11, a plumbing contractor's registration shall be issued. 
(Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.12. - Registration and certificate renewal. 
    All registrations and apprentice certificates shall be renewed biennially, on January 1, at the fees set forth in § 114.08. If a registration or certificate of an apprentice is for a period of less than one year, the fee therefor shall be as provided for in § 114.08. No part of any fee shall be refunded for any cause. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 25277, passed 4-6-77; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.13. - Renewal of expired registration. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of plumbing who shall fail to procure a renewal of registration as herein provided within 30 days from the date of its expiration, shall, before he or she is issued such registration, be required to show proof of current plumbing contractor's specialty license pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Revised Code, with payment of the fee therefor, as in the original instance. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.14. - Registration and certificate nontransferable. 
    No license or certificate shall be transferable. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 25277, passed 4-6-77; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.15. - Disposition of registration and examination fees. 
    All registrations or apprentice certificates required by §§ 114.01 through 114.20 shall be issued by the Department of Building Services, and all money derived from registration fees herein provided for shall be paid into the city treasury and be credited to the general fund. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.16. - Display of registration number on vehicle required. 
    It shall be the duty of every person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of plumbing to display his or her certificate of registration number on all vehicles while engaged in the business of plumbing. These numbers shall be attached in a legible manner in contrasting colors on both sides of said vehicles with not less than two-inch block numerals. 
(Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 114.99. 
Sec. 114.17. - Apprentice certificate application renewal. 
    Apprentice plumbers shall: 
(A)  File an application for a certificate of apprenticeship with the Board of Examiners of Plumbers, which application shall contain his name, address, experience in the trade, and such other information as the Board of Examiners shall require; 
(B)  An apprentice plumber must, at all times while engaged in the trade of plumbing, be under the direct supervision of a registered journeyman and not more than one apprentice shall be permitted to work under the supervision of a registered journeyman at the same time; and 
(C)  The certificate of apprenticeship must be renewed biennally within 30 days from the date of expiration, but shall not be renewed for more than five successive years unless a further extension shall be granted by the board. 
(Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 114.99. 
Sec. 114.18. - Revocation or suspension of registration or certificate; notice; hearing. 
(A)  The Board of Examiners shall have the power to revoke or suspend all registrations or certificates of apprentice issued under §§ 114.01 through 114.20. A registration or certificate of apprentice shall be revoked immediately by the board upon conviction of the holder thereof, in a court of competent jurisdiction, of a violation of the laws of the state or of the ordinances of the city relative to plumbing and sanitation. 
(B)  A registration or certificate of apprenticeship may be revoked or suspended by the board, in its discretion, when it finds that the registrant or holder of a certificate of apprenticeship is guilty of fraudulent use of his or her registration or certificate; or of violation of the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city relative to plumbing and sanitation; or of incompetence in the exercise of the privileges of such registration or apprentice certificate; or of fraud or misrepresentation in connection with securing the registration or apprentice certificate, or permits granted by virtue thereof; or of refusal to conform his work to the requirements of law; or of such other breaches of duty, as a registrant or apprentice, as the board may regard contrary to the intent and purposes of these sections. 
(C)  (1)  In all cases involving revocation or suspension of registration or apprentice certificate, at least 15 days' notice of the contemplated revocation or suspension shall be served upon the registrant or apprentice whose registration or certificate of apprenticeship is in question, and such notice shall be in the form of a summons as provided by the laws of Ohio for civil actions, and shall be served in the manner provided in those laws for such summons. It shall indicate the time and place of the hearing and the general grounds of the contemplated revocation or suspension, and shall advise the registrant or apprentice of his right to appear at the hearing in person, and by counsel, for the purpose of presenting his defense therein. 
(2)  The registrant or apprentice shall have the right to interrogate witnesses at said hearing and be heard orally upon the merits of his defense. The board shall have the power to subpoena witnesses and compel attendance of the same; to administer oaths; punish for contempt; compel the production of records and other documentary evidence; and all lawful things essential to a full hearing of the case before it. It shall make a complete record of such cases, and may, at its discretion, keep a stenographic record of the testimony produced in such hearings. It may request legal advice from the law department and adopt such procedure for its decorum and the dispatch of business at such hearings as it may regard advisable. 
(3)  The decision of the board shall be final, and no registrant or apprentice whose registration or certificate of apprentice has been revoked shall be granted a new registration or certificate of apprentice until the expiration of six months after the revocation as aforesaid, and after successful examination and payment of all fees as in the original instance. A revocation of registration or certificate of apprentice shall not entitle the registrant or apprentice to a refund of any part of the registration or certificate of apprentice fee that he may have paid. 
(Ord. 13434, passed 11-30-27; Am. Ord. 22164, passed 7-27-66; Am. Ord. 25735, passed 4-18-79; Am. Ord. 29118-95, passed 11-22-95; Am. Ord. 30057-01, passed 12-26-01) 
Sec. 114.19. - Nonapplicability of §§ 114.01 through 114.20. 
(A)  The provisions of §§ 114.01 through 114.20 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Public utilities, public institutions, public buildings, or mercantile, commercial, or industrial plants, which maintain departments for the installation and maintenance of plumbing in or on the premises, under expert supervision, in conformity with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city, relative to sanitation and plumbing.
