(Ord. 24572, passed 9-5-73; Am. Ord. 25030, passed 12-17-75; Am. Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 28204, passed 10-17-90; Am. Ord. 29496-98, passed 1-7-98; Am. Ord. 30135-02, passed 8-14-02; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14; Ord. 31404-15, passed 6-17-15) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.49. - Horse-drawn taxicabs-Additional requirements; restricted routes and hours of operation. 
(A)  Every horse which draws a taxicab shall be fitted with a device which shall prevent fecal matter from being deposited on the public right-of-way, and every horse-drawn taxicab shall be equipped with a pail and shovel to be used in removing fecal matter from the public right-of-way. Any fecal matter which shall be deposited by the horse upon the public right-of-way shall be promptly removed by the independent operator and/or driver and disposed of in a sanitary manner. 
(B)  No operator or independent operator and/or driver of a horse-drawn taxicab shall operate such taxicab on any route, street, or public way other than those specified in writing by the Director of Police. 
(C)  No operator or independent operator and/or driver of a horse-drawn taxicab shall operate such taxicab at any time other than during the hours specified in writing by the Director of Police. 
(D)  All operators or independent operator and/or driver of a horse-drawn taxicab must provide written notice to the Director of Police at least 30 days prior to the dates they wish to operate for purposes of safety of the horse-drawn taxicab and to allow for traffic concerns. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.50. - Display of photograph and taxicab number. 
    Every taxicab independent operator and/or driver shall display on the dashboard of the vehicle in plain view and with proper lighting a duplicate of his/her photograph together with a card not less than three inches by five inches in size showing his/her name and independent operator and/or driver's taxicab number, so that any seated passenger occupying the vehicle may have a clear view of the photograph and taxicab number. The independent operator and/or driver of a horse-drawn taxicab shall display the photograph and card in any conspicuous place within the carriage, which shall not be required to be lighted. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.51. - Display of rate schedule. 
    It shall be the duty of each taxicab operator and of each taxicab independent operator and/or driver to see that the schedule of rates and the most current schedule of approximate fares, as approved by the Director of Police, are posted within the interior of the taxicab operated or driven by him/her in such a manner that it is in sight of and can be read by the passenger or passengers. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.52. - Passenger occupying front seat. 
    When two or more passengers are being transported in the rear of a taxicab, or when a new independent operator and/or driver is being trained, or when a passenger is handicapped, the taxicab independent operator and/or driver may permit a handicapped passenger or other person to ride in the front seat with him/her, otherwise it shall be unlawful for the independent operator and/or driver of any taxicab to permit any passenger or other person to ride in the front seat with the taxicab independent operator and/or driver. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.53. - Additional passengers. 
    A taxicab independent operator and/or driver, having a passenger in the taxicab, may not solicit or accept for carriage any other passenger, unless he/she obtains permission from the original passenger. If two or more passengers are transported to different destinations, the taximeter shall be reset at the end of each trip; if they are transported to the same destination, only the extra fee provided by §115.48 hereof shall be charged. It is the passengers' obligation and responsibility to decide how the fee will be shared. Failure to do so will result in all passengers being equally obligated for the total fare. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.54. - Receipts; credit and debit cards. 
(A)  A taxicab independent operator and/or driver shall, on request by a passenger, give a receipt to the passenger for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the date, the taximeter amount, name of the taxicab operator and the name of the taxicab independent operator and/or driver. 
(B)  Every taxicab shall be equipped to accept credit and debit cards as form of payment, and issue printed receipts for credit and debit card transactions. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.55. - Carrying passengers engaged in unlawful activity prohibited. 
    No taxicab operator or taxicab independent operator and/or driver shall solicit or knowingly accept passengers engaged in or about to engage in any immoral or unlawful activity. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.56. - Solicitation of passengers restricted; exceptions. 
(A)  No taxicab operator or taxicab independent operator and/or driver shall solicit passengers by the sounding of a taxicab horn, by spoken word, or in any other manner at any place other than the lawfully designated taxicab stands. 
(B)  Nothing herein shall be construed to interfere with accepting passengers at other places when such is previously arranged with the passenger, or when hailed while en route. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.57. - Misrepresentation and improper conduct of operator or independent operator and/or driver prohibited. 
    No taxicab operator or taxicab independent operator and/or driver shall: 
(A)  Deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger, prospective passenger, or other person by any misrepresentations as to the number, ownership, or other information regarding his/her taxicab; 
(B)  Coerce or attempt to coerce any person for the purpose of securing or attempting to secure the person as a passenger in said taxicab; 
(C)  Use any profane, boisterous, or improper language; 
(D)  Be the cause of or engage in any quarreling, fighting, or other unlawful disturbance; 
(E)  Loiter about a taxicab stand, except upon the independent operator and/or driver seat of his/her own taxicab; 
(F)  Solicit passengers while at a taxicab stand, except while seated upon the independent operator and/or driver seat of his/her own taxicab; 
(G)  Solicit passengers by loud, boisterous outcry; 
(H)  Accept passengers who have requested service from another taxicab operator; 
(I)  Take any route other than the most direct route to a passenger's destination unless otherwise authorized or directed by the passenger. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.58. - Delay of passengers prohibited. 
    No taxicab operator or taxicab independent operator and/or driver shall cause his/her taxicab to remain parked and delay the transporting of the passenger or passengers occupying the taxicab to their requested destination for a period in excess of two minutes after the passenger or passengers have entered the taxicab. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.59. - Refusal of passenger to pay legal fare. 
    No person shall refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab after having hired it. No person shall hire any taxicab with the intent to defraud the person from whom it is hired of the value of the service. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
Cross reference- Penalty, see § 115.99. 
Sec. 115.60. - Taxicab provisions are exclusive. 
    The provisions in §§ 115.30 through 115.598, of this Code, are enacted by the City Commission of the City of Dayton solely and exclusively for the purpose of regulating taxicab operators, taxicab independent operator and/or drivers, while engaged in the business of operating taxicabs or other vehicles in and upon the public streets and highways of the City of Dayton, and nothing therein shall be interpreted or construed so as to give any right or cause of action against the city, its officials, officers, agents, employees, and representatives regarding the enforcement, non-enforcement, or any action or actions as a result thereof. 
(Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14; Am. Ord. 31511-16, passed 9-7-16) 
Secs. 115.61-115.98. - Reserved. 
Sec. 115.99. - Penalty. 
(A)  Any person violating any of the provisions of §§ 115.01 through 115.15 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense, and guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a second or subsequent offense. Every violation of these sections shall constitute a separate offense. Violations occurring simultaneously shall be prosecuted as separate offenses, but two violations at the same time shall not require that the accused actually be given a separate sentence of imprisonment. However, in case of a third offense, the court shall have the discretion to do so. 
(B)  Any person violating any of the provisions of §§ 115.16 through 115.28 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Every violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(C)  Any person violating any of the provisions of §§ 115.30 through 115.58 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
(D)  Any person violating § 115.59 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
('77 Code, § 115.99; Am. Ord. 25506, passed 4-5-78; Am. Ord. 26952, passed 2-22-84; Am. Ord. 27414, passed 6-25-86; Am. Ord. 31362-14, passed 12-31-14) 
DIVISION 4. - COMMERCIAL QUADRICYCLE 

Sec. 115.701. - Quadricycle permit. 
(A)  In order to operate a commercial quadricycle, an individual or business must obtain for a commercial quadricycle permit. 
(B)  To obtain a permit pursuant to subsection (A) above, an individual or business may submit an application to the Director of the Department of Planning on a form provided by the Director. The application shall include proof of insurance coverage for the business, a statement of planned routes, and a list of business practices and policies. 
(C)  Each permit shall expire 12 months from the date it is issued by the city. 
(Ord. 31549-17, passed 2-8-17) 
CHAPTER 116. - CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE[2] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Capitalization in the Cable Television Franchise has been retained as per Ord. 28338 adopted July 24, 1991. Misspellings and grammatical errors have been set out in brackets. 

Sec. 116.01. - Short title. 
    This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "Cable Television Franchise Ordinance." 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.02. - Grant of Franchise renewal. 
(A)  Upon consideration of Grantee's request for renewal and after duly considering its compliance with the existing Franchise, and its character, legal, financial, technical and other qualifications, the city deems it to be in the best interest of the city and its citizens to renew Grantee's Franchise on the terms and subject to the conditions contained herein. 
(B)  Grantee is hereby granted the right, privilege and Franchise to install, operate and maintain a Community Antenna TV System within the corporate limits of the City of Dayton, Ohio, on the terms and subject to the conditions contained herein. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.03. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this ordinance the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, words in the singular number include the plural number, and the use of any gender shall be applicable to all genders whenever the sense requires. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. 
    Broadcast channel. A channel provided by the Cable System to relay to subscriber terminals television broadcast programs that are received off-the-air or by direct connection to a television station. 
    Cable Act. The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 (47 USC, Section 521, et seq.), and as it may hereinafter be amended from time to time, and any regulations promulgated thereunder by the FCC. 
    Cable communications System or System, also referred to as cable television System, Cable System, CATV System, or community antenna TV System, shall mean a System of antennae, cables, wires, lines, towers, waveguides, microwave and radio, or other conductors, converters, amplifiers, headend equipment, master controls, earth stations, equipment and facilities designed and constructed for the primary purpose of producing, receiving, transmitting, amplifying and distributing audio, video and other forms of electronic or electrical signals within the city. 
    Channel. A band of frequencies in the electromagnetic spectrum that is capable of carrying one NTSC audio-video signal, or a larger number of frequency modulated audio signals or several thousand digital signals. 
    City. The City of Dayton, Ohio, a charter City of the State of Ohio and all the territory within its present and future boundaries and including any area over which the city exercises jurisdiction. The City Commission, or any delegate acting within the scope of his/its authority, exercises the authority of the city. 
    FCC. The Federal Communications Commission. 
    Franchise. Shall mean the right to use City Streets to erect, construct, reconstruct, operate, dismantle, test, use and maintain a Cable Communications System in the city. 
    Franchise agreement. Shall mean this cable television Franchise ordinance. 
    Franchise Fee. The fee assessed by the city on the Grantee pursuant to § 116.09 as compensation for Grantee's occupation and use of City Streets pursuant to this Franchise. 
    Grantee. Shall mean Viacom Cablevision of Dayton, Inc., its lawful successors, transferees or assignees. 
    Grantor. Shall have the same meaning as "city". 
    Gross Receipts. Shall mean all cash and noncash revenue received by Grantee directly or indirectly from Subscribers or any other Persons arising out of operation of the Cable Television System and relating to activities for which this Franchise is required, including but not limited to revenues derived from the following: 
(1)  Provision of entertainment and nonentertainment services to Subscribers (e.g., charges to Subscribers for basic, tier, premium, pay-per-view and remote service charges); 
(2)  Affiliate fees from insertion of commercial advertisements into ad availabilities in programming transmitted to Subscribers of the System (i.e. ad sales revenues); 
(3)  Installation, connection and reinstatement of equipment of equipment necessary for the utilization of the System by Subscribers; 
(4)  Lease of studio space and/or production equipment to Persons for a production which airs on the System; 
(5)  Lease or use of all or part of a channel on the System to or by any person (e.g., leased access fees, home shopping revenue sharing, fees charged to cable programmers in return for carriage, fees charged to Persons who cablecast local origination or community programming); 
(6)  The sale, exchange or use of any programming developed by Grantee and aired on the System for community use or institutional users; and 
(7)  The production and sale to Subscribers of a locally produced channel guide, including the sale of advertising space in such guide. 
    For the purposes of the foregoing definition, "non-cash revenue" consists of the value, at fair market value, of any goods, services or other form of noncash compensation or remuneration received by Grantee in consideration for Grantee's provision of any service or performance of any activity which is includable in the calculation of Gross Receipts, above. 
    Leased access shall mean the use on a fee-for-service basis of the Cable Television System by business enterprises (whether profit, nonprofit or governmental) and shall include without limitation all uses pursuant to Section 612 of the Cable Act. 
    Person. Any individual, corporation, partnership, association, joint venture or organization of any kind and the lawful trustee, successor, assignee, transferee or personal representative thereof. 
    Public access facilities means the total of the following: 
(1)  Channel capacity designated for public, educational, or governmental use; and 
(2)  Facilities and equipment for the use of such channel capacity. 
    Street. Shall mean the surface of and the space above and below any public right-of-way, street, road, highway, freeway, easement, lane, path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or driveway now or hereafter existing as such within the city. 
    Subscriber. Any person who legally receives any one or more of the cable television services provided by the Cable Communications System. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.04. - Police powers. 
    Nothing in this ordinance or in any agreement awarding a Franchise in accordance herewith shall be construed as an abrogation by the city, or limitation upon, of any of its police powers. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.05. - Franchise renewal; application. 
    This Franchise may be renewed in accordance with the provisions of Section 626 of the Cable Act, as it may hereinafter be amended from time to time, or of any successor statute. Application for a Franchise renewal shall include at a minimum: 
(A)  If renewal is sought by an affiliated entity other than Grantee, a clear description of the identity of the applicant, including but not limited to the name of the applicant, the address of the applicant, the nature of the business entity and its relationship to Grantee, and evidence of the compliance of the business entity with all applicable law; 
(B)  If the applicant seeks a Franchise for a geographic area which differs from that served by Grantee hereunder, a map or maps of a scale of not less than one inch equaling 1,000 feet showing the precise geographic area for which the applicant seeks a Franchise ("Franchise Area"); 
(C)  Evidence of financial responsibility in the form of a performance bond conforming to § 116.35. 
(D)  If the applicant proposes to serve areas beyond those served by the Grantee, a schedule of construction, as established by the applicant, and reflected upon map(s) showing by a logical progression which streets within the Franchise Area shall be constructed by the applicant within each calendar quarter during the period of construction. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.06. - Grant of nonexclusive Franchise. 
    Upon consideration of the Company's request for renewal of its cable television Franchise agreement and after duly considering the Company's character, legal, financial, technical and other qualifications, the city does hereby grant Viacom Cablevision of Dayton, Inc. a renewal of nonexclusive revocable Franchise to use City Streets to construct, own and operate a Cable System. The Franchise granted hereby shall be nonexclusive. The city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such additional Franchises for a cable communications System as it deems appropriate and in accordance with applicable law, provided, however, that such additional grants shall be on the same terms and conditions as those contained in this Franchise, and shall not operate to materially modify, revoke or terminate rights previously granted to any Grantee. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.07. - Franchise territory. 
    The Franchise is for the present territorial limits of the city and any area annexed thereto during the term of the Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.08. - Term of Franchise renewal. 
    The term of this Franchise renewal and the rights, privileges and authority granted is for a period of 15 years commencing on September 1, 1991 and ending on August 31, 2006. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.09. - Franchise fee. 
(A)  In consideration for the use of the streets and for the purpose of providing revenue with which to defray the cost of regulation arising out of the granting of the Franchise under this ordinance and promoting, assisting and financing public, educational, and governmental access programming, the Grantee shall pay to the city an amount equal to five percent per year of the Grantee's annual Gross Receipts. 
(B)  In the event that federal law, in the future, allows the city to charge a Franchise fee of a greater percentage than the percentage contained herein, the city and the Grantee shall proceed under § 116.65. 
(C)  Said Franchise Fees shall be paid quarterly not later than May 15, August 15, November 15, and February 15 for the preceding three-month periods ending, respectively, March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31. Not later than the date of each payment, the Grantee shall file with the City Manager or his designee, a written statement which identifies in detail the sources and amounts of Gross Receipts received by the Grantee during the quarter for which payment is made. 
(D)  No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as an accord that the amount paid is, in fact, the correct amount, nor shall such acceptance of payment be construed as a release of any claim which the city may have for further or additional sums payable under the provisions of this Section. 
(E)  Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as relieving the Grantee of its liability for other properly applicable local taxes. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.10. - Interest on delinquent Franchise Fees. 
    Any Franchise Fees which remain unpaid after the dates specified in § 116.09 shall be delinquent and shall thereafter accrue interest at the rate of one percent per month or 12 percent per annum until paid. In the event late payment of Franchise Fees is beyond the control of the Grantee, the city may waive the interest. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.11. - Annual report; accounting standards. 
    Not less than annually, the Grantee shall provide the city with the statement of an independent certified public accountant certifying the accuracy of the quarterly Franchise fee payments paid within the preceding 12 months pursuant to § 116.09. Said certification shall be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting standards as established by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB). 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.12. - Restriction on benefit from Franchise. 
    Grantee has not established, and will not, without consent of the city, during the term of this Franchise, establish or participate in the establishment of any subsidiary, affiliate, or other entity under common control with Grantee for the purpose of diverting items of revenue includable in the definition of "GROSS RECEIPTS" from Grantee to such other person, and therefore not paying a Franchise fee on such item of revenue. All activities for which a Franchise is required hereunder and under the cable act will be performed solely by Grantee, and not by any other person whatsoever. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.13. - Auditing; books and records. 
    During each year of the term of the Franchise, the city may, not more frequently than once in such year, conduct an audit of the books, records and accounts of the Grantee for the 12-month period covered by the most recent annual report delivered by the Grantee pursuant to § 116.09, for the purpose of determining whether the Grantee has paid Franchise Fees in the amounts prescribed by § 116.09. The audit may be conducted by the Finance Director of the City or by an independent certified public accounting firm retained by the city, and shall be conducted at the sole expense of the city. The party conducting the audit shall prepare a written report containing its findings, and the report shall be filed with the city, and mailed to the Grantee. The audit shall be completed and the written report filed within six months of the audit's commencement. Grantee shall have 60 days after receipt of the audit report to either accept it or to notify the city of any objections it may have. If accepted by the Grantee, the audit shall be deemed closed. Any objections shall be resolved in accordance with the dispute resolution provisions of this Franchise. Grantee shall, to the best of its ability, keep its books and records in such a way to show the activities of the System serving the city separate from any other activities of Grantee. The Grantee shall make available for inspection by authorized representatives of the city, those books, accounts and other financial records reasonably necessary to verify the calculation of Gross Receipts hereunder, at reasonable times during normal business hours and upon reasonable advance notice for the purpose of permitting exercise of the authority conferred by this section. Access to such books and records shall not be denied on the basis that said books and records contain "proprietary" information; provided, however, that in the case of any document which contains a confidentiality agreement, the Grantee shall join with the Grantor in requesting that the other party to such agreement waive the confidentiality clause for the limited purpose of the audit. Grantee shall not be required to give the city access to any contract with a third party which contains a confidentiality clause or otherwise restricts disclosure of its terms. The city shall treat all information obtained from Grantee with the same degree of confidentiality it accords its own proprietary information. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.14. - Flow-through of refunds. 
    If, during the term of this Franchise, the Grantee is required by final order of any regulatory authority or court of competent jurisdiction to refund any tax or fee collected by the Grantee from Subscribers on behalf of any regulatory or taxing authority, it shall without delay notify the city, suggest a plan for flow-through of the refunds to its Subscribers, and retain such refunds pending order of the city. After considering the plan submitted by the Grantee, the city shall order the flow-through of the refunds to the Grantee's Subscribers in a fair and equitable manner. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.15. - Construction codes and standards. 
    Construction codes and standards to be utilized by the Grantee are as follows: 
(A)  Methods of construction, installation, and maintenance of the Grantee's Cable Television System shall comply with the National Electrical Safety Code, National Bureau of Standards Handbook 81 (Part 2), United States Department of Commerce, November 1961, as amended, to the extent that such Code is consistent with local law affecting the construction, installation, and maintenance of electrical supply and communication lines. 
(B)  Any tower constructed for use in the Grantee's Cable Television System shall comply with the standards, as amended, contained in the Structural Standards for Steel Antenna Towers and Antenna supporting Structures, EIA Standards RS-222-A, as published by the Engineering Department of the Electronic Industries Association, 2201 I Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20006. 
(C)  All methods of construction, installation, and maintenance of the Grantee's Cable Television System shall also comply with all applicable laws and rules of the State of Ohio and the city. The city reserves the right, from time to time, to issue, by duly adopted ordinance, such reasonable rules and regulations concerning the construction, operation, and maintenance of the System as are consistent with its police powers and the provisions of this chapter, to the extent necessary to protect its residents' rights to the peaceful enjoyment of the streets, provided such rules and regulations will not materially impact the Grantee. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.16. - Grantee to exercise reasonable care and diligence. 
    In construction, installation, maintenance, removal, or repair of the facilities herein contemplated, the Grantee shall exercise reasonable care and diligence to avoid damage, injury, or nuisance to Persons or property and shall install and maintain its facilities in a workmanlike manner so as to minimize the public inconvenience and so as not to interfere with any facilities of the city. The Grantee shall comply with all existing city regulations pertaining to the use of the streets and shall, at its own expense, carefully guard and protect all streets and shall, at its own expense, carefully guard and protect all streets entered and opened by it so as to prevent injury to Persons or damage to property while work therein is being performed. All such streets shall be restored to their former condition by the Grantee as soon as is practicable after completion of work; provided, however, Grantee shall not be required to repave an entire street. The Grantee's obligations hereunder shall be to backfill and repave the trench or street cut involved, all to applicable city standards. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.17. - Overhead and underground construction. 
(A)  The Grantee shall be permitted to place its cable, wires, or other equipment overhead when local and state law permits overhead construction and other like facilities are overhead. The Grantee shall place its cables, wires or other equipment underground when local or state law requires like facilities to be placed underground, or when other like facilities are underground. 
(B)  In case of new construction or property development where utilities are to be placed underground, the developer or property owner shall give Grantee at least ten working days notice of the particular date on which open trenching will be available. Grantee will install conduit, pedestals and/or vaults in such trench, and the developer or property owner will reimburse Grantee for the cost of such equipment and installation. Grantee shall also provide specifications as needed for trenching. Costs of trenching and easements required to bring service to the development shall be borne by the developer or property owner. 
(C)  The city shall use its best efforts with pole and conduit owners to promote the joint use of poles and conduit so as to assure the broadest possible wiring of premises within the city. The Grantee shall not erect any new pole or conduit without first obtaining the city 's written approval of the location, type, and specifications thereof. 
(D)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Franchise, if, in any part of the city, satisfactory aerial or underground easement rights over private property cannot be obtained on reasonable terms or pursuant to Section 621(a)(2) of the Cable Act, the Grantee shall have no obligation to build its System or provide service in said area. 
(E)  Any poles owned by the Grantee shall be available for use by the city at just and reasonable rates and for lease to other parties at a reasonable fee, so long as such use complies with all applicable safety standards and Grantee's standards. In the event the city's use requires rearrangement of Grantee's equipment to facilitate the placement of the city's equipment, the city shall bear the expense of such rearrangement. 
(F)  All city-owned poles and conduits installed within the city shall be made available for attachment or use by the Grantee at just and reasonable rates which shall be equivalent to those paid by other utilities. In the event the Grantee's use requires rearrangement of city's equipment to facilitate the placement of the Grantee's equipment, the Grantee shall bear the expense of such rearrangement. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.18. - Tree trimming. 
    The Grantee shall have the right hereunder to trim trees in and overhanging the streets, in a workmanlike manner, so as to protect its facilities from abrasive contact. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city, at its option, may, following 14 days written notice to the Grantee, undertake such trimming at the Grantee's expense. In the event of an emergency, Grantee will waive such notice requirement. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.19. - Relocation to accommodate public and private improvements. 
    The Grantee shall, upon reasonable notice and without expense to the city, relocate its facilities to accommodate such public works or improvements as the city shall in its [judgment] designate. The Grantee shall, at the expense of any person holding a building moving permit issued by the city, temporarily raise, lower, or remove its wires to permit the moving of said building. In such event, the Grantee shall be given no less than 30 days advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. The Grantee's estimated charges for such work shall be payable not less than 48 hours in advance. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.20. - Right of inspection and restoration. 
    The city shall have the right to supervise or inspect all work performed by the Grantee or its agents upon streets to ensure compliance with the Franchise. In the event such inspection reveals that the Grantee has failed, in the city's reasonable judgment, to fulfill its obligations under this Franchise, the city shall notify the Grantee, in writing of its specific deficiencies. Absent commencement of corrective action by the Grantee within 48 hours of receipt of said notification, the city may undertake the necessary repairs or restorations at the Grantee's sole expense. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.21. - System configuration. 
    As appropriate, Grantee or the Cable Television System shall, at a minimum: 
(A)  Install and continue to provided cable television service to all residential dwelling units in existence as of September 1, 1991; 
(B)  Install and continue to provide cable television service to all residential dwelling units constructed after September 1, 1991, provided the development within which such residential dwelling units are located is developed at a density of not less than five dwelling units per acre; 
(C)  Upon request, install and continue to provide cable television service to nonresidential Subscribers provided the cost of installation does not exceed $600.00 per subscriber. The cost of installation limitation shall be adjusted every three years to reflect any change to the September 1, 1991 consumer price index; 
(D)  Relay to subscriber terminals those broadcast signals required by the Federal Communications Commission; 
(E)  Distribute in color all television signals which it receives in color; 
(F)  Make available upon request by any subscriber, a lockout device which prevents the unauthorized viewing of such channels; 
(G)  In accordance with applicable FCC rules or, in the absence of FCC rules, at a reasonable charge and in accordance with Grantee's reasonable safety standards, including prevention of connection of the System to ungrounded or improperly grounded antennas, make available to Subscribers, upon request, an RF switch (an A-B switch) permitting conversion from cable to antenna reception; 
(H)  Within four years from the date of this Franchise be rebuilt or upgraded to at least 400 MHz with at least 54 channels in accordance with the construction timetable provided for in § 116.29 hereof. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.22. - Override capability. 
    The Cable Television System shall include an "Emergency Alert Capability" which will permit the city, in times of emergency, to override by remote control the audio portion of all channels simultaneously. The Cable Television System shall include the ability to broadcast from City Hall. At such time as video override is technically and economically feasible, Grantee shall, within 12 months of its receipt of a request by the city, provide this service. Grantee shall be exempt from all responsibility for the operation of the emergency alert override. The city shall provide and maintain the audio override equipment at City Hall. If the city decide[s] to test such equipment, it shall first give Grantee at least three business days' notice so that Grantee can prepare for the test. The city agrees to test the emergency override System only and at such times during nonprime time hours as may be agreed to between city and Grantee, so that Subscribers will not be interrupted or inconvenienced by such test. The city shall indemnify and hold Grantee harmless from and against any cost, claim, loss or damage of whatever nature arises out of the use of the emergency override System. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.23. - Interconnection. 
    Grantee shall extend its Cable Television System to the appropriate city limit boundaries in order to interconnect the System with other Cable Systems serving the city and contiguous Greater Dayton area so as to enable each such System to carry and cablecast the public, educational, and government access programming carried on Grantee's System. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.24. - Service to schools and city-occupied buildings. 
    All public school Systems (grades K through 12) occupied and city-occupied buildings located in the city which are accessible or contiguous to the existing Cable System and require a normal installation shall be given, upon request, one free outlet and subscription to the System's lowest level of subscriber service. "Normal" installation means an aerial drop of up to 150 feet from Grantee's distribution System, or an underground drop of up to 100 feet from Grantee's distribution System. The Grantee will commit up to $50,000.00 to be used to fund the installation, material, labor and overhead necessary to construct cable plant or provide alternative equipment to those public buildings designated by the city that are not accessible or contiguous to the existing cable plant. Additional free outlets providing subscription to the System's lowest level of subscriber service for each facility shall be given upon request provided the wiring for each additional outlet is installed at no cost to the Grantee. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.25. - Subscriber services. 
(A)  Grantee will continue to offer the wide diversity of programming and information on its System as reflected in those services provided during the fourth quarter of 1989. Grantee reserved the right during the Franchise to add new services and to replace services and to otherwise modify its channel lineup, but it will maintain the mix, quality and level of service, and the broad categories of programming represented by its fourth quarter 1989 services. 
(B)  The Grantee shall make available such channels for commercial use and leased access as are required by applicable federal law. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.26. - Public, Educational and Governmental access (PEG). 
    In accordance with Section 611 of the Cable Act, Grantee will provide the following channels for public, educational and governmental ("PEG") access: 
(A)  Immediately upon the effective date of this Franchise, one channel for public access, one channel for educational access, and one channel for government access. 
(B)  Upon completion of the rebuild described in § 116.21(8) of this Franchise, one additional channel for each of public, educational and governmental access; provided, each additional channel in each category shall not be made available until the city can demonstrate a need. In the event the first additional PEG channel is not utilized within 24 months of the completion of the rebuild it will revert to the Grantee for its exclusive use. If the second additional PEG channel is not utilized by the 36th month it will revert to the Grantee for its exclusive use. If the third additional channel is not utilized by the 48th month it will revert to the Grantee for its exclusive use. Demonstrated need shall be established when an existing public, educational and governmental channel is programmed a minimum of eight hours a day with appropriate access programming. For purposes of the foregoing conditions and calculations, character generated programming and programming of a commercial nature shall not be considered as appropriate peg programming. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.27. - Public access equipment and facilities. 
    Grantee will pay Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton or such other public access television entity as designated by the city the following amounts for capital costs for public access facilities and equipment: 
(A)  To aid in the remodeling of the Access 30 facility, up to $250,000.00 during 1991; to the extent Access 30 has not requested monies totaling the full $250,000.00 by year end 1991, Grantee will pay Access 30 the remainder of the $250,000.00 by January 31, 1992. 
(B)  Between January 1, 1997 and January 31, 1997, $250,000.00. 
(C)  Between January 1, 2002 and January 31, 2002, $250,000.00. 
(D)  One hundred fifty thousand dollars per year during each year of the Franchise beginning September, 1991; the payments of $150,000.00 per year shall be made in 12 equal increments prior to the 10th day of each month. 
(E)  In the event Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton has not vacated the studio space it currently occupies in Grantee's building by September 30, 1991, Grantee may charge Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton a fair monthly rental for each month (prorated for any partial month) during which Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton continues to occupy such space after September 30, 1992. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.28. - Support for use of access. 
    Nothing contained in this ordinance shall be construed to require or limit the authority of the Grantee to make monetary payments in support of the use of public, educational and/or governmental access. Such payments are expressly not a requirement of the Franchise granted hereunder and shall in no event be considered a Franchise fee in the calculation of Franchise Fees pursuant to this ordinance. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.29. - Construction timetable. 
(A)  In September 1992, the Grantee shall submit a construction timetable for rebuilding and/or upgrading the Cable Television System serving the city to the capacity specified in § 116.21(H). Such rebuild/upgrade shall incorporate generally accepted technology for Systems of comparable size. The rebuild/upgrade shall commence no later than January 1993 and shall be completed by September 1995, subject to extension for good cause. 
(B)  The Grantee may, however, submit with its timetable a request that the commencement of the rebuild/upgrade be delayed. Such request shall evaluate the need and justification for rebuilding/upgrading the Cable System. Based on that report and any other material which it deems necessary and which it will provide to the Grantee, the city shall determine whether the System rebuild/upgrade is necessary at that time and is reasonable in light of the future cost of meting such needs and interests. The city may modify the rebuild/upgrade requirements or delay the commencement of construction for periods of not less than two years and not more than five years, if such rebuild/upgrade is not necessary at that time or does not meet the criteria established herein. 
(C)  The criteria the city shall use for making such a judgment on whether to permit a delay shall include, but not necessarily be limited to: 
(1)  The technical reliability of the cable television service, as determined by such standards as the number of System outages, the quality of the cable signal, and whether the Cable Television System can reasonably be expected to continue to provide reliable service for the period of the requested delay. 
(2)  Whether the System conforms to generally accepted technological standards for Systems of comparable size and will accommodate the future cable-related needs and interests of the community. 
(3)  Whether the System has the ability to accommodate, both in channel capacity and in technological performance, the current service developments in the market; 
(4)  Whether the rebuild/upgrade and the provision of such service would present a clear and convincingly unreasonable financial burden to either the Grantee and/or to the Subscribers and any other matters relevant to the financial feasibility and practicality of rebuild/upgrade. 
(D)  As a part of the review process for a requested delay the city may require the services of independent consultants to evaluate the condition of the System and any financial and other date pertinent to the rebuild/upgrade. Such consultants shall be mutually chosen by the city and Grantee, with the cost to be equally borne by the city and the Grantee. The city specifically retains the right to solely choose and employ such consultants and bear their cost when so chosen, and the Grantee shall cooperate in such consultants' evaluations. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.30. - Local business office. 
    The Grantee shall maintain its principal office within the corporate limits of the city. The office shall be open during normal business hours. Said office shall have a publicly listed telephone and shall be so operated that complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments may be received and processed with a minimum delay. Provisions shall also be made for telephonically receiving interruption service calls from Subscribers on a 24 hour basis. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.31. - Service maintenance standards. 
(A)  Grantee will maintain its Cable Television System in conformity with generally accepted standards for Systems of comparable size and age to the System serving the city. 
(B)  The Grantee shall render prompt and efficient service and repairs and shall voluntarily interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as is reasonably possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum use. 
(C)  Without additional charges to any subscriber, the Grantee shall maintain its facilities in good working order and repair. Any verbal, telephonic, or written complaint relating to the quality or continuity of service shall be attended to as soon as possible. In the event of an outage, if service is not restored as outlined in the NCTA Customer Service Standards, the subscriber shall be entitled upon request to a rebate of one-thirtieth of the monthly service fee for each day or part thereof until service is restored. In the event of an outage caused by an event of force majeure, the provisions of § 116.64 shall control. 
(D)  The Grantee shall maintain the existing System and any rebuilt System installed and operated pursuant to § 116.21(H), so that, at a minimum, it conforms with the following technical guidelines: 
(1)  C/N-36dB 
(2)  Gain vs. Freq. Single Channel-+/-2dB from 75 MHz to 5.0 MHz above lower boundaries frequency of the television channel 
(3)  Gain vs. Freq. Sys.-12 dB (overall) 
(4)  2nd Order Dist.-54 dBc 
(5)  Hum Mod.-less than five percent 
(6)  Carrier to Triple Beat-52 dB 
(7)  System Leakage- 
Up to 54 MHz,-15 microvolts/meter @ 100 ft. 
54 to 216 MHz,-20 microvolts/meter @ 10 ft. 
Above 216 MHz,-15 microvolts/meter @ 100 ft. 
(8)  Subscriber Isol.-18 dB 
(9)  Sys. Level Stab.-12 dB in a 24-hour period 
(10)  Min. Signal Level-0 dBmV 
(11)  Aural Carrier Level-12-17 dB below related visual signal carrier level 
(12)  Vis. Car. Freq.-1.25 MHz from lower boundaries +/-25åKHz (nonaeronautical channels) +1/-5KHz (aeronautical channels) +1/-250 KHz (converter output) 
(13)  Aur. Car. Freq.-4.5 MHz + 1 KHz from visual carrier 
(E)  The Grantee shall perform proof of performance tests from the System following the rebuild and at other times at least annually throughout the life of this Franchise. Tests shall be performed at the end of each trunk line and on each headend. These tests shall be completed within a 30 day time frame and a written report of the results shall be completed within seven days. Included in this report will be any corrective measures and the results of all retests made to the trunk, distribution System, or headend(s) that fail to meet the performance specifications outlined in subsection (D) of this section. The proof of performance report shall be kept on file and made available to the city upon request. 
(F)  The city retains the right to perform proof of performance tests for the System at any time upon reasonable notice to the Grantee, and the Grantee shall cooperate in such tests. The city shall bear the costs of performing such tests. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.32. - General indemnification. 
    The Grantee shall save and keep the city and its officials, agents and employees free and harmless from any loss, expense, or damage to person or property arising out of, or resulting from, the operation of the Cable System or any provision of the Franchise except any loss, expense or damage arising out of the sole negligence, gross negligence, willful misconduct or fraud of the city, its employees or agents. The Grantee shall, at its sole cost, defend and indemnify the city from any charges, claims, suits, causes of action, penalties, fines and costs (including, but not limited to, reasonable legal fees and court costs) caused by, or arising out of this Franchise or the construction, operation or maintenance of the Cable System pursuant thereto, provided, however, the Grantee shall have no obligation to pay damages, penalties or fines which are levied on the city as a result of the sole negligence, gross negligence, willful misconduct, or fraud of its officials, employees or agents. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.33. - Liability insurance. 
    The Grantee shall obtain within 30 days prior to the effective date of this Franchise, and specifically agrees to maintain throughout the term of this Franchise, liability insurance insuring the city and the Grantee with regard to all damages and penalties mentioned in § 116.32 in the minimum amounts of: 
(A)  One million dollars for bodily injury or death to any one person, with the limit of $2,000,000.00 for bodily injury or death resulting from any one accident. 
(B)  Two million dollars for property damage resulting from any one accident. 
(C)  From time to time, but not more often than every five years, this insurance coverage shall be increased or decreased to ensure that adequate coverage is purchased to reflect the effects of inflation and the likelihood damage awards; provided that any such increase shall not exceed CPI. 
(D)  Copies of current possibilities of insurance shall be promptly provided to the city. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.34. - Performance bond. 
    The Grantee shall establish and maintain throughout the term hereof the following bonds: 
(A)  During rebuild/upgrade construction (i.e., from the date of commencement of construction through the proof of performance test following construction), a labor and material bond in the sum of at least 25 percent of the anticipated cost of construction which shall be used to insure the satisfactory completion of construction. Upon completion of the rebuild to 400 MHz, Grantee shall be relieved of this requirement. 
(B)  A faithful performance bond running to the city in the sum of $100,000.00 conditioned upon the faithful performance by the Grantee of all terms and conditions of this Franchise and upon the further condition that, in the event the Grantee fails to comply with any law, ordinance, rule or regulation governing this Franchise, there shall be recoverable, jointly and severally, from the principal and surety of the bond, any damage or loss suffered by the city as a result of such failure, plus costs and reasonable attorney's fees up to the full amount of the bond. 
(C)  For any period of time other than rebuild construction, an annual blanket in the amount of $25,000.00. Such blanket bond is to cover any excavation or cutting into by the Grantee in any street right-of-way area in the city for that calendar year. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.35. - Proof of insurance and bonding. 
    Within 30 days of the effective date of this Franchise, the Grantee shall furnish proof to the city that a satisfactory insurance policy and performance bond shall be approved by the city, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. A certificate of insurance evidencing the required insurance coverage, and a copy of the performance bond along with written evidence of payment of the required premiums, shall be filed and maintained with the city. The insurance policy and bond shall specify that at least 30 days prior written notice shall be filed with the city of any intention not to renew, to cancel, or to make a material change therein. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.36. - Liquidated damages. 
    By acceptance of a Franchise granted hereunder, the Grantee understands and agrees that failure to comply with any time and performance requirements, as stipulated in this chapter will result in damage to the city, and that it is and will be impracticable to determine the actual amount of such damage in the event of delay or nonperformance. The Grantee therefore agrees that it shall pay to the city the following amounts as liquidated damages: 
(A)  Failure to complete the rebuilding of the Cable System as set forth in §§ 116.21(E) $200.00 per day or part thereof. In addition to the liquidated damages, the Franchise term shall be reduce one month for each month that the Grantee defaults in the completion of construction of a rebuilt Cable System as herein provided. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.37. - Reports. 
(A)  Upon request, the Grantee shall file with the city true and accurate plant maps of the System to be constructed, rebuilt and/or upgraded hereunder and shall keep the same as current practicable. 
(B)  The Grantee shall upon request make available to the city for inspection any forms, reports, or other filings it has made with the DCC during the two year period prior to such request. 
(C)  Upon reasonable notice, the Grantee shall appear at any meetings or public hearings called by the city to review or evaluate the Grantee's activities or performance. 
(D)  All complaints, petitions, or orders received by the city related to the Grantee's activities hereunder shall be forwarded to the Grantee and answered by it with a copy to the original addressee within 20 days of receipt. 
(E)  Within 90 days of the end of each fiscal year, the Grantee shall file with the city: 
(1)  The current list of names and business addresses of the Grantee's principal management personnel; and 
(2)  The current list of all Persons owning a three percent or greater ownership interest in Grantee. 
(3)  The 10K financial report of Viacom International Inc. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.38. - City approval required for assignment or transfer of Franchise and for certain transactions affecting Grantee's ownership. 
    City approval, pursuant to the provisions of § 116.39, shall be required prior to: 
(A)  The assignment or transfer of this Franchise; 
(B)  The issuance by the Grantee of more than 20 percent of its voting stock to any person or group of Persons; 
(C)  The transfer by the Grantee of more than 20 percent of the Grantee's outstanding stock to any other person or group of Persons; 
(D)  Any judicial action or proceeding resulting in the transfer of more than 20 percent of the voting stock of the Grantee; 
(E)  Any other transfer of stock or ownership interest which results in a change in de jure or de facto control of the Grantee. 
(F)  The transfer, sale or assignment of the Cable System. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.39. - Procedure for city approval of transfers. 
    The following procedure shall be followed in the city's consideration of the transaction described in § 116.38: 
(A)  Applications for the city 's approval shall be made when possible at least 90 days prior to the effective date of said transaction and shall contain such information and supporting documentation as would be reasonably necessary for the city 's consideration based on the criteria specified in subsection (C) below; 
(B)  Within 90 days of receipt of an application pursuant to subsection (A) above, and following a property noticed public hearing affording due process, the city shall, by a written resolution, issue its approval or disapproval of the proposed transaction, stating therein the basis of its decision; 
(C)  The city's approval or disapproval of the requested transaction shall be based on a determination of whether or not the proposed transferee possesses the character, legal, financial, and technical qualifications then required by federal, state, or local law to operate a Cable Television System and the proposed transferee's ability and commitment to assume all of the obligations of this Franchise. The city's approval of said transaction shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.40. - Rights of assignment and transfer to and by mortgages or pledges. 
    Nothing in § 116.38 shall in any way limit the Grantee's parent's right to pledge, mortgage, or hypothecate its interest in Grantee or Grantee's right to similarly encumber its assets to a recognized financial institution to secure borrowed funds or said institution's right to foreclose on, hold, sell, assign or transfer such interests. Provided, however, that such mortgagee, pledgee, or its transferee shall be subject to all of the terms of this chapter, and provided further that six months after the date of foreclosure by any mortgagee or pledgee, said party or its transferee shall have been reviewed and approved by the city pursuant to the procedures enumerated in § 116.39. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.41. - Notification of city in the event of certain transactions indirectly affecting control of Grantee. 
    The stockholders of Grantee shall notify the city of any transaction which results in a transfer or assignment of more than 20 percent of the voting stock of their respective corporations. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.42. - Events constituting grounds for revocation. 
    Subject to § 116.43, the city reserved the right to decide that this Franchise and all rights and privileges of the Grantee hereunder should be revoked in the event that the Grantee: 
(A)  Fails to complete construction, rebuild and/or upgrade as specified herein; 
(B)  Breaches or violates any material provision of this ordinance; 
(C)  Practices fraud or deception upon the city or upon Subscribers which actions may include any attempt to purposefully evade or avoid any of the provisions of this Franchise, provided however, nothing herein shall make any subscriber a third party beneficiary of this Franchise, or give any subscriber the right to sue to enforce the provisions hereof; 
(D)  Is adjudged bankrupt, has a receiver appointed for it, makes an assignment for the benefit of creditors, or has a significant amount of its property sold under the execution or other legal process or seized by creditors; or 
(E)  Is in default in the making of payments under this chapter. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.43. - Notice, time to correct and due process required in revocation. 
    In the event the city believes there is a reasonable probability that grounds for revocation of this Franchise exist, the city shall notify the Grantee in writing, setting forth the nature and facts relating to the grounds for such revocation. Within 30 days following such written notice, the Grantee may furnish evidence reasonably satisfactory to the city that corrective action has been taken or is being actively or expeditiously pursued, or that the alleged violations did not occur, or that the alleged violations were beyond the Grantee's control. If the Grantee does not do so or if the city is not satisfied with such response, the city shall establish a date, time and place for the conduct of a public hearing on the grounds for revocation, with the date of said public hearing no sooner than 30 days or not later than 60 days following the expiration of such 30-day period. Based on the testimony at the public hearing, the city shall establish findings and may revoke the Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.44. - Removal of facilities in the event of revocation. 
    In the event that the city decides this Franchise should be revoked, the city may require the Grantee to continue operating for a period not to exceed 12 months from the date of the city's decision. In the event of said revocation, the Grantee shall have two years from the date on which it ceases operations to remove, at its own expense, all portions of its System from all streets within the city and to restore said streets to a condition reasonably satisfactory to the city or Grantee shall have the right to dispose of the Cable System to a third party at fair market value. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.45. - Discriminatory practices prohibited. 
    The Grantee shall not deny service or access, or otherwise discriminate against its Subscribers, users, or employees on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, or sex. The Grantee shall strictly adhere to the equal employment opportunity requirements of Section 634 of the Cable Act, and other applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.46. - Cable tapping and monitoring prohibited without permission of subscriber. 
    In order to protect the privacy of the Subscribers to the Grantee's System, the Grantee shall comply with the requirements of Section 631 of the Cable Act, and other applicable state and federal requirements. 
    Neither the Grantee nor the city shall tap and/or monitor or arrange for the tapping and/or monitoring permit, either expressly or impliedly, any other person to tap and/or monitor any cable, line, signal input device, or subscriber outlet or receiver for any purpose whatsoever, without the express permission of the subscriber. Notwithstanding the preceding sentences, the Grantee shall be entitled to conduct a System-wide or an individually addressed Systems audit or the purpose of verifying System integrity, controlling return path transmissions, investigating theft of service, or verifying billing for cable services. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.47. - Privacy. 
    Grantee's policy with regard to personally identifiable subscriber information shall be consistent with federal law. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.48. - Censorship prohibited on access channels. 
    The Grantee shall exercise no control over program content on any of the Access Channels. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.49. - Liability for obscenity, defamation, or invasion of privacy on access channels. 
    Liability for obscenity, defamation, or invasion of privacy on any Access Channel shall rest with the Person or groups of Persons utilizing said Access Channels. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.50. - Resolution of disputes. 
    In order to provide for the orderly resolution of any controversy or dispute between the city and the Grantee arising out of the enforcement or interpretation of this Franchise or any rule, regulation, or procedure relating to cable communication matters, fact finding, mediation and arbitration shall be the preferred means of resolving such controversies or disputes where both parties consent to such resolution. None of these methods, however, shall be the first resort of the parties, but shall be undertaken only after a reasonable time, not to exceed 30 days, has been expended in good faith negotiation. If both parties mutually [agree], fact finding and/or mediation may be waived. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.51. - Fact finding. 
    Any controversy or dispute, upon the consent of both the city and the Grantee, shall be submitted to an expert individual, acceptable to the parties, for an investigation of the facts and a report thereof. Such fact finding shall be for the purpose of developing better information for the use of both parties and shall not be binding. The fact finder's investigation and report shall be delivered not more than 30 days after submission of the dispute to the fact finder. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.52. - Mediation. 
    Any controversy or dispute, upon the consent of both the Grantee and the city, shall be submitted to an expert individual, acceptable to the parties, for the purpose of facilitating discussion and receiving new perspectives on the issues and new proposals for compromise. Such mediation shall not be binding. Any such mediation shall be conducted for a period not to exceed 30 days after the mediator is chosen. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.53. - Arbitration. 
    Any controversy or dispute, upon the consent of both the Grantee and the city, may be submitted to nonbinding arbitration in accordance with the guidelines established by the American Arbitration Association. If both parties so agree at the commencement of arbitration, any decision reached shall be binding on both parties, and shall be subject to confirmation, vacation, modification or correction in accordance with Chapter 2711 of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.54. - Selection procedures. 
    In fact finding or mediation, the parties shall, within ten days after any party elects either such process, each present a maximum of three names for possible service as the expert. If there is no agreement on any of the names, the American Arbitration Association shall, within ten days after the request of the parties, select a person to fulfill the function of expert. In arbitration, the parties shall select an arbitrator according to the procedures of the American Arbitration Association. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.55. - Fees and expenses. 
    The expense of nonbinding arbitration, fact finding and mediation (other than the fees of the experts, which shall be borne by the party calling each expert) shall be borne equally by the parties. In binding arbitration, the cost of expert witnesses selected by an individual party shall be borne by that party, but all other expenses shall be borne equally by the city and the Grantee. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.56. - Acquisition of the Cable System. 
    Pursuant to Sections 151 and 152 of the Charter of the City of Dayton, the Grantor reserves the right to acquire the Cable System after the expiration of the term for which this Franchise is granted or, the revocation or cancellation of the Franchise for cause as provided herein. In either event such purchase option must be exercised by written notice to Grantee stating the Grantor's intention to purchase at least 42 months before the expiration of the term or not more than 60 days after revocation or cancellation of the Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.57. - Acquisition price of the Cable System. 
    The purchase price shall be determined as follows: 
(A)  In case of purchase as provided for herein, the purchase price shall be the System's fair market value as a going business with no value allocated to the Franchise itself as determined by appraisals and negotiations by the parties. If the parties cannot agree on the price within 120 days, after the delivery of the aforesaid written notice then it shall be determined by a panel of three arbitrators, one to be selected by the Grantor, one to be selected by the Grantee and one to be selected by the two thus chosen, or if they do not agree, the third shall be designated by the American Arbitration Association. The panel shall be governed by the rules of the Association and shall be instructed to make its determination of the System's fair market value as a going business with no value allocated to that Franchise itself within six months form the date of the Grantor's notice of exercise. 
(B)  Within 90 days of the final determination of the purchase price provided for herein, Grantor shall elect either to purchase or not to purchase at that price and shall give official notice to Grantee of its election. In the event Grantor elects to conclude the purchase, the Grantee shall immediately and concurrent with the payment to Grantee of the purchase price transfer to the Grantor possession and title to all facilities and property, real and personal, of the cable television System, free from any and all liens and encumbrances not agreed to be assumed by the Grantor in lieu of some portion of the purchase price set forth above. The Grantee shall execute such warranty deeds or other instruments of conveyance to the Grantor as shall be necessary for this purpose. The Grantee shall make it a condition of each contract entered into by it with reference to its operations under this Franchise that the contract shall be subject to exercise of the options herein provided for by the Grantor and that the Grantor shall have the right to succeed to all privileges and obligations thereof on the exercise of such option. 
(C)  If the Grantor fails to make either election, the Grantor's offer to purchase is terminated. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.58. - Powers of court to enforce compliance with Franchise. 
    Nothing in this Franchise shall be construed to prevent any party hereto from pursuing its full legal rights, including, without limitation, seeking relief from a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the rights created by this Franchise, or to contest an adverse decision or action by the other party (including revocation of the Franchise or imposition of monetary penalties). 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.59. - Nonenforcement; waiver. 
    Neither the Grantee nor the city shall be relieved of its obligation to comply with the provisions of this Franchise by reason of any failure of the other party to enforce prompt compliance, nor shall any inaction by the Grantee or the city be deemed to waive or void any provision of this Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.60. - Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. 
    During the terms of this Franchise, and subject to the conflict of laws provisions of § 116.61, the Grantee shall comply with all present and future applicable laws, rules and regulations, and any amendments thereto, promulgated by and federal, state, or local authority of competent jurisdiction, including but not limited to the laws, rules, and regulations of the FCC and, to the extent of its lawful exercise of police power to protect the health and welfare of its citizens, the city. Nothing in the Franchise shall be deemed to waive the requirements of the other codes and ordinances of the city including those regarding permits, fees to be paid or manner of construction. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.61. - Conflict with state or federal laws. 
    The Franchise granted herein shall be consistent with federal laws and regulations and state general laws and regulations. In the event of a conflict between the terms and conditions of this Franchise and applicable state or federal laws and regulations, the applicable state or federal laws and regulations shall, without exception, control. Provided, however, if any such state or federal law or regulation shall require the Grantee to perform any service, or shall permit the Grantee to perform any service, or shall prohibit the Grantee from performing any service, in conflict with the terms of the Franchise or any law or regulation of the city, then as soon as possible following knowledge thereof, the Grantee shall notify the city of the point of conflict believed to exist between such regulation or law and the laws or regulations of the city or the Franchise. In the event state or federal law is amended and such amendment requires the modification of this agreement, the city and Grantee shall where the applicable state or federal law requires, modify this agreement within one year of the state and/or federal amendment. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.62. - Separability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court or agency of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision an such holdings shall not affect the continued effectiveness or validity of the remaining portions. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.63. - Delegation of functions. 
    The city may delegate any of its functions, or responsibilities, pursuant to the Ordinance, to a board, commission or officer. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.64. - Notice. 
    Whenever, under the terms of the Franchise, a provision is made for notice of any kind, it shall be sufficient if such notice is in writing, addressed to the appropriate party at the current address and sent by registered or certified mail with postage prepaid, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.65. - Modifications. 
(A)  Modifications to this Franchise may be initiated by the Grantee in accordance with Section 625 of the Cable Act. 
(B)  In the event state or federal law is amended and such amendment would permit either the city or the Grantee to initiate a modification to this Franchise, both parties to this Franchise shall within one year review such amendment for the purpose of determining whether or not modifications shall be made to the Franchise. The appropriate documents shall be executed by both parties which acknowledge this review. 
(C)  In the event the city and the Grantee cannot agree with respect to modifications as may be permitted in an amendment to state or federal law said disagreement shall be resolved as provided for in §§ 116.50 through 116.55 of this Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.66. - Force majeure. 
    Prevention or delay of any performance under this Franchise due to circumstances beyond the control of the Grantee or the city including weather, acts of God, strikes and similar unforeseen circumstances but not including economic hardship shall not be deemed to be noncompliance with or a violation of this Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.67. - Rate regulation. 
    In the event Federal Law is amended to allow rate regulations, the city specifically retains the right to exercise such rights to regulate rates or other activities of the Grantee as may be permitted by state or federal law, existing or as amended, added or modified during the duration of the Franchise. 
(Ord. 28338, passed 7-24-91) 
Secs. 116.68-116.79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 1. - DAYTON PUBLIC ACCESS TELEVISION, INC. 

Sec. 116.80. - Support. 
    The City of Dayton will continue to provide the two percent of the five percent Franchise fee to Dayton Public Access Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton. (40 percent of the Franchise fee payments received by the City of Dayton.) 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.81. - Services. 
    Because the City of Dayton desires to continue to support Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton for so long as it continues to promote public access effectively, it will provide that support for so long as Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton provides at least the services or their equivalent as provided for herein for the residents of Dayton. In consideration for the Franchise fee and support payments Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton shall provide at least the following services for the public and the City of Dayton: 
(A)  Basic Port-a-pak training classes will be offered a minimum of 32 times each year for up to a total of 200 Persons. 
(B)  Basic studio training classes will be offered eight times each year for up to a total of 70 Persons. 
(C)  Basic Technical Director training classes will be offered six times each year for up to a total of 15 Persons. 
(D)  Basic Directing training classes will be offered six times each year for up to a total of 15 Persons. 
(E)  Basic Audio training classes will be offered six times each year for up to a total of 15 person. 
(F)  Edit training for the public will be provided on an as needed basis for up to a total of 100 Persons. 
(G)  Basic graphics classes will be offered for up to 12 times each year for up to a total of 48 Persons. 
(H)  Training for the public will be offered for up to 50 Persons per year as master control operators. 
(I)  Produce the City of Dayton's regularly scheduled weekly City Commission meetings. 
(J)  Provide video tape or live coverage of up to 12 per year of City of Dayton sponsored events. 
(K)  Assist the City of Dayton with specifications for video equipment and facilities. 
(L)  Conduct for the City of Dayton up to six basic Port-a-pak training classes per year with up to six Persons per class. 
(M)  Provide to the City of Dayton up to 24 hours per year of technical assistance. 
    Nothing in this paragraph shall be interpreted to require Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton, as a condition of receiving payments from the city, to undertake any activity which would require it to construct or pay for capital facilities or equipment, require it to incur any extraordinary operating expense, or to act in any way which would endanger its status as a not for profit 501(c)(3) corporation. Further, nothing shall require Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton to produce a live remote production except in cases where Viacom (pursuant to the Franchise or its contract with Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton) is willing to provide a return path at no charge. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.82. - Representation. 
    The Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton Board of Directors shall be residents of the City of Dayton and consist of a cross representation of the residents of the City of Dayton. The Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton Board of Directors shall determine its size and composition, provided however, the City of Dayton shall be represented on the Board by a member of the City Commission and the Cable Administrator shall be a nonvoting ex-officio member of the board. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.83. - Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton employees.
