    All employees of Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton hired after the effective date of this Agreement must and shall be actual residents of and physically live in the City of Dayton at the time of their appointment, and shall continue to be actual residents and physically live in the City of Dayton during the term of their employment. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.84. - Cancellation. 
(A)  In the event the cable television Franchise between the Grantee, Viacom, their successors or assigns and the City of Dayton is terminated as provided for in the Franchise, this Agreement shall be terminated simultaneously. 
(B)  This Agreement may be terminated for good cause, including any substantial default in compliance with the terms and conditions of this Agreement by either party, provided, however, that notice is given of intent to terminate at least 180 days prior to the effective date of said termination. Notice of termination shall be in writing, addressed to the appropriate party at the current address and sent by registered or certified mail with postage prepaid, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.85. - Modifications. 
    In the event state or federal law is amended and such amendments would permit either the City of Dayton or Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton to initiate a modification to this Agreement, both parties to this Agreement shall within one year review such amendment for the purpose of determining whether or not modifications shall be made to this Agreement. The appropriate documents shall be executed by both parties which acknowledge this review. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.86. - Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. 
    During the term of this Agreement, Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton shall comply with all present and future applicable laws, rules and regulations, and any amendments thereto, promulgated by any federal, state, or local authority of competent jurisdiction, including but not limited to the laws, rules and regulations of the FCC and, to the extent of its lawful exercise of police power to protect the health and welfare of its citizens, the city. Nothing in the Agreement shall be deemed to waive the requirements of the other codes and ordinances of the city including those regarding permits, fees to be paid or manner of construction. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Sec. 116.87. - Conflict with state or federal laws. 
    This Agreement shall be consistent with federal laws and regulations and state general laws and regulations. In the event of a conflict between the terms and conditions of this Agreement and applicable state or federal laws and regulations, the applicable state or federal laws and regulations shall, without exception, control. Provided, however, if any such state or federal law or regulation shall require Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton to perform any service, or shall permit Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton to perform any service, or shall prohibit Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton from performing any service, in conflict with the terms of the cable television Franchise or any law or regulation of the city, then as soon as possible following knowledge thereof, Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton shall notify the city of the point of conflict believed to exist between such regulation or law and the laws or regulations of the city or the Franchise. In the event state or federal law is amended and such amendment requires the modification of this Agreement, the city and Dayton Public Television, Inc. aka Access 30 Dayton shall where the applicable state or federal law requires, modify this agreement within one year of the state and/or federal amendment. 
(Ord. 28339, passed 7-24-91) 
Secs. 116.88-116.99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BASIC CABLE SERVICE AND EQUIPMENT RATES 

Sec. 116.100. - Scope; application. 
    This [division] governs the regulation of rates for basic cable service and equipment within the city for any Franchisee which has been notified that the city has been certified to regulate its basic service and equipment rates; and the city has adopted regulations governing regulation of basic service and equipment rates. The provisions set forth below constitute those regulations and are intended to be consistent with all Federal Communications Commission (FCC) regulations governing the regulation of basic service rates and equipment, and the city will interpret the provisions so that they are consistent with FCC regulations, as if those regulations were set forth in full herein. The Franchisee is prohibited under this chapter from engaging in any activity which is prohibited under FCC rules, as if those rules were set forth in full herein. For purposes of these provisions, the terms "basic service" or basic cable service" has the same meaning as the term "basic service" at 47 C.F.R. § 76.901, and the term "equipment" refers to all equipment and services subject to regulation under 47 C.F.R. § 76.923. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.101. - Initial filings by Franchisees. 
(A)  Filings; when made. Upon receiving notification from the city that its basic service and equipment rates are subject to regulation, the Franchisee must make a rate filing within 30 days of the notification, (but is not required to make a filing earlier than November 15, 1993) explaining its then-existing basic service and equipment rates for all rates in all customer classifications. Once a Franchisee has been so notified, it may not thereafter increase its rates for basic service and equipment without the prior approval of the city. This requirement applies in all cases, including rate increases which are announced, but not implemented, prior to the date the Franchisee was notified that its rates were subject to regulation. An "increase" occurs when there is an increase in rates or a decrease in programming or customer services. Rate filings proposing rate increases must be filed for review at least 30 days in advance of the proposed effective date of the increase. A rate filing shall be considered filed for review on the date the rate filing and all required copies are received by the cable administrator. Seven copies of each rate filing (including all supporting materials) must be submitted. This filing requirement does not alter or eliminate any other notice requirement. 
(B)  Filing; where made. Every rate filing must be submitted to the Cable Administrator. 
(C)  Filing; contents. Subject to any FCC regulations governing the burden of proof, a rate filing submitted by a Franchisee must show that the rates the Franchisee proposes to charge for basic service and equipment are reasonable. Except as inconsistent with FCC rules: 
(1)  The rate filing must contain all applicable FCC forms and these forms must be correctly completed. The pages of each rate filing must be numbered sequentially. 
(2)  Every rate filing must be accompanied by a cover letter which states whether the filing explains existing rates or proposes a rate increase. The cover letter must also identify any rate that is based, in whole or in part, upon cost of service as set forth in subsection (C)(4) of this section, and identify any pages of the rate filing that contain information that the Franchisee claims is proprietary. If an increase is sought, the cover letter must state whether any part of the proposed increase is based on an inflation adjustment or an increase in external costs. The cover letter should also contain a brief, narrative description of any proposed changes in rates or services. 
(3)  If different rates for basic service or equipment are proposed for different classes of customers, the filing must show that the classifications and the differences in the rate charged are reasonable and consistent with federal law. 
(4)  In addition to other information the city requires the Franchisee to provide, and unless the city grants a waiver of this provision, a Franchisee that seeks to explain all or any part of its rates based upon its cost of service must to the extent the requirement is consistent with FCC regulations: 
(a)  Submit a complete cost of service analysis that shows all expenses it incurs, and all revenues derived from operating the System, directly or indirectly, by the Franchisee or any person that constitutes a cable operator of the System within the meaning of 47 U.S.C. § 522(4). The cost of service must identify the accounting level (as that term is used in 47 C.F.R. § 76.924(d)) at which each expense or revenue item identified was aggregated and also must clearly show how the expense or revenue was allocated. The Franchisee may not include costs at an accounting level unless it also includes all revenues from that same level attributable to the System or to a group of Systems of which the System serving the city is a part. 
(b)  Identify the name and address of any entity with which it has a contract, other than a programmer, which derives revenues from the System, and must state whether and how the revenues of that entity were included in the cost of service. In addition, the cost of service shall clearly show the derivation of a proposed charge per channel and the application of that charge to yield a basic service rate. 
(c)  Show and support the derivation and allocation of any amounts included in the rate for: 
1.  Operation and maintenance expenses; 
2.  Administrative and general expenses; 
3.  Programming expenses (identifying retransmission consent costs and copyright fees separately); 
4.  Costs for PEG access and any institutional network; 
5.  Franchise fee expenses; 
6.  Investment in the System and associated depreciation; 
7.  Other expenses, including federal, state and local taxes, itemized; and 
8.  The proposed return on equity and actual interest expense paid by the Franchisee. 
(d)  The replacement cost of a comparable System must be identified and supported. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Franchisee is not required to include equipment rates in the cost of service analysis specified in subsection (C)(4) of this section, and instead shall initially complete, submit and support the costs of equipment using applicable FCC forms. Any cost of service analysis submitted to explain basic service rates must show that the cost of service does not include equipment costs. 
(D)  Initial city review. 
(1)  After receiving a rate filing, the Cable Administrator shall promptly publish a notice that a filing has been received and that, except for those parts which may be withheld as proprietary in accordance with § 116.108, it is available for public review. The notice shall state that interested parties may comment on the filing, and shall provide interested parties seven days to submit written comments on the filing to the Cable Administrator. The Cable Administrator shall submit the comments received and its recommendations for action to the City Commission and shall make those recommendations available for public inspection. The Franchisee may submit a response to public comments or staff recommendations, but must do so no later than three business days after the staff recommendations are submitted to the City Commission. The response shall be filed with the Cable Administrator, and if submitted in a timely fashion, the Cable Administrator shall forward a copy to the City Commission. 
(2)  Within 30 days of the date of the filing, the City Commission shall issue a written order ("rate order"), which may be in any lawful form, approving the proposed rate in whole or in part; denying the proposed rate in whole or in part; or tolling the proposed rate in whole or in part. If the City Commission tolls the rate in whole or in part, its rate order shall explain that it requires additional time to review the rate filing, identify generally any then-known deficiencies in the Franchisee's filing, and state that the Franchisee may cure any deficiency in its filing by submitting a supplementary filing as provided in § 116.102. With respect to existing rates, tolling means the rates may remain in effect, subject to refund; with respect to proposed rate changes, tolling means the portion of the proposed rate change that is tolled may not go into effect. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.102. - Supplementary filings. 
(A)  If a proposed rate is tolled in whole or in part, the Franchisee shall submit a supplementary filing to the Cable Administrator within 20 days from the date the tolling order issues. A supplementary filing must contain corrections, if any, to its filing (including any required supplement to its cost of service filing); any responses to information filed by interested parties; a response to the recommendations of the staff; or any additional information necessary to support the proposed rate. A supplementary filing also must contain such information as the city directs the Franchisee to provide. 
(B)  Unless the city grants a waiver of this provision, a Franchisee who claims that it is entitled to a rate increase based in whole or in part upon the adjustments for inflation and external costs contemplated by 47 C.F.R. § 76.922(d)(1)-(2) must submit the following: 
(1)  A calculation showing how each part of the inflation adjustment was derived. 
(2)  A statement itemizing: 
(a)  Each external cost element (as defined by FCC regulations); 
(b)  The dollar amount of those external cost elements for the two calendar years prior to the date of the filing and the year in which the filing is made; and 
(c)  The projected dollar amount of the external cost elements for the remainder of the year in which the filing is made, and for the following calendar year; and 
(d)  Any increases in revenues, in whatever form, from programming services. 
(3)  If the increase is attributable to any increases in programming service cost: 
(a)  The contract for each programming service whose cost has increased; 
(b)  A sworn statement identifying each programming service whose costs increased, if the programmer is an affiliate of the Franchisee (as defined by FCC regulations); and 
(c)  For any contract that has been in effect less than 12 months, the prior contract for the service. 
(4)  A sworn statement by the Franchisee's chief financial officer or an independent, certified public accountant affirming that: 
(a)  He or she has examined all external costs (including all programming costs) and has offset against any increase claimed, the amount of any decreases in external costs, and the amount by which any increase in external costs was below the GNP-P1, as required by 47 C.F.R. § 76.922(d)(2); 
(b)  The Franchisee has sought to recover only any external cost to the extent that it exceeded the GNP-P1; and 
(c)  The Franchisee has not attempted to recover any increase in the cost of programming purchased by an affiliate except as provided in 47 C.F.R. 576.922(d)(2)(vi). 
(C)  Upon receiving the supplementary filing, the Cable Administrator shall promptly publish a notice that a filing has been received and that it is available for public review (except those parts which may be withheld as proprietary as defined in § 116.108). The notice shall state that interested parties may comment on the filing, and shall provide interested parties 20 days to submit written comments on the filing to the Cable Administrator. The Cable Administrator shall submit the comments received and its recommendations for action to the City Commission. The recommendations shall be made available for public inspection. The Franchisee may submit a response to public comments or staff recommendations, but must do so no later than ten days after the staff recommendations are submitted to the City Commission. The response shall be filed with the Cable Administrator, and if submitted in a timely fashion, the Cable Administrator shall forward a copy to the City Commission. 
(D)  The city shall issue a written order ("rate order"), which may be in any lawful form, approving the proposed rate in whole or in part; denying the proposed rate in whole or in part; or allowing the rate to go into effect in whole or in part, subject to refund. If the City Commission issues an order allowing the rates to go into effect subject to refund, it shall also direct the Franchisee to maintain an accounting in accordance with 47 C.F.R. § 76.933. A rate order shall be issued 90 days after the tolling order for any rate the Franchisee justifies based on the FCC benchmark. The rate order shall be issued within 150 days of the tolling order for any rate the Franchisee justifies with a cost of service showing. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.103. - Provisions generally applicable to rate orders. 
(A)  Any rate order of the City Commission shall be effective upon adoption. Each rate order shall be released to the public and the Franchisee. In any case where the City Commission approves, denies, or tolls a rate, orders that a rate may go into effect subject to refund, orders refunds, or establishes rates, a public notice shall be published stating that the rate order has been issued and is available for review. Any such rate order shall be in writing. 
(B)  The City Commission may take any action as part of any rate order or by any other means that it is not prohibited by federal law from taking to protect the public interest. Such action may include prescribing rates, requiring and/or enforcing refunds, imposing forfeitures and penalties directly or through the city's delegated representatives, or any other such action to protect the public interest. If the Franchisee seeks to support a rate based upon cost of service, the city will establish a rate that provides the Franchisee an opportunity to recover the reasonable costs associated with providing basic cable service, including a reasonable profit. An expense or investment is not presumed reasonable merely because the Franchisee has incurred or made it. A Franchisee is not entitled to recover monopoly rents in any form. Any order prescribing a rate must explain why the Franchisee's proposed rate was unreasonable, and why the prescribed rate is reasonable. However, before prescribing a rate or ordering a refund to Subscribers, the City Commission shall ensure that the Franchisee has had notice and opportunity to comment on the proposed rate or refunds. If the recommendations of the Cable Administrator propose a refund or a rate, then mailing a copy of the recommendation to the Franchisee at the time it is submitted to the City Commission shall be deemed to provide the Franchisee this notice, and the Franchisee must comment on the refund or rate in its response to the recommendations. 
(C)  No order approving or setting a rate using the FCC benchmarks shall be interpreted to establish a just and reasonable rate to Subscribers. Every such rate approved or established shall be subject to further reduction and refund to the extent permitted under applicable laws and regulations, as the same may be amended from time to time. By way of illustration and not limitation, should the FCC reduce the benchmarks, the city shall have the right to reduce a Franchisee's rates and to require the Franchisee to refund any amounts collected above the benchmark, except to the extent prohibited by federal law. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.104. - Franchisees' duties. 
(A)  A Franchisee must implement remedial requirements, including, but not limited to, implementing prospective rate reductions and refunds within 60 days of the date the City Commission issues an order mandating a remedy. 
(B)  Within 90 days of the date an order mandating a remedy is issued, a Franchisee must file a certification, signed by an authorized representative of the cable company stating: 
(1)  Whether the Franchisee has complied fully with all provisions of the City Commission's order; 
(2)  Describing in detail the precise measures taken to implement the City Commission's order; and 
(3)  Showing how refunds (including interest) were calculated and distributed. 
(C)  A Franchisee must keep books and records of account so that it is able to refund any amounts owed to Subscribers. 
(D)  It shall be a violation of this division for a Franchisee to knowingly withhold information or make an incomplete filing under applicable law. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.105. - Information requests. 
(A)  A Franchisee and any other entity that has records of revenues or expenses that are allocated to the Franchisee's System must respond to requests for information from the city within the deadlines established by the city. A Franchisee is responsible for ensuring that such other entity responds to the city's request. 
(B)  Because federal law limits the time available for an initial response to a filing by a Franchisee, the Franchisee must be prepared to respond to requests for information regarding its filing within five days of the date an information request is mailed to it. The information may include the information the Franchisee would be required to provide as part of any supplementary filing. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.106. - Duties of cable administrator. 
(A)  The City Manager may designate a person or department to serve as a Cable Administrator who shall be responsible for administrating the provisions herein. Without limitation and by way of illustration: 
(1)  The Cable Administrator shall ensure that notices are given to the public and each Franchisee, as required herein and by FCC regulations. 
(2)  The Cable Administrator may submit requests for information to the Franchisee and establish deadlines for response to them, as provided in §§ 116.104 and 116.105. 
(3)  The Cable Administrator may, for good cause, waive any provision herein, or extend any deadline for filings or responses, except as to such matters that are mandatory under FCC regulations. 
(4)  The Cable Administrator shall rule whether information so claimed is proprietary. 
(B)  The Cable Administrator shall prepare the recommendations to the City Commission contemplated by §§ 116.101(D) and 116.102(C). If the Cable Administrator recommends that any increase be denied in whole or in part, it shall: 
(1)  Propose a new rate, or propose that rates remain at existing levels, and explain the basis for its recommendation; 
(2)  Recommend whether, and on what basis, refunds should be issued; and 
(3)  Notify the Franchisee of its recommendation at the time it is submitted to the City Commission. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.107. - Penalties and forfeitures. 
    Except as prohibited by federal law, a Franchisee shall be subject to penalties and forfeitures under applicable contracts, statutes or ordinances, and a Franchisee's request for approval of a rate may be denied if it: 
(A)  Knowingly submits false or fraudulent information to the city in connection with any rate proceeding; 
(B)  Fails to comply with any lawful order or request of the city including, but not limited to a request for information or an order setting rates; or 
(C)  Evades, or attempts to evade, federal or local rate regulation, provided that, filing for approval of a rate that is later determined to be unreasonable is not in and of itself an evasion of federal or local rate regulation. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.108. - Proprietary information. 
(A)  If these provisions, or any request for information requires the production of proprietary information, the Franchisee must produce the information. However, at the time the information is submitted, a Franchisee may request that specific, identified portions of its response be treated as confidential and withheld from public disclosure. The request must state the reason why the information should be treated as proprietary and the facts that support those reasons. 
(B)  The request for confidentiality will be granted if the city determines that a preponderance of the evidence shows that nondisclosure is consistent with the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552. The city shall place any decision it issues which results in information being withheld in a public file for inspection. 
(C)  If the Cable Administrator determines that information submitted is not proprietary, the Franchisee may withdraw the proposal if the proposal sought a rate increase, in which case the alleged proprietary information will be returned to Franchisee. Alternatively, the Franchisee may seek review in the appropriate forum within five working days of the denial. Release of the information will be stayed pending review. 
(D)  Any interested party may file a request to inspect material withheld as proprietary with the Cable Administrator. The Cable Administrator shall weigh the policy considerations favoring nondisclosure against the reasons cited for permitting inspection in light of the facts of the particular case. It will then promptly notify the requesting entity and the cable Franchisee that submitted the information as to the disposition of the request. It may grant, deny or condition a request. The requesting party or the Franchisee may seek review of the decision by filing an appeal with any appropriate forum. Release of the information will be stayed pending review. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
Sec. 116.109. - Petition for change in status. 
    Any Franchisee may petition for a change in status in accordance with 47 C.F.R. § 79.15, and the city shall consider that petition in accordance with 47 C.F.R. § 79.15. The petition and seven copies must be filed with the Cable Administrator. 
(Ord. 28716-93, passed 9-1-93) 
CHAPTER 117. - ELECTRIC FRANCHISE 

Sec. 117.01. - Underground wires. 
    The wires and cables of the Dayton Lighting Company shall by the company at its cost and expense be placed, maintained, and operated underground in conduits in accordance with the provisions of this chapter within the following parts of the city: 
    The territory on the north bounded by the Great Miami River; on the east by Webster Street from Monument Avenue to Third Street, and by Bainbridge Street from Third Street to Fifth Street; on the south by Fifth Street, the Miami and Erie Canal, Sixth Street and the railroad tracks from the west end of Sixth Street to the Great Miami River; and on the west by the Great Miami River. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.02. - Construction time limit. 
(A)  All of the wires and cables within the territory shall by the company be placed, maintained, and operated underground in conduits constructed beneath the surface of the streets, lanes, alleys, and public grounds in the parts of the city, and all necessary man and hand-holes may be constructed, and all other things required in connection with said conduits and underground wires may be done and are authorized to be done by the company. 
(B)  The company shall commence the construction of the conduits and placing its wires and cables underground within 90 days from the taking effect of this chapter, and shall have same completed within 18 months from the same date. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.03. - Indemnity agreement. 
(A)  The company shall hold the city harmless from all loss or expenses and from all damages to persons or property by reason of the construction, maintenance, or operation of conduits, wires, and cables therein. 
(B)  During the progress of the work and construction hereunder the company shall conform to all and singular the ordinances of the city in regard to the work in streets, lanes, alleys and public grounds, and in regard to barricades and red lights. 
(C)  All work of every description to be done hereunder shall be in accordance with the regulations of the city, in force at the time same is done, in relation to the particular kind of work to be performed, and everything to be done hereunder shall be to the satisfaction of the Board of Public Service. 
(D)  The work shall be so conducted as not to interfere with the fire hydrants or their use. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.04. - Street restoration. 
    All pavements and the surface of all streets, lanes, alleys, and public grounds which are torn up by the company in doing the things herein provided for shall be restored as soon as possible to as good condition as they were before being disturbed. The company shall remove all debris and surplus material consequent on the construction of conduits and underground work as rapidly as practicable. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.05. - Plans filed. 
(A)  Before beginning work hereunder the company shall file with the Board of Public Service a map, plat and plan of conduits, and no conduit, man-hole or hand-hole shall be changed from the location shown by the plan, except with the consent of the board, provided, however, that where unforeseen and unknown difficulties or impediments are discovered in the progress of the work, such changes may be made as are necessary. 
(B)  The company shall provide and set apart one duct in the conduit for the wires of the Police and Fire Departments of the city, and the use thereof by the city shall be free of charge. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.06. - Pole locations. 
(A)  On the completion of the conduits and of the placing of the wires and cables therein, the aerial wires and cables and poles of the company on the streets, lanes, alleys, and public grounds in the territory shall be removed by the company, but the company may place, maintain, and use such distribution poles as are absolutely necessary to furnish electric current to those using or wishing to use same, and thereafter the company shall not erect or place within the territory any aerial wires or cables or poles, except for distribution purposes as aforesaid, and to sustain lamps used for lighting the streets, lanes, alleys, and public grounds. 
(B)  Distribution poles, so far as possible, shall be placed in alleys. 
(C)  The company shall at its own cost and expense make good and restore any settlements or disarrangements that may occur in the surface of any streets, lanes, or public grounds due to the construction of the underground conduits. 
(D)  The Board of Public Service may appoint an inspector to see that the work is done in accordance with the provisions hereof, and the company shall pay into the city treasury an amount equal to the wages of such inspector at the rate of $3.00 per day. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.07. - Acceptance required. 
    If the company shall file with the Clerk of the Council within 60 days from the taking effect hereof, its declaration that it will abide and comply with the aforesaid requirements, and its acceptance of the conditions hereof, then this chapter shall inure as and be a grant to and contract with the company, its successors, and assigns to construct, maintain, and operate the conduits and underground wires and cables, and the company shall have full power and authority to do all and singular the things necessary in that behalf, and such grant shall be in addition to that made by §§ 117.08 through 117.11, which sections shall remain in force, except as modified by this chapter. If the company shall fail to file the declaration that it will comply herewith, then the Clerk of Council shall notify Council, to the end that such further proceedings may be had in the premises as are provided by law and directed by Council. 
(Ord. 6580, passed 7-31-05) 
Sec. 117.08. - Franchise grant. 
    The right, authority, and power is granted to the Dayton Electric Light company, a corporation under the laws of the state, its successors and assigns to construct, maintain, and use lines, and to maintain existing lines for conducting electricity for power, heat, and light purposes through the streets, alleys, lanes, lands, squares, and public places of the city by the erection of the necessary fixtures, including posts, piers, abutments necessary for the wires which may be strong and hung thereon. And the company may manufacture, sell, and furnish electricity for heat, power, and for lighting the streets and public and private buildings in the city, subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 6164, passed 3-21-04) 
Sec. 117.09. - Insulation required. 
    All wires erected and operated under this chapter shall be covered with a waterproof insulation, and the poles, piers, and abutments shall be located and arranged so as not to incommode the public in the use of streets, alleys, lanes, lands, squares, and public places. 
(Ord. 6164, passed 3-21-04) 
Sec. 117.10. - Conditions. 
    The plant and lines of the company shall be maintained and operated in accordance with the provisions of an ordinance passed December 21, 1883 (C.G.O., Sections 1943-1948), and entitled "An ordinance to amend an ordinance entitled 'An ordinance to control and regulate the use of streets, lanes, alleys and public grounds in the city by telegraph, telephone and other companies or individuals for operating lines or wires for the purpose of communication or correspondence, passed December 16, 1881, and in accordance with such other provisions of the city relating to electric light and power, and the companies producing and selling same, and not destructive of the rights granted, as Council may hereafter enact under and pursuant to the laws of Ohio'." All the rights herein granted shall inure to the successors and assigns of the Dayton Electric Light Company and such successors and assigns shall be bound by the conditions herein as accepted by the Dayton Electric Light Company. 
(Ord. 6164, passed 3-21-04) 
Sec. 117.11. - Acceptance required. 
    This chapter shall take effect and be in force from and after ten days from the date of its first publication and from the filing with the Clerk of Council of the written acceptance of the company of this ordinance and the terms hereof. 
(Ord. 6164, passed 3-21-04) 
Sec. 117.12. - Franchise period. 
    The time during which the Dayton Electric Light Company shall be authorized and empowered with the right and privilege of using the streets, avenues, lanes, alleys, highways, and public grounds of the city as it is now laid out or may hereafter be laid out or enlarged, for the purpose of erecting six or more iron towers 250 feet high, and wood poles 30 to 50 feet high, for placing insulated electric wires for the conveyance of electric current for electric light in and through the city for the use of the city and inhabitants thereof, shall be and is extended for and during a further term of 25 years, beginning at the expiration of its present contract with the city, on the same terms and conditions as those embodied in the present contract between the city and the Dayton Electric Light Company. However, the grant extending the Franchise in the foregoing section of this ordinance is made on the condition that the Dayton Electric Light company's plant shall be constructed and operated in accordance with the provisions of an ordinance entitled, "An ordinance describing the terms and conditions of the use of the streets, lanes, alleys and public grounds of the City of Dayton by telegraph, telephone or individuals, for the purpose of communicating correspondence and production of light", passed December 21, 1883 (C.G.O., Sections 1943-1948), and in accordance with the provisions of such other ordinances and regulations as the city may hereafter adopt, provided that wires shall not be ordered underground, and also that this ordinance shall not be so construed as to invalidate any portion of an ordinance passed July 28, 1882, entitled "An ordinance to provide for the lighting of the City of Dayton with electric light, except that of the extension of time." 
(Ord. 3563, passed 4-7-1893) 
CHAPTER 118. - GAS FRANCHISE 

Sec. 118.01. - Definitions. 
(A)  The naming or designation of any public officer or body in this chapter shall include his or its successors in office or authority regardless of subsequent changes of title or official designation. 
(B)  For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Artificial gas. Gas produced for heat, light, and processing and power purposes resulting from an admixture of natural gas and manufactured gas. It also includes manufactured gas alone as defined herein. 
    CCF. One hundred cubic feet. 
    Company. The Dayton Power and Light Company, its successors and assigns. 
    Manufactured gas. Gas produced for heat, light, and power and processing purposes by means of manufacturing processes as distinguished from gas produced by nature and supplied from wells drilled or sunk into the earth. 
    Natural gas. An admixture of gases, obtained from wells drilled or sunk into the earth, refined and processed, and standardized by commingling, dispatching and, when and to the extent deemed necessary or desirable by the company or the company's suppliers, by stabilization in order to insure, so far as possible, uniformity in the utilization factor thereof. The term "natural gas" shall also include an admixture of natural gas, as defined above, and other available hydrocarbon gases, such as liquified petroleum gas-air mixture. 
    Plant. All of the pipes, mains, conduits, valves, curb boxes, manholes, and all other proper and necessary appliances, devices, construction and facilities, whether located on private property or in private ways or in public ways for transmitting, distributing, and supplying natural gas to the city and its inhabitants, and for manufacturing, transmitting, distributing, and supplying artificial gas thereto. 
    Public ways. Public streets, alleys, lanes, boulevards, and places open to the public for pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.02. - Term; discontinuance of service. 
(A)  Subject to the terms, conditions, stipulations, and provisions hereof, the company is granted the right, power and privilege for the period of 25 years, commencing on the effective date of this chapter, to do, carry on, and transact within the city the business of supplying natural gas to the city and its inhabitants for light, heat, process, chemical, and power purposes and such other purposes for which gas is now or may hereafter be used and to that end to enter on, use and occupy the public ways of the city to maintain, use, lay, relay, replace, and operate pipes, mains, conduits, valves, curb boxes, manholes, and all other proper and necessary appliances, devices, construction, and facilities for transmitting, distributing, and supplying natural gas to the city and its inhabitants for those purposes, and this grant shall apply to all of the plant of the company owned by it and now in the public ways, and also to such as may hereafter be placed therein by it, provided, if at any time before the expiration of a 25-year period the company shall be unable by reasonable effort and at reasonable cost and under a reasonable contract to obtain sufficient natural gas, or if the economics of the gas industry should prevent the company from efficiently obtaining adequate volumes of natural gas, to supply the needs and demands therefor of the city and its inhabitants, the company may, by giving at least six months' previous written notice to the city of its intention so to do, discontinue supplying natural gas in the city on and after a day named in the notice and such written notice shall be filed with the Clerk of the Commission of the city, and thereafter the succeeding provisions hereof applicable on the giving of such notice shall govern. 
(B)  On receipt of such notice it shall be the duty of the Clerk of the Commission to give notice thereof to the City Manager and to read the same before the City Commission at its next meeting. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.03. - Rates. 
(A)  For the purpose of this section, "rate period" shall mean any period of time lawfully fixed and binding on both the city and company during which certain specified rates may be charged by the company for natural gas supplied by it in the city pursuant to this chapter. 
(B)  The rates for residential service and commercial, industrial, and governmental service (other than large commercial, industrial, and governmental service) to be charged for natural gas supplied hereunder for the period beginning with the effective date of this chapter and ending at 12:00 midnight, May 31, 1966, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential gas rate. 
(a)  Applicable. To all single residences, single flats, and single apartments for use in ordinary household appliances. 
(b)  Rate. 
First 500 cubic feet, or less or none, per meter per month, $1.25. 
Next 2,500 cubic feet per meter per month, $.085 per 100 cubic feet. 
Next 3,000 cubic feet per meter per month, $.075 per 100 cubic feet. 
All over 6,000 cubic feet per meter per month, $.0687 per 100 cubic feet. 
(c)  Delayed payment charge. $003 per 1,000 cubic feet of gas, or fraction thereof, over 500 cubic feet shall be added if not paid within a period of seven days after rendition of bill for the service. 
(d)  Minimum monthly charge. A charge of $125.00 net per month. 
(e)  Cost adjustment clause. 
1.  The consumers' bills shall be decreased or increased by an amount per CCF equivalent to the amount of change in the company's average cost per CCF of purchased gas. The amount of change in average cost per CCF shall be determined by comparing the results of applying the company's supplier's currently effective rate and its rate in effect on August 22, 1958 to the company's most recent billing demand and the average monthly volume of gas purchased during the 12-month purchase period ending immediately prior to the month preceding either, the current calendar quarter, or the month in which a change in the supplier's rate shall have occurred in the current calendar quarter. Each decrease or increase shall be in units of .00025 per CCF (stated to the nearest unit), and shall be effective with the beginning of the next billing month. 
2.  Refunds including interest received by the company from its supplier for which an increase in billing has been made under this cost adjustment clause shall be refunded. The refund per CCF to be made by the company to the consumers to whom this rate schedule is applicable shall be determined by dividing the amount to be refunded by the total volume of gas sold to such consumers and which was received from such supplier during the 12-month period immediately preceding the month in which the refund was received by the company. The company will apply this refund per CCF to decrease the consumers' bills on a monthly basis until the amount to be refunded has been refunded by the company. 
3.  The company shall submit to the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio a report setting forth the computations on which any decrease or increase is determined under this cost adjustment clause. Such reports shall be submitted to the Commission on or before day 25 of the month prior to the month in which the change will be made effective. 
(2)  Commercial, industrial, and governmental gas rates. 
(a)  Applicable. To all commercial, industrial, governmental, and other nonresidential consumers for process and space heating purposes. 
(b)  Rate. 
First 500 cubic feet, or less, or none, per meter per month, $1.25. 
Next 2,500 cubic feet per meter per month, $.085 per 100 cubic feet. 
Next 3,000 cubic feet per meter per month, $.075 per 100 cubic feet. 
All over 6,000 cubic feet per meter per month, $.0687 per 100 cubic feet. 
(c)  Discount. A consumer using more than 25,000 cubic feet monthly will be entitled to discount under the following conditions: 
1.  A consumer will be entitled to a discount of one-half cent per 100 cubic feet for all gas used in excess of 25,000 cubic feet during any month where the total gas used during such month is not more than 20 percent greater than such consumers' base load. 
2.  For discount purposes a consumer's base load shall mean such consumer's average monthly use during the four consecutive monthly meter reading periods, beginning on or after June 15. 
3.  A new base load will be determined annually and in case of new consumers or consumers who install additional gas burning equipment for regular operation at such time that their complete installation will not have operated during the preceding summer months, a base use value will be established by estimate after notice from the consumer until the next regular summer base period. 
(d)  Delayed payment charge. A charge of two percent will be added to the amount of the bill if not paid within a period of seven days after rendition of bill for the service. 
(e)  Minimum monthly charge. A charge of $1.25 net per month. 
(f)  Cost adjustment clause. 
1.  The consumer's bills shall be decreased or increased by an amount per CCF equivalent to the amount of change in the company's average cost per CCF of purchased gas. The amount of change in company's average cost per CCF shall be determined by comparing the results of applying the company's supplier's currently effective rate and its rate in effect on August 22, 1958 to the company's most recent billing demand and the average monthly volume of gas purchased during the 12-month purchase period ending immediately prior to the month preceding either the current calendar quarter, or the month in which a change in the supplier's rate shall have occurred in the current calendar quarter. Each decrease or increase shall be in units of $.00025 per CCF (stated to the nearest unit), and shall be effective with the beginning of the next billing month. 
2.  Refunds including interest received by the company from its supplier for which an increase in billing has been made under this cost adjustment clause shall be refunded. The refund per CCF to be made by the company to the consumers to whom this rate schedule is applicable shall be determined by dividing the amount to be refunded by the total volume of gas sold to such consumers and which was received from such supplier during the 12-month period immediately preceding the month in which the refund was received by the company. The company will apply this refund per CCF to decrease the consumers' bills on a monthly basis until the amount to be refunded has been refunded by the company. 
3.  The company shall submit to the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio a report setting forth the computations upon which any decrease or increase is determined under this cost adjustment clause. Such reports shall be submitted to the Commission on or before day 25 of the month prior to the month in which the change will be made effective. 
(C)  Rates for any gas service of the company other than the service specified in subsection (B) hereof may be such rates of the company as shall be on file from time to time with the Public Utilities Commission of the state and as the same may be filed, modified, or withdrawn by order of such Commission. 
(D)  No ordinance of the city fixing natural gas rates shall do so for a period of more than five years. 
(E)  Midnight of May 31, 1966, shall be the end of the first rate period hereunder. 
(F)  At any time after 45 days prior to the end of a rate period, the city and company, having failed to agree on natural gas rates to be charged by the company to consumers within the city for the next ensuing rate period, the city Commission may pass an ordinance to establish such rates and fix the rate period therefor, and the company, if not willing to accept the rates contained in such ordinance during the rate period so fixed, may complain of and appeal from such rates to the Public Utilities Commission of the state and proceed according to the provisions of the State Revised Code applicable to such complaint and appeal, and exercise the rights conferred on public utilities by the provisions of the Revised Code in cases of such complaints and appeals, or the company may invoke any other remedy or remedies in law or equity available to it. 
(G)  The gas service general service rules and regulations set forth in schedules duly filed by the company with and pursuant to the authority of The Public Utilities Commission of the state, as the same are now in effect and as the same may be amended from time to time pursuant to the authority of The Public Utilities Commission of the state, shall apply to, and shall control the furnishing of natural gas pursuant to this franchise and the extension of company facilities for the furnishing of gas to consumers located in the city. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.04. - Metering. 
    Gas supplied by the company hereunder shall be measured by meters of standard type and manufacture supplied and set in position ready for service without charge therefor by the company, and it shall not charge any rental for such meters. The company or the manufacturer shall test each meter before it is on a customer's line, and only those meters which are found accurate and in good working order may be installed. The company shall retest meters in conformity to and on the conditions set forth in R.C. §§ 4933.07, 4933.08, and 4933.09 as at present effective. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.05. - Quality of gas. 
(A)  Gas supplied by the company shall be of standard commercial quality, free of sand, dirt, and other foreign matter. In no case shall the British Thermal Unit content of such gas for the type hereinafter set forth be less than as herein specified: 
Gas BTU's Per Cubic Foot 
Natural 900 
Artificial gas, consisting 700 of mixed natural and manufactured gas 
Manufactured 500 
(B)  In order to determine the British Thermal Unit content of gas the city shall be privileged to make such tests as it desires in the presence of an authorized representative of the company, which shall provide facilities or equipment for such tests. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.06. - Extensions. 
    The company, at its own cost and expense, shall extend its pipes and mains for furnishing natural gas or artificial gas, if same should be substituted under the provisions hereof, in and on any public ways of and public utility easement in the city, now existing or hereafter dedicated or acquired, as the corporate limits of the city now exist or may be extended by annexation or any other means or mode provided by law, whenever one consumer on an average for each 100 feet of pipe in the public way or public utility easement in which the extension is to be run has agreed in writing to take a supply of gas at the then established rates. The company shall not be required to make any extensions on private property at its own expense, nor on any public way or public utility easement for which the way has not been cleared and the grade has not been established. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.07. - Natural gas pressure. 
    The company shall provide for, maintain, and deliver to each customer's premises a constant flow pressure of natural gas of not less than two ounces per square inch, except when same is rendered impossible by action of any governmental authority, or act of a public enemy, or by act of God, or any casualty sustained by the company, or by any casualty sustained by or any action of a producing or transmission company from or through which the company, or its successors, may receive its supply of natural gas. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.08. - Natural or artificial gas plant purchase. 
(A)  The city reserves to itself the right at any time during the term of this franchise to terminate the grant made and to purchase all the property of the company in the streets and highways of the city and elsewhere used in or useful for supplying natural gas under this chapter or for supplying artificial gas under this chapter, if the company should supply artificial gas pursuant to the provisions hereof to the city and its inhabitants, but not including any property of the company wholly or partly used in or useful for its business of supplying electricity or steam to the city and its inhabitants or others, at a price which shall be the value of such property so subject to purchase under this section at the effective date of the chapter of the city providing for such purchase, which value shall be determined according to law governing the valuation of property in condemnation proceedings, but excluding all value resulting by virtue of the grant made and by reason of the fact that the company may be enjoying a monopoly, or virtually so. Such value to fix such purchase price shall be determined by three persons, competent for the purpose, one of whom shall be appointed by the company, and one of whom shall be appointed by the city, and these two shall appoint the third, and they shall be known as the Board of Appraisers, which board may employ such assistants as it deems necessary and fix their compensation, which shall be reasonable. On completion of such valuation the board shall make in duplicate a detailed written report thereof and file one copy with the company and one copy with the city, and the report shall be agreed to and signed by the three members of the board. The members of the board shall each be paid fair compensation for the time reasonably devoted by them to making the valuation. One-half the cost and expense incurred by the board in making such valuation shall be paid by the company and one-half by the city, and such payments shall be made from time to time to the parties entitled thereto on certificates of the board to the company and to the city. Such purchase shall be consummated within one year after the filing of the report by the board, or within such extension of time as may be agreed between the city and company. 
(B)  Nothing herein shall be construed as prejudicial to the right of the city to acquire gas property belonging to the company by the lawful exercise of its powers of eminent domain or by employing any other method or mode provided by law. 
(C)  If the city, by the exercise of its powers of eminent domain or otherwise, should proceed to acquire the property of the company used and useful for supplying either natural or artificial gas pursuant to this chapter, in any such event all value of the grant made by this chapter and all value due to the fact that the company may be enjoying a monopoly, or virtually so, shall be excluded. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.09. - Nonexclusive franchise. 
(A)  The city expressly reserves to itself the power to grant the right, through, in, under, and on the public ways for the laying, maintenance, and use of pipes and mains of any other persons, company, or corporation for purposes similar to those expressed in this chapter or for other purposes, and to grant to any other persons or corporation rights similar to those granted, and to require the relocation of any of the company's plant located in a public way or place when such relocation, in the judgment of the Director of Service and Buildings of the city, is necessary on account of a public improvement, subject, however, to the right of the company to appeal to the City Commission, which shall act by motion. 
(B)  If due to public construction by the city or its contractor, the city, through its Director of Service and Buildings, should require the moving of any gas facility located in a public way (whether owned by the company or someone else), the company, without expense to the city, and provided the owner (if other than the company) shall consent, will move and relocate such gas facility or cause same to be done to the satisfaction of the Director of Service and Buildings of the city. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.10. - Construction and maintenance regulations. 
(A)  The company shall comply with all regulations of the city in force from time to time in regard to excavations or construction in public ways, including obtaining and paying for permits required by such regulations. 
(B)  All work performed hereunder in and on public ways shall be done to the satisfaction of the Director of Service and Buildings of the city, and before excavations may be made in any public way the company shall submit to the Director a plan of the lines proposed, showing where such lines are to be laid, the size of the pipes, the approximate depth at which same are to be laid, the location and dimensions of stops, branches, manholes, and all other structures or appliances located in the public ways or places appurtenant to or necessary for the proper maintenance and use of such lines, together with such other and further information as the Director may require in the premises, and such plans in all parts, except as to kind, sizes and dimensions of pipes, valves, stops, regulators, drips, and other operating facilities shall be subject to the approval of the Director, and except in emergency situations, no openings in the public ways or places may be made until after such approval is given by the Director and permit is obtained by the company pursuant to the provisions of this Code and other lawful regulations of the city pertaining thereto, provided, however, that if the Director shall refuse to issue the permit for such constructions, or should refuse to approve the plans so that the company is unable to proceed with the contemplated constructions, then the company shall have the right to appeal to the City Commission of the City, which body shall act by motion. 
(C)  All trenches and ditches shall be dug, pipes laid, and trenches and ditches closed and the paving or other public improvement disturbed in the course thereof shall be restored as expeditiously as same can be done with skillfulness and safety. All such work shall be done so as to interfere as little as possible with public use of and travel over public ways. All service pipes in streets and roads shall be laid to the curbs, or in the absence of curbs, then to curb lines. All service pipes in alleys shall be laid to the property line, and all service pipes in public utility easements in the rear or on the side lot lines shall be installed to points determined by the company within such easements; which together with the installation of curb (valve) boxes, where needed, shall be at the expense of the company. All pipes, curb boxes, and construction hereunder shall be laid and installed with reference to and at such reasonable distance below the established grades of public ways through or in which the same shall be placed as the director of service and buildings shall prescribe. 
(D)  The mains, pipes, construction, all and singular, of the company hereafter installed in the public ways shall be laid and placed so as not to interfere in any way with any conduits, lines, sewers, water pipes, or other public improvement of the city or the pipes, mains, conduits or other underground facilities of any other person, company, or corporation which may now or hereafter own or operate any system of pipes, mains, lines, or conduits for the transmission or distribution of any utility product or service or interfere with the operation of any electric trolley coach or other transit facility. There shall be no unnecessary or permanent obstruction of public ways or any of them. The mains or pipes of the company shall be laid at such places and at such reasonable depths with regard to established grades in public ways as the Director of Service and Buildings shall prescribe. 
(E)  The company, at its expense, shall carefully guard and protect all public ways entered and opened hereunder so as to prevent injury to person or property while work therein is being prosecuted by the company, and as soon as practicable after completion of work and construction therein all public ways entered and opened hereunder shall be restored to their former condition or usefulness by the company, all to the approval of the Director of Service and Buildings. 
(F)  The company, at its expense, shall do all the refilling, puddling or tamping, paving, and repaving made necessary by reason of construction, installation, operation, abandonment, or repair of its mains, pipes, or construction in public ways, under the direction and to the satisfaction of the Director of Service and Buildings, and if any such work so done by the company in the restoration of a public way proves to be defective and unsatisfactory to the Director of Service and Buildings, he shall give notice to the company and require repair thereof by the company, and on its failure to comply therewith shall make such repair and charge the cost and expense thereof to the company, all as hereafter provided in this section. 
(G)  The company further agrees to cause its pipes and other underground structures, devices and appliances to be re-laid and reconstructed at its own expense when the same is rendered necessary by the proper exercise of the police power of the city. 
(H)  In case the company shall fail to refill any excavation made by it in any of the public ways of the city or fails or neglects to make any repairs or restoration that may be necessary in any of the public ways of the city by reason of any operation or work therein by the company, the Director of Service and Buildings may, after five days' written notice to the company at its office in the city or served on any officer, manager, superintendent, or other person in charge of the plant of the company, make such repairs or restoration as he may deem necessary, and the cost and expense thereof shall be a debt due from the company to the city, and if not paid within 30 days from the presentation of a bill therefor to the company, may be collected by the city in accordance with the provisions of the law for collection of contract debts and obligations. If a dangerous condition is created by virtue of the settlement of any trench or by virtue of repair or restoration to street surface thereby resulting in an emergency, the city, on notice to the company's designated representative, will make temporary repairs and the cost of such repairs shall be billed as provided elsewhere in this section. In determining cost and expense of any work done by the city through the direct employment of labor and purchase of materials right is reserved to the city to add 25 percent for the use of tools and equipment and for other overhead expense. 
(I)  In the construction, installation, maintenance, operation, abandonment, or repair of any of its mains, pipes, lines, or other facilities the company shall exercise reasonable care and shall comply with all the regulations now existing or which may hereafter be made by the city relating thereto and shall be liable for any damage that may arise by reason of the failure or neglect of the company to use reasonable care or to comply with such regulations, and it shall save and keep the city free and harmless from any and all claims or damages caused by, arising out of, or incident to such failure or negligence. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.11. - Artificial gas. 
(A)  If the company, pursuant to § 118.02 hereof, relieves itself of the obligation to supply natural gas hereunder, then, from and after the date named in the notice provided for in § 118.02 when the company will discontinue supplying natural gas, the company, for the unexpired part of the 25-year period, shall carry on and transact within the city the business of supplying artificial gas, which shall be either manufactured gas suitable for light, heat, and power purposes, or a mixture of natural gas and such manufactured gas, to the city and its inhabitants for light, heat, and power purposes, and to that end may use, operate, and maintain the company's plant in the city or any part thereof for transmitting and supplying artificial gas in the city and may enter on, use, and occupy the public ways of the city for that purpose and lay, relay, replace, and operate pipes, mains, conduits, valves, curb boxes, manholes, and all other proper and necessary appliances, devices, construction, and facilities for transmitting and supplying artificial gas to the city and its inhabitants for those purposes. 
(B)  Before artificial gas is supplied hereunder the company shall give notice as required in § 118.02 hereof, and, in addition, shall state in writing whether manufactured gas alone or a mixture of manufactured gas and natural gas is to be supplied. Likewise, when one of these two types of artificial gas is being furnished and it becomes necessary to change to the other type, three months' notice thereof, with statement of reasons or necessity therefor, shall be given by the company to the city, same to be filed with the Clerk of the Commission. 
(C)  The artificial gas supplied shall be of recognized standard quality for the particular kind of gas supplied in accordance with the requirements of § 118.05 hereof. 
(D)  If the city and company should not agree on the initial rates to be charged in the city for artificial gas, then the City Commission may pass an ordinance (for purposes hereof to be known as Artificial Gas Rate Ordinance No. l), which ordinance shall fix artificial gas rates which shall not be less than the natural gas rates in the city in force immediately preceding the time the company begins supplying artificial gas, and if the company should not be willing to accept same, it may complain of and appeal therefrom to the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio and proceed in accordance with the provisions of the Revised Code applicable to such complaint and appeal, except that during the pendency thereof before the Public Utilities Commission the rates contained in the Artificial Gas Rate Ordinance No. 1 shall prevail. The company, instead of so complaining and appealing to the Public Utilities Commission, may invoke any other legal remedy or remedies available to it. 
(E)  If, at the expiration of any artificial gas rate period, the city and company should not agree on such rates for an ensuing period, then the City Commission may pass an ordinance fixing artificial gas rates in the city for an ensuing period, and if the company should not be willing to accept same, it may complain of and appeal therefrom to the Public Utilities Commission and proceed in accordance with the provisions of the Revised Code applicable to such complaint and appeal. 
(F)  The company, instead of so complaining and appealing to the Public Utilities Commission, may invoke any other legal remedy or remedies available to it. 
(G)  No ordinance of the city fixing artificial gas rates shall do so for a period of more than five years. 
(H)  If the company supplies artificial gas hereunder, it shall provide for, maintain, and deliver to each customer's premises a constant flow pressure of artificial gas of not less than two ounces per square inch, except when same is rendered impossible by action of any governmental authority, or act of a public enemy, or by an act of God, or any casualty sustained by the company, or by any casualty sustained by or any action of a producing or transmission company from or through which the company, or its successors, may receive its supply of natural gas if the artificial gas supplied consists of mixed natural and manufactured gas. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.12. - Company reports; examination of records. 
    When requested so to do by the City Commission, acting by motion duly passed and spread on its minutes, the company shall as of the first day of the month following the passage by the Commission of such motion make and file with the Clerk of the Commission a statement of its gas operations for the preceding 12 months' period including assets, liabilities, receipts, and disbursements under this grant. Such statements shall be in detail, adequate for determining the cost of gas service rendered, and shall be signed and sworn to by the proper officer or officers of the company. The right to verify such statements by proper examination of the books, records, and accounts of the company is granted and reserved to the city, acting through such officers or representatives as may be designated by the City Commission by motion duly passed and spread on its minutes. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.13. - Artificial gas regulations. 
    Whenever the company supplies artificial gas in the city hereunder, all the provisions of §§ 118.06, 118.09, and 118.10 hereof shall apply to and bind the company in the same manner and to the same extent as when natural gas is being supplied. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.14. - Examinations of company records. 
    If the city and company should have the controversy as to whether the company has performed all and singular the things required by it to be performed pursuant hereto, or as to the termination of rights and privileges granted, or as to rates for gas supplied by the company hereunder, then the city by and through its representatives to be designated by motion of its City Commission, duly passed and spread upon the minutes, shall have access during business hours throughout the existence of this contract to the accounts, contracts, reports of engineers, records, books, premises, and property of the company pertaining to the subject of the controversy for the examination and investigation of all matters relating to or arising pursuant to the franchise granted by this chapter including its performance, its termination and the fixing of rates for gas. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.15. - Annexed territory. 
    On the addition of territory to the corporate limits of the city by annexation or other mode provided by law all the terms, provisions, conditions, privileges, and obligations of this chapter shall become applicable to the company and such territory and its inhabitants. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.16. - Indemnification. 
    The company shall at all times hereafter defend, indemnify, and keep harmless the city from any and all damages, claims and demands for injuries to persons or property to which the city may be subject by any proceedings at law or in equity, or otherwise, caused by, arising out of, or incident to the grant of the privileges of this chapter, or in the exercise thereof, or out of the exercise or enjoyment of the same by the company, or by reason of the existence of any gas facility located in a public street or any other public way, and the company, at its own cost, may defend against such actions either in its own name or in the name of the city. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.17. - Waivers. 
    No waiver of any breach of any covenant, condition, or stipulation in this chapter contained shall be taken or construed to be a waiver of any subsequent breach of the same or any other covenant, condition, or stipulation. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.18. - Charter provisions. 
    All the terms, conditions, and provisions of the Charter of the City as it now exists relating to franchises and applicable hereto except as lawfully modified, or departed from, are and shall be considered a part of this chapter the same as if such terms, conditions and provisions were fully written herein. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
Sec. 118.19. - Acceptance. 
    Within 30 days from the date this chapter takes effect the Dayton Power and Light company shall file with the Clerk of the City Commission its written acceptance hereof, and thereupon this chapter shall be a contract between the city and the company and binding on both the city and the company. 
(Ord. 21266, passed 6-24-64) 
CHAPTER 119. - STEAM FRANCHISE 

Sec. 119.01. - Definitions. 
(A)  The name or designation of any public officer or body in this chapter shall include his or its successors in office or authority regardless of subsequent changes in title or official designation. 
(B)  For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Plant. All the pipes, mains, conduits, valves, manholes, boiler plants, and all other proper and necessary appliances, devices, and constructions, whether located on private property or in private or public ways for manufacturing, transmitting, and supplying steam for heating, cooling, and processing purposes to the city and its inhabitants. 
    Public ways. Public streets, alleys, lanes, boulevards, places, and grounds open to the public for pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 21132, passed 3-11-64) 
Sec. 119.02. - Terms of franchise. 
(A)  Subject to the terms, conditions, stipulations, and provisions hereof, the company is granted the right, power, and privilege for the period of 25 years, commencing with the effective date of this chapter, to do, carry on, and transact within that portion of the city, which is bounded as follows: 
On the south beginning at the intersection of the east line of South Patterson Boulevard and the Cincinnati, Lebanon and Northern Railroad; thence north on the east line of South Patterson Boulevard to the south line of Apple Street; thence east along the south line of Apple Street to a point 550 feet east of the east curb of Main Street; thence north across Apple Street to the north line of Apple Street; thence west along the north line of Apple Street to the east line of South Main Street; thence north along the east line of South Main Street to the east line of South Patterson Boulevard; thence north with the east line of South Patterson Boulevard to the elevated railroad tracks; thence east along the elevated railroad tracks to the intersection of the elevated railroad tracks and the north line of Bacon Street extended; thence east along the north line of Bacon Street to the east line of McDonough Street; thence north along the east line of McDonough Street to the north line of East Third Street; thence west along the north line of East Third Street to the east line of Webster Street; thence north along the east line of Webster Street to the south line of Monument Avenue; thence east along the south line of Monument Avenue to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad tracks; thence north along the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad tracks to the south bank of the Great Miami River; thence west along the south bank of the Great Miami River to the west line of North Perry Street extended; thence south along the west line of North Perry Street to the north line of West First Street; thence west along the north line of West First Street to a point on the west line of Charter Street extended; thence south along the west line of Charter Street extended to a point on the north line of Mead Street; thence west along the north line of Mead Street to the east line of Backus Street; thence south along the east line of Backus Street to the elevated railroad tracks; thence east along the elevated railroad tracks to the west line of Longworth Street; thence south along the west line of Longworth Street to the south line of Franklin Street; thence east along the south line of Franklin Street to the west line of South Perry Street; thence south along the west line of South Perry Street to the north line of Apple Street; thence west along the north line of Apple Street extended to the Cincinnati, Lebanon and Northern Railroad; thence south along the Cincinnati, Lebanon and Northern Railroad to the point of beginning. 
(B)  The business of supplying steam to the city and its inhabitants for heating, cooling, and processing purposes and to that end, to enter on, use, and occupy the public ways in the portion of the city, to maintain, use, lay, relay, replace, and operate pipes, conduits, valves, manholes, and all other proper and necessary appliances, devices, and constructions for transmitting and supplying steam in the above described territory to the city and its inhabitants for those purposes, and in addition thereto the company may maintain, use, lay, relay, replace, and operate in public ways of the city, outside the described territory, and enter thereon for the purpose, its present plant and such as may hereafter be desirable to conduct steam from its several sources of supply thereof to said described territory, and may also continue to maintain, relay, replace, and operate all plant it now has outside the described territory and continue to serve such customers as it now supplies steam to by means of the plant outside the described territory. 
(Ord. 21132, passed 3-11-64) 
Sec. 119.03. - Rates. 
(A)  For the provisions of this section, "rate period" shall mean a period of time lawfully fixed and binding on both city and company during which certain specified rates may be charged by the company for steam supplied by it in the city pursuant to this chapter. 
(B)  Rates. The rates to be charged for steam supplied hereunder for the purposes aforesaid shall be no higher than the following: 
(1)  For the one-year period beginning with the effective date of this chapter: 
(a)  RATE A 
First: 200,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $1.19 per 1,000 lbs. 
Next: 800,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $1.01 per 1,000 lbs. 
All over 1,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.93 per 1,000 lbs. 
(b)  RATE B (Large Use) 
1.  Rate: 
Demand Charge 
First: 10,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $50.00 per 1,000 lbs. 
All over 10,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $27.00 per 1,000 lbs. 
Steam Charge 
First: 5,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.78 per 1,000 lbs. 
Next: 20,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.73 per 1,000 lbs. 
All over 25,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.70 per 1,000 lbs. 
2.  Determination of billing demand. The billing demand shall be the customer's greatest use of steam in any 60 minute interval as shown by or computed from readings of the company's demand meters in the 12 months ended with the current billing month. 
(2)  For the period of one year beginning one year after the effective date of this chapter: 
(a)  RATE A 
First: 200,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $1.33 per 1,000 lbs. 
Next: 800,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $1.14 per 1,000 lbs. 
All over 1,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.98 per 1,000 lbs. 
(b)  RATE B (Large Use) 
1.  Rate: 
Demand Charge 
First: 10,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $75.00 per 1,000 lbs. 
All over 10,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $35.00 per 1,000 lbs. 
Steam Charge 
First: 5,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.85 per 1,000 lbs. 
Next: 20,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.75 per 1,000 lbs. 
All over 25,000,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $0.70 per 1,000 lbs. 
2.  Determination of billing demand. The billing demand shall be the customer's greatest use of steam in any 60 minute interval as shown by or computed from readings of the company's demand meters in the 12 months ended with the current billing month. 
(3)  For the period of one year beginning two years after the effective date of this chapter: 
(a)  RATE A 
First: 200,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $1.46 per 1,000 lbs. 
Next: 800,000 lbs. steam or condensation, per month, $1.27 per 1,000 lbs.
